column2: RYE, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- The Royal Canadian Yacht Club team of five took a 2-1 lead in their series with American Yacht Club skippers today.

ONCE again the nation has become achingly aware of the heartbeat on which the Presidential succession depends. Once again the national spotlight has swung to the Vice Presidency -- the most neglected office in America.
KYOTO, Oct. 8 -- Behind the tinsel facade of Westernism in present-day Japan the country's own ancient culture seems to be safely kept in the dainty hands of the famous geisha of Kyoto.
BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 4 -- If a Socialist economic planner could manage to conceal his politics, he could feel right at home in Spain.

One hundred and twenty-five leading exhibitors of antiques are gathering art treasures for the second annual Winter Antiques Show. A benefit for the East Side House, it will be held at the Seventh Regiment Armory and will be open to the public from Jan. 23 through Jan. 28.

BECAUSE we are accustomed to making a clear-cut and rather emphatic distinction between pretentiousness and brilliance, it's a little hard to remember that these two qualities are not mutually obliterative, and that they may even exist side by side, in the same work, without canceling out one another's effects.

SAXIFRAGES are one of the three plant families that most truly live on rocks. They are outstanding for wall and crevice plants, although some of them are suited for shaded pockets, woodland paths, poolsides, border edging or even the wet moraine. Few gardens lack a place for at least one member.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 8 -- Aviation and science will team tomorrow for an "egg hunt" test of detecting radioactive materials.

Parcels intended for Christmas delivery to members of the armed forces outside the continental United States should be mailed from next Saturday to Nov. 15, Postmaster Robert H. Schaffer of New York advised yesterday.

The introduction of a three-in-one garment for infants is spurring sales for Winer Sportswear, Inc. The company has placed in its fall line an item that can be used for newly born children as a bag or bunting, converted into a pram suit when the child begins to crawl and finally, by changing snaps, into a snow suit.

GROSSINGER, N. Y. -- The concern felt by American hotelmen over the growth of superhighways and toll turnpikes and the effect upon their business was clearly evident at the Eastern Hotel Conference held here last week at the Grossinger Hotel and Country Club under sponsorship of the New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania State Hotel Associations.
In a speech to the Supreme Soviet last Feb. 8, Russian Foreign Minister V. M. Molotov said:

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The surprising Baltimore Colts scored a 24-20 decision over the Green Bay Packers tonight. A 10-yard right-angle field goal by Bert Rechichar brought the Colts their third National Football League triumph without a loss.
UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 8 (UP) -- Governor Harriman said tonight the Republican party was "against labor, against the little fellow, against the people's interests, and for the special interests."

SOON the "frost will be on the punkin" as fall settles over the land. If the wise gardener has all his fall planting and clean-up behind him, he can take time out to relax and perhaps even attend a lecture or two.
Bobby Courchesne of Holyoke, Mass., and Lulu Perez of Brooklyn will meet in the feature ten-round featherweight fight at the St. Nicholas Arena tomorrow night.

JONATHAN LEONARD has been science editor of Time magazine for ten years. "The Time Book of Science" is made up of pieces he has written for that magazine during that time -- surely one of the most important decades in the history of science.

A SUMPTUOUS new package from R. C. A. Victor offers Aida with an all-star east headed by Zinka Milanov, Fedora Barbieri, Jussi Bjoerling, Leonard Warren and Boris Christoff. It was recorded in Rome with the Rome Opera chorus and orchestra, under the direction of Jonel Perlea (three disks).
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The question of who should go to college is no longer academic, it is beginning to trouble a great many top-level educators and school men.
Instead of letting the season for speed-boat events taper off and end with approach of autumn and hibernation, the month of October promises world records and international excitement.

There is no gainsaying that the action of the stock market is now closely linked with the President's recovery. Just a quick look at the various stock averages shows how much starch has been taken out of the extreme confidence that had been in evidence ever since the 1954 Election Day.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Jim Swink scored all three Texas Christian touchdowns and rolled up 139 yards rushing today as he powered the Horned Frogs to a 21-0 victory over a fumbling Alabama team.

THE tower is a ruined fortress high in the Alps in one of the French cantons of Switzerland. There the daughter of an innkeeper meets an American student and the two are caught up immediately in a preposterous mystery -- something about the hidden treasure of a Balkan state, a French countess and a stolen pistol.

THERE is enough Ludwig Bemelmans in this large, economy-size package to glut a gourmand: four complete books and five pieces that the publishers call stories. The volume starts with "My War With the United States," Mr. Bemelmans' first book, and in many respects his best.

Fulbright scholarships in science, musicology, colonial affairs and other, fields are available to American college graduates for study in Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands during 1956-57 under the United States international educational exchange program.
HONG KONG, Oct. 8 -- Thirty-nine well-groomed Chinese, former residents in the United States, arrived today aboard the liner President Cleveland.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 8 -- Westchester's youngest and fastest-growing activity is helping to keep older residents busy, healthy, happy and unburden-some to children.
Where do we go from here?
On the eve of its biggest selling season, the liquor industry is in a state of ferment.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- Following is a translation of the text of Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov's letter published today in the Communist party journal Kommunist:

Four and a half years ago Australia inaugurated a method of killing off rabbits, which had become a formidable pest, by spreading among them the virus myxomatosis. The disease killed off so many rabbits that sheep, which could not find grass enough in denuded pastures, began to flourish again, so that wool production has increased by about 70,000,000 pounds, worth about $54,000,000.

Taconite processing operations will start this week at the big E. W. Davis Works of the Reserve Mining Company at Silver Bay, Minn. The $190,000,000 taconite project, jointly owned by Republic Steel Corporation and Armco Steel Corporation, will be the first to produce iron ore pellets from hard taconite rock on a large commercial scale.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 -- Water in the center of inundated Tampico has receded nearly a foot and a half in the last twelve hours, the Government reported here today.

THE electric drill is a hardworked piece of machinery, and as such it needs a certain amount of maintenance. About every three months of regular use, or at least once a year, the drill should be checked for worn brushes, dirty commutator and proper lubrication.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Two Southeastern Conference powerhouses, Kentucky and Auburn, fought to a 14-14 tie today. Unbeaten Auburn missed three field-goal attempts, including one from the 20-yard line in the final seconds.
THE production of Prokofieff's opera "The Flaming Angel" at La Fenice Theatre has overshadowed everything else at the Venice International Festival of Contemporary Music.
The McDonnell Aircraft Corporation of St. Louis has received orders from the Air Force for three versions of the supersonic F-101 Voodoo aircraft.
RICHMOND, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Penn State capitalized on Virginia's mistakes today to grind out a 26-7 victory over the Cavaliers in rain-soaked City Stadium before a Tobacco Bowl festival crowd of 18,000.
GENEVA, Oct. 8 -- Ambassador U. Alexis Johnson pressed the Chinese Communist Government again today to implement its four-week-old promise to release all imprisoned Americans and let them leave.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Administration has turned down a proposal to pay farmers for taking land out of production voluntarily. It said it would be too costly and complex.

" FOR the want of a nail, the kingdom was lost," the adage runs. And for he want of a dollar, or a comparatively few dollars by today's Hollywood standards, many of the nation's finest vintage films have been lost forever, the victims of neglect and circumstance.

I should like to add a footnote to the interesting article, "The Role of the Ex-President" (Sept. 25), by Sidney Hyman, in which he dealt with various proposals to "institutionalize" our ex-Presidents by giving them some fixed position in government -- such as lifetime, non-voting Senate membership.

WHEN the curtain goes up on Tchaikovsky's "Golden Slippers" Thursday evening at the City Center, it will be the first time in over thirty year's that the opera has been seen in America. The Russian Opera Company staged the work at the New Amsterdam Theatre in New York on May 27, 1922, and performed it again a few days later.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 8 (UP) -- The nation's No. 1 passing combination -- Dick Young to Jimmy Orr -- clicked twice for touchdowns as Georgia registered a 28-7 victory over North Carolina before 25,000 fans today.

DALLAS, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Oklahoma's Sooners blunted a furious Texas passing attack with timely interceptions and turned loose Tommy McDonald and Bob Burris for touchdowns to post their twenty-second straight victory by downing Texas, 20 -- 0, today.

RICHMOND, Calif., Oct. 8 (UP) -- Mary Lena Faulk, who never has won a title since turning professional but who has finished second six times, took the lead at the end of thirty-six holes in the $5.000 Richmond women's open golf tournament today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- Princeton scored the touchdown but Pennsylvania supplied the thrills in their gridiron clash today. Regarded as a comparatively easy opponent for the Tigers in the pre-game calculations, the Red and Blue offered such surprising resistance that the visitors were content to walk off with a 7-0 triumph.
RHODODENDRONS are universally popular for their masses of bloom, glossy foliage and greenness the year around. If kept in a gleaming, healthy state these shrubs are a constant source of pride.
SINCE 1952, an American Negro company has been touring Europe, the Near East and South America in the folk opera "Porgy and Bess" with the support and blessings of our State Department,

" RIMMED by a vast, mysterious mountain cup," as Thomas Wolfe once noted, Biltmore House, seat of one of the great country estates, and a mere mortal named Alec Guinness are facing American cameras for the first time in Molnar's "The Swan," courtesy of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and the Vanderbilts.
The men behind the hundreds of tugs and other specialized craft without which the harbor could not function are a quiet, shy breed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- A new opera of high professional competence had its American premiere here last night. "Troilus and Cressida," the work of Sir William Walton, a composer who knows his craft, sings and plays with striking effectiveness.

I think Mr. Waithman and other Britons have misunderstood the point of psychology used in the booklet "The Child From Two to Six." This point was a reference to using imagination, such as "tired truck drivers going to bed," which the child would consider s fraud long before he became six years old.

RICHMOND, Oct. 8 -- Department store sales in the Fifth Reserve District for September were 9 per cent higher than in that month last year. Port activities in the district are on the upgrade. A new peak was set at Hampton Roads in August when it handled more cargo shipped than in any previous month.

CAIRO, Oct. 8 -- An Arab technical committee of engineers from Jordan, Lebanon, Syria and Egypt approved today a plan for integrated regional development of Jordan River water resources that will divide Jordan waters between the Arabs and Israel.

At 3:43 P. M. last Tuesday in the Borough of the Bronx, Mr. Harold H. Reese threw a baseball to Mr. Gilbert R. Hodges and the Brooklyn Dodgers officially became the world champions of baseball. There was a joyous and riotous return of the faithful of Flat-bush back across the East River and Kings County has not been the same since.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 8 -- The president of the Independent Unions of New Jersey said today that the approaching amalgamation of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations might present serious problems to small independent unions.
WITHERBEE, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Johnny Podres' rural Adirondack neighbors today gave him a hero's welcome.
BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Georgia Tech called on a long-range scoring punch to down Louisiana State University, 7-0, in a bitterly fought football game before a record crowd of 60,000 tonight.
ATHENS, Oct. 8 -- It appeared today that Premier Constantin Karamanlis would be backed by a united Rally party, which holds two-thirds of the parliamentary seats.

I have just finished reading John Lardner's provocative "Perilous Plight of the Pitcher" (Sept. 18). I think that a crisis is at hand and something will have to be done before the situation gets completely out of control.

MONTREAL, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Montreal's power clicked twice tonight as the Canadiens spoiled Boston's 1955-56 National Hockey League debut with a 2-0 victory. The shutout was the second straight for Goalie Jacques Plante.
OSTEND, Belgium, Oct. 5 -- The seafarers' section of the International Transport Workers Federation resolved here today to intensify its campaign against Panlibhonco registered ships.

THIS American author, with a number of solidly wrought books about her own country to her credit, is concerned in her new novel with a village in France and a group of young people who were among those that shaped and shared its fate in World War II.

NEW CASTLE, Ind., Oct. 8 -- Plans of the Perfect Circle Corporation to reopen its struck foundry here on Monday have become embroiled in a controversy over whether Indiana National Guard troops should be used to permit nonstrikers to enter the plant.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 8 -A reporting service to supply information on legal aspects of education, race relations and related problems resulting from court decisions on segregation will be established here by the Vanderbilt University Law School.

It was Julie Adler's favorite quip about himself that he didn't know if he was primarily a newspaper man who was also a soldier or primarily a soldier who was also a newspaper man. The answer is that he was both -- more than both, for he crowded two lifetimes into one, a lifetime devoted to the newspaper profession and a lifetime to the military.
Elisabeth Schwarzkopf will open the 1955-56 Hunter College concert series on Saturday, Oct. 22 at 8:30 P. M. in the college Assembly Hall, 695 Park Avenue.
THE fastest-growing time capsule in town is bursting out of two old filing cabinets in the National Broadcasting Company's news room in Rockefeller Center.

HAZLEHURST, Ga., Oct. 8 (UP) -- A Southern Railway passenger train rammed a freight train head-on on a "blind" single track curve today. At least five persons were killed. Eight to ten others injured.
WACO, Tex., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Baylor's bruised Bruins defeated Arkansas tonight, 25 -- 20, and virtually eliminated the Razorbacks from the Southwest Conference race.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 8 (AP) -A riotous demonstration by 600 diehard French colonials tonight brought the resignation of Francois de Panafieu as French Morocco's chief civil affairs officer. He was a backer of Premier Edgar Faure's home rule plan.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 8 -- Delaware pushed over two first-half touchdowns today and then held off Lafayette's second half attack to post a 14 -- 6 victory.
The thirty-sixth annual observance of Fire Prevention Week opens today throughout the country.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- With ore and coal continuing to set a brisk pace, vessels hauled 16,069,377 tons of freight through the Sault Ste. Marie locks last month, it was reported today.

Forest rangers, state forestry departments and lumber companies are constantly alert for forest fires, and research on their control extends along several lines. Considerable study has been given in many areas to the relationship of plants to forest fires. There is, for example, variation in resistance of trees to fire.

The first New York performance of Boris Blacher's Piano Sonata, Op. 39, and a distinguished interpretation of Schumann's "Davidsbuendler Dances" were presented by Robert Mueller in his Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon.

Nail, a gray 2-year-old colt owned by Mrs. Anson A. Bigelow of Palm Beach, won the $125,125 Futurity at Belmont Park yesterday. The net was $100,425 -- with 10 per cent to Nail's rider, Hedley John Woodhouse, and another 10 per cent to the colt's trainer, George P. (Maje) Odom.

THE address of the conservation commissioner, Louis A. Wehle, was the highlight of the New York State Conservation Council convention in Poughkeepsie. The main points have become public knowledge in broad outline, but more detailed examination of what the future holds under the new commissioner appears warranted and is presented here in excerpts.
Buyer response to resort collections of sportswear and dress manufacturers last week was good, resident offices reported.
Initial arrangements have been completed by a committee headed by Mrs. Herbert T. Mundin for the sixth annual Fan Ball, to be held in the grand ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 18.

Members of the Vassar Alumnae from the classes of '41 and '42 have taken over the Nov. 16 performance of "The Chalk Garden," with Gladys Cooper and Siobahn McKenna at the Barrymore Theatre for the benefit of the unrestricted Alumnae Fund of Vassar.
Jose A. Mora, Uruguay's Ambassador to the United States, was honored here yesterday for his role as president of the Council of the Organization of American States in ending a conflict in Costa Rica.

S. HUROK, the well-known impresario now doubling as a television producer, has signed five outstanding musical artists for his "Music for the Millions" video production. It will be presented over the National Broadcasting Company network on Jan. 30.

THE bat boy was so astonished and so hurt that he was on the verge of tears. The kindly and considerate Bill Rigney was giving him an unmerciful bawling out and the kid just couldn't understand it. Ray Poat, the bulky Giant pitcher, had just hit a triple and was standing on third base, snorting and heaving like a wounded sea lion.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 8 -- Dartmouth's football squad furnished the threats but Brown won the game. That was the story today as the Hanoverians clashed with the Bruins at Brown Stadium.

THERE is little doubt that the high level of business activity will continue well into the first quarter of next year. The question in the minds of many merchants and manufacturers now is: What can we expect from the end of the first quarter through 1956?
CAIRO, Oct. 8 -- Like Mid-Eastern riots and border fighting, Egypt's decision to trade cotton for Czechoslovak arms looks worse several thousand miles away than it does here on the scene.
A seven-man engine company team from Brooklyn won top honors yesterday in a city-wide competition sponsored by the Civil Defense Auxiliary Fire Corps.
SHRUB OAK, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Loyola Seminary, largest training center for Jesuit priests in the world, was dedicated here this afternoon by Cardinal Spellman.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., a leading pharmaceutical concern, has marked its first working link with its new antibiotics plant at Sandwich, England Pfizer's Brooklyn laboratories have received from the British unit an air-shipped soil sample.

HERLESHAUSEN, Germany, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- Hans Bauer, whose testimony may enable German courts to declare Hitler legally dead at long last, was one of thirty-two German war prisoners who crossed the East German border near here tonight after being freed by Russia.
Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov's "self-criticism" is an ordeal many notable Communists have had to pass through.

Capes are coming back in a big way after an absence of many years. And about time, too: they have a swashbuckling dash unequaled by other overgarments. Both Paris and New York rediscovered the cape this season. To the omnipresent slim silhouette it adds bulk and a gentle roundness; it is capable of infinite variations, some of which are shown here.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 5 -- A Georgia political struggle that involves powerful national political influences from the White House down is increasing in intensity daily.

ONE of the Orkney Islands, a little over a century ago, is the setting for this quietly told, appealing love story. From the mainland comes talented Cathie Sutherland, to the island where her mother's family had lived for generations.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va. (UP) -- Vic (Jack) Rabbits got a sputtering West Virginia attack going with a spectacular 99-yard punt return late in the first quarter and the Mountaineers rolled to an easy 47-12 victory today over Virginia Military Institute.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 -- Argentina was considering tonight whether to request Paraguay to intern General Peron.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Italian and Austrian miners who may be imported to work in Yorkshire pits will have to learn the local dialect, if one union official has his way.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 8 (UP) -- Maryland's ground devouring first team was the big difference today as the top-ranked Terrapins routed Wake Forest, 28 -- 7.

Information available in Washington indicates that recently announced reductions in the size of Communist armed forces represented no appreciable reduction in the combat effectiveness of the Communist states.
The national board of Americans for Democratitc Action urged yesterday that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation be sent to protect the constitutional rights of Negroes in Mississippi.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The Chicago Natural History Museum formally opened to the public today its newest display, the Hall of the Earth.
MIAMI, Oct. 8 -- The Air Force cannot operate at full efficiency until the "undesirable results" of crowded and inadequate air bases are corrected, a high Air Force official warned today.

ATLANTA, Oct. 8 -- Economic activity continues to expand in the Southeast. Manufacturing and payrolls have shown further increases in recent weeks to all-time highs in some centers. Pro duction of cotton textiles is on the uptrend.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Once again a French Government has put both its life and its policy into the hands of the Deputies forming the National Assembly.
The Hell's Canyon dispute, with its overtones of public versus private power, now is headed for the courts.
HARTFORD, Oct. 8 -- The $398,000,000 Connecticut Turnpike, which up until now has seemed scarcely more than a gleam in draftsmen's eyes, is expected to be completed on schedule in the next two years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- In the nearly four months since President Eisenhower signed the recriprocal trade bill with its supposed "protectionist" amendments, only one application has been filed by domestic industry for tariff relief under the law's "escape clause."
The aircraft carrier Saratoga, named and symbolically launched yesterday, is described officially as the world's most powerful warship. No unofficial challenge to the designation is likely to arise.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- Officers of the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company were elected last week at the organization meeting of the directors.

SAN MIGUEL DE ALLENDE, Mexico -- Most of the multiple thousands of North Americans who visit Mexico each year go home and take up their lives where they left off. For them home is where the heart is, their roots and, an item quite important, the job.

PRAIRIE creatures are the characters in this book as they were in the movie of the same name upon which it is based. In the early days antelope, buffalo, cougar, rattlers, sage-grouse -- all the animals, reptiles and birds of the prairie -- managed to live and multiply in spite of their natural enemies.

LAST week-end was marked by seismic disturbances from which the local world of the Spanish dance is not likely to recover in the foreseeable future. The first quake occurred Friday night when Carmen Amaya appeared in Carnegie Hall after an absence of a dozen years, and proved herself to be no longer simply the high-tension gypsy night club dancer of earlier days, but a breathtaking artist.

The year was 1905. Teddy Roosevelt was President. The Japanese had just defeated the Russians. Clara Bow, the "It" girl, was born in Brooklyn. The Giants beat the Philadelphia Athletics in the World Series. G. B. McClellan was Mayor.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- A new firefighting unit, patterned after an anti-aircraft gun, has been developed by the Philadelphia Fire Department.
The University of California has the world's biggest supersonic high-altitude wind tunnel. It will permit researchers to "fly" higher than man has ever ventured in the laboratory.

EVER since the early part of the sixteenth century people have been writing books about Christopher Columbus but very few of these have been for young children -- and none was as handsome as these two. Both volumes are beautifully illustrated and each one is excellent in its presentation of the Admiral of the Ocean Sea -- his background, his aims and his achievements. Neither is fictionized.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Even if economists are perhaps not quite as excited about the point as politicians, the question of a balanced budget is rapidly taking its place as one of the two or three top issues of next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Former President Truman went far this week to put Adlai E. Stevenson on notice that the candidate of 1952 will not necessarily have the field to himself when in mid-November he makes his bid for renomination. Mr. Truman's choice of Albany to stress the Presidential qualifications of Governor Averell Harriman of New York and display less than enthusiasm for Stevenson's bore every mark of a deliberate warning.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Emiddio (Turk) Petrarca, a powerful fullback, crashed over for two third-period touchdowns today as Boston College erupted in the second half to down Villanova, 28 -- 14, in Fenway Park.

DEVON, Pa., Oct. 8 -- A Connecticut entrant, Ch. Barrowdale Flier, a white-and-liver marked English springer spaniel, owned by Henrietta H. Barrows of Quaker Hill, gained the best-in-show honors today at the forty-third annual all-breed Devon event.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Attorney General is seeking to determine whether he has the power to terminate deportation proceedings against Jacob Burck, Pulitzer Prize - winning cartoonist.

THERE is a moral for our theatre and opera in the performances of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company that are filling the Sam S. Shubert Theatre with enchantment. In its Gilbert and Sullivan repertory the company has a rich, basic substance.

Some of the most loyal allies that the French have in the United Nations believe that while France's walkout was fully justified, it would have been smarter politics to stay and fight out the General Assembly's claim to jurisdiction over Algeria.
MAURICE SCHWARTZ, drifting one recent twilight between memory and prophecy, painted glowing word pictures of the Yiddish Art Theatre that will be reborn on Wednesday.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 -- The route by which the ancient Israelites sought in vain to enter Canaan from the south is believed to have been determined. The finding was made during a three-month archaeological survey in the Negev region in Israel, Dr. Nelson Glueck said today.

May I endorse wholeheartedly every word of Robert Waithman's article pointing out how superior British childrearing methods are to those employed in these United States? ("In Britain Mummy and Daddy Know Best" -- Sept. 25).
DENVER, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower's doctors hoisted "a flag of warning" today against overoptimistic reports about his recovery.

I have read your critic's column for many years and I have admired his searching inquiry into the hundreds of plays he has reviewed. I am old enough to have read Heywood Broun, George Jean Nathan and many others when they were young.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- British soccer and rugby results today:

POSTMASTER General Arthur E. Summerfield announced last week that before the Navy Operation Deepfreeze expedition leaves for the Antarctic in November, arrangements will be completed for servicing philatelic covers as an integral part of a postal system near the South Pole.
Two touchdowns by Mel Horowitz and a 63-yard scoring run by Joe Kazlazskas led Jefferson to a 19-6 victory over Erasmus yesterday at Boys High Field, Brooklyn.

WHEN "Vanity Fair" began appearing in 1847, Thackeray, then 36, had endured a tough apprenticeship as a struggling journalist. Some dozen books, several markedly original, had sold so modestly that he considered generous the 60 a month he was to receive -- less than half the 150 Dickens had drawn a decade earlier for "Nicholas Nickleby," his third novel.
A fivefold membership increase since World War II was reported yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union. Enrollment reached a total of 32,600 as of Sept. 1.

Gertrude Samuels' attention to me in her article, "Rebirth of a Community" (Sept. 25), was most kind and I am flattered to have my views personally quoted. In any article of this length it is of course impossible to recognize fully the many organizations and individuals on all levels whose cooperation and interaction, along with the religious, medical and educational institutions, have brought about healthy community rebirth in Morningside Heights.

For the second consecutive month, more than 70,000 overseas air passengers arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, in September. In addition, another 20,000 from Canada passed through the United States Public Health, Immigration and Customs examining areas.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 8 -- Garden State Park opened the twenty-five-day fall meeting of its fourteenth racing year in showers and slop today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Ohio State's All-America Halfback, Howard (Hopalong) Cassady, put on one of his finest shows today as he paced the Buckeyes at a 27-12 victory over Illinois.

ALTHOUGH no such vital statistics is mentioned by John Taylor in the pages of his autobiography, it might well be estimated that the steaks, chops and roasts of the elephants he killed would be sufficient to feed the residents of New York City for approximately 134 1/2 days.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 -- Argentina was enjoying a honeymoon with freedom this week. There was reason to hope that it might develop into a long, happy marriage.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Investments in industrial plant projects in the Chicago area during Sep tember dipped to $12,092,000, compared with $19,729,000 in the same month last year, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported.

AS the leading lady of "Caesar's Hour," each Monday night on the National Broadcasting Company television network, Nanette Fabray finds herself in a happy position. She discussed it here last week before a rehearsal for tomorrow night's appearance.
THOSE who support the ancient premise that good food demands good wine will find a reward for their palates in sampling vintages that, for want of a better word, might be called "obscure."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 8 -Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Levy, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Jane Levy, to Leo M. Rodgers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodgers of Fort Smith, Ark. The wedding will take place in December.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- Unemployment in the Cleveland area, totaling 10,000 men and 8,000 women, is at the lowest point since October, 1953, according to Donald P. Smith, area director of the Bureau of Unemployment Compensation.

THE thesis that "enemies are human" is particularly acceptable if you happen to be the enemy. Reinhold Pabel, a German P. O. W. who escaped from a prison camp in Illinois in 1945, eluded the F. B. I. for eight years.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Syracuse University's football team, sometimes brilliant but frequently ragged, overpowered Boston University, 27 -- 12, tonight to hand the Terriers their third straight loss.

Soldier and newspaper man, Julius Ochs Adler won distinction in two careers which he pursued with zest. In both fields he made the contributions of a man devoted to the general good, courageous and steadfast even where he felt bound to give counsels not immediately attractive to the public.

BUCHAREST, Rumania Oct. 8 -- Gheorghe Savin, chairman of the Chamber of Commerce, revealed today that the past year's industrial production reached a value of 1,730,168,450,000 lei. This, he said in an interview, was three and one-half times the industrial production of 1938 and twice the amount at the beginning of the five-year plan in 1950.

PORTOBELO, Panama -- This old Spanish settlement, once the site of one of the great fortifications which ringed the Spanish Main, and the port whence the fleets of royal treasure galleons annually sailed for Spain, will come alive again for a day -- Oct. 21 -- and revive a trifle of its ancient glories.
WARSAW, Sept. 19 -- Warsaw now has more ample housing space than Moscow but less than Prague.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- The Asian-African nations, with the support of the Soviet group and scattered countries of Latin America, pushed the issue of colonialism to the front of the United Nations stage last week.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Washington State forced favored California to come from behind in the final three minutes today to earn a 20-20 tie in a Pacific Coast Conference football game.

THE journal or daybook is a deceptively simple form of writing which really stands or falls on the author's ability to infuse it with a personality and a viewpoint. At its best it is a related series of personal essays -- and it is a commentary on current civilization that most of the daybooks of the present are set in the country.
City College has started a campaign to raise $200,000 during the academic year for non-curricular needs, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of the college.
The second great aircraft carrier of the nuclear era was named Saratoga yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Westinghouse Electric Corporation accused the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., today of "deliberately misrepresenting" the "most liberal offer of wage and benefit increases ever made by Westinghouse."

THIS book does not pretend, as Wayne Andrews explains in his foreword, to be an encyclopedic history of American architecture, "to tell all the changes that have come over our buildings since Jamestown." It is a book, "not about building in America but about architecture as a fine art, a book about taste."

Under cover of a gray sky and in a sprinkle of rain, Casey Stengel and his Yankees left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday morning on the first leg of their six-week exihibit ion and goodwill tour to the Orient.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 8 -The National Farm Organization, formed in Iowa three weeks ago to combat the decline in farm income, has spread to three other Midwestern states.

ONE late evening in April, 1917, a New York Times reporter named Elmer Davis came into the city room, uncrooked an ash cane from his elbow, and sat down to peck at a typewriter. After a few minutes he raised the carriage of his old-fashioned machine -- reporters in those days had to furnish their own typewriters -- and sadly read the result.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan sank a seven-foot birdie putt on the eighteenth hole today and regained the lead in the $17.500 Eastern open golf tournament.

THE proposed amendment to the New York State Constitution to provide $750,000,000 of highway bonds for road building is being debated bitterly by people and organizations who favor more and better roads.
Lovers of the outdoors have long feared that the huge demand for lumber generated by the postwar housing boom might be denuding the country's forests.

THE C-man, a new kind of cop, is fighting crime's clutch on the juicy grab bag that is the New York-New Jersey waterfront. He is the confidential investigator for the bi-state commission that is making it harder each day for crooks to batten on America's greatest and busiest port.

Dorothy Barclay's "New Approach to Sunday School" (Sept. 25) was most constructive. It should be pointed out, however, that Sunday School teaching that "aims to help youngsters in terms of their own lives, here and now, to begin to grow in faith and spiritual feeling" is hardly new.
Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. described the United Nations yesterday as "the world's greatest single engine for influencing world opinion."
TOKYO, Sept. 30 -- In sprawling Fuchu Prison on the outskirts of Tokyo there are fifty-three United States service men serving sentences of eight months to fifteen years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Air Force said tonight its planes would drop 500 tons of building equipment and supplies at the South Pole from October, 1956, through March, 1957.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- The directors of the Piasecki Helicopter Corporation have voted in favor of changing the company's name to Vertiplane Corporation. They also voted to enlarge the board from eleven to thirteen members. Stockholders will be asked to approve the actions at a special meeting on Oct. 27.
A club that virtually wrecked a pennant race by July and then went on to siay a world series jinx after seven previous autumn failures, could be regarded as sitting pretty for the next season.

EVER since Theophile Gautier came to Spain and exclaimed that the climax of the bullfight was "worth all Shakespeare's tragedies," foreign writers have gotten themselves intellectually involved and emotionally enraptured with the Spanish fiesta nacional.

OF the nine colleges in America surviving from colonial times eight were founded under the direct influence of a church. Even today approximately 450 of the nation's 750 four-year liberal arts colleges -- where nearly 3,000,000 students are now settling down for a new school year -- are church-related.

THE Professional Photographers' Association of New Jersey, which has a membership of 500 studio owners throughout the state, will hold its annual convention and trade show tomorrow and Tuesday at the Hotel Douglas in Newark.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Texas A. and M. mixed timely passes with a bruising ground game today to smother Nebraska, 27 -- 0, in an intersectional football game played before 40,000.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 8 -- A survey now in progress indicates shortages in facilities and personnel for treatment of mental illness in the western United States, Alaska and Hawaii.

SAN FRANCISCO -- An organization formed to represent the Japanese photographic industry in the United States will start functioning in December at 437 Fifth Avenue, New York City, it was revealed here last week at the Western States Convention and Photographic Trade Show.
LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 8 (UP) -- Government investigators sought today to find out why the airliner in Thursday's crash was off course.
A man who has saved dollars by ignoring pennies finds his business growing so big he has had to hire an electronic brain to keep track of the money.
SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 8 -If you want to see an Indian on a reservation, you still have plenty of time. But for your children or grandchildren, it may be a different story.
With this week's schedule of auction sales, New York galleries have attained a pace which, with the exception of the customary Christmas lull, will remain unbroken until early next summer.

SOME three-quarters of the way through this enormous novel a young woman remarks: "Relationships are a bit odd here, aren't they?" Indeed, the relationships in "These Lovers Fled Away" are so odd and so complicated, and Mr. Howard Spring's cast of characters so huge, that if he had supplied his novel with a dramatis personae he probably would have needed a professional genealogist to sort them out.

IN the first sixty-three pages of this lush romance, hero Richard Tucker wins his lady fair, then finds out from his wealthy father that he is of illegitimate birth. He goes off in a sweat, turns privateer, participates in the taking of a prize, witnesses the flogging of a Negro officer from the prize ship, and abandons his privateering ambitions on returning to port.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- Mayor Anthony J. Celebrezze, whose surprise victory in Tuesday's primary catapulted him into state and national prominence, has announced that he will devote the next five weeks to putting over the $8,000,000 Seaway bond issue at the polls next month.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: "Clear moon, frost soon" is a warning to have coverings handy for the tenderest plants. On chilly evenings burlap supported by stakes or newspaper tents may be thrown over dahlias, zinnias, or tomato plants. One peach basket per plant is another type of quick protection.

YOUR reviewer Maxwell Geismar seems to reject Herman Wouk's thesis in "Marjorie Morningstar" that religious conformity provides a sound way of life, and urges culture as more satisfying. It is regrettable that he failed to define the term. Greece and the area now called Italy, both in the Latin and Italian periods, are history's two great cultural centers, but both periods glorified the conqueror.

A COLLEAGUE passed along a release from Definition Press which attempts to drum up interest for a book of poems by Martha Baird, titled "Nice Deity" -- or "Good God:" (as it was retitled by our colleague). Poetry, the release informs us, "is in a mysterious doldrums, or -- put more colloquially -- is stuck somewhere between congested, intricately egotistic, dismally baffling though elegant ,verse. and* * * . "

ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- Former President Harry S. Truman gave Governor Harriman a big boost on the Presidential ladder today. Mr. Truman told a press conference that he considered Mr. Harriman a "genius" and a man with all the qualifications for the White House.

ATTICA, N. Y., Oct. 8 (AP) -- William C. DeKoning Sr., onetime labor leader on Long Island, was released from state prison here today. He had served a full eighteen-month sentence for grand larceny and extortion, charges that had grown out of a harness racing scandal.

History has bequeathed France a vital role among nations. She is one of the cradles of democratic liberties. She is a key to Europe -- the indispensable staging ground for NATO. Her empire, though shrunken, acts and reacts upon the political ferment among the peoples of the world.

The election of David Rose, New York builder, as president of the American Technion Society was announced yesterday. The society supports the Israel Institute of Technology, the only engineering school in Israel.

At a special press conference held in Washington, D. C., last Monday Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, discussed what is officially known as "Project Sherwood" but what he called "the idea." And what was the idea? The fusion of hydrogen into helium under control so that a thermonuclear reaction could be applied to lighting cities, driving ships, locomotives, perhaps automobiles.
AFTER having read your critic's review of "A View From the Bridge," I find it hard to believe that he and I saw the same two plays at the Coronet Theatre on Sept. 29.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Dr. Joseph Maguire, senior surgeon for the Cunard Line, resigned last weekend. He acted shortly after the Queen Mary, on which he had been principal medical officer for seven years, left Southampton for New York.

The news from Denver was good. Day after day, the bulletins from the President's doctors contained the same eagerly-awaited, reassuring words -- "cheerful," "comfortable," "satisfactory without complications," "excellent."

SUCH heroes and heroines of negativism as Julian Sorel, Emma Bovary, George Babbitt, Julian English and Sammy Glick are symptoms that warn of some malaise in their society. I tried to suggest Sammy's as "A way of life that was paying dividends in the first half of the twentieth century."

WIT and strong corrosive acids are blended liberally in this novel of fiendish ingenuity. It will make you laugh, it will make you wince, and it may just possibly make you crawl under the bedclothes forever. The quality of the book is elusive, but imagine a funny nightmare and you've got it. Nigel Dennis, a critic and novelist, is a savage satirist.
The nation's primary aluminum capacity will burgeon at least 36 per cent by 1958 if all the proposed expansion is built on schedule.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Capital is now engaged in the usual quadrennial diversion of hanging political labels on the Presidential candidates and dividing them into heroes and villains.
Idaho Power Company is going full speed ahead in its development of the controversial Hell's Canyon area of the Snake River on the Idaho-Oregon border.
How liberal or restrictive is the law under which the Administration is preparing to make its first use of new tariff-cutting authority?

IN what may be the most distinguished detective story of this decade, "The Daughter of Time," the late Josephine Tey argued convincingly for the innocence of Richard III in the murder of his nephews and struck out in general against what she called "Tonypandy" -- the historical "facts" which "every schoolboy knows" and which simply are not true.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Guy Martin's field-goal attempt, with 16 seconds remaining in the game, sailed wide of the goal posts today to save a 15-14 victory for Holy Cross over Colgate.

A course designed to help fill the need in industry for men who can write clear, easily understood technical reports is offered during the evening this fall by the Industries Training School (Hoboken, N. J.). The course, called "Technical Report Writing, is held weekly on the campus of Stevens Institute of Technology.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Aside from an appreciable interest in color and amateur movies, the Western States Convention and Photographic Trade Show held here last week reflected no dominant trend in any particular direction.

OF course, there will always be plenty of rocks. But there will not always be a rock garden, that is, in the accepted sense of the term. Rock gardening in America has had a rather checkered career. The initial blaze of interest that spurted in the Nineteen Twenties resulted in monstrosities called "rock gardens."
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Enrique Morea of Argentina opened the Pan American tennis championship today with a 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1 triumph over Mexico's Rafael Osuna.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, Oct. 8 -- The eleven weeks since the end of the Geneva conference must be reckoned as one of the most successful periods Russian diplomacy has known since the war. Soviet activity in that time has been a salient example of how an aggressive totalitarian policy can take advantage of a relaxed atmosphere and can exploit the hopes of the world.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- An outstanding collection of about 400 pieces of Chinese porcelain has been given to the Philadelphia Museum of Art by the estate of the late Alfred H. Caspary of New York.
A $17,000,000 contract to build a key military seaport in Spain has been awarded to the Corbetta Construction Company, Inc., of New York, and a Spanish concern taking part in a joint venture.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 4 -- A subtle form of censorship is being imposed on newspapers in South Africa.

AT this time of year, scores of Eastern girls' colleges become possessed with the absurd fear that hundreds of newly arrived freshmen, intoxicated with higher education, will turn into bookworms and wallflowers -- unless something is done. The problem is boys. How can the freshman classes of Vassar, Smith and all their sister institutions be introduced to the greatest number of boys with the least possible delay? The solution is the Freshman Mixer.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, just back from its European tour, can look back on a highly successful trip abroad. The orchestra was warmly received wherever it played, and, a Philharmonic spokesman said, there was "tremendous enthusiasm" for its musical director, Dimitri Mitropoulos.

Department store sales across the nation in the week ended Oct. 1 were 15 per cent higher than sales in the comparable week last year. This was the twenty-third consecutive weekly gain in sales reported by the Federal Reserve Board.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 8 -- Wisconsin's fullback, Charles Thomas, pounded through the Purdue line from the 6 for a second-quarter touchdown and Paul Schwaiko kicked an 18-yard field goal today for a 9-0 Badger victory before 45,000 Purdue homecoming fans.
ROME, Oct. 8 -- Senator Dennis Chavez said today that the United States was underpaying its "lower echelon" Foreign Service employes and that he was planning to do something about it.

ROUEN, France, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- Flaming bottles of gasoline and a hail of rocks marked a second outbreak of violence tonight as demonstrators massed to protest the sending of more French troops to North Africa.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 8 -- It took ten years for Michigan to score its first football victory over Army, but it was worth waiting for when the opportunity arrived today.
STILLWATER, Okla., Oct. 8 (UP) -- Wichita's 14-7 football upset of Oklahoma A. and M. College today turned into a riot among 250 to 300 fans on the field after the game.
BOSTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens put on another display of shooting ability tonight in whipping the Boston Bruins, 5 -- 2, for their third straight victory.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee accused the Defense Department today of having misled the public and Congress on data about leading defense contracts.

Arthur Rivituso, pianist, who made his debut at Town Hall Saturday evening, is a native New Yorker. He has studied here and abroad with the late Dinu Lipatti, Robert and Gaby Casadesus, Egon Petri and Nikita Magaloff.

The National Board of Americans for Democratic Action said yesterday that the opportunity for world peace might be lost "unless the United States fulfills its responsibility for leadership." The board issued a statement on foreign policy after a two-day closed meeting at the Commodore Hotel.
Registration of voters for the general election of Nov. 8 begins in the city today with Democratic leaders worried over a new Communist political threat.
The American tourist, gallivanting around the world with camera, guidebook and a well-stuffed billfold, is making an important contribution this year to growing prosperity abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals fiercely charging line forced the Washington Redskins to commit an unending string of errors today and enabled the Cards to topple the Redskins from the ranks of the unbeaten, 24 -- 10. A crowd of 26,337 saw the game.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 9 (UP) -- The Fund for the Republic has authorized a grant of $5,000 to determine the feasibility and practicality of a study of the performance of the United States press during the 1956 Presidential campaign.
The Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Eleventh Avenue in Manhattan may soon become one-way thoroughfares, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley said yesterday.

September orders for Navy cargo ships have raised the work on order in private American shipyards to eighteen vessels of 359,650 deadweight tons, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 -- The singer with the big voice and glamorous reputation is the best international currency in the opera world. A production like last night's "Andrea Chenier" by the San Francisco Opera depends almost wholly on its three principal performers.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- The formation of a customs advisory council for the Port of Chicago was announced today by Frank Peska, Collector of Customs.
ROME, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Poland defeated the United States and Italy swamped Australia today in opening team matches of the men's foil events.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Samuel D. Sturgis, Chief of Army Engineers, said today that the recent New England floods were the "most disastrous and most costly" in United States history.

An easing in the international tensions that "have racked and torn our peace of mind" was noted yesterday by Dr. John Haynes Holmes, minister emeritus of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

PARIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Ribot, an Italian 3-year-old colt and only undefeated entry in a field of twenty-three starters, won the Prix de I'Arm de Tromphe -- Europe's richest horse race -- at Longchamp today.
The resignation of another top official of the Waterfront Commission, the second in as many weeks, was made public yesterday.

More than 5,000 men and women, all unpaid volunteers, are circulating these days among their fellow New Yorkers asking for contributions in the annual drive of the United Hospital Fund, 8 East Forty-first Street. Campaign officials have succinctly described the dilemma of the voluntary hospitals.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 9 -- There were increasing indications today that an anti-Communist coalition government might result from the voting in Indonesia's first nation-wide elections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Administration is watching the new Argentine Government carefully and is planning to send one of its top Latin American experts there as Ambassador. He is John M. Cabot, now United States envoy to Stockholm.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored a goal in every period tonight to beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1.
Six new films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
DENVER, Oct. 9 -- President Eisenhower may have started a new fashion trend for convalescing patients today. He wore a snappy bow tie with his pajamas.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 9 -Steam produced from sunshine in Jerusalem today was said to be the first solar steam collected without the aid of lenses or mirrors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Allen Dulles, director of the Central W. Intelligence Agency, reported today that world-wide subversive activities of the Soviet Union were continuing unabated despite the "smiling" of Soviet leaders.
American Telephone and Telegraph Company stockholders have just four more days in which to change their subscription rights into cash or the equivalent.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Sir Robert Fraser, Director General of the Independent Television Authority, prophesied today that within twelve months British commercial television would be available to about 30,000,000 persons, or 69 per cent of the population.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Y. A. Tittle threw two scoring passes to Billy Wilson today to guide the San Francisco 49ers to a 20-19 victory over the Chicago Bears.

" Joyce Grenfell Requests the Pleasure . . ." is the general invitation extended to theatre-goers by Miss Grenfell, London entertainer, to witness her American stage debut. The first performance will start at 8 o'clock this evening at the Bijou.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Defense ministers of the fifteen nations in the North Atlantic Alliance will meet here tomorrow for a three-day session. They will discuss the defense plans of the alliance in the light of nuclear weapons and a general tendency to restrict defense expenditures.

IT has become almost a figure of speech in this town for people to threaten to commit some rash deed or other in a department store window, but probably the first to actually execute the threat is Miss Russell Elizabeth Lee, a University of Virginia Bachelor of Science from Charlottesville.

Some of the more pressing problems of state government will be reviewed at the eighth American Assembly, which will begin Thursday. The four-day meeting will be held at Arden House on the Harriman (N. Y.) campus of Columbia University.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Five skippers from the Royal Canadian Yacht Club of Toronto took the fourth race of the new international sailing series against American Yacht Club representatives today, 30 1/4 points to 25. The Canadians won the scheduled best-of-five team competition, 3 to 1.

HAVANA, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The police said today that Hans G. Knoll of New York and an unidentified woman were burned fatally last night when a highway truck smashed into their parked car at Matanzas, a beach resort sixty miles east of Havana. The crash set the ear afire.
A rearmed Germany might be a good thing in opposing Russia, but three out of five students on the New York Times Youth Forum last night were wary lest it produce a new Frankenstein monster.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A thirty-eight-day strike of 3,200 workers at the Bendix Radio plant ended tonight when a union membership meeting voted to accept a company settlement offer featuring a six-cent-anhour wage increase.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 9 -- The modern music program of the Louisville Orchestra, perhaps the most extensive to be found anywhere in the world today, was concretely demonstrated here by two concerts over the week-end.
Three hundred handicapped persons received clothing and baskets of food at a church festival service here yesterday.
Governor Harriman said yesterday he was not "morally bound" to support Adlai E. Stevenson for the Democratic Presidential nomination next year.
THOMPSON, Conn., Oct. 9 -Five course records were bettered at the Thompson Raceway today as the New England region of the Sports Car Club of America finished its season with a nine-event program.

Lost your wallet, soldier? Your pass, your papers and all your money, too? That's tough luck, buddy, but don't let it get you down. They'll find some way to help you over at the Times Square U. S. O. The United Service Organizations Center, off Times Square at 132 West Forty-third Street, gives personal services to service men.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party chief, has told a United States corn expert that the Soviet Union wants to enlist United States help in the present program to expand corn production.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Talk arose in Moscow's diplomatic colony today that the shadow that had fallen across Vyacheslav M. Molotov stemmed from some phase of Soviet foreign policy rather than his confessed error in enunciating Communist ideology.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he would argue the state's case for the state business and commercial rent laws in two pending actions.
St. Patrick's Cathedral, in a service yesterday marking the forty-fifth anniversary of its consecration, was called "a fact of beauty, of history and of faith."

Prices of cotton in the domestic market continued to lose ground last week. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses for the week of 11 to 189 points. Weakness centered in the more distant positions.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 -- Otho G. Bell, one of three "turncoat" prisoners who returned from Communist China in July after having once refused repatriation, is to get a general court-martial.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -Representative Robert C. Byrd charged today that the Government's cancellation of its coal purchase program represented a "dishonorable and unrealistic action."

A conference here to consider the high cost of easy credit has been called by Governor Harriman. The day-long discussion will be held Thursday at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street. Dr. Persia Campbell. consumer counsel to the Governor, will preside.

THE VERY REV. DR. JAMES A. PIKE, Dean of New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine), began his own television program at 1:30 P. M. yesterday over Channel 7. Originating from his study on the Cathedral grounds, the program took the form of a discussion of the relationship between church and state, with particular emphasis on the matter of Federal aid to parochial schools.

After several weeks of negotiations, the P. Lorillard Company and the Revlon Products Corporation have failed to agree on terms for sharing sponsorship of a new television show titled "The $64,000 Panel."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- The steel industry is on its way to a new record in steel ingot production. It is almost certain that output of steel this year will reach or approach 115,000,000 tons. That record would be 3,500,000 tons more than was produced in 1953, the previous record year.

A TELEVISION glimpse of our civilization as it might look twenty-one years from now must have sounded like a bright idea when first conceived. But someone forgot to consider the limitations of video. So, "1976" seen yesterday from 4:30 to 5:30 P. M. on Channel 4, was an elaborate bore.

ONE of the most versatile do-it-yourself products to appear on the market recently is plastic sheeting with self-adhesive backings. Any flat surface in the home may thus be covered with a wipe-clean material that is available in a wide variety of designs and colors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Congress called industrialists, labor leaders, economists, scientists and Government officials today to help in an investigation of automation and what it is doing to the country.

The eighteenth-century novelist-playwright, Henry Fielding, is probably best known for his novel "Tom Jones." His role as magistrate and founder of "the first British police force" is the subject of Patrick Pringle's "Hue and Cry," which Morrow will publish in an American edition Oct. 24.

" SPRING'S AWAKENING," Frank Wedekind's 1891 sermon on the necessity for sex education, received a solemn airing last evening at the Provincetown Playhouse.

DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK, the pediatrician and professor of child development at Western Reserve University, began a new program series yesterday [3 P. M. on Channel 4] for parents who have not yet been through the mill.

DENVER, Oct. 9 (UP) -President Eisenhower's wife was described today as eager to return to the Eisenhowers' Gettysburg, Pa., farm but resigned to the "necessary" four or five more weeks the President might have to spend in the hospital here.
AMSTERDAM, Oct. 9 -- Conditions were rather hectic all last week on the Amsterdam stock market.
TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, Oct. 9 -- Moroccan nationalists here are cooperating with the Spaniards while next door part of the native population has revolted against the French.

St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church formally received its new rector, the Rev. Terence John Finlay, yesterday morning. The institution ceremonies were presided over by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
THE New York City Opera presented its first performance this season of the familiar twin bill, "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "I Pagliacci," at the City Center last night.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Quarterback Otto Graham and End Dante Lavelli teamed up in the final four and a half minutes today to bring the Cleveland Browns from behind to a 21-17 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

This year of 1955 is pretty much an "off-year," as elections go, with the city and state balloting out of the way in 1953 and 1954, respectively, and the national election not due until next year. But even in this off-year there will be a ballot with ten proposed amendments to the State Constitution, one proposition, some judgeships and a few other offices in which vacancies are to be filled.

Most New Yorkers can remember the shock and excitement of the terrific explosions which occurred in May, 1950, just two days apart. One of them went off in South Amboy, when 467 tons of miscellaneous ammunition was detonated on the 19th.
RICHMOND, Cailf., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Betty Jameson of San Antonio won her sixth major tournament of 1955 today by rallying on the last round of the $5,000 Richmond women's open.
First-class air fares on many world routes will go up by 10 per cent beginning April 1, the International Air Transport Association announced yesterday.

An oil exploration boom is under way in Western Europe and in the Mediterranean area. Spurred by scattered oil discoveries over the last year or two, and generally liberalized petroleum laws in most of the countries involved, the search is being carried out by both the large international organizations and independent operators.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- Adolf Hitler's valet said here today that he helped burn the dictator's body after Hitler had committed suicide in his Berlin bomb shelter in April 1945.
There is no mistaking the virtuoso blood of Stanley Babin, the 23-year-old pianist who played his first full recital program in Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Oct 9 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan won his first golf tournament as a professional today. His one-under-par 71 on the final round was good for a one-stroke victory over Art Wall Jr. in the $,17,500 Eastern Open.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- French Premier Edgar Faure, victorious in an exhausting three-day parliamentary defense of his policy in Morocco, faces a new assault by his political enemies on Tuesday on the issue of Algeria.

The Cardinal Hayes football team scored on two sustained marohes and a quarterback sneak to turn back St. John's Prep of Brooklyn, 20 -0, yesterday. The game was played at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The "redcoats" marched in Washington again today.

Products of Asia, Inc., has been established to promote trade with the Far Eastern area, it has been announced by Austin T. Graves, president. Its main interest will be sales in this country of quality consumer products of fine design, with initial emphasis on imports from Japan.
St. Vincent's Hospital will stage at 9 A. M. today a fire drill in which its nurses' residence, a fourteen-story building, will be vacated.
Sir Winston Churchill warned last night that the unity of the Western world should be maintained to guarantee improvement in international affairs.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- A porous pass defense sent the New York Giants to their third straight defeat in the National Football League today.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 9 -- International health endeavors are good weapons in the struggle for peace, Dr. Howard A. Rusk said today.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 9 -Northern India has been hit by the worst floods of the century.
The fine autumn weather New Yorkers have been enjoying has apparently been favorable for fishing. Generous shipments have resulted in lower prices on Boston mackerel and scallops.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 9 -- The Indian Government made public today a controversial plan for revamping the country's political framework.
The United States will commence next week a new series of nuclear tests at the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada Test Site near Las Vegas.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 9 -- Prefabricated housing designed to withstand the icy blasts of the Antarctic is being hammered out these warm October days in a modest little plant on the Danbury-Brewster highway.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A committee composed of doctors who handle many traffic accident cases advocated today an automobile design "which does not masticate pedestrians and children on bicycles."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Two influential Representatives expressed the belief today that the new military reserve program had made a "discouraging" start. But they thought it could be sold to the public with the proper publicity.
DENVER, Oct. 9 (AP) -Fallowing is the White House transcript of the remarks of Dr. Paul Dudley White on President Eisenhower's condition at a news conference today:

THE debut of a promising new baritone named Louis Quilico in the role of the elder Germont was a highlight of yesterday afternoon's excellent "Traviata" at the City Center.

The United Nations Children's Fund, known as UNICEF, is an integral part of the U. N. with ninety-one countries and territories benefiting from its programs of nutrition, health services and disease control. Funds have increased from the "have" nations to support UNICEF from year to year -- but not yet to the extent that budget goals have been realized.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9 -- A charge that Warner Brothers was "again resorting to the unfair and uneconomic practice of requesting bids before exhibitors have had an opportunity to see the picture" highlighted the closing sessions of the convention of Theatre Owners of America yesterday.
Members of the visiting Russian housing delegation expressed a "good deal of astonishment" yesterday at the numerous individual television aerials they observed in housing developments here.
British former service men in uniform marched with their colors into Trinity church yesterday for the celebration of the thirty-fourth annual British Harvest Festival.

BILL RIGNEY, the new manager of the Giants, had been rambling away in this space yesterday when he bumped into the bottom of the column. He'd been about to take off with a description of some of his adventures as skipper of Minneapolis during his apprenticeship days. So the use of the hall is turned back to him forthwith.
A 76-year-old man was killed and three persons were injured at 9 A. M. yesterday when a car plowed into another car that had stopped on the Belt Parkway near Seventy-second Street, Brooklyn.

VELIA, Italy, Oct. 9 -- Elea, which was the home of the philosopher Zeno at the beginning of the fifth century B. C. and gave its name to the Eleatic school of thought, is being brought to light again by Italian excavators.

Murray Stahl, operator, who recently contracted to buy the sixty - four - family apartment building at 1838-40 Vyse Avenue in the Bronx, has sold the contract to Nathan Wach. The sale is subject to mortgages totaling $157,000, according to Langsam Siegel, brokers in the transaction.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 9 -- The Social Democratic party decisively defeated Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition in today's election in the city-state of Bremen.
DETROIT, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The New York Rangers toppled the Detroit Red Wings to their third straight defeat, 3 -- 2, before 10,152 fans at Olympia tonight.

History over the last third of a century demonstrates that a nation withdrawing from organized international cooperation hurts itself far more than it hurts the international agency.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 9 -- The cruelest aspect of the Palestine dispute is that, in a tragic sense, it has become a conflict between refugees. Israel has provided haven for more than a million Jewish fugitives from terror in Europe, North Africa and Western Asia.
ROME, Oct. 9 -- Thousands of young athletes performed calisthenics, juggled, formed acrobatic "human pyramids" and played basketball before Pope Pius XII in St. Peter's Square today.

Pupils in the public schools are learning "relatively little" about the important issues and pressing problems in public education, a report from Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday.

The New York Public Library's 500-year-old Gutenberg Bible, most valuable volume in its rare collection, took part in some very modern goings-on yesterday.

The English sound engineer Gilbert A. Briggs, who sold out a London concert hall for his recent demonstration of recorded sound equipment, duplicated this feat at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. He proved hi-fi enthusiasm to be at an equally feverish pitch on both sides of the Atlantic.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The City's reaction, as expressed in the stock markets, to important statements made by Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler last week have been varied and sharp.
The Republican and Democratic members of the Eighty-fourth Congress have received equal billing for assertedly accomplishing little in civil rights legislation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Threats to free world security resulting from the British-Greek-Turkish quarrel over Cyprus and Egypt's decision to obtain arms from the Soviet bloc are expected to get attention from the National Security Council this week.

The charter market continued its strong position last week, with slight rate increases noted virtually throughout the field. Coal, however, the bulwark of the market, showed a leveling-off tendency at the high rate plateau of a week ago.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 9 -The mass return of German prisoners of war from the Soviet Union began today. Two trains of freight cars brought 750 officers and men to the Lower Saxony frontier station of Herleshausen.
The site of the present Washington Retail Market might be even more valuable to the city as a new downtown park than if it were sold for private development, it was suggested yesterday.
John Davis is a man who likes records. He has collected dozens for his prowess in weight lifting and hundreds because of his ambition to become an opera singer.
A crude bomb exploded at 6:48 o'clock last night in the Paramount Theatre. Fragments struck the shoe of one moviegoer, but he was not injured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- John B. Hollister, new chief of the Foreign Economic Aid program, has run into strong opposition in his first major decision. This is a decision to terminate a policy of his predecessor, Harold E. Stassen, of occasionally reserving some foreign aid purchases for American suppliers.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Oct. 9 -- Acceptance of United States aid by Nationalist China does not deprive it of the right to counter-attack against the Communist-held mainland, President Chiang Kai-shek declared today. At the same time he assured his countrymen that a counter-attack "will come."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Harold E. Stassen said today that "the man President Eisenhower wishes to have nominated will be nominated" in 1956 and will win the Presidency.

BY the time the leaves on campus trees begin to turn, and once-white buckskin shoes have achieved the proper patina, most college freshmen have awakened fully to the truth that academic life bears but little resemblance to the moving-picture or fashion-magazine versions they have seen.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- France has notified the Organization for European Economic Cooperation that she is ready to begin freeing a part of her exchanges with the dollar zone. Other members of the O. E. E. C., such as Belgium, Germany, the Netherlands and Great Britain, have already removed currency restrictions on important segments of their trade with the United States and other dollar zone countries.

Economists have drawn pictures of a future in which men will live to the age of 90, retire at 50 and spend the last forty years sitting around being bored with each other. A work-week of twenty-four hours will leave more time for boredom.

OF interest to fine home cooks are culinary demonstrations that will start tomorrow in the Au Gourmet department of Bloomingdale's. To be given without attendance charge on Tuesdays and Fridays at 11 A. M. for six consecutive weeks, the "how-to" series will detail such dishes as veal scallops Viennese, omelet aux fines herbes, veal kidneys flambe and cheese beignets (fritters).

With a commendable sense of present-day realities, the French National Assembly has averted a new Cabinet crisis at this important juncture in world affairs by endorsing Premier Faure's North African policy by decisive majorities which reached 521 against only 100 opposition votes on some test ballots and amounted to 477 against only 140 on the final vote.
Holders of common stock of the Rochester Telephone Corporation are receiving warrants to subscribe at $18 a share for 195,312 additional shares of common.

DENVER, Oct. 9 -- Boston continues to put interesting figures in the national limelight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -A Commerce Department study today showed that the less skilled worker had tripled his average wage between 1939 and 1951. But those in this category still received about the same share of the nation's total wages.

SIKESTON, Mo., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Political supporters of Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, will hold "preliminary'' discussions on a proposed "Symington-for-President" campaign at a meeting of state Democrats here next Saturday.

Recent changes in the rate and discount structures of the four radio networks have so affected the "comparability" of the figures that the Publishers Information Bureau is discontinuing all efforts to report such data. The art of the illustrated book, from the days before printing with movable type to about a century and a half after its invention, is on view in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Rare English and American literary items have been selected for an exhibition, "Treasures from the Berg Collection," opening today at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. They were among the 50,000 items presented in 1941 by the late Dr. Albert A. Berg.

It is now nearly thirty-five years since George N. Peek and Hugh S. Johnson, then executives of a company manufacturing farm implements, presented privately in 1921 their plans for reflating farm prices following the drastic collapse that followed World War I.

The average rate of interest charged by leading New York City banks on business loans has increased rather sharply, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the week end. Rates on short-term loans average 3.48 per cent in the first half of September, 0.25 per cent above the average rate in effect in the first half of June and in the September period a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey accused the Agriculture Department today of having put out "pure, unadulterated political propaganda."

Plans for a twelve-story apartment house from a design by H. I. Feldman, architect, have been announced for the plot 100 by 100 feet at 337 to 345 East Fifty-second Street. The site has been sold by 341 East Fifty-second, Inc., represented by Hiram S. Gans.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 9 -The taxpayer at Main Street West and West Neck Road, occupied by an A. P. supermarket and nine other stores, has been sold to the Investors Funding Corporation of New York by the Huntington Center Properties, Inc., for cash above mortgages amounting to $220,000.
The picked team of the American Soccer League defeated the eleven of the Ontario Soccer Association, 2 to 1, before 1,500 fans at Zerega Oval in the Bronx, yesterday.
" OMNIBUS," making its seasonal debut on Channel 2, tried to do the Renaissance in about eighty minutes yesterday afternoon. The program had the advantages and disadvantages of every quick tour.

FEZ, French Morocco, Oct. 9 -- The heavy French National Assembly vote for the Government's reform plan in Morocco came as a blow today to European opponents of reform in Morocco. The reform plan aims at bringing some home rule to Morocco.

Newsday, independent Long Island newspaper, said yesterday it favored Adlai E. Stevenson for the 1956 Democratic Presidential nomination. The decisiveness of Michigan's victory over Army was as much of a joit as anything the football season has brought forth.
