UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- In the first six months of 1955 the world's total industrial output reached a level one and a half times that of the entire year 1948. Results for the second quarter of this year set a historic peak, the United Nations monthly Bulletin of Statistics for October disclosed today.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 (UP) -- A runaway truck loaded with almost fifteen tons of cotton sped down a congested hill street at more than fifty miles an hour today. It sidewiped automobiles and sent pedestrians scattering for their lives.

A biography of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia by Ernest Cuneo has been scheduled for Nov. 7 publication by Macmillan under the title, "Life With Fiorello." The author was La Guardia's one-time law clerk and lifelong friend.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- What Secretary of State Dulles has called the "spirit of Geneva" was notably lacking at the meeting here today of the defense ministers of the Atlantic alliance states.

Investment bankers headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and Riter Co. placed on the market after the close yesterday a new issue of 240,000 shares of Copperweld Steel Company common stock priced at $25 a share.

Directors of the Telautograph Corporation, developers and producers of equipment to transmit written messages, voted yesterday to increase the company's annual dividend rate to $1.50 a common share. Directors also approved a quarterly dividend of 37 1/2c a share for payment on Nov. 14, an increase over last year's third quarter dividend of 25c a share.
RHINEBECK, Oct. 10 -- Children referred for institutional care today are increasingly disturbed and more in need of special services than in past years, a medical expert reported here.

Gen. Mark W. Clark has accepted for the third successive year the national chairmanship of the Heart Fund Campaign. This drive of the American Heart Association and its affiliates will be held throughout the month of February, 1956.

A group of medical buildings is planned in Flushing, Queens, where John D. Connaughton has sold his home at 59-25 Kissena Boulevard to the Upper Queens Medical Group. The property comprises a plot 140 by 216 feet and contains a dwelling with ten rooms and three baths.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Changes in the employment picture followed mainly a seasonal pattern last month.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 (UP) -- Nearly 22,000 telephone workers in Northern California and Nevada went on strike at 6 A. M. today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Israel will open a campaign tomorrow to win a security guarantee and sharply increased weapons deliveries from the West to offset Egypt's arms deal with Communist Czechoslovakia.
Two women were badly burned in an explosion last night after gas leaked into four East Side brownstone houses.

Tennessee Gas Transmission Company and a new associate, Midwestern Gas Transmission Company, announced at Houston yesterday filing of applications with the Federal Power Commission for permission to provide a new natural gas service to the Midwest from the Texas-Louisiana Gulf Coast and Western Canada.
Lulu Perez of Brooklyn out-boxed and outpunched Bobby Courchesne of Holyoke, Mass., in the ten-round main event at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Friday's total of 478 pints of blood donated to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program included 375 pints given at Fort Monmouth, N. J. On Saturday 141 pints were contributed at the Masonic Temple, 137-70 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.
Two top - level personnel changes along Madison Avenue were announced yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 10 -- Israel charged today that Egypt was maintaining military positions in the Sinai peninsula opposite the demilitarized zone of the Negev in violation of the armistice agreement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs remained at a high for nearly two and one-half years.

Cook County, Ill., financed yesterday the first stage of a proposed $245,000,000 expressway system to serve the Chicago area through the sale of $40,000,000 of tax secured serial bonds maturing over twenty years at an interest cost of 2.555 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today granted a hearing to Harold I. Cammer, New York attorney who was fined guilty of contempt and fined $100 for sending letters to members of a grand jury.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The French Cabinet prepared today to water down its policy of outright "integration" of Algeria with France. Premier Edgar Faure and his Cabinet ministers at a meeting this evening were reported to have considered modifications of Government policy.
The New York Knickerbockers will play in the feature game of twelve professional basketball double-headers at Madison Square Garden during the coming season.

AFTER five years as an experimental gallery and workshop, The Contemporaries Gallery has reopened this season in new and attractive quarters at 992 Madison Avenue. Margaret Lowengrund, director, has achieved a longstanding ambition in this well-designed new gallery.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Surface Transportation Corporation renewed their bids yesterday to take over operations of all surface routes controlled by the Transit Authority in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Westbrook Pegler, the columnist, and two Hearst corporations today were denied a Supreme Court review of a trial in which they had been ordered to pay $175,000 libel damages to Quentin Reynolds, writer.
The Mayor's Interdepartmental Committee for a Clean City began the educational phase of its campaign yesterday morning on the lower East Side.
TO people who are properly tuned in, Joyce Grenfell seems to be a hilarious entertainer.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 10 -- Brazil was plunged today into a crisis over monetary policy.
A state court ruled yesterday that picketing could be held illegal if it did "actual harm" to an employer's business.
GENEVA, Oct. 5 -- All across southern Europe, from the Golden Horn to the Pillars of Hercules, ancient lands are astir with new forces of economic growth.

The letter from Fred R. Field Jr., which appears on this page, shows a striking change in tone and manner from the I. L. A. pronouncements with which the public has been afflicted of late. Speaking for the New York District Council, of which he is president, Mr. Field presents several suggestions which he thinks, if adopted, would help to stabilize labor conditions on the waterfront.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct 10 -- Gen. Juan D. Peron faces immediate internment in Paraguay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Government said today that it was holding up settlement payments on the abandoned Dixon-Yates power contract while it determined whether any "conflict of interest" had made the contract illegal.

Thirty-four years ago the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) became a pioneer in instituting an employes' stock purchase plan. And the company is still enthusiastic about it, according to an article by Robert E. Wilson, chairman of the board, in the current issue of The Exchange, published by the New York Stock Exchange.

A Yorkville neighborhood committee urged city and state officials yesterday to help low-income families who are being squeezed out of the East Side community by the boom in high-rent apartment buildings.

ROBERT J. SHAW, one of television's abler writers, had himself a play going last night on the Robert Montgomery hour on Channel 4. It was called "Paper Town" and highlighted a difference in moral values between the elder and younger generations.

A possible site for a new building figures in one of the latest deals on Third Avenue. The property, at the northeast corner of Fifty-eighth Street and running through to Fifty-ninth Street, has been purchased by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, from a group headed by Samuel Gale Jr.
Sharers of the Ivy championship a year ago and the top favorites again, Yale and Cornell meet at New Haven Saturday in the game that may decide the race for the title.

The next President of Brazil is almost certainly going to be Juscelino Kubitschek and his Vice President will, in all likelihood, be Joao (Jango) Goulart. Enough votes from the Oct. 3 election have been counted to make these results clear.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The United States was criticized today as seeking to make economic aid to underdeveloped countries dependent on political conditions.
MARGATE, England, Oct. 10 -- A grand inquiry into the decline of British socialism opened here today at the annual Labor party conference.
Striking scalemen in the port voted yesterday to reject a new employer offer and continued their ten-day walkout.

It is not likely that the number of advertisements appearing in the lost and found columns appealing for the return of eyeglasses is any indication of the number of eyeglasses lost or mislaid daily in a city the size of New York.
" The Carefree Tree," a new play by Aldyth Morris, based on a Chinese legend, begins a limited engagement of five weeks tonight at the Phoenix Theatre, 189 Second Avenue, at 8 o'clock.
MIAMI, Oct. 10 -- The American Legion opened its thirty-seventh annual convention today with speakers emphasizing the need to combat Communist subversion by improving community relations.
Drinking places throughout the state will be required to provide visibility from the street under a State Liquor Authority policy that will become effective on Nov. 1.
Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday he was not lining up delegates for any Democratic Presidential contender in 1956 -- that he did not want to boss the convention.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 10 -- The leader of the Masjumi, Moslem political party, charged today that he had uncovered evidence of widespread intimidation and fraud in the balloting in central Java. His party had suffered a sharp setback there in the nation's first parliamentary election, Sept. 29.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The State Department has approved visas for four Russian scientists to attend an international conference here on the use of antibiotics in agriculture.
DENVER, Oct. 10 -- For the first time since his heart attack President Eisenhower was moved out of his hospital room today to lie in mellow autumn sunshine and breathe the fresh Rocky Mountain air.
A young woman teller frustrated last night an attempt by a shabbily dressed plumber to hold up the Bronx Savings Bank at Tremont and Park Avenues. The would-be robber was captured.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The Secretary of the Treasury said tonight that the Administration of the Government was in the hands of a "trained team."

WASHINGTON, Oct 10 (UP) -- Two pioneers in the field urged President Eisenhower's physicians today to consider heart surgery. They said this would extend the President's life expectancy and permit him to carry a bigger workload.
A half-hour film made in Russia by the National Broadcasting Company will be televised on Sunday, Oct. 23, at 1 P. M.
MIAMI, Oct. 10 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the inconstancy of Soviet world policy had posed "difficult and delicate" diplomatic tasks for the free world.

ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Business activity rolled along at a record rate in New York State during August and nonagricultural employment hit a high for the year, the state Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston said today the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee was investigating "the illegal and political removal" of postmasters. The South Carolina Democrat is committee chairman.
Willie Mays of the New York Giants captured the National League slugging title for the second straight year.
DETROIT, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Auto production continues at low levels as the car makers complete the transition to 1956 model output.
ATHENS, Oct. 10 -- Premier Constantinos Karamanlis voiced the determination of his new Government today to continue supporting "the just claims of the Cypriotes."
Leonard W. Hall scented yesterday a Democratic plot to dump Adlai E. Stevenson in midstream.

The granddaddy of all Arctic icebergs -- a monster measuring three quarters of a mile by half a mile, and 650 feet thick -- was observed in Melville Bay, near Thule, Greenland, by the Coast Guard icebreaker Westwind.

YONKERS, Oct. 10 -- Belle Acton, a brown filly by The Widower-Diane Scot by Scotland, bettered the world record for 2-year-old pacers on a half-mile track with a 2:02 2-5 mile in the $14,200 Autumn Pace for 2-year-olds before 18,115 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 (AP) -- There has been little abatement of the power of Washington over the lives and businesses of this country, retail merchants were told here today.
ANTIQUES dealers showing at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory are presenting a persuasive case to the shopper uncertain about which decorating direction to take.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court, in a case involving fabulous mineral riches, refused today to put a three-mile limit on Louisiana's seaward boundary.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 10 -- Benny Howarth, football coach at St. Mark's School, claims he's a surprised man. His Blue and White eleven has won its first two games and Howarth now is comparing himself to the dazed individual who picks himself up after being struck by a car and asks:
HARTFORD, Oct. 10 -- A special session of the Connecticut General Assembly will start Nov. 9, Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff announced today.
Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' foreign policy address yesterday to the American Legion convention in Miami, as recorded by The New York Times:

Prime Minister Nehru has presented to India the new plan for redrawing the political map of the country. In place of the present twenty-nine states there would be only sixteen. Of those, twelve would be established on a linguistic basis and thus represent all but two of India's major language groups by political divisions.

HARTFORD, Oct. 10 -- (UP) -- The police captured Herbert Brown, 34 years old, of Ozone Park, Queens, late today. He was one of two "very dangerous" convicts who escaped yesterday from the Connecticut State Prison at near-by Wethersfield.

Operating revenues and net income of the Bell System for the three and twelve months ended Aug. 31 continued to show heavy gains over the like 1954 periods, according to the quarterly statement mailed yesterday.

I HAD hoped that some day we could build an international organization that would eventually work on the same basis as the union of the United States. I had made a study of the "Grand Design" of King Henry IV of France. This plan called for a kind of Federation of Sovereign States in Europe to act in concert to prevent wars.
The sound of a fire extinguisher going off seemed to cause as much nervousness yesterday as the sight of fire. This scene was observed by 300 student nurses of St. Vincent's Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today that it had restored export privileges to Arbuckle, Smith Co., Ltd., of London, England.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The elusive Soviet secret agent who signs simply "Astigmatoff" to his confidential reports to the Kremlin about American affairs has suffered the indignity of still another interception. As on previous occasions a translation of his latest dispatch was made available to this department only.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 -- It is "high time" this country got busy applying atomic propulsion to commercial shipping, and Congress intends to press for action in the next session.
Mayor Wagner praised 340 school children yesterday for their help toward fire prevention.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 11 -- A Baptist minister was cited for contempt of court today for his criticism of Superior Court Judge Frank T. Lloyd Jr. in a case involving a ban on Sunday sales of liquor.

ROME, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Christian D'Oriola of France, the defending titleholder, squeezed through with three victories in five bouts to reach the third round of the men's foils event in the world fencing championships today.

When commodity traders indulge in "hedging" -- as they do every working day -- they are not playing it coy. As hard-headed business men they are, in effect, insuring themselves against untoward financial loss.

MONTREAL, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens' all-star center, Jean Beliveau, and Ron Murphy of the New York Rangers lead the individual scorers in the National Hockey League with 5 points each, statistics showed today. Murphy has four goals and an assist and Beliveau two goals and three assists.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 11 - Princeton will be facing Colgate's football team here on Saturday without the services of Royce Flippin.

FAMILIES often discourage an older relative from taking up a craft. "You've worked hard enough in your life," a daughter may tell her mother. But, according to a Danish expert, the craft is important not only for the sense of achievement and creativeness, without which few human beings can be happy. It is important also for the oldster's independence, which depends on his ability to take care of himself.

A PIANIST of unusual promise made his debut at Town Hall last night. The young artist's name is Joel Rosen, and he is a product of the Juilliard School, where he studied under Sascha Gorodnitzki and Felix Salmond.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 -Argentina will ratify the 1948 Bogota Inter-American Charter "very soon" in a move to restore hemisphere ties that Gen. Juan D. Peron did much to weaken.

ISFIYA, Israel, Oct. 11 -- Although founded as a Jewish state, Israel is neither ethnically nor religiously homogeneous. Her inhabitants include, of course, two distinct minorities that have nothing but geographical location in common with the Jews.
BONN, Oct. 11 -- Dieter Friede, West Berlin journalist who disappeared from West Berlin in 1947, returned today with a group of German war prisoners from the Soviet Union.

The flow of American visitors overseas is reaching for new records this year, according to reports from correspondents of this newspaper in the nineteen countries most popular with travelers. Of all the economic forces at work in this complex world of today tourism is one of the most beneficent.

SHORTLY before the turn of this century, W. J. Henderson referred to Eugen d'Albert as "The Little Giant." Another "little giant" played last night in Carnegie Hall. Emil Gilels from Russia is, like d'Albert, a short and stocky man. And, as d'Albert is supposed to, he played the piano with amazing strength, color and resource.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Senate investigators said today they had received charges that postmasterships had been sold in Texas for $100 to $1,000 under the Republican Administration.

Brush Burn showed a great liking for the turf course at Belmont Park yesterday. The 6-year-old owned by Stanley Mikell met seven others in the Wheatley Hills Handicap, run over a mile and three furlongs on the grass, and won by more than a length.
ALAMOGORDO, N. M., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Air Force scientists will hurtle a rocket tomorrow night forty to seventy miles above the earth to probe the secrets of dawn and dusk.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 11 -- The Eighth Army's drive against the black market here appears to have taken a discriminatory turn against Korean nationals.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 11 -- Mario Camara became Finance Minister of Brazil today.

CAIRO, Oct. 11 -- The weak Syrian Government of Said el Ghazzy held out tonight against accepting a United States-backed plan to develop the Jordan Valley for the benefit of both Israel and the Arabs.

Directors of Johnson Johnson, manufacturers of surgical dressings, voted yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of 35c, payable on Dec. 9, and a 25c extra, payable on Jan. 11. The company paid a similar extra dividend last January.
Oklahoma state officials were given encouragement by investment bankers here yesterday as to the feasibility of furthering the financing of Oklahoma's projected toll turnpike system soon.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Tony Trabert, United States amateur tennis champion, today accepted the offer of Jack Kramer to turn professional for a reputed guarantee of more than $75,000. The figure was reported to be the highest ever given to a net star to turn pro.
The New York Civil Liberties Union protested yesterday a state court order limiting the right to picket.

Former President Harry S. Truman went without his usual morning walk yesterday. Instead, he took Mrs. Truman to meet their daughter Margaret as she returned aboard the liner United States from a two-month vacation in Europe.
BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- Applause for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in a corridor of the Boston Federal Building caused a mistrial today.
The Ogden Corporation yesterday acquired all of the assets of Luria Brothers Co., Inc., iron and steel scrap concern, for about $20,000,000.
Carmine G. DeSapio is taking off for the West Coast today for the apparent purpose of putting a few road blocks in the path of the Stevenson bandwagon.

Stockholders of the Automatic Washer Company, at a special meeting in Newton, Iowa, yesterday approved a proposed amendment to the articles of incorporation which authorizes the issuance of additional stock. The proposal would increase the 180,000 outstanding shares to 1,250,000 and reduce the present par value of $3 to $1.50 a share.
Michigan's victory over Army so impressed the United Press football board of coaches that the Wolverines yesterday were placed first in the weekly poll.

Campbell Chibougamau Mines, Ltd., $1 par value capital stock was admitted to trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday at 11 A. M. The opening transaction was for 1,200 shares at 13 3/4. The stock closed at 13 1/2. The ticker symbol is CCH.L.
The nation produced more steel in the first nine months this year than in any other similar period in history. Output last month set a record for any September, too.

TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- A group of Japanese industrialists and traders has concluded unofficial barter agreements with four Communist countries totaling $7,000,000 each way, the Japan-Soviet Trade Association said here today.

Although all blood centers of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program win be closed today, Columbus Day, the Flatlands community in Brooklyn will participate in a mass donation. The time will be 3 P. M. to 9 P. M. and the place will be the Prudential Savings Bank, Kings Highway and Flatbush Avenue.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- Field Marshal Sir John Harding, new British Governor and Commander in Chief in Cyprus, tonight announced a break-down in his talk with Archbishop Makarios, Great-Cypriote leader, and termed the rupture "a very serious matter."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- The Secretary General of the United Nations made a bid today to take the self-determination provision out of the draft covenants on human rights.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 11 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, 79-year-old West German Chancellor, was reported today by his doctors to be recovering from a light case of bronchial pneumonia.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 11 -- An item in the parish bulletin distributed at last Sunday's masses of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church here has upset this community. It also threatens the success of the annual Community Chest fund drive, which is now under way.
A $350,000,000 bond issue to provide additional funds for school construction was demanded yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, member of the Board of Education.

Wes Santee and Fred Dwyer will continue their indoor foot-racing rivalry in an invitation mile here Thursday night, Oct. 20. The test will be part of the Olympic sports carnival at Madison Square Garden, where a six-sport program will begin the United States Olympic Committee's fund-raising drive for next year's Olympic Games.

MARTHA RAYE is an exasperating girl. When she is given the right material and is willing to accept guidance, she can be a true mistress of the slapstick. But when not afforded every protection, she can exhaust a viewer's patience, as she did last night on Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Fred G. Aandahl, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, told House of Representatives investigators today that the threat of "Federal regional monopoly" had helped to produce power shortages in the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Pacific Northwest.

The International Business Machines Corporation attained record earnings in the first nine months of this year, according to figures issued yesterday. Net income for the period increased 14.5 per cent to $38,437,353 from $33,575,088 earned in the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1954. The results equaled $9.38 a share and $8.19 a share on 4,098,471 shares for the respective periods.
Inability to recover from fast beating of the heart appears to be a major difference between heart-muscle tissue in young and old persons.
A RECENT report from New Hampshire indicated that a fisher had visited Berlin and caused a slight sensation because none had been seen in the city before.
Canada's second major bank merger in less than a year was proposed yesterday. The Imperial Bank of Canada and Barclays Bank (Canada) announced plans to amalgamate under the name of the former.
Forty representatives of large New York business interests reserved decision yesterday on a proposed national promotion campaign to bring visitors to Manhattan.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 11 -- Communist China has agreed to pay increased prices for sheet rubber sold under a new Sino-Ceylonese trade agreement. A spokesman for the Commerce Ministry here said today that a Ceylonese trade delegation now in Peiping, led by Minister of Commerce Shirley Oorea, reported it had successfully negotiated a price increase for rubber delivered from June until the end of 1955.

Despite the numerical superiority of the Soviet Air Force, the Russians have not pulled ahead of us in air power, Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, declared yesterday.

THE most puzzling team in the big leagues last spring was the St. Louis Cardinals. "I just can't figure them out," said Birdie Tebbetts, as shrewd and as penetrating an analyst as there is in the business. "They can finish anywhere from first to seventh."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- State Department officials warmly welcomed today news that Iran was seeking membership in the "northern tier of defense" in the Middle East.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Australia today warned countries receiving economic aid that the main burden would inevitably fall on the peoples of these lands.
The Yiddish Art Theatre will be reactivated at 8 o'clock tonight.

Improvements in styling, horsepower and safety have been incorporated in the 1956 Chrysler car line, the Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday. And buyers may choose from optional equipment that includes a high-fidelity record player.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 11 -- Aneurin Bevan, long the hero of British socialism's left, suffered a crushing defeat today. Hugh Gaitskell, the right wing's candidate for leadership of the Labor party, routed Mr. Bevan in a contest for the key post of party treasurer.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 11 -- The new Ohio Corporation Act became effective today. It provides several regulations designed to protect minority shareholders. Its main purpose, however, is to revise and renumber the State's corporate laws and to separate the sections dealing with corporations for profit from sections pertaining to non-profit organizations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Today, as usual, the major debate in the current General Assembly involved a proposal by India. The Political and Security Committee, discussing the peaceful uses of atomic energy, was asked to choose between conflicting resolutions introduced by the United States, India and the Soviet Union.
The gunfire that led to the establishment of martial law around the strikebound Indiana foundry of the Perfect Circle Corporation is a throwback to the Stone Age in industrial relations.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 12 -- Canada and the Soviet Union agreed last night to accord each other most-favored-nation privileges in their trade. This means that each country would give imports from the other country the same treatment that it accords to its most favored trading partner.
Voter registration in the city continued at a sluggish pace yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart of Indiana said today that he did not think President Eisenhower's choice for a sucessor would be binding on the 1956 convention.

Don Heinrich, former Washington U. All-America who twice led the nation's collegiate passers, will start at quarterback for the New York Football Giants Sunday when they open at the Polo Grounds against the Chicago Cardinals, Coach Jim Lee Howell said at a Polo Grounds luncheon yesterday.
"THE Carefree Tree," which was acted at the Phoenix last evening, is a charming play that needs a superb performance.
Diversification is coming to mean as much to the French textile industry as to American manufacturers, Jacques Lesur, head of the French wool concern which bears his name, said yesterday.
CHRISTMAS begins this Saturday for post office employes -- Oct. 15 marks the opening of the period for overseas mailing, to close Nov. 15.
ATHENS, Oct. 11 -- Opposition speakers in Parliament tonight attacked the policy statement of the new Greek Government and demanded prompt general elections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said tonight that radioactive full-out from last spring's Nevada tests was too slight to have killed cattle or raised blisters on human faces in New Mexico.

CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 11 -- The club system at St. Paul's School is going full blast. The Isthmians, Delphians and Old Hundreds have just started their annual intramural football campaign and already there are some surprising developments.
Marine stokers on city fireboats will receive a $550 yearly wage rise if a new contract negotiated yesterday is approved by the Board of Estimate. The stokers now receive $4,980 a year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Following are excerpts from an unofficial Soviet translation of the text of the statement made to the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee today by Vasily V. Kuznetsov, Soviet representative:

New York State carried forward yesterday the permanent financing of its 535-mile Thruway by selling $50,000,000 of state-guaranteed Thruway bonds at public bidding at an interest cost of 2.5164 per cent.

Garland Evans Hopkins, executive vice president of the American Friends of the Middle East, Inc., was rebuked yesterday for having said a wave of anti-Semitism in this country could be the consequence of activities in the Middle East by the Zionist Organization of America.

QUEBEC, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Emile Castonguay, president of the Canadian Daily Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that an increase in the price of newsprint at this time "would be unjustifiable."

Last night's play in the seventh round of the women's chess tournament failed to break the tie for first place between Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York and Milunka Lazarevic of Yugoslavia. Both won their matches, according to a report from Moscow. Their scores are 6 -- 1.

The young airman was flustered. "You see it's like this," he said. "I've got three days leave before I'm sent to Iceland -- so Sally flew in from Denver and we're going to get married -- tonight at 7 o'clock in the Presbyterian Church over on Fifth Avenue.

The Department of Welfare was guilty of a slip of the printing press in allowing a pamphlet on foster homes for children to ask applicants for information on their "race," Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy admitted yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen warned the free world today against compalcency. The President's special assistant on disarmament spoke at the twenty-eighth convention of the Future Farmers of America.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- The United States urged today that the United Nations trim its administrative and overhead costs. The United States, the largest contributor, pays a one-third share of the United Nations budget, which Secretary General Dag Hammar-skjold has estimated will come to $46,278,000 for 1956.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Israel asked the United States today to promise to help her to match whatever arms Egypt receives from Communist Czechoslovakia.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Stock prices moved narrowly today, with dullness among the industrial issues tending to continue.

LENTILS, marinated in French dressing, appear with delicious regularity in Italian antipasto and French hors d'oeuvre varies in restaurants. Those American home cooks who consider preparing the legumes too much bother now can make a quick version of this dish with a new import, canned baked lentils.

Three cents of the consumer's food dollar today goes into profit for the manufacturer and distributor, compared with 6 cents before World War II, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, said yesterday.

Futures prices on the New York exchanges were generally higher yesterday. Coffee, onions, cottonseed oil, rubber, potatoes, sugar, burlap and tin rose; cocoa, hides and zinc eased, and soybean oil, wool, lead and copper closed mixed.

The newly formed Du Mont Broadcasting Corporation announced yesterday it would enter the radio broadcasting business while expanding its telecasting interests. Changes in management were also disclosed yesterday, following a meeting of the directors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission published today the first detailed survey ever made of corporation pension funds. It showed these funds had built up $11,200,000,000 in assets by the end of last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Two leading medical authorities today suggested a "relatively rare" nerve operation and the long-term use of anticoagulent drugs as possible measures to help defend President Eisenhower against future heart attacks.

The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization announced yesterday the giving of the Kalinga Award to Dr. Augusto Pi-Suner, former Professor of Physiology at the University of Barcelona, Spain.
Coach Norm Daniels of Wesleyan has a novel complaint.

MURRAY INGBER, the 35-year-old man who is printing the subway timetables, worked his way up to that contract from printing ads on pencils, schoolbook covers, locality maps and matchbook covers, all handout items.

Imogene Coca has voluntarily given up a $100,000-a-year television contract with the National Broadcasting Company, but she expects to make more by appearing in night clubs and other areas of show business.

When the clothing industry's $2,000,000 advertising campaign swings into action to promote men's and boys' wear, newspapers will get a major share of the budget. This assurance was given yesterday by Willard W. Cole, president of Henry C. Lytton Co., Chicago department store, and president of the recently-formed American Institute of Men's and Boys' Wear, which will direct the campaign.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Air Force will enlarge its temporary academy at Lowry Air Force Base in Denver and limit classes to 300 cadets because of an unforeseen delay in the construction of the permanent academy near Colorado Springs.
Things are apt to be very dull in the financial district today, although the Big Board, the American Stock Exchange and brokerage houses will be open.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Marshall MacDuffie of New York resigned today as chief counsel of the Senate subcommittee on constitutional rights in a behind-the-scenes dispute over conduct of an inquiry into freedom of religion and free speech.

Fab-Knit Manufacturing Corp, Geraldine Fabrics Inc, McGee Knit Inc, Downen Knitwear Ltd, Glenora Casuals Inc, in 1407 Broadway; Lu-Pearce Fashions Ltd, Color Line, Ilsa Engle Originals, in 1431 Broadway -- A. M. J. M. Hirsch Co, brokers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Is a bowling ball bag a piece of luggage? Yes, the Internal Revenue Service says, if space is provided for shoes. Otherwise, no.

Today's new film is "The Deep Blue Sea," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama, based on the play by Terence Rattigan, with Vivien Leigh, Kenneth More, Eric Portman and Emlyn Williams, at the Plaza. Directed and produced by Anatole Litvak, in CinemaScope and color, the Alexander Korda presentation was adapted by Mr. Rattigan. Moira Lister, Arthur Hill and Dandy Nichols head the supporting cast.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 5 -- The nation's first supersonic bomber is slated to be powered by a new jet engine said to incorporate some remarkable innovations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that crops developed favorably in September to uphold previous estimates that the harvest would be the second highest of record.

A thousand representatives from all segments of the transportation industry will gather this morning in Boston for the tenth annual convention of the National Defense Transportation Association. The meeting will continue through Saturday morning at the Sheraton-Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today the national average support price for 1955-crop corn will be $1.58 a bushel. This is the same as the minimum level announced before planting time. Last year's average was $1.62.
A former President of Colombia criticized yesterday the readiness of United States business men and Governments to do business with Latin-American dictators.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -Experts agreed today that cuts in the level of cotton price supports and in the national cotton acreage allotment are probable for 1956.
MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- A Soviet economist has been denounced for painting too dark a picture of the capitalist economic situation.

Considerable publicity, in the form of news releases and paid advertisements, accompanied the announcement that provision was being made to reimburse persons injured by uninsured automobile drivers. There is no question that the new coverage is helpful.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Eighteen nations agreed yesterday that New York was too hectic a place for a body of international lawyers to deliberate at top efficiency.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -Economic conditions, the Federal budget, national security affairs and probably some politics will be on President Eisenhower's conference schedule in the next week or ten days.

The inclusion in Henry K. Norton's elaborate traffic plan, as explained in The Times for Oct. 4, of an elevated bus track demonstrates the desperate expedients to which traffic experts are driven in the effort to solve Manhattan's traffic problem by distinctly traffic expedients.
The Transit Authority rebuffed yesterday a proposal by two private bus companies to buy the agency's Manhattan surface lines.
Eighty-six per cent of the city's school children eligible received their second shots of Salk anti-polio vaccine, the Department of Health announced yesterday.
The City Council shelved yesterday a bill that would have placed a limited ban on the use of kerosene heaters in New York dwellings.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11 -- The Federal Maritime Board lashed back today at critics of national shipping policy who have been muttering about Federal inaction.

Plans for the alteration of the four-story dwelling at 367 West Forty-sixth Street have been disclosed in connection with the announcement of the sale of the property. Now vacant, the building formerly was occupied by Dr. John White for thirty-five years as his medical office and dwelling.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Britain had a surplus of 17,000,000 ($47,600,000) in her business dealings with the rest of the world during the first half of this year. But the accounting included $93,000,000 in defense aid from the United States.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 11 -- An American Legion convention committee report on the controversial subject of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was adopted in a closed session today.
The Johns-Manville Corporation announced yesterday three appointments to the new Johns-Manville pipe division, effective next Jan. 1.
BUFFALO, Oct. 11 -- Strong opposition arose from upstate judges today against a proposal to consolidate the state's entire judicial system into five levels of courts.
RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 11 -- A French spokesman said tonight the residency believed the rebellion in Morocco was being directed from Cairo in coordination with the revolt in Algeria.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey advocated today Federal assistance as a means of coordinating and accelerating a program for developing Delaware River resources.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The question of whether E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. illegally monopolized interstate commerce in cellophane was argued in the Supreme Court today.
A gift of $25,000 from John D. Rockefeller Jr. to expand camp facilities of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York was announced yesterday.
TRENTON, Oct. 11 -- New Jersey is carrying out the most extensive school construction program in its history.

Latest developments in equipment for heating and ventilating as well as in adequate wiring were the main features at the third National Electrical Industries Show in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, which opened yesterday.
DENVER, Oct. 11 -- President Eisenhower resumed an active role today in shaping United States foreign policy.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday rallied 26 to 54 points ($1.30 to $2.70 a bale) with the near months showing the most strength.

In an effort to reduce the huge cotton surplus (then approaching a full year's consumption requirements) the Government last fall called for a reduction of 14 per cent in the acreage to be planted, bringing it down to 18.1 million acres, the lowest it had been in seventy-five years.

"The McCormick Reaper," a book that took Norbert Lyons, a former newspaper reporter and editor, twenty-three years to write, has been scheduled for Nov. 21 publication by Exposition Press. In 1932, Mr. Lyons was asked by Henrietta McCormick-Goodhart, daughter of Cyrus McCormick's brother, Leander, to look into the question of who actually invented the machine that bore the family name.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 11 -- Rumanian Government spokesman said today all questions affecting United States-Rumanian relations were open to solution.

Donald Campbell, the English-man who has steered a speed boat faster than any other navigator, this week-end will transfer his tests from English lake country to the man-made Lake Mead, near Las Vegas, Nev.

Musical instruction for an increased number of students will be made possible as a result of a theatre party for the benefit of the Turtle Bay Music School on the evening of Oct. 25. The play chosen is "The Desk Set," a new comedy starring Shirley Booth at the Broadhurst Theatre.

NEW CASTLE, Ind., Oct. 11 -- A contingent of nonstriking employes returned to work at the struck foundry of the Perfect Circle Corporation today. In the background, the motors of four National Guard tanks roared.

The Presidential Committee on Athletics at Brooklyn College voted yesterday to cancel the football game between Brooklyn College and Norwich University, scheduled to be played at North-field, Vt., this Saturday.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 -Extensive Government credits for reconstruction and rehabilitation in Mexico's flood-damaged areas have been ordered set up immediately by President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines.

Musical instruction for an increased number of students will be made possible as a result of a theatre party for the benefit of the Turtle Bay Music School on the evening of Oct. 25. The play chosen is "The Desk Set," a new comedy starring Shirley Booth at the Broadhurst Theatre.

The Presidential Committee on Athletics at Brooklyn College voted yesterday to cancel the football game between Brooklyn College and Norwich University, scheduled to be played at North-field, Vt., this Saturday.

Knowing that your editorial opinion carries a great deal of weight and influence, I find it necessary to comment on your editorial of Oct. 4 "Russia in the Middle East."

PARIS, Oct. 11 --The defense forces of the North Atlantic alliance in Europe are lagging behind schedules in both quantity and quality, according to Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, their supreme commander. He made this statement today in a two-hour discourse to the defense ministers of the fifteen nations in the alliance.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Democratic Digest, official organ of the Democratic National Committee, had a new author today -- former President Herbert Hoover, often a prime target of the Digest.
Present-day counterparts of Christopher Columbus could not discover America without a ten-year immigration delay, Governor Harriman said last night.

NAGASAKI, Japan, Oct. 11 -- The waters where the Imperial Japanese Navy secretly trained crack units for the attack on Pearl Harbor will be drained to create new rice land for this war-impoverished country.
Members of the City Council amended the Administrative Code yesterday to give themselves the right to have official city seal shields on their private cars.
Alger Hiss' first article since his release from prison is being published this month by Pocket Books, Inc. Title: "Yalta: Modern American Myth."

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 11 (AP) -- A suit charging five officials and employes of the Thermoid Company with manipulating the company's books to avoid Federal taxes has been dismissed by Superior Court Judge C. Thomas Schettino.

Ceremonies marking the home state's interest in the screen version of "Oklahoma!" took place last night at the Rivoli Theatre. Later, a showing of the film was attended by Gov. Raymond Gary, other state officials, an estimated 300 visiting Oklahomans and other invited guests.

DALLAS, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Fred B. Lee, administrator of Civil Aeronautics, announced plans today for the nation's first all-radar airway. It will permit traffic control of planes by eye instead of by ear as is done now through radio.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 -- Arguments in the case of Jack Howard, labor reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle, who was held in contempt of court for refusing to divulge his sources of information, will be heard in Sacramento next Wednesday.

The Yankees purchased the contracts of three farm-club players yesterday. The new Bombers, who will join the club in training camp at St. Petersburg, Fla., next spring are Jerry Lumpe, a shortstop, and Jim O'Reilly, a left-handed pitcher, from Birmingham of the Southern Association, and Jim Coates, a right-handed pitcher from Binghamton of the Eastern League.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11 -- A walk-out, which began without notice at 11 o'clock last night, halted public transportation in St. Louis today. Streets were jammed with private automobiles and thousands of persons were late for work.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- Representatives of the Laotian Government and Communist rebels agreed today on principles for a cease-fire in Laos.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Argentina's Enrique Morea was the victim of the first big upset in the Pan-American tennis tournament today. He dropped a 6-3, 7-5 verdict to Roger Becker of England in a second-round match. Becker was unseeded. Morea was ranked No. 3.

Columbia Pictures Corporation has been named defendant in a $6,000,000 suit charging breach of agreement. The suit was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Joseph A. Fields and Jerome Chodorov, authors of the play "My Sister Eileen."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has entered into a production and releasing association with the newly formed producing unit named Jonathan Productions.

A Housing Authority patrolman at the large Brownsville housing development in Brooklyn was disarmed and shot early today by a suspected burglar. The assailant was in turn shot and killed by a probationary patrolman on his way home from the Police Academy.

The young man who climbed nimbly, one step ahead of the police, to the top of the scaffolding on the tower of Big Ben the other day must have been in an unhappy state. It would not be right to say confused, for that is the obvious comment and possibly offensive, but certainly he was unhappy.

Phillip P. Zipes has contracted to buy the five-story building containing forty-five apartments at 95 East Mosholu Parkway, in the Bronx. A client of Altieri Schwartz is the seller. This is the first sale of the building since it was built about twenty-five years ago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 --The famed Pinkerton Detective Agency will be the subject of a new television series to be filmed by the Desi Arnaz-Lucille Ball company, Desilu Productions.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 -Provisional President Eduardo Lonardi scrapped today General Peron's second five-year plan for Argentina's economic development.

Essex County Property, Inc., represented by Max Druz, attorney, has purchased the apartment building at 222 Chancellor Avenue in Newark, N. J., from J. G. Inga and Frank Abruzzo. The sale was negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

The Russian Ambassador to Egypt was laughing when he announced to reporters that "we will send economic missions, scientific missions, agricultural missions, meteorological missions and any other kind of mission you can imagine that will help these countries."
Demands for a national boycott of all products from the State of Mississippi were cheered yesterday at a rally protesting the recent murder there of 14-year-old Emmett Till, Chicago Negro boy.
Bernice P. Rogers, Deputy Housing Commissioner, complained yesterday that the courts were not enforcing the tenement safety laws.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Prices for grain and soybean futures were lower in early trading today, but there was a considerable expansion of commission buying on the setbacks. Shorts were inclined to take profits and even up pending the Government crop report after the close.
American participation in the equestrian events of the Olympic Games next year will be furthered by the proceeds of the Horse Show Ball to be held on Nov. 4 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The George Junior Republic, a miniature co-educational self-governing community for youth at Freeville, N. Y., will be the beneficiary of a dinner on the St. Regis Roof the evening of Oct. 26. Mrs. H. Huber Boscowitz is benefit chairman.

Shareholders of the Procter Gamble Company, at their annual meeting yesterday in Cincinnati, elected as directors Edwin J. Thomas, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, and Kelly Y. Siddall, administrative vice president of Procter Gamble.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 11 -- Iran announced today she would join the defense alliance of Turkey, Iraq, Pakistan and Britain. In doing so, the Government acted in defiance of the Soviet Union, which has sought to keep Iran neutral.

Shareholders of Detroit Steel Corporation in exercising their primary and additional subscription privileges to additional common stock at $12 a share sent in requests for more than double the 503,155 shares of common offered, Roger A. Yoder, treasurer, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Group Capt. Peter Townsend, friend of Princess Margaret, arrived in London fom Brussels tonight "just for a holiday."
Under the revised substitution rules, the two-platoon system is creeping back into college football.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery said today that the Western powers' present organization for war was unsuited to modern times.
The Rev. Father Trevor Huddleston in his letter in The New York Times of Oct. 3 in effect says that I lied about Stephen Ramasodi.

ATHENS, Oct. 12 -- The Government of Premier Constantin Karamanlis won a solid victory today in its first test in Parliament. The Deputies gave it a 200-to-77 vote of confidence, with two abstentions.
United States business men saw $202,360,000 go up in flames last year.

An expanded Imperial car line for 1956 was announced yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation. Four models, one more than last year will be on the market. The addition is a four-door hardtop model designated the Southampton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- The State Department warned today that several thousand Americans holding "dual citizenship" might be in danger of losing United States citizenship unless they re-affirmed their allegiance before Dec. 24.
Brown Brothers Harriman Co., the country's oldest and largest private banking firm, announced plans yesterday to admit Gerry Brothers Co., as a partnership, to limited partnership as of Nov. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- The Government today expanded the priority age group for Salk polio vaccine shots and recommended that pregnant women be included in the program.
BRIDGETON, N. J., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Pickets have been holding up construction of a new school near here for more than five months. Today, two dozen mothers picketed the pickets.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York suffered her first setback in the women's challengers' chess tournament last night, according to a report from Moscow. She lost to Mme. Kristina Holuj of Poland in the eighth round.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Reserve Officers Association assailed today the Army's reorganization of its Reserve structure. The association charged the Army was endangering the President's program for the standby forces.

City Administrator Luther Gulick plans to resign before the end of this year. It is expected that his successor in the $30,000-a-year post will be Charles F. Preusse, now serving as First Deputy City Administrator.
Ten Fordham runners finished in three separate dead heats before the first City College man crossed the line in a dual cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday.

West Palm Beach, Fla., has decided to bring to market an issue of $14,250,000 of water and sewer revenue bonds on Oct. 27. The obligations will be dated July 1, 1955, and will come due serially on July 1 from 1958 to 1995.
NANCY CIRILLO, violinist, made her New York recital debut in Town Hall yesterday afternoon as a winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award.
Former President Herbert Hoover will tell the story of his life in a one-hour film to be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, Nov. 6, at 2 P. M.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Cotton futures advanced here today on trade buying and short covering, induced by reports that farmers were putting their cotton into the government loan because of low commercial prices.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- The Thor Corporation announced today it had signed agreements to sell its manufacturing plants in suburban Cicero and in Bloomington, Ill., for a total of more than $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Maryland and Virginia Milk Producers Association, the Maryland Cooperative Milk Producers, Inc., and Chestnut Farms-Chevy Chase Dairy Company were indicted today for alleged violations of the anti-trust laws.

The formation of a conciliation panel to resolve landlord-tenant disputes was announced jointly yesterday by State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

WHEN buying a dishwasher, the labor-saving features should be considered, says Mrs. Doris Anderson, extension home management specialist of Rutgers University. She adds that the style selected and where it is placed in the kitchen have some bearing on its efficiency.

Plans have been made at recent meetings at the Pierre for the bazaar and Christmas sale for the benefit of the philanthropic enterprises of the Central Presbyterian Church. The event will be held on Nov. 3 and 4 in the church house at Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.
RENATO BONACINI, violinist, who has delighted listeners at earlier hearings here, gave a somewhat disappointing account of himself at Town Hall last night.
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Oct. 12 -- The Illinois Federation of Labor, in convention here, barred reporters and photographers of four city dailies from the convention floor yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 12 -- Brazil's Communists can be counted among the winners in the Oct. 3 Presidential election.
The recent ably written letter of Philip H. Bagby on representation abroad prompts me to comment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Interior Department made public today an opinion by the Attorney General that the Government must sell Federal power to cooperatives or other preferred public agencies making competing offers with private utilities.

The American public school system was described yesterday as "undoubtedly the best and most modern in the world." The comment was made by the leader of a group of Yugoslav educators here to study primary, secondary and vocational education as part of a plan to decentralize Yugoslavia's educational system.
Registration of voters in the city picked up somewhat yesterday as 230,434 more men and women became eligible to participate in the Nov. 8 general election.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- High prices have prevented coffee consumption from keeping pace with the national growth, the coffee industry was told today.

Anglo-American relations are made and held firm by men like Hector McNeil, who work below the summit and carry the main burdens. That period between 1946 and 1949, when McNeil was Minister of State under Ernest Bevin and represented Britain at the United Nations, was a stretch of friendship and of brilliance.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 12 -- The Propeller Club of the United States today elected Raymond M. Hicks of New York for a second term as president. Mr. Hicks is executive vice president of the United States Lines.

Three apartment houses, each accommodating sixteen families, at 543, 553 and 557 Forty-sixth Street in Brooklyn, have been sold by the Kalgo Realty Corporation to the Minc Realty Corporation. The combined property, on plot 138 by 100 feet, has an assessed valuation of $123,000.

The pace of financing by utilities is lagging far behind the 1954 rate. That is disclosed by the latest monthly survey issued by Ebasco Services, Inc., based on figures compiled by the Edison Electric Institute. Total financing in the first nine months amounted to $1,084,905,000, against $1,939,074,000 in the similar period last year.

Gray was the fashion for the $62,000 Ladies Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Christopher T. Chenery's Manotick, the only one of that color in the list of fifteen fillies and mares participating in the mile and a half test, was the surprise winner, by a head over the Wheatley Stable's Misty Morn.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Texas Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that state funds could be spent for schools where Negro and white students were mingled.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 13 -- Japanese Socialists -- divided for four years over the question whether their country should face East or West -- gathered this afternoon to form ranks anew as a united party.
The ball and roller bearing industry, which got its big start with the bicycle, is now spinning along at an approximate $600,000,O00-a-year clip.
MIAMI, Oct. 12 -- The American Legion's national convention overwhelmingly denounced by voice vote today the activities of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

PERHAPS the first television program to be labeled "For Adults Only," with viewers told to send their youngsters into another room, was presented last night at 9 o'clock over WPIX. Sensationalism under the guise of helpful education now has gone about as far as it can on TV.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- A series of criticisms were uttered today by Russian housing officials on an inspection tour of a Chicago housing authority project under construction on the city's West Side.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 12 -- The world touring company of "Porgy and Bess" opened a two-week engagement here last night to a "bravoing" audience.

When the Manhattan telephone directory arrived the other day a newly minted suburbanite looked for a name that he knew would not be there. He was succumbing to an old habit -- checking his name, address and telephone number, his formal carte d'itentite among the millions of unknown people.

Even as brilliant and dedicated a public servant as Robert Moses must have his limitations, and I have long suspected one is that while he would undoubtedly concede that only God can make a tree, he has never quite understood why the Deity would bother to do so.
Dr. Roger M. Bellows has been named director of personnel research and communications at the General Foods Corporation.
"WE'RE talkin' in terms of latitude," says Mr. Robert Heaney of Scottish Woollen Mills, when he discusses the differences in coloring fabrics for the British and American markets.
Stocks, which put on the brakes Tuesday at the end of a four-day decline, turned on the power yesterday and charged upward in the third best advance of 1955.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas today proposed a program for increasing farm income.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Members of the bench and bar in the Rochester area appeared in solid opposition today to proposals for a sweeping reorganization of the state's court system.
Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, made a spirited defense yesterday of United States private investment in Latin America. He spoke at a conference on hemisphere problems.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey labeled Adlai E. Stevenson today as "the top Democratic candidate" for the Presidency, at least now.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- The Secretary General of the United Nations found today that he had thrust his hand into a hornets' nest.
An anonymous telephone call and the presence of a foot patrolman helped to avert a gang battle on the lower East Side last night. Six teen-agers preparing for a fight were arrested.

The political face of the Middle East has changed considerably as a result of Iran's decision to join Turkey, Pakistan, Iraq and Britain in a five-nation alliance that closes the Iranian gap in the "northern defense tier" against possible Soviet aggression in that area.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Eisenhower Cabinet is reported split over the farm prices issues.

Directors of the Hammond Organ Company proposed yesterday a 100 per cent stock distribution and declared an extra cash dividend of 35 cents and the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents. All three distributions are payable Dec. 10.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 12 -- After wrecking eight classrooms at Public School 25, Zabriski Street and Hudson Boulevard, here this afternoon vandals celebrated Fire Prevention Week by starting a two-alarm fire in the school building.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office has advised a go-slow policy on negotiating a settlement of claims under the now defunct Dixon-Yates power contract.

Today's new film is "Trial," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama, at the Radio City Music Hall. The cast is headed by Glenn Ford, Dorothy McGuire, Arthur Kennedy, John Hodiak, Katy Jurado, Rafael Campos and Juano Hernandez. Charles Schnee produced and Mark Robson directed from Don M. Mankiewicz' adaptation of his novel.
New York retailers took yesterday's unseasonably warm weather in stride and posted substantial gains in their Columbus Day sales.
From all five boroughs, New Yorkers converged on Fifth Avenue yesterday from Forty-fourth Street to Eighty-fourth Street for the annual Columbus Day parade.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 12 -- West Germany's first report to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on its economic and financial ability to arm has been turned back.
A 33-year-old woman was arrested yesterday after fighting the police for nearly twenty minutes in a Madison Avenue shop. The police say she formed a shoplifting team with her 9-year-old son.

The difficulties with Dr. Louis B. Sohn's proposal, in his letter published Oct. 5, that the General Assembly of the United Nations should ask the International Court of Justice for an opinion on the question of jurisdiction are twofold. It presupposes that a genuine issue requiring legal construction is present and it suggests that an expedient -- delay merely for purposes of delay -- serves a proper or useful purpose at this juncture.
Mayor Wagner will make a two-day inspection of the Croton, Catskill and Delaware watersheds upstate today and tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- The country is in for "another dose of inflation," F. W. Hubbell, outgoing president of the American Life Convention, said today at its fiftieth anniversary meeting here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A University of Chicago Law School professor said today that the school intended to continue planting secret microphones in jury rooms.
A drastic revision of the Board of Education's Bureau of Child Guidance is proposed in a two-year study made public yesterday.
A man of habit, Harry S. Truman took a walk before breakfast again yesterday.
Signorina Eugenia Inc. women's apparel and shoes imported from Italy, store in 430 Park Ave -- William A. White Sons, brokers.
ALBANY, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits holds that labor unions need not register with the Social Welfare Department to solicit strike funds.

AN important loan exhibition of thirty-four old master and modern paintings opening today at the E. A. Silberman Galleries celebrates two events. The pictures are being shown for the benefit of the Spanish Institute's Research Fund of Art and Archaeology, and the gallery opens new quarters at 1014 Madison Avenue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12 -- The nation's scientific attack force is suffering from an acute shortage of "flag officers," Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said today.
ST. PAUL, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Warren E. Burger, an Assistant United States Attorney General said today a research project into jury deliberations contemplated "eavesdropping on 500 to 1,000 juries."
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 12 -- The Paraguayan Government today ordered Juan D. Peron interned in Villarica in central Paraguay.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, reported to top Administration officials today on his talk with President Eisenhower in Denver.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 12 -- Practical politicians of the Labor party defeated today an amendment to a resolution that would have committed the party to support Moscow's policy on Germany at the Geneva conference this month.
BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- Automation on American railroads was predicted here today by Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

CAIRO, Oct. 12 -- Eric A. Johnston, President Eisenhower's special ambassador to the Middle East flew to Israel today. A last-minute conference that he held with Arab leaders here failed to dissuade them from deferring action on a $200,000,000 project to irrigate both Arab and Israeli lands with Jordan River waters.

JACK KRAMER is a big, handsome chap with charm, personality, persuasiveness -- and money. The combination is rather close to being unbeatable. Hence it hardly was a surprise when Tony Trabert succumbed to Big Jake's blandishments and deserted the amateur tennis ranks to become a professional. Trabert has all of the Kramer qualities except one, money. And this is a good way of remedying that deficiency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- The appointment of Lieut. Gen. Clyde D. Eddleman to be army deputy chief of staff for plans was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Industry complaints of injustices and confusion in the operation of Federal excise taxes mounted today before a Congressional panel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Britain, France and the United States have yet to agree on a tactical plan for persuading the Soviet Union to acquiesce in unifying Germany when their foreign ministers meet in Geneva.

A real estate dealer from Maywood, Ill., was showered with more gifts yesterday at La Guardia Airport than a lucky contestant on most television give-away programs.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada tonight applied anothre brake on credit, increasing its interest tolls on loans to chartered banks by one-quarter of 1 per cent to an all-time high of 2 1/4 per cent.
LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R., Oct. 12 -- "There come your English uncles," a Russian told his small son today as the British carrier Triumph glided into Leningrad Harbor.
UNITED NATIONS N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Poland called on the members of the United Nations today to support her election to the Security Council in accordance with the "spirit of Geneva."

The urgent -- not to say desperate -- need for new school construction in this city is underlined by Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the Board of Education's building committee, in proposing a 50 per cent increase in expenditures for this purpose during the next seven years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Corn and soybeans declined today following the Government's October crop forecasts of late yesterday afternoon. Its estimate was a little higher than had been expected for both these crops.
Three hundred persons attended a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of Spain and her contribution to the discovery and independence of the United States.

A T-formation quarterback is supposed to think, as well as to pass, fake, handle the ball and occasionally run. Cornell's Billy DeGraaf displayed all these abilities in abundance against Harvard last Saturday and earned the designation as The Associated Press Back of the Week.

Stanley Weingast has joined the staff of Phillip P. Zipes, realty operator and investor of the Bronx. Since 1950 he had been with the Louis Weingast Realty Company, Berley Co., Inc., and represented New York realty interests on the Pacific Coast.

DENVER, Oct. 12 -- President Eisenhower's doctors approved today his second working conference with a key Administration leader since his heart attack. On Saturday the President will meet with George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, one of his most trusted and influential advisers.
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The French Government offered Parliament today a small down payment on a new Algerian policy, with the badance payable within thirty days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Public Housing Commissioner Charles E. Slusser announced today the priorities under which 45,000 units of Federal low-rent public housing would be allocated by next summer.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 12 -- Governor Harriman will urge the Defense Department to channel more contracts to Long Island's aircraft industry as a temporary emergency measure to counteract increasing layoffs.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- The United States took pains today to scotch a belief here that political strings or conditions were attached to economic aid grants for underdeveloped countries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Further evidence that the National Broadcasting Company sees its future in color terms can be found in the network's current underwriting of two color pilot films, "The Further Adventures of Tom Sawyer" and "Johnny Moccasin."

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Curry, a 100-to-6 shot, took the lead at the halfway mark today on the mist-shrouded Newmarket track and galloped to a three-length victory in the Cesarewitch Stakes.

EXCEPT for a slightly bumpy landing at the end, Ernest Pendrell's "Obsession" provided a high level of TV entertainment last night on Channel 2. The tightly knit story of discord in suburbia gave the star, Phyllis Thaxter, a chance to run the gamut of emotions in a way that held the viewer's attention for the entire hour. Philip Abbott and Neva Patterson gave able seconding performances.

Fires caused by the use of kerosene heaters have killed more than one hundred people in New York City in the past five years. Already this year they have taken no less than twenty-three lives -- and there are still months of cold weather to come. Fire Commissioner Cavanagh thinks that from fifteen to twenty more people are doomed to die from this grisly menace during the next twelve months.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 -- The appearance of Negroes in America's major opera companies is not yet a commonplace thing, but the day is not far off when it will require only routine notice. Mattiwilda Dobbs became a member of the San Francisco Opera in good standing last night, and the fact that she happened to be the first Negro to sing with this group was taken in stride by nearly everyone in the audience.

DENVER, Oct. 12 -- Following is the text of a letter from President Eisenhower to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin on the matter of exchanging information about military establishments and permitting reciprocal aerial inspection between the Soviet Union and the United States, as made public today:
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Admiral Earl Mountbatten of Burma, First Sea Lord, disclosed tonight that Britain was starting to design her own atomic-powered engines for submarines and other warships.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 12 (UP) -- Willie Hartack, the nation's leading rider, booted the Brookfield Farm's Imagem to a three-quarter-length triumph today in the $30,350 Benjamin Franklin Handicap at Garden State Park.

A new ballet by Zachary Solov, called "Soiree, will be presented by the Metropolitan Opera for the first time on Dec. 23. It will be part of a double bill with the revival of Donizetti's opera "Don Pasquale."

MUNICH, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Vladimir Nikolai Stogov sent Russia away in front in the world weight-lifting championships tonight by winning the bantam-weight title with a world record lift of 335 kilograms (737 pounds).

NEW HAVEN, Con..., Oct. 12 -- Jordan Olivar isn't stampeded easily. The fastest set of backs in the Ivy group, if not in the East, will go into action for Cornell against Yale in the Bowl Saturday. The game may ultimately decide the league champion.
RITA GAM played the role of a truck driver's wife in "Trucks Welcome," the drama presented last night from 9 to 10 o'clock on Channel 4.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 -- Motorists' dreams of a superhighway network from Maine to Florida soon were shattered today by one of the country's foremost engineering consultants.
Three city links in the city-state-Federal arterial highway system will be opened officially Nov. 5, Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, announced yesterday.
Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff criticized last night those who avoid their religious affiliations because they belong to minority groups.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 12 -- The reform plan agreed on by Moroccan nationalists and the French Government in August will be insufficient to restore peace if it is not executed "very soon," Mohammed Lyazidi said here today.
MIAMI, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Ralph (Tiger) Jones' harder punching earned him a unanimous ten-round decision over Al Andrews of Superior, Wis., tonight in their TV-radio fight at Dinner Key Auditorium.

WHEN a President of the United States leaves Washington, even on a short trip, many special operations and people are set in motion. But when he travels overseas under wartime conditions, it is a vast undertaking.

A critical study of Theodore Dreiser and his work is planned for Nov. 8 publication by Indiana University Press, entitled "The Stature of Theodore Dreiser." Edited by Alfred Kazin and Charles Shapiro, the volume includes critical essays, reminiscences of Dreiser by Edgar Lee Masters, Ludwig Lewisohn, Ford Madox Ford and James T. Farrell, and studies by Malcolm Cowley, F. O. Matthiessen and Eliseo Vivas.

Japan's thriving export industry will display a wide range of first-quality products in an exhibit opening Monday at the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue. The show, which is open to the public, has been organized as a non-profit presentation of Japanese merchandise selected as most suitable for world markets. It will continue until Nov. 4.

MILK provides the base for many delicious drinks that are particularly timely now. After school, hungry youngsters might like hot cocoa spiced with nutmeg, or a pretty pink milk shake flavored with peppermint and topped with meringue. A hot almond eggnog might be served to grown-ups just returned from a football game on a chilly Saturday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- A United Nations body again has condemned the racial separation, or apartheid, policies in South Africa.

ALWAYS in demand with busy home cooks are dishes that can be prepared in a hurry. Of course, there is no limit to the slapdash concoctions that can be readied with no more than a twist of the can opener and a fast heating in the skillet. But the conscientious cook wants quick dishes that show she has done at least a little work to make them appetizingly distinctive.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer turned to television again today for another projected film story.

PAWLING, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Jack Karpoe, head football coach at Trinity-Pawling School, denies he is planning an atomic-type attack against Hopkins Grammar when his eleven meets the Connecticut school at New Haven next Saturday.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Oct. 12 -- A second oil-producing formation was struck today at Haletz in the same hole where the first Israeli "black gold" was discovered twenty days ago.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Oct. 12 -- An improved balloon that can rise straighter and faster than older types and therefore better collect weather data has been produced by the Army Signal Corps.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct 12 (UP) -- The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association paid tribute today to the memories of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, first vice president and general manager of The New York Times, and Sidney F. Harris, Kansas and Iowa publisher.

During the year from July 1, 1954, to June 30, 1955, the four major institutions of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences -- the Brooklyn Museum, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Children's Museum and the Brooklyn Academy of Music -- attracted about 2,250,000 persons to the use of their facilities.
George Axelrod's new comedy, "Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?" which pokes fun at the delusion of success in Hollywood, opens tonight at the Belasco Theatre at 7:45 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today to block rate reductions proposed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in connection with the Air Force's SAGE radar warning project. The name of the project is Semi-Automatic Ground Environment System.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy outlined today some of the information that initiated a Congressional investigation of subversion and espionage in defense plants around Boston in 1953 and 1954.

A one-story taxpayer on plot 40 by 100 feet at 53-24 Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens, has been purchased by Murray Hill Estates, Inc. The property is occupied under lease by the American Greeting Card Company of Cleveland, Ohio.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Following is the text of a statement made by Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov to the Iranian Charge d'Affaires, Abolhatem Etesami, protesting against Iran's adherence to the Turkish-Iraqi-Pakistani alliance:
Eugene Mori and Walter H. Donovan, president and executive vice president, respectively, of Garden State Park at Camden, N. J., are the members of one of the top teams in thoroughbred horse racing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Carmine DeSapio, New York County Democratic leader, arrived here by plane today to sound out the rank and file of his party about their preference for a Presidential nominee.
