Members of the New York Times unit of the Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. O., voted yesterday against arbitrating the dismissal of Melvin L. Barnet, former copy editor on The Times.
Representatives of city departments and 130,000 civil service workers will have an opportunity today to set forth their ideas on proposed new rules governing vacations and sick leave.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Fred Hutchinson and Frank Lane joined forces today as field and office bosses of the St. Louis Cardinals and set their sights on an "ultimate" pennant for the club.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 12 -- On the eve of the return of David Ben-Gurion to the Premiership, political pressure has mounted here for a reappraisal of the Government's foreign and security policies.

The Mead Corporation, manufacturer of paper, paperboard and wood pulp, yesterday reported a 58 per cent increase in earnings for the forty weeks ended Oct. 2. Directors at the same time voted to raise the dividend 10 cents quarterly and declared a 2 1/2 per cent dividend in stock, both payable Dec. 1.

THESE Indian summer days are not likely to remind a man that the duck season is imminent, but that is the fact. Except for Long Island, it will begin for New York State on Saturday. Long Island's season will start Oct. 29.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Supreme Court of Texas, which long has been a distinguished tribunal, merely reminded the citizens of an established fact in its ruling today that state funds may not be denied to desegregated public schools. This fact is that no State Constitution or statute remains valid that controverts the latest interpretation by the Supreme Court in Washington of the Constitution of the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Virtually, all leading industrials appreciated sharply today as strength in Wall Street encouraged bargain hunters. Demand which, for a week or more, has centered on British Government securities, switched to industrials and some of the issues that sustained biggest losses in the last few days scored the greatest gain.

Statistics of the United Service Organizations for the last year are impressive. But statistics can be cold as winter in Alaska. So picture a company of tense, weary men suddenly transformed into howling, laughing boys when you read that U. S. O.-Camp Shows played to audiences totaling three million G. I.'s.

There are two things for the intelligent citizen to do this week. One is to register to vote. The other is to enroll in a political party at the time of registration. So far as registration is concerned, there is no disagreement. Everyone thinks it is a good idea.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 -- Five hundred white egrets were found dead today. The magnificently plumed birds have been protected by Federal law for nearly half a century.

DENVER, Oct. 12 -- President Eisenhower has offered conditionally to permit Soviet inspection of United States key military concentration points. The condition involved is Soviet acceptance of the President's plan for exchanging military blue-prints and aerial inspection rights.

GENEVA, Oct. 12 -- The results of the latest East-West trade consultations, which ended here this morning, were "not spectacular." This characterization was given by Gunnar Myrdal, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, under whose auspices the discussions were held.

The annual conference of the Labor party this week at Margate is of capital importance to the British Socialists. It is presumably the last at which the former Prime Minister, Clement Attlee, will be the head of the party and the Leader of Her Majesty's Opposition in Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The State Department said today it had indications that the Soviet bloc might be willing to supply arms to Israel as well as to the Arab states. An Israeli Embassy spokesman said that the embassy was aware of these indications but that no Communist state had made any formal approach.
NEW CASTLE, Ind., Oct. 12 -- Production of piston ring castings was resumed today at the Perfect Circle Corporation's foundry here. This was the first resumption of work since the riot of a week ago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Managing director Walter Wolfner of the Chicago Cardinals said today the club never again would play the Forty-niners in San Francisco unless scheduled by the National Football League.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The United States and India have begun private consultations aimed at bringing a resolution on atomic radiation before the General Assembly.
BETWEEN weathered tenements at 422 and 424 West Forty-sixth Street, east of Tenth Avenue, stands a high wrought-iron gate. It gives into a narrow alley that runs back thirty feet.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Consumers must buy $40,000,000,000 more goods and services in 1956 than were sold in 1954 if a continued expansion in the country's economy is to be assured, Arno H. Johnson, vice president and research director of J. Walter Thompson Company, said today.
Governor Harriman and his consumer counsel, Dr. Persia Campbell, focused attention yesterday on gyps in the installment sales field.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Forty-four railroads were involved in a $173,263 suit today because a station in Iowa has no tracks.

The Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association announced the election of W. F. Rockwell Jr. as its new president and H. Leigh Whitelaw as executive vice president, a newly created post. The twentieth annual meeting of G. A. M. A. opened yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif.

Governor Harriman, a leading possibility for the Democratic nomination for President, announced yesterday what amounted to his economic platform for expanding production and maintaining national prosperity.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation said yesterday that the main effect of the one-way traffic rule on Seventh and Eighth Avenues had been to "inundate" Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) with trucks.

It will necessarily take a bit of planning to carry the Olympic torch from the original site in Greece to Melbourne, Australia, for the traditional games that will be held there from Nov. 22 to Dec. 8, 1956. Lighted on the plains of Olympia in Greece from a fire set by the sun's rays, the torch will be carried almost 12,000 miles to light the flame at Melbourne.

Lawrence D. Maran, real estate operator, has contracted to purchase the building at 1860-62 Lexington Avenue, near 116th Street, containing four stores and sixteen apartments. The seller is the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank as executor of the estate of Jeanette Forsheim, who had acquired the property in 1905.
An Academy for Liberal Judaism has been established here under the direction of Rabbi Louis I. Newman of Congregation Redeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.
The State of Colorado has tentatively designated Dec. 6 for the sale of $8,000,000 highway construction warrants due serially over fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Minneapolis and St. Louis Railroad Company today filed a competitive application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to buy the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization announced today that it was willing to grant special rapid tax write-off privileges for builders of twenty-five roll-on, roll-off ships.
WASHINGTON Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today ordered another 6,000,000 pounds of nickel diverted to industry to relieve a persistent shortage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Federal Court of Appeals affirmed today the conviction of four Puerto Rican terrorists who shot up the House of Representatives on March 1, 1954. Five members of the House were wounded. All recovered.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 13 -- The newspaper El Lider opened a strong campaign today against the return of La Prensa to its former owners.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Things are humming these days at Canterbury School. All hands, including the head football coach, Roger Des Roches, have been pitching in to get the school's new athletic field and ice hockey rink in shape.
All but three of the candidates running for judicial office in New York County this fall were rated as qualified last week by the New York County Lawyers Association.

Most of the advertising copy linked to Christmas giving is on specific products, suggesting what should be given to business associates, customers, clients, friends and families. Institutional advertising at the Christmas season is something of an exception.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Commonwealth Edison Company, Chicago, has expanded its construction program and increased projected expenditure on it to $600,000,000 in the five years, 1955 through 1959.

Under the chairmanship of Harrison Tweed, the Temporary Commission on the Courts has embarked on a series of ten public hearings on its plan to reorganize the courts of New York. These are being held in various parts of the state, and will end with sessions in Brooklyn and Manhattan on Oct. 24 and 26.
If the apparel industry is to arrest the decline in its share of the consumer dollar, man-made fibers must be properly and aggressively promoted, a fabric styling clinio was told yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- A move to revive the project for a federal union of Western Europe was announced today by Jean Monnet. It was M. Monnet who devised and long headed the European Coal and Steel Community.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Group Capt. Peter Townsend, British air attache in Brussels, visited Clarence House, the residence of Princess Margaret, for two hours this evening.

Members of the junior committee for the theatre benefit for the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, Inc., have been holding a series of luncheon meetings at the Plaza to discuss plans for the event.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The constitutional right of the military forces to arrest and try a discharged soldier while in civilian life for a crime committed while in the service was argued in the Supreme Court today.
Two and two don't seem to make four in Detroit.
The showers and hamburgers are hot. That's why the Seoul U. S. O. is the most attractive spot in Korea for American servicemen. Snow lies three feet deep in northern Korea valleys during the winter.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Defense Department today issued a draft call for 18,000 men in December -- 8,000 for the Army and the remainder for the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Two former agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today they would start a drive next week to raise $4,000,000 to set up a comprehensive "public library" of alleged subversives.

DENVER, Oct. 13 -- A blue golf cap and a waving arm were briefly visible today over the eighth - floor sun - porch railing at Fitzsimons Army Hospital. President Eisenhower, in a happy mood on the eve of his sixty-fifth birthday, was propped up in bed, gazing over the sun-deck parapet, when he waved his arm for the first time at patients on the ground eight floors below him.
The first New York performance of Sir William Walton's "Troilus and Cressida" will be given next Friday evening by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center.

Pressure of Hollywood commitments is apt to prevent Jean Simmons from starring in Paul Osborn's "Olympian comedy," which has just acquired the title of "Maiden Voyage." This unexpected development was confirmed yesterday by Bert Allenberg, the star's representative.
YONKERS, Oct. 13 -- Kimberly Kid, a 5-year-old horse owned by Leonard J. Buck's Allwood Stable of Far Hills, N. J., won the $29,000 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Southwestern Industrial Electronics Company, Houston, Tex., announced yesterday completion of negotiations for a merger with Dresser Industries, Inc. The purchase price was not disclosed, but it was understood to include cash and Dresser stock.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 -- Mexico was re-examining her position regarding Spain today following a declaration in the Senate here yesterday that the nation could not endorse Spain's entrance in the United Nations.
These recently published leaflets may be of interest to homemakers:
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 13 (AP) -- A delay in presenting a proposed plan for reorganization of the state's judicial system to the State Legislature was urged today at a public hearing on the proposal.

The advertising account of the Coca-Cola Company of Atlanta, parent concern of all the Coca-Cola bottlers, is leaving the D'Arcy Advertising Company after an association of forty-nine years. The business involves direct billings in excess of $10,000,000, plus at least $5,000,000 more in cooperative advertising, point-of-purchase display materials and other items.

Commentaries by two prominent members of the Democratic party are listed by Harper for publication soon. On Nov. 16 it will publish Dean Acheson's "A Democrat Looks at His Party." The former Secretary of State says about his book: "It is not an apologia, nor a party pamphlet, nor a history.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The major league draft will be held here Nov. 28, and the minor league draft the next two days, George M. Trautman, the president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, said today.
NEW CASTLE, Ind., Oct. 13 -- An extended period of martial law, tough-sounding but gently applied to date, appeared today to be in prospect for this section of eastern Indiana.
A series of proposals put forward by the International Longshoremen's Association to bring "peace and stability in the Port of New York" was dismissed yesterday by the Waterfront Commission.
Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer Pictures has decided to talk about itself less and with more modesty in a television program that it produces for the American Broadcasting Company.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday orders for forty-five jet-propelled airliners costing $269,000,000. The two-model fleet will bring this country its first jet transport service starting in December, 1958.
City Administrator Luther Gulick said yesterday that he expected Mayor Wagner to "relieve" him of his assignment by the end of this year.
American automobile exporters were told yesterday not to get excited about the possibility of expanding sales to Communist countries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The United States National Commission for UNESCO expressed "profound regret" today at the Legion resolution.

Thomas J. Curran said yesterday that New York County's delegation to next year's Republican national convention would back former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the Presidential nomination if Mr. Dewey wanted it.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, broke officially today with Ngo Dinh Diem, Premier of South Vietnam.
MARGATE, England, Oct. 13 -- The bitter, almost violent heckling of a trade union official by Bevanites today symbolizes the disunity that has frustrated progress at the Labor party conference.

VILLA SANJURJO, Spanish Morocco, Oct. 12 -- Hundreds of Berbers, some of whom were wounded fighting the French in the Riff region, have fled to this area. About 400 families, or more than 2,000 Moroccans, have left their homes in what they call the "triangle of death" of Aknoul, Boured and Tizi Ouzli.
THE thrifty housewife can avail herself this week-end of an attractively priced Sunday roast as well as vegetable and fruit to complete the meal.
"OUTSIDE U. S. A.," Channel 7's recently inaugurated study of news-in-depth under the tutelage of Quincy Howe, took up the problems of Egypt and Israel last night.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 13 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano indicated today that the Bonn Government feared a relaxation of East-West tensions might result in a "Munich" agreement at the expense of German reunification.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- The political activities of Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, Harvard president, during the Wisconsin Senatorial campaign of 1952 became part of the record today in a contempt trial in Federal District Court.
PARIS, Friday, Oct. 14 -- Premier Edgar Faure put the fate of his Government in the balance early today in an effort to win parliamentary acceptance for his program of moderate reform in Algeria.

WOMEN in the last fifty years have proved, through going out and earning, that they have a right to a working career. Young women have the right, that is. For women of mature years who try to enter the labor market for the first time, or to re-enter it after an absence, often are rebuffed.
A discouraging picture of conditions in the city's high schools was presented to members of the Board of Education yesterday.
CAIRO, Oct. 13 -- A Soviet offer to help finance the projected High Dam near Aswan has been confirmed by two high Egyptian Government officials.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee voted today for prompt discussion of self-determination as a "human right."

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Mary Ann Mitchell, 16, of San Leandro, Calif., upset the top-seeded Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., in the Pan-American tennis tournament today. The score was 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Sherman Adams, The Assistant to the President, was asked by investigating Democrats today for details of Executive Branch conferences on a controversial proposal for sale of federal power to the Georgia Power Company.

The executive board of the New York Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., voted last night to take to arbitration the discharges of Melvin L. Barnet, a New York Times copy editor, and David Gordon, a Daily News reporter.
ROME, Oct. 13 -- Pope Pius XII urged world statesmen today to "try new ways" to rid the human race of the "recurrent nightmares of war."

A decline of 260,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies amounted to 151,006,000 barrels, compared with 151,266,000 a week earlier and 151,550,000 a year ago.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The United States and Britain are expected to increase arms supplies to Iran and Iraq soon to counter Soviet moves in the Middle East.

IT isn't difficult to determine which of tomorrow's games will most interest countless millions of football fans throughout the nation. The eye-catcher is the engagement between Notre Dame and Michigan State. The reason? That's simple. This is the nationally televised offering for the day and will command the biggest audience that the season yet has drawn.

A program almost entirely of premieres was presented in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by the Composers Group of New York City. The only work of the evening that had been heard publicly before was Charles Haubiel's 'Cello Sonata, which dates from 1944.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce gave a cautious "yes" today in answer to the question of whether the economy can be made depression-proof.
Loans to business by leading New York City Banks declined $48,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the first weekly decline in five weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported.

In the last paragraph of the installment of Mr. Truman's Memoirs, appearing in the Oct. 7 issue of The New York Times, the former President referred to Canada as one of the countries whose soldiers were equipped "by Lend-Lease means" during Word War II.

The regional Red Cross will collect blood today from Naval and civilian personnel at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn. Blood will be collected also at the National Association of Manufacturers, 2 East Forty-eighth Street; St. Anastasia's Roman Catholic Church, 245-60 Northern Boulevard, Douglaston, Queens, and from residents of Cold Springs, N. Y., at the Haldane Central School there.

Herb Rich and Pat Knight, the Giants' regular defensive backs, who have seen limited action in the first three games, will be in the line-up when the New Yorkers play the Chicago Cardinals in their National Football League home opener at the Polo Grounds Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Western diplomats said today the Western powers would seek a four-power agreement on freedom of information and communications when the Big Four foreign ministers met in Geneva later this month.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Arthur Lynch of Winged Foot and James Weldon of Rochester shared the lead in the New York State Golf Association's senior fall tournament today.
Thank you for your editorial on registering for the coming election and in particular for pointing out so vividly that voting is a privilege which too many citizens, unfortunately, hold lightly.

Net investment assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation as of Sept. 30 slipped slightly from the record high at the end of the first half, Francis F. Randolph, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

Some recent letters published on this page have expressed timely concern over the status and morale of our Foreign Service staff. When the role of the United States in world affairs today is considered, and when one stops to think of the part that our Foreign Service staff plays in the conduct of American policy, it is a wonder that more attention is not called to this vital segment of our Government.
The crime situation in New York is "still bad," although improved in the last two years, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said last night.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Eddie Lopat's major league pitching career, which covered twelve years, including five as a mainstay of pennant-winning New York Yankee teams, appeared over today with his unconditional release by the Baltimore Orioles.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved irregularly, closing 17 points up to 10 points down.
THE 1955 version of the Carnegie Institute's long series of international exhibitions of painting, which began in 1896, opened last evening with a preview and reception.

After a session of fairly general gains, stocks receded in the last ninety minutes of yesterday's market and the close was irregularly lower. Aircrafts and some of the oils and chemicals held on to good gains but steels and motors were weak.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Two Senators investigating a University of Chicago Law School "jury-bugging" project said today that the only way to stop such incidents in the future was to make it a crime to "eavesdrop" on jury deliberations or record them in any way. They issued a joint statement at the end of two days of hearings by the Internal Security subcommittee.

WEST CALDWELL, N. J., Oct. 13 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair scored 39, 38 -- 77 today to win Group 1 honors in a Garden State Women's Golf Association one-day tournament at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of the American Legion resolution asking that the United States withdraw from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization:
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- A new morning newspaper appeared in Paris today. Called L'Express, it replaced the weekly of that name.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 13 (UP) -- A crudely written diary today told of the slow death of a Phoenix, Ariz., sailor in the badlands of Mexico after his plane crashed.

Louis J. Glickman, New York real estate investor, announced yesterday that he planned to undertake a major investment program in Canada, where he has started a one-month business survey in eleven cities. Rudolph Grunfeld, one of Mr. Glickman's associates, is in charge of a staff real estate and financial specialists conducting the study.
During his morning walk yesterday Harry S. Truman admonished the American Legion for denouncing the activities of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The State Department gave its full backing today to William Lacy, United States Ambassador in Korea, who has been at odds with the Government of President Syngman Rhee over taxation of American business men in Seoul.
The American Legion's action on UNESCO does it no credit.
ROME, Oct. 13. (AP) -- The United States' team was eliminated today from the epee competition of the World fencing championships.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Internal Revenue Service has confirmed reports that it has revoked the tax-exempt status of the Institute of Pacific Relations. This controversial research body has been under investigation by a Senate subcommittee.
The United Jewish Appeal received $10,330,000 yesterday to aid Jews in Morocco and to assist in the removal of North African Jews to Israel.
With only two days remaining for registration here, this year's enrollment of qualified voters appeared yesterday to be heading for the lowest total since 1943.

AMONG a trio of shows featuring contemporary Italian painters, a group exhibition at the Catherine Viviano Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, of both Italian and American contemporaries offers the most serious judgments on the current Italian situation.

Polio patients will be aided by a luncheon and fashion show to be held on Monday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Jack Martin Polio Fund. Proceeds from the event will be donated to the construction fund for the Jack Martin Respirator Center at Mount Sinai Hospital, now nearing completion.

THE pleasantest thing about "The Golden Slippers" is the abundance of its gay and gracious tunes. In this opera, which was revived at the City Center last night, Tchaikovsky's rare melodic vein is not weighed down by the woes of the world.
THREE painters associated with the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, are jointly showing recent work.
Sales and earnings of the Douglas Aircraft Company for the nine months ended last Aug. 31 fell behind those of a year earlier, according to the results announced yesterday.
After being relegated for years to a minor spot in the lineup of Federal Reserve credit controls, the discount rate appears to be enjoying new vigor as a medium of monetary policy.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 13 -- Union negotiators accepted a new three-year contract today for 3,500 atomic workers in the K-25 plant at Oak Ridge and for 1,000 more at Paducah, Ky.
COSENZA, Italy, Oct 11 -- Italy expects to spend $2,000,000,000 before the end of 1962 in an effort to develop the south socially and economically.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A group of sightseeing Soviet sailors from the goodwill squadron at Portsmouth asked today to see a United States tourist.
The two-year-old financial tie between the International Brotherhood of teamsters, A. F. L., and the Fruehauf Trailer Company was cut yesterday.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and its consolidated subsidiaries did the largest volume of business in its history in the fiscal year ended on July 30. Sales aggregated $376,422,324 and net earnings were $5,615,300. These earnings were the highest in five years and 23 per cent ahead of the 1954 level.
The first construction for permanent passenger facilities at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, will begin within three weeks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Ezra Taft Benson asserted today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon and all members of the Cabinet were "solidly behind the Administration's farm program."

The Greater New York Chapter of the Institute of Real Estate Management will hold its annual dinner and election next Wednesday night in the Jade Suite of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street.

SHORTLY before five o'clock on the afternoon of July 17 I arrived at Cecilienhof Palace in Potsdam for the opening session of the conference. Cecilienhof had been the country estate of the former Crown Prince Wilhelm. It was a two-story brownstone house of four wings with a courtyard in the center -- a courtyard which was now brilliantly carpeted with a twenty-four-foot red star of geraniums, pink roses and hydrangeas planted by the Soviets.

The Strategic Materials Corporation announced yesterday it had sold privately 340,000 shares of capital stock at $10 a share net. It plans to use about two-thirds of the $3,400,000 to build a pilot plant for making ferromanganese directly from low-grade manganese ores mined in Canada and the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- A woman who spent the first months of her life as a three-pound premature baby in a cotton-lined shoe-box beside an open fireplace became tonight the first woman in history to head a major professional American medical society.
FROM the very opening measures of the Bach-d'Albert Prelude and Fugue in D, it was evident that Jose Kahan was a serious, well-trained pianist. Further events did nothing to erase that impression.

Arthur Longsjo of Fitchburg, Mass., plans to make a world tour next year at no cost to himself. If things work out as Longsjo hopes, he will spend the early months of 1956 in Europe and travel to Australia the following November.
Simon E. Sobeloff, United States Solicitor General, renewed last night Secretary of State Dulles' proposals designed to achieve peace in the Middle East.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Representatives of five nations proposed today that the United Nations set up new international conferences on the peaceful use of atomic energy.

Today's new film is "A Prize of Gold," a Columbia melodrama in color with Richard Widmark, Mai Zetterling Nigel Patrick, George Cole and Donald Wolfit, at the Palace. The Warwick Production was directed by Mark Robson from a screen play by Robert Buchner and John Paxton and a novel by Max Catto.

You have described in your issue of Oct. 3 how the city has used Section 903 of the City Charter to discharge Dr. Harry Slochower of Brooklyn College for refusing to tell a Senate subcommittee whether he was a Communist in 1940 or 1941, although he has denied being a Communist at the time of his questioning.
Abraham Straus goes on the theory that the fairy godmother is unnecessary these days. Why? Because, the store maintains, any girl can buy the fixings in Brooklyn to make herself a dream.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Samuel Cardinal Stritch has banned the Wagner and Mendelssohn Wedding Marches, eight versions of the "Ave Maria" and three other secular selections from Roman Catholic churches of the Chicago archdiocese. The ban becomes effective the first Sunday of Advent, Nov. 27.
MIAMI, Oct. 13 -- The American Legion's new national commander is a Navy veteran who is as much at home on sea as on land.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Britain's Ryder Cup golf team sailed for the United States today with Dai Rees, its captain, urging sports writers: "Don't write us off as not having a chance."
A "happy Wolverine" makes some pointed comments on the emphasis placed on Army's statistical superiority and fumbling in the cadet eleven's 26-2 defeat by Michigan.

BRITAIN'S unofficial ambassadors of goodwill, the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company players, treated the faithful Savoyards last night to a presentation of "Princess Ida" at the Shubert Theatre. The rarely produced operetta was the fifth in the current program of Gilbert and Sullivan repertory.

A card party for the benefit of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service will be held on Oct. 31. The party will take place in the ballroom of the Colony Club through the courtesy of Mrs. H. Schuyler Cammann.
Francis J. Bloustein of the Bronx has been recommended to Mayor Wagner for appointment as chairman of the City Planning Commission by the city's three top Democratic county leaders.

Futures on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly higher yesterday. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar, lead and silk rose; rubber, hides, wool and most coffee options eased and copper, zinc and potatoes closed mixed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Eisenhower made clear yesterday in his letter to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of the Soviet Union that the United States was determined to keep the current "disarmament" negotiations going.

NEWARK, Oct. 13 -- Bernard F. Kenny, former executive director of the Jersey City Redevelopment Agency, was sentenced today to two years in prison and fined $5,000. Kenny had been convicted on Sept. 28 on a charge of concealment.

At the annual meeting of the Consolidated Foods Corporation held yesterday in Chicago, Nathan Cummings, chairman, told stockholders that the sales and earnings trend continues to be favorable. Referring to last year's acquisitions, he said that serious studies are being held with a very major company, but nothing has been determined as yet.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- Ernest Hemingway's first major novel, "The Sun Also Rises," published in 1926, will be brought to the screen by Twentieth Century-Fox.

The $415,000,000 toll expressway system proposed to flow out of the Chicago area was pictured by Governor William G. Stratton of Illinois yesterday as the hub of an interstate expressway system that ultimately will be carrying the heaviest automobile traffic in the nation.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- A special $100 tax on every motor vehicle manufactured in the next ten years was advocated today as one method for financing an expanded Federal highway program.
The Committee to Save Carnegie Hall last night presented the first of a series of musical events in connection with its campaign to buy the concert hall.

The six-story building containing twenty-seven apartments and two stores at 486 East 165th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Seymour M. Tannenbaum, operator. The property, assessed at $58,000, was sold for all cash by the Metropolitan Mortgage Company, Inc., through James Boyd, Inc., broker.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- A detailed plan to recapture the leadership of France has been prepared by M. Mendes-France with the 1956 elections as the target, according to reliable French political sources.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Uranium mining in the United States is booming steadily, an Atomic Energy Commission official told the American Mining Congress.
The recent action of the American Legion at its Miami convention in censuring the activities of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization cannot pass without challenge.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- A deal is in the making for several thousand acres of New York City's upstate water supply land to become available for state parks.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- State governments were warned today that unless they changed their way of doing things the Federal Government would assume many of their responsibilities.
A Nov. 5 start for a new conservative weekly journal of opinion, The National Review, was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Conflicting testimony concerning the value of recently imposed credit curbs was heard today by the special Congressional subcommittee inquiring into housing conditions in various cities.

Earlier this week we commented here on what we referred to as the "Paradox in Cotton." This paradox was presented in the latest estimate of the Department of Agriculture, which indicated that, despite a 14 per cent reduction in the number of acres planted this year, the crop, at 13,920,000 bales, would actually exceed that of 1954 by some 232,000 bales, or about 2 per cent.
MIAMI, Oct. 13 -- The American Legion's national convention endorsed overwhelmingly today continued United States membership in the United Nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Dr. Luther Evans, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, replied today to criticism by American Legion members.
Eleven adjourned games from several rounds of the women's challengers' chess tournament were played off yesterday, according to a report from Moscow.
The racing at Belmont Park yesterday was marked by a series of tumbles, bumps and spills.
LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R., Oct. 13 -- More than 1,000,000 persons turned out today to welcome sailors from the first British naval squadron to visit Leningrad since shortly after World War II.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Jack Kramer said today he was "as much in the dark as anyone else" over the prospects of Australia's Davis Cup stars, Lewis Hoad and Ken Rosewall, joining his coming professional tour with the United States champion, Tony Trabert.
The State Attorney General's office will act today to lower the curtain on the operations of two theatrical investing corporations that allegedly swindled the public of $400,000.

MUNICH, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Rafael Tchimichkian retained his world featherweight title and gave Russia her second straight victory in the world amateur weight-lifting championships today. He equalled his own record with a total lift of 770 pounds.
GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- There has been an important adjustment in the balance of trade between Eastern and Western Europe.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 -- Presidential jousting in California in both Republican and Democratic camps waxed lively today.
New Yorkers who have been hoping to ride the subways next summer in air-conditioned comfort will have to wait until 1957 at least.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- High class industrial shares continued buoyant today, helped by yesterday's rally on Wall Street and today's early strength there.
NOW that "The Seven Year Itch" is out of the way, George Axelrod has gone on to his second comedy, "Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?", which opened at the Belasco last evening.

It was at this season of the year that Thoreau wrote in his journal, "One wonders that the fathers of the town are not out to see what the trees mean by their high colors and exuberance of spirits, fearing that some mischief is brewing.

BISHOP FULTON J. SHEEN returned to television last night. The program, sponsored by the Admiral Corporation, with the Roman Catholic prelate's fee going to charity, was carried for the first time by the American Broadcasting Company. It was seen locally on Channel 7 from 8 to 8:30 P. M.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- If more money is needed to stage the 1960 winter Olympics at Squaw Valley, Calif., a member of the State Legislature said today he was prepared to ask for it.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Ernest C. Strobeck made his last annual report as president of the vast Dairymen's League today and predicted, "There are good times ahead for the dairy industry and for the Dairymen's League."

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, set a new record for a nine-month period with a net income of $63,142,811. This was 79.9 per cent above the $35,093,946 earned in the first nine months of last year, and exceeded the profits for all full years except the $63,795,000 earned in all 1950.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 13 -- Brazil's new Finance Minister, Mario Camara, has promised there will be no change in the nation's policy on coffee prices.
Coaches Lloyd Jordan and Lou Little felicitated each other by telephone yesterday. They agreed that Harvard and Columbia should be evenly matched in their football game at Baker Field tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Soybean futures, after an initial rally today, were driven down to new lows on the present movement. But the prices came back well from the low spots, with shorts covering in a big way and a lull in hedge selling.

Freddie Hutchinson, the new St. Louis manager, faces a difficult task in realigning the Cardinals' pitching staff. This is particularly true in the matter of "gopher" balls -- pitches that are belted for home runs.
The Soviet Union's program for training scientists was cited yesterday as an argument for building a new $6,000,000 Bronx High School of Science.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Three high officers of the Government hailed today the announcement that Pan American World Airways had decided to purchase forty-five commercial jet transports.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union protested today against the candidacy of the Philippines for a seat in the United Nations Security Council. The Soviet delegation contended that the place belonged to the countries of Eastern Europe.

ACKNOWLEDGING that he hadn't met an eel except in smorgasbords for fifty years, Sparse Grey Hackle nevertheless weighed in with his sure-fire method for removing eels from hooks. He was prompted to the kind suggestion by a reference here to the difficulty Long Island Sound bottom fishermen sometimes experienced retrieving the hook once an eel had gobbled it up.
A two-part experiment, begun in New York in June and completed in Paris just recently, shows that bees have a time sense, or, as the American Museum of Natural History calls it, "an internal clock."

The four - story apartment house accommodating forty-seven families at 645 Summer Avenue in Newark, N. J., has passed to new ownership. The Summer Avenue Corporation, of which Fred Hinderer is president, has acquired the property from the New Jersey Realty Company.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- The year-long smoldering fight between this country's common carriers and those in the private, or contract, field, was brought into the open here today in an address by Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce.

NORMAN MAILER'S third novel, "The Deer Park,"* presents a difficult challenge to any critic who hopes to discuss it fairly and objectively. It is a long and competently written story about eight contemptible persons. All of them are completely amoral. Several of them are more vicious than the others and one is a monster of such depravity that even imaginative readers will have trouble conceiving his depths of vileness.
The Public Service Commission ruled yesterday that the New York Telephone Company is illegally collecting the 3 per cent city sales tax on calls from New York to Nassau and Westchester Counties.
The nation's leading commercial banks increased the price on loans to business yesterday to the highest level in more than twenty-five years.

In an address before the Pennsylvania Newspaper Publishers Association Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the executive advisory committee of the United States Steel Corporation, has discussed price-making in industry under what is usually referred to as a system of "administered prices."

ROME, Oct. 14 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador, commemorated President Eisenhower's birthday here today by turning over to the Italian Government a technical library on nuclear energy.
A large number of patrons has subscribed to the Nov. 16 performance of "Tiger at the Gates" at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.

ALTHOUGH some of her tricks are done with mirrors, there is generally a wonderful air of boldly sketched vitality in Jessamyn West's stories. She writes with far more vigor than many of the sadder young men now slouching morosely through the realms of beautiful letters. Her new portfolio, "Love, Death and the Ladies' Drill Team,"* is the best collection of short stories I have read since Elizabeth Enright's "The Moment Before the Rain."

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Twenty British agriculturists have returned from the Soviet Union convinced that Russian geneticists are inclining more and more toward the "orthodox" scientific philosophy of the West.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 14 -- Five Republican Governors from the Midwest today called for new emergency aid for the nation's farmers.

At the moment the General Assembly of the United Nations is deadlocked over the election of one of the three new nonpermanent members of the Security Council to be chosen this year. There was no real opposition to Australia and Cuba, but the election to the third seat has precipitated a bitter contest between the Philippines, backed by the United States, and Poland, backed by Soviet Russia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board's index of industrial production rose an additional point in September to another new high.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Trading was slower today on the Board of Trade. Soybean and grain futures closed below yesterday's final prices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Leonard W. Hall, chairman of the Republican National Committee, tonight debated "a political review of 1956." Fourteen hundred persons attending the thirty-seventh annual banquet of the Illinois State Chamber of Commerce in the Conrad Hilton Hotel heard the debate.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday. Prices were 15 to 40 points (75 cents to $2 a bale) net higher than on Thursday.

Milunka Lazarevic of Yugoslavia sustained her first defeat last night in the women's challengers' chess tournament. She was tied at 7 -- 2 for the lead by Mme. Larissa Volpert of Russia, according to a report from Moscow.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Army's injury-ridden football squad will strive to regain its winning ways against Syracuse before a crowd of 25,000 at Michie Stadium tomorrow. For the fourth successive week Coach Earl (Red) Blaik will be forced to start a different cadet backfield combination, as three of his best backs are on the sidelines.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 14 -- Technology will not stand still in America, Eugene G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Company, told more than 300 engineers and industrialists this afternoon. He spoke at the dedication of the world's largest universal testing machine in Lehigh University's new Fritz Engineering Laboratory.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Pentagon said today that agreements had been signed making possible the exchange of secret atomic information among the United States, Britain and Canada.
In preparation for the defense of their honors next year, the world champion Brooklyn Dodgers did some personnel shuffling yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 14 -- The Hungarian announcement that Archbishop Josef Groesz would be released from prison means no change in the "militantly anti-religious attitude" of communism. L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, said today.

The industrial plant of the Patchogue-Plymouth Mills has been sold in Patchogue, L. I. Purchase was made by an investing customer of Amos Lamphear and Saul Kirschner, who were co-brokers in the deal. The C. Grant Keck Organization represented the seller as broker.

BIG white heads of cauliflower of the variety appropriately named "Snow Ball" now are coming here in abundance from Long Island and the Catskills. At the reasonable price of 35 cents a head -- 25 cents in some chain stores -- the vegetable should figure importantly in October menus.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 14 -- Negotiations to end the 8-year-old war in the Malayan jungles between the British-led Government forces and the Communist terrorists will begin shortly. Announcing this in Kuala Lumpur, Tangku Adbul Rahman, Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya, said he had today received a personal letter from Chin Peng, secretary general of the Malayan Communist party.

Commodity futures prices were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume eased in most markets and trading was generally limited to evening of holdings for the week-end. Coffee, cocoa, lead, zinc, burlap, potatoes and onions rose: copper, rubber, hides, sugar and soybean oil eased, and cottonseed oil and wool closed mixed.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 14 -- There was evidence in Rabat today of increased tension between France and Spain as a result of the Riff revolt, which the French say has been engineered from Spanish Morocco.

The Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries realized an increase of 37.2 per cent in earnings for the quarter ended Aug. 31 on a sales gain of 18.9 per cent over the corresponding three months last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- State Department officials conceded today that they did not "have the answer" to a problem of diplomatic protocol that has arisen because of President Eisenhower's illness:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The United States and Britain are cautioning Israel against any thought of preventive war against Egypt.

A 23-year-old Army veteran whose conscience refused to let him rest surrendered yesterday. He confessed the attempted holdup on Thursday of a branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company at 230 Second Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 -- When the University of California at Los Angeles meets Stanford tomorrow at Palo Alto, the contest will involve two elements of suspense for West Coast football fans instead of the usual one.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The Soviet Union is prepared to drop the disarmament and prohibition features of its proposal for the establishment of an atoms-for-peace agency.

ROME, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Julia Schoeck, formerly of New York, was beaten by Italy's Olympic champion, Irene Camber, 4 -- 3, today in the third round of foil competition in the world fencing tournament.

HONG KONG, Oct. 14 -- France signed a one-year trade agreement with Ho Chi-minh's North Vietnam Government in Hanoi today. It calls for commercial exchanges of 1,000,000,000 francs ($2,857,000) on each side, according to the North Vietnam radio.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 14 -- The provisional government of Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi prepared today for possible serious trouble during the week-end as Oct. 17, the historic date of Peronism, neared.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 14 -- Regularly employed workers in fifty-one potato warehouses in Suffolk County voted down today membership in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers, A. F. of L.

Riverdale School's football team, unbeaten last year, is riding high again. A rugged and fast-charging line generates the Indians' power, and there are enough capable backs available to maintain a smooth attack.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Peter Thorneycroft, president of the Board of Trade, said today that uncertainty about the disposal of United States cotton stocks was causing damage to nearly every textile industry in the world.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Otto Strasser, former political associate of Hitler, has founded a political party that will participate in the next West German general elections.

New fiction, says Malcolm Cowley in "The Literary Situation," can be spied at once. A book of this kind will be as thin as a volume of poetry; among other things it will be praised on the dust wrapper for its "graceful irony" and "effective use of symbols."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 14 -- All users of electric power here have been ordered to reduce consumption by 30 per cent or risk having their power cut off entirely. The Water and Power Council is considering a plan to order a further 10 per cent cut as the power supply continues to dwindle because of the drought.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 14 -- Princeton, whose strong ground attack is ranked eighth in the nation, will meet its toughest test of the season tomorrow. The Tigers will face Colgate, rated sixth in rushing defense. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P. M. in Palmer Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Francis Biddle took exception today to a recent statement by former President Harry S. Truman that Mr. Biddle had "suggested" Tom C. Clark as his successor in the Cabinet post of Attorney General.
The following books of a religious and inspirational nature have been issued recently:

THE important frontier crossings made by contemporary artists are more often intellectual than geographical, but among this week's exhibitions are paintings that illuminate the visual world for the traveler.
PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Governor Harriman accused the national Republican Administration tonight of trying to solve the farm problem by plowing under the small farmer.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Angela Mortimer of England and Mary Ann Mitchell of San Leandro, Calif., fought their way into the women's singles final today in the Pan-American tennis championships.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The General Assembly reached a deadlock today over the candidacies of Poland and the Philippines for a seat in the Security Council.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Insurance companies are becoming increasingly active in international finance through purchase of long-term debt securities issued by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).
Bad weather yesterday held down the already lagging pace of registration as this year's enrollment of qualified voters here neared an end.
While Notre Dame is undergoing possibly its most dangerous test of the season against Michigan State, Yale and Cornell will provide the top football attraction in the East today.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 14 -- Dr. Harry Rice, principal of Bloomfield High School, suspended seven students today as the aftermath of a fight following a football game here Wednesday. He also apologized for the incident to the student body of the rival school, Clifton High.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Leading educators predicted today that a struggle for political control over education would soon develop into one of the greatest issues of state government.

MONTREAL, Oct. 14 -- A three-man royal commission, charged with a complete inquiry into the coastal trade of Canada, left Montreal today for Ontario and western Canada after receiving a series of briefs from shipping companies, railways and other interested parties.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -- The "slap-on-the-wrist technique" in dealing with traffic violators is an affront to the public, toll highway operators were told today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today to grant permanent authorization to Mohawk Airlines, Inc., of Ithaca, N. Y., to serve sixteen of its points in New York, Massachusetts and New Jersey.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 14 -- Victims of Nazi persecution will have received about 14,000,000,000 Deutsche marks (approximately $3,300,000,000) compensation from the West German Government by April, 1963, an official spokesman asserted today.

The United Service Organization calls its Mediterranean program "Operation Leap frog." Moving in advance of the Sixth Fleet, a roving U. S. O. field team mobilizes American residents of the port cities.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 14 -- The Israel, new flagship of Israel's merchant marine, sailed today on her maiden trans-Atlantic voyage carrying an 1,822-year-old coin for Mayor Wagner of New York.

Nashua is slated to run his final race of the 1955 season in the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park today. When the Belair Stud's star was entered for the $75,000 added race yesterday, the track was classified as fast. When he goes postward in the two-mile event at 4:20 P. M. today, the course is expected to be sloppy.

A great variety of cookbooks are scheduled for fall publication. In an article last week, Publishers' Weekly discussed thirty different books, which ranged from the type of book that blends recipes with reminiscences to books intended solely for the juvenile market.

District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn picked up 402 votes yesterday in a recount of the Democratic primary ballots for District Attorney in four Queens Assembly districts. The recount in the remaining nine districts is expected to be completed today.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Clement R. Attlee assured the Labor party's annual conference today of a vigorous fight against the Conservatives when Parliament reassembles.

Vincent A. G. O'Connor, city Marine and Aviation Commissioner, struck yesterday at a proposal that the city turn over its vast pier modernization and rehabilitation program to the Port of New York Authority.
MANY parents are finding the period between 8 and 8:55 A. M. these weekdays more bearable because of the delightful artistry of a television performer named Bob Keeshan.

A Yiddish-American musical play, "The Wedding March," in which no less than eight performers are co-starred, opens tonight at 8:30 o'clock at the Second Avenue Theatre, Second Avenue and Second Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Government released today another 1,113,930 shots of Salk polio vaccine for the states and terrritories and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.
An increase in the price of newsprint would close some American newspapers and impoverish others, an official of a publishers' organization declared yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Princess Margaret drove tonight to a cousin's country home where Group Capt. Peter Townsend was spending the week-end.

Columbia and Harvard will meet at Baker Field today in what shapes up as a close contest. The football game, which will start at 1:30 P. M., will be the highlight of Columbia's annual Fall Homecoming and Alumni Reunion Day.
CATANZARO, Italy, Oct. 13 -- Southern Italy shows signs of being about to awake from the deep slumber into which it fell some centuries ago.
VIENNA, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Prague radio announced tonight a major reorganization in the government of Communist Czechoslovakia.
Steve Allen, the National Broadcasting Company's midnight oil-burner, may expand his TV work week to six days.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 14 -- Services have been suspended in the Roman Catholic Mission of St. Cecilia at Jesuit Bend, about fifteen miles south of here, because parishioners refused to let a Negro priest say mass.

Americans of every race and creed, including responsible members of his own organization, will have been profoundly shocked by the irresponsible reference to anti-Semitism made by Garland Evans Hopkins, executive director of the American Friends of the Middle East, at a press conference on Oct. 10.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it would investigate the Lackawanna Railroad's stockholdings in the Nickel Plate Line in the light of transportation and anti-trust laws.

Bank clearings of the twenty-six leading cities of the nation for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $17,641,783,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. This represented a gain of 7.4 per cent over the $16,421,497,000 cleared in the correseponding 1954 week and was 20.5 per cent below the preceding week's $22,196,120,000.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

In a letter published on this page last Tuesday Fred R. Field Jr., president of the New York District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association, made several proposals "to bring peace and stability in the Port of New York." Compared with previous union pronouncements it was notable for its reasonable tone and the absence of attacks on the Waterfront Commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Automation is full of glowing promise, social significance and potential danger, an economist told Congress today.

Wall Street yesterday re-enacted Thursday's performance, in which stock market volume fell, more issues declined than gained, the averages rose, du Pont moved vigorously upward and the average investor seemed content to wait and see.
A capital budget of more than double the $9,251,789 proposed for the Traffic Department for 1956 was requested yesterday.

A roaring gale lashed the East Coast from Hatteras to Maine yesterday and last night. Winds of thirty to fifty miles an hour were recorded, with gusts up to seventy. The storm drenched the area with three to five inches of rain. It extended more than a thousand miles.

The new $1,000,000 New York Cardiac Home has opened its doors to patients at a time when the subject of heart disease is high in public interest as a result of the coronary thrombosis suffered by President Eisenhower. Just as the President is now convalescing, so must other victims of heart attacks.
Fall business of the nation's chain and mail order companies got off to a strong start last month with sales increases averaging 12.5 per cent over September of last year.
The parishioners and friends of Christ Church, Methodist, will hold an autumn fair next Friday and Saturday at the church in honor of Peter Praa Van Zandt.

What may be the world's oldest commercial oilfield is about to start producing again. Last month the Greek Government signed royalty contracts with a group of seven St. Louis men headed by Martin Lerman. It covers drilling, exploration and extraction on and around the island of Zakynthos.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Industrial equities threw off much of their early dullness today but net gains were small. Some blue chip issues such as Unilever N. V., Dunlop I. C. I. and Ford finished slightly lower.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -- Yale and Cornell, co-champions of the Ivy League last year, will meet at 2 P. M. in the Yale Bowl tomorrow in a gridiron test that may well decide this year's title.

Today is the final day of registration for the election of Nov. 8. If you have put off registering this week, register today. It is your last chance. The polling places in New York City will be open from 7 this morning until 10:30 this evening.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- A striking exhibition of Steuben glass has just opened at the Park Lane House here.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- When Mr. Dulles received the news that Moscow was unloading Soviet-bloc arms in the Middle East, it is said he had "a conniption fit." From a human standpoint this is understandable. The Secretary of State has been giving a passable imitation of Sisyphus rolling the rock of peace up Levantine slopes. It was surely no pleasure to be shoved down by Mr. Molotov.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Asian and other Far Eastern nations outstripped the world in the rate of increase of Industrial production last year, a United Nations economic commission reported today.
Verbal dust is rising in Texas about imports of natural gas from Mexico.
Against the background of last-minute sawing and hammering, members of the Actors Studio met for their first fall session yesterday in their first permanent quarters.

One of the buildings in the old Alexander Smith Carpet Company plant in Yonkers, N. Y., is under contract of sale to the Ideal Tea Packing Company, Inc., of New York. The structure, at Lake and Nepperhan Avenues, is four stories high and contains 50,000 square feet.
Ask the man who has flown one and he will tell you this about what is scheduled to be the nation's first jet airliner:

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- The deadline for the replacement of the vast bulk of the present-day American merchant fleet is less than seven years away. Richard C. Colton, vice president of the Lykes Brothers Steamship Company. Inc., declared today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Abnormally high tides, driven by gale-force northeastern winds, flooded onto Connecticut's 120 miles of shorefront from Long Island Sound tonight and for the second time in less than twenty-four hours forced the evacuation of hundreds of families.

DENVER, Oct. 14 -- President Eisenhower spent his sixty-fifth birthday today confined to a hospital bed but very much in a "happy birthday mood." The famous grin was in evidence almost continuously from 7 o'clock this morning, when he received his first gifts from his family, to his visit shortly before noon to the exposed western sun terrace at Fitzsimons Army Hospital.
" THE MARRIAGE OF FIGARO" was a merry entertainment as performed at the City Center last evening.

The wedding march from Wagner's opera "Lohengrin" should not be played during wedding ceremonies in New York's Roman Catholic Churches. This was made known yesterday by Msgr. William T. Green, director of the New York Archdiocese Commission on church music. He had been asked to comment on a ban placed Thursday on the "Lohengrin" march and other secular music by the Chicago Archdiocese.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A flying submarine was patented this week by Donald B. Doolittle, a Wilmington, Del., engineer. The plans call for propeller drive under water and jet operation in the air.

A resumption of corporate debt financing is about to take place in the market for new capital. Six issues of debt securities totaling $96,055,000 are slated to be marketed next week, the issues including public utility, industrial and railroad securities.
ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits has ruled that New York City does not have the power to sell the site of the abandoned Neponsit Beach Hospital in Queens.

TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, Oct. 14 -- Spanish authorities in this protectorate are understood to have created a sort of political-military no man's land in the Riff Mountains bordering on the Gueznaia region.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Opposition in the South to the Supreme Court's decision outlawing segregation in public schools "is great and in some areas is growing," newspaper editorial writers were told today.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- James W. Weldon of Rochester carried off the chief honors in the New York Seniors Golf Association fall tournament today. Weldon turned in an 85 on the east course of the Winged Foot Golf Club for a winning 36-hole aggregate of 161.

A reception will be held on the afternoon of Oct. 25 at Gracie Mansion, the home of Mayor and Mrs. Wagner, for the 300 persons aiding the annual Lenox Hill Neighborhood House Apartment House Appeal. Mrs. Alfred Ogden is chairman of the apartment house committee.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The White House refused today to supply Congressional investigators details of top Administration conferences on plans to sell Federal power in Georgia to a private utility.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 14 -- Princedoms, ruggedly independent tribal belts and sprawling provinces were merged today into a single administrative unit. The area, inhabited by 36,000,000, is equal to the combined size of Texas and Tennessee.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (UP) -- A doctor charged in a suit for $2,500,000 damages today that organized medical groups had refused him membership and barred him from hospitals because he would not charge more than $3 an office call.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 14 -- Nazi war criminals convicted of crimes against humanity and high-ranking officers of the former Waffen S. S., the Nazi Elite Guard, will not be permitted to serve in the new West German Army.

Bao Dai's sudden eruption into the limelight with a denunciation of the proposed plebiscite in South Vietnam cannot be viewed with any degree of sympathy. What Premier Diem has proposed, and expects to carry out later this month, is a popular ballot to decide the issue of the "Chief of State" for the beleaguered country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Senate subcommittee on Constitutional Rights was accused today of trying to suppress "the facts concerning religious liberty and church-state separation."
GENEVA, Oct. 14 -- Chinese Communist impatience with the imperceptible progress of the talks here on United States-Chinese problems is becoming more and more manifest.

The South American Gold and Platinum Company, a United States concern, announced yesterday an offer to buy the outstanding ordinary shares of Anglo-Ecuadorian Oilfields. Ltd., at 50 shillings (about $7) a share. The company said it had purchased in the last six months 159,350 of the 1,500,000 outstanding shares of Anglo-Ecuadorian.

Dr. Eugen Buresch, director of the Austrian Information Service here since 1952, has been appointed acting Austrian Minister to Iran, according to information received yesterday from Vienna. He will be the first Austrian diplomatic representative in Teheran since 1938.
Vigorous demand for copper and increased offerings resulting from higher prices helped send deliveries of the refined metal last month to the highest level since May, 1953.

A Harvard University senior, who attributed his apprehension by English police last summer to a talkative Yale man, pleaded guilty y terday in Federal Court to stowaway charges. He was sentenced to one day's probation.
WASHINGTON Oct. 14 (AP) -- A new labor-saving machine will take over much of the work of handling Government checks, with a money saving estimated at $2,250,000 a year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -- "The Heart's A Forgotten Hotel," a television play by Arnold Schulman about a hotel owner and his relationship with his son, will be presented on the National Broadcasting Company's television program "Playwrights '56" on Oct. 25.

James Finucane, in his letter which you published recently, appears to be a part of those hurricane proportions referred to by Seymour J. Rubin as seeking the return of German and Japanese private assets to their former owners.

OTTAWA, Oct. 14 -- The theory that North America's earliest populations migrated from Asia across the Bering Strait has gained added weight with the discovery of traces of nine extinct civilizations in the Canadian North.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Stella Walsh, the 44-year-old international track and field star, said today she would quit competition next year if she was not allowed to run for the United States in the 1956 Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 111.2 (1947-49 equals 100) in the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products and foods, largely reflecting price declines in meats and livestock, accounted for most of the decrease.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was honored yesterday at a luncheon in the Gramercy Park Hotel. The occasion was the Twenty-fifth anniversary of his consecration to the episcopate.
IT WAS blowing half a gale from the northeast at Montauk Point yesterday morning. There was wind up to thirty knots that drove rain before it and whipped the sea to a froth.
The relevance of an individual's religion to his daily task will be explored at a three-day Church and Work Congress in Albany beginning Wednesday.

The relevance of an individual's religion to his daily task will be explored at a three-day Church and Work Congress in Albany beginning Wednesday.
Events today: "The Merry Wives of Windsor," New York City Opera, New York City Center, and Claudio Arrau, pianist, Town Hall, both at 2:30 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Secretary of the Treasury will take some unpleasant, though familiar, news to President Eisenhower in Denver tomorrow.
LENINGRAD, Oct. 14 -- Soviet authorities sharply restricted today the number of Russians permitted to go aboard the British warships visiting Leningrad.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- British Government officials said today that special passes for shore liberty had been issued to approximately seven Soviet correspondents accompanying the Russian goodwill squadron visiting Portsmouth.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14 -- Yale University had a $452,898 deficit for the 1954-55 fiscal year. According to the annual report of the treasurer, Charles S. Gage, the deficit was caused by work on a long-deferred program of maintenance and rehabilitation of campus buildings.

DETROIT, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today the six millionth new car of 1955 was sold on Tuesday. The agency said it based the assertion "on the assumption new car sales during the first two weeks in October carried on September's 26,300- unit daily sales pace.
PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The failure of the National Assembly to agree today on a policy for Algeria opened prospects for a new Government crisis and other consequences for France.

Felice Orlandi, young stage and television actor, has been signed for his first featured screen role as a boxer in Columbia's "The Harder They Fall," based on the Budd Schulberg novel. Currently appearing as the soldier in the Circle in the Square production of "La Ronde," Mr. Orlandi was previously seen on Broadway as the foreman in "27 Wagons Full of Cotton." . . .

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- An Algerian Nationalist leader, Messali Hadj, appealed today for President Eisenhower's personal intervention to end what the Algerian called the "cruelty and horror of the French colonial repression."
ONE of the most difficult lieder-composers to grasp and project across the footlights is Hugo Wolf. Yet it was with Wolf that Lily Windsor reached the climax of her Town Hall recital last night.
DOWNSVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- A ghostly valley from which 1,000 persons have been moved to make way for the biggest of New York City's new reservoirs was inspected today by Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Strategic Air Command surrendered to a little flock of whooping cranes tonight.

A short ownership has been terminated in the sale by Arthur Maxwell Co., realty investors, of the five-story apartment building with two stores at 338 East Forty-ninth Street. The buyer is a client of Klein, Wikler Gottlieb, attorneys. Wilfred Stachenfeld was attorney for the sellers, who took cash above mortgages of $37,000 for the property.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 14 (UP) -- East Acres' Cosmah headed a field of thirteen 2-year-old fillies entered today for the first running of tthe $130,300 Gardenia Stakes tomorrow at Garden State Park. The sleek bay has five straight victories to her credit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -- Van Johnson, currently on location in Tucson, Ariz., making "Bottom Of The Bottle" for Twentieth Century-Fox, intends to start the new year by going to London for "I'll Take The High Road."

THE older woman in quest of a job sometimes has only herself to blame if she doesn't find one. While some employers' prejudices against hiring her are based on outmoded ideas of her capabilities, she often does nothing to discourage their beliefs.
TRENTON, Oct. 14 -- The State Federation of Labor charged today that the Hospital Service Plan of New Jersey (Blue Cross) was "wasting indiscriminately" funds of its subscribers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Cigar and cigarette manufacturers complained to Congress today it was costing them millions yearly to affix revenue stamps on tobacco packages.

The regional Red Cross will collect blood today from residents of Levittown, L. I. The collection will be made at Levittown Town Hall from 9:45 A. M. to 3:30 P. M. Blood will be collected also at Baron De Kalb Council, Knights of Columbus, 3000 Emmons Avenue, Brooklyn.
ATHENS, Oct. 14 -- Foreign Minister Spyros Theotokis said today that the West could lose Greece in next April's election here.
PARIS, Oct. 14 -- French officials, concerned about the Saar referendum Oct. 23, are considering steps the French Government might take next week to encourage a favorable vote.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- President Eisenhower's appointment this week of a top industrialist to the Atomic Energy Commission points up the dual role of that Federal agency and the multiple problems it faces in carrying out its responsibilities.
SASEBO, Japan, Oct. 13 -- Many Japanese cities have heard the slogan "Yanks go home." In this naval base town it is "Yanks stay here."

Jean Monnet, who is all French and all "European," has raised a new banner -- a customarily brilliant and timely one. He is seeking a means of furthering his great dream of a federated Europe, and this time he has hit upon the idea of a European organization for the economic development of atomic and nuclear energy.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 11 -- The English language, which has its back to the academic wall in India, has received stanch support from high places.

Three ill-behaved Britons the other day perpetrated a daylight hold-up in the heart of historic London. The day in question was one of the loveliest days London has ever had. The fog had cleared, the sun shown brightly through, the pigeons strutted their stuff in Trafalgar Square, decorations were being put up well in advance for the still impending opening of Parliament.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- Eleven scientists in varied fields of endeavor will be honored Wednesday at the annual Medal Day ceremonies of the Franklin Institute here. Those to be rewarded are seven Americans, three Britons and a Frenchman.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Failure to make extra point conversions cost Gettysburg College its first loss on its home field in three years today. The Bullets were beaten by Lehigh, 21 -- 18.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 15 -- Juscelino Kubitschek, who apparently has won the Brazilian Presidential election, appealed tonight for national unity to help develop the country.

NEWARK, Oct. 15 -- Most of New Jersey appeared tonight to have escaped disaster in the storm that swept the Northeast Friday and today.
Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, declared yesterday that "there is nothing to apologize for" in going ahead with the Salk vaccine program.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Britain's long-striding Gordon Pirie again ran a world record holder, Emil Zatopek, into the ground today. Pirie won the 5,000-meter race in 14:19 at a meet against Czechoslovakia.
State laws that permit manufacturers to fix minimum store prices on their products occupied much of the business world's attention last week.

LONDON -- Despite some obvious points of friction between the British and American characters -- extremes of self-assertiveness and reserve, for instance -- Anglo-American relations seem to have had a good year.
TRENTON, Oct. 15 -- The New Jersey legislative campaign is expected to increase in intensity from now until Election Day.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 15 (UP) -- West Virginia turned three opposition fumbles into touchdowns in the first quarter today and went on to crush William and Mary, 39 -- 13. It was the Mountaineer's fourth consecutive victory this season.
The stock market, its eyes fixed on the distant highlands of 1975 or thereabouts, has stubbed its toe on the realities of late 1955 and early 1956 several times in the last three weeks.

BECAUSE some confusion appeared to have developed over the aims of the New York State joint legislative committee on the revision of the Conservation Law, Assemblyman Leo A. Lawrence, the chairman, was sought out for an explanation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A Government official put a seal of approval on automation today.
