THE proposed amendment to the New York State Constitution to provide $750,000,000 of highway bonds for road building is subject of a bitter debate. To clarify the issues, The Times invited spokesmen for both sides to present their cases in this space.
BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- Massachusetts Republicans opened the 1955 campaign this week by raising $460,000 at a $100-a-plate dinner. No Presidential booms developed.

HONG KONG, Oct. 15 -- The Chinese Communist party has decided to convoke its first national party congress in ten years. The party also decided to step up the rate of mobilizing private tillers into land-pooling "agricultural producers' cooperatives."
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 15 -- The sixty-ninth annual convention of the Printing Industry of America, Inc., will open here tomorrow.

TIFLIS, U. S. S. R., Oct. 15 -- Soviet foreign policy since last April may be summarized as falling into three parts: a series of limited concessions; stepped-up wooing of underdeveloped non-Communist countries, particularly in Asia; a marked change in Soviet language toward the West and in its attitude toward the question of contact with the West.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 14 -- In many capitals of free Asia, a dry economic report was made public today. It will not get a great deal of attention throughout the world but its twenty-four pages probably are considerably more important to the people of Asia than any number of high-powered political statements.

APPARENTLY Faulkner has embarked on a new undertaking. He seems to be dismantling some of his earlier works and reassembling them into what he regards as their permanent form. A first result of the undertaking is this impressive cycle of stories, old, revised and new, dealing with hunters in the Mississippi wilderness.

THE European summer travel season, which is only just now beginning to wane -- into an unusually busy autumn season -- brought but all the standard superlatives, as to the number of visiting Americans, the crowds at tourist sites and in the museums, the amount of money they spent and how lavishly.

The annual newspaper story contest of the New York Newspaper Women's Club, with Nov. 5 as the deadline for entries, was announced yesterday. All women writing for New York newspapers are eligible contestants, except the winners of last year's awards.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today sixty-five leading industrialists had agreed to attend the Administration's conference Oct. 25 on eliminating racial discrimination in employment. He said he was "highly gratified" at industry's response.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15 (AP) -- An order for twelve tons of stainless steel to be made into coins for a foreign country has spurred makers of steel alloys to study the possibilities for a major new market.

Registration in the city ended last night with the lowest final enrollment in twenty-four years.

Aside from one concentrated drive in the third quarter, when the losers covered 70 yards in a dozen plays for their only touchdown, it was Harvard all the way for a convincing and merited 21-7 victory over Columbia yesterday at Baker Field.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Angela Mortimer of England won the Pan-American women's tennis singles championship with a 6-3, 6-3 victory over young Mary Ann Mitchell of San Leandro, Calif., today.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Hopes that Britain's former rabbit population of 100,000,000 animals will be reduced to 3,000,000 next year are spurred by the continued spread of the rabbit disease, myxomatosis, across the country.
Hopes for a reduction of the cotton surplus have been dashed by the latest official forecast, which placed the crop in excess of that in 1954.

ATLANTA, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Auburn Plainsmen, led by Howell Tubbs, an underrated quarterback, and Jimmy Phillips, a sensational sophomore end, upset Georgia Tech 14 -- 12, today. The triumph was the first for Auburn over Georgia Tech since 1940.

Lofty Webster, so called by the crew of the British cable ship John W. Mackay because of his height, has been lucky so far. In four months at sea as the ship's second cook, he has never dropped his monocle in the soup.

In celebration of the tenth anniversary of the United Nations, Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, has proclaimed this week as United Nations Week at the college.

A probationary patrolman who still is a student at the Police Academy pursued and captured a robbery suspect yesterday while on week-end patrol in the midtown area. Dave Brown of Adams and Vince McKenna of Arlington in Poughkeepsie were the individual winners yesterday in the nineteenth annual New York University interscholastic cross-country meet. West Catholic of Philadelphia and Nott Terrace of Schenectady took the team titles.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Halfback Jon Arnett and a battery of other Southern California ball-carriers blasted Wisconsin out of the unbeaten ranks last night, 33 -- 21, before 75,162 fans in Memorial Coliseum.
Sixty new evening community centers are being opened this month in New York, increasing the number to 348.

Buyers interested in modern paintings, fine books, early American silver and French period furniture and decorations may find them this week in four auction sales at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Oklahoma spotted Kansas a touchdown then pounded the Jayhawks into submission, 44 -- 6, today as the Sooners started on the path to their eighth consecutive Big Seven Conference football title.

A NEW Don Carlo of considerable distinction has just arrived from R. C. A. Victor (three disks). The recording, conducted by Gabriele Santini, was made in Italy by soloists, chorus and orchestra of the Rome Opera House.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 15 -- Colgate toppled Princeton from the ranks of unbeaten football teams today. Playing on a muddy field through a heavy rain, the Red Raiders triumphed, 15 -- 6, for their first gridiron victory over the Tigers since 1925.

ROME -- The number of United States tourists who visited Italy during the 1955 travel season was an estimated 20 per cent higher than last year. The increase has not made everybody happy. Hotel men complain that the standards of visitors from the United States are slipping.

" WHAT a start we had this season!" said Birdie Tebbetts, the manager of the Cincinnati Redlegs. "We lost nine of our first eleven, while the Dodgers were winning everything in sight. The season wasn't two weeks old before we were trailing by nine games."
NICASTRO, Italy, Oct. 15 -- Despite the huge sums spent by the fund for the development of southern Italy more persons in the region have become Communists than anti-Communists.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 15 (UP) -- Touchdown runs of 59 yards by Jim Rountree and 62 yards by Jackie Simpson helped Florida outlast Louisiana State today, 18 -- 14. The Southeastern Conference thriller was played before 30,000 fans.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield urged tonight that Republicans stop "political maneuvering" and unite behind the principles of the Eisenhower Administration.

DENVER, Oct. 15 -- President Eisenhower's doctors are concerned over how to relax tensions that are expected to develop when the President moves to Gettysburg, Pa.

TEANECK, N. J., Oct. 15 -- A hard-driving Tenafly High eleven scored its tenth straight triumph over a two-year span by defeating Teaneck's Highwaymen, 12 -- 0, at rain-drenched Hooke Stadium today.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 15 (UP) -- Fullback Henry Moore gained a yardage record at Arkansas as his slashing line bucks brought the Razorbacks a 27-20 victory over Texas today.

THE latest in the long series of international exhibitions of painting held at Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, is a disturbing event. This is the fortieth in the series which began in 1896. Many of the exhibitions have raised controversies, particularly in the selection of prizes, but these controversies may be attributed to the juries rather than the exhibitions as a whole.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Duke's Blue Devils spotted Ohio State a 14-point lead today, then roared back with a surge of power and passing to defeat the Buckeyes, 20 -- 14.

THE familiar cry of "give us more pictures and more money will flow to the nation's box offices" was sounded again during the convention here of the Theatre Owners of America. Hollywood production leaders listened with interest and sympathy and reassured the exhibitors that no plot had been hatched, or was in the process of being hatched, to keep film production at its current low state.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- If, as most Britons now expect, Princess Margaret decides to marry Group Capt. Peter Townsend, the match will have the enthusiastic support of the rank and file of the British nation.
Donald Townsend of St. John's took first place but Manhattan captured team honors yesterday in a triangular cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park. Navy was second in the team scoring.

BEETHOVEN'S "Fidelio" is always a fruitful source of argument. WILSON, Olka., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Three men were killed and six injured tonight when 100 quarts of nitroglycerin exploded prematurely. A three-man crew, preparing to drop the nitro into an oil well to blast loose subterranean oil sand, was blasted to bits.

COLORADO, a state abounding in fictional material, has seldom inspired a first-rate novel; the present title is an exception. Marion Castle, author of "The Golden Fury," has picked her way with sure-footed tread through the gulches and around the cliffs of the land she writes about.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Oct. 15 -- A truck fire in the westbound tube of the Lincoln Tunnel today caused a three-hour traffic tie-up. Thirteen persons were treated for smoke poisoning. The walls and ceiling of the tube in the area of the blaze were damaged.
DENVER, Oct. 15 -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of T. Coleman Andrews as Commissioner of Internal Revenue, effective Oct. 31.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Feed shade trees. Even after leaves fall, roots continue growth until the ground freezes. Fertilizing now invigorates trees, large and small, and offsets weakening from drought and storms. A well-balanced commercial fertilizer is satisfactory. Cut off at ground level any suckers that are growing up around the trunk.

Glaciers in the Pacific Northwest mountain ranges are advancing substantially for the first time in about one hundred years, finds Richard Hubley, project leader of an expedition sent to the Olympic and Cascade Mountains. Hane, a university physics student.

It is the annual autumn change of colors on the 1,300 different species of shrubs and trees that carpet all but a few thousand of the park's 507,000 acres.

HARTFORD, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Federal Judge J. Joseph Smith dismissed today a suit filed by eight alleged Communists seeking to avoid a jury trial. They are charged with conspiring to teach or advocate the violent overthrow of the Government in violation of the Smith Act.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Unbeaten Boston College, featuring thunderous line play led by its huge tackles, Frank Cousineau and John Miller, unleashed two long touchdown plays from its otherwise battering attack to defeat youthful Detroit tonight, 23 -- 0.
THERE is only one way to account for the soft radiance of "The Diary of Anne Frank." The play and the performance are inspired.
ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- Controversial issues in the fields of conservation and highway construction will be put before the state's voters on Nov. 8.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 15 -- Phil Bucalo scored thirteen points and ran for 164 yards to pace Northeastern to victory over Hofstra, 21 -- 12, on the Hofstra gridiron today. It was the Huskies' fourth triumpth.

Rain, fog and wind reduced attendance at the annual personnel inspection of Marine and Naval Air Reserve units at Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station yesterday. But the weather could not dampen the spirits of the 10,000 visitors.

UNLIKE many authors, Bernard Rudolfsky, architect, engineer and industrial designer, is a modest man. He tells us that this collection of essays about humans and their houses fills no need. This is an error that must be corrected at once.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 -- In a southeaster rainstorm that drenched 15,000 howling and mostly happy football fanatics huddled in the cavernous Bowl. Yale today overwhelmed its co-champion of the Ivy League, Cornell.
GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Development of a 15-acre wildlife laboratory for pupils is planned by the Board of Education of this Finger Lakes city.

The Hoover Medal for 1955 will be presented to Charles F. Kettering, research consultant and a director of the General Motors Corporation. The award for "great, unselfish, nontechnical services by engineers to their fellow-men" will be made at the diamond jubilee celebration and dinner of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in Chicago on Nov. 17.
IOWA CITY, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Quarterback Len Dawson pitched a 14-yard touchdown pass on the final play that enabled Purdue to tie Iowa, 20 -- 20, before a homecoming crowd of more than 52,000 today.

THE most authentic dish of black-eyed peas, side meat and collard greens to be served up on the legitimate stage in a parcel of years is Andy Samuel Griffith, a 29-year-old North Carolinian in near-mint condition.

WHEN television finally was ready to grace the national scene it borrowed rather liberally of two of Hollywood's major resources: its money and its mediocrity. As box-office receipts waned, the virtuosi of the grade B films made a mass migration from the motion-picture lots to the television studio closets.

YONKERS, Oct. 15 -- An exhibit of musical items, including eighteenth and nineteenth century instruments, is on view at The New York Times Information and Service Center at the Cross County Shopping Center here.

MOST books on wine are learned tomes. They are authoritative as all get out but discouraging to the uninitiated, who is pretty soon lost among the vineyards and the vocabulary. Fortunately, "Invitation to Wines" is not written for experts.

MONTREAL, Oct. 15 -- The Richard Brothers, Maurice and Henri, paced the Montreal Canadiens to their fourth straight National Hockey League victory tonight as they whipped the previously unbeaten New York Rangers, 4 -- 1, before 13,697 fans.

THE fall of Gen. Juan Domingo Peron, for ten years dictator-President of Argentina, raises the perennial question: How stable is Latin America? The answer is that it certainly is more stable now than it was. Probably it is moving gradually toward a condition of greater stability than at any time.

THE HAGUE -- American tourist in Holland may be approaching the revered and noble status of the herring. That is to say, he arrives in great numbers at a predictable time each year, he is widely liked, he doesn't stay long enough to wear out his welcome, and he adds to the national income while he is here.

Three cheers to Mr. Wilson. The sponsors of the National Merit Scholarship plan, as well as the various other scholarship plans, have forgotten one very important fact. That is: our American universities are presently bursting at the seams.

The men who operate the world's scheduled airlines, at least 200 of them, will convene at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow for the annual general meeting of the International Air Transport Association.

MANY years of devoted study of the literature of Israel have been concentrated in this book. M. Z. Frank, press officer to Haifa's irrepressible Mayor Abba Hushi, has with great discrimination pieced together literary fragments to tell the story of Israel from the days before political Zionism, when the Jewish population consisted of religious mystics living on charity.

TWO shows with widely contrasting approaches have just opened here. Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, presents work by the late Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, who felt that "the only justification of photography lies in the production of visual sensations that cannot be produced by any other means."
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -- Mexico's growing economic strength has impressed financial circles throughout the Western World, the Mexican Finance Minister has reported to President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines.

GABRIELLE ROY has written a remarkable book, remarkable for its truth and its quiet, unsensational power. One of the chief difficulties of the novelist is to prevent the characters he has conceived of as individuals from turning, before the bored eyes of the reader, into all - too - familiar types -- the confused intellectual, the unfulfilled housewife, the young man more concerned about his personal integrity than any reader can possibly be.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Queen Juliana left today by plane for a three-week official tour of Dutch territories in the Western Hemisphere. It will be the first time in 400 years of Dutch colonial history that a ruling monarch has visited Dutch overseas possessions.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- A letter written in 1789 by President Washington to Thomas McKean, then Chief Justice of Pennylvania, was discovered recently among uncatalogued documents at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.

THE paeans of praise and laughter generated by "Auntie Mame" ever since the publication by Vanguard last January of that irreverent, fictional "biography" by Patrick Dennis, is about to be followed by rich rewards from the movies.

CAIRO, Oct. 15 -- Aircraft thundered low over Cairo today showering leaflets calling attention to Armaments Weeks. During this period Egyptians will contribute to a public subscription for the purchase of arms.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Stella Walsh, five-time winner of the Amateur Athletic Union's women's national pentathlon championship, was stopped today in her bid for a sixth straight title by Barbara Mueller, a 22-year-old school teacher from Chicago.

The 12,800-ton cargo liner President Jackson, a sleek addition to the American President Lines' 'round-the-world fleet, will sail today on her maiden voyage. She will call at twenty-six ports in fifteen countries on a four-month cruise.

THIS year sees the celebration of the two hundredth anniversary of the birth of Marie Antoinette, Queen of France. During her lifetime, she roused violent and contradictory passions, and even today these are not stilled.

THERE is no such thing as a perfect anything because everybody's idea of perfection in anything is different. Perhaps, then, the perfect bar, gin-mill, saloon, grogshop, or tavern, is one where, for one thing, there never is heard such a sterling cliche as that one.
Varied social events are being planned by two committees in connection with the sixty-seventh National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 1 through Nov. 9.
HARTFORD, Oct. 15 -- A state Commission on Adult Probation is nearing the end of its search for a director of the new State Adult Probation Department that comes into existence on Jan. 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Discussions with India and Pakistan on plans for joint development of Indus River resources have been extended for another six months, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today.

A new type of refrigerator that can maintain lower temperatures than any hitherto reached outside of the laboratory has been developed by the staff of Arthur D. Little, Inc., Cambridge, Mass. The temperature in this machine -- approximately 500 degrees below that of a kitchen refrigerator -- comes to within a fraction of a degree of the lowest that scientists believe possible.
GRANTS, N. M., Oct. 15 -- Texas talk notwithstanding, this uranium prospecting town is not for sale.

The rage for boldly textured fabrics has swept across the Atlantic from Paris and infected American designers. Smooth surfaced wools are neither gone nor forgotten, but most of the excitement lately focuses on three-dimensional fabrics. Nubby tweeds wools with a knitted look and basket weaves are this season's favorites.

For three generations the Adamses were statesmen of national and international stature, and in each generation the family genius for public affairs was concentrated in a single man. The third statesman in succession, Charles Francis Adams, had four sons who displayed a dazzling variety of talents.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Another round in the East-West contest over Germany opens in twelve days on neutral Swiss territory. The stakes are high, but no decision is expected.

Graduate fellowships and scholarships in the record amount of $76,260 have been granted by Teachers College, Columbia University, for the 1955-56 academic year. This was announced yesterday by Frank H. Hagemeyer, college registrar.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Arlington National Cemetery received today from a rural Indiana graveyard the body of Maj. Samuel Woodfill, called America's greatest hero of World War I.

AUGSBURG, Germany, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A West German court today convicted two former Nazi S. S. (Elite Guard) officers of responsibility for the war-time executions of Admiral Wilhelm Canaris, former counter-intelligence chief, and four other anti-Hitlerites.

IT is not often that a work of original scholarship is also a work of great topical interest. Richard Hofstadter's new book is both. In it he examines, criticizes and replaces some of the most popular stereotypes of recent American history, but his historical investigation has a high degree of contemporary utility.

President Eisenhower's illness is forcing Republicans to contemplate a national campaign next year with a new standard-bearer. Their big problem is to try to find a candidate who can hold together the political coalition which accounted for the 1952 Republican victory.

REPAIRS and chores about the house as well as any construction projects, large or small, cannot be done without the right tools. And if the tools are to be in working order constantly, then there must be a place to keep them. Both time and temper will be saved if there is a workbench, equipped with a basic set of tools, in the cellar or garage.
Brooklyn Tech began its Division I Public Schools Athletic League drive yesterday by whipping Jefferson, 25 -- 7, at Tilden High's field in Brooklyn.

The undisputed lead in the women's chess challengers' tournament was taken last night by Mme. Larissa Volpert of Russia when she drew her tenth-round game with Mme. Kira Zvorkina of Russia in fifteen moves.

IN order that Carol Channing be flawlessly vampish, beguiling and pleasingly unwholesome as the star of the musical on the silent movie era which comes to Broadway Nov. 10 and is called, not unexpectedly, "The Vamp," she has had as a kind of adviser, aide de camp, critic and coach, that exotic former siren named Nita Naldi.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. l5 -- Whether to keep or return a $5,000 award has aroused a controversy among members of the Plymouth Monthly Meeting of the Society of Friends.

South from Moscow, beyond the great Black and Caspian inland seas, lie the hills and the deserts of the Middle East, with their underground oceans of oil. Almost due south is Mecca, religious capital of the Moslems. Nearby are Suez and the Red Sea, for generations the waterways of European influence and power in East Africa and the Orient.

UNION jurisdictional issues, born of technological progress in television, are beginning to ruffle the surface calm that currently exists among craft and talent groups in the entertainment world. While there is no telling how soon the big blow may come, the general feeling is that widespread conflicts that may result in a substantial reshuffling of areas of union jurisdiction are practically unavoidable.

TORONTO, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins cashed in on a penalty to fire two third-period goals and earn a 2-2 deadlock with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight. A crowd of 13,001 watched the National Hockey League contest at Maple Leaf Gardens.

The New York Giants, still in search of their first victory of the National Football League season, will open their thirty-first campaign at the Polo Grounds this afternoon. The thrice-beaten New Yorkers will face the Chicago Cardinals, victors in two of three starts.

" All the world," as President Eisenhower remarked in his letter to Marshal Bulganin, hopes that it will be possible to put into effect "comprehensive plans for inspection, controls and reductions of armaments." Anyone who doubted the intensity of these hopes, and the corresponding fear of a nuclear war, has only to study the amount of space given the Bulganin-Eisenhower letters in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Congressional investigators reported today that forty-seven butter dealers had netted $279,949 last year in questionable "sell-back" transactions under the farm price support program.

STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A committee of the European Consultative Assembly urged the West today to hold fast on German reunification in forthcoming negotiations with the Soviet Union at Geneva.
FUKUOKA, Japan, Oct. 14 -- Communism in one of Japan's poorest areas has been struck a body blow by the United States Refugee Relief Program.

A state-wide conference to consider problems of the aged will take place this week in Albany. Called by Governor Harriman, the three-day session beginning Tuesday will bring together some 400 persons interested in the older members of the population.
As a soft-hearted parent and teacher, rapidly losing my mind in the struggle to teach English in an average city high school, I feel I must point out some instances in which Mr. Wilson strays.

A SMALL boy armed with a purple crayon need never lack for adventure if he is as resourceful as Crockett Johnson's Harold. Having decided to take a moonlight walk on a dark night, Harold simply draws a moon and a long straight path and goes on from there.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings at the Ambassador and in private homes for the annual tea dance for the benefit of the Judson Health Center to be held on the afternoon of Nov. 17 in the ballroom of the Ambassador.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 15 -- The Nobel Prize in medicine or physiology, to be awarded next Thursday by the Stockholm Royal Caroline Institute, will by-pass the United States.
Two recorded concerts are scheduled this week at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Dr. Ralph E. Lapp, former Government atomic scientist, charged today that the Atomic Energy Commission had failed "utterly" to make known what was to be expected in an atomic attack.
WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Conecticut's $2,300,000 beach erosion control program will be started in Fairfield County.
FUKUOKA, Japan, Oct. 15 -- Japan's coal industry, seriously ailing for several years, threatens to become the focus of a national economic crisis.
The world's biggest city will soon be getting additional natural gas from the world's biggest pipeline.

BOSTON -- The annual list of honors awards distributed by the Photographic Society of America at its four-day annual meeting here recently included honorary memberships for Norris Harkness, who was succeeded in the presidency of the society by Melvin Phegley of California, and John W. McNair of New York.

LONDON'S famous fog -- or rather the combination of natural fog, coal smoke and other pollutants that is called smog -- has just now been officially banished from the City of London, which has become a smokeless zone.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Duke Snider of the Brooklyn Dodgers was named the outstanding player in the National League and Al Kaline of the Detroit Tigers won similar honors in the American in the annual poll of the Sporting News.
Carmine G. DeSapio said yesterday he had found a surprising amount of support in California for Governor Harriman as the next Democratic candidate for President.
MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- The Soviet Union's expedition to Antarctica is being equipped for air and ground reconnaissance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, said today that he and thirty-three colleagues plan to urge the creation of a special committee to supervise the Central Intelligence Agency.

A FRESH breeze has been blowing through San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House, bringing with it some contemporary works and a modern approach to staging. It has not swept aside all the old ways of doing things, but it has accomplished enough to insure a lively future.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Quarterback John Blalack passed for two touchdowns and went 11 yards for another today as Mississippi's speedy Rebels gained a 27-13 victory over Tulane before 25,000 fans.

INTRIGUE and derring-do crowd this colorful tale of thirteenth-century Sicily. Ottavio Bucolini, only son of a great Genoese house, is only 16 when he is sent to Palermo to arrange trade between his father's house and the Saracens.

THE golden days of fall are here and they serve as a fitting theme for a flower show, too. On Tuesday and Wednesday the second district of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., will open the doors of its "Golden Days" show.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, champions of the National Hockey League, showed last year's form tonight and beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 1. It was the Wings' first victory of the season. They have lost three games.

THE Republic of Indonesia's postal administration recently issued a series of stamps commemorating the launching, a decade ago, of a postal service, while the Indonesians were fighting for their liberty from the Netherlands.

THE cool days of autumn are ideal for starting new groundcover plantings. As with new lawns, fall planting gets groundcovers off to an especially good start. There is ample moisture during the months after planting and cool weather for fast growing.
The Rev. John Courtney Murray, editor of Theological Studies called yesterday for a recreation of the liberal tradition in American public philosophy.

WALTER FARLEY'S famous Black Stallion will just have to resign himself to sharing the popularity poll with Flame, the island stallion who starred in two earlier books. This time Steve Duncan, Flame's discoverer, takes the stallion from uninhabited Azul Island in the Caribbean to Havana for the International Race.

Please accept my commendation for the enlightening article by Melvin J. Lasky concerning the growth of the Volkswagen works in Germany and of the sale of its automobiles everywhere. ("The Volkswagen: A Success Story," Oct. 2.)
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- A strong British police cordon, equipped with walkie-talkie sets, police dogs, radio motorcycles and patrol cars, is assuring the privacy of Princess Margaret this weekend.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Syracuse perpetrated one of the most startling upsets of this football season today by defeating Army, 13 -- 0, in an unceasing downpour at Michie Stadium. The Orange, striking in each instance after the cadets had been guilty of a ball-losing offensive misplay, went 26 yards in four plays and 43 yards in thirteen plays for its touchdowns.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington called today for a nationwide "grass-roots" crusade to reform state government.

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Oct. 15 (AP) -- A big, two-deck Chicago-to-New York Greyhound bus, hugging the side of a four-lane highway, ripped into a stalled semi-trailer truck in the dark early today. Six persons were killed and twenty-one injured, several from the New York area.

BOSTON -- In spite of poor weather, which spoiled the traditional picture-taking outing, the 1955 convention of the Photographic Society of America held here recently polled up the record attendance of 1,600 during its four-day program.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 15 -- Roswell Garst, Idaho corn farmer who recently visited the Soviet Union, praised the collective farm system in Rumania today.

Permit me to thank you for the editorial which appeared in The Times of Oct. 7 concerning the situation in France and North Africa. As a Frenchman I welcome such criticism when it is made, as is the case with you, in a friendly state of mind and with the obvious and sincere desire to understand, if not to approve.

GARY Cooper and Irving Berlin, two gentlemen who are virtually unknown in the television medium, have agreed to appear on a show being produced by the Overseas Press Club in cooperation with the National Broadcasting Company.
PARIS, Oct. 15 -- President Rene Coty today defended the republican regime but condemned the way in which it was functioning.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Top-ranked Michigan lost some of its glitter to an inspired Northwestern team today, but finally posted a 14-2 victory to remain unbeaten.
CONCORD, Mass., Oct. 15 -Municipal descendants of the men who fought "by the rude bridge that arched the flood" in the American Revolution are up in arms again.

YOUR home and family can be protected against fire by installing a home fire alarm system. A maker of industrial units now offers a do-it-yourself kit that includes two heat-sensitive detector units, wires and a signal unit that works on ordinary household current.
" Wanted: Engineers" is the cry in every section of the country today. Industrial concerns of all kinds -- large and small, military and civilian -- seek men with technical skills.

THE Paris art season is starting slowly. Once again, beginning with the Autumn Salon and then on to the May Salon -- its two equinoxes, in a way -- it is about to embark on the round of its officials and private exhibitions.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Negotiators for Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., struggled today to break a deadlock in a contract dispute that threatened to erupt into a walkout of 44,000 workers at midnight tomorrow.

Ground-breaking ceremonies will be held Thursday for City College's new $3,500,000 library on the South Campus. The library will be named after the late Morris Raphael Cohen, renowned pholosopher and a member of the City College faculty for more than thirty-five years.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- Acceptance "in the main" by the Arab countries and Israel of the technical and engineering details of the Jordan Valley plan was announced here this afternoon by Eric Johnston, President Eisenhower's special representative to the Middle East.

The American Red Cross has rehabilitated 10,219 families who were victims of the August floods in the East. Robert Pierpont, director of Eastern Area Disaster Relief, said yesterday at his headquarters in the New York Chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue, that the cost of this work was $8,692,687.

THAT flush on the cheeks of Theresa Helburn, Armina Marshall and Lawrence Langner, who when added together equal the Theatre Guild, can now be explained. It is, our man says, nothing, but nothing more than their pardonable excitement over a new musical they have just picked up.

THE notion that the old songs are the best songs is getting a good ride from the recording companies this fall. A particularly assiduous job of poking around in the embers of popular music has been done by Decca, which has drawn thirty-six somewhat aged recordings by Bing Crosby from its vaults to make up a three-disk set called Old Masters.
The fifteenth annual Columbia Alumni Athletic Award was presented to Maj. Gen. William J. (Wild Bill) Donovan during Homecoming Day celebrations at the university yesterday.
The Belair Stud's champion 3-year-old colt, Nashua, won the two-mile Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park yesterday and thereby set up a dizzy list of statistics.

Every physician is required to redeem his profession in the eyes of a mistrustful public, Dr. Hobert C. Moore, president of the American Osteopathic Association, declared yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 15 -- On the surface all seems quiet in the small communities south of here affected by the order of Archbishop Joseph Francis Rummel suspending services in one Roman Catholic mission and reducing the number of masses in another.

A committee of women headed by Mrs. Peter Darlington has taken over a large block of seats for the Christmas show at the Radio City Music Hall on the afternoon and evening of Dec. 20. Part of the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza also has been reserved that evening for a theatre dinner.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- The number of cases of rabies in upstate New York during the first nine months of 1955 has risen slightly over the previous year.
An election campaign of exceptional bitterness in the 1,200,000-member United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., will end Oct. 25.
CAIRO, Oct. 11 -- The Soviet Union's answer to "Porgy and Bess" is a poor sort of provincial cultural variety show. But it was Russian and it was here, and that seems to be good enough nowadays.
RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 15 -- Fatmi ben Slimane, former Pasha of Fez, a moderate nationalist, is regarded as the man most likely to head Morocco's first Government on the Western model.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 15 -- Howell E. Jackson's Nasrina, a Nasrullah filly with a fondness for an "off" track, splashed through the mud at Garden State Park today to win the $130,300 Gardenia Stakes, the world's richest race for 2-year-old fillies.

KINGSTON, Ont., Oct. 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson cautioned today against the assumption that "the evils" that had plauged the world for the last half century would necessarily end with a friendlier relationship between the East and West.
LEWSBURG, Pa., Oct. 15(AP) -- Bucknell crushed Temple today, 38 -- 0, to win "The Old Shoe," emblematic of football supremacy between the two Pennsylvania football rivals.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York announced yesterday the list of committees appointed by Allen T. Klots, president, for 1955-56:

Chester Bowles, former Ambassador to India and Nepal and author of "Ambassador's Report," has a new book on Harper's list scheduled for publication Oct. 31. In "The New Dimensions of Peace" Mr. Bowles presents his analysis of what American foreign policy must be in the years ahead to meet the challenge of Moscow's new approach.
As a result of the August floods, the National Retail Dry Goods Association started preparation of a detailed guide for member stores on coping with problems of water damage.

DETROIT, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Gordie Howe scored two goals and added two assists tonight to take over the National Hockey League scoring leadership. His efforts paced the Detroit Red Wings to a 6 -- 0 rout of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

The De Soto division of the Chrysler Corporation announced its 1956 line yesterday. The cars, which feature increased horsepower, will go on display in dealer showrooms here on Wednesday. New York City - delivered prices, exclusive of city sales tax, will be given then.

Artloom Carpet Company, Inc., reported net sales for the year to July 30 of $12,362,671, net before refund of income taxes of $125,915, and net loss of $97,707. Due to a change in the fiscal year, no direct comparison is available.
LIBRARIANS at the New-York Historical Society have come across curious marginal notes and markings in some of the Bibles that are on display at the society this week.

Banker's dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States increased by $15,845,000 during September to $670,700,000 at the end of the month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the week-end. This is $61,954,000 greater than a year ago.

MIAMI, Oct. 16 --Hurricane Katie, a small but dangerous storm, sprang up suddenly today in the central Caribbean Sea. Shortly before midnight it struck the south coast of Hispaniola, second biggest of the West Indies islands.

GENEVA, Oct. 10 -- The problems that get the most attention in connection with the new prospects for economic growth in the countries of southern Europe are mainly industrial. But the most intractable problems, and those which, in the long run, must govern the growth process, are in agriculture.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Joseph L. Rauh Jr., national chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, advised the Republicans today to "drop" Vice President Richard M. Nixon as a 1956 Presidential possibility. The independent voter will "never swallow" him, Mr. Rauh said.
Philip Sporn, president of the American Gas and Electric Company, will receive the John Fritz Medal for "notable scientific industrial achievement," it was announced over the week-end.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The love story of the Princess and the pilot was shadowed today by the awful solemnity of an affair of state.

AKNOUL, French Morocco, Oct. 8 -- Swarthy men in turbans and dark woolen cloaks called djellabas are fighting side by side with hard, blond khaki-clad veterans of the Nazi Wehrmacht here in the Riff "triangle of death."

Five journalists from four nations will receive Maria Moors Cabot gold medals Friday for their work in the "advancement of international friendship in the Americas." The awards are given annually by Columbia University.
Three days of drenching rains had spawned a new flood disaster in the Northeastern States last night. Property losses ran in the millions of dollars. Railroads and highways were disrupted.

JULY 22 was Sunday, but we had decided to continue the daily conferences without interruption. During the morning, accompanied by my old friend, Colonel and Monsignor Tiernan, and my military and naval aides, I attended the Protestant church service in the Colosseum Building, a former film laboratory in the Babelsberg area. An hour later I attended a second service in the same building, a Catholic mass conducted by Colonel Tiernan.

THE Broadway Chapel Players must have gotten inspirational guidance in deciding to open their new season with W. B. Yeats' "The Hour-Glass." For they gave the verse play -- a difficult one to stage -- a lovely rendering yesterday during vesper services at the Broadway Congregational Church.

" The one church that Christ established is where Peter is today," the Rev. Bernard P. Donachie declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

William Piriggi knows that a tenor's big top notes will bring down the house, especially if they have the characteristic Italian brilliance Mr. Piriggi often commands. His knowledge of this conditioned much of his singing yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

Your editorial "Master Plan Against Dirt" gives timely impetus to the campaign for a clean city. Of many objectives involved in a program for improving life in New York, this one can be classed as the least controversial. Hardly anyone is in favor of dirt.
FUKUOKA, Japan, Oct. 16 -- Informal fishing arrangements between Chinese Communist and Japanese fleets in the Yellow Sea have increased the latter's catch in the area by 20 per cent.

Bad weather on Friday and Saturday doubtless had something to do with it, but in any case it is disappointing to learn that last week's registration in this city ended with the lowest final enrollment in twenty-four years. Of the five city boroughs, only Richmond topped the figure for 1951, the last so-called off-year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens and the Chicago Black Hawks battled to a 2-2 tie in the Chicago Stadium tonight. The deadlock preserved the Canadiens' unbeaten record in five National Hockey League contests this season.
The questions a Christian must ask himself are not only how to take an active part in the work of the church on Sunday but also how to go to work with God on Monday.

Election of George V. Holton as a director of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation was announced over the week-end by Richard S. Perkin, board chairman and president of the Norwalk, Conn., precision instruments producer.
LONDON, Oct, 16 -- Eighty officers and sailors from six ships of the Soviet Baltic fleet visiting Britain were enthusiastically applauded today when they put on two concerts at Empress Hall here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- October lard had a rather spectacular upturn last week. The upturn was followed in part by other nearby positions, but deferred futures failed to make much headway. October buying was credited largely to shorts who at times found offerings extremely light.

Talks at the ambassadorial level in Geneva between representatives of Red China and of the United States have been going on for many weeks. At the fourteenth meeting it was announced that Red China was finally willing to release American citizens still held captive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns struck for two touchdowns in a three- minute stretch of the third quarter today and that was good enough for a 24-14 victory over the Washington Redskins in a rough defensive game.
POINT CLEAR, Ala., Oct. 16 -- Factional differences among Southern political leaders were stressed today by three Covernors arriving here for the twenty-first annual Southern Governors Conference.

ONE of the reasons Rossini's "Cinderella" has so much sparkle is that in the composer's work the diamond-like wit is backed so handsomely with the velvety softness of lovely melody and honestly touching sentiment.

Rain and flood waters washed out railroad bridges yesterday and sent embankments cascading onto tracks, stalling trains and passengers in many points throughout the East. Major lines, however, worked through the night to provide skeleton service wherever possible. A New York, New Haven and Hartford eastbound freight train derailment at Darien, Conn., late Saturday night still blocked all four tracks of the main line.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- Northern New England was virtually isolated from the rest of the East Coast today, except by air, as rain-swollen rivers in Connecticut created roadblocks on highways and railroads.

Mobile canteens from the Salvation Army and Red Cross bloodmobiles converted to moving vans rolled out from New York yesterday to provide food and shelter for the homeless in New York and Connecticut floods.
Amarillo, Tex., has designated Nov. 10 for the sale of $2,825,000 of school district bonds. Dated Nov. 1, 1955, the obligations will come due serially on Nov. 1 from 1956 to 1980.

THE season's second performance of "La Boheme" at the City Center Saturday evening was fresh and zestful. Part of this pleasant impression came from two newcomers to the cast. They were the conductor, Mr. Rudel, and the tenor, Barry Morell, who sang Rodolfo.
The privately owned merchant fleet flying the American flag had a net loss of six vessels last month. They amounted to 58,500 deadweight tons.
The lowest New York City registration in twenty-four years brought demands yesterday for replacing the present annual enrollment system with permanent personal registration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- Vivian Blaine will be starred in "Dream Girl" when the Elmer Rice play is presented on Dec. 11 as a ninety-minute color "spectacular" on the National Broadcasting Company television network.

A DEEP red rose jam in which the flower petals are suspended is one of the new Egyptian delicacies now offered at the Fraser Morris shop, 872 Madison Avenue. Other exotic imports include rose and mango syrups, and a marmalade made with Egyptian oranges that have a distinctive, somewhat bitter tang.
Carmine G. DeSapio, New York County Democratic leader, last night criticized the Eisenhower Administration for an asserted lack of planning in its foreign policy.

Leadership of the National Defense Transportation Association changed hands last week as Clark Hungerford, president of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, assumed the presidency of the association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The national income attained a record annual rate of $321,000,000,000 during the second quarter of this year, the Government reported today.
Incomplete reports indicated last night that the toll of the latest flood disaster in the Northeastern states would fall far below the figures compiled after the inundations of last August.

The fact that the Soviet Union representative at the United Nations voted to put on the agenda of the General Assembly the problem of Algeria in my judgment opened the door to the Governments in exile of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, or any Government on their behalf, to present to the United Nations their right to independence and sovereignty.

Among the various organizations that keep the torch of liberty alight in the subjugated countries behind the Iron Curtain, a special niche is occupied by the Kosciuszko Foundation, now observing its thirtieth anniversary. The foundation is a living memorial to the Polish patriot who rendered valiant service to this country during the Revolutionary War.

TORONTO, Oct. 16 -- In the summer of 1952, prospectors Albert Zeemel and Walter Blair were tramping the rugged bushland of northern Saskatchewan when they stumbled on a cluster of radioactive boulders. They had chanced upon the outcroppings of one of the richest deposits of uranium yet discovered.
Technical and meteorological problems failed to prevent "Wide Wide World" from providing another absorbing ninety minutes of television yesterday.

For the second time this year the metropolitan area of New York and adjacent communities has met with disaster by flood water. We have reason to hope that the human and material loss will not be as great as it was in the earlier catastrophe. As yet, we cannot measure it.
Rising flood waters inundated yesterday parts of eastern Pennsylvania from Scranton to Allentown and bordering Warren County in northwestern New Jersey.

Appearing in Philadelphia before a special Congressional subcommittee inquiring into housing conditions in various cities of the country, the president of one of the nation's leading building firms expressed gloomy forebodings for the immediate future of the economy unless existing mortgage credit controls were promptly lifted.
HARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- A man with sharp eyes, earnest manner, thinning hair, baggy clothes and a briefcase of data is campaigning for public office here.
In a pelting rain, through a howling wind and over a muddy gridiron the New York Football Giants got "healthy" yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

DETROIT, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Quick thinking by Y. A. Tittle turned his own fumble into a touchdown with less than two minutes to play today. As a result, the San Francisco 49ers scored a 27-24 victory over the Detroit Lions before 51,438 rain-drenched fans at Briggs Stadium.
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 16 -- The Port of Houston is preparing to demonstrate to experts from other ports how it has developed into one of the busiest shipping centers of the country.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 16 -- The Resident General's office charged tonight that French troops were fired on Friday from the Spanish zone of Morocco. It said the French troops did not return the fire.
A minister and a layman shared a pulpit yesterday to discuss "The Power of the Pew."
THE BELIEF that only the young can find success in business, a fallacy regarded as a fact by most people in this country, can discourage the woman-over-40 who seeks a job.

Adoption of a compulsory automobile insurance program in New York State was urged yesterday by State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits. He appeared on the "Between the Lines" program over station WABD of the Du Mont Television Network.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Susan Kelly is 71 years old. Early this morning she swam for her life when the rain-swollen Norwalk River carried away her two-story home.
New York State and city Civil Defense authorities moved to the aid of stricken Connecticut yesterday.
Cotton prices moved irregularly in the domestic market last week but managed to close in higher ground. The best gains were in the near deliveries.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Sherwood Johnston of Greenwich, Conn., in a Jaguar D today won the 100-mile race for the President's Cup in the national sports car races. He averaged 87.9 miles per hour.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 16 -- United Nations observers at the international frontier on the Sinai Peninsula were shot at today by Egyptians, according to an Israeli Army report.
CLINTON, N. J., Oct. 16 -- Ray Jewel's Hayride from Hillside, won the open all-age stake, completed today in the annual fall program of the North Jersey Field Trial Club.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 16 (UP) -- Holy Cross, playing with only three substitutions, made a second-period touchdown stand up for a 7-0 victory over the Quantico Marines before 8,000 rain-soaked spectators at Fitton Field today.
HARTFORD, Oct. 16 -- Connecticut was staggered today by its second flood disaster in two months.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 16 -- The West German Bundestag and Cabinet will move to West Berlin tomorrow for a two-day session to show the Federal Republic's continued interest in reunification. Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, still bedridden with bronchial pneumonia will remain in his home at Rhoendorf-on-Rhine.

LAKE MEAD, Nev., Oct. 16 -- Donald M. Campbell's record-holding jet-propelled hydroplane sank today in fifty feet of water near the shore of Lake Mead. The accident occurred as the Bluebird was being towed to shore after two trial speed runs.
AMSTERDAM, Oct. 16 -- Moderate optimism regarding the economic development of Indonesia was expressed by the governor of the Bank of Indonesia in an interview here last week.
From the air waterlogged Fairfield County appeared yesterday afternoon to be dealing with the flood emergency with almost unbelievable calmness.
Having achieved stardom in pictures, Patricia Neal will appear in her first Broadway starring role at 8 o'clock tonight when "A Roomful of Roses" opens at the Playhouse.

The heroic shipmaster who snatched 10,000 Korean refugees from the beaches of Hungnam only hours before the Chinese Communists overran the port in 1950 has walked the bridge of a ship for the last time.
Operators were active in Bronx realty deals reported over the week-end.

Negotiations have resumed between the producers of "Porgy and Bess" and the Columbia Broadcasting System. a proposed deal to televise the American folk operetta seemingly had collapsed a few weeks ago.
The Police Department must apply the "rule of reason" to individual cases in order to determine whether bingo games are legal, Corporation Counsel Peter Campbell Brown declared yesterday.
Acting Controller Louis Cohen criticized yesterday as "unusual" and "pointless" an opinion by Attorney General Jacob K. Javits concerning the Neponsit Beach Hospital in Quenes.
The city is planning much stricter enforcement of traffic regulations in the immediate future, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The Soviet offer of arms in the Middle East was abrupt if not unexpected. Beset with political and economic difficulties, Egypt's governing junta had already chosen to give the people guns rather than butter. There wasn't much butter on the immediate horizon, and guns are popular, so Colonel Nasser warned our Ambassador that if we didn't sell him weapons Russia would.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Leo Labine scored his first three goals of the season tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 4-1 victory over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game witnessed by 11,336 fans at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Democratic National Chairman predicted today that "whomever we nominate in our convention can defeat for the Presidency and Vice P-residency whomever the Republicans nominate in their convention."

The death of Alexei Minaev, a clerk at the headquarters of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations at 680 Park Avenue, was listed as suicide yesterday by Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's chief medical examiner.

DENVER, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union, C. I. O., announced today the signing of three major contracts. It said the signing "guarantees three years of industrial peace in a major segment of the atomic industry."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Three members of the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee expressed qualified optimism here tonight as to the course of its deliberations and the future of humanity in the nuclear era.
Five new films, including imports from England and Poland, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
ROME, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Giorgio Anglesio of Italy gained the world championship in the men's epee competition tonight.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- For the first time in French industrial history, steel production will reach 12,500,000 tons this year, not including the production of the Saar.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16 -- Spelling rules have become an international issue here. President Joao Cafe Filho's refusal to drop an agreement that Brazilians must spell as the Portuguese do has set him at odds with Congress.

The city cannot put off much longer making a flat and binding decision on the vast job of rehabilitating and modernizing its piers. Since 1948, when the decision was made by the city to undertake the job itself rather than to turn it over to the better-equipped Port of New York Authority, there have been plans and promises of action, but little in the way of appropriations.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The referendum in the Saar next Sunday will take place in some obscurity regarding what is at stake.

For his New York debut the week before last, Emil Gilels, the Soviet pianist, wanted to play three piano concertos in a single evening. This explains why his appearance last night at Carnegie Hall -- his third in thirteen days -- was an orchestral concert rather than the originally announced recital.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16 -- A handful of faithful arrived as usual about 8 A. M. today in front of the small asbestos-sided St. Cecilia Roman Catholic Mission at Jesuit Bend, about fifteen miles south of New Orleans.

Financial and manufacturing companies over the week-end were inclined to minimize the possible effects of the advance of money rates instituted by commercial banks on Friday. The prime rate -- that charged to the best borrowers -- was raised from 3 1/4 to 3 1/2 per cent, the highest level in twenty-five years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- October Government crop forecasts were regarded last week as bearish on corn and soybeans. This started a selling wave in futures that lowered prices substantially for soybeans and moderately for corn.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 16 -- The trustees of Colonial Williamsburg announced today the creation of the Williamsburg Award.
Aside from drenched clothing and wet feet, New Yorkers suffered little damage from yesterday's storm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A Soviet proposal to build the projected High Dam on the Nile River at Aswan in Egypt would scrap plans by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to finance the project.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Fairfield County was inundated today by torrential rains that caused the worst havoc the area has suffered in modern times.

United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation has announced purchase of the Fein group of can companies, which have annual sales in excess of $15,000,000. Hyman Marcus president of United States Hoffman, said that earnings of the new subsidiaries should add about $1 a share annually to the parent company's earnings.
HARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Fifty riders and as many horses competed today in the thirty-third annual Harrison Horse Show at the Kentucky Riding Stable.

Investment clubs have become an important factor in the American capital market, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared at the annual convention of the National Association of Investment Clubs held over the weekend in Detroit.
Soggy with rain, New York State and northern New Jersey battled flooding streams and high tides yesterday.
Public support for a proposal to simplify the state-wide court system was urged yesterday by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
Many major highways in the drenched Northeast remained closed or subject to detour last night.
CAIRO, Oct. 16 -- Israeli and Egyptian troops clashed today in the Sinai peninsula opposite El Auja demilitarized zone, an Egyptian Army spokesman reported tonight.

" What U. S. O. has done with such conspicuous success is to make each and every individual service man feel that he is remembered and that he is important," says Lieut. Gen. Jimmy Doolittle, World War II hero, about the United Service Organizations.
A program consisting entirely of the works of Ariadna Mikeshina was presented last night in Town Hall with the composer presiding at the piano as she did at a previous concert of her works.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad, Australia's young Davis Cup aces, have decided to turn down Jack Kramer's professional offer and keep playing tennis as amateurs.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Fred Cone's 26-yard field goal with 24 seconds to play today propelled Green Bay to a 30-28 victory over the Los Angeles Rams. The triumph catapulted the Packers into a three-way tie for first place in the National Football League's Western Division.
HIGHLAND, Ind., Oct 16 (UP) -- The Knights of Columbus dedicated a twenty-foot crucifix in a public park today. Protestant groups were ready to seek a court order, if necessary, to have it removed.

Armour Co. has named N. W. Ayer Son to handle the advertising for three of its major food divisions, four departments and two subsidiaries, effective Jan. 2. Armour's Dash Dog Food has been handled by the agency since last spring.
Saturday was a nightmare that will not soon be forgotten by numerous football teams, athletic directors and spectators.

The only point of novelty about last night's "Die Fledermaus" at the City Center was the presence of Julius Rudel on the podium. And Mr. Rudel conducted as he always does -- with clarity, consideration for his singers, and a good deal of rhythmic impetus.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 16 -- Mrs. J. J. McDonald's 7-year-old gray mare Wings took the working hunter championship at the first Mid-Island Kiwanis horse show, held at the Thomas School of Horsemanship today under the sponsorship of the Kiwanis Club of Mineola.

Six high school seniors agreed at the New York Times Youth Forum last night that the basic purposes of schooling were to prepare pupils for citizenship, vocations and professions. But their comments on methods, aims, teaching and teachers differed widely.
The Department of Health issued yesterday a list of instructions on the detection of defects in gas appliances, coupled with the warning that faulty devices were "potentially deadly."
Nature has been staging a sort of one-sided meteorological football game eight miles in the atmosphere to drench the Northeast.

CAMP FRIEDLAND, Germany, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A forced labor revolt crushed by Soviet tanks was described today by freed German war criminals returning from the Soviet Union. They also disclosed the presence of Westerners in captivity.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Six helocopters from the Sikorsky aircraft plant here picked up today 112 men, women and children who had been stranded in this area by flood waters. They also distributed food and medical supplies and did flood survey work.
Former President Herbert Hoover will receive the Frank H. Lahey Memorial Award "for outstanding leadership in medical education" Wednesday at 3:15 P. M. in the Waldorf-Astoria Towers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The body of the man Gen. John J. Pershing called the "outstanding" soldier of World War I will be reburied tomorrow at Arlington National Cemetery will full, though belated, military honors.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- With little more than a week to go before the reopening of Parliament and disclosure there of the Government's plans for dealing with the country's economic difficulties, the stockmarkets remain in a sensitive condition.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The Navy hopes to start work on its first atomic-driven super aircraft carrier by 1957 at the latest.
DENVER, Oct. 16 -- Sherman Adams, The Assistant to the President, sent the following telegram to Gov. Abraham Ribicoff of Connecticut today:

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 16 -- The unqualified success of Nassau County's new permanent personal registration system was assured here today. The Board of Elections estimated the total registration at 409,934, second in the state only to Kings County's 556,920.
MUNICH, Oct. 16 (AP) -- America's star heavyweight, Paul Anderson, won the world weight-lifting title tonight with a record of 1,130 pounds for the Olympic triathlon.

Judging by the recent output of books, the industrial worker today can hardly move without stepping on a sociologist disguised as an ordinary human being. Perhaps factory hands should be warned: If a man really listens when you talk, he soon will be galloping home to write it all down for the greater glory of industrial psychology.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Danbury has been declared an emergency area in the wake of a flood described by one official as "ten times worse" than the disaster of Aug. 19.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 15 -- The Government has announced new apartheid, or racial separation, measures.
Federal insurance to compensate individuals for losses caused by disasters such as hurricanes, floods and atomic explosions was advocated yesterday by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- In spite of mild statements on the subject by Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, a vigorous behind-the-scenes fight is expected against Congressional attempts to create a special joint committee to oversee the agency's work.
More than 600 Government representatives and business men from both sides of the Pacific will meet this week to assay the outlook for Asian-American economic cooperation.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16.-- A spot check in the steel industry and among steel consumers last week uncovered no evidence of an industrial slow-up or a hesitation. Whether that view will change soon remains to be seen. But new order volume, production and unsatisfied steel demand assure a busy steel industry for many months.
The steamship charter market continued its frim tone through last week. There were some slight retreats in rates but the general freight rate index rose again.
GENEVA, Oct. 16 -- The search for new sources of energy for Europe has led to the possibility of frozen gas.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 16 -- Continuing rains that have dumped 6.89 inches of water on Westchester County since Friday caused more floods today. Major parkways were impassable at many points throughout the day and utility and communication crews worked overtime to keep up with disruptions of service.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Figure skaters to represent the United States in next year's Olympic games were chosen today subject to approval by the United States Olympic Committee.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Iran told the Soviet Union today its objections to Iran's joining the three-power Baghdad defense pact were "incorrect and inadmissable."
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears trounced the previously unbeaten Baltimore Colts, 38 -- 10, for their first National Football League victory today.

The four hundredth anniversary of the martyrdom of two Bishops of the Church of England was observed yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, Seventy-fourth Street and York Avenue.

Your editorial of Oct. 2 "More Research Needed" brings certain thoughts to one who has been concerned with research in cardiac disease for many years. While we believe that very important discoveries are yet to be realized from the continuing research in heart disease, one must not think that medical scientists in recent years have been unproductive of important accomplishments.

Among the more historically interesting items carried in the financial news pages last week was a survey of the nation's corporate pension funds and their activities -- the first complete, detailed and up-to-date report of its kind to be published.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- The American Assembly proposed today a broad program to overhaul state governments to meet the needs of changing times.
ATLANTA, Oct. 16 -- The Southern Regional Council announced today it had received a $150,000 grant from the Fund for the Republic for interracial improvement programs.
A "Works of Mercy Window" was unveiled yesterday afternoon in All Souls Chapel of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

National Bible Week, which begins today, deserves to achieve its high purpose of reawakening religious thinking and action in all possible ways. The Laymen's National Committee, Inc., representing eminent Americans from all walks of life, is sponsoring this fifteenth annual observance of the week.
DENVER, Oct. 16 -- President Eisenhower limited his "work" program to five minutes today in a calm Sunday on the eighth floor of Fitzsimons Army Hospital.

SINCE everyone at the Second Avenue Theatre is a conservative, it is no surprise that the new Yiddish-American musical "The Wedding March" is taking no risks. The book by William Siegel with music by the venerable Joseph Rumshinsky to lyrics by Chaim Tauber opened Saturday night and left the status quo intact.

It is only fitting that the name of Cordell Hull should continue to be of service to a cause he promoted so ably and zealously while living -- that of amity and understanding between Latin America and the United States. We are referring to the Cordell Hull Foundation for International Education, which has launched a drive for $10,000,000 to carry on its important work.
The floods that destroyed the public library of Seymour, Conn., after Hurricane Diane in August backwashed yesterday to swamp a project for a new library.
An addition to the expanding apartment house group in the East End Avenue section of Manhattan is planned as a result of the sale of the northwest corner of the avenue and East Eighty-third Street.
A warning against "piecemeal disposal" of public power from the low-cost hydroelectric plants on the St. Lawrence and the Niagara Rivers was issued yesterday by the New York State C. I. O. Council.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- Presentation of evidence by the film company defendants in the 16-mm. movie anti-trust suit will begin Tuesday before Judge Leon R. Yankwich in Federal District Court, Los Angeles.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Jack Peach, 35 years old, and his neighbor, Mrs. Arden Murphy, are polio victims who need help from iron lungs.
RABAT, Oct. 16 -- The four-man Council of the Throne set up yesterday to exercise the prerogatives of Moroccan sovereignty is to hold its first meeting tomorrow.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- The annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball, to be held in the Tuxedo Club next Saturday night, will be the largest since World War I and will have nearly 100 of the New York metropolitan area debutantes in attendance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The Smithsonian Institution announced today that one of its archeologists has discovered big roofless stone houses of the mysterious Dorset people on Walrus Island in the Canadian Arctic.
The relationship of individual liberty and national security will be explored throughout the city during the next six weeks in discussion groups organized by the Freedom Agenda Committee.
" I can dream, can't I?" Football coaches ask this question wistfully as they talk of fleet-footed backs, sharp-shooting passers and lines that stand like stone walls.

QUEBEC, Oct. 16 -- $200,000,000 aluminum and hydro-electric project that will increase aluminum production in Canada about 30 per cent over the present rate has been announced by Premier Maurice Duplessis.

SVETLANA BERIOSOVA, the youngest ballerina of the Sadler's Wells Ballet, gave her first New York performance of "Lac des Cygnes" at the Metropolitan Opera House Saturday afternoon. She is the sixth of the company's ballerinas to take on the dual role of Odette-Odile during the season, and it is a pleasure to report that she upheld the high standards of this exemplary organization.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Congress appears likely to prescribe remedies for some of the taxpayer's most annoying headaches next year by overhauling the long-neglected excise-tax system.
Joseph P. McMurray, State Housing Commissioner, appealed yesterday for the approval of two housing proposals being submitted to the voters at referendums on election day.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- The Newark Portuguese, one of three undefeated teams in the American Soccer League, played a 2-2 tie today with the Philadelphia Uhriks.

Ervin Laszlo, who has not given local recital for several years, returned to Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His program consisted mostly of piano favorites -- Bach's "Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue," Schumann's "Carnaval," Prokofieff's Seventh Sonata and several Liszt pieces.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Ten members of the Turkish Parliament resigned from the ruling Democratic party today in a revolt against the party leadership of Premier Adnan Menderes.

REDDING, Conn., Oct. 16 -- When the lights went off in the home of 13-year-old Teddy Phoenix on Diamond Hill Road last night, he telephoned his parents to let them know, and to ask when they would be home.
Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. called on the nation yesterday to create "a golden age for civil rights." He pledged Federal cooperation in stamping out racial segregation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Secretary of State Dulles will submit to President Eisenhower on Wednesday an agreed Western program for testing professions of goodwill and cooperation at Geneva.

The American Spice Trade Association will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary with a dinner at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel Wednesday evening. Founded here in 1905, the organization now has 235 members, including importers, agents, brokers and manufacturers in the trade.
Autumn is what one makes of it. A sad season, say some -- who see in it the end of summer's warmth and fun, the return to school, the jump upward of the fuel bill.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A preview of coast-to-coast commercial jet travel was staged today by a Boeing 707 Stratoliner, forerunner of the airliners scheduled for service in 1958.
PITTSBURGH, Monday, Oct. l7 -- Forty-six thousand workers of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in ten states struck at 12:01 A. M. today.
The week-end rains did not put as much of a damper on moviegoing as expected at first-run film houses, a survey of leading showcases revealed.

THE War Between the Sexes that James Thurber chronicled with such fervor in the past usually found the ladies winning. In his new book, "Thurber's Dogs,"* the dogs generally win, paws down, in any comparison between mutts and men. Any way Mr. Thurber looks at modern man, he seems to be bound briskly for hell in a handbasket.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The United States urged today that new machinery be set up to review verdicts handed down by the United Nations Administrative Tribunal.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 17 -The flooding of the Norwalk River was described here today as the greatest local disaster since the British burned the community in 1779.
Party slates were completed yesterday for a special election to fill vacancies for posts of a state Senator and Assemblyman from Brooklyn.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies was picketed yesterday for four hours by a union representing employes of seven casework agencies.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A Federal judge accepted today Tennessee's plan to admit Negroes gradually to its white colleges.

FAVORITE recipes of famous people have been collected in any number of cookbooks, some conspicuously impractical for actual use. But "Specialty of the House," which has just been published for the benefit of the Florence Crittenton Mission, is an excellent exception.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- General Pate entered military service thirty-seven years ago as an enlisted man in the Army. He became a Marine after his graduation in 1921 from the Virginia Military Institute.

A new project was announced here yesterday by a group of handicapped persons organized to help their afflicted fellow men throughout the world. They made public plans for a $500,000 center on a tract of seven acres in North Hempstead, in Nassau County.
ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- Republican state officials agreed today on a program to make public employes eligible for both state retirement benefits and Federal Social Security.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Douglas A-4-D Skyhawk, the Navy's newest and lightest jet attack plane, has set a world speed record of 695.163 miles an hour for the 500-kilometer closed-circuit course.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- A partial resumption by France of participation in United Nations activities was indicated today. Word was received that Robert Bargues of the permanent delegation would return to New York for the opening meeting next Monday of the Trusteeship Council, on which he is the French representative.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, chairman of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, said today he believed there were additional Communist spy rings to be exposed in this country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -- Many of the heroic incidents involving the French Foreign Legion will form the basis for a new television film series. Tony Bartley, executive producer in charge of European sales and production for the Columbia Broadcasting System, expects production to get underway before the first of next year.

The former Dr. Lyons Toothpowder plant of the Sterling Drug Company on Elizabeth Avenue in Rahway, N. J., has been purchased by the Joe Lowe Corporation of New York. The property comprises a tract of eight acres with a four-story building containing 165,000 square feet of space.
Chekhov's comedy "The Cherry Orchard," as translated by Stark Young, opens tonight at the Fourth Street Theatre at 7:45 o'clock.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Gov. George N. Craig ended martial law in Richmond today. He announced that National Guard troops in Perfect Circle strike areas in two other cities would be reduced by 400 men.

That the Trustees of Colonial Williamsburg have created an award to be made from time to time to "a person who has influenced the course of national or world events significantly by expressing in sustained action or eloquent and persuasive statement a dedication to liberty and justice for all men" seems a logical evolution of the Williamsburg Idea.
Basketball will be the first sport on the Public Schools Athletic League program to receive funds from the $85,000 appropriated by the city this year for interscholastic sports.

Stockholders or the McWilliams Dredging Company at a meeting here yesterday elected eight new directors. Heading the new group is Alfred A. Strelsin, who was made chairman of the board. He is also president of the Cenco Corporation, makers of laboratory and scientific equipment, General Scientific Corporation and Reliance Advertising Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -Some of the Democratic professionals are maneuvering to gain for the South and the conservatives generally an extraordinary and conceivably even a decisive influence on the Democratic National Convention next year.

MANY of Marino Marini's drawings and gouaches at the Martha Jackson Gallery, 22 East Sixty-sixth Street, are hybrid in character: neither the firmly modeled studies of the sculptor nor the swift, highly abstracted sketches of the painter.
