PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Despite denials by Madrid, the French Government was understood today to have stood by its charges that some rebels in northern Morocco were operating from the Spanish Zone.

Aviation leaders, civil and military, are deeply worried by what they feel are serious inadequacies in air-traffic control. They are urging immediate short-range remedies and a prompt start on planning for eventual twenty-four-hour all-weather control of almost all flights.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A soldier who once was sentenced to life imprisonment for treason escaped a second trial as a result of an order by the Supreme Court today. The first conviction was reversed on a legal technicality.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--Vice Admiral Bryant, who'retired in August, 1948, was a graduate of the Naval Academy in 1919 and later of the Submarine School at New London, Conn. He was a native of Rushville, Ill.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -- Universal - International has obtained motion picture rights to the late Eugene O'Neill's early one-act stage success, "The Emperor Jones."
ASPROMONTE FOOTHILLS, Italy, Oct. 17 -- This mountain area is brigand country, and Angelo Macri is its king.

A new man-made fiber, said to be different chemically from any now on the market and suitable for use in a wide variety of wearing apparel, was introduced yesterday by B. F. Goodrich Chemical Company.

STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Edouard Bonnefous. French Communications Minister, called upon the European Consultative Assembly today to support a seven-point plan for dovetailing national postal services.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art and The Cloisters, the museum's medieval branch in Fort Tryon Park, reported a record attendance for the year ended last June.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The Inland Steel Company and the Cleveland Steel Barrel Company announced today they had agreed on the terms of a contract under which Inland would purchase the Cleveland company for 18,463 shares of stock.

Committees have been holding luncheon meetings at the Pierre to work out details for a benefit the Vassar Club of New York is sponsoring at the Metropolitan Opera House on the evening of Jan. 14. The club has taken over the entire seating capacity for the performance of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," starring Renata Tebaldi.

President Eisenhower widened the Federal flood relief program yesterday to include new areas of New York, Connecticut and New Jersey hit by week-end floods. These were in addition to sections already being helped under August proclamations.

Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, cocoa, zinc, lead, copper, potatoes, onions, soybean oil and hides rose. Changes were irregular in rubber, burlap, wool and sugar. Only cottonseed oil ended lower in all positions.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 17 -A property loss of $3,000,000 has been estimated by Stamford. Merchants were worst affected by surface water that ran through their establishments up to a height of fifteen feet.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 17 -- Rioting flared today in Mar rakesh, where bands of boys set fire to shops and battled Senegalese troops. Meanwhile the newly forme@ Council of the Throne held its first meeting here.

LONDON, Oct. 17 (Reuters) -- British shipbuilders, still keeping well ahead in quantity production of such earnest challengers as the West Germans and the Japanese, are taking an active part in exploring nuclear propulsion for ships.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 18 -- One of the most tantalizing mysteries of the post-war period was solved this morning with the return from a Soviet labor camp of Mrs. Erika Glaser Wallach, adopted daughter of Noel and Herta Field.
The removal from the city of a quantity of a jet rocket fuel ingredient described as highly flammable and explosive was ordered last night by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
An award of $50,000 will be given to the writer of what is adjudged the best original play on the "Kraft Television Theatre" during the coming year.
CAIRO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Four United States Senators dropped donations for Egypt's armaments fund drive into a contribution box presented to them outside Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser's office today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- To meet the growing need for more young persons of college caliber the Civil Service Commission opened today the first of a series of Federal-service entrance examinations.

LOVE - AT - FIRST - SIGHT, at least to the skeptics, may be only romantic, well-versed (and rehearsed) material for movies or television. However, it can be a foundation as well for a lasting, real-life relationship, in the opinion of Dr. Milton R. Sapirstein.

When the forty-seventh annual State Conference on Probation opened yesterday to mull over problems and progress, some New York City members were not present. Presiding Justice John Warren Hill had told Domestic Relations Court probation personnel they were too busy even to talk about their problems.
Seven Soviet journalists arrived here yesterday to begin a month-long study of the "best of things" in American life.
DENVER, Oct. 17 -- Charles E. Wilson said today that there would be no significant changes in the levels of defense spending or the size of the military establishment in the next fiscal year.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 -The new president of the Printing Industry of America today noted a trend to larger companies in the business.

According to the latest United Nations survey most of the free world is now producing goods, at least in the industrial field, at more than twice the rate before the last World War. In consequence, and despite some strains and stresses, it is enjoying an unprecedented prosperity which has forced even the Soviets to review their ideas on the achievements and the durability of "capitalism."
Spontaneous fires may be one unexpected hazard resulting from the week-end's floods, the National Board of Fire Underwriters said yesterday.
GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 17 -Jay Hebert of Woodmere, L. I., won the Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship with a par-equaling score of 140 today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 17 -- A longstanding ambition of some of Canada's leading citizens to create in Ottawa an international music and arts center similar to the Edinburgh Festival in Scotland was made public here today. The hope is that the Canadian capital might represent in North America what Edinburgh does in Europe.

Back in 1941 Howard Samuels was far from organizing a business that would chalk up $10,000,000 a year in sales. The job on hand then was a senior thesis for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The subject of this paper was "The Manufacturing and Distribution Problems of a Vinyl Coated Sisal Rope as a Clothesline."

Three centers -- Bill Brown of Syracuse, George Wolfe of Bucknell and Frank Reich of Penn State -- were named yesterday as the "unsung heroes" of last Saturday's games in the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Princess Margaret and Group Capt. Peter Townsend returned separately here today after a weekend at the country home of the Princess' cousin, Mrs. John Lycett Wills.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- A group of countries opposed to colonial rule opened a battle today against attempts to remove a provision for self-determination of peoples from the Covenants on Human Rights.

John M. Fox, president of the Minute Maid Corporation, producer of the Minute Maid and Snow Crop brands of frozen foods, says consistent consumer advertising is a prime responsibility of the frozen food packer to distributors.
The Belair Stud's Tremor, a 3year-old Prince Simon filly, won the Poughkeepsie Classified Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company raised $30,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of an issue of 3 1/4 per cent debentures due on Oct. 15, 1995.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., the nation's largest chemical producer, had the highest sales and earnings for the first nine months in its history, according to the preliminary figures announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon is now making a conscious effort to modify his reputation as a fiercely partisan and highly controversial figure in American politics.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 17 -The sun shone in Westchester County today and traffic on all main roads returned to normal.
A Communist party cell existed on the Hunter College campus from 1935 to 1955, Dr. George N. Shuster, president, told students and faculty at an Academic Freedom Week program yesterday.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 17 -- Wild rejoicing marked the return here today from two years of exile of the Kabaka of Buganda, King of one of Uganda's four provinces.
The American Women's Unit for War Relief, Inc., wrote last October asking for dolls and toys to be sent to the homeless children of South Korea and Vietnam in time for Christmas.

The supply of water to the city from the Croton reservoirs was cut off yesterday. Water officials here explained that the muddiness of the water resulting from the week-end storms was the principal reason for the shutdown.
GENEVA, Oct. 17 -- United States officials are by reports they have been receiving about the treatment of political refugees in Austria from Iron Curtain countries and Yugoslavia.
HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 17 -- The bell atop Wilson Hall, which tolls thirty minutes before the dinner hour at The Peddle School, rang out right on schedule today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -Walter P. Reuther foresaw today a four-day work week for Americans within ten years as a result of automation.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 17 -- The coalition of parties that have agreed to form Israel's new Government will go through a stiff test of its unity tomorrow when the Knesset (Parliament) debates foreign policy.

Steel production failed to come up to expectations last week. Instead of setting a record high as expected on the basis of beginning-of-the-week estimates of scheduled operations, output fell to 2,330,000 tons compared with 2,334,000 tons the previous week, and operations dropped to 96.5 per cent of rated capacity from 96.7 per cent. The forecast had been for operations at 97.4 per cent, equal to output of 2,350,000 tons.

All around the city, indeed all around a great many cities, workmen now are rushing to complete new roads. The speed is in order not only because of the bond issue, but also because contractors, like concrete, are not at their best while hovering around a wintry salamander.

Business and industry in the Northeast have taken a beating from flood waters for the second time in two months. The damage from last week - end's high waters, however, was far less than that caused by the floods touched off by Hurricane Diane in August.

Four bloodmobiles of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will go out today. They will visit the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street; the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 708 First Avenue; the H. C. Bohack Company, 48-25 Metropolitan Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, and the New York Telephone Company, 9 Barstow Road, Great Neck, L. I.
Three youths and a 21-year-old man accused of having flooded the home of a Queens minister with his own garden hose were arraigned yesterday in Queens Felony Court, Ridgewood.
ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- State revenues were reported today to be running $50,000,000 to $60,000,000 ahead of Governor Harriman's estimate for the present fiscal year.
The long-hidden sun emerged yesterday to cast its healing rays on devastated areas in southeastern New York state.
With a promise to "throw the whole Government at this flood," Val Peterson, National Civil Defense Director, flew to Connecticut yesterday with a party of relief experts.

NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 17 -At the age of 80, the spark of battle has not died in the calm blue eyes of Admiral Harry E. Yarnell. But the man who uttered the loudest "No!" to the Japanese before Pearl Harbor does not hope for war.

FOR the present, it would seem that Jose Ferrer has no other fields to conquer with his inspired interpretation of "Cyrano de Bergerac." Having brilliantly established his characterization of Rostand's flamboyant hero on the stage and in a film, Mr. Ferrer brought it to television last night. It was, perhaps, less than entirely satisfying for those who had seen it in the theatre or as a movie.

ERIVAN, Soviet Union, Oct. 16 -- Relations between the Soviet Government and churches are steady improving, Vazgen I, recently elected Catholicos of the Armenian Gregorian Church, said today. The Catholicos is the pontiff of the church.
MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- Soviet industry has been losing ground since 1950 in its struggle to raise the man-hour output faster than the major capitalist countries.
Bucky Walters, once an outstanding hurler for Cincinnati, was named pitching coach of the Giants yesterday. The move was made at the request of Bill Rigney, new manager of the Polo Grounders.
BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- A broad picture of what the country can expect in the way it lives was painted today by a group of experts in the manufacturing and distribution of goods of all types.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -Government scientists soon will announce the development of a new vaccine that experts believe will prove effective against one of the many viruses linked with the common cold.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States today Charles S. Haight, and Nathan Tolk both of New York, among others, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 -The tenth anniversary of Juan D. Peron's assumption of dictatorial powers over this nation was celebrated peacefully today. The overwhelming majority of the workers reported to their jobs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -The Office of Defense Mobilization has approved Federal tax benefits to assist the Bethlehem Steel Company in a $30,100,000 expansion of its facilities to produce heavy steel plate at Sparrows Point, Md.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 17 -- The task of improving the lot of the most impoverished quarter of the world's population was tackled today by the members of the Colombo Plan for international economic cooperation.

Today at noon 100 balloons will be sent aloft from Roosevelt Field, L. I. Attached to each will be a certificate giving the finder a $1 start in a savings account at the Franklin National Bank, Franklin Square, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -Short-term borrowing costs of the Treasury remained today at the highest level in two and onehalf years.
THIS D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, holding forth at the Sam S. Shubert, certainly is a drain on a reviewer's collection of adjectives meaning grand.

The Zoe Chemical Company, Inc., manufacturer of household chemicals, has leased the one-story building at the southeast corner of Jamaica Avenue and 211th Street in Jamaica, Queens. The property, owned by the E. B. E. Realty Corporation, was leased through the Greiner-Maltz Company as broker.
Daitch Crystal Dairies, Inc., and Shopwell Foods, Inc., which now operate supermarket chains in the metropolitan area, are planning to consolidate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -Maj. Samuel Woodfill, whose burial in a rural Indiana cemetery went unnoticed four years ago, was reburied here today with full military honors.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- One of the country's most distinguished diplomats and statesmen warned today that France was in danger of being "stricken from the roll of great peoples" because of governmental instability.
Mary H. Donlon, the first New York state woman to be appointed to a Federal bench, was inducted here yesterday as a judge of the United States Customs Court.
An issue of $3,500,000 of bonds of the Southfield, Mich., School District has been posted for sale on Nov. 1. Dated Nov. 1, 1955, the bonds will come due serially on Sept. 1 from 1958 to 1982.
T. Vincent Quinn, Democratic District Attorney of Queens, lost his recount battle for renomination yesterday against State Senator Frank D. O'Connor.

TRENTON, Tuesday, Oct. 18 -- The cities of Camden and Paterson were invaded yesterday by flood waters. Six Bergen and Passaic County communities, untouched by the week-end deluge, were beset by light flooding.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 17 -America's forests have come back to a remarkable degree but face a tremendous challenge, Richard E. McArdle, chief of the United States Forest Service, said today. He spoke at the annual meeting of the Society of American Foresters here.
The conversion of Don Holleder from an All-America end to just another passer at West Point apparently will continue. Coach Earl Blaik, it appears, has no intention of switching Holleder again.
Artie Towne, a New York middleweight, gained a split decision over Milo Savage of Salt Lake City in the ten-round main event at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
IN the textbooks, Edith Sommer's "A Roomful of Roses," acted at the Playhouse last evening, might be classified as a problem play.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Egyptian Ambassador informed Secretary of State Dulles today that Egypt would prefer to have the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the United States rather than the Soviet Union finance the construction of the Aswan High dam.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 17 -Prof. Karl Clauberg, head of the so-called experimental medical center in the Auschwitz [Oswiecim] extermination camp, returned last Thursday from Soviet captivity in a convoy of 598 war prisoners.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 17 -The United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in Jerusalem asked Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today to take diplomatic action with the Egyptian delegation in connection with an attack on the United Nations personnel.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- An increase in the price of newsprint in the foreseeable future is unjustified, B. H. Ridder Jr., outgoing president of the Inland Daily Press Association, said today.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 17 -In normal times in Danbury, they say you can toss a match into the little Still River in the morning and find it floating in the same place in the evening.

" Soviet Espionage," David J. Dallin's ninth book on the Soviet Union, will be published tomorrow by Yale University Press. Working with information supplied by former Soviet agents, foreign police, official reports and unpublished material, the author has drawn a picture of Russian methods of gathering secret information of foreign affairs by illicit means.

Michigan retained its No. 1 college football ranking over Maryland and Oklahoma yesterday. The wave of week-end upsets carried Michigan State, Auburn and Southern California to places among the United Press' top ten teams.
CONSTANTA, Rumania, Oct. 17 -- In contrast with Bucharest, Rumanian capital, the presence of the Soviet military forces is very much in evidence in this Black Sea port.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Supreme Court rejected today the petition of Thoger Jungersen for a rehearing of his patent infringement suit against a number of manufacturers of costume jewelry.

SCHLOSS BLUEHNBACH, Austria, Oct. 13 -- It did not take many hours, after our arrival at this picturesque castle on the Salzach, to realize that hunting here is more than a mere "sport" involving a hunter, a rifle, a deer or a chamois.

THOMAS SCHERMAN'S zest for fresh program building continues undiminished. Starting his ninth season at the head of his Little Orchestra Society at Town Hall last night, he proved that he has not lost his curiosity for new and neglected works nor his capacity for finding them in places where other conductors seem not to bother to look.

MANILA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Japanese textiles reshipped illegally from the United States and misrepresented as American goods are appearing on the Philippine market, Customs Commissioner Manuel P. Manahan reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Administration set Dec. 1 today as the deadline for filing new requests for Federal airport assistance by cities and local public agencies.

A NEW Roosevelt shrine is revealed in a collection of photographs on exhibition at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel until October 26. The summer home where Franklin D. Roosevelt became ill with polio and "changed from a politician into a statesman" is pictured in a series taken by Bette E. Barber.

The French are going through one of their extraordinarily complicated and confused political maneuvers today. Only a French politician could cope with a situation such as faces the Chamber of Deputies at the moment. When the crises in Morocco and Algeria are added to French internal politics one gets a puzzle that almost defies analysis.

The board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera decided yesterday to inform Parks Commissioner Robert Moses that it would cooperate with him in sponsoring a new opera house in the Lincoln Square area.

While the mighty were toppling, Michigan, Maryland and Oklahoma held their places at the head of the football parade last week. The prospect is that the perfect records of all three will remain inviolate again Saturday.
Prices of cotton futures on the York Cotton Exchange moved 24 points ($1.20 a bale) up to 9 points (45 cents a bale) down yesterday.
HONG KONG, Oct. 17 -- A sharper crack-down on "rich peasants" and other rural capitalist elements" is projected in the text of a Chinese Communist party resolution released today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The trouble with the samplings of political sentiment that have been taken since the President's illness is that the cross-sections were too narrow and the period between the events and the questions was too long. Accordingly this department decided to take some polls of its own in which these defects would be removed, and the results are herein presented with pardonable pride.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The eighty-four proposed members of the atoms-for-peace agency will get a chance to state their views on its articles of incorporation at an international conference.
Real estate operators were active in Manhattan transactions reported yesterday.
Private utilities renewed yesterday their opposition to the State Power Authority's plans to build its own lines for transmission of power from the St. Lawrence River.

ON the afternoon of July 28 the heads of the British delegation returned, although Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden were no longer among them. Their party had suffered a decisive defeat in the elections, and as a result the Conservative Cabinet had resigned.
The daily ride into the city, almost a reflex action for suburban commuters, was transformed yesterday for tens of thousands of them into an uncertain adventure.

The storm that hit the Northeastern states over the week-end raises again the question of warnings in advance. In this case they seem to have been meager, at least as far as the general public was aware -- compared with the size of the calamity that followed.

AFTER a year in Paris where he worked closely with master printers, Ralston Crawford is showing some striking lithographs at the Weyhe Gallery, 749 Lexington Avenue. Most of the work, semi-abstract in character, reveals new possibilities of the medium in the use of areas of intense black with white shapes played against them in intricate organizations.
A FEW unusual piano pieces were programmed by Harriet Line, who made her debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

American Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday a new high of $37,448,073 in net income for the twelve months ended Sept. 30. This represented a gain of 22.2 per cent over the $30,646,965 reported a year earlier.
An advertising executive charged yesterday that too many agencies had been spending their clients' money without knowing why, where or how.

American know-how will help West Germany to resume armament production, according to a group of German industrialists. A four-man delegation from Germany began a twenty-nine day tour here yesterday that will take it to leading munitions plants throughout the nation.
The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation realized an increase of 23.4 per cent in its ninemonth earnings of $39,376,583 over the $31,915,511 made in the corresponding period a year ago.
A resolution of condolences on the death on Oct. 3 of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler has been adopted by the board of directors of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 17 -- Members of the Waterside Workers Federation will stop work for twenty-four hours in all Australian ports from midnight tonight in protest against the refusal of an arbitration court to grant them increases in marginal pay over the basic wage.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation made no effort to operate today in thirty plants shut by a strike of 46,000 productions workers.
ROME, Oct. 17 -- The Vatican commended publicly today the Archbishop of New Orleans for his measures against the racial discrimination practiced by some Roman Catholics in Louisiana.

After numerous discussions on the subject of transportation in and around New York that we have had at the Citizens Budget Commission it is interesting to see the letter of Sidney Dean, vice president of the City Club, in your paper of Oct. 7.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Senator Estes Kefauver told a news conference today that he did not know whether he would seek his party's nomination for the Presidency again.
BEFORE World War II textiles was among the chief industries of Czechoslovakia. Today, at Lord Taylor, you can see Czechoslovak looms of a small group of Czech refugees living in Vienna.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Grain and soybean futures turned stronger today, following early dips in wheat. Corn and soybeans closed higher, oats were down and moves in wheat and rye were irregular.

AT THE age of 86, Frank Lloyd Wright, versatile and voluble American architect, has embarked on an enormous new venture. Mr. Wright has lent his name to a collection of commercially produced furniture, fabrics, wallpapers, floor coverings and accessories.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon said here last night that the Big Four Foreign Ministers' meeting, starting in Geneva Oct. 27, held "more promise" than any other East-West conference in the last decade.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -Fourteen California Communists won a Supreme Court review today of their convictions for violation of the Smith Act.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Oct. 17 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff began a three or four day trip by helicopter and car today to inspect the flood damage in Fairfield County and the Naugatuck Valley.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 17 (AP) -Hurricane Katie whipped across Haiti and the Dominican Republic today, causing heavy damage, then spun into new power 700 miles east southeast of Miami.
A prophylaxis against tuberculosis is under study in the hope of preventing the disease among persons who are "tuberculin positive." Those persons comprise 75 per cent of tuberculosis cases.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- In quiet trading today, modest and selective demand brought improvements to many of the leading industrial equities. Gains, however, were usually in the order of six pence (7 cents). There were many scattered losses, also in pennies.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- VickersArmstrongs, Ltd., announced today plans for a new turbo-propeller airliner that would exceed in speed and passenger capacity its highly successful Viscount.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Secretary of State Dulles urged Latin-American Republics today to contribute the weight of their public opinion and moral pressure to the Western cause at the forthcoming Big Four foreign ministers conference.

Every shot fired by Egyptian or Israeli troops on the uneasy armistice line that separates them causes the world to jump. Border tension between the two countries has been high for months, and any act seriously upsetting the equilibrium between Israel and the Arab states could throw the whole area into flames.

Wall Street yesterday broke a Monday habit of three weeks' standing. It opened a week without a sharp sell-off. In the slowest trading since Aug. 22 and the narrowest since Aug. 18, it made moderate gains that were somewhat reduced before the close.
The big New York banks that increased the prime rate (charged on top business loans) last week were far more pinched for money than many people dreamed.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -Leonard W. Hall predicted this afternoon that the Republicans would win the 1956 Presidential election regardless of who the candidates were on either side.

A men's committee has been formed to aid in planning the sixth annual Fall Frolic, a dinner dance for the benefit of the Hemophilia Foundation. Mrs. Andrew W. Schuman is chairman for the event, which will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Friday evening.

CHICK MEEHAN would never qualify as a meteorologist but he ranked at the top as a football coach. When Chick was directing New York University along the glory road -- remember when N. Y. U. was a gridiron power? -- the shrewd little dynamo had a theory. Perhaps there was no sound basis for it but Meehan discovered enough factional confirmation for his theory to profit by it.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon said here last night there could be "no greater step toward peace" than acceptance of President Eisenhower's proposal for adoption of both the American and Russian arms-inspection plans.
A view of southern Connecticut from an airplane yesterday presented a kind of autumnal reprise to the wild floods of mid-August.

More than 25 per cent of the young Americans in the armed forces today are under 21 years old. Half of our three-million service men are overseas. And, on this continent, increasing numbers of G. I.'s are stationed on remote antiaircraft or guided missile bases. Many are teenagers, away from home for the first time. Separated by thousands of miles from their families and friends, churches and schools, they are often desperately homesick.
POINT CLEAR, Ala., Oct. 17 -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland said today he would urge President Eisenhower to express a choice for the 1956 nomination if he did not sek reelection.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (AP) -Jack Kramer said today that Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad, Australia's 20-year-old Davis Cup twins, were "in the bag" to turn pro but somebody Down Under pressured them out of the decision.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Another deep slash in new car dealer inventories was reported by Automotive News.

In the passing of Ernest P. Goodrich the committee on housing of the Community Service Society is bereft of a warm friend and valued counselor. For about a third of a century he has been a faithful, hardworking member of our housing committee.
Many desirable items for holiday selling in dress and sportswear departments are being withdrawn from sale by manufacturers because lines are sold out, resident buying offices reported yesterday.
Three Brooklyn teen-agers went on trial yesterday for the second time in Kings County Court on charges of murder in the first degree in the slaying of another youth.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon said here last night there could be "no greater step toward peace" than acceptance of President Eisenhower's proposal for adoption of both the American and Russian arms-inspection plans.
The Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission announced yesterday that it had retained four engineering organizations and a financial expert to study New York-New Jersey transportation.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The Daily Oklahoman came out as usual today despite a strike by its 140 composing room employes.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that experts chosen by the "states concerned" consider the articles of incorporation of the proposed atoms-for-peace agency.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, tennis promoter, today told a jury hearing Mrs. Maureen Connolly Brinker's $265,000 damage suit for a horse riding injury that she had asked him to pay her $75,000 the first year as a professional.

An increase in the volume of their truck-leasing business has prompted the Hertz Corporation to buy six service garages in the New York area, two in Philadelphia and one in Pittsburgh. The deals were announced here yesterday by Walter L. Jacobs, president.
The Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company and its subsidiaries yesterday reported net earnings of $27,535,000 after taxes and charges for the nine months ended Sept. 30.

OTTAWA, Oct. 18 -- The opening of a branch rail line into the craggy base metals area around Manitouwadge, in northern Ontario, tomorrow, will give new impetus to the development of one of Canada's more recently discovered reservoirs of natural wealth.

An acre in the Lincoln Square project is being held for a new concert hall for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony. The land adjoins three acres designated for a new Metropolitan Opera House on the West Side north of Sixtysecond Street.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Prime Minister Eden presided over a Cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street this morning. At day's end he drove to Buckingham Palace for an audience with Queen Elizabeth II, who had arrived earlier from Scotland.
The Industrial Rayon Corporation in the first nine months of this year realized an increase of 53.7 per cent in earnings on a sales gain of 30.5 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago.
Three horses, only a nose and a head apart, came down to the finish line in the five-and-a-half furlong Cross Island Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

DENVER, Oct. 18 -- President Eisenhower pledged to the Governors of the New England states today that he would suggest legislation for some form of Federal disaster insurance to the next session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -About 78,000,000 Americans had incomes last year that were about the same as in 1953, but considerably higher than in 1945.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- B. H. Ridder Jr., president of the Inland Daily Press Association, which is holdiRg its annual meetring in Chicago, said today that !the financial status of the newsiprin industry does ndt justify a prace increase.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 18 -The Air Force's plan for a flying box car training unit at the Westchester County Airport in Purchase was disapproved today by major county officials.
MADRAS, India, Oct. 17 -- For the last six months a Kentuckian new to the diplomatic business has been doing quietly well at the ambassadorship to India.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 18 -The vote of confidence won by Premier Faure in Paris today dispelled the gloom that had fallen over Algiers at the prospect of a prolonged Cabinet crisis.

The French genius for carrying on even when logic, reason and mathematics are against them was well demonstrated yesterday. By rights, so to speak, Premier Faure's Government should have been defeated in the National Assembly. Instead, he got a generous vote of 308 to 254 and so his Government will stagger on for a while longer.

Dealers in commercial paper -short-term unsecured notes issued by industrial concerns and small finance companies -- yesterday increased the yield they offer buyers of the paper by oneeighth of one percentage point.

QUEBEC, Oct. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Emile Castonguay, president of the Canadian Daily Newspaper Publishers Association, said today that judging by the profit of Canadian newsprint mills, "there is no justification for increased newsprint prices at this time."
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 4 points lower on the nearby December contract but 21 to 30 points above Monday's final levels for other months.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 -- Premier Moshe Sharett called on Israel and Jews throughout the world to unite in buying arms for Israel.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 18 (UP) -- Willie Hartack rode both ends of a $28.40 daily double today and finished in the money with two other mounts at Garden State Park.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, decreed the dismissal of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem today. But the Premier, who is himself preparing to strip Bao Dai of his official status by a referendum next Sunday, will ignore the order, according to his representatives in Paris.

More than 100 Korean medical men are receiving training in the United States to meet a tragic health situation in their homeland, Dr. Howard A. Rusk told a gathering of New York physicians last night.

The Southern Societies of six states will join the New York Southern Society tomorrow evening in a cocktail dance for the benefit of the Relief Fund of the New York group. It will be held in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
Adlai E. Stevenson called on Senator Herbert H. Lehman yesterday at the Senator's apartment, 820 Park Avenue, for a political discussion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Stalls and spins, preventable in most instances by good pilot technique, were responsible for most of the serious small-plane accidents last month, the Civil Aeronautics Administration said today.
Sterling Drug, Inc., announced yesterday perfection of a new process for converting organic waste liquors into power.
PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Rebellion in Algeria took a toll of 2,946 French and native lives from Nov. 1, 1954, to Sept. 30, 1955, French officials repoted tonight in Algiers.
The battleship Wisconsin went aground at the mouth of the East River yesterday. Her 45,000 tons lay for close to an hour in the mud of Dimond Reef about 500 yards north of Governors Island.

The renewed efforts of Senator Mansfield of Montana to achieve some kind of Congressional control over the Central Intelligence Agency will, we hope, meet with success at the next session. The C. I. A. naturally enjoys its position of virtually complete independence of Congress, but for its own protection as well as in the general interests of good administration the C. I. A. ought to be brought into closer contact with legislative authority.
MIAMI, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Doris Hart, the national women's tennis champion who at one time thought she might never walk again, turned professional today after twenty years in the amateur ranks.
Nineteen persons were affected by escaping coal gas fumes in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday.

The Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust has granted fellowships to Mrs. Lois Crisler of Lake George, Colo., and Robert E. Hazel of Louisville, Ky., for the completion of works in progress. Mrs. Crisler is working on a book of personal experiences covering a year and a half of life in the Arctic Circle during which her husband filmed a caribou run.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- A reactionary trend developed today in Board of Trade pits, following a fairly steady tone at the start.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he had instructed his Senate business subcommittee to look into fair trade enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission, the Department of Justice and manufacturers themselves.
BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- Four counties in Massachusetts were named today as disaster areas in the aftermath of the week-end floods.

NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 (UP) -- A small plane crashed into an apartment house and exploded into flames in the midst of a christening party last night. Four persons were killed, including the pilot and the newly christened infant. The pilot was Joel Wolfe Thorne, sportsman.

FOR THOSE who have stared in round-eyed wonder at the slant-eyed look, here are step-by-step directions for going Oriental. Rod Barron of Helena Rubinstein sets the degree of the eye slant with the brow.

Mrs. Clara S. Eaton Voss, founder and president of a small manufacturing concern in Manhattan, left her company to five employes. She died Wednesday. Her will containing the bequest was fried yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
Better understanding among countries, races and cultures will be furthered by the proceeds of a theatre party on Nov. 3 at the Broadhurst Theatre.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- A rescue operation to aid hundreds of stateless seamen, many of whom are unable to leave their ships, has been initiated by the United Nations.
Stocks moved selectively higher yesterday in dull trading, Price changes generally were measured in fractions and in the specialties they ranged from three points higher to two points lower.
WASHINGTON, Oct 18 (AP) -The Department of Justice said today it was studying the price situation in newsprint.

The New York City Ballet will open an eight-week season at the City Center on Nov. 8. This will be its first appearance here since March. Meanwhile it has made an extensive European tour and played a series of engagements on the West Coast and in the Middle West.
The British golf team that will meet the United States aggregation in the Ryder Cup match arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Mary.
The American Retail Federation said yesterday that consumer debt is "within very safe limits."
Full commuter service has been promised for today by the New York Central. Its repair crews worked late yesterday on the 104 miles of track that were out of service because of flood damage.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 18 (UP) -Jimmy Carter of New York will try to win the world lightweight crown for the fourth time tomorrow night in a return fifteenround fight with Wallace (Bud) Smith at the Cincinnati Gardens.

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, took refuge for a time in the Fifth Amendment yesterday. He had been confronted with the words he was alleged to have used to keep dockers off the piers during the eight-day waterfront strike last month.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 18 -Undefeated in the Ivy League, Princeton goes to Cornell this week as the leading rival of Yale for the group championship. The meeting with the Big Red is the first of five successive games the Tiger plays against Ivy opponents.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Oct. 18 (UP) -- A Negro minister who vanished from Lake City has written a letter describing an exchange of shots that preceded his departure.
WASHINGTON, Oct, 18 -George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, said tonight labor's quest for a better life was an effective resistant to communism.

SCHENECTADY, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Republican state chairman tonight envisioned President Eisenhower as "counselor to another progressive Republican" President if he should decide against seeking a second term.
Mayor Wagner held a toplevel conference at City Hall late yesterday to plan assistance to 700 storm victims at Oakwood Beach on Staten Island's south shore.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 18 -- Britain announced today she would more than double her contribution in technical assistance to members of the Colombo Plan.
After twenty-nine consecutive years and over 200 games, Brooklyn College has decided to terminate its intercollegiate football program.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- The Communist Chinese trade fair opened here today. Among the several thousand products shown, some might have bemused a Hairy Ainu fresh from the wilds of Hokkaido, but would hardly impress the average patron of any big Tokyo department store.
If an Eastern college football official can't come up with a reply to a knotty rules problem in a matter of seconds, it isn't because he hasn't been asked the question before under the gun.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 18 -Through passenger traffic between New England and New York is going through all right but it is setting no speed records.
ALTHOUGH the script is old, the play is new. The script is Chekhov's "The Cherry Orchard," which he wrote more than a half century ago.

ANOTHER of the steadily growing number of American artists who have profited by protracted stays in Italy has returned with work done abroad. Adja Yunkers is showing some of his truly extraordinary color wood block prints and monotypes at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The railroads succeeded today in converting a temporary 15 per cent freight rate increase into "fixed income." Simultaneously, there were reports of preparations for a campaign to wrest another 5 per cent from the nations shippers.

For the first time since "The $64,000 Question" television show started, a contestant missed the $32,000 question last night. He was forced to go home with a Cadillac convertible as a consolation prize.

Prospects for the Boston Woven Hose and Rubber Company have never looked better, John M. Bierer, president, told the annual meeting in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday. He said that last month the company had the largest sales of any month in more than three years.

According to disturbing reports from recently freed Austria increasing pressure is being put on some 25,000 refugees from behind the Iron Curtain, still in Austria, to return to their homelands. There is even mention of "repatriation" by force.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 -- The labor camps at Vorkuta, in northern European Russia, are being liquidated, a farmer inmate reported today. Many prisoners are being released from detention on condition that they remain in Vorkuta.

A parcel consisting of an apartment house and a one-family dwelling on the northeast corner of North Avenue and Anderson Street in New Rochelle, N. Y., has been sold by FischerLandis, operators and investors.

Some of the atmosphere of New York's Little Italy, as it appeared around 1890, has been recreated, complete with hurdygurdy music, in an exhibition opening today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.
A compromise designed to win Congressional approval for development of Niagara River hydroelectric power by the State Power Authority was proposed yesterday.

The reaction from Washington and other parts of the country to the tapping of jury deliberations by the University of Chicago group indicates the usual lack of thought and absence of understanding on the part of our governmental officials, both elective and appointive.

A new policy of offering season subscription reservations to a Connecticut-wide public for major plays produced by the Yale School of Drama has been instituted. This was announced yesterday by Dean F. Curtis Canfield.

NEW pastries to tempt even the most strong - willed weightwatcher wore sampled recently in The New York Times' test kitchen. A luscious pie -- apple raisin crunch -- was Schrafft's entry for the tasting, The Bari bakery, with shops on upper Broadway and in the Bronx, sent five unusual delicacies, all of them good to the last bite.

Bloodmobiles of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will visit today the Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation at 444 West Fifty-sixth Street and the New York Typographical Union 6 at 62 West Fourteenth Street.

POINT CLEAR, Ala., Oct. 18 -- Harold E. Stassen, special assistant to President Eisenhower on disarmament, tonight described the United States proposal for international control of nuclear weapons as "flexible."
The stir created over the "bugging" of jury deliberations in Wichita by the University of Chicago lawyers and social scientists is well justified.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18 -Mexico, gradually drying out on her east coast, faces new and serious floods in three states on her Pacific coast.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy shook up the Thirteenth Patrol Division in the Bronx yesterday because he was dissatisfied with its work.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Gordon Wallace of Ontario, Canada, knocked out a former world middleweight champion, Randy Turpin of Leamington Spa, England, tonight in the fourth round. After the fight, Turpin announced his retirement from boxing.
The New York Public Library last night honored Louis M. Rabinowitz, a Lithuanian immigrant who became a bibliophile and philanthropist.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff promised flood-stricken Fairfield County today that the state would help it to rebuild and replan.

Six Soviet newspaper men visited the New York Stock Exchange and the nation's largest brokerage house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane yesterday. They asked a good many questions and said they had had a very nice time.

The 1956 Plymouth will arrive in dealer showrooms here Friday. New York City delivered prices will be announced then. Throughout the line announced yesterday by the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation there are changes from bumper to taillight.
Issues of corporate securities having a market value of more than $44,000,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates as follows:

SCHLOSS BLUEHNBACH, Austria, Oct. 14 -- Hunting the red deer and the chamois (a small goatlike antelope) in the Alps has but one thing in common with hunting the whitetail in the Catskills, Adirondacks or Green Mountains.

All new United States dry cargo vessels of 9,000 deadweight tons or more are being designed to have a service speed of at least eighteen knots. This policy was made known yesterday by Clarence G. Morse, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, in a statement released here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, appointed today two new aides. They will work with a departmental committee to speed research, development and production of manned aircraft systems

Today's new film is "The Girl in the Red Velvet Swing," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama in CinemaScope and color, at the Roxy. Ray Milland, Joan Collins, Farley Granger, Luther Adler and Glenda Farrell head the cast.
Plans for stock splits were made by the boards of directors of four companies yesterday. Three of them also voted dividend distributions.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 18 -A married woman in Brooklyn is claiming $260,000 in the estate of her former husband, as his legal widow. She is Mrs. Myra Richrnan Duck of 339 Ninth Street.
PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Premier Edgar Faure won a vote of confidence tonight continuing his Government in office and approving a program of moderate reforms in Algeria.
The world's airlines were urged yesterday to seek prompt implementation by their governments of measures to cut red tape in international travel.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Traffic accidents will injure 66,000,000 Americans each generation, Thomas N. Boate estimated today.

Ten years ago this month the representatives of twoscore Governments met at Quebec. They had an ambitious purpose. They decided, in the words of Sir John Boyd Orr, now Lord Boyd Orr, "to invite all the nations in the world to cooperate in abolishing hunger and raising the standard of living of land workers, the majority of whom in the underdeveloped countries live in abysmal poverty."

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Governor Harriman set off today what he said he hoped would be a "wholesome chain reaction'' inspiring the state's residents to give more attention to problems of the aging. The Governor spoke at the opening of a three-day conference on problems of the aging.
New York City was accused yesterday of trying to "nullify and destroy" the Fifth Amendment by an "unworthy" and "completely erroneous" argument to the United States Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The "Geneva spirit" is posing serious threats to unity and resolve in the Western world, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was told today.

THE historic message of the first explosion of an atomic bomb was flashed to me in a message from Secretary of War Stimson just before lunch on July 16, 1945 at Potsdam. The most secret and the most daring enterprise of the war had succeeded. We were now in possession of a weapon that would not only revolutionize war but could alter the course of history and civilization.

Up at 5 A. M. On the ice by 6:45 for the first of two daily practice sessions. In school at 10 and back on the ice by 2:15 P. M. This routine has produced the world's No. 2 women's figure skater and two others who are gaining fame in the sport.

Many underprivileged children in the Greenwich Village section will have summer vacations as a result of a series of benefits sponsored by the Greenwich House Camp Fund Parties Committee. The first event will be a cocktail party next Monday at the new Cherry Lane Restaurant, adjoining the Cherry Lane Theatre, at 42 Commerce Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -The Government today came up with a plan to let small businesses in hurricane and floodravaged states buy surplus Federal equipment and materials at about 10 per cent of cost.

The future development of a trucking terminal is planned for a tract of three and one-half acres at the northwest corner of Division Street and Woodruff Lane in Elizabeth, N. J., which has been purchased by the Johnson Brothers Trucking Company of Newark.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 (AP) -Union and company officials -with Government urging -- made a new attempt today to settle a two-day strike of 44,000 workers at thirty Westinghouse Electric Corporation plants. Neither side appeared optimistic.
POINT CLEAR, Ala., Oct. 18 -- Southern Governors for the most part were cool today to any move to form a regional coalition for a more decisive role in next year's Democratic National Convention.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Following is the transcript of the record of the news conference held today by Secretary of State Dulles.

On that greatest of all days in the meteoric career of Juan Domingo Peron -- Oct. 17, 1945 -- as he stood on the balcony of the Casa Rosada in Buenos Aires, with many thousands of wildly cheering workers below him in the Plaza de Mayo, someone should have gone up to him and whispered in his ear: "Beware of Nemesis!"

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 -- Desilu Productions has added two new television film projects to its production schedule. The company will produce the 90minute CBS-TV spectacle "High Tor" on color film with Bing Crosby in the starring role.
Two of the Russian players triumphed last night in the eleventh round of the women's challengers' chess tournament, according to a report from Moscow.

A Wall Street man envisages the day when advertisers will not only state that their product is a pretty good buy but that theirs is a pretty good company in which to buy stocks. Louis Engle, partner in charge of advertising of Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, drew that picture yesterday before a luncheon of the Advertising Women of New York in the Sheraton Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Washington's 846,000 residents will be required to flee the city in the event of a probable bombing attack, District officials were advised today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- An important indication of the Government's economic thinking emerged from the Federal Reserve today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Hog prices slipped to a new low since Jan. 4, 1946 in slow trade today. The decline came even though salable receipts, at 13,000 head, were in line with the advance estimate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The chairman of the Republican National Committee, Leonard W. Hall, denied today that he had ever said President Eisenhower might not make up his mind about running again until "shortly before the convention in San Francisco next August."
Transit management and labor have decided to go to school to learn more about their major problem -- traffic.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The British motor industry unveiled today its answer to the increasing threat to its export markets from other countries.
A chemical difference between cancer cells and normal human cells has been discovered.
A Queens couple who came here from Germany four years ago received last night a cable from their only son saying he had been freed from imprisonment in the Soviet Union.
The P. Lorillard Company and the Revlon Products Corporation finally have agreed to share sponsorship of a new television show titled "The $64,000 Panel."
A long-sought atomic particle that nature has until now hidden from man has been created artificially in man's most powerful "atom-machine" at the University of California.
From Oct. 18 through Oct. 20 there is an important Governor's Conference on Problems of the Aging in Albany.

Events tonight: "Art of the Fugue," orchestra conducted by Beatrice Brown, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Esther Fernandez, pianist, Town Hall 8:30; Telemann Society, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:15; New York Trio, New School for Social Research, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The Army Engineers "manufactured" a giant hurricane sea wave today, said to be the first ever produced by man, at a new research laboratory built to combat floods and beach erosion.
PAUL FERDINAND du Marchie van Voorthuysen, a tall, dark-bearded, exotically clad mystic, has set up house in a station wagon on the Holland-America Line pier at Fifth Street, in Hoboken.
GENEVA, Oct. 18 -- The intergovernmental effort to assist migration from Europe to less crowded overseas areas is running into serious financial difficulties.
DENVER, Oct. 18 -- President Eisenhower moved closer today to a return to an active life.
LAS VEGAS, Oct. 18 (UP) -Donald Campbell surveyed the damage to his jet-powered Bluebird II today and said the speedboat appeared to be in much better shape than he had anticipated.

As one of those for whose alleged protection there is presently a bill before the City Council to prohibit the use of kerosene heaters to some as yet undetermined extent, I would like to register my strong protest.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Beware of a labor shortage rather than an army of unemployed in the years ahead, a manufacturer told Congress today.
SIMONETTA and Fabiani are probably the only couple in the world who have made their marriage work by agreeing to disagree.
CAIRO, Oct. 18 -- An Egyptian midget jumped square into the political laps of four United States Senators here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today he expected to talk over the Middle Eastern situation with Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov of the Soviet Union at Geneva. Mr. Dulles held his last Washington news conference before the Big Four foreign ministers' meeting on Oct. 27.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- An airline union representing flight engineers said today its members lines Snetaoietaoi ET ET ET E would strike against United Air Lines Saturday.

WHAT is the South? This morning's books bring us three views of its changing and enduring patterns through the eyes of a creative artist, a blithe tourist and a happy critic. Who are they? They are William Faulkner, Emily Kimbrough and H. L. Mencken.
PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 18 -Residents of the flood-stricken areas of Passaic, Morris and Bergen Counties were advised today to boil all drinking water.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Sales and profits of manufacturers both hit record highs in the second quarter of this year, two Government agencies reported today.
The Canadian dollar, which has been worth more than the United States dollar since March 1, 1952, may fall to an equal or lesser value today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -President Eisenhower, who has been listening to music recordings during his convalescene in Denver, will get a special recording of the National Symphony's concert tomorrow night.

AT 9:30 last night, when the drama called "The Battler" began on Channel 4, there were reasons to hope that something special might be in prospect. The presentation was based on a story by Ernest Hemingway.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 19 -- The Soviet Union has told the Western Big Three that it will continue to control Allied military traffic between West Berlin and West Germany.
ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Republican legislative leaders declared today that state fiscal reports had indicated Governor Harriman's "irresponsibility" in vetoing their tax-cut bills this year.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- A major expansion of frozen food production by Libby, McNeill Libby was announced today by Charles S. Bridges, president.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 18 -- The Board of Selectmen has complained to New York City that the closing of a tunnel between the Byram River and Kensico Reservoir played a part in the heavy flooding here.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 18 (AP) -- A resolution calling for a Congressional investigation of the newsprint industry was released today by the Empire State District Council of the American Newspaper Guild.

The New York Rangers, with new players and a new coach, make their home debut of the 1955-56 season tonight skating aaginst the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. The National Hockey League game will start at 8:30.

CHICAGO, Oct 18 -- Four directors will resign tomorrow from the Liquid Carbonic Corporation's thirteen-man board to make room for four additional representatives of a group holding a strong minority interest in the company, sources close to the management said today.

Rubber futures soared on the Commodity Exchange of New York in active trading yesterday. Higher prices abroad induced heavy short covering. Contracts were supplied by long liquidation and profit taking. The close was up 170 to 200 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 4,670 tons.

LOUISE KRUGER displays her talent in two mediums, sculpture and printmaking, in an exhibition of recent work at the Artists Gallery, 851 Lexington Avenue. In both, she deals with figures in a strained, exalted near-realist style, but the sculpture makes the stronger impression.

NEWARK, Oct. 18 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight of California said here today that "it is too early to say" that President Eisenhower would not be a candidate for re-election. He considered it "quite conceivable" that the President would run again.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Our Middle Eastern policy will now have to be reexamined as a result of Soviet intervention in the area. One of the first problems to be faced is an Israeli request for a United States security guarantee plus new supplies of arms to counterbalance those Moscow is making available to the Arabs.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 18 -A new agreement carrying the British Protectorate of Uganda closer to self-government was signed here today. The signers were Sir Andrew Cohen, Governor of Uganda, and the Kabaka of Buganda, who returned yesterday from two years' exile in London.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Charles E. Wilson called on Department of Defense officials today to save $500,000,000 in next year's defense budget.
Governor Harriman predicted yesterday that courses in probation would one day become an important part of the curriculum of "many of our great universities."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 18 -One of Brazil's best known generals was relieved of his post today without public explanation. It was rumored he was being disciplined for utterances in connection with current political tension.
New York may be a "melting pot" to some people but to Mayor Wagner it is a place where everyone has the right to be different.

Having demonstrated their adeptness with "Othello," "Twelfth Night" and "The Merchant of Venice," the Shakespearewrights are getting around to "Macbeth." Starting at 7:45 o'clock this evening, the tragedy will be examined at the Jan Hus Auditorium, 351 East Seventyfourth Street.
There are many ways of saying "thank you." The United Service Organizations hears them all. Each month 20,000 G. I.'s are served at the U. S. O.'s Information Center, just off Times Square.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 -An Institute for Basic Research in Science, in some respects similar to the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, has been established at the University of California, Chancellor Clark Kerr announced last night.

The possibility of a radical increase in resistance to tuberculosis through the use of hormones was advanced here yesterday. The suggestion was made by Dr. Max Lurie of the Henry Phipps Institute of the University of Pennsylvania.

Four individuals and a church have been named to receive special citations for outstanding contributions to social welfare in this country, the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. announced yesterday.
BOSTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Representative John W. McCormack, House Majority floor leader, today asked Secretary of State John Foster Dulles to protest the increase in the price of Canadian newsprint.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Miss Margaret Divver of Boston, advertising manager of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, was appointed head of the Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Services today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 -- A statistical survey of the economic development of television from 1949 through 1954 was started today in Federal Court in Los Angeles as film company defendants began the presentation of evidence in the Government's anti-trust suit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -Staate Department officials said today they had received no information as reported from Geneva that Austria was forcing Iron Curtain refugees to return to the countries from which they had escaped.
The City of Philadelphia borrowed $39,920,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of serial bonds maturing on July 1 and Jan. 1 from 1957 to 1981.

A sober music critic of The New York Times went obviously far, in his own opinion, seventy-three years ago this week when he wrote that the music of Jacques Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" "might have been written by Meyerbeer and Gounod combined."

North American Aviation, Inc., aircraft producer, has announced the establishment of a separate division called Atomics International to handle its nuclear engineering and manufacturing operations. J. H. Kindelberger, chairman, said the division would be an integrated organization that could provide all services necessary for reactor development, manufacture and operation.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Oct. 18 -- Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard arrived here today for their first royal visit.

Governor Harriman last night called for reaffirmation of the 1950 declaration by the United States, Britain and France pledging immediate action against any nation preparing to violate the Arab-Israel borders.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 -Gen. Eduardo Lonardi, Argentina's provisional President, issued a decree today abolishing the law of desacato (disrespect). Under this law any Argentine citizen making a remark that could be constructed as disparaging against a public functionary could be imprisoned.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- The drawing up of realistic health standards for merchant seafarers was recommended today at the annual convention of the Marine Section, National Safety Council.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Oct. 18 -Canada's newest province told a royal commission today that it could contribute much to the country's prosperity if it had federal help in developing its natural resources.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 18 -There was preparation on two fronts at The Hill School today for the Blue and Gray's football game with Penn Military College Prep next Saturday.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- After opening dull, British Government securities rallied today to finish the only consistently improved section of the stock market here. Demand for industrials declined and buying was selective
MILTON BERLE'S second show of the season appeared on Channel 4 last night in a new format which made one feel that he never should have left home.

Companies needing outside marketing assistance can obtain it best through an advertising agency, it was said yesterday by Daniel A. Packard, vice president and senior marketing executive of McCann-Erickson, Inc.
OMAHA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A banana-filled Marine Corps recruit boarded a train tonight on his way to boot training after literally eating his way into a Marine uniform.
A Canadian company raised newsprint prices yesterday to the highest level in the modern history of the industry.

The Brooklyn Borough Hall Welfare Center was dedicated yesterday by Mayor Wagner and other city officials. It is the newest addition to that borough's civic center and the city's second structure to house regional welfare activities.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner put aside his bat today for a swivel-chair job.
BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- A White House adviser indicated here today that plans to balance the budget are "flexible" and will be "adapted to the good of stable economic growth."
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Twenty - eight sandhogs escaped from the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel tonight when fire in a donkey engine filled the tunnel with poisonous fumes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -House Democratic investigators overrode Republican protests today and refused to give the Georgia Power Company an immediate chance to give its side of the Clark Hill power controversy.

Secretary of Agriculture Benson must be beginning to suspect that he has a genuinely Sisyphean task on his hands in trying to cut the country's mountainous stock of cotton down to a level where it bears some reasonable relationship to potential consumption.

In its first change of ownership in about fifty years, the five-story commercial building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 1151 Third Avenue, northeast corner of Sixty-seventh Street, has been sold by Millie P. Wildnauer to David S. Meister, realty operator.
Record sales for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30 were recorded by the Radio Corporation of America and domestic subsidiaries, it was reported by David Sarnoff, chairman.
Among the casualties of last week-end's stormy weather was the thirty-foot tower on Cole Field from which Coach Len Watters had been directing Williams College football practice.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The United States and the Soviet Union started negotiations today to draft an atoms-for-peace resolution.

The news that state tax receipts are running so far ahead of expectations that a surplus of $50,000,000 or $60,000,000 in this fiscal year may be in the making is highly encouraging, yet the good tidings should be read in relation to other aspects of the budgetary situation.

Former President Herbert Hoover said yesterday it was up to laymen and industry to find the funds needed to accommodate more pre-medical students in medical schools and thus alleviate the shortage of physicians. Mr. Hoover discussed support of private medical schools in accepting the Frank H. Lahey Award for "outstanding leadership in medical education" at a ceremony in his suite at the Waldorf Towers.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Branch Rickey said today he would step out Nov. 1 as general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates. During his five-year regime the team finished last four times and seventh once.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 12:

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Wallace (Bud) Smith of Cincinnati retained his world lightweight title tonight by outpointing Jimmy Carter of New York. However, there was a question whether his fifteen-round decision over the three-time champion was split or unanimous as a confusing situation developed after the bout.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 19 -- Premier Moshe Sharett accused the Soviet Union today of having created danger of war in the Middle East.

The pulpits of America were described last night as neglected sources of psychiatric guidance at the dedication of the new headquarters of the American Foundation of Religion and Psychiatry, 3 West Twenty-ninth Street.
The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation attained record sales and earnings in the first nine months of this year.
The Hudson Guild Neighborhood House, one of New York's largest and oldest settlement houses, will be the beneficiary of two theatre parties this season.

The 1956 Pontiac cars have a new type of automatic transmission designed to provide smoother, quieter gear-shifting and more efficient use of power. The line was announced yesterday by the Pantiac division of the General Motors Corporation. Models will go on display in dealer showrooms here tomorrow, when city delivered prices will be announced.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Kremlin, breaking a decade of silence, has disclosed the death in a Soviet jail of Gen. Leopold Okulicki, a top commander in the Polish wartime resistance against the Nazis.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Yesterday's rally in British Government securities was extended today, with gains of between two shillings sixpence (35 cents) and seven shillings sixpence common.
Intensive negotiations were promised yesterday to head off a possible milk strike in the metropolitan area at 4 P. M. Monday.

IT was in 1934 that Asa Bushnell dreamed himself a dream. The then graduate manager of athletics at Princeton University found himself faced with a problem that is common to all mankind, finances. He had to pay the freight for the Princeton-Cornell team on the even of its trip-abroad to meet Oxford-Cambridge in track.

GENEVA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A secret hearing was held here today on Mrs. Kathryn Bernstein's appeal against her dismissal by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization for "lack of integrity."

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- With demand very slow. butcher hogs sold steady to 25 cents lower today. That brought prices to another new low since Jan. 4, 1946. Steady quotation were paid on early round. Later the entire market was down 25 cents and in some instances 35 cents. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 19 (Reuters) -- British Field Marshal Sir John Harding declared today that as commander in chief of Cyprus he "will not have Her Majesty's armed forces insulted."

Franklin Knobel and Norman Bender have completed the assemblage of a site for a supermarket on the northeast corner of Ogden Avenue and West 166th Street, in the Bronx, with the purchase of land from Harry Durning, former Collector of the Port of New York.
An electrical typewriter that can punch out whole words or simple phrases at the touch of a single key was demonstrated here yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad's profit nearly tripled in the first nine months of this year compared with the same period in 1954.
On tonight's calendar are two events -- "No Time for Sergeants,'' at the Alvin, and "Ruddigore," at the Shubert. Each will get under way at 8 o'clock.
A five-year program calling for the reclamation and development of 250,000 acres in Israel has been recently started.
PARIS, Oct. 19 (Reuters) -- Jean Cocteau will become a member of the 320-year-old French Academy tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct, 19 -- "Les Girls," described as a gay, romantic story about four show girls in Paris, was announced today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as one of the first pictures to be produced by Sol Siegel, who has an independent producing arrangement with the company.

Group Securities, Inc., one of the largest mutual funds, notified stockholders yesterday that year-end capital gains distributions from certain of its funds would be so large as to warrant their declaration in shares, with cash optional,
A group of business men will soon make an important investment in this city's youngsters, a member of the New York State Probation Commission reported yesterday.

The police of eleven states are hunting for the one or more miscreants who put a surprise ending to the wanderings of nine Colt pistols. This, according to Deputy Inspector Frederick M. Lussen in charge of Manhattan West detectives, is what happened:

ANSONIA, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Carrying signs reading, "We Can't Take It Any More," residents of this flood-weary city stormed a City Hall mass meeting this afternoon to demand an end to the Naugatuck River's rampages.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Improvements in the number of contacts between Communist countries and the Western bloc is the most that higher echelons of the British Government expect from next week's Geneva conference.
Rock-'n-roll hockey, as promised in advance and later delivered in person by the Rangers' Lou Fontinato, ushered in the Madison Square Garden hockey season last night.

A publishers' spokesman declared yesterday that the newsprint price increase on Tuesday by one Canadian company was surprising in view of the stand taken by several other leading Canadian Producers, who indicated they plan no price rises at this time.
The Jersey City, N. J., Sewerage Authority borrowed $13,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of serial revenue bonds maturing on Jan. 1 from 1959 to 1993 and callable in 1962.
REGGIO DI CALABRIA, Italy, Oct. 19 -- This ancient city in southern Italy is undergoing a thorough clean-up.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 -- A poll of California Republican leaders shows Vice President Richard M. Nixon far ahead of other possible 1956 Presidential contenders in popularity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Representative Earl Chudoff said today an investigation of the Eisenhower Administration's power policy by his House subcommittee had shown the Interior Department was "sabotaging" public power laws.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Britain has no intention of surrendering control of the Royal Air Force's Fighter Command despite warnings that Allied air defenses in Europe must be more closely integrated.

Benjamin Franklin's portrait is probably more widely known than that of any American except those who served as President. Because of his long residence in England and in France quite a few distinguished painters and sculptors were able to make studies of his features from life, thus furnishing a variety of originals from skilled hands to be copied in profusion in each succeeding generation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 -- Senator Estes Kefauver saw today evidence of "monopolistic concentration" and an "incoming danger of totalitarianism" in a report by a committee to Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee announced today a new series of fund-raising dinners and party gatherings, with Governor Harriman of New York listed for four speaking appearances in the Northwest.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Senator Johnson today told The San Antonio Express that he was not trying to line up a coalition against an automatic nomination of Mr. Stevenson for President.

The death of Jose Ortega y Gasset on Tuesday will bring a crowd of memories back to all who are old enough to remember the Spanish Republican Revolution, the civil war and the great intellectual conflict of the century, which Spain has yet to settle.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- It is a question who is gamer under punishment -- the Pennsylvania football players or their coach, Steve Sebo.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Navy Ministry announced today that Alberto Teisaire, a retired admiral and vice president of Argentina when Juan D. Peron's regime fell, would be tried by a five-man Naval Court of Honor.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Florida Supreme Court, in a 5-2 decision, delayed desegregation today at the University of Florida until it can be determined that the all-white school is ready to accept Negro students without harmful effects.

Edward Arnoldi's fifty years "at the most enjoyable work" will be celebrated today with a golden jubilee luncheon at the Commodore Hotel. His half century has been spent at the city headquarters of the Young Men's Christian Association, where he rose from office boy to assistant treasurer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Farm income, a hot and growing political issue, dipped sharply again in the third quarter of this year.

A decline last week of 526,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 150,480,000 barrels, compared with 151,006,000 a week earlier and 150,676,000 a year ago.
