Mme. Larissa Volpert of Russia regained the lead in the women's challengers' chess tournament last night when she defeated Mme. Vera Jovanovic-Nedeljkovic of Yugoslavia, according to a report from Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The exasperations of working in alliance with the Soviet Union are documented in the official account of events leading up to Moscow's entry into the war against Japan a decade ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Senate Preparedness Investigating subcommittee cited today what it called "a case history of frustration and confusion in defense procurement." It was said to be one of many.
NO one will be bored by the production of "Macbeth" which the Shakespeare wrights opened at the Jan Hus Auditorium last evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The membership of the two major parties is mutually inclusive of many citizens whose political philosophy seems to be about the same. Therefore, certain influences must provide the explanation why one of these citizens is a Democrat and another a Republican in a period when the line of demarcation becomes more and more blurred.

BOTH pears and grapes now are in good supply. And these fruits are here in great variety. The following descriptions might serve as a guide to the variety names, many of them not always easy to remember. The grapes are all of the kind the trade describes as "table," that is, for eating fresh.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 18 -- Rio de Janeiro was uneasy today over the dismissal of two generals last night.

The eleventh seagoing Naval Merchant Marine Company to be formed aboard an American steamship based in the Port of New York was activated yesterday. The unit, made up of officers and seamen of the Panama Line passenger ship Panama, was commissioned in a brief ceremony aboard the liner at Pier 64, Hudson River and Twenty-fourth Street.

Aluminium, Ltd., large Canadian producer of aluminum, plans to expand its primary aluminum capacity in Quebec by 22,000 tons a year. The cost of the program, which will be started immediately, is estimated at $15,000,000.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- A Democratic legislative leader proposed today that the state investigate the possibility of granting tax benefits to companies that employ older workers.
BERLIN, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Sherman R. Knapp, chairman of Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff's Flood Recovery Committee, announced tonight recommendations to speed relief and recovery.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The General Assembly failed today to break the deadlock over a seat in the United Nations Security Council.

YONKERS, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Beware scored a length victory in the Palisades Pace before 15,352 persons at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 4-year-old gelding, owned and driven by Jack Brown of Macon, Ga., covered the mile in 2:06 2-5 and paid $21.20 for $2.
ATLANTA, Oct. 19 -- Georgia's Attorney General accused today the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People of "subversion" in its anti-segregation crusade.
ON August 10, at 7:33 in the morning, our radio monitors heard this news item being given out over Radio Tokyo:

A campaign in all types of media led by a four-color four-page newspaper insert described as adding "a new dimension" to newspaper advertising has been planned to introduce the 1956 Plymouth automobile.
NEWARK, Oct. 19 -- Federal regulation was suggested here today to end recurrent price wars that have plagued New Jersey's retail gasoline dealers for almost twenty years.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- The Franklin Institute awarded medals tonight to eleven men for outstanding achievements in the field of science.
The nation's department stores bettered their net profit margin during the first-half of 1955 by 50 per cent, according to figures released yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 19 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood fired a 41, 39 -- 80 to take gross honors in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament at Piping Rock today.

A third centralized clinic for after-care treatment for mental patients in the New York City area has been opened in Queens, Dr. Paul H. Hoch, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, announced yesterday. The new clinic is at 150-11 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica.

HONG KONG, Oct. 19 -- Mao Tse-tung, Communist China's chairman, was reported today to have said he would be willing to visit the United States if he were invited. He was said to have added he did not expect such an invitation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Soybean and most grain futures were weak in early trading today. But wheat and corn staged a good recovery from their lowest. Wheat closed up slightly, and changes in corn prices were small and mixed Oats and rye finished above yesterday's closing levels; soybeans were down.
Baseball's sacrifice-fly rule caused a general increase of 2.1 points in major league batting averages in 1955.
Inspired by the oils, chemicals and metals, the stock market rose yesterday for the sixth consecutive day.
New Yorkers do not often have a chance to hear Johann Sebastian Bach's last, great masterpiece, "The Art of Fugue," which was presented in Carnegie Hall last night.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- When man divorces his daily work from his religion, the results are "invariably calamitous."

Management and labor both understand the importance of the job of the United Service Organizations in this period of armed peace. For industry has a similar problem. When routine jobs become humdrum, efficiency is impaired. Accidents can happen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Secretary of State Dulles will brief a bipartisan group of Congressional leaders tomorrow on the four - power foreign ministers conference in Geneva.
Cargo handling on the Pan Atlantic Line freighter Chickasaw was halted at her Port Newark pier yesterday when the ship's seamen honored a longshoremen's picket line.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Princess Margaret and other members of the royal family dined tonight with the Archbishop of Canterbury. He is head of the Church of England, which, it is said, would oppose her marriage to Group Captain Peter Townsend.

Packard has zoomed into the 1956 horsepower derby with a 310-horsepower engine. The new line was announced yesterday by the Packard division of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation. This is the highest rating yet presented in the 1956 models.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Oct. 19 -- The proposal for an international police force to insure order in the Saar referendum next Sunday has been rejected. The approximately 1,500 Saar state policemen will be the only force on duty.

Like most people I was glad to read about the expansion plans of the Ford Motor Company because of the importance of high levels of business investment spending to the maintenance of prosperity and full employment.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 19 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, the state medal and match play champion, led New Jersey to a 40 1/2-to-4 1/2 victory over a team of Westchester-Fairfield golfers today at the Rock Spring Club. It was the twenty-sixth meeting between the teams since 1925.
Women searching for jobs may find useful information in two recently published pamphlets.

The New York Central Railroad resumed full runs yesterday on two flood-damaged commuter divisions, but it lost ground upstate to the swollen Mohawk River. A washout at Cransville, near Amsterdam, made two of the four main line tracks unusable and delayed trains between the West and New York City.

Net income and net sales of the Crucible Steel Company and wholly owned subsidiaries for the nine months ended Sept. 30 increased 434 per cent and 45 per cent, respectively, above results achieved in the corresponding period of 1954.

A HANDSOME molded salad of cottage cheese and the grapes that now are so plentiful makes a delicious and timely center of interest for a bridge or women's club luncheon. Given today is a recipe for this concoction and for several other salads that make use of vegetables that are at their best in the fall.

Two hold-up men robbed a woman messenger of $1,200 in payroll checks in a Pennsylvania Railroad train yesterday while forty other passengers looked on helplessly. The robbers escaped. The company quickly stopped payment on the checks.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur could not be reached yesterday for comment on the Department of Defense report concerning the Yalta controversy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The dispute over whether General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had or had not urged Soviet participation in the war against Japan gave the Defense Department historian one of his major jobs.
The head of the world's largest manufacturing corporation thinks business will be very good for the rest of this year and in 1956.
PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Premier Edgar Faure began today the application of his Algerian reform program. Also, he began a study of the political advantages to be drawn from his improved political position.
DETROIT, Oct. 19 -- The Chevrolet Motor Division of the General Motors Corporation expects to set new records in automobile production this year and again in 1956.

Why doesn't the Civil Defense Council eliminate these air raid siren tests once and for all? Aside from the fact that they are quite irritating, there is the more serious factor that the public is becoming so accustomed to these tests that when and if the real thing comes along it will think of it as "just another test."

In anticipation of the new Geneva conference, at which Germany will be the main topic of discussion, Moscow has delivered a seemingly reassuring but still equivocal reply to the Western protests against threats of a new Berlin blockade voiced by the East German puppet regime.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California criticized today "some of our Allies" for "supporting Communist Yugoslavia in a bid for a seat on the United Nations Security Council."

Late fall and Christmas volume of men's sports and leisure wear should run about 15 per cent ahead of last year's excellent figures, according to Harry Doniger, president of David D. Doniger Company, producer of McGregor sportswear.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Florida Supreme Court ruled today that hotel picketing in the Miami area was unlawful because the Hotel Employes Union, A. F. L., represented "an insignificant number" of workers.
President Eisenhower took up some problems of national defense this week, but in cursory form and without any detailed analysis of next year's defense budget.
BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 19 -- Next Saturday is an open date on Blair Academy's football schedule but it never could have been guessed from the way the Blue and White practiced today.

The Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for September and for the nine and twelve months ended Sept. 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Barrows Dunham, former professor of philosophy at Temple University in Philadelphia, was acquitted in Federal District Court of charges of contempt of Congress.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Bluebird II, the sleek, jet hydroplane that sank last Sunday after an ill-fated speed attempt by England's Don Campbell, today was moved to Nellis Air Force Base.

Two utility companies serving multi-state areas are pressing campaigns to promote new temperature controls for top burners as the major feature of 1956 gas ranges. Other concerns serving additional markets are watching the promotion closely, and several have made known that they are planning similar local advertising.
Slum clearance will do away with the Bowery in five or ten years, thus increasing tenfold arrests of vagrants and alcoholics, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Federal Communications Commission authorized the American Telegraph and Telephone Company today to start work on the Air Force's multibillion dollar SAGE aircraft warning system.
Air commuters between New York and Chicago will get an additional seventy flights a week starting Oct. 30.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 -- A contempt-of-court sentence ordered last March against William H. Timbers of Washington, chief counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was set aside here today.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 19 -- Hudson County Superintendent of Elections William MacPhail of Kearny was named in thirteen of fifty-six indictments handed up today by a special Hudson County grand jury to Superior Court Judge Hayden Proctor.

A two-thirds increase in total advertising over the next fifteen years was predicted yesterday by Dexter Merriam Keezer, vice president and director of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. This would be a rise from the current annual rate of $8,500,000,000 to $14,500,000,000 in 1970, he said.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--An attorney for a dismissed teacher argued before the Supreme Court today that states may not pass laws that require surrender of rights guaranteed by the Federal Constitution.

THE lariat, the buffalo and the cow pony. These three bring the legendary West to mind as quickly as any other symbols. They are strewn lavishly through three big picture books on our table this morning: "The American West: The Pictorial Epic of a Continent,"* by Lucius Beebe and Charles Clegg; "The Settlers' West: Taming the Western Land," by Martin F. Schmitt and Dee Brown; "The Pony Express," by Lee Jensen.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 19 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey predicted tonight that Adlai E. Stevenson would head the Democratic national ticket next year and that the party would win a "sweeping victory."
A RUG is all the furniture needed by nomadic peoples. It is a floor, a blanket, a place for sleeping, eating and sitting -- and this portable home can be rolled up and carried on a camel's back.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- There were sights around the United Nations today to make even trained diplomats lift an eyebrow.
In your front page article in The Times of Oct. 16 your reporter Benjamin Fine describes an appalling shortage of engineers in most branches of industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Department of Defense has rejected pleas that older draftees in service -- married men and fathers -- be released and replaced by younger eligibles. It also does not contemplate deferment of men in those classes.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The New York Yankees are scheduled to arrive today. Baseball-mad Japan is expected to greet the American League champions with one of its "ichi-ban" (No. 1) red-carpet welcomes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A challenge to the provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 under which aliens awaiting deportation are held in "supervisory parole" was argued in the Supreme Court today.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon replied last night to Democratic charges that the Eisenhower Administration favored big business.

A PERFORMANCE of compelling sincerity by Lillian Gish imparted interest last night to a drama in which the author, Paul Crabtree, regrettably wrote himself into a corner. What promised to be a stimulating play on morality in politics finished up as a trite whodunit.
BONN Germany, Oct. 19 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Economics Minister, submitted today to the Bundestag an eleven-point program designed to avert a threat of inflation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Spokesmen for organized medicine advised Congress today to go slow in any move to tighten Federal control of barbiturate drugs.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Delegates to the General Assembly stood for a minute in silence today to honor the memory of Dr. Davila.
A quarter-million dollars worth of prize-winning diamond jewelry dazzled the public yesterday when the second annual "Diamonds U. S. A." awards were presented at the Plaza Hotel.

The Philhalunonic SymphonyI Orchestra ill open itz ll4th season tonight in Calmegie Hall under the direction of Dimitri[ Mitropoulos. In observation of[ I the bicentennial of Mozart's[ birth, the program will consist entirely of that master's works.
A one-day strike yesterday won 6,000 Mack Manufacturing Company employes wage increases, improved welfare and other fringe benefits and promise of a guaranteed annual wage.
PARIS, Oct. 19 (Reuters) Thousands of Parisian jazz fans battled with the police and smashed chairs and pictures at a concert tonight by Sidney Bechet, American clarinetist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- It will take more documentary evidence than the Pentagon made public today to settle the controversy over the role of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in the events that led the Soviet Union to join the war against Japan three weeks before it ended.
DENVER, Oct. 19 -- Secretary of State Dulles took a cautiously optimistic line today toward the Big Four foreign ministers' conference in Geneva next week.
Moscow encountered Brooklyn -- sixth grade division -- for the first time yesterday and promptly lost its heart in an unequal encounter.
THE search for the Northwest Passage was a languid feeler compared to the ardent efforts by scattergun shooters to come up with a practical all-round shotgun.
All airlines operating across the North Atlantic are being invited to provide 40 per cent reductions in fares for G.I.'s in Europe who are paying their way home on leave.

Esther Fernandez, pianist, played a debut recital at Town Hall last night. A product of the Juilliard School where she studied with Rosina Lhevinne and Nadia Reisenberg, Miss Fernandez has won an impressive number of awards and prizes, including the Recital Award of the New York Madrigal Society.
POINT CLEAR, Ala., Oct. 19--Southern Governors assembled here for their annual conference continued today to emphasize the political problems posed by next year's Presidential election.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 19 (UP) -- Jack Delaney's Lenny G., a Best Seller colt that won the first start of his career two months ago, caught the pacesetting Ancient Greek in the stretch at Garden State Park today and went on to score a nose triumph in the $11,775 New Jersey Breeders Stakes.

The Chamber of Commerce Building, a six-story office structure at 39-01 Main Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Vincent Astor to an investing client of Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc. Brooks, Harvey Co. were the brokers in the sale.

Eric Guerin and the Foxcatcher Farms' 4-year-old Alibhai colt, Chevation, a combination of fine riding and fancy stepping, won the sixteenth running of the $20,000-added New York Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 19 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, leader of the Opposition, said tonight that Vyacheslav M. Molotov had branded Soviet espionage documents as fabricated.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Acquisition of the White Cap Products division of the White Cap Company, Chicago, by the Webster-Chicago Corporation for almost $1,000,000 was announced today by Titus Haffa, Webster-Chicago president.
RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 19 -- Spain was reported today to have protested in Paris against the machine-gunning by a French plane of a hamlet in the Spanish zone of Morocco.

PAINTINGS and drawings by the late Jankel Adler are being shown at the Meltzer (Serigraph Society) Gallery, 38 West Fifty-seventh Street. Adler, conscripted into the Russian Army in World War I, later worked with Paul Klee in Duesseldorf, was forced to flee from Germany during the Nazi ascendency and died in 1949 in England, where he had taken refuge.

A three-hour, six-sport program that will be part of the Olympic Fund drive will be held in Madison Square Garden tonight. It is sponsored by the United States Olympic Committee and is billed as the "kickoff" for National Olympic Day, proclaimed for Saturday by President Eisenhower. The starting time is 8 o'clock.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 19 (AP) -- State Senator Walter J. Mahoney said today he would ask Governor Harriman to approve reinstatement of the 10 per cent "forgiveness" on state income taxes next year. He added that he might even push for a higher percentage of "forgiveness."

If any further proof were needed of the artificial and synthetic character of the Zionist movement it is offered in C. L. Sulzberger's sympathetically written column on Israel in The Times of Oct. 12.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Defense Department released today a documentary review of the Pacific War that showed virtually all the nation's military leaders favored Soviet participation in the knockout blow against Japan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--The Soviet Union started building a space ship early this year. It also plans to spend $20,000,000 on the project, Aero Digest Magazine said today.
Efforts to involve non-Israeli Jews in the problems of Israel's national security were attacked yesterday by Clarence L. Coleman Jr., president of the American Council for Judaism.

DOROTHY ANDREWS. exhibiting recent paintings at the Passedoit Gallery, 121 East Fifty-seventh Street, is a generous painter whose exuberance is matched by a well-developed, personal technique. In her boldly plotted landscapes -- many of the New England coast and some of the Southwest -- Miss Andrews finds the specific rhythms and peculiar play of light of each terrain, interpreting them with a sure, swinging brush.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 19 -- Preparations are under way to rebuild the Synagogue of Worms, the oldest Jewish edifice in Central Europe and one of the greatest centers of Hebrew scholarship in the Middle Ages.
A national church organization is considering the presentation of a one-hour jazz program on New Year's Eve over the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network.
The State Insurance Department is asking applicants for licenses if they have ever been members of 130 organizations that have been listed as Communist or Fascist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. predicted today that President Eisenhower would seek another term and win by a landslide if he felt conditions in the United States and the world required his continued leadership.

Sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company for the thirty-six weeks ended Sept. 4 were higher than in any corresponding period in the company's history, Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman, and Albert K. Chapman, president, announced yesterday.
CONSTANTA, Rumania, Oct. 18 -- In this Black Sea port closeness to the Soviet Union is balanced by sharper evidences of apathy to communism than are visible in Bucharest, the capital.

Commodities on the New York futures markets were generally lower yesterday. Cocoa, cottonseed, oil, rubber, hides, burlap, silk and zinc declined; potatoes, onions, and copper rose, and coffee, sugar, soybean oil and wool closed mixed.
The bull market in airplane sales reached into the helicopter field yesterday.
A more comprehensive, program of health care for the aged, with greater attention to preventive measures and rehabilitation, was called for yesterday by three city officials.
Directors of the Lehman Corporation will "take under consideration" the possibility of splitting the common stock, Robert Lehman, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday.
Members of the Board of Health visited two cavernous dwellings in Harlem yesterday, and at once promised to crack down or occupancy of insanitary cellar apartments.
The value of the Canadian dollar slipped below that of the United States dollar yesterday for the first time in three and a half years.

An Oriental motif, carried out in decorations of red, white, black and gold, will provide the background tonight for Le Festival de Poivre, a gala dinner dance to be held in the grand ballroom of the Ambassador.
PARIS, Oct. 19 (AP)--A French Government decree published today sets forth safety precautions for Grand Prix automobile races and limits speeds for rallies.

Two Brooklyn boys, members of a teen-age gang in the Bedford - Stuyvesant section, confessed last night to stabbing a schoolboy to death, the police said. The reason: he was supposed to have said that he knew that the Bishops, one neighborhood gang, had sold a shotgun to the Chaplains, another gang.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Four veteran directors of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation resigned today to make room on the thirteen-man board for four additional representatives of a strongly entrenched minority interest headed by three Californians.
A dispute that had threatened to halt all service on the New York Central system between New York and Buffalo was settled last night.

A banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $30,000,000 of Burlington Industries, Inc., subordinated debentures convertible into common stock until Oct. 1, 1965.
DENVER, Oct. 19 -- President Eisenhower went through his biggest "work" schedule today since he entered Fitzsimons Army Hospital twenty-six days ago.

The Model T Ford is the subject of a second book to be published within a period of three weeks. On Oct. 17, Simon Shuster issued Philip Van Doren Stern's "Tin Lizzie," which was illustrated with photographs from the Ford Archives and other sources and with drawings by Charles Harper.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- A far-reaching economic transformation of the southern Ukraine has been set in motion with the opening of the Kakhovka hydroelectric station on the lower Dnieper River.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Reopening of El Tiempo, Colombia's leading newspaper, is among the conditions set by Conservative party leaders of Antioquia State for the reunification of the widely-split government party, it was announced today.

Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson hopes to save several hundred millions of dollars in his department in the next year or so by stringent economies in civilian personnel, in procurement and in production.
WILLEMSTADT, Dutch West Indies, Oct. 19--Queen Juliana signed today a general amnesty for all prisoners in the Netherlands West Indies.

There are twenty-odd so-called "fundamental particles," the stuff of which everything in the universe is made. Now comes the important news from the University of California of another, the negative proton. Physicists have been saying for thirty years that there ought to be a negative proton, and they said so largely for philosophic and esthetic reasons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The United States produced goods and services at a record annual rate of $392,000,000,000 in the third quarter of this year, according to preliminary estimates of the President's Council of Economic Advisers made available today.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is to present a supplementary budget to the House of Commons next Wednesday.

Two years of legal wrangling ended on Tuesday when a Federal District Court jury decided in favor of Anthony Wilko in his suit against Hayden, Stone Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange. Damages of $5,000 were awarded.

The United States, not the Soviet Union, as had been reported, won the world weight-lifting team championship in the recent competition in Munich. That was the claim of Bob Hoffman, coach of the American team that returned yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- A United Nations official has advised that the 900,000 Arab refugees from Palestine be allowed to choose between repatriation or compensation for their lost holdings.
BAKU, U. S. S. R., Oct. 19 -- This Soviet oil center and its surrounding Apsheron Peninsula still have rich oil reserves, according to a Soviet official.
Cotton futures closed irregular yesterday, 3 points (15 cents a bale) higher to 21 points ($1.05 a bale) lower than Tuesday, with the far months showing the most weakness.

The Jackson Vitrified China Company is planning to spend $500,000 for a world trade and expansion program for Jackson and its subsidiary, Vogue Ceramic Industries, Inc. This was disclosed yesterday by Philip R. Distillator, president of Jackson, who noted that the plan was in addition to the concern's regular advertising, most of which runs in magazines in the shelter group.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- The Columbia Broadcasting System is considering producing a weekly ninety-minute dramatic television show to originate at its Television City studios here. The project will be presented live, possibly in color.

The Women's City Club of New York began yesterday a year of celebration of its fortieth anniversary. It has fought many battles in its twoscore years. Some of its past objectives have been so long accepted that it seems almost incredible that a battle for them ever had to be made.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Two officials of Local 52 of the Painters, Caulkers and Cleaners Union, A. F. L., were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Taft-Hartley Act by unlawfully receiving $98,004.59.
Rats in great numbers are taking over Central Park. They cruise along the edge of the lake in wait for birds. On the high ground they saunter out from the rocks and wander about the ledges.

We have had fresh evidence this week that the Federal Reserve's tighter money policy has passed the stage of moral suasion and is operating directly upon the demand-supply equation in the field of credit. Two money rates that are particularly sensitive to money market conditions have been marked up.

The United Hunts Racing Association opened its annual two-day meeting at Belmont Park yesterday on a happy note. There was a crowd of 14,709. There were two exciting jumping races. There were some long-shot winners and a $288.50 daily double. It was a sunny afternoon with an autumn tang in the air.

AN exceptional group of more than thirty works by seventeen modern European masters is on view at the Rose Fried Gallery, 40 East Sixty-eighth Street. Selected for both historical and esthetic values, the show represents all of the major visions of the early part of this century.

Four United States servicemen, armed with swords and pistols and headed by a former Hungarian Army officer, are in Macolin, Switzerland. They are awaiting the start of competition tomorrow for the world's modern pentathlon crown.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Sir Leslie Munro, chairman of the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee, appealed today to all United Nations members to make possible the unanimous adoption of a resolution on the atoms-for-peace program.
TOKYO, Oct. 20 (UP) -- It was Yankee Day in Tokyo today. The New Yorkers made a triumphant entrance and not even a driving rain could dampen Japanese enthusiasm.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 20 -- Two members of the French Cabinet. Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, Interior Minister, and Gen. Pierre Billotte, Defense Minister, flew to Algeria today to spur military action against the rebels in the northeast.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Industrial stock prices fell sharply today in anticipation of measures the Government will take next week to reduce consumption and curb inflation.
A talent union has taken a stand against pay-as-you-see television.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -The Government today dropped a ten-count perjury count against Henry (the Dutchman) Grunewald, a key figure in the tax scandal investigations in 1953.

Dr. Allen B. Du Mont of Clifton and Cedar Grove, N. J., an internationally famous television scientist and inventor, was re-elected commodore of the Eastern Cruiser Association at the annual meeting last night at the Shelton Hotel. Using his 54-foot Annapolis-built Hurricane III. Dr. Du Mont captured the national high-point championship during the season just ended as he did a year ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The General Assembly today completed organization of the United Nations Economic and Social and Trusteeship Councils. The world body postponed for a week, however, the bitterly contested election for a seat on the Security Council, the most powerful United Nations group except the Assembly itself.

The regimental band and pipers of the Scots Guards, now touring the United States and Canada under the auspices of the English-Speaking Union, will perform at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 27 and Dec. 5. Proceeds from the two performances will aid the educational program of the English-Speaking Union.
The nation must be prepared to cope adequately with "eroding'' small wars if freedom is to be preserved in an atomic era, Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, said last night.

The Canandaigua, N. Y., City School District announced yesterday plans for the sale of $1,445,000 of serial bonds on Nov. 1. The obligations will be dated Nov. 1, 1955, and will come due May 1 from 1957 to 1985.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that his office was seeking to question a stock broker concerning the disappearance of 40,000 shares of stock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- Mr. Brownell will report to President Eisenhower tomorrow on the study of the Government's use of business men as unpaid advisers, informed sources said today.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Brookmeade Stable's Lawless today broke the one-mile track, record at Garden State Park, making the second time in five days the mark was shattered. Each time it was accomplished by a 2-year-old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Nine Russian seamen who deserted at Formosa are being admitted to the United States as special immigrants.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Oct. 20 -- To oversee the referendum in the Saar next Sunday more than 1,000 officials will come here from Britain, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. The Saar's frontiers will be tightly shut Saturday to keep out illicit foreign influences on election day.
The New York City Mission Society announced yesterday that its theatre party, scheduled for Nov. 10 at the ANTA Theatre, had been canceled because of the closing of "Reuben Reuben" out 'of town.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -S-D Day is Dec. 1, six weeks from today. It will be the second national twenty-four hour period dedicated to safe driving.

The blockfront on the west side of Lexington Avenue from Seventy-fifth to Seventy-sixth Street has been purchased by Edward H. Benenson, builder and realty investor, from a client of Ornstein Associates. The deal was announced by Pease Elliman, Inc., the brokers, who said no immediate plans were in view for improving the block, which is one of the few large plots in the area available for apartments.

Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler left the bulk of his estate to his widow and their three children, according to his will filed yesterday in New York County Surrogate's Court. General Adler, who was vice president and general manager of The New York Times, died on Oct. 3.
Following is the text of a statement by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur regarding the Defense Department's report on the issue of the Soviet Union's entry into the war against Japan.

After many years on Fifth Avenue, A. Sulka Co., shirt-makers and haberdashers, will move to Park Avenue. The company has leased space in the sixteen-story office building to be erected by William Kaufman and Jack D. Weiler at 405 Park Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-fourth Street.
CAIRO, Oct 20 -- Egypt and Syria signed a mutual defense treaty in Damascus today.
An uninformed or poorly informed electorate could bring this country to disaster, Lester Markel, Sunday editor of The New York Times, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The Air Lines Pilots Association said today that pilots would continue to fly even if the Flight Engineers International Association, A. F. L., called its threatened strike against the United Air Lines Saturday.

THE guns were silenced. The war was over. I was thinking of President Roosevelt who had not lived to see this day. He would have rejoiced in the fulfillment of the pledges he had given the nation when war was forced upon us in December, 1941. I reached for the telephone and called Mrs. Roosevelt.
Summer is definitely over. For the end of summer is hidden away upstairs in a young man's desk drawer. It came, the end of summer, in the mail, and it was put away, and the drawer closed on it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Department of Defense was silent today while sharp reactions to its documentary review of the question of Soviet entry into the Pacific war continued.
DENVER, Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower will meet tomorrow with Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General and one of the Republican party's chief political strategists.
The old Times Square-Grand Central shuttle -- slated for replacement by a conveyor belt -- won a reprieve yesterday.

ALLEGORY, says Fowler's "Modern English Usage," is "a narrative of which the true meaning is to be got by translating its persons and events into others that they are understood to symbolize." William Golding's "Lord of the Flies,"* up for discussion today, has the shape of the novel and all its obvious mechanics.
TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- A seven-day conference to formulate a program for improvement of the state of blind persons in the Far East was opened today in Tokyo.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Britain is bracing for an unpleasant dose of economic medicine.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to move for the delisting of four common stocks. Public hearings will be held next month at which objectors may appear to argue against the step.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society opened its 114th season at Carnegie Hall last night, behaving as skittishly as a young 'un who wants to be noticed. There was nothing pretentious or showy about the music and the performances, but a determined effort was made to invest the opening with glamour.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Defense Department said today it was sending two Air Force planes to Europe to return three Senators and their wives at a cost of about $20,000.
Directors of the Intertype Corporation yesterday declared an extra dividend and recommended a two-for-one split of the common stock.
Fifth Avenue's dignified Tiffany Co., now conducting its first bargain sale in a decade and a half, yesterday elected its fifth president since the store was founded 118 years ago.

Queen Juliana of the Netherlands is touring the Caribbean areas that are related to the Dutch Crown. She has had a warm welcome in the Netherlands Antilles, formerly the colony of Curacao and Aruba, and will go on from there to Surinam, which was a part of our geography books as "Dutch Guiana."

Winthrop Rockefeller testified in Supreme Court yesterday that his net worth was "not less than $15,000,000" and that his annual income was "at least $300,000." He appeared in a $100,000 suit for legal services brought by Joseph Sax, Boston lawyer, against him and his former wife, Mrs. Barbara (Bobo) Rockefeller.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Oct. 20 -- Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands inaugurated today this island's hopeful bid as a new Caribbean tourist center.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 20 -- Consolidation of the state's entire judicial system -- with two exceptions -- was backed today by leading Westchester County lawyers.
CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- High Government sources said today Premier Robert Gordon Menzies had decided on a parliamentary election in December.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Gerben Sonderman, chief pilot for Fokker Aircraft and personal pilot of Prince Bernhard of The Netherlands, was killed today demonstrating a jet training plane here.
Sales of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company for the first nine months of this year reached a record of $396,545,092, R. S. Stevenson, president, reported yesterday.

Capt. Hans W. Lohr will begin his last voyage for the Holland-America Line with the sailing tomorrow of the liner Ryndam. The 60-year-old skipper has spent forty years at sea in the service of the company. He has reached the mandatory retirement age.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 20 -- Dr. Hugo Theorell, Swedish biochemist, won the 1955 Nobel Prize in medicine today for discoveries on the nature and action of oxidation enzymes.

A former Finnish Army ammunition inspector sought yesterday to stay his deportation on the ground that he had given twenty-five pounds of secret Finnish documents to United States authorities. He said he had been told he would be "taken care of" for this.
" RUDDIGORE" is one of the wittiest and most musically pleasing shows on Broadway today.
The State Supreme Court was asked yesterday to rule that labor-management welfare funds have the right to self-insure benefits totaling hundreds of millions of dollars each year.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Princess Margaret dined tonight again with Group Capt. Peter Townsend.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -Senator J. Glen Beall, Republican of Maryland, today urged a Senate investigation of the newsprint market, saying any increase in price might narrow the public's access to news.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Public opinion now and history eventually will have to decide what are the right answers to the two principal questions posed by (a) Gen. Douglas MacArthur's attack on the concessions made to Soviet Russia at Yalta by President Roosevelt, in exchange for a promise to enter the war in the Pacific, and (b) the partial documentation of the issue released by the Pentagon yesterday.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 20 -- Premier Moshe Sharett said tonight Israel felt entitled to a security treaty with the United States.
MOST families consider good housing more important than fine clothes or expensive vacations. But their concepts of what constitutes good housing vary widely.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- Government attorneys today sought to discredit the reliability of defense statistics about the physical and financial structure of the television broadcasting industry for the years 1949 through 1954.

A jolly time for all is the football season! The coach has the "grandstand quarterback" at his side. The sports department has the "armchair editor" at its collective elbow. Perhaps these volunteer assistants would do better jobs, at that.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's Committee on Migratory Labor today adopted a set of recommendations that the Secretary of Labor. James P. Mitchell, called "the first really positive step taken to solve the migrant question.''

Columbia has a great respect for Army's line, and the cadets have the same regard for the Lions' aerial offensive. That was the gist of the reports exchanged at the football luncheon at Columbia University's John Jay Hall yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The French Cabinet will decide tomorrow whether to call for new parliamentary elections this fall under an amended electoral law.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur interpreted the Defense Department's documentary review of the Pacific war yesterday as confirming that he never had been consulted about the Yalta conference.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System came up with another likely film success last night in a new program called "Wanted." A variation on the old "Gangbusters" radio pro gram, it is a documentary presentation of the life of a man sought by the police.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 -- School officials here defined their disciplinary policy today as permit- ting corporal punishment in emergency cases.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The Government's investment in price-supported farm commodities jumped to $7,116,855,000 in the month ended Aug. 31, a rise of more than $100,000,000 over the previous month.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 20 -- Members of the Business Advisory Council asserted today that the group would welcome a thorough Congressional investigation of its operations. The council is made up of business leaders who counsel the Secretary of Commerce.
TROY, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. declared here tonight that in the search for a cure for war the influence of world opinion was more effective than legal power.

FOOTBALL fans hereabouts who were smart enough to stay home last Saturday did more than save themselves a drenching. Through the marvels of electronics they were able to watch Michigan State play and they were thereby treated to the most satisfying and eye-pleasing display of collegiate ball that they are likely to see all season.

Dr. Alice Masaryk, daughter of Thomas G. Masaryk, first President of Czechoslovakia, will speak during the intermission of the New York City Opera's revival of Smetana's "The Bartered Bride" next Wednesday evening.

The line reaches into Forty - third Street. It's 7 o'clock of a Saturday evening, and G. I.'s are jammed into the Times Square U. S. O. This is the hour for the nightly distribution of tickets to New York's theatres, movies, concerts and sports events.

FROSTING flowers as lovely as those that grow in a garden probably are the prettiest adornment for a cake. Some bakeries specialize in this kind of cake decoration, but few amateurs have the skill to do it themselves.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A House of Representatives committee moved today to block Defense Department plans to close fourteen of its manufacturing and commercial facilities.

Business loans outstanding on the books of leading New York City banks declined $47,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was the second weekly decline in a row.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 -- A poll of California Democratic leaders shows Mr. Stevenson as the overwhelming 1956 Presidential favorite.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Following is the text of a Soviet aide-memoire on the draft statute of the international atomic energy agency, which was transmitted to the United States in Moscow and circulated to United Nations members today:
Free Asian and Western nations are moving gradually toward a closer economic cooperation through private efforts, delegates at the eighth Far East Conference were told yesterday.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman formally reaffirmed last night his preference for Adlai E. Stevenson as next year's Democratic candidate for President. His action followed con sultation with Governor Harriman, Mayor Wagner and Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany and Democratic National Committeeman for New York.

Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally sentenced four delinquent jurors yesterday to ten days in the Sheriff's Jail. He imposed fines ranging from $10 to $100 each on nine others who ignored jury notices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay, "unalterably" opposed today an attempt by the Army to take over for a firing range land set aside in Oklahoma for the preservation of wildlife.
Fossil remains of a creature that scientists have long called "a missing link" in the evolution of mammal from reptile were excavated from Arizona rock during the summer and brought to New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- Senator Styles Bridges demanded today a Congressional investigation of the dismissal of Prof. Donald M. Dozer as a State Department historian.

CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 20 (UP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, asked the Department of State today to protest a $5-a-ton increase in the cost of newsprint announced by a Canadian concern.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 20 -- A $10,000 scholarship fund at the University of Chattanooga, established in memory of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, was announced here today. General Adler was the first vice president and general manager of The New York Times and publisher of The Chattanooga Times.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 20 -- Mrs. Henry G. Hay of Evergreen, Old Brookville, chairman of the benefit committee of the North Country Speedwell Society unit, and her aides have been meeting at La Vie En Rose in Little Neck to further plans for the program by Burl Ives, folk singer, at the Glen Cove High School on Sunday evening.

" The Terrible Swift Sword" will initiate the New Director's Series of four plays at the Phoenix, where it will be appraised Nov. 16-20. Arthur Steuer, a new author, wrote the play, to be staged by Fred Sadoff, who gained some experience in that field at the Actors Studio.

A 4:05.2 mile, the second fastest ever achieved at Madison Square Garden, was Wes Santee's contribution to the Olympic Carnival last night. Kansas University's gift to track, now with the United States Marines, ran away from the six others in the field, beating Fred Dwyer, his old rival, by twenty yards, going away.
Reginald M. Schmidt, vice president and a director of the investment banking house of Blyth Co., Inc., took time out yesterday to look back over half a century in Wall Street.

That there is a shortage of engineers, chemists and other technically trained men we have been told repeatedly ever since the end of the recent war. The Government's requirements in themselves account for much of the shortage. Add to this the needs of industry at a time when production is at its peak and we have what amounts to a crisis.
Senator Irving M. Ives appealed last night for approval of the proposed highway bond issue amendment to the State Constitution.
State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams announced yesterday the reorganization of the functions of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission and a change in top personnel.
The General Electric Company set a new high in earnings for the first nine months of the year.
Cotton futures closed irregular here yesterday, with December 14 points up and other months 9 to 18 points down. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -Legislation to extend the Coast Guard's authority to cover commercial boats of under fifteen gross tons was called for here today.

TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- Communist China, where an organized birth-control movement is reported to have taken a strong hold, has received permission to send observers to the fifth International Conference on Planned Parenthood here next week.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 20 -- The United States proposed today that a nuclear research and training center be set up in Asia. It offered to contribute to such a regional atomic institute with all laboratory facilities, including one and perhaps two nuclear reactors.

Buford Long, an offensive end and halfback of the New York Giants, will be inducted into the Army this morning. Long, in his third year with the New York club, led the team in kick-off returns and had caught six passes this season that were good for a total of 64 yards.

Hats at Ohrbach's Oval Room this season are said to have a "bountiful look." By dictionary definition bountiful means "plentiful; abundant," and that Ohrbach's hats are -- in quantity, size and interest.

The Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation of New York has acquired a tract of about thirty-two acres near Princeton, N. J., for a central research laboratory. The property is on Highway 1, adjacent to the James Forrestal Research Center of Princeton University.
The New Haven Railroad succeeded yesterday in breaking through bottlenecks at Darien and Glenbrook, Conn., caused by week-end floods.

Six teen-agers pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to second-degree murder charges for two separate slayings in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn. Four others were arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court in a killing in the same area Wednesday afternoon.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 20 -- The death of Juliu Maniu, aged Peasant party leader of Rumania, in 1952 while under detention was confirmed today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20 -- Prospects for a week-end settlement of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation strike dimmed tonight. Thirty of the company's ninety-eight plants have been closed since Monday by a walkout of 44,000 members of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Monsanto Chemical Company and its consolidated subsidiaries in the first nine months this year.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 20 -- Fatmi ben Slimane, Morocco's Premier-designate, has formally asked for a definition of the "prerogatives" before he decides whether to form the first representative Government in Morocco's history.

SCHLOSS BLUEHNBACH, Austria, Oct. 15 -- The direction of the wind in these Alpine peaks and valleys, not only determines the direction of the hunt, but the terrain to be hunted and the game to be sought.

The Red Cross will collect blood today from residents of Queens Village and Bellerose, Queens, in a community donation at the Roman Catholic Church of the Incarnation, 207th Street and Eighty-ninth Avenue, Queens Village.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- An official of German Athletic Association said today there was no doubt that Russia had won the team championship in the world weight-lifting tournament which ended here last Sunday.
Protestant church leaders declared anew last night against any attempt to legalize bingo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to uphold a judgment of the Federal Court of Appeals that the Communist party must register with the Attorney General as a Communist-action organization.

Net earnings of the Republic Aviation Corporation in the first nine months this year climbed 98.8 per cent to $12,312,873 from $6,192,292 earned in the period last year, according to the report released today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Grain and soybean futures were generally weak in early trading today. But most prices firmed later on reported reinstatement of long ones of wheat that had been sold but early this week and active buying of corn and soybeans on the declines.

A recommendation that New York University's only non- coeducational undergraduate college admit women students was received coolly yesterday by both students and administrators at the University Heights campus. The college is the University College of Arts and Sciences.
Sitting in a chair has been found to be a better position for recovery from a coronary accident than is lying in bed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles pleaded with the Russians at Geneva last July not to insist on re-creating in Europe the conditions that led to World War II.
NEWARK, Oct. 20 -- A share contrast between gasoline price-war chaos in New Jersey and stability in New York was drawn here today by eleven service station operators.
City-delivered price increases for the 1956 Plymouth, Chrysler, Imperial and Pontiac lines were announced yesterday by dealers here.

Stocks gave a strongly bullish performance yesterday. Volume expanded as prices rose and contracted as they eased off a little in the afternoon. The gains for the day were impressive, especially for the leading motors, oils, chemicals, steels and rubbers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Hog prices declined again today, selling at a new low since Dec. 3, 1945. Butchers sold steady to 25 cents lower while most sows were down 25 cents. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
An increase in interest rates on consumer bank loans in New York City is under active study. The first move toward a higher cost structure may be made within a fortnight.
Seven touring Russian journalists visited City Hall yesterday and found themselves on the receiving end of a flow of democratic propaganda -- from the Mayor of New York.
SOME time ago an amiable Southern writer had a unique idea. It occurred to him to write a book -- fiction, of course -- about an American boy who did not object to being drafted.

The Puget Sound Power and Light Company's earnings this year should be about $2.25 a share, Frank McLaughlin, president, told a special meeting yesterday in Boston. This would compare with $2.05 a share in 1954, he said.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Administration received today from Congressional leaders assurances of bi-partisan support on plans for the Big Four foreign ministers' conference in Geneva.

Two books about individual units of the German Navy are planned for publication soon. Macmillan will issue on Nov. 7 "The Altmark Affair," by Willi Frischauer and Robert Jackson. It is an account of the career of the supply ship to the Nazi raider Graf Spee and of her captain who was determined to deliver to Germany the 300 Allied prisoners in her hold.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Belgium today attacked the Commitee on Information from Non-self-governing Territories as infringing on areas in which it had no competence.

With the Geneva conference less than a week away the Defense Department has revealed hitherto secret documents which dovetail with former President Truman's memoirs being published in this newspaper to cast new light on Soviet policies and tactics during the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- T. Coleman Andrews, Internal Revenue Commissioner, who is retiring, will join a company that has a major tax case pending with the Government. The Secretary of the Treasury, George M. Humphrey, has given his approval.

A complex controversy over prices had the zinc market in a state of confusion yesterday. Battle lines were being drawn over the question of whether a recent -- and by no means unanimous -- zinc price increase should be rescinced as harmful to the industry.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (AP) -Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan advocated today a Federal program of aid to the public schools. His program would cost $16,640,000,000 during the next five years.

Events today: New York Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor, Rudolf Serkin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M., and "Troilus and Cressida." New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15 P. M.

Events today: New York Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor, Rudolf Serkin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M., and "Troilus and Cressida." New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15 P. M.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased their borrowings from the Federal Reserve by $135,000,000 on a daily average basis during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Common Pleas Court set aside today the dismissal of a 43-year-old high school English teacher. The teacher had been ousted for "incompetency" after refusing to tell a Congressional committee or the Board of Education about alleged past Communist connections.
ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- The State Conference on Problems of the Aging submerged Governor Harriman today in a flood of proposals.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Quarterback Charlie Bussey steered Clemson to two quick first-period touchdowns today, enough for a 28-14 victory over South Carolina. The teams' fifty-third State Fair football game was witnessed by an overflow crowd of 35,000.

Oliver D. Appleton, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and an associate of Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, yesterday was elected chairman of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The United States is ready to contribute substantially to the financing of the High Dam in Egypt. It is also willing to aid the unified development of the Jordan River valley, diplomatic officials said today.
Longshoremen of the Port of New York yesterday moved a pier's length closer to their longheralded "working alliance" with organized teamsters.
POINT CLEAR, Ala., Oct. 20 -- Gov. Frank G. Clement of Tennessee was elected today to the chairmanship of the Southern Governors Conference for the ensuing year.

Rabbi Irving Miller, chairman of the American Zionist Council, said yesterday that Arab propagandists were attempting to cause "dissension and disunity among the American people through the promotion of anti-Semitism."

KILLER JOE is cadaverous, dark - haired, catfooted. You bend close to catch his words because his speech is just a cut or two above a whisper. Killer Joe is shy. His large, dark eyes have puppy softness.

Everyone interested in and concerned with the proposed redevelopment of that part of the West Side in the Lincoln Square area will rejoice in the recent announcements that the Metropolitan Opera's board of directors is ready to cooperate with city officials in sponsoring a new opera house there and that an acre in the proposed Lincoln Square project is being held for a new concert hall for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

UNION CITY, N. J., Oct. 20 -- An injured bus driver saved fifty passengers from serious injury today when he kept the vehicle from plunging down an embankment after a collision with an oil truck. Twenty-four persons, including drivers of both vehicles, were injured.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 -Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, sharply criticized today a report of a special committee to Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. The report recommends changes that assertedly would weaken the Robinson-Patman Act and repeal the Federal Fair Trade Laws.
The Government fined two concert artist corporations and two subsidiaries yesterday for monopolizing the field. Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman set a total penalty of $16,000.

Today's new feature is "Simba," a British-made drama in color filmed partly on location in Kenya, at the Palace. Dirk Bogarde, Donald Sinden, Virginia McKenna and Basil Sydney head the cast of the J. Arthur Rank presentation, which was produced by Peter De Sarigny and directed by Brian Desmond Hurst. John Baines' scenario is based on an original story by Anthony Perry Lippert Pictures is the distributor.
Dimitri Mitropoulos, who conducted "Salome" and "The Masked Ball" at the Metropolitan Opera last season, will direct the company's revised production of "Tosca," to be given Dec. 8.
Permit me to correct some of the more blatant misrepresentations in the letter signed by the press attache of the Embassy of Egypt published in your columns on Oct. 12.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Martial law ended in the Perfect Circle Corporation strike areas today. Gov. George N. Craig said he was assured a reduced force of National Guard troops, operating under civil control, could maintain order.
A warning of growing inadequacies in handling of airplane traffic was issued yesterday by experts of the world's airlines.
WASHINGTON, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Gunnery School's light but aggressive football team "should turn out to be a good outfit once we correct defensive mistakes," Coach Roderick Beebe Jr. said today.

With the death of Carlos Davila the inter-American world has lost one of its most important and also one of its most attractive figures. It was fitting that the crowning work of his long and distinguished career should have been as Secretary General of the Organization of American States.

HAWORTH, N. J., Oct. 20 -- The Women's Tri-County Golf Association's team of twenty players defeated the Garden State Women's Golf Association today in a best-ball team match. Playing over the White Beeches course, the Westchester group triumphed, 15 1/2 to 14 1/2.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -From his sickbed Chancellor Konrad Adenauer urged Saar-landers tonight to approve the French-German statute in Sunday's referendum.
Final instructions were given yesterday to the interdepartmental force of 234 men who on Monday will begin the enforcement phase of the city's cleanup program.
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Kawasaki Stadium echoed yesterday to the thunder of Yankee bats -- and herds of Japanese school kids.
BERN, Oct. 20 -- A fourteen-nation convention was signed here today that, when ratified, will give railroads of Europe a powerful instrument for buying modern equipment.
The twenty-first annual metropolitan contract bridge championships took place yesterday afternoon at the McAlpin Hotel, with one-session men's and women's events.

EVERY night at 5, Jane Wilson Gruen strap-hangs home from 498 Seventh Avenue, where she has been walking for seven hours, fixes dinner for her husband and her Siamese cat. Then, for five more hours she stands before a canvas.

The nation's top steeplechase racer, Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji, handled by the No. 1 steeplechase rider, Frank (Dooley) Adams, won the thirty-second running of the Temple Gwathmey Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
New York University alumni will soon occupy the former home of the defunct Town Hall Club at 123 West Forty-third Street.

GENEVA, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Scott McLeod of the United States said today its refugee relief program would not be completely successful. He gave as the reasons "shifts in the pressure for immigration" in Germany and Austria since the United States refugee act became law.

Gov. Goodwin J. Knight of California warned Republicans last night that unless they held the labor and independent vote that was attracted by President Eisenhower they would lose the White House for "the next generation.''

Japan, unlike some countries, must discourage an unrestricted flow of foreign investment into her economy, delegates at the eighth Far East Conference were told yesterday. The meeting, sponsored by the Far East-America Council of Commerce and Industry, was held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 21 -- Ceylonese tea producers decided today to form a national corporation to handle the export of tea.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Oct. 21 (AP) -- A private plane exploded and crashed in flames in this north central Pennsylvania region today, killing five persons.
HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 21 -Halfback Jack Nicolette and End Monte Pascoe will start against Harvard tomorrow.
Directors of the Mojud Company, women's hosiery and lingerie producer, said yesterday they are planning to sell the operating assets and name of the company to an undisclosed purchaser.
The New Haven Railroad began sending through trains to Boston and Springfield yesterday for the first time since floods and a wreck cut the main line Sunday.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has just acted to make the temporary general freight rate increases granted to the railroads in 1952 part of the latter's permanent rate structure. It has done this by canceling the expiration date of these surcharges, set for Dec. 31, 1955.
A resolution citing the career of the late Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler and his service to the Boy Scout movement has been adopted by the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America.

There are signs that this city may soon have a unified family court which will emphasize preventive rather than punitive treatment for families in trouble. It will emerge -- if the public gets behind the drive of legal experts to make it a reality.

The business dip that began in late 1953 frequently has been described as an "inventory recession." Goods accumulated faster than they could be sold, with the result that orders and production were cut back all along the line.

It takes little perspicacity to observe that the transportation systems of New York are rapidly approaching mass immobility. Our inhuman subways are similar to the stockyards of Chicago before they moved west to Omaha.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Oct. 21 -- International officals overseeing the Saar referendum Sunday are determined it shall not be a repetition of aspects of that of 1935. Pressure and threats by the Nazis led to a majority of more than 90 per cent for Germany in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Consumer Price Index has gone up three-tenths of a per cent to the highest point in a year. This rise is big for peacetime and is the second of its size in a few months. Since the last big rise, however, there has been a partial fallback.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Government fixed today for the first time pay rates for miners producing bituminous coal for the Government.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 20 -- An $84,000,000 program to bolster economic development has been undertaken by the small British protectorate of Uganda.

Today's new film is "Adventure in Warsaw," a Polish-made musical comedy in color, at the Stanley. Leonard Buczkowski directed the Film Polski production, which features Lidia Korsak and Tadeusz Schmidt and the State Song and Dance Ensemble Mazowsze. There are English titles.

Three large zinc producers who had announced a zinc price increase of one-half cent a pound early this week rescinded that advance yesterday. The price of the basic grade, prime western, thus was restored industry-wide to 13 cents a pound, East St. Louis -- the level in effect until last Monday.
DEDICATED to telling about the life of the haut monde, "Igor Cassini's Million Dollar Showcase," teed off on Channel 5 last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Navy got a patent this week for a method of teaming up helicopters -- "workhorses of the air" -- to lift a load that would be too heavy for one of them. The harness consists of a framework that keeps the helicopters from colliding, but allows them some freedom of movement.
Tentative plans for reviving the defunct Brooklyn Eagle as an afternoon tabloid were being made yesterday by Eagle Newspaper Enterprises, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Albert Pratt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for personnel and Reserve forces, today apologized for the barring of a reporter from a Navy graduation where Mr. Pratt made an address.

An increase in interest rates on consumer loans by at least one major New York City bank is expected to become effective about mid-November. There's a good chance others will follow. The increase is expected to bring the present cost of $3.33 a year on each $100 borrowed to $3.75, and $4.25 on loans carrying life insurance.
Nine Russian sailors, crew members of the Soviet tanker Tuatse seized by the Chinese Nationalists, arrived here yesterday from Formosa. They had been granted asylum in this country.

The five-story building containing fifty apartments at 1107 Gerard Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the Berdorette Realty Corporation to the Pleasantville Realty Corporation, subject to a mortgage of $160,000. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers in the sale and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The $20,000,000 nonprofit housing cooperative built on the lower East Side by the East River Housing Corporation will be dedicated today. David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., will preside.
Isaac Logart of Camaguey, Cuba, gained the unanimous decision over Gil Turner of Philadelphia in the featured ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
A railroad man and a trucking representative tried to break bread peacefully in Wall Street yesterday. It wasn't peaceful.
Though it is mid-season, the championship of the Ivy Prep School League should be decided today when Poly Prep meets Riverdale in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Air Force was told to go ahead today with its SAGE electronic network for continental defense.

STOP at any fish market these days and note the abundance of crab meat. This is not the soft-shelled crab, which went out of season with fresh New Jersey corn, blueberries and other available-only-in-summer foods. It is the cooked meat of the shellfish, packed in one-pound pry-open tins that require constant refrigeration.

MADRID, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Three Democratic Senators tonight denied they had asked for two large Air Force planes that were being sent on special flights to Europe to bring them home with their wives at a cost of more than $20,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today "the Western powers, including the Federal Republic of Germany, are ready to meet every legitimate Russian concern for security."

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Strong criticism of the inadequacy of the British Government's measures to meet a deteriorating economic situation is implied in a survey published today by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- Mrs. Erika Glaser Wallach, who spent five years in Soviet prisons, said tonight her departure from Moscow had been "delayed until the middle of next week" because of administrative red tape.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Juscelino Kubitschek, the apparent winner of Brazil's Presidential election, said today that when he took office he hoped to attract capital to build automobiles as a symbol of the nation's expanding industry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -United States and Canadian officials conferred here yesterday on problems of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 -- Ned E. Depinet, president of R. K. O.-Radio Pictures until he retired in 1952, was the principal witness today in the Government's anti-trust suit against five motion picture companies and their subsidiaries.

As the president of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, a privately supported agency which has tripled its program in the last decade, I would like the privilege of commenting on a report which appeared in The Times of Sept. 30 calling for a public adoption service for the "thousands of children who are in foster care homes despite a super-abundance of families that would like to adopt children but find it impossible to do so."

SCHLOSS BLUEHNBACH, Austria, Oct. 16 -- The American big game hunter who roams the woods, shoots, shoulders his kill and takes the shortest route home is certain to be impressed by the ceremony that follows a successful shot in the Alps.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George said tonight that Vice President Richard M. Nixon might be a "handicap" to President Eisenhower if the latter ran for a second term.

The public exchange of correspondence, via Letters to The Times, between Dr. Robert E. Wilson, chairman, Standard Oil (Indiana), and the Senator from Illinois, Paul H. Douglas, on the subject of natural gas regulation, is an interesting debate in modern economics.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The president of the American Heart Association said today that 65 to 70 per cent of men who have suffered a first "coronary" attack -- such as President Eisenhower has had -- could return to their original occupation" but must live and work "in moderation."
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Army and Columbia meet in the penultimate game of a colorful gridiron rivalry at Michie Stadium tomorrow.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 21 -- Finance Minister Levi Eshkol told a study mission of the United Jewish Appeal today that for the next ten years Israel must produce more at a cheaper price for export while importing less for consumption.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer asserted today that his controversial 1947 "white paper" report on China and Korea had been suppressed on direct written orders from President Truman.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 21 -- Troops based on Tebessa in eastern Algeria inflicted heavy losses today on a rebel band, already severely mauled near the frontier post of Tamerza in Tunisian territory yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Philharmonia Orchestra of London will begin its first American tour here Sunday afternoon with a new arrangement of "The Star Spangled Banner" by Sir William Walton.
The Bronx Grand Jury refused yesterday to indict a plumber in connection with an attempted bank robbery on Oct. 10.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 15 points higher to 19 points lower yesterday. The old crop months showed the most strength.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission decided today not to hold parallel arms limitation discussion here and among the Big Four foreign ministers at Geneva.

A series of big money requisitions -- most of them stemming from local government borrowing -- are about to be made on the public market for new capital, threatening underwriting resources with more strain than at any time this fall.

Stanley M. Isaacs, minority leader of the City Council, criticized Corporation Counsel Peter Campbell Brown yesterday for three recent legal opinions. He suggested that Mr. Brown seemed to lack respect for the law and the Constitution.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The Soviet Union eventually will agree to German reunification, Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, predicted tonight.
DENVER, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower supported today a six-point Federal program for ending the jam in the nation's courts and dealing with the rapidly growing prison population.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Britain, through her Queen, today honored George VI, a sailor King, and Lord Nelson, the brightest star in British naval history.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 21 -- The Administration is determined to get its highway program through Congress and will make whatever "reasonable concessions on financing" that are required to do so, Sinclair Weeks asserted today.

The makers of cigarette paper were not surprised by the prediction on Thursday by Joseph F. Cullman 3d, executive vice president of Philip Morris, Inc., that cigarette consumption this year will rise 3 per cent to 375,000,000,000 units. Their business has been booming all year, almost as much as in 1952 when cigarette consumption hit a peak of 394,000,000,000 units.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Station WJIM-TV of Lansing protested to the United States Department of Justice today against the National Collegiate Athletic Association's refusal to let it telecast a sellout football game tomorrow between Illinois and Michigan State.

There are 52,800 Girl Scouts in this city's five boroughs. An additional 14,320 girls are waiting for membership. To bring into their ranks as many as possible of the girls, not now members, who want to come, the Girl Scouts are conducting their annual campaign for funds with a goal this year of $804,000.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 21 (UP) -- Admiral Ben Moreell, retired, who headed the Hoover Commission task force on water resources and power, said here today that public power was "a fraud and a delusion, fraught with danger to our whole system of private enterprise."
Thousands of New Yorkers are discovering the new world of atomic technology.

There are two significant omissions in your special dispatch from Seoul, under date of Oct. 11, which was printed in The New York Times of Oct. 12. The black market in Korea is dependent on goods and articles outside Korea.

The autumn is a very disconcerting time, at least for cooks. Opposite her at the dining table sits a great hulk of a figure, one obviously thickening more than a trifle each passing day. Between herself and this grotesque monolith sit thin shadows.
Kickback charges against six Port Newark dock workers were found "proven" in recommendations filed with the Waterfont Commission by Richard G. Moser, hearing officer.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 21 -- The Army is still the "dominant force" even in nuclear war, its Secretary, Wilber M. Brucker, told the first annual meeting of the Association of the United States Army tonight.
WOMEN with foot sizes ranging from an 8 to a 13 and widths of AAAAA to C will welcome the "Tall Gals" service of Shoecraft, Inc., at 603 Fifth Avenue.
ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- The Roman Catholic Bishop of the Diocese of Albany expressed strong criticism today of the recent State Conference on Youth and Delinquency.
New York on Tuesday will celebrate fifty years of ownership of one of its cherished institutions -- the 5-cent Staten Island ferry.
Federal legislation to strengthen the Justice Department's civil rights powers was urged yesterday in a special report by the American Jewish Committee.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- French officials see more than unusual commercial significance in the arrangement by a United States syndicate to purchase from France a one-sixth interest in the huge Roechling steel works in the Saar.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Film production here will go on a five-day week under terms of a new basic labor agreement reached today between the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

SIR WILLIAM WALTON'S opera, "Troilus and Cressida," wears exceedingly well.
