It had its New York permiere at the City Center last night, and to one who was present at the first American performance in San Francisco a fortnight ago, it reinforced the initial conviction that here was an impressive contribution to the lyric theatre.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 -A three-year working agreement covering about 2,400 stewards on West Coast ships has been announced jointly by employers and officials of the Marine Cooks' Union, A. F. L.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- Prime Minister Nu of Burma arrived here today, four days before the Soviet delegation leaves for the Big Four foreign ministers' conference in Geneva.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Increasing pressure of long liquidating sales combined with buying indifference throughout the session caused lower prices in all Board of Trade pits today.
CAMP FRIEDLAND, Germany, Oct. 21 (AP) -- German repatriates from the Soviet Union told today of having met three more Americans in Soviet prison camps.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester C. C., with 43, 42 -- 85, and Mrs. Alex Ewing of Silver Spring, at 46, 39 -- 85, shared low-gross honors today in the final tournament of the low-handicap Women's Tri-County Golf Association season.
WITH hostilities over, the emphasis had now shifted to domestic problems and political leadership. Among the many things that demanded urgent attention was the world's great need for food.
DONALD MANDELL, 27-year-old pianist who made his debut at 17 and since then has given recitals extensively in and around New Jersey, was heard at Town Hall last night.
Samuli Romppanen, a former Finnish Army aide, denied yesterday that he had accepted a bribe from Soviet officials in Finland to obtain information in this country.
Polly Bergen, who amused playgoers last spring in the part of a complicated young woman in "Champagne Complex," will star in Albert Halper's drama "Top Man" later this season.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 19 -- A high Rumanian official said today that Rumania expected to build within the next five years an electric power station using atomic energy.
ROME, Oct. 21 -- Pope Pius XII said today that television could play an important role in reuniting the family by bringing it together around a set.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A State Department spokesman refused today to discuss the discharge of Donald M. Dozer from its historical section.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 21 -- The levels of food consumption in South and Southeast Asia are lower now than before World War II and below accepted standards of nutrition.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- A fifteen-year agreement covering airline use of O'Hare Field was approved today by the City Council, 46 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- New hearings into the loyalty record of William Henry Taylor, United States official of the International Monetary fund, have been completed. His lawyer, Byron N. Scott, said today the reopened hearings before the international organization's loyalty board had lasted two days and closed last evening.
Retail furriers are questioning whether their traditional August sales are really good for business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Air Force said today that it had collected $123,906 for the cut-rate round-the-world trip its former Secretary, Harold E. Talbott, had allowed a Moral Re-Armament group to make in Air Force aircraft last summer.
PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Premier Edgar Faure announced today that the Government would ask Parliament to authorize new elections early in December.
Commodity futures on the New York exchanges were irregularly lower yesterday. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless, generally limited to evening of holdings for the week-end.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 21 -- The Istiqlal nationalist party announced today that it would not participate in any Cabinet under a Premier appointed by the present Throne Council. Fatal ben Slimane, a moderate nationalist, has been asked by the council to form the first representative government in Morocco's history.
Mayor Wagner told the city's Protestant Council yesterday that "I did not at any time state, and I do not wish to state, that Judge Delany was not a loyal American citizen."
Travel on the Long Island Rail Road was delayed as long as seventy-five minutes yesterday afternoon when 150 yard workers in Brooklyn and Queens left their jobs to attend a union meeting.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Stock market activity contracted sharply here today. The relatively heavy selling pressure of yesterday, on fears of new controls next week, died and most industrials were steady at the close.

Events today: "Carmen," New York City Opera, City Center, 2:30 P. M.; New York Philharmonic-Symphony, Wilfrid Pelletier, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 3 P. M.; "La Traviata," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15 P. M.
TOKYO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Union went to the Yalta conference in February, 1945, knowing that Japan wanted to make peace, a United States investigator says.

IN spite of a certain condescension in the phrase "Down South" (as though the center of the universe were elsewhere) and in other Northernisms of speech and attitude, North-South relations in the world of letters have long been cordial and profitable to both parties. Southerners continue to write more than their share of America's books and Northerners to publish them. It has been suggested that average Southerners would rather write a book than read one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The report appeared here to foreshadow another and more intensive drive when Congress reconvenes in January for enactment of the long-pending civil rights program. It got nowhere in the first session.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Land-grant colleges and universities will need "at least twice as much tax support" within ten or fifteen years as they now are receiving to keep pace with the expanding population, John Cowles, Minneapolis publisher, predicted tonight.
There is widespread and deep interest in religion among college and university undergraduates today. This is in marked contrast to twenty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The State Department said today it is looking into reports that Communist China had shipped 100 tons of arms to Egypt.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Boston College, the victim of an alert defense that put it two touchdowns behind in the first eight minutes, rallied for a 13-13 tie against Marquette tonight. A clever reserve quarterback, Billy Donlan, stood out as the Eagles maintained their undefeated football status.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Princess Margaret is sounding out British leaders of state and church on the possibility of her marrying Group Capt. Peter Townsend.

OLD-TIMERS are wont to complain that Greenwich Village is no longer what it once was. Memories are vague and in collecting together and showing a large group of paintings by prominent artists past and present, who lived and worked in the Village, the New School, 66 West Twelfth Street, performs a pious local service.
ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- A labor leader told a religious gathering here today that the church must cultivate the worker as assiduously as it cultivates its wealthier members.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A five --year-old anti-trust suit against the General Outdoor Advertising Company ended today with a consent decree.

Russian women chess players kept on winning in the challengers' tournament in Moscow yesterday. The top three all captured their thirteenth round games, according to a report received through Russian news sources.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- The secrecy that covers the private lives of the top Soviet leaders has been lifted long enough to permit an American tourist to meet the wife of the Soviet Premier.

The red carpet of official welcome is unrolled almost daily at New York City's City Hall as a diplomatic outpost to which visitors from far lands sooner or later come. Among the callers this week was a delegation of seven touring Russian journalists.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged at 111.2 over the week ended Oct. 18, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 21 -- Adlai E. Stevenson called today for an immediate return to rigid farm price supports at 90 per cent of parity.

The National Supply Company, a leading independent manufacturer of oil and gas field equipment, realized a gain of 5.2 per cent in nine-month earnings on a sales increase of 8.8 per cent over the similar period last year.

The Saar Statute, providing for a species of "Europeanization" while the area remains economically linked to France, is to be voted upon tomorrow. The signs point to its rejection. If this happens the consequences, in the words used yesterday by Belgian Foreign Minister Spaak, could be "extremely dangerous" for Europe.

Four buildings at the southeast corner of Hudson Street and West Fourteenth Street have been purchased by Louis Lederer and Edward T. Jobbagy. The sellers were eight hospitals and other charitable institutions, which had acquired the property under the will of Jacob Myers.
The Kansas City Southern Railway yesterday declared the usual quarterly dividend of 75 cents and an extra of 50 cents on the common stock. Both are payable on Dec. 31. No extra was paid a year ago.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Parlo, the Foxcatcher Farms' 4-year-old filly that is a good bet to become the horse of the year among her sex, is favored in an overnight field of twenty-one fillies and mares entered for the $40,000 added Vineland Handicap at Garden State Park tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A lawyer for a Georgia Negro under sentence of death for murder asked the Supreme Court today to reverse the conviction. He said the Supreme Court of Georgia had defied a mandate of the Federal tribunal.
The world's major airlines formally called on governments yesterday to modernize traffic control and navigation facilities without delay.

A sale-leaseback transaction has been negotiated by the Standard Packing Corporation of New York City on its new building at Sargeant Avenue and Lisbon Street in Clifton, N. J. The company sold the property to the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston, Mass., and leased it back for occupancy.

In offering a nuclear reactor, possibly two of them, to the Colombo Plan powers the United States has made another forward step in the application of the knowledge of nuclear fission to human welfare. This is another and entirely logical part of the whole great atoms-for-peace program.
AIDONE, Sicily, Oct. 20 -- The secrets that the mystery city of Sicily has kept from the world for close to twenty-two centuries are beginning to be revealed to United States archeologists.
It takes no more than a glance to see that the new St. Sebastian's Church in Woodside, Queens, is completely a religious edifice.
Games involving upstate New York teams will command the main attention in the East as the college football season reaches the halfway mark today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today it is setting up a series of antitrust conferences with United States producers of newsprint in a program to prevent any joint effort to increase newsprint prices.

Mayor Wagner has ordered the heads of city departments to make their files, equipment and manpower available to a commercial television corporation headed by Theodore Granik, a long-time personal friend.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 21 -- Maryland's undefeated Terrapins, speedy, deep and resourceful, were two-touchdown favorites today to defeat Syracuse's upsetminded eleven before 32,000 fans here tomorrow. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.
A United Nations service will be held tomorrow afternoon at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 21 -- A special Hudson County grand jury today censured State Auditor Frank Durand of Sea Girt and Edmund T. Stevenson of Kearny, former county Republican chairman. The jury, which is investigating the county's Election Bureau, handed up an eighty-eight-page presentment to Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Eugene J. Martin, 52, general manager of the Syracuse baseball club, today was named farm director of the Philadelphia Phillies. He replaces Eddie Collins Jr., who resigned yesterday in a disagreement over policy with General Manager Roy Hamey.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 21 -- A dozen lawyers and judges on Long Island expressed opposition in varied degrees today to the simplification of the New York State court system as proposed by a special commission.

Thousands of New Yorkers have left our city to join the armed-forces. They are serving in military installations all over the world. What sign of friendliness reaches out to these young people who are half-a-world away from home? What can they find to prove that we are concerned with their happiness and welfare?
KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A mob stoned, beat and kicked to death today an African who did not kneel in homage tothe king of Buganda.

After seven consecutive sessions of grains in the averages, the stock market yesterday just about held its own. While seventy-five more issues rose than fell, prices as measured by The New York Times combined average of fifty representative listed issues drifted down 0.15 to 310.73.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Two particular post-war events stimulated United States interest in the Middle East. The first was Palestine's partition and the creation of Israel. The second was the Mossadegh crisis when Iran almost disintegrated into Russia's lap. We then decided that the Middle East was our business.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21 -- The Peron Government left a debt of $1,200,000,000, financial circles reported today.
Secretary of State John Foster Dulles rejection of the old concept of neutrality was praised yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, continued today a series of conferences, with top Democratic figures -- this time Senator Stuart Symington -- at his Pedernales River ranch.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 21 -- Republicans won a victory today in their fight to retain control of New Castle in the Nov. 8 election.

Contract negotiations between representatives of 200 milk companies in the metropolitan area and five locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., continued yesterday at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel. The union represents 12,500 milk truck drivers and pasteurization plant employes.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- A new type of golf competition began today at the Dellwood Country Club. Devised by Mrs. Marge Mason, it is called a mixed open Scotch tournament.
" You'll Never Get Rich," the Columbia Broadcasting System's TV comedy about Army life, will be renamed "The Phil Silvers Show," after the star, beginning next Tuesday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct 21 -- The Yale football team will meet Colgate tomorrow in the Yale Bowl at 2 P. M. in what promises to be one of the East's top gridiron attractions.

READERS of "Forty Plus and Fancy Free" will be delighted to know that Emily Kimbrough has continued her travels. This time they have taken her south to New Orleans and the Cajun country roundabout, involved her in as many gentle imbroglios as ever, and provided the subject-matter for this pleasant, informal journal and guide.
DENVER, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Following is the White House transcript of the news conference held here today by Dr. Paul Dudley White of Boston on President Eisenhower's condition:
WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 22 -- The "Hillbilly Special" hopes to be coming round the bend on schedule next week.

" THERE'S no reason why pictures aren't made forty-five minutes from Times Square," said Joseph L. Mankiewicz. Lighting his pipe, one of the newer, better-known independent producers looked out of his office window toward a vicinity he recently recreated for Samuel Goldwyn's "Guys and Dolls."

GENERALLY speaking, it isn't news when collaborators split up. But it is news when a writer of the caliber of Cleveland Amory and a subject as famous as the Duchess of Windsor come to a public parting of their private way. Mr. Amory's stand -- "I will omit but I will not distort" -- will probably go down in history as the cornerstone of The Ghost Writers' Declaration of Principles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Air Force made plain today that three Senators now in Europe had made no special request for expensive transport planes to fly them back to the United States.

OF three recently released disks containing readings from the Bible, Shakespeare and Dylan Thomas, some listeners may reach for the Thomas offering first. It is a Westminster recording of the Welsh poet's last work: Under Milk Wood: A Play For Voices, in a B. B. C. production.

IF I may be forgiven for reviving an old chestnut, I should like to play a few variations on the desert island reading theme. I was recently asked to contribute to a sort of symposium on that timeworn subject, this one being launched, with some refreshing precautions, by Broadcast Music, in celebration of the fourth birthday of The Book Parade.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Sparked by the brilliant running and passing of Halfback Jon Arnett, the University of Southern California rolled over California, 33 -- 6, today. A crowd of 51,000 saw the Pacific Coast Conference game.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Fullback Paige Cothren ripped the University of Arkansas line to shreds and used his skillful toe to lead Mississippi to a 17-7 football victory today.

IT may not have been noted generally because it has been so gradual, but the fact is that the New York theatre is in the midst of a trend toward larger, heavier and more complicated sets. Last season's "The Desperate Hours" displayed a cut-out house in which were visible the living room and kitchen, while upstairs could be seen the master bedroom and a child's room.

The petroleum industry is confident that it will meet the demand for home heating oil this winter without serious difficulty, even if the weather proves unusually cold. Stocks on hand are at a peak level, some 12 per cent higher than at the start of the last heating season.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 22 -- The score may not show it, but Colgate's Red Raiders gave the Yale football team a thorough whipping today before 42,000 spectators in the Bowl. The 7-0 victory for Hal Lahar's soundly coached short-enders against the previously unbeaten Bulldogs was a mild upset.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Ohio State, displaying ground power, rolled over favored Wisconsin today, 26 -- 16, to remain unbeaten in Big Ten competition and share the conference lead with Michigan.
Mayor Wagner appointed a new advisory committee yesterday to help direct a "massive attack" on the city's tangled traffic problems.

A profound change, far too little recognized, is taking place in the status of the various economic groups of American workers: the narrowing of wage differentials. It is a process of leveling up, or off, in which the lowest paid are advancing more rapidly than the highest to bring them closer together on the income scale.

AT 16, Susan Strasberg, who has been raised in the atmosphere of the theatre since her playpen days, is a striking example of success without the usual struggle experienced by the majority of young actresses. In contrast to her contemporaries, she never has had to make the long detour to a big role by first playing a dozen bit parts and being rejected by two dozen producers.

THE name of Bishop James Cannon Jr. means little to the present generation. Yet older citizens who remember the enormous political influence wielded by this Southern Methodist Bishop during the Presidential campaign of 1928, and the reverberating scandals that broke around him almost immediately thereafter, will not need to be reminded of the place he once occupied on the American scene.
An advertising campaign is under way for the Leroux line of liqueurs, and behind the fact is a story.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Senator Walter F. George predicted today that Congress would cut lower-bracket income taxes, restore high rigid farm price supports and approve a long-range highway program next year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 22 -- Sparked by its leading scorer, Dan Nolan, Lehigh registered its fourth straight triumph today by turning back Rutgers, 21 to 14, in the sixth annual Football Hall of Fame game at Rutgers Stadium.
BRISTOL, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Democratic party leaders must seek to enlist women and young voters more effectively to win the 1956 Presidential campaign, Senator Estes Kefauver said today.

WHEN James Thurber brings out a collection of what he has written and drawn on the subject of dogs over a period of thirty-odd years, it is safer to accept his own definitions of himself and his dog model than to venture into any freehand interpretation of them.
Seven years ago a little girl used to run around the neighborhood telling her friends that her father "took twenty-five years to get through medical school."
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Lafayette registered three first-period touchdowns today and then coasted to an easy triumph over Bueknell's football team, 34 -- 13.
The uncertainties of weather forecasting were forcibly dramatized in the extra-tropical cyclone that brought killer floods to the Northeast last week-end.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 22 -- New weapons "of almost unbelievable possibilities and staggering to the imagination" may soon replace conventional artillery and the piloted plane, the leaders of the nation's ground forces were told here today.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Terry Logan of Essex Fells and Ken Smith, Ridgewood, upset Mrs. Marge Mason and Jack Moone of Dellwood in the quarter-finals of the mixed open Scotch foursomes golf tournament at the Dellwood Country Club today.

THE traveler in Europe, especially when far from the cities, can hardly avoid being impressed by the penetration of the American movie. No matter how active the native industry, however many festival awards its pictures may have won, the Hollywood product is still the main current in the flow of film entertainment through the small towns and hamlets of the Continent.

Shirt and pajama production will continue next year at the accelerated rate established this year, according to Benedict Berkowitz, retiring president of the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers.

" The indisputable leader in his field" is the estimate that Dr. Goran Liljestrand, secretary of the Nobel Committee on Medicine, gives of Dr. Hugo Theorell, who has been awarded the Nobel prize for clarifying one of the most mysterious and most important of life processes.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Halfback Sam Brown returned a punt 67 yards for a touchdown that broke the back of Iowa and the Bruins went on to score a 33-13 victory last night before 75,692 fans in Memorial Coliseum.
A program to help develop better science teachers was announced last week.
NEWARK, Oct. 22 -- Candidates for the New Jersey Legislature have a more forthright stand on the state minimum wage issue than on any other.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 22 -- For the thirteenth consecutive year the residents of Oyster Bay will pay no township tax. This is in spite of an increase of more than $500,000 in the budget for 1956.

IT will be far more fun than parking them with grandmother or sending them to camp. They'll get the thrill of a lifetime out of the Crown Jewels at the Tower of London, and the Kings and Queens at Madame Tussaud's Waxworks, and the historic ceremony of Changing the Guard at Buckingham Palace. And they'll enjoy being able to talk to the English children: same language.

JUST off the sea-bitten northwest coast of Scotland is Skye, a great lobster of an island with its tail toward Inverness-shire and its claws reaching out into the Minch. It is fifty miles long, has three hundred miles of coastline, and no place is more than four miles from the sea.

BARUIPUR, India, Sept. 14 -- All over India and in many countries of the West economists are watching an experiment that started with a carpenter who had an extra bit of wood and a blacksmith who had an extra scrap of steel.
ALTHOUGH the manner is light, the meaning is ominous. In "Tiger at the Gates" Jean Giraudoux has written a witty play to prove that war cannot be stopped by reason.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has turned down a claim by seventeen steamship and stevedoring companies. The companies said they had been overcharged for workmen's compensation insurance for their longshoremen from July, 1948, to January, 1950.

GENEVA, Oct. 10 -- The European countries bordering the Mediterranean have many things in common, ranging from dryness of climate to an apparently deeply rooted incapacity to cope with economic drains. It is the more surprising that they differ so widely in their approach to the role of government in promoting economic development.

IN "The Ragged Edge" Marquis Childs, who is entitled after all these years to rank as one of our most indefatigable and durable columnists, lecturers and authors, has a thesis. We are living on "the ragged edge" of destruction, balanced precariously, our destiny in the hands of individuals "faced with problems seemingly insurmountable," who are playing a performance "of almost nightmarish unreality."

DALLAS, Oct. 22 -- Southwestern business last week continued at its steady high-level pace, but ironically rains were causing trouble in the formerly drought-stricken High Plains area of West Texas. Lack of transportation and storage facilities were threatening to ruin about $2,000,000 worth of grain sorghums already harvested, and the harvest was only about 20 per cent completed.

When the corn is as high as an elephant's eye, the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway rides high, too. Just at the moment, with the corn harvest at its height, this longest United States railroad is rounding out its best year since 1950, and its best peacetime year ever.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The United States Government is delaying action on a proposal of the International Labor Organization to combat forced labor throughout the world.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 22 (UP) -- High Voltage, a stretch-running invader from New York, streaked to a three-length victory in the fourteenth and richest running of the $51,850 Vineland Handicap today at Garden State Park.
DENVER, Oct. 22 -- Dr. Paul Dudley White estimated today that President Eisenhower would be well enough to leave the hospital within three weeks.

Two national human relations agencies asserted last night that controversies on social problems among the three major religious faiths in this country could not be resolved by open Congressional hearings without friction or strife.

FOR more years than anyone can remember, the voice of Bert Bell has been raised in the councils of the National Football League with the strident plea that the point after the touchdown be abolished. Thus far the suggestion of the Commissioner has been ignored and recent events indicate that Bell's ringing words will clang even more hollowly in the future.
CAIRO, Oct. 19 -- Land reform, heart of the Egyptian revolution, has been a success in its first three years.

WHEN in 1862 Sylvanus Cadwallader changed from steamer to train at Cairo, Ill., en route to Grant's headquarters in western Tennessee, he was filled with reservations concerning this Union general who had looked so good at Donelson and so bad at Shiloh, and who, as far as anyone could tell, was now running out of breath in a game of hare and hounds with the Rebels.

TORONTO, Oct. 22 -- Tod Sloan scored in the first and third periods tonight to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-2 victory over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game before 12,947 at Maple Leaf Gardens.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Nebraska's alert Cornhuskers overcame a 6-point half-time deficit to send the Missouri Tigers to their sixth football defeat of the season, 18 -- 12, before a home-coming gathering of 25,300 today.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 22 -- A thundering Pittsburgh line, led by a 220-pound end, John Paluck, forced Duke into seven fumbles today and this paved the way for a 26-7 rout of the team that had been rated seventh in the nation.

DURHAM, N. H., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Quarterback Jim Stehlin scored one touchdown and passed for two others -- the last with three minutes remaining -- today as Brandeis turned back New Hampshire, 20 -- 14, in a mild upset.

CHRYSANTHEMUMS continue to dominate the fall scene both in gardens and flower shows. In Westchester, the first countywide all-chrysanthemum show will take place on Friday and Saturday, when thirty-nine horticulture classes plus a roomful of Oriental and modern arrangements will go on view.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Princeton's football players, working out of the single wing with telling effect, defeated Cornell, 26 -- 20, today before 25,000 persons at Schoellkopf field.

THIS is a powerful study of the role of the German officers' corps in shaping the foreign and domestic policies of the Prussian Kingdom and, after 1871, of the German Reich. It covers the same period and much of the same material as does Walter Goerlitz' "History of the German General Staff," published here in the spring of 1953.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Navy said today it had suffered an outright loss on only twenty-nine of its controversial F3H Demon fighter planes. This is the plane that would not fly properly because the engine was not powerful enough.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Mississippi State downed Alabama, 26 to 7, today for its fifth straight victory. A homecoming crowd of 28,000 saw Alabama go down to its tenth consecutive defeat over a two-season span.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority released today its financial statement for the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1955. Net revenues from power operations were $47,900,000, compared with $28,800,000 in the previous fiscal year. This was an increase of almost 65 per cent.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 22 -- There was war talk in Israel during the week. But there was more talk about the foolishness of war. Since Israel is a democracy, the voices that are ultimately decisive are those raised in the nation's Parliament, and there a large majority showed itself against aggressive action.
The city's celebration of National Farm-City Week opened yesterday with a Department of Agriculture exhibit at Pennsylvania Station.

The Coast Guard -- seagoing angel of mercy for thousands -- used its emergency abilities last week for one of its own. As a result, Radarman 1/c Charles F. Waters Jr. is now at the bedside of his critically ill mother, Mrs. Mildred Waters.
ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- The boxer that had impressed by taking best American-bred at Westminster last February, became best, in show tonight in the twelfth event of the Albany Kennel Club.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 22 -Indications are growing that Connecticut will increase its sales tax temporarily to pay for flood relief.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Indiana dropped Northwestern into the Big Ten cellar today with a 20-14 victory. The power running of Fullback John Bartkiewicz and the passing of Gene Cichowski paced the winners.
UNION CITY, N. J., Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Sign, national Roman Catholic magazine, said today that the social pattern of the United States was killing people before their time.

WILLIAM WILLIS is a dreamer who made his most ardent dream come true; a philosopher of sorts with a poetic streak in him. Some of his friends thought he was a bit cracked to undertake a voyage across the Pacific alone aboard a raft.

ORANJESTAD, Aruba, Dutch West Indies, Oct. 22 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands told Aruban youth today it had "a country with a future" that could be realized by meeting community responsibilities.

SOME cocktail party hosts and hostesses provide enough canapes, tid-bits and dunks to make a light supper. Others keep a cold roast and the makings of a salad secreted in the background to provide sustenance for the late lingerers, but Marion Flexner goes farther and invites all her cocktail guests to stay for supper.
TRIVANDRUM, India, Oct. 20 -- Southern India, a world in itself of many peoples and many tongues, is a restless collection of all the problems and strains that weigh on the Indian nation.
THE current excitement about whether Johnny can or cannot read seems incidental to the ultimate fact that all the Johnnies end up reading. We are one of the "readingest" nations in the world.

AFTER what can be described truly as a triumphal European tour, followed by engagements on the West Coast and in Chicago, the New York City Ballet returns to its home stand, the City Center, for an eight-week season beginning November 8.
ODESSA, a Russian city in the southwest Ukraine, has long been known as a musical center. It has produced its share of internationally known virtuosos. The late Simon Barere was born in Odessa.

THESE two beautiful books on the most highly evolved animal group are so alike in format and title that one hopes that there will not be confusion in their choice. For in fact these two extensive volume complement each other, and neither can truthfully be said to be the more valuable.

THOMAS DOZIER'S review of "Bull Fever," by Kenneth Tynan, used the word "intellectual" three times. We are frequently told these days that one must be intellectual to understand the "pageantry" and "grace" of bullfighting.
NOISE, and more noise. Such was a visitor's first impression of the Audio Fair, which last week completed a hectic five-day stand at the New Yorker Hotel.
Stanley Hoffman, a young French scholar, has won the first prize of $1,500 in the annual competition of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace on international organization problems.

Under the Constitution of the Fourth Republic, France must hold parliamentary elections at least every five years. The first took place in 1946; the second in 1951, and the third must be held by June, 1956, at the latest. But the French Government can advance the date, provided the National Assembly agrees.

SAIGON, Oct. 22 (Reuters) -- The Premier scheduled tomorrow's plebiscite in the hope of finally unraveling a political tangle that has ensnarled South Vietnam since April. At that time, Bao Dai ordered Mr. Diem to fly to his Cannes villa. Mr. Diem, stripped of all military authority by the Chief of State, refused to obey -- and set up a new government that "deposed" Bao Dai.

GENEVA, Oct. 22 -- The Inter-government Committee for European Migration has adopted a target of 125,900 Europeans to be moved to new homes abroad with the committee's assistance during 1956. This is about the same as the 1955 scale of movements.

STAY-AT-HOMES during the Civil War glimpsed the front through two media: prints made from the negatives of Mathew Brady and other practitioners of the time-exposure, on view in the larger cities, and wood engravings, made from the work of artists in the field, in the illustrated weeklies.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- U Nu praised the Soviet Union tonight for having saved his country from an economic crisis by purchasing its surplus rice. He said Burma wanted to import Soviet factories, machinery and equipment as well as technicians in exchange for rice exports.

Hats off to G. Gaddis Smith for his wonderful and accurate expose of that refined form of torture known as the freshman mixer. [The reference is to "Freshman Mixer: or, the Wallflower Must Go" (Oct. 9), in which Mr. Smith described the get-acquainted week-end dances arranged by Vassar, Smith and sister colleges to introduce their freshman girls to their opposite numbers in such "male strongholds as Dartmouth, Amherst or Yale" -- Editor.]
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Donald M. Dozer, fighting his dismissal as a State Department historian, attributed his troubles today to Democratic hold-overs.

A "glass rat" is percolating and pumping blood in the physiological chemistry laboratories of the University of California. Dr. David Jensen, a junior research biochemist, watches over the glass rat. He is working in collaboration with Dr. Harold Tarver, an associate professor of physiological chemistry.
ALBANY, Oct 22 -- The controversy over the proposed $750,000,000 state highway bond continued unabated this issue week.
Brooklyn's trans-Atlantic passenger shipping will be increased early next year under the terms of a pier lease signed last week by Zim Israel America Lines.

ON page 1 of this book we learn that Jane, celebrating her tenth birthday, had left home "with the thought of living in a tree, because Theodore had said he was going to kill her." On this realistic note we are introduced to the four Cares children, probably the most uninhibited youngsters in fiction since Richard Hughes wrote "The Innocent Voyage."
BOSTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- David Schine, whose early Army career led to the much-publicized Army- McCarthy controversy, said tonight he was through with politics and investigations of communism.

AT this time of year, when bitter cold spells can follow upon sunny, balmy weather in the space of only a few hours, it pays to be prepared. A motorist should make certain, while a little time still remains, that the car is ready for the freezing winter days ahead.
A hitherto undiscovered poem by Elizabeth Barrett Browning was added yesterday to the list of her works.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Deputy Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty forces in Europe, listed President Eisenhower today as "among my great friends."

Many tickets have been purchased for Thursday night's performance of "The Young and Beautiful" at the Longacre Theatre for the benefit of the West Side Day Nursery. It had been announced previously that the benefit would be held at the performance of "A Day By the Sea," but that play closed.

A middle-income housing development on the lower East Side, financed by a union, was dedicated yesterday at ceremonies attended by 5,000 persons. The first group of 1,668 families to occupy the I. L. G. W. U. Cooperative Village, on the East River in the Corlears Hook section, will begin moving in tomorrow.
Foreign students from eighty-four nations will be honored tomorrow afternoon at a convocation - reception marking New York University's observance of United Nations Day.
SYRACUSE, Sicily, Oct. 21 -- More than 2,000 objects of great antiquity were recovered by divers last summer from Syracuse harbor.

NO doubt about it, Belle Boyd was quite a girl. This pistol-packin' Confederate spy was in prison three times before she was 20. The Federals were embarrassed to detain her, but what could they do with someone so fiercely determined to win the war all by herself? Stonewall Jackson commissioned her a captain and an honorary aide-de-camp for the important part she played in the Battle of Front Royal.

THIS story of a British surgeon gives a revealing glimpse of England under the last National Health Insurance Act, which set up, in the essence, a system of socialized medicine. Well trained, personable, courting the daughter of Sir Arthur Benson-Gray, head of the surgical staff at Graftondale Royal Hospital, Philip Selwood is a fortunate man indeed.

HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 22 -- Everything was perfect in the Hanover Hills today. Dartmouth won a football game after losing four straight, topping its old Ivy rival, Harvard, 14 -- 9, at Memorial Stadium.

The New York City Opera has added a talented conductor to its staff.

The statesmen who represent most of the effective power in the world will meet in Geneva this coming Thursday to begin the next round in the struggle for peace. They will meet in a foreign ministers' conference, projected for some three weeks, at which the United States, Britain and France will apply the "acid test" to the real meaning of the "spirit of Geneva."
The New York Giants, who beat the Chicago Cardinals in the mud and rain last week at the Polo Grounds for their first league victory, will play hosts to the Pittsburgh Steelers today.

The swelling tide of Japanese textiles and finished goods coming into the United States is being met by a counter-wave of resentment on the part of American textile interests. A result may be an all-out drive to place sharp restrictions on imports from Japan.
MIDLAND, Tex., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Led by Captain Chick Harbert and Ted Kroll, the United States Ryder Cup team gained a 12-3 advantage over Jimmy Demaret's challenge team at Midland Country Club today.

NOT much bigger than your thumb, Sugarplum was the kind of doll that one remembers long after bigger, showier darlings are forgotten. LONDON, Oct. 22 -- For the last two and one-half years relations between the Soviet Union and the West have shifted from the patterns established by the victory in World War II in 1945 and the "cold war" into a more fluid and, from the Western standpoint, more uncertain situation.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 22 -- India, a country in a hurry with a lot on its mind, last week unwrapped a reorganization plan that will affect the states of the union from the Himalayas to Cape Comorin.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Reports that Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler wishes to leave the Treasury have encouraged Laborite leaders to call for a full-scale attack on the Government when Parliament reassembles next week.

I saw him only once in World War II -- in London, during a time when the Cross of Lorraine was far from triumphant, when Free France was France beyond the seas. He was clothed in glacial reserve, and his seeming pomposity was a repellent force.

TODAY, 79-year-old Constantin Brancusi, of Paris, whose long overdue retrospective exhibition will open this Wednesday at the Guggenheim Museum, is considered by many to be the greatest living sculptor, a man who significantly changed the course of sculpture from what he called Rodin's "beefsteak and muscle" art to suave, geometric abstractions and who left telling marks on such important artists as Moore, Arp and Noguchi.

MERVYN LEROY, who has won distinction as a director over the years and also has accumulated some knowledge about the workings of publicity, insists he has not resorted to trickery in withholding the ending he has devised for the film version of "The Bad Seed."
Two-way military traffic flows through the heart of the national security program. Nearly a million young Americans are separated from the Armed Forces each year.

CHILDREN love stories of trolls and ogres and kind-hearted fairies; of brave young princes rescuing beautiful young princesses; of talking trees and golden apples. They will be delighted with these tales from fifteen countries.

In the frantic search for more teachers, quality is taking a back seat. Hard-won professional standards are losing ground in many of the nation's schools. Unqualified teachers are being recruited into the classrooms in all grade levels.
SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Oct. 22 -- Under cloudy skies and in an equally murky political atmosphere the Saar prepared today for a referendum tomorrow to which great importance has been attached.

For the first time since its founding in 1924, the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., will present, a fall show in conjunction with the thirty-second annual Women's International Exposition. The exposition will be held Nov. 7-13 at the Seventy-First Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

ROME, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A young American who established the Church of Christ in Italy plans to leave Rome Monday for home because the Italian Foreign Ministry has refused to extend his permit to remain in Italy.

SUBTITLED "a collection of parody, satire and literary burlesque of American writers past and present," this is an amiable addition to the special shelf of anthologies best exemplified by John Macy's "American Writers on Literature" and Edmund Wilson's "The Shock of Recognition.

IN designing the three chapels -- one Protestant, one Catholic and one Jewish -- that will be dedicated next Sunday on the campus of Brandeis University at Waltham, Mass., the noted architects, Harrison and Abramovitz, had as their aim the spiritual and architectural unity of three separate places of worship.

Bless Beverly Kelley for his nostalgic account of the calliope on its hundredth birthday. ("They Call It 'Cally-ope'", Oct. 9). One might add that old wives circulated the falsehood that calliopes were dangerous and often blew up.

In "Lengthening Longevity" (Sept. 25), William C. FitzGibbon, setting forth the life expectancy in various countries, cited among "low rates" that of Puerto Rico, with a life expectancy of forty-six years.

THE manufacturer of the engine that will power this country's jet airliners looks to the jet-transport race to help quash public doubts about the nation's air supremacy. This line of thinking was outlined here last week by Frederick B. Rentschler, chairman of the United Aircraft Corporation.
Jean Kerr's delightful article. "How to Decorate in One Easy Breakdown" (Oct. 2), was just what I needed.

Three museum events are interspersed among numerous and diverse attractions in art galleries this week. The Metropolitan Museum will show, beginning tomorrow, pictures, memorabilia, miniatures and other material relating to the theatre in France, in recognition of the visit of the Comedie Francaise.

THIS is by far Leigh Brackett's best novel to date and it comes awfully close to being a great work of science fiction. With a remarkable zest for detail she has drawn an agrarian post-Destruction America of many farms and few towns, peopled by a God-fearing, progress-hating simple folk.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Mootov was asked tonight whether he intended to resign. He eplied: "I will give an answer to that question in Geneva." The Soviet Foreign Minister will leave Tuesday for Geneva with other members of the Soviet delegation to the Big Four foreign ministers' conference.

NEWARK, Del., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Halfback Jim Zaiser scored two touchdowns and passed for another as the University of Delaware defeated Connecticut, 26 -- 14, today with three fourth-quarter touchdowns.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 22 -- Fired-up Minnesota shook proud Michigan to its foundations today before the top ranked football team in the land wiped out a two-touch down deficit for a 14-13 victory.

BETWEEN the second quarter of 1954 -- the low quarter of the recent recession -- and the second quarter of 1955, output in the United States rose by the enormous amount of $27.2 billion a year, or 7.6 per cent. This is one of the largest and quickest recoveries on record.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Communist China charged the United States today with repeated espionage. Peiping asserted that the United Nations Secretary General, Dag Hammarskjold, had recognized Red China's right to sentence intruding airmen, and outlined its attitude toward world affairs.

THE star boarder at the Aqueduct racetrack, a dozen miles from Times Square, is a big, handsome, light-mahogany-colored horse with H 3749 tattooed under his upper lip. He weighs close to 1,200 pounds; he wears size 6 shoes; he has breakfast at 4 A. M.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- A completely unknown sophomore from the junior varsity replaced George Welsh at quarterback today as Navy swamped Pennsylvania, 33 -- 0, on Franklin Field. It was Navy's fifth successive victory and Penn's seventeenth defeat in a row going back to 1953.

President Eisenhower's illness has had at least one constructive consequence: that of emphasizing the untenable physical and emotional burden which can only increase with time for any occupant of that office. Cabell Phillips' article, "The Crushing Burden of the Presidency" (Oct. 2), does overdue service in defining this impossible situation.

America's eighty-one medical schools must have $10,000,000 in additional annual income from private sources or eventually turn to Federal Government subsidies, according to S. Sloan Colt, president of the National Fund for Medical Education.

MANILA, Oct. 22 -- Government red tape surrounding international air travel came apart in a score of places at the closing sessions of the international aviation conference. The conference will formally adjourn on Monday.

REVERED wherever French is understood, the 275-year - old Comedie Francaise is ready to make its first appearance on an American stage. Following its Canadian tour, the distinguished state-owned repertory company will settle down at the Broadway Theatre Tuesday night for a four-week engagement.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 22 -- The Brazilian public had assurances today from both political and military elements that there would be no move to set aside constitutional government.

Flood has always been one of man's awesome enemies. In all lands and all languages there are stories of the Great Flood. Noah's story is one version of it. Man's racial memory reaches back to days when old mountains were new, and even then the floods were carving out the valleys, driving man for safety to the hills.
TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The word probably has gone out to all the pitchers in Japan not to throw those "inside corner balls" when they face the New York Yankees.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Mexican Army horse show team gave evidence tonight that it will take more than a crippling auto accident to prevent it from winning international jumping competition. The patched-up Mexicans ran off with both first and second places in the opening international jump of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Oct. 22 -- George T. Weymouth of Wilmington, Del., watched two of his horses capture the top two races at the twenty-fifth annual Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association meeting today.

WHEN we were young and some issues were more clear-cut than they seem to be today, parents of a baby girl adorned their child in pink and those with an infant son to dress chose shades of blue. Today in many circles a cheerful yellow serves for both.

A group of Villagers will take a new look at Greenwich Village in a series of five Sunday evening meetings to be held this fall at the New School for Social Research. The series, which opens this evening, will explore what Greenwich Village was, what it is, and what it may become.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The United States is now engaged in the most ambitious search for a workable arms limitation program in the centuries-old history of this subject.

ROSE FRANKEN has not gained her large reading public by luck or chance. She is a specialist in the things women think about, worry about, laugh about or dream about. She skillfully builds a plot around some human, fundamental problem and sees that there are plenty of everyday bits of living for the reader to recognize and apply to herself.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 22 -- West Virginia passed its stiffest football test of the season today as it rallied to beat Penn State, 21 -- 7.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland -- Next year Europe expects to receive 17 per cent more American tourists than it did this year and these visitors will pay an estimated 10 to 15 per cent more for rooms, meals, services, souvenirs, etc.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 22 -- A motorist will be able to drive his automobile across Indiana on the northern toll road for $1.95 when the 156-mile turnpike is opened to traffic.

MODERN gardeners are giving more thought to the planting of dwarf evergreens, especially since modern home design makes impractical the planting of the taller and heavier plants. Because this trend is expected to continue, its elements should be thoroughly understood by all who intend to beautify their own property.

LOOUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 22 -- The Buckram Beagle Hunt Ball will be held here on the night of Nov. 12 at the Piping Rock Club. Dr. Joseph B. Conolly Jr. and J. Wooderson Glenn are joint masters of the Buckram Beagles.

After reading "Miniature Militias" (Oct. 2), Pierce G. Frederick's article about the Hersbruck, Germany, collection of toy soldiers and the widespread interest in miniatures as a hobby, I went up into the attic and brought down something for the children to see -- a miniature of a dying Nazi, which I bought in Germany in August, 1939. It is called "A Dying Nazi." (See above.)
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Jack Pardee led Texas A. and M. to a 19-7 victory over Baylor to send the Aggies to the top of the Southwest Conference before 35,000 fans today.

TULIPS are unsurpassed as bright accents among the fresh green of spring. The flowers, gay and cheerful, are beautifully and often uniquely formed, and they last well when cut. And to obtain these delights next spring, the gardener need only observe a few basic planting points this fall.

This afternoon at Morris Park Avenue and Eastchester Road in the Bronx, formal dedication ceremonies will be held for the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University. This new medical school, which admitted its first students last month, is the first medical school in our nation to be established under Jewish auspices.

A NEW plastic material in putty form is claimed to be resistant to chipping, cracking, peeling or shrinking. Pipe leaks, valve seats, cracks and splits in metal or wood can be filled with the synthetic metal.
Herbert M. Schatz and William F. Blitzer have been elected vice presidents of Lightolier, Inc., manufacturers of lamps and lighting fixtures.
American Export Lines yesterday put up its fleet of thirty vessels for adoption -- by the nation's school children.
Although Mr. Smith's story was substantially accurate, it failed to include a fine innovation arrived at after long and arduous research here.

Tufts University has just produced a film as a special service to the cause of higher education. The film is available free to high schools and preparatory schools, Parent-Teacher Associations and other groups interested in college and university education.

UNPAINTED furniture is deservedly in favor because there are on the market so many well-designed cabinets, dressers, desks and other pieces for home furnishing. These pieces are practical and quite well made of clear ponderosa pine.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Oklahoma crushed Colorado, 56 -- 21, today with shocking power that overcame a 14-point deficit and virtually clinched the Sooners' eighth straight Big Seven championship and another Orange Bowl bid.

A granite plaque in memory of Fireman John P. Hamilton was unveiled at Ladder Company 17 at 341 East 143d Street, the Bronx, at 11 A. M. yesterday. His mother, Mrs. Blanche King of 309 East 164th Street, the Bronx, took part in the ceremony.
NEWARK, Oct. 22 -- The crucial decision as to which major political party will control the State Assembly in 1956 appears to rest on the Nov. 8 balloting in Essex.

The news from Fitzsimons Army Hospital in Denver is good in two ways. First, as an examination by the President's physicians and specialists shows, Mr. Eisenhower is recovering from his attack of coronary thrombosis. The doctors are professionally cautious, but the outlook justifies optimism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The whole of the Democratic Party, right-wing, left-wing and center, is engaged now in a series of mutual accommodations intended to submerge all harsh factionalism for reasons both of necessity and of ultimate hope.

Profits of industrial manufacturers in the first half of this year were the highest ever recorded for any similar period -- war or peacetime. Continued booming operations in the third quarter indicate that nine-month results will hold that lead.

WIDE - SCREEN movies for 16mm moviemakers the Hollywood Cinemascope way were introduced here last week in the 16mm Vidoscope Anamorphic Lens by Walter Futter's Vidoscope Corporation, 730 Fifth Avenue.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 22 -- The vituperation that marked the Democratic primary campaign for the governorship has carried over into the election campaign.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- The principal problems claiming attention of the West, particularly relations between the United States and Italy, were discussed by Secretary of State Dulles and President Giovanni Gronchi tonight. The Italian Foreign Minister, Dr. Gaetano Martino, and United States Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce also were present.

Two upstate harriers, Dave Cotton of Nott Terrace, Schenectady, and Vincent McKenna of Arlington, Poughkeepsie, ran off with individual honors yesterday in the fifth annual St. John's interscholastic cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park.

HAVERHILL, Mass., Oct. 22 (UP) -- An official of the state Baptist convention said today that he had canceled reservations for guest speakers at a hotel here because of the management's refusal to admit a Negro educator.
GENEVA, Oct. 22 -- Swiss official circles believe the United States was once on the right track in dealing with the Soviet Union under the "new look," but is now off it.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Rake leaves from the lawn and under shrubs, and add to the compost pile. It is especially important to keep a newly sown lawn free of leaves. Clear away after autumn storms broken or dangling branches of trees. Make a clean cut behind the break and cover with shellac or tree wound paint to prevent start of decay.
As a Frenchman and as a political scientist I should like to comment briefly upon some of the statements in the editorial "European Crossroads" which appeared in The New York Times of Oct. 16.
Recalling the heroism of individuals in the recent floods, a rabbi called on his congregation yesterday in a sermon to "stand upright against the flood waters of evil and of herd thinking."

THOSE who like to put comparative interpretations under the microscope have an ideal opportunity with Mozart's Linz Symphony. Two eminent Mozart specialists have come out with recordings, both for Columbia.

The value of systems is determined by their usefulness to the society which creates them. It is in this spirit that the University of Chicago with the aid of the Ford Foundation undertook a study of our jury system.

THE title of this highly original first novel is the name given, symbolically, to the head of a wild pig which has been slaughtered for food by a horde of English schoolboys stranded on an uninhabited island somewhere in the Pacific.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 12 -- Minister of Government Lucio Pabon Nunez has sent a circular to the Governors of States and heads of districts confirming his instructions of last year with regard to activities that may be carried out by non-Catholic pastors and their flocks, both Colombian and foreign.

THE annual Photo Jamboree sponsored by the Metropolitan Camera Club Council will be held on Saturday and Sunday at the Hotel Empire, Broadway at Sixty-third Street. The principal event will be the annual awards dinner at 7 P. M. Saturday, the occasion for the distribution of a long list of honors for various club achievements during the past year.

THE "Kraft Television Theatre" stirred controversy last week by announcing that it would give a bonus of $50,000 to the writer of the "best original play" produced by Kraft during a fifty-two-week period.

THE Staten Island-Manhattan Ferry, whose charge it is to connect the North American continent to Staten Island, is going to take a satisfied look at its fifty-year history this week and congratulate itself on having come so far and done so well.
Aid to sightless persons will be furthered as the result of the Thanksgiving Eve annual dinner dance for the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- During the last two weeks the Supreme Court has heard arguments in eighteen cases. Four of them were in the category that has come to be known as "civil rights" cases.
TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Land reforms introduced by the United States occupation have added the equivalent of another island, as large as one of the four main ones, to Japan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The State Department has received assurances that Israel will delay her plan to divert the Jordan River to Israeli soil at least until the end of the rainy season.

REASONABLENESS is a virtue which one does not naturally expect to find shining in every motion picture like a jewel in an Ethiope's ear. There are certain types of entertainment, such as Alfred Hitchcock's candid opera bouffe (not boff!) called "The Trouble With Harry," now at the Paris Theatre, wherein an obvious abandonment of reason and intellectual respectability is the key to the very nature of the humor or whatever it contains.

FROM December 8, 1952 to December 20, 1954 Life published at intervals of about two months a series of thirteen magnificently illustrated articles by Lincoln Barnett in which he traced the evolution of the earth as a planet, with its rocks and rills, its life and its destiny.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- With the retirement of David E. Finley, the National Gallery of Art will lose the direction of the man whose association with it began when the gallery was only a dream of Andrew W. Mellon.

Applications are now open to college and university faculty members for places in the Oak Ridge Research Participation Program for 1956. The program enables teachers in educational institutions to spend the three summer months in Oak Ridge laboratories to conduct research.

AS a science fiction writer, Chad Oliver is unusual. His stories are not based on the usual sciences of physics, chemistry, astronomy; he adds the fresh viewpoint of anthropology and sociology. In five of this volume's seven stories, he explores the effect of man's appearance in space, and his relationship with the alien cultures he meets there.

EXACTLY a century ago Delacroix won a grand medal of honor at the Paris Exposition of 1855. It was his first great official success and not obtained without that rumble of academic protest which accompanied the great romantic's career from start to finish.

THE world does move. Or does it? At long last the Metropolitan Opera will have a new home. Or will it? The Metropolitan board of directors is acting decisively. This is an era of optimism and goodwill. There will be a new opera house.

BASED on fact, this is the strange tale of John Tanner who, in the Seventeen Seventies, was kidnaped by Indians from his Kentucky frontier home and carried off to Canada. With the exception of his foster par ents, the Indians hated the boy with the deep hatred they held for all white men.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 22 (UP) -- A touring team of top Russian builders and engineers were mildly critical of construction methods used on an apartment house project today but admitted that the end result was "very similar to what we have in Russia."
MADRID, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Two United States Senators tonight spurned a special four-engined DC-6 plane sent to bring them home from Europe and said they would travel by regular Air Force services.

CORVALLIS. Ore., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Oregon State gained its second Pacific Coast Conference victory today, 14 -- 6. The Beavers scored two first-half touchdowns and resisted a Washington State uprising in the second half.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- With the Geneva conference only days away, a cautionary note seems to dominate Soviet press comment on foreign affairs. To Western observers the aim seems to be to warn the Soviet people not to have exaggerated hopes that the foreign ministers' meeting will solve all problems and end all international tension.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Barbara Friedemann of Larchmont and the Boulder Brook Cllub, Scarsdale, won the hunter seat horsemanship championship at the Saddle Tree Farms' fall horse show today. Geraldine Mannion of Rye and the Kentucky Riding Stable, White, Plains, was selected for the saddle seat equitation tri-color.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 22 -- Alert Notre Dame turned Purdue's passing attack into an Irish weapon and avenged its only 1954 defeat, 22 -- 7, today before a Ross-Ade Stadium record crowd of 55,500.

Members of the Women's Committee of the Big Brother Movement of Greater New York have taken over the mezzanine of the Radio City Music Hall for the Christmas show on the night of Dec. 15 to raise funds for the organization.

OBVIOUSLY Nina Pulliam is a highly energetic, somewhat garrulous and decidedly outgoing woman. She thoroughly enjoyed the 40,000-mile tour of Australia she made in 1953, and her book shows it from first page to last.

HOWEVER controversial his separate careers as novelist, playwright, philosopher and would-be-political leader, at least one total impression Jean-Paul Sartre ought to have established by this time -- that he is one of the most brilliant minds alive.

THIS fall several million hunters in the United States will bag several million pounds of feathered and furred game. In Pennsylvania alone, hunters will bring home 1,800 tons of deer meat. MANY a sincere European music - lover has been looking forward to the Mozart Year in 1956 with pleasure not unmitigated by apprehension. There is such thing a thing as too much, even of Mozart, and many a man is still alive who remembers the excessive Beethoven homage of 1927.

NEW ALBANY, Ind., Oct. 22 (UP) -- David Gilkey of Cincinnati, who lived for three weeks in the middle of the Army's heavy artillery range, near Madison, was fined $25 and costs in Federal Court here yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Princess Margaret left late today to join Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh at Windsor Castle for the week-end.
Sgt. Barney Arluck of the New York Police Department won $50,000 last night by answering two questions on law during the National Broadcasting Company's television program, "The Big Surprise."

WASHINGTON, D. C. -- The great, motherly heart of the United States Government goes out to its citizens in many a way, none more helpfully than through the Government Printing Office. Among the many documents issued there, ranging as they do from tips on how to bring up babies to how to raise broccoli, is a wide collection especially interesting to people planning vacation trips.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Steel production in the Chicago area during the first nine months this year rose to 16,046,000 net tons, a new record for the nine-month period, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported.
ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Excellent defensive play by an end, Grover Jones, who blocked two punts and recovered a fumble, helped Virginia Tech gain a 17-13 uphill victory over Virginia today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Hungary took the lead in the opening event of the 1955 modern pentathlon world championships today. The United States is eleventh in the fifteen-nation competition.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Upsala College's football team blocked two Hofstra punts for a safety and a touchdown today and went on to triumph, 28 -- 7.

NON-STOP service between Ciudad Trujillo, capital of the Dominican Republic, and New York was begun last week by Pan American World Airways, making the 1,630 miles in less than six hours. DO-6B's leave Idlewild at 1 A. M. Sunday, Wednesday and Friday, and Ciudad Trujillo at noon on the same days.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Members of the Westchester County Historical Society re-enacted today the flight and capture 175 years ago of Maj. John Andre, the British spy.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Spurred by Walter Fondren, the Texas Longhorns today upset the Rice Owls, 32 -- 14, before 46,000 football fans.

IN 1830 a French Army arrived in Algeria to begin the conquest and "pacification" of a territory four times as large as France itself. For over a century since, Algeria has been regarded -- by the French -- as essentially French soil; that is, not a protectorate, like Morocco on the west or Tunisia on the east, but a legal, constitutional extension of Metropolitan France across the Mediterranean into North Africa.

ALTHOUGH Alfred Hitchcock currently is represented by two films ("The Trouble With Harry" and "To Catch a Thief"), a forthcoming feature remake of his thriller, "The Man Who Knew Too Much," and a pair yet to be made ("The Wrong Man" and "Flamingo Feather"), he is not the man to rusticate.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- It will be more than a year before tourists visiting Florida win be able to motor over the toil turnpike now being built between Fort Pierce and Miami and possibly a year later when a full-length state turnpike will be completed.

NICOLAS, one of our foremost illustrators and winner of the 1951 Caldecott award, has written his first story. It is an off-beat, rather wry little tale concerning Siegfried, a polar bear who hopes to lead his fellow inmates out of the zoo to Bear's Land.

A little more than twenty years ago the Saar was closing a stormy campaign for a plebiscite to decide its future. The Saarlanders were given a choice, then, of becoming part of France, or Germany, or carrying on under the commission appointed by the League of Nations.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 22 -- West German politicians are naturally concerned with the problem of leadership, particularly now, in view of the age and illness of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. Once again the political machinery has ground almost to a halt during Dr. Adenauer's absence from office.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sunday, Oct. 23 -- Five Syrians soldier were captured by the Israelis during the night, Army headquarters announced here today.

DENVER, Oct. 22 (UP) -- President Eisenhower sent his "very best wishes" today to the Conference on Anti-Discrimination in Government Contracts. It opens Monday in Washington with Vice President Richard M. Nixon presiding.
ATHENS, Oct. 22 -- Turkey will show military honors to the Greek flag Monday at Izmir (Smyrna).

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 22 -- National prosperity, buttresed by higher employment, will continue through the first half of 1956 and probably through the year, the Business Advisory Council told Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks today.

BYRON REECE is the author of a fine novel, "Better a Dinner of Herbs," and of four volumes of verse. Reviewing in these columns his "Bow Down in Jericho," I had the pleasure of voicing unstinted praise, although I did note some echoes "ingenuously evoked."

PLOESTI, Rumania, Oct. 20 -- This city is in the heart of Rumania's chief oil-producing region. It was an important and bombing target during World War II, in which Rumania started fighting alongside the Nazis but wound up on the side of the Russians.

" SAN FRANCISCO," a voluntary exile in its midst opined, "is a mad city, inhabited for the most part by perfectly insane people whose women are of a remarkable beauty * * *. [It] has only one drawback -- 'tis hard to leave."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 22 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem today told the people of free Vietnam that they would determine the fate of their country when they chose between him and Chief of State Bao Dai in tomorrow's referendum.

THOSE who know the little daffodils consider them truly enchanting. Any yellow daffodil, large or small, has a perfection in each petal, an intricacy of trumpet and stamen, but this perfection and intricacy -- and charm -- is multiplied many times when the daffodil is a diminutive replica no larger than a delicate buttercup.
WALTON - ON - THAMES, England, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Four British runners today bettered the world's best performance for distance covered in two hours, an unofficial record held by Argentina's Jose Ribas.

A microfilm reproduction of The Manila Tribune, the daily English language tabloid published by the Japanese during their occupation of the Philippine Islands in World War II, has been given the Columbia University Libraries by a former graduate student at the university.

MIAMI BEACH -- Settlement of the strike of hotel employee that has flared sporadically in Miami Beach's ocean-front hotels since last April 13 seemed in the offing last week -- the offing here meaning any time before the opening of the big winter tourist season in December.
James W. Rodgers' Duc de Fer, a 4-year-old Spy Song Colt running in the mutuel field at 10 to 1, captured the thirty-fourth edition of the Interborough Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

CAIRO, Oct. 22 -- Following is an unofficial translation of the text of the mutual defense treaty signed by Egypt and Syria in Damascus on Thursday. The Arabic text was published today in the Government newspaper Al Gamhouriya.
The men's clothing industry is capitalizing on the increasing fashion consciousness of the American male.
The first of the season's New York Public Library free art lectures, "Design and Decoration," will be given at 6:15 P.M. Tuesday in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building.

Four years ago, when Sid Gordon was a slugging infielder-outfielder for the Braves, the asking price for his contract was $100,000. One or two clubs were interested, although nothing in the way of a deal developed.

It is more difficult to get spectacular news out of industrial production increases these days. A leveling off of output is apparent. Nevertheless, figures for the whole third quarter are excellent. WHEN the Western Foreign Ministers sit down at Geneva this week they hope that they may be able for the first time to establish whether Russia's "New Look" is something more than a false face designed to lull the unwary West into a fatal mood of bonhomie.
A musical attack on juvenile delinquency has been proposed to state authorities by the head of New York's 30,000 union musicians.
WAKE FOREST, N. C., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Wake Forest's passers turned last - half breaks into touchdowns today for a 25-0 triumph over North Carolina in the last Homecoming football game on this campus.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Lieut. Roger Carl Hagerty, Marine Corps, son of the Presidential press secretary, James C. Hagerty, today married Miss Eva Margareta Thoren, a Swedish school teacher, in a ten-minute wedding ceremony at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Mediator.
BOSTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Countermand scored a stunning upset in the $30,700 Mayflower Stakes at Suffolk Downs today. He defeated Combustion II, the favorite, by three-quarters of a length.

TWO outstanding modern American printmakers who have just returned from years in Europe are holding exhibitions which illuminate in differing ways the artist's manner of making over themes to suit individual needs of pictorial statement.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 22 -- Democratic and Republican leaders in Nassau County are pleased with the surprisingly large turnout of potential voters under the new permanent personal registration system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Pentagon budget makers are busily trying to melt the fat in national defense without damaging the sinew. The task is admittedly difficult because the Administration is determined to maintain the force levels set for June 30, 1956.
A truly prosperous year for United States world trade -- one based on more solid foundations than in the recent past -- is nearing an end with some new records in the making.
A substantial increase of the newsprint price on the world market would threaten the very existence of one of the most stalwart friends of the United States abroad -- the pro-American free press.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Rhode Island overpowered Brown in every department today to upset the Bruins, 19 -- 7, at Brown Stadium.

MANY a woman, like many a tree, is turning gold or russet-topped almost overnight. Autumn is always the hair colorists' busiest season but this year they're booked solid and a spot check on druggists shows do-it-yourself color kits are doing well, too.

DACCA, Pakistan, Oct. 22 -- The Opposition Awami (People's League), the largest of eight Moslem political parties in East Pakistan's Provincial Assembly, extended membership today to non-Moslems.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct 22 (UP) -- Gene Newton, a sophomore quarterback with the open-field poise of a seasoned player, ran 49 yards for an opening score and 8 yards for a last-period tally to give Tulane a 14-0 upset victory over Georgia today.

Members of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York reviewed last week the qualifications of nominees for vacancies on the bench. Voters in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens will make the final decisions in the November election.

SAMUEL CHOTZINOFF will be at the helm as usual when the National Broadcasting Company opens its seventh season of televised opera on Nov. 6. And as in years past, he will be staging a relentless campaign to eliminate the "Grand" from Grand Opera.
Poly Prep ended Riverdale's domination of the Ivy Prep School football league yesterday with a 26-20 verdict over the Indians on the losers' field in the Bronx.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Gettysburg College turned loose an array of fleet backs today to swamp Muhlenberg, 53 to 14. The Bullets came from two touchdowns behind to run up eight scores on runs ranging from 19 to 80 yards.
SEATTLE, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Stanford's Indians gained a 7-7 tie today and knocked Washington out of first place in the Pacific Coast conference.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Oct. 20 -- The Canadian Pacific Airlines has announced the purchase for delivery in 1957 of three Bristol Britannia turbo-prop airliners. The value of the contract for the 100-passenger aircraft, the largest commercial airliners in the world, was $10,000,000.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open tomorrow an exhibition in honor of the first appearance in New York of the Comedie Francaise. The display will include paintings, stage properties, treasured souvenirs and other objects collected by the famous French company.

CAIRO, Oct. 22 -- The Pharoah Osorkon II. who lost his head about 847 B. C., had it restored this week. The replacement came about because an American archaeologist did some digging in corridors and basements of museums here and in Philadelphia.
The common man of Asia is "grateful beyond measure" for the benefits he has received through the Roman Catholic foreign missionaries, according to Valerian Cardinal Gracias of Bombay, India.

The National Broadcasting Company gave a tourist's eye view of Moscow and Russian farm areas yesterday. The half-hour film steered clear of political differences between the Soviet Union and the West; it took the point of view that the rank and file in Moscow and New York share some of the same daily grind.
Mterial advance may only add to human peril unless it is "regulated and disciplined by moral and spiritual control," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday.
Robert Morley, the British actor noted for the grand manner, will make his American television debut by starring in "Edward, My Son," on the "United States Steel Hour."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The London Philharmonia Orchestra won the acclaim of a large Washington audience today on the opening of its first American tour.
A colorful procession of children dressed as nuns and priests marched yesterday afternoon into St. Patrick's Cathedral, where Mission Sunday was observed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today it had sent two experts to Cairo to discuss with Egyptian authorities "some technician problems relating to the organization and management of the Aswan High Dam project."

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- To say that the City was surprised by the news that R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, would introduce an autumn budget next Wednesday expresses but mildly the effect of the announcement.
