HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- Some 15,000 production employes in the major film studios are looking ahead to Jan. 30, when they will begin a five-day week.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 23 -- Moslem merchants today called a strike of protest and mourning in this capital's native quarter over the killing of four Moroccans in last Friday's demonstration. Shops stayed closed all morning and reopened early this afternoon.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Three junior riflers in the Secor Farms horse show quali-j fled today for the national equi-1 I ta]ion final at Madison Square Garden.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation reported over the week-end a consolidated net income of $34,835,000, or $5.40 a share, for the nine months ended on Sept. 30. For the similar period last year, the company earned $16,534,000, or $2.49 a share.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Federal Reserve Board instituted today an entirely new statistical system for describing what happens in the national economy.
A selection from a book astronomy, "The Nature of the Universe," was read yesterday as the sermon lesson at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley has ruled out physical reconstruction of the Columbus Circle area as a solution to the acute traffic problem that will be posed by the Coliseum.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The United States population rose by 7 per cent to 162,409,000 between 1950 and 1954. All but seven states shared in the increase, the Census Bureau reported today.

Milk industry and union negotiators got nowhere last night in their efforts to head off a possible milk strike in the metropolitan area at 4 P. M. today. They will meet again at 10 o'clock this morning.
The First National City Bank of New York is raising to $25,000 the top amount it will lend under its monthly payment business loan plan. The previous ceiling was $10,000.

The New York Rangers struck back with two goals in the third period to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 4. at Madison Square Garden last night.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Oct. 23 -- An Israeli Army raiding force killed three Syrian soldiers, wounded six others and took at least five prisoners last night.
DENVER, Oct. 23 -- President Eisenhower served notice today he was in complete harmony with the stand to be taken by Secretary of State Dulles at the Geneva conference of foreign ministers.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week. At the close of trading Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 39 points to down 41 from the close of the previous week. The nearer months were higher while the more distant positions lost ground.

After nine years it is now possible to assess some of the results of the Occupation's "land reform" program in Japan, and the Japanese Department of Agriculture just has done so. Some of the findings are astonishing. Obviously, the program was a good one and it changed the pattern of Japanese land holding in a dramatic fashion.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 -- Five heartless state legislators shot Santa Claus for myriad West Coast wrestling fans last week. They brazenly illuminated in public hearings the fact that professional wrestling was a rigged showy.
Summertime traffic jams returned to the highways yesterday, along with the unseasonably balmy weather.
The American Jewish Committee, an agency combating bigotry, defended yesterday the work of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- France's Ambassador to the United States, Maurice Couve de Murville, arrived in Paris today for consultations amid a flurry of speculation that he might face recall. The speculation hovered over an alleged diplomatic indiscretion on a United States radio program.
TROY, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Ch. Barrage of Quality Hill, the 2-year-old boxer owned by Mr. and Mrs. Jouett Shouse of Washington, completed a perfect dog-show week-end today.

Driving through the country these days the eye of the wanderer will light upon an annual symbol of the autumn. Before roadstands and farmhouses pumpkins of all sizes have been thrown together, as though carelessly, to form towering mountains.

Events tonight: Philharmonic Symphony, Sir William Walton and Leonard Bernstein, conductors, Emil Gilels, pianist, United Nations General Assembly Hall 8:45; Dorothy Maynor, soprano Town Hall, 8:30; Salvatore Allegra's opera, "Ave Maria," Walter Tassoni, conductor, the Tolibia Opera Showcase, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Monday, Oct. 21 -- By a vote of more than 2 to 1, the Saar rejected yesterday the French plan, accepted by West Germany, to give this disputed territory a "European" statute.

QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 23 -- A forty-one-year-old dream is nearing realization here. The Government of Ecuador is completing a new railroad line linking the Pacific coast with the snowcapped Andes. Freight traffic is expected to begin moving over the route by early 1956.

In your editorial of Oct. 6 you state that United Nations member nations voted "to drive a democracy like France out of the General Assembly," a theme which is reiterated on Oct. 10. We hardly need draw your attention to the fact that France withdrew entirely of her own volition and by way of protest against the majority vote.

A second book about the Hebrew manuscripts found in a cave near the Dead Sea will be published Nov. 4. "The Dead Sea Scrolls," by Millar Burrows, chairman of the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Literature at Yale University, will be issued by Viking Press.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The Cleveland Browns routed the Green Bay Packers, 41 -- 10, today in celebration of their tenth anniversary as a pro football team.

Improvement of firemen's pension benefits and recognition of heart disease as one of their occupational hazards was urged yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. He made the suggestions at annual memorial services for members of the Fire Department, held at the Firemen's Monument, Riverside Drive and 100th Street.

MYSORE, India, Oct. 23 -- The city of the maharajas of Mysore is sparkling this week with the light of a million lights and gay to the music of a thousand martial musicians. The full scarlet pomp of princely India is flaring once more and probably for the last time.
A strike of 475 flight engineers delayed flights on United Air Lines yesterday. However, only one flight, from New York to Chicago, had to be canceled.

PARIS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Two Democratic Senators, en route home after a swing through United States bases in Europe, said today they were mystified by reports that the Administration had been requested to send a special plane for them.
IT is as necessary to make use of left-overs as it is to wash the dishes and pay the grocery bill. But seldom is yesterday's-dinner-warmed-over popular with the home cook -- or with her family.
Two letters arrived in the same mail the other day from prep schools hundreds of miles apart. Both had to do with the recent world series.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Price increases averaging 5 per cent are expected to be announced by the shoe industry this week when manufacturers assemble in Chicago for the annual National Shoe fair. Higher material, labor and operating costs are responsible for the rise, a spokesman said.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 23 -- The Arab nationalists in North Africa are rapidly dividing into two hostile camps: those who oppose any understanding with the French and those who favor cooperation with the French.

The phrase "mortgage loan warehousing," either in that form or some variant of it, is a phrase that has been creeping into the consciousness of the reading public -- and particularly the financial page reading public -- at an accelerating rate in recent months.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith agreed yesterday that there was need for a study to determine whether objective courses "about religion" could be developed in the public school system.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- An earthquake jolted San Francisco and the Bay Area tonight. There were reports of cracked windows, falling statues and disrupted telephone service.
Increased state control over lobbyists at Albany was urged yesterday by Attorney General Jacob K. Javits.
WITH its first concert of the season Saturday night in Town Hall the New York Pro Musica Antiqua resumed its exploration of the vast world we patronizingly call pre-Bach music.

In a deal announced over the week-end, a syndicate represented by Allan Haymes purchased the Bronx blockfront on East 165th Street, between Morris and College Avenues, from the Vignon Realty Corporation. The buyers then immediately resold the holding to Eagle Equities, Inc., headed by Moses Friedman.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Two frightened 9-year-old boys tumbled out of an old commercial laundry machine today after having been imprisoned fifteen hours.
Fifty Americans in public affairs announced yesterday the formation of the American Liberal Association. They described it as dedicated to fighting "extremists both of the left and of the right."
District Attorney Edward S. Silver, of Kings County, went on record yesterday in favor of bingo games for the benefit of religious and charitable organizations.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Eddie LeBaron, one of the National League's smallest players, scored both touchdowns for the Washington Redskins today while leading a rally that produced a 14-13 victory over the Baltimore Colts.

The men's clothing industry operated at 78 per cent of capacity in the first nine months of the year, compared with 70 per cent in the corresponding 1954 period and 82 per cent in the 1953 period, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 23 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem replaced Bao Dai as South Vietnam's Chief of State today in a ballot- box revolution aimed at establishing a new republic.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Senator James E. Murray of Montana called on the National Reclamation Association today to purge "betrayers" among its spokesmen.
AFTER an absence of almost a decade, Paulina Ruvinska returned to Town Hall last night in a piano program largely of familiar works which exhibited her customary musical zest and fluent technique.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Government agencies have set up thirty additional security classifications to protect information they consider "confidential" despite a Presidential order to cut security labels.

IT is always open season in musical circles to hunt for unknown and neglected works by the great masters. With the bicentennial of Mozart's birth to be observed in January, 1956, an effort will be made to dig up and perform pieces of his not commonly encountered.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- It can be argued that NATO's outstanding triumph paradoxically produced its greatest crisis. For, until the Summit conference in Geneva, the Western alliance was on the crest of a wave. Ever since it has been visibly slipping. Why?
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Economic grants to foreign countries rose sharply in the last fiscal year, reversing a five-year downward trend, the Commerce Department reported today.
BUDAPEST, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Sandor Iharos, Hungary's star distance runner, set two world records today during the Hungarian national track and field championship before 50,000 fans.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams' spectacular aerial game struck down the Detroit Lions, 24-13, today. The Rams kept the lead in the Western Conference of the National Football League and sent Detroit deeper into the cellar.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- France will again be represented in United Nations deliberations when the Trusteeship Council opens its session here tomorrow. Robert Bargues of the permanent French delegation will resume his post, returning to New York from Paris, because of the importance to the French Government of the impending discussions of its trust areas.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- A ceremony marking United Nations Day was marred here today when three young men hauled down the blue and white flag of the United Nations and trampled it.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- New York, as the headquarters city, will be the hub tomorrow of a world-wide observance of the tenth anniversary of the United Nations.
As college seniors and as citizens who will be directly affected by the "Reserve Forces Act of 1955" we would like to voice the following sentiments which we believe are shared by most students.
The National Association of Manufacturers continued yesterday its campaign for a 35 per cent top income tax rate.

MORE than 60 per cent of the 11,800 taxicabs in use in the city right now are the small, stock-car models. Of these, more than 45 per cent are two-tone, not unlike most of the late-model private vehicles.
MISS VIRGINIA CARTER, a Macy employe of twenty-five years this month, visited Barcelona last summer and stopped in a strange hotel to look up a phone number.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Princess Margaret and Group Capt. Peter Townsend did not see each other today. It was only the second day during the last eleven that they had not met.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight of California denied today that he was "feuding or fighting" with his fellow- Californian, Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

THE labor unrest that developed during the closing months of the war and mushroomed into violence during the early period of my Administration presented one of the most difficult and persistent of all the domestic problems I faced as President of the United States.

Today the second phase of the great drive to clean up the city, and to keep it clean, begins. For the past two weeks the people who live and do business in the 3,057 blocks where conditions are the worst have been alerted to the urgent need to clean up their litter and dirt -- and what will happen to them if they don't.
Edmond Cahn's new book on ethical problems of law, "The Moral Decision," is part of a report that caused him to renounce a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation in 1950.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 23 -- Senator Allen J. Ellender of Louisiana asserted tonight that restoration of high, rigid farm-price supports would not stand "a ghost of a chance to pass the Senate."
The 1956 Cadillac cars have a new type of Hydra-Matic transmissions and 305 and 285-horsepower V-8 engines. Two new models have been added to the line.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Legislation for cultural "competitive coexistence" is being prepared in cooperation with officials of the State and Commerce Departments and the United States Information Agency.

The nation's newest medical school -- the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University -- was dedicated yesterday. Five thousand persons attended the ceremonies in front of the sparkling, clean-lined building at Morris Park Avenue and Eastchester Road, in the East Bronx. presented by the college's first class of fifty-three young men and three young women to Dr. Hans Albert Einstein, son of the man for whom the school was named.

Come spring, when the mists of melting snow hang moodily in the hollows and the skunk cabbage chirrups to its mate, our outdoor men of 1956 may leave the fishing tackle mouldering on the attic beams. Instead, they may be burnishing the little old Geiger counter and leafing eagerly through their files of maps and state mining laws

The steamship charter market registered marginal rate gains last week despite the fact that coal, generally its bulwark, slipped slightly. Rises in rates for grain, lumber and sugar took up the slack, the weekly survey showed, and the general freight rate index was nudged upward a fraction of a point.
A syndicate headed by Louis Schragg has purchased the thirty - seven - family apartment house with four stores at 241-3 North Avenue in New Rochelle, N. Y.

There was little wrong with the Giants while they were attacking against the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday at the Polo Grounds. There was a lot wrong while they were on defense, though, and their inability to contain the visitors' running or to stop their passing cost the New Yorkers heavily.

The contract bridge team of Alfred Sheinwold, Edgar Kaplan, Richard Kahn and Ralph Hirschberg, all of New York City, and Norman Kaye, Merchantsville, N. J., came from behind early today to capture the 1955 metropolitan team-of-four championship.

Last week the Canadian dollar was quoted at a slight discount in terms of our own in the foreign exchange market. It was the first time that this relationship had prevailed even momentarily for three and one-half years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Ed Brown scored two touchdowns and passed for a third today as the Chicago Bears overcame a 10-point first-quarter deficit and defeated the San Francisco 49ers, 34 -- 23.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Approval by the voters of a $750,000,000 bond issue for highways would "clear the road" for increased state aid to schools, the Republican Sstate Chairman said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Grain futures generally declined last week. The demand for wheat was slow for this time of year, and there was seasonal pressure on corn, accentuated by the fine weather for picking.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The question of the Soviet diplomatic offensive in the Middle East will be raised by the three Western foreign ministers when they meet Vyacheslav M. Molotov at Geneva this week, Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, said today.

"ALICE IN WONDERLAND," starring the 14-year-old English actress Gillian Barber, yesterday afternoon opened the new Maurice Evans monthly series of special productions over the National Broadcasting Company's television network.
Why do we pay no attention to our architectural heritage until some particular building is about to be pulled down and then make a great fuss when it is too late?

It had been raining and the clouds were still low and dark over the city, making for a general gloom. This may have had something to do with the dour appearance of our visitor, who was clad in a raincoat somewhat frayed at the sleeves and wearing a pair of elderly overshoes.

Mayor Wagner's executive order to department heads of the city government to open the use of their files, equipment and manpower resources to commercial television exploration has run into trouble. The basic reason it has done so is that the order seemed, at least at first, to favor a single TV corporation headed by an old friend of the Mayor, Theodore Granik, who has been well known in the broadcasting field for many years.

Will the record business boom roll on into 1956? More and more business men are convinced that the answer to that all-important question is a ringing "Yes." Latest to join the affirmative chorus is a representative group of executives interviewed by Dun Bradstreet.
An increasing number of new foods and services can be expected by the American public as a result of stepped-up attempts of the food industry to broaden its market potential.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The Council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association voted today to allow athletes to compete in the Olympics without loss of college eligibility. The group also decided to recommend inauguration of a new small-college basketball tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- South Africa walked out of a United Nations General Assembly committee today in protest against a discussion of "the racial conflict in South Africa resulting from the policies of apartheid [race segregation]."
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- The coming visit to Afghanistan by Nikita S. Khrushchev and Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin is the latest move in the Soviet drive to cement relations with the remote Asian state.
On its fiftieth anniversary, the National Desertion Bureau announced yesterday the change of its name to the Family Location Service. Its headquarters will remain at 31 Union Square West.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The United Nations celebrated its tenth anniversary today with an international concert and a deluge of best wishes from around the world.

This city now has a new medical school, fittingly named the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and dedicated on Sunday before an audience of 5,000 persons. Congratulatory messages sent by high public officials from the President down emphasized the part that this college will play in meeting the shortage of physicians.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 24 -The extract of the ancient East Indian herb that is alleviating high blood pressure and diseases of the mind is also producing "significant improvement" in coronary cases, physicians reported today.

THIS COUNTRY may return to the "dark ages" of kindergarten education unless the number of new kindergartens opened yearly keeps pace with the rapidly increasing number of 4-year-old and 5-year-old children.
Strong demand for steel products and a high level of operations lifted nine-month earnings of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company by 115.9 per cent and sales by 39.6 per cent over the 1954 period.

Walter B. Devereux, president of the National Horse Show Association, announced yesterday the boxholders for the sixtyseventh National Horse Show, which opens next Tuesday at Madison Square Garden and continues through Nov. 8.
TOKYO, Oct. 24 -- A minor crisis in United States-Japanese trade relations appeared tonight to be somewhat abated.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 24 -- Forty-eight hundred foreigners whose lives are given over to carrying the message of Christianity live in Hindu India. Some do it through the Gospels, most through the example of work in schools and hospitals.

A twenty-four-hour stay of execution was granted yesterday on the threat of a milk strike in the metropolitan area. Leaders of five locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., agreed to put off until 4 P. M. today a walkout that would have cut off the milk supply for 12,000,000 persons in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) at a meeting yesterday in Chicago declared a special dividend of one share of stock of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for every 150 shares of Standard of Indiana held. Directors also declared the regular quarterly dividend of 35 cents a share. Both are payable Dec. 19.
Fourteen Supreme Court justices in Brooklyn opposed yesterday the Loeb plan to reorganize the state's court system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -Republicans were circulating today a report accusing union labor leaders of using "violence and coercion" in a "conspiracy of national proportions" aimed at controlling 1956 election results.

When the Comedie Francaise opens tonight at the Broadway Theatre, New York will welcome for the first time the most famous troupe of actors in France. The company is one of the traditions of France. It goes back to the second half of the seventeenth century, when Moliere formed the nucleus of what was called "The House of Moliere."
Construction began yesterday on the huge Terminal City at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

Debate will be resumed this week in the United Nations General Assembly on the question of the remaining vacancy on the Security Council. The Philippines and Yugoslavia are still in a relative deadlock. That impasse should be resolved in favor of the Philippines.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Provisional President Eduardo A. Lonardi dissolved the Peronist party tonight.

Completion of a basis for the merger of the Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., and Alexander Smith, Inc., was announced yesterday by the boards of directors of both companies. The agreement is subject to the approval of stockholders of Mohawk and Smith as well as to review by governmental agencies.

The statesmen of the Western World have moved into high gear to counteract the serious blow struck at both German and European unification by the negative result of the Saar plebiscite before it develops into a new crisis between France and Germany that would weaken Western solidarity at Geneva.
District Attorney Daniel V. Sullivan of the Bronx has assigned five members of his staff to work with the police to curb juvenile delinquency, it was disclosed yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The proposal by Premier Edgar Faure to hold new elections in December faces a week of parliamentary hurdles beginning tomorrow.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Oct. 23 -Newfoundlanders who for centuries have looked to the sea for their livelihood now are beginning to look to their rock-ribbed soil for future wealth.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Three French representatives quietly resumed their places here today as the Trusteeship Council opened a special session. They let it be known that they would participate Wednesday in a conference on the Technical Assistance Program.

MURAL sketches and sculpture models submitted in a competition for potential decoration of the United Nations Headquarters Building will be displayed in a gallery on the second floor of the Whitney Museum, beginning today.

WACO, Tex., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Five Baylor University football players, including the entire center of the line, were dropped today for breaking training rules. Four were barred from playing football again in the Southwest Conference.

A two-story building containing about 55,000 square feet of space at 48-34 Van Dam Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Viking Paper Company, wholesaler and jobber of paper and allied products. The sellers were the estate of Ernest Katz and the Bayonne Steel Company.

The strike of its flight engineers caused United Air Lines yesterday to cancel seventeen of its 280 daily flights throughout the nation. Seven of the cancellations were out of New York, where forty-one had been scheduled.
GENEVA, Oct. 24 -- A curious little episode in East-West relations ended quietly here today.

Trading in commodity futures was dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Price moves were irregular with changes in coffee, soybean oil, hides and wool mixed; cottonseed oil, zinc, lead and sugar lower and rubber, cocoa and potatoes higher.
We are again appealing for volunteers for Metropolitan Hospital, which has just moved from Welfare Island to a beautiful new building at Ninety-ninth Street and First Avenue.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 24 (AP) -- School taxes in the state must go up even if the quality of the schools goes down, James E. Allen Jr. declared here today.
Football at the University of Pennsylvania is "getting better, improving each day," Steve Sebo told the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's yesterday.

MONTREAL, Oct. 24 -- Proctor Academy of Andover, N. H., capitalized on American football rules today to defeat Westmount High of Montreal, 7 -- 5, in the seventh international competition between the schools.

HEWLETT, L. I., Oct. 24 -Captured after an eighty-milean-hour chase in a stolen car through five miles of residential streets here early this morning, a 26-year-old Jamaica man was shot through the chest when he turned on an arresting policeman.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 24 -- Senate investigators found the farmers divided on politics and united on profits today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A Californian who argued that his constitutional privilege against self-incrimination had been violated when he was forced to submit to a blood test after being arrested for drunken driving lost his case in the Supreme Court today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- Otto Preminger, director-producer of "The Man With the Golden Arm," protested today about criticism of the picture by a Government official. In a telegram to George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, Mr. Preminger attacked criticism of the picture attributed to Harry J. Anslinger, United States Commissioner of Narcotics.
Northrop Aircraft, Inc., of Hawthorne, Calif., reported yesterday record earnings and sales for the fiscal year ended July 31.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 24 -- The Bonn Government prepared cautiously today to seek new negotiations with France over the Saar in view of the Saarlanders' rejection yesterday of a "European" status for the area.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- A new television film company, Conne-Stephens Productions, Inc., has been incorporated with a production schedule of twenty-six pilot films. The company, capitalized at $1,000,000 under California law, expects to get the first group of four films before the cameras by Dec. 5.

A $1,000,000 program for producing thirty-nine commercial television films, based on city files, was announced yesterday by Theodore Granik, beneficiary of an executive order by Mayor Wagner to all city departments.
New York City denied yesterday that it had "any desire to eliminate the Fifth Amendment from the United States Constitution." But it held city employes should be "open and frank."

The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $65,189,370, or $3.80 each on the 17,137,510 share outstanding, at the end of the period. Gross income amounted to $660,404,899.
A 17-year-old youth was stabbed yesterday near a Queens school during a fight with another boy. The police said the fisticuffs ended as a duel with deadly weapons.

THE pungent flavor of sauerkraut has particular appeal on crisp fall days. For an unpretentious dinner, serve it with such traditional accompaniments as spareribs, boiled potatoes and tall glasses of cold beer. Or the brined vegetable can be presented more exotically, as when it is drained, simmered in champagne and mixed with cubed pineapple.
Everything for the office of the future went on display yesterday in the Sixty-ninth and Seventy-first Regiment Armories.
An unusual advertisement in yesterday's New York Times offered to transfer the title of a five-story former hospital building, gratis, to a philanthropic organization.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Premier Edgar Faure was understood tonight to favor negotiations for a new solution of the Saar question, but not until after the French national election that he proposed for December.

ISABEL O'NEIL was striping the fluted legs of an antique white French coffee table in her East Fiftieth Street studio one afternoon this week. She continued to paint deftly away as she talked of her work -- restoring and refinishing painted pieces of furniture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The only thing about the outcome of the Saar referendum that surprised the State Department was the extent of the majority for rejection of the proposed "European" statute. The Department's experts had predicted a vote of 3-to-2, whereas the Saarlanders actually voted somewhat more than 2-to-1 against Europeanization.

Two top officials of the International Longshoremen's Association testified yesterday that the union had to issue a general strike call to end the eight-day work stoppage in the Port of New York last month.
GENEVA, Oct. 24 -- One of its elder statesmen warned the United Nations today, on its tenth anniversary, not to try to do too much.
A luncheon in behalf of the Women's Division of the State of New York Chapter, Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, will be held next Tuesday in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria.
A man in Brooklyn has a black-and-white cow that is beginning to look like a white elephant.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Oct. 24 -- Burglars cracked open a vault and stole about $46,500 from a bank in the heart of the heavily guarded Sandia special weapons atomic base.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Supreme Court struck down today the Kansas law under which exhibition of the motion picture, "The Moon Is Blue," was banned in that state as obscene.
Maryland and Oklahoma moved to the top of the national rankings yesterday while Michigan tumbled to third place.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Government announced today an $85,000,000 pork and lard purchase program to help halt the decline in hog prices.

The National Dairy Products Corporation, the nation's top dairy concern, will spend $200,000,000 in expansion in its fiveyear plan from 1956 through 1960, E. E. Stewart, president, disclosed yesterday. The concern, with assets of $450,000,000, is composed of sixty companies which operate in every state and four foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Supreme Court ordered a Federal District Court in New York today to consider on its merits the challenge of fourteen alien Communists to a provision of the immigration laws. Under that provision the fourteen are being held in "supervisory parole."
ATHENS, Oct. 24 -- The drive by Opposition politicians for early elections seems to be lessening as the acceptance of Constantin Karamanlis as Premier becomes more general.
The commercial finance industry was cautioned yesterday to foster only sound business expansion in the present period of national economic growth.
DENVER, Oct. 24 -- President Eisenhower will ask Congress next year for a domestic version of the Point Four technical assistance program to aid the nation's chronically depressed areas.
The city should be able to balance its budget in 1956-57 without any increase in taxes, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Britain warned anticolonial countries today that they would find the right of selfdetermination of peoples a twoedged sword.
One of the most remarkable streaks in local scholastic sports is the ten straight shutouts recorded by Sewanhaka's soccer team. Jim Fraley, a 16-year-old junior, is the impassable goalie.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The State Department said today that on the basis of the results of the referendum in South Vietnam, it henceforth recognized Premier Ngo Dinh Diem as Chief of State.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 24 (UP) -- A Dutch district court sentenced four persons to prison terms today on charges of abducting and hiding a young Jewish war orphan. The terms range from four months to one year.
" ALL my life I've been crazy about horses," said Lou Costello. He sighed. "The trouble is that I just don't get along with horses -- or any other animals for that matter."
Blazing Home, Mrs. James Purdey's 5-year-old gelding, scored his fourth victory of the year at the Jamaica race track yesterday.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 24 -Douglas McKay, the Secretary of the Interior, said here today that there would be no difference in the "end result" if a private utility financed the power aspects of a multi-purpose river project instead of the Federal Government.

THE occupation of Japan was succeeding beyond our expectations. Dr. Karl T. Compton, the distinguished president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, had spent some time in Japan in order to learn what advances Japanese scientists and technicians had made in the course of the war.

AYELET HASHAHAR, Israel, Oct. 22 -- A Canaanite sanctuary to a God or a memorial to a king, apparently situated just where it was when Joshua destroyed the city of Hazor 3,200 years ago, was uneathed this week near this settlement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A prominent Moslem leader called here tonight for a spiritual and moral revolution to match and "even outstrip" contemporary scientific and technological advances.

SCHLOSS BLUEHNBACH, Austria, Oct. 18 -- We will leave this Alpine hunting ground in the morning, with only a "gamsbock" (chamois) to show for a week of active hunting, but there are pleasant memories and no regrets.

It was with the greatest surprise that I learned this morning in reading the editorial about Jose Ortega y Gasset that we Spaniards do not belong to Europe. It was long ago that somebody wrote that "Africa began at the Pyrenees," meaning that Spain was, more or less, an Arab country, which, by the way, is not an insult, but an honor.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 24 (AP) -Florida-bred Needles, a fast-running 2-year-old colt, today was nominated as a supplementary entry for Saturday's running of the Garden State Stakes at a cost to his owners of $10,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -The Department of Justice's Antitrust Division today held the first of a series of planned conferences with United States newsprint producers in an announced effort to prevent any concerted advance in newsprint prices.

Clinton W. Murchison, who early in 1954 bought a half interest in 800,000 shares of New York Central Railroad stock to topple the Harold Vanderbilt directorate, thinks his whole wealth totals about "five, six or seven million dollars."
Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and subsidiaries yesterday reported increases in operating revenues and net income for nine and twelve months ended Sept. 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -Twelve Puerto Rican Nationalists lost in the Supreme Court today an attempt to have their convictions for plotting revolution against the United States set aside.
It is high time, I believe, that the citizens of this state reconsider the so-called Sullivan Law, which infringes upon the right of the citizen to carry and bear arms.
DOROTHY MAYNOR'S recital last night attracted almost 1,200 to Town Hall. Special interest attached to the event because it was the soprano's first New York recital since December of 1947.
BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- Harvard University has $442,000,000 worth of investments, but still hears the wolf scratching at the door.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Two Army lieutenants duplicated their captain's perfect performance tonight to give the Irish Army horse show team its first international jumping victory of the 1955 Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Stomach ulcers have increased more than 30 per cent in the last ten years among women who aspire to "wear the pants in the family," a medical authority said here today.

A taxpayers group charged yesterday that the neediest families often were excluded from subsidized public housing. For this reason it urged defeat of a proposed constitutional amendment to increase the amount of state housing subsidies from $25,000,000 to $34,000,000 a year.
Your front-page article on the shortage of engineers written by Benjamin Fine and published on Oct. 16 has inspired me to write you on this subject.
After a negligible dip on Friday, stocks yesterday returned to the upward trend that characterized their course for seven straight previous sessions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Supreme Court rejected today the Government's appeal from a lower court ruling reversing the convictions of the International Longshoremen's Association, several of its locals and three union officials for contempt of court.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 -- The difficulties of government and of life in Asia seem even larger when seen at first hand than when seen from a distance, Thomas E. Dewey said today. The former Governor of New York made this remark shortly before he left for home by plane.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 (AP) -- John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany, brought to Berlin today President Eisenhower's pledge that the United States firmly supported the reunification of Germany.

A family ownership of about one hundred years has been terminated in the sale of five buildings at the northwest corner of Third, Avenue and 116th Street. The property has been acquired by Peter I. Feinberg from George W. Welsh, as trustee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The report comparing educators' salaries to others against the background of general wage payments since 1904 was prepared by The Seventh Company under the supervision of Beardsley Ruml in the interest of better education.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- General Motors' world-wide employment reached a record average of 621,958 in the first nine months this year. Payrolls totaled a whopping $2,321,000,000, also a record.
HARTFORD, Oct. 24 -- Alton H. Cowan of Grand Rapids, Mich., a Michigan district supervisor of adult probation, was appointed today as Connecticut's first state adult probation director.

BALDWIN, L. I., Oct. 24 --A Nassau County policeman, the son of a retired burglary squad detective, was charged with burglary here this morning after he was caught by a fellow officer as he hurried from a looted store to his waiting patrol car.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The stock market was quietly firm today although business volume was small.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The auto industry's huge production program is moving ahead on schedule.
The merged labor movement is likely to get its active start in politics by endorsing a Presidential candidate next year.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 -- Over population coupled with a growing consciousness of inferior living standards may again drive needy nations to consider expansion in terms of war, the Fifth International Conference on Planned Parenthood was warned today.
Paul A. Pfeffer, 23-year-old ex-convict who was saved from a life sentence when another convict confessed to the murder, was convicted of second-degree murder last night in a different case.

The tenth anniversary of the United Nations was observed in New York yesterday with music, prayers and special events expressing thankfulness for past accomplishments and a hope for peace in the future.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign for the Presidency is gaining momentum even before it was supposed to begin.
Rezoning potential flood areas against residential or business use was urged yesterday as the best flood prevention.
ALBANY, Oct. 24 (UP) -New York State Thruway toll tickets now carry a brief lesson in safe driving for the motorist.
The inadequate salaries paid to many persons in the teaching profession, especially to those in executive positions, are discouraging qualified young persons from entering the field.

The gold "Oscar of Industry" trophy for the best annual report in all industry was won this year by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. The presentation was made last night before 1,400 business and financial leaders at the eleventh annual awards dinner of The Financial World in the Statler Hotel here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Despite an increase in automation, factory productivity in seven post-war years rose no faster than it did in the comparable period after World War I.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 24 -- Premier-Designate Fatmi ben Slimane, a moderate nationalist, began today the task of attempting to form a Moroccan national government. However, it was former Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef who appeared to have the power of making the ultimate decision.
Ten former stars of the ring, including Gene Tunney, Mickey Walker, Benny Leonard and Harry Greb, have been elected to the Boxing Hall of Fame.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -- The nation's leading traffic experts took a hard look at their problems today and found little room for complacency.

A gale-force squall, with gusts up to eighty miles an hour, ripped through the New York area last night. The short, sharp tempest, hitting at the height of the commuter rush, cut power source, disrupted rail and road traffic and created scores of freakish accidents.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet Union's rapprochement with Yugoslavia and its new ties with West Germany were enshrined today in official Communist slogans marking the thirtyeighth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution.
Navy and Notre Dame, who will play before a sell-out crowd of 56,000 at South Bend, are the main attraction in college football this week.
MOMBASA, Kenya, Oct. 24 -They are still talking in Mombasa about a young Negro labor leader who settled a strike that crippled the port here for a week last March.

MAYOR WAGNER pulled a bubu. His generosity in awarding a key to the city's files to his old friend Ted Granik was not the way to handle the important matter of allowing the television industry to make commercial use of the city's records.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (Reuters) -An inquiry court here was told today that a shifting grain cargo loaded in Canada had not caused the sinking of the 7.373-ton British freighter Tresillian. The ship went down last November with the loss of twenty-four of the forty persons aboard.
The American Broadcasting Company plans to hold auditions for several television quiz programs with giant jackpots. At least three shows are under consideration.
The amount of soot falling in New York City decreased almost steadily in the ten years between 1944 and 1954, the Department of Air Pollution Control reported yesterday.
The day of reckoning arrived yesterday for violators of sanitary and fire laws in 3,057 heavily littered city blocks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The Army formally began today its training program to help soldiers live up to President Eisenhower's new code of conduct for war prisoners.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (UP) -The International Union of Electric Workers, C. I. O., and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation were ordered today to refrain from violence and intimidation in a picketing dispute at the company's strikebound East Pittsburgh and Homewood plants.

JERUSALEM (Israel Sector), Oct. 24 -- All Israeli parties with the exception of the Communists united tonight in a Parliamentary resolution expressing anxiety over the arming of Egypt and Iraq. The resolution also called on "the powers" in general to supply Israel with arms.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 -- The Ford Motor Company expects to produce 2,500,000 Ford cars and trucks for domestic sale next year.

Friday's total of 462 pints of blood given to the New York regional Red Cross blood program included 109 donated by the staff of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. At the General Aniline and Film Corporation, 435 Hudson Street, 107 pints were given.

A new graduate program for the training of laboratory associates in the biological sciences was announced yesterday by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, and Dr. C. P. Rhoads, director of the SloanKettering Institute.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The French Government recognized Ngo Dinh Diem as Chief of State of South Vietnam today.

There will be a touch of drama along with the pageantry today when Britain's Parliament is formally opened by Queen Elizabeth. This time the Queen's speech, giving the Government's program for the coming session, will be overshadowed by the forthcoming autumn budget.

NICHOLAS MONSARRAT, author of "The Cruel Sea," a best-seller of yesterday, is still writing about the cruel sea in his new novel, "Castle Garac."* This time, however, the cruel sea is poverty -- and Mr. Monsarrat rescues his hero from it more romantically than ever.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The Western Big Three put in final form today the European security package they will offer the Soviet Union at Geneva.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 24 -Premier Ngo Dinh Diem is expected to proclaim a republic in South Vietnam and become its Chief of State on Wednesday. He wrested the top leadership from the absent Bao Dal in a landslide referendum victory yesterday.
TRENTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -Grand juries conducting general investigations do not have to warn witnesses of their rights under the Fifth Amendment, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Navy took a calculated risk on ordering jet fighter planes during the Korea emergency, and the cost of bad judgment was about $302,000,000, House investigators heard today.
A new issue of $25,000,000 of preferred stock of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company is to be placed on the market today.
Tighter rules for advertising, market letters and sales literature of New York Stock Exchange firms were issued yesterday by the exchange.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Department of Defense apologized tonight to two Democratic Senators for having incorrectly implied that they had sought special and costly air transport from Europe.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 22 -- One of the main impressions obtained during a month's newsgathering stint in Rumania is the atmosphere of tenseness and suspicion.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday barely steady at net losses of 7 to 59 points, or 35 cents to $2.95 a bale. Weakness was centered in the more distant positions. Trading was only moderate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Burglars tapped the petty cash of the World Bank over the week-end. They took about $27,500 in cash, money orders and travelers' checks from the bank, which uses its $9,000,000,000 capital to aid fifty-eight member nations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren warned the nation today against carrying its security program against communism so far that it trampled traditional American freedom.
NO gentleman would be boorish enough to notice that Shirley Booth's new play is inadequate.

Newsprint prices were raised by a second large Canadian producer yesterday. An increase of $5 a ton was announced by Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., effective on Nov. 1. It was identical to that announced last Tuesday by St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd.

France's world-famous theatrical troupe, the Comedie Francaise, begins a four-week engagement tonight at the Broadway Theatre under the auspices of S. Hurok by arrangement with the Government of France.
A special program to promote California's premium wines is planned by that state, with the authority of the State Director of Agriculture.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- The grain list was unexpectedly strong this morning, in contrast to the prevailing weakness of late last week. The lull in the selling pressure induced some short covering. After the initial firmness, however, wheat and corn both turned weak, running into commission absorption on the setbacks.
Thomas S. Gates Jr., Under Secretary of the Navy, asserted last night that changes in the Navy since World War II had brought about "a revolution in the art of waging war at sea."

The 1956 Clipper line designed for the medium price field was announced yesterday by the Studbaker-Packard Corporation. The custom series has 275 horsepower engines and the super and deluxe 240 horsepower. Both engines are the V-8 type.
MACOLIN, Switzerland, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Lieut. Edgar O'Hair of San Antonio, registered 194 of a possible 195 today to win the marksmanship competition of the modern pentathlon world championships.

POMFRET, Conn., Oct. 24 -Pomfret School's football squad was up to its old tricks today. After practicing for 90 minutes in a brisk sou'wester, the red and black performers trooped off the gridiron and headed for the cluster of apple trees near the gymnasium.

THE first comprehensive exhibition of sculpture by Constantin Brancusi, long a controversial figure in the art world, will open to the public today at the Guggenheim Museum. More than fifty pieces from public and private collections in America and Europe are included in the showing.
The Rev. Alvin Kershaw, a jazz-loving Protestant Episcopal minister, proved his knowledge of his subject last night by winning $32,000 on a television quiz show.
LANSING, Mich., Oct. 25 -- Oldsmobile expansion plans call for an additional 1,036,500 square feet of plant space by the end of 1956.
A plan to provide free inter-airport helicopter service to certain air travelers as well as reduced helicopter fares for others was announced yesterday by New York Airways.
TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Thermoid Company announced today a reorganization of the duties of its top executives and separation of its divisions.
FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, Oct. 25 -- As from today the security of Cyprus will be in the hands of a triumvirate presided over by the Governor, Sir John Harding.
ALBANY, Oct. 25 -- The Harriman Administration took the first formal steps today toward drafting the state's 1956-57 budget.

NOW here are two books that take us on fascinating explorations of marginal life in America. The first is Rachel Carson's "The Edge of the Sea,"* a deeply moving evocation of plants and animals that live between high and low tides along the ocean's shores. The second is A. C. Spectorsky's "The Exurbanites," a lightly probing spoof on the far-ranging commuters who live in Fairfield County, Rockland County and Bucks County.

ANTONIO and his Spanish Ballet Company, having completed a three-week engagement at the Broadway Theatre, moved down to the Mark Hellinger Theatre last night to begin a supplementary engagement of two weeks.

The New York Rangers, victorious in both of their home games this season, will play host to the Detroit Red Wings for the first time tonight at Madison Square Garden. The National Hockey League contest will start at 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Senator J. Glenn Beall, Republican of Maryland, urged the Administration and Congress today to look into the possibilities of increasing United States production of newsprint from Alaskan pulpwood and sugar cane bagasse.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today penalized St. Louis University, Baylor and Wichita for violations of regulations on athletic practices.

Word comes from Moscow that Feodor Dostoevsky is about to be re-established in the Soviet Union as one of Russia's great writers. After many years of official apathy and disfavor the nineteenth-century novelist's fiction will be republished to commemorate the seventy-fifth anniversary of his death.

You recently published my letter regarding the proposed demolition of Carnegie Hall and I now, with even greater personal feeling, wish to protest the possible destruction of the Metropolitan Opera House for the very same reasons -- its acoustics, its convenience to various forms of transportation, its significance in the social and cultural life of the city -- and added to these, the beauty of its auditorium.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., is offering a new issue of $2,500,000 of 3 3/8 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Natural Gas Company.

AN enthusiasm for new places and new faces sent Ernest Koves, chef of the Sulgrave Hotel, to Mexico for a month's vacation. He has just returned with another new interest -- the food served south of the border.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Warrants for forty-two arrests in six states were issued today as the Federal Government moved against illegal traffic in amphetamine drugs -- potent stimulants commonly known as "lift pills."
Arthur Godfrey's "Talent Scouts" lost some of its talent yesterday. The star dismissed a co-producer and two cast members from the show.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, said tonight he had turned over to a Federal agency the power to decide whether any Government officials, including Congressional investigators, should have access to his diaries.
BEILSTEIN, Germany, Oct. 19 -- Moving from Bluehnbach, in Austria, to Beilstein, in the German Eifel, might be compared to a transfer from the Rockies to the Catskills.
Issues of bonds totaling $20,000,000 were posted for sale yesterday by Los Angeles, Calif., school districts. Bids will be taken on the offerings on Dec. 6.

Adlai Stevenson plumped for high, rigid price supports on "basic" farm commodities on Friday, and twenty-four hours later Governor Harriman went out on the same economically weak limb. Since both men were presumably acting with their eyes open in espousing this proposal, they could hardly have been surprised to be awakened on Monday to the sound of a salvo fired in their general direction.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- More than 50,000 seniors will bukle down to a test in 10,000 high schools tomorrow that will lead to college scholarships for 350 eventual winners.

The United Press board of coaches named Michigan the No. 1 college football team in the nation for the third straight week yesterday. However, the Wolverines' lead dwindled from 66 points two weeks ago to only 6 points over Maryland.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Sleepy Hollow was wide awake today, waiting for administrative and operational fireworks at two Rockefeller-endowed shrines.

Trading was dull yesterday in almost all New York commodity futures markets. Only rubber and cottonseed oil registered fair volume. Prices closed generally higher, with rubber, cottonseed oil, potatoes, onions, soybean oil, burlap and wool advancing; cocoa easing, and coffee, sugar, hides and copper ending mixed.

Thelma Matesky, who gave a song recital here several years ago, returned to the New York stage not only as singer but also as composer. The soprano presented an entire evening of her own songs last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. She was expertly accompanied by Anita de Mars.

GENEVA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Polish sources here said today the Soviet Union had released 3,000 Polish officers, most of them leaders of the futile 1944 anti-Nazi Warsaw uprising. In that uprising about 200,000 Poles were killed while Soviet armies stood poised outside the city.
A New York County grand returned yesterday an indictment against two vice presidents of the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company of 115 Broadway.

WELL-PLANNED lighting at the principal work centers of the kitchen reduces fatigue, says a new Rutgers University report. When there is sufficient light, there is no waste of energy in trying to see what you are doing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 -- Thomas E. Dewey, former Governor of New York, arrived here today on his way home from a business tour of Asia and the Middle East. He told a press conference that at present he had no political plans.
Four men believed by the police to be involved in a long series of hold-ups here were arrested yesterday.

The case for compulsory liability insurance on automobiles is strengthened by the arrival of new, dependable statistics. It was commonly said in the old days before we had firm facts that perhaps 95 per cent of the cars in New York State were insured.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- All evidence available here indicates the Soviet Union is determined to make disarmament the first topic of the Geneva foreign ministers conference opening Thursday.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway reported yesterday a net income for September of $1,112,510 after all interest charges and sinking funds compared with $643,030 in the like month last year. This September's showing helped lift earnings for the first nine months this year to $7,754,140, or $3,168,396 above net income in the like period of 1954.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Reports that conditions under which wheat is sold to foreign countries will ease, coupled with announcement that pork and lard would receive Government buying support, stimulated buying of grain and soybean futures as well as of lard today.

The United States Steel Corporation declared an increased dividend of 65 cents a share yesterday and reported that its sales, profits and shipments all broke records in the first nine months of this year. The company's third-quarter revenue, net income and shipments also were the best for any September quarter.
The trustees of the Roosevelt Hospital yesterday elected Stuart M. Crocker as president of the voluntary institution at Ninth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Favorable dividend and earnings news failed to stir the stock market yesterday. After nine days of virtually unbroken advance, investors seemed inclined to reappraise the situation. As a result, recent favorites were under a little pressure and the market as a whole receded moderately.
SAN MARINO, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The Communist-dominated Government of this thirty-two square mile republic within Italy announced plans tonight to put the tiny enclave on a Marxist footing.
Mary Bothwell, soprano, made her appearance at Town Hall last evening, offering, as usual, an interesting program.
The American Can Company set new high records in sales and earnings in the first nine months this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- The General Assembly urged member governments today to give their "fullest support" to the expanded United Nations program of technical assistance to underdeveloped countries.

An unsung industry, one with a product so small yet so universally used that we have long taken it for granted, is offering its first academy awards. This is the match industry, which is presenting "Joshua" plaques for the most distinguished use of matchbook advertising in each of forty-six industries.

The Torch of Hope Award for exceptional community welfare work will be presented today to Francis G. Barrett, president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, in a ceremony at the Commodore Hotel. This was announced yesterday by the City of Hope National Medical Center, 220 West Forty-second Street.

While chiefly known for his activity in various phases of show business, Joe E. Brown, the father of Pittsburgh's new general manager, has had a lifetime interest in and close connections with baseball.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The tempo of official life in Washington has slowed to the point where officials are now taking time to think about the important fundamentals of American policy.
Apartment houses figured in trading in real estate transaction reported yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- The Constitution of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts was removed from the state house today for the first time. As part of the 175th anniversary of its effective date, the document was placed on exhibition at a dinner of the Massachusetts Bar Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A manufacturers' spokesman said today that automation would be a blessing for the nation if unions did not demand all the fruits of it.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The resolutions committee of the Jewish War Veterans sent to the convention floor today a recommendation expressing full faith in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and praising the work of the Fund for the Republic, Inc.
MONTREAL, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The International Paper Sales Company announced tonight a $4 increase per ton in the price of newsprint. This brings the delivered price to $130 a ton in New York.

THE sad part about the retirement of Branch Rickey as boss man of the Pittsburgh Pirates is that the Mahatma ended his brilliant baseball career on a note of failure. He wouldn't have failed on this occasion if he had more time to get his long-range plans into operation. But time is a commodity that no one can sell to understandably impatient fans. He was estranging the customers and making the stockholders go for broke.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct 25 -- The Soviet Union continued today to condition its acceptance of the proposed atoms-for-peace agency on provisions that were unacceptable to the United States.

Sir Eric Bowater, chairman of the Bowater Paper Corporation, said last night that the problem now in newsprint is one of supply, not price -- and he is pessimistic about the outlook for increased supply.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Lars Hall of Sweden won the fourth event of the modern pentathlon championships today when he swam 300 meters in 3:57 for 1,012 points.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The Illinois Toll Highway Commission finally got its turnpike program under way financially today with the sale of $415,000,000 of bonds for construction of 193.3 miles of expressway.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- Louis R. Inwood, the city's aviation director, announced today that a $500,000 aircraft manufacturing and engineering plant would be built at North Philadelphia Airport.

Two three-story buildings at 738-740 and 742 Nostrand Avenue, southwest corner of Park Place, in Brooklyn have been sold by Sarah Schlakman to an investing customer of M. C. O'Brien, Inc., broker in the transaction.

Any major reduction in business inventories in the immediate future is "out of the question," and predictions of an inventory recession in the second quarter of next year probably will not be fulfilled, Charles T. Broderick, chief economist of Lehman Brothers, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Hog prices broke sharply to a new low level for nearly thirteen years today. Heavy arrivals, caused in part by a strike at the Indianapolis livestock yards, were behind the price drop.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 25 -- A bill to include Finland in the Nordic Council is expected to become law in time for her to participate in the council's next meeting in January.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The Times of London, long considered an unofficial voice of the British Government, suggested tonight that Princess Margaret should "pass into private life" if she decided to marry Group Capt. Peter Townsend.
The following books may be of interest to parents and sons ($2.50 each, E. P. Dutton Co.):

The entire fifteenth floor of the reconstructed office building at 625 Madison Avenue, between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Streets, will be occupied by B. T. Babbitt, Inc., manufacturer of household cleaning preparations. The lease was negotiated by Collins Tuttle Co., agents for the building.
ROME, Oct. 25 -- Severe financial burdens on foreign companies that seek the oil that may or may not exist in the Italian subsoil are indicated under a bill that the Cabinet approved today.
Lackawanna, N. Y., is certain that one of its native sons has something original to contribute to art. So certain that it has helped collect money to send the artist to Paris to back its conviction.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Two top-ranking Government officials said here today that national security depended on a deep and abiding religious faith.
Most of us don't give a newspaper, a telephone or a phone directory a second thought. But for G. I.'s stationed in Alaska these commonplace items can be dearer than mink coats.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A powerful Congressional Democrat, Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, came out today for a centrist Democratic Presidential candidate and platform in 1956.
Eddie Arcaro piloted White Cross, E. Barry Ryan's Revoked filly, to her third triumph of the year yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 25 -- Under the title of "Il Federalista" the first European translation of Madison's, Hamilton's and Jay's Federalist Papers in more than one and a half centuries was presented to the Italian public today.
A new wide-angle atomic ray detector said to be an improvement on other such devices now in use has been developed by the General Electric Company.

DAYDREAMING during school hours, at one time an off-to-the-principal's-office offense, would be not only an acceptable but a compulsory classroom procedure if Dr. Catharine Patrick, a research psychologist, had her way with the makers of school curriculums.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Billy Steinkraus made the final ride of the international jumping a perfect one for the United States equestrian team's first victory in the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.
Rene Pinchart, who has weathered countless fencing storms, will sail into a snug harbor tonight. The master of the Fencers Club of New York is retiring after twenty-eight years of service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Department of Commerce, in reporting the familiar good news about the business situation today, took a close look at inventories and new orders and found them both encouraging.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox' eighteen-year search for a reliable clean-up hitter apparently ended today when they obtained Larry Doby from the Cleveland Indians.
Trans-Atlantic steamship passenger fares -- largely unchanged since the end of the war -- probably will not be increased until after next summer, it was forecast yesterday.

To a former service man who served under General MacArthur during the second World War there is something tragic in his frantic attempts to deny that he ever felt Russian intervention was required to aid in the defeat of Japan.
The American Federation Labor dropped yesterday its objections to the admission of union ousted from the Congress of Industrial Organizations five years ago on charges of Communist domination.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 22 -- It seems the Rumanian leaders have scored a substantial number of successes in industrializing their economy.

Stockholders of the Van Norman Company, maker of machine tools, will be asked to change its name, increase authorized common stock and approve a new issue of preferred stock and a new corporate structure at a special meeting Nov. 30.

CAIRO, Oct. 25 (UP) -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that the United States air attache had been expelled from Egypt for siding with Israel in fixing the blame for an air clash over the Gaza strip.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Army announced today that Lieut. Gen. Floyd L. Parks, who led the first American troops into Berlin at the close of World War II, would retire in February. He has been commander of the 2d Army at Fort Meade, Md., since August, 1953.
Everyone can rest easy, for Cow will have a new home. The Contributors Information Bureau has placed the Canarsie heifer -- and only a day after she was put up for adoption by her Brooklyn owner.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- A General Assembly committee voted today to allow United Nations members to demand a review of the verdicts of the Administrative Tribunal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Army expects to complete an atomic power plant by the spring of 1957 that can be transported by air.

Football's X-and-O clan gave the tablecloths in Syracuse a hard time after last Saturday's Maryland-Syracuse game. The diagramming featured Maryland's ruthlessly efficient execution of the split T attack and the Syracuse buck-lateral pass that caught the rock-ribbed Terrapin defense off balance.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The No. 1 discrimination problem in industry today is not so much in hiring but in equality of opportunity afterward.

TYPICAL of our impatience in the fall of 1945, with the capitulation of Japan, was the rush of wartime officials in key Government posts to return to civilian life. Despite the urgent jobs that still had to be done in the transition from war to peace, officials in great numbers in all ranks were submitting resignations.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The Middle Eastern situation has deteriorated even faster than anyone expected. The danger of a new Arab-Israeli war is becoming greater each day. Eight ships carrying Soviet-bloc arms have now arrived in Egypt. Fourteen Iron Curtain military technicians are already there and forty more are expected soon.

It was no accident that the celebrations of the tenth anniversary of the United Nations this week should have been accompanied by warnings and unhappy portents. No one can fairly question the assets and accomplishments of the U. N. which provided such a rich source of congratulations on Monday.

Sidney M. Barton, New York real estate investor, has purchased two supermarkets now under construction in the Greater Los Angeles area from Raisin Markets, Inc. Simultaneously with this transaction, the food chain leased back the stores on a twenty-five-year net basis.

The Socony-Mobil Oil Company announced yesterday that it earned $17,000,000 more in the first nine months of this year than in the like period last year. It also voted to pay a bigger year-end extra to its shareholders.
The United States Court of Appeals contended yesterday that it was playing "at hide-and-go-seek" with the United States Tax Court in support cases.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Harold Philby, former first secretary at the British Embassy in Washington, was named in the House of Commons today as "the third man" in the Maclean-Burgess case as Parliament reassembled after its three-month recess.
"NEW WORLD A'COMING," the prize-winning series of radio plays, returned to the air last night over Station WMCA with a drama of vigorous protest against the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 -- A well-known physician and writer, Dr. Alfonso Nunez Malmero, initiated legal proceedings today for the extradition of deposed President Juan D. Peron.

Celebration of fifty years of Manhattan-Staten Island ferry service under municipal ownership -- at a nickel a ride, one of the world's greatest transportation bargains -- was observed yesterday morning aboard the ferryboat Tompkinsville.
GENEVA, Oct. 25 -- An Arab leader predicted today that the Big Four foreign ministers would be unable to find a solution to the Middle East arms issue in their talks here.
Among those sauntering in "The Chalk Garden," which arrives at 8 o'clock this evening at the Barrymore, are two stars -- Gladys Cooper and Siobhan McKenna.
RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 25 -- France's strongest Moroccan ally went over to the nationalists' camp today and dealt a serious blow to French policy in Morocco.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor accused an affiliate yesterday of "collusion" with United Air Lines to break a strike by members of the Flight Engineers International Association, A. F. L.
THE WHOOPER that struck out of the skies late Monday afternoon and ripped stout hangings from buildings was one of a long line of freakish town visitors whose lusty entry left devastated track.

Representative John J. Rooney, Brooklyn Democrat, described the United States Information Agency yesterday as "futile." He said it was more interested in propagandizing the American people than in combating communism abroad.

Gotham's banks, with the price of their commodity -- money -- at the highest level in more than twenty years, look forward to a very prosperous final quarter, according to the First Boston Corporation.

The Base Metals Mining Corporation, Ltd., announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached through which the Stanolind Oil and Gas Company, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), would develop Base Metals' oil and gas concession on the island of Jamaica.

The apartment house property at 5301-5305 Palisade Avenue in West New York, N. J., has been sold by David and Lillian Goldstein to Leo and Annette Ewartler. On a corner plot, the five-story structure contains a store and thirty-eight apartments.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The British Government announced today the creation of the post of chairman of the British Joint Chiefs of Staff.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Egypt's arms deal with the Communist bloc is reported to total $80,000,000 with individual weapons priced at one tenth to one fifth of what Western countries would charge.

Electronic cooking for the home has become a reality. Ushered into the homemakers' realm by the Tappan Stove Company, the new range, which will be in national distribution early next year, is priced at $1,200.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- The General Assembly appealed to the governments of the world today to support the United Nations' $16,000,000 refugee program.

PARIS, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Four of France's leading fashion houses announced tonight they would file in a New York court tomorrow a complaint charging a New York man with style piracy and asking $1,350,000 damages.
Record earnings were achieved by the Gulf Oil Corporation in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.
BETTY HUTTON found herself on a cruel television treadmill last night on the variety show presented over Channel 4 from 8 to 9 o'clock.
A plan to give tax concessions to property owners who improve old-law tenements was brought out yesterday by the Wagner Administration.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 25 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem tonight interpreted his victory over Bao Dai as a popular mandate not to proceed with unification elections in Vietnam until "true liberty" was established in the Communist-ruled North.
HAWKINS, Tex., Oct. 25 (UP) -- A roaring oil well fire that threatened this East Texas community of 2,000 persons for nearly twenty-four hours was snuffed out with salt water today.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, said today he hoped the Western European Union, in accord with France and West Germany, would find a solution of the Saar problem.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that traffic deaths had increased 10 per cent and traffic accidents 5 per cent in the first nine months of 1955, compared with the same 1954 period.

When the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France walk into the new Geneva conference tomorrow to make another effort to reach a settlement with the Soviets they will have behind them not only the united support of their own countries but the backing of the whole North Atlantic alliance.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- High class industrial stocks rallied further today on some good dividend statements and earlier firmness of Wall Street. In general price movements were in pennies although a few selected issues, such as Unilever, Ltd., and N. V., scored gains of around two shillings (28 cents).

New York Telephone Company registered sizable gains in operating revenues and net income during the third quarter and in the twelve months ended Sept. 30 according to the monthly statement released yesterday.

There seems to be some impression that there is no law covering the "jury-bugging" project of the University of Chicago Law School and the Ford Foundation in the United States District Court at Wichita, Kan. It appears to be both a common-law crime and a contempt of court.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Stalled by Colgate in the Bowl last Saturday, Yale expects its football machine to be running smoothly against Dartmouth.

Japanese fishermen, particularly in the southern part of the archipelago, are pleased with an informal agreement that has been worked out with the Red Chinese. Boundaries have been set in the Yellow Sea for the fishing fleets of both and the result has been more and cheaper fish for the Japanese.
HONG KONG, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- Communist China said tonight that the Portuguese colony of Macao, forty miles southwest of Hong Kong, was Chinese territory.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 25 -- Supporters of a large reclamation developments in the Western states were warned today that they must stop fighting each other's projects or they would defeat all of them.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt praised yesterday the international program of student exchange as a means of bringing about a better feeling throughout the world. She spoke as guest of honor at a luncheon given by Isaac Liberman in the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.
Contributors of "A Gift in Thrift" to the Child Study Association of America will be guests the afternoon of Nov. 14 in five Manhattan homes.
Clare M. Tousley came out of the Midwest to New York in 1912 and took a "temporary" two-week job as a social worker.
Airports fifteen miles or more away from population centers risk the loss of 40 per cent of their potential air traffic, it was asserted here yesterday.
DENVER, Oct. 25 -- Smiling, tanned and chatty, President Eisenhower went before the cameras today to give the nation its first good look at him since his heart attack.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 25 -- This small Fairfield County city, struggling to recover from two damaging floods, got a pat on the back today from Connecticut's two Senators.
A three-day mass donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will begin today at the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, 33 Nassau Street.

Today's new film is "Rebel Without a Cause," starring the late James Dean, at the Astor. The Warner Brothers drama is in color and CinemaScope. Featured in the cast are Natalie Wood, Jim Backus, Ann Doran, Sal Mineo, Rochelle Hudson and William Hopper.
MIAMI, Oct. 25 (UP) -- A Coast Guard plane found a missing atomic engineer and his bride on an island today. The castaways used part of their clothes for distress signals.

A suggestion to stop talking about the spectacular and glamorous aspects of advertising and to start explaining its role as the "work horse" of mass distribution was put forward yesterday by Elon G. Borton, president of the Adveritising Federation of America.
Milk company and union negotiators reached virtual agreement early today on a contract that would head off a milk strike in the metropolitan area.
