The Holland-America Line announced yesterday that the motor vessel Sommelsdyk would make a special sailing Jan. 18 from New York to Antwerp. The passenger-freighter, which is in the company's affiliated Red Star Line service, accommodates twelve persons, all in outside rooms with private facilities, at a minimum rate of $210 each.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- R. Marlin Perkins got his job back today as director of the Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago. His future with the zoo had been in doubt because of his television commitments.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Joe L. Brown, son of the famed movie comedian Joe E. Brown, became general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates today. In taking the post, Brown promised to get the team "back in the race and into the world series."
Directors of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of fifteen shares of Standard Industries, Inc., common stock for each 100 shares of Bellanca common, payable on Nov. 29.

Guaranteed annual wage payments do not constitute remuneration and a worker receiving such payments during lay-offs or other jobless period is as unemployed as if they were no such plan, Attorney General Jacob K. Javits held yesterday.
WORTHINGTON, Minn., Oct. 25 -- Farmers in this Midwest corn-hog area greeted with cautious optimism today the Administration's decision to buy pork in an effort to stem sliding hog prices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The president of the company that produced the Demon jet fighter assumed full responsibility today for shortcomings in the manufacturing end.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The Western powers are ready to consider a security treaty including all Europe if in return the Soviet Union will agree to unite Germany by free elections.
The New York Telephone Company believes in the city's economic future and is spending a lot of money to back its judgment, the Fifth Avenue Association was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Air Force said tonight that it soon would have a vertical rising, man-bearing plane resembling a flying saucer. However, it again said at previous sightings of flying saucers were illusions or explainable as "conventional phenomena."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- Allied Artists is looking for a new home in the San Fernando Valley. The company is unable to accommodate at its studios in Hollywood the pictures it has in production and has had to rent stage space at four other studios.
World-wide ship construction activity continued to increase during the year's third quarter, according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping's current report.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, announced tonight that he was recommending to President Eisenhower Russell C. Harrington of Providence, R. I., as the new Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Premier Edgar Faure's plans to call early elections in France suffered setbacks within his Radical party and in the National Assembly today. The Premier has proposed to end the life of the present Assembly six months before its normal demise in June.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today lent the Japan Development Bank $5,300,000 to help finance a modern steel plate mill for the Yawata Iron and Steel Company, Ltd., on Kyushu Island.

GREAT BRITAIN has sent us a superb orchestra. The Philarmonia of London, which made its New York debut at Carnegie Hall last night, is an ensemble that has both virtuosity and the subtlest teamwork. And in Herbert von Karajan, who is the conductor in this first American visit, the orchestra has a virtuoso leader worthy of its powers.

Mayor Wagner called a halt last night to all projects involving use of city files for television and radio shows pending a study by a special committee. The Mayor named Dr. Luther H. Gulick, City Administrator, to head the committee.

Harold S. Vanderbilt, a former director of the New York Central Railroad, denied yesterday that he had rejected an opportunity to purchase the 800,000 shares of Central stock that figured so prominently in last year's proxy contest for the railroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A Senate interstate and foreign commerce subcommittee will open hearings tomorrow at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, N. Y., on proposals to clarify the status of the nation's merchant marine school.
A dozen patients who said they had been treated for cancer by a relatively new technique devised by a Rumanian physician now practicing in Brooklyn were heard here yesterday afternoon.
MOMBASA, Kenya, Oct. 25 -- An important facility for the growing industrialization in Kenya and Uganda is the ancient port of Mombasa.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- The National Broadcasting Company expects to settle final budget details of its new half-hour color film series, "Johnny Moccasin," by the end of the week and to give the green light for a start of production on Nov. 10.

WE waited 275 years for the Comedie Francaise to come to us, which made it a great and joyous occasion last night to see a scintillating performance of Moliere's "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme" (The Would-Be Gentleman). It was a happy stroke of genius to choose this gay and witty play for the opening of the series, in which we are to see four more classical comedies over the next four weeks.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Secretary of State Dulles plans a personal meeting with Marshal Tito at Brioni, Yugoslavia, Nov. 6.

Across the nation yesterday young men left breakfast tables, factories and commuter trains and raced to airfields. The Air National Guard was testing its ability to respond to a threat of enemy bombers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 25 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies tonight accused Dr. Herbert V. Evatt of tactics directed against the Prime Minister and his own country and in favor of Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union.
TO create an atmosphere where the fine art of dining can flourish is the sole aim of Carole Stupell's new salon at 54 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Though perhaps it is superfluous by now to point out the essentially sterile and negative character of the American Council for Judaism, the letter of that organization's vice president, H. S. Moyer, published Oct. 20, affords fresh opportunity of doing so.
FLASHING colors greet the eye in Macy's glassware department, where hand - crafted Blenko glass is on display.
NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 25 -- Pete Rothermel, head football coach at St. George's school, doesn't want rival coaches to worry, but he admits he is toying with an 800-pound backfield.
United Air Lines placed an order yesterday for thirty Douglas DC-8 jet airliners.

A NEW material for home craftsmen, yarn made from jute is being introduced at Macy's in time for creation of home-made Christmas gifts. The new yarn, made from the same sturdy vegetable fiber long used for rug backing, is called "Jutacord."
A SWEDISH woman who composes sweater patterns with her knitting needles while listening to music has just put two New York stores into an absolute dither.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., confirmed yesterday its intention of building a new generating plant on Staten Island. The company also announced that it would apply on Nov. 1 to the Public Service Commission for authority to issue $70,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds series "K" due Dec. 1, 1985.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Powerful Senate Democrats have agreed in principle on the main program for the second session of the Eighty-fourth Congress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture officials said today that sales of Government-owned surplus corn to exporters soon will be cut off temporarily.

Consolidated net profit of the Procter Gamble Company for the three months ended Sept. 30 dropped to $17,318,098 from $18,914,709 for the corresponding quarter a year ago, the company reported yesterday.
By the end of 1956 Third Avenue, cleared of its elevated railroad line and newly widened will be "a tree-lined boulevard with the latest in traffic signals and street lighting."
Dr. Foster Murray, president of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. J. Burns Amberson as its director.
A hundred city health officials attended a surprise bon voyage party yesterday for Dr. Leona Baumgartner, City Health Commissioner. She leaves today for a two-month tour of India.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 -- The outlook for more United States tourists in the Soviet Union is promising, a representative of one of the largest western travel agencies reported today.

There is no place like home, as the New York Rangers proved once again last night. The Broadway Blues went on a scoring spree to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 6 -- 2, in their National Hockey League contest at Madison Square Garden before 9,552 fans.

In the first nine months of this year Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company had net earnings of $26,984,159, equal to $5.19 a share. This was 51.7 per cent above the like period of last year. In the 1954 period earnings were $17,785,724, equal to $3.43 a share.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Two persons who supervised the restoration of historic shrines in Sleepy Hollow charged today that the shrines were about to be converted into "honky-tonk Coney Islands."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 26 -- Brazilians have been cheered by the booming coffee exports in the first three months of the prevailing crop year. Exports were more than double the light shipments in the same period last year, and the Brazilians are optimistic that big sales will continue.

The nation's greatest talent hunt got under way yesterday. Sixty thousand boys and girls from 10,850 high schools in all the states spent two hours seeking the right answers for 115 brain-teasing questions. The stakes were high -- but so were the odds. Only 400 scholarships are to be awarded, making this a 1,500-to-1 conest.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The politically explosive farm issue apparently put an end today to Ezra Taft Benson's plans to make a nineteen-day tour of Europe.
Americans may be taller today than they were fifty years ago, but they are still eating the same amount of food.

GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles pledged the United States today to "necessary conciliation" in negotiating with the Soviet Union for Germany's unity, for disarmament and for improved contacts between the East and the West.
A JACK O' LANTERN in the window, the excitement of bobbing for apples and a table spread with foods to tempt young appetites -- these are ingredients for a successful Halloween party for children.
Plans for a modern office building at Broadway and Thirty-first Street, in the heart of the shopping and toy and shirt manufacturing district, were announced yesterday by Joseph P. Blitz, a builder.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Howard R. Hague appeared an overwhelming winner today in a bitterly contested election for vice president of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O. His supporters hailed the election as a "resounding vote of confidence" for the union's president, David J. McDonald.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 26 -- The National Reclamation Association objected today to several recommendations in the Hoover Commission's report on water resources and power.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Jim Turnesa led the field in the opening round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association's championship today. He posted a two-under-par 70 at Fairview against one of the most formidable challenging groups that has competed for this title. with 76's.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Rockcastle today became the first New England-owned horse to win the Yankee Handicap. He outbattled the favorite, Nance's Lad, in the stretch to score a length-and-a-half victory in the twentieth running of the $58,200 race at Suffolk Downs.

A new one-story building on Review Avenue, near Laurel Hill Boulevard, in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Shaw-Walker Company, dealer in office furniture and appliances. The building was erected and is owned by the Michael Contracting Company.
The University of Vermont's policy of banning the possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages at football games has the enthusiastic support of the Vermont football team.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The State Legislature unquestionably will be asked to appropriate a substantial increase in funds for education, Senator Walter J. Mahoney, Republican floor leader, said here today.

The City Planning Commission tentatively approved yesterday a proposal for a $5,205,000 middle-income housing development on a site bounded by First and York Avenues and East Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets.
A delightful evening of music-making by the Australian pianist Leonard Hungerford was last night's attraction at Town Hall.

A trade policy for the United States that would gear tariff concessions to the willingness of foreign producers to pay their workers on a scale approaching the levels of American industries was advocated yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The United States, Britain and other Western powers decided today to vote against Soviet amendments to their atoms-for-peace resolution. Although the rejection of the amendments is therefore a certainty, most delegates believe that the Soviet bloc will end up by voting for the resolution.

One of your recent editorials makes handsome welcome to the restoration of the steeple of Christ's Church ("Old North") in Boston after Hurricane Carol had ripped it off last year. But in so doing the editorial breathed further life into a hoary old myth: that the two lanterns hung in that spire the night of April 18, 1775, were signals to Paul Revere to begin his famous ride to Lexington.

We must begin all over again in Morocco. Nothing that has been done makes sense any more, now that the Pasha of Marrakesh, Thami el Glaoui, has reversed himself so completely. From having been the man above all others to drive Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef off the throne in August, 1953, he becomes the champion who doubtless will bring him back.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 19:
DENVER, Oct. 26 -- President Eisenhower increased his exercise budget today by taking ten strolls across his hospital room.
The Fund for the Republic will award three prizes totaling $40,000 for television programs using the themes of liberty and freedom "with the greatest distinction, taste and effectiveness."

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury in the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations, will appear voluntarily before members of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in Washington tomorrow morning in a closed meeting.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- British-led Arab forces clashed today with a Saudi Arabian military unit occupying the Buraimi Oasis in southeastern Arabia.

The Red Cross will collect blood today from students and staff of Barnard College. Donations also will be collected from employes of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, 195 Broadway; Guaranty Trust Company, 35 Nassau Street; Lever Brothers, 390 Park Avenue, and New York Telephone Company, 2885 Ocean Avenue Brooklyn.

NOW that the Philharmonia Orchestra of London has firmly established itself as a first-rank organization, which it immediately did to New Yorkers Tuesday night, greater attention can be paid to its actual music-making and its conductor.
CHITTAGONG, Pakistan, Oct. 25 -- A senior police official, said today that the Communist party was recruiting in East Pakistan. The party was banned last year.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Business activity declined on the stock market here today in anticipation of the new budget, details of which were not announced until after the exchange closed.
BOLD is the word for two new upholstery and drapery collections introduced to the public this week.

The sixtieth annual meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound at the New York Yacht Club yesterday developed bright reports of the organization's present condition and future prospects but no startling departures from routine.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 26 -- A new republic was born in South Vietnam at noon today. It was proclaimed by Premier Ngo Dinh Diem, who became its first President under a provisional constitutional act.
RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 26 -- Morocco's religious leaders publicly alligned themselves today with the Nationalists by urging the return of former Sultan Mohammed beh Youssef.

Egypt's decision to barter in Communist arms has introduced a new dimension into the already troubled affairs of the Near East. No American familiar with the location of the Suez Canal may view the prospect of Soviet influence straddling that international lifeline with equanimity.
The industrial redevelopment of certain blighted areas in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens was advocated yesterday by Abe Stark.
STRATFORD, Conn., Oct. 26 -- The new multi-million-dollar plant of the Sikorsky Aircraft Division of the United Aircraft Corporation was dedicated here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The United Nations' Palestine truce chief said today he doubted that a major conflict between Israel and her Arab neighbors was imminent.

A former residence that was altered into apartments five years ago has passed to new control with the sale by the Essen Realty Company, Aristotle Souval, president, of the five-story building at 441 East Fifty-seventh Street, adjoining Sutton Place.

Sales of chemicals and allied products will amount to $23,000,000,000 this year, compared with $20,377,000,000 last year, it was estimated last week by John R. Hoover, chairman of the Manufacturing Chemists Association. Mr. Hoover, who is president of the B. F. Goodrich Chemical Company, addressed the fourth chemical sales clinic of the Salesmen's Association of The American Chemical Industry at the Roosevel Hotel.

BEILSTEIN, Germany, Oct. 20 -- After almost ten days of deer hunting in the Alps and the Eifel, we are firmly convinced that there is a shortage of hirsch (red deer) with dwarfed, malformed or unsymmetrical antlers.
DENVILLE, N. J., Oct. 26 -- Otto Greiner of Knickerbocker led the way into the semi-finals of the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship after two rounds had been completed today.

Directors of the Southern Peru Copper Corporation yesterday elected as its president and chief executive officer Edward McL. Tittmann. Recently he was general manager of the Western department of the American Smelting and Refining Company.
Pan American World Airways obtained yesterday a temporary order staying a union from striking while United Air Lines felt increasingly the pinch of a four-day-old strike by another union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N. J., won today the contract to build the fifth giant aircraft carrier of the Forrestal class.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Producers cut back hog shipments today and prices worked upward. Butchers sold strong to 25 cents higher while sows were steady. Salable receipts at 12,000 head were 2,000 under the advance estimate and 6,000 below yesterday's heavy run.

Jewelry worth at least $43,500 was stolen Tuesday afternoon from a ninth-floor suite at the Plaza Hotel, Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue. The suite is maintained the year around by Mr. and Mrs. William E. Levis.
PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Premier Moshe Sharett sought Western backing for Israel in conversations today with Secretary of State Dulles and Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary.
A $20,000 pay roll in cash was stolen in Brooklyn yesterday by three armed men at the Knomark Manufacturing Company, maker of Esquire shoe polish.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 26 -- Cyprus faces an economic crisis while the Government prepares to fit it out as a first-class military base in the Middle East.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 -- Roger Tubby, former press secretary to President Harry S. Truman, has quit the Harriman Administration to join the staff of Adlai E. Stevenson, who is expected to announce his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination soon.
William Zeckendorf, real estate expert, foresaw yesterday a New York choked by "fluid suburbia," or "endless chains" of outlying communities.

Directors of Merck Co., Inc., have elected John G. Bill president of the Sharp Dohme division and Dr. William H. McLean president of the chemical division, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Antoine T. Knoppers was made vice president and general manager of the Merck-Sharp Dohme international division of the pharmaceutical company.
A program to train key leaders in the Protestant ecumenical movement began yesterday afternoon at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits urged yesterday that the state help its employes, the aged, unemployed and medically indigent to pay for voluntary health plans and group medical practice units.

Thirteen municipal housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $122,305,000 in the public market yesterday. The borrowing moved ahead the permanent financing of low-rent housing developments.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 26 (UP) -- Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Subahdar, the 9-5 favorite, hung on gamely in the stretch today to score a neck victory over Paper Tiger in the $29,650 Quaker City Handicap at Garden State Park.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- Soviet officials indicated strong interest today in a proposal to send the famous Bolshoi Theatre Ballet Troupe or the Moisseyev Folk Dancers to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson contended today that the Democrats had proved themselves superior to the Republicans in developing the unity and strength of the free world.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The president of the Methodist Conference today added his voice to those suggesting that Princess Margaret renounce all claim to the throne if she marries Group Capt. Peter Townsend.

Clinton W. Murchison, Texas millionaire, has had a second thought about the extent of his wealth. On Monday, Mr. Murchison said he believed he was worth about "five, six or seven million dollars." Yesterday he revised that estimate, upward to the neighborhood of thirty million dollars.

The General Motors Corporation, world's largest manufacturing enterprise, apparently will show record net income of well over $1,000,000,000 for 1955. The huge automotive producer yesterday reported record net income of $912,887,537 after taxes for the first nine months of this year, more than for any full year in its history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 -- A three-year working agreement covering more than 2,000 members of the Marine Firemen, A. F. L., on West Coast ships was reached today. It is subject to ratification by the membership.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The medalist, C. D. McAllister of Orlando, Fla., defeated T. M. Belshe of Washington, 3 and 2, to advance with seven others to the quarter-final round of the annual North and South seniors golf championship at the Pinehurst Country Club today.

A prediction that Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy would eventually participate in a properly safeguarded plan to dramatize the work of all city departments by means of commercial television shows was made yesterday by Dr. Luther Gulick, City Administrator.

PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 27 -- Premier Edgar Faure, fighting to save his Government and its plan to call new Parliamentary elections, asked a predominantly hostile National Assembly for a vote of confidence early this morning.

If American democracy as we know it should ever collapse, one of the major causes would certainly be public indifference to the economic plight of the teaching profession. The report just issued by the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education helps dramatize the economic degradation to which teachers have been subjected over the years.
DENVER, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement on the foreign ministers' conference at Geneva opening tomorrow:

Mrs. Barbara Rockefeller, in a purchase for occupancy, has acquired the five-story dwelling at 13 East Sixty-seventh Street. She bought it from the Artists Equity Association, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co. as brokers.

We wonder if it is not time for official review of the wisdom of present policy on testing air raid sirens. The more than 700 sirens in New York City now get a full test of the three-minute warble and the steady, repeated all-clear sound once a month, at a pre-publicized time.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Three days before the game here with one of the strongest Colgate football teams in years, another major change in the Army eleven has been forced upon Coach Earl Blaik.
ENID BAGNOLD is "the lady of quality" who once wrote a novel from which S. N. Behrman wrote a drama of quality, "Serena Blandish." It was warmly admired by a few people in 1929.

GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- The United States asked other nations today to take a close look at national economic policies that are threatening to flood the world with high-cost wheat. It also approved the idea of a new world wheat agreement to stabilize prices and trade in wheat provided the pact could cover "most international trade in wheat."
THE closest that the City Center's revival of "The Bartered Bride" last night came to the spirit of its native Bohemia was when Dr. Alice Masaryk was on the stage.

Economists and business men yesterday were given thirty-four new statistical tools. These are economic sector indices prepared by the Bureau of Labor Statistics from the 2,000-odd prices that go into the wholesale price index.

I KNEW that it was time to make things perfectly clear between the Secretary of State and myself. I wanted to do it without delay, without publicity, and in writing. So I wrote out in longhand a letter to Byrnes, and when he came to the White House on Jan. 5, I read it to him as he sat at my desk in the Oval Room:
Arthur H. Dean, former United States peace negotiator in Korea, has resigned from the board of directors of the Fund for the Republic, reportedly "for policy reasons."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The unanimous decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth District in a case involving the restricted intraoffice files of the Securities and Exchange Commission was, in language and effect, one of the most drastic rebukes a Federal trial judge has ever received from above.

Nine hundred persons were delayed in boarding a Hudson River Day Line vessel at West Point last Saturday. As a result some of the passengers have written sharply critical letters to the Navy blaming the presence of three destroyer escorts at the pier for their difficulties.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad declared an extra dividend of 50 cents a share today along with the regular 25-cent quarterly.

WHEN A Fifth Avenue store noted for fine silver and jewelry goes into the furniture business, it would be reasonable to expect the offerings to be one - of - a - kind antiques. But Black, Starr and Gorham's new department features Danish and Italian pieces in distinctly modern styles.

PUMPKINS, some of them almost as big as the Plymouth Rock, add a bright orange hue to fall vegetable displays in city stores and country roadside stands. They are just one of the many varieties of squash now abundantly available.

With the nation's newspapers facing a rise in the cost of their most vital material -- newsprint -- they will have no choice but to raise advertising rates and per-copy prices, a publishers' spokesman declared yesterday.
Elof Hansson Inc, imports-exports, in the nineteen-story building being erected by William Kaufman at 711 3d Ave. between 44th and 45th Sts -- Collins Tuttle Co, agents.

An increase in the week ended last Friday of 1,056,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 151,536,000 barrels, compared with 150,480,000 a week earlier and 149,834,000 a year ago.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, introduced today a supplementary budget cutting housing subsidies and other Government expenditures.

Mrs. Gertrude Folks Zimand was honored with a luncheon yesterday on her retirement as general secretary of the National Child Labor Committee. She has been with the agency since 1916 and served as its chief executive since 1943.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Sixty-one nations pledged today a provisional total of $28,031,536 to the United Nations Technical Assistance Program of aid to underdeveloped countries. Statements by spokesmen for others of the seventy-six governments participating indicated that the total might reach $30,000,000 or more.

The traditional waterfront tumult heralding the arrival today of the first modern Israeli-flag liner will mean more to the city than just the re-establishment of direct passenger shipping services to the Holy Land. For the Port of New York the new Israel will be a steady caller, adding considerably to the harbor's stature as the leading foreign trade terminal in the world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Leaders of the world's major religious faiths were called upon today to work together "in warm friendship" for the achievement of "peace among men" and "unity and cooperation among nations."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Philip Young, Civil Service chairman, has ordered the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics to rehire a young Cleveland scientist who had been dismissed in April, 1954, on "guilt-by-kinship" charges.
Searching, the fine 3-year-old filly owned by Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs, won the feature at Jamaica yesterday.
Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Beckinella yesterday set aside a $152,000 judgment given to a 19-year-old Brooklyn girl by a jury Monday for personal injuries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Ralph J. Cordiner, president of the General Electric Company, said today the advance of automation would have a stabilizing and stimulating effect on the economy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Corn futures turned active and decidedly strong today, following reports regarding the disposition of Government-owned corn. Some reports indicated there would be a lull in Commodity Credit Corporation sales of good quality corn from bins, but that corn threatening to deteriorate would still be placed on the market.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 26 -- R. Douglas Stuart, the United States Ambassador, cautioned Canadian business men and newspapers today against careless criticism that could build up an atmosphere of tension between Canada and the United States.
Better professional training for the police was urged yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Retrial, an 18-1 shot with 19-year-old Peter Robinson in the saddle, won the 113th running of the Cambridgeshire Handicap Stakes today by a neck.

In The Times of Oct. 17 there appears an editorial commenting upon my testimony before the Rains Congressional subcommittee. Too much of what appears in that editorial has been taken out of context, giving an impression of my thoughts and philosophy quite different from my testimony.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A man dismissed yesterday from a Bank of America branch at International Airport rented a light plane today and then flew the craft into the bank in an apparent "get-even" suicide crash.
West Palm Beach, Fla., announced yesterday postponement until Nov. 3 of its sale of $14,250,000 of water and sewer revenue bonds originally scheduled for today.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 26 -- Henry Pennell, head coach of Taft School's football squad, was marveling about his team's attitude this afternoon. The Red and Blue has won only one game in four starts this season, but the Taft mentor was praising his players' spirit.

The issues involved in the controversy over the Panther Mountain reservoir have indeed been obscured, as a Long Island resident indicated in a letter appearing in The Times Oct. 12. If the people of the state are to vote intelligently on the proposal Nov. 8, however, they are entitled to better than the misinformation contained in her letter.

Three of four men who were arrested here Tuesday in the investigation of a long series of hold-ups were held yesterday in $10,000 bail each. The fourth man was held without bail on disorderly conduct charges.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today its sales and earnings for the third quarter of this year were "off" because of work stoppages.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Lew Hoad underwent a minor operation on his left ankle today and then announced he would consider signing a professional tennis contract with Jack Kramer for u30,000 (about $67,500).

The Strategic Air Command, a military organization that feels itself peculiarly dedicated to "taking the profit out of war" and keeping the peace, has expanded its aircraft with nuclear capabilities by some 200 per cent in the last two years.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 -- The "impact of television," unassisted by the motion picture studio, "was so violent the box office declined to such an extent that almost 6,500 theatres closed down within three years' time" in this country, Spyros P. Skouras testified today in Federal Court here.
Wholesale mergers of small concerns in the women's coat and suit industry were advocated last night to reduce "disastrous competition."

Sir John Cockcroft, director of Britain's Atomic Energy Research Establishment, declared here yesterday that industrial atomic power was "certainly on the verge of being competitive [with conventional fuels] in the United States if the forecasts of costs of six to seven mills per kilowatt-hour are realized."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, detailed today a plan designed to eliminate conceded defects and abuses in the personnel security system.

The Loeb plan for state-wide reorganization of the courts got more sympathetic treatment from Manhattan and Bronx judges yesterday than it had received from judges elsewhere. Though it won support from some judges here, it continued to run into strong judicial opposition, here as elsewhere.

MACOLIN, Switzerland, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Konstantin Salnykov, a 27-year-old Russian, today finished sixth in the cross-country run and won the world modern pentathlon championship. Hungary captured the team title.
Congress should expand maritime training facilities offered by both Federal and state merchant marine academies, Senator Herbert H. Lehman said here yesterday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 22 -- Two major developments appear to have affected Rumanian Government policy in recent months.

MORE than thirty artists are represented in an exhibition devoted entirely to wood sculpture at the Sculpture Center, 167 East Sixty-ninth Street. The natural warmth of wood and its variety of textures create a specially harmonious atmosphere.
DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers baseball club changed owners under a legal technicality today.
The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations virtually completed preparations yesterday for their merger in December.
EDWARD R. MURROW and Fred W. Friendly last night resumed their television presentation, "See It Now," with an informative and timely study of the importance of the office of the Vice Presidency.

The Southern Pacific Railroad announced yesterday that its consolidated net income for the first nine months of this year totaled $47,912,388, equal to $5.30 a share. This compares with $35,138,258, or $3.88 a share, in the similar period in 1954.

Two amphibious airplanes, turned in by the Police Department as outmoded, will be sold by the city. Helicopters have replaced them. One of the planes is a 1944 Grumman Goose. It is powered by two Pratt Whitney 450-horsepower engines capable of 145 miles an hour. It has a fuel tank capacity of 220 gallons and consumes about forty gallons an hour.
The Inland Steel Company, Chicago, yesterday reported record sales, production and earnings for the third quarter and the nine months ended Sept. 30.

Issues of new public utility bonds and common stock priced at more than $20,400,000 will be offered to investors today. The purpose of the financing is to retire bank loans and to defray the cost of additions and improvements to plant property.
" Deadfall," a melodrama by Leonard Lee co-starring Joanne Dru and John Ireland, makes its Broadway debut at the Holiday Theatre at 8 o'clock tonight.

New York University students gave a lukewarm reception yesterday to closed-circuit television for classroom use. Teachers said they "dreaded" the composition class conducted on television. The experimental program, in its third week of operation, is the most extensive use of the medium by a college.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- The House Agriculture Committee today ordered a study of the futures markets in onions, potatoes and other perishable foods.
The client asks: "Is the advertising budget too big, too small or just right ?"

WHEN KINGS and generals become civilians, they head for Cavanagh's, a swank men's hat shop at Park Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. where they replace their crowns and visored caps with homburgs and snap brims.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that the board approve the purchase of Colonial Airlines by Eastern Air Lines.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 26 -- An Egyptian force routed Israeli police from a desert outpost in the Negev this morning.
The New York Times Company moved in State Supreme Court yesterday for a stay of arbitration of the discharge of Melvin L. Barnet, a copy editor.
The day that a housewife can trade in an old sofa on a new one in a department store may not be too distant.
WASHINGTON Oct. 26 -- The United States said today the Soviet Union was making new approaches to Israel about purchases of Soviet bloc weapons.

" ANDERSONVILLE,"* by MacKinlay Kanor, is the story of those thousands dead and of other thousands of Northerners who as prisoners of the Confederacy went through the long, smoldering hell of that infamous stockade in the South's darkest victory. We need not say that the North also had prisons that live in infamy, unless we are chasing some phantom logic to find two wrongs making alright.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first nine months. However, net income for the September quarter and the twelve months ended Sept. 30 lagged behind the year-ago levels.
DENVER, Oct. 26 -- President Eisenhower called upon the Soviet Union today to match the West's "genuine spirit of conciliation and accommodation" at the bargaining table in Geneva.

Futures on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregularly lower yesterday in more active trading. Cocoa, coffee, potatoes, rubber, cottonseed oil and soybean oil eased. Hides, zinc and sugar rose. Onions, burlap, wool and copper ended mixed.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 -- The Coast Guard's system of screening maritime workers as security risks was declared unconstitutional today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

Directors of the Allied Finance Company voted in Dallas to increase common stock from 83,333 shares to 125,000, subject to approval of shareholders at the annual meeting in February. Approval would permit a 50 per cent stock dividend, directors said.
With every tick of the clock a G. I. somewhere is being served by the United Service Organizations. Service men make more than 4,000,000 visits a month to the world wide network of U. S. O. centers.

" ANDERSONVILLE,"* by MacKinlay Kanor, is the story of those thousands dead and of other thousands of Northerners who as prisoners of the Confederacy went through the long, smoldering hell of that infamous stockade in the South's darkest victory. We need not say that the North also had prisons that live in infamy, unless we are chasing some phantom logic to find two wrongs making alright.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first nine months. However, net income for the September quarter and the twelve months ended Sept. 30 lagged behind the year-ago levels.
DENVER, Oct. 26 -- President Eisenhower called upon the Soviet Union today to match the West's "genuine spirit of conciliation and accommodation" at the bargaining table in Geneva.

Futures on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregularly lower yesterday in more active trading. Cocoa, coffee, potatoes, rubber, cottonseed oil and soybean oil eased. Hides, zinc and sugar rose. Onions, burlap, wool and copper ended mixed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Following is the text of the message adopted by the Conference of Spiritual Foundations:
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 9 to 23 points (45 cents to $1.15 a bale) higher on active months.
FLORENCE, S. C., Oct. 26 (AP) -- A grand jury indicted the Rev. Joseph H. DeLaine, Lake City Negro minister who has gone North, for assault in firing on an automobile containing four white men.
A broad traffic-relief plan calling for widening a major north-south street from the Battery to Fulton Street was announced yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The jet engine blamed for crashes of the all-weather Demon fighter plane lost its combat strength through changed Navy plans, House of Representatives investigators heard today.

A fifteen-minute shutdown of the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the George Washington Bridge in this evening's rush period may snarl West Side traffic for as long as an hour, the police said yesterday.

A new book by J. Robert Oppenheimer, "The Open Mind," will be published Nov. 14 by Simon Schuster. The volume contains eight lectures given by the author during the decade since the end of the war, dealing with atomic weapons and the relationship between science and the wider culture of our times."

The Society of St. Johnland, which provides homes at Kings Park, L. I., for needy elderly persons, will gain from a benefit performance of "The Desk Set," starring Shirley Booth, at the Broadhurst Theatre on Nov. 28.

Edward Wayne LeBaron Jr., the Washington Redskins' quarterback, is 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighs 168 pounds. When he was graduated from the College of the Pacific after electrifying the college football world, the so-called experts said: "He'll never make the grade as a pro; he's too little."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Federal Commissioner of Public Building Services told a Congressional committee today he had retained a 90 per cent interest in his consulting engineering firm.
An underwriting group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Hemphill. Noyes Co. is offering publicly today 1,500,000 shares of International Resources. Inc., a mutual fund, at $5 a share.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- Nine feature films will be produced by Joseph Mankiewicz Figaro Productions for United Artists release during the next four years under an agreement just completed by the independent production unit and the distribution company.
New Yorkers got simultaneous relief yesterday from the threat of a milk strike and a rise in milk prices.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey returned to New York yesterday after a month-long trip around the world.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 26 -- A top Iowa farm leader called today for a Government land rental program to bolster sagging farm income. He estimated the program might cost as much as $1,000,000,000 in the first year of operation.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26 -- Provisional President Eduardo Lonardi broke the hard news about the state of Argentina's economy tonight.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Mexican Army horse show team earned another international jumping trophy at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.

Outstanding figures from the world of sport and other prominent public men will attend a dinner at the Commodore Hotel tonight that will kick off the campaign to send a complete United States team to the 1956 Olympic Games in Australia.
The chairman of the Citizens Waterfront Committee denied yesterday "intimations" that the group had been formed as a "cat's-paw for the International Longshoremen's Association."

Yesterday Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Richard A. Butler, presented to Parliament a revised budget for the fiscal year 1955-56. No British Government has found it necessary to adopt this unusual procedure since 1947, the year of Britain's ill-advised and almost disastrous premature attempt to restore the pound sterling to convertibility.
MONTREAL, Oct. 26 (UP) -- An International Paper Sales Company spokseman denied tonight that his company was following a "pattern" in raising its price of newsprint $4 a ton.

The sale of radio station WNEW for $4,000,000 was announced yesterday. The independent outlet, which is said to be one of the biggest money makers in the country, had been sold last year for $2,100,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- A resolution endorsing the progress made toward establishment of an international atoms-for-peace agency was approved tonight. The vote was 53 to 0 with six abstentions, in the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly.

The observance of Hospital Week of the United Hospital Fund was opened yesterday at a noon outdoor rally in the Lower Plaza of Rockefeller Center. The group is seeking $3,500,000 this year to support eighty-two voluntary, nonprofit hospitals.
The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company realized a 77.7 per cent increase in nine-month earnings on a sales gain of 39 per cent over the first nine months of last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The General Assembly failed again today to break the deadlock between the Philippines and Yugoslavia for a seat on the Security Council.
A pioneer in the development of aviation since World War I and in rocket and jet propulsion since 1929 has been elected to honorary membership in the American Rocket Society.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Patrick B. McGinnis' plan to clear his path to the presidency of the Boston and Maine Railroad failed today to win the approval of an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner.
HARRISBURG, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Humberto Mariles of Mexico picked up another trophy by defeating Hugh Wiley of the United States in the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.

The Cerro de Pasco Corporation, 53-year-old mining company with principal operation in Peru, reached yesterday an agreement to buy the assets of the Circle Wire and Cable Corporation of Maspeth, L. I., for $20,250,000.

IS there anyone left in the British Isles? The Philharmonia Orchestra of London has been charming New York this week. And last night the Regimental Band and Massed Pipers of the Scots Guards, plus a remarkable octet of Highland dancers, transformed Madison Square Garden into a happy colony of Her Majesty, the Queen.

The Times of Oct. 20 tells me that "The Federal Communications Commission authorized the American Telegraph and Telephone Company today to start work on the Air Forces' multibillion dollar SAGE aircraft warning system."

Eugene G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, asserted yesterday that his company's expansion program was being delayed by failure of the Justice Department to speed action on Bethlehem's proposed merger with the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

Mr. Molotov looked pleasant, though serious, in a photograph reproduced in this newspaper showing him as he arrived in Geneva for the Big Four conference. But Mr. Molotov, by an accident of perspective and a few other things, was not the high point in the picture.

Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, back from his trip around the world, said last night that the Communists were trying to conquer the world with what he called brilliant new methods. He said they posed even greater challenges "than we have yet faced" and that they would continue "for many years."
Despite great gains in medicine in recent years the city still faces many health problems in the next decade, experts said yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The fortunes of Premier, Edgar Faure took an upturn today when a parliamentary committee agreed to urgent consideration of the Government's plan for early elections.

The intriguing behind-the-scenes story of former President Truman's difficulties with Henry A. Wallace, published today, closes the series of excerpts from Volume One of Mr. Truman's memoirs which have been appearing in this newspaper during the past month.
The General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday record operating revenues, net income and share earnings for the nine and twelve months ended Sept. 30.

Premier Diem has assumed, for the time being at least, the status of President of the newly constituted Republic of Vietnam. He obtained a popular mandate in a plebiscite that disposed of the claim of ex-Emperor Bao Dai to act as "Chief of State.
An injunction was obtained in Supreme Court yesterday against a second company linked with the business operations of Robert J. Morman, a realty man accused of fraudulent stock deals.

Customs officials "found" 900 carats of diamonds yesterday afternoon in a waiting room at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The diamonds, valued at $100,000, were picked up from behind a bench that had just been vacated by a suspected woman smuggler.

The General Electric Company's payroll at its electronic installations in central New York State now runs between $76,000,000 and $80,000,000 a year, Ralph J. Cordiner, president, reported yesterday. The company employs some 16,000 in Syracuse, Utica, Clyde, Auburn and Ithaca.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday a reduction of 20 to 25 cents a pound in prices of titanium metal sponge -- a primary form of the strong, lightweight metal.
A bandit suspect was killed and six others were captured yesterday after spectacular police chases through downtown Brooklyn and upper Manhattan.

National newspaper advertising achieved still another record last month. This was reported yesterday by Media Records, Inc., and the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association. A new high was recorded for the first nine months of the year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- The American Broadcasting Company television network is pushing ahead on its new pro-gram plans for the near future. Indications are that the network has unannounced plans, to join its competitors, C. B. S. and N. B. C., in scheduling "special event" or "spectacular" programs of sixty and ninety minutes duration.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday estimated its consolidated net earnings for the nine months ended Sept. 30 at $523,000,000. This was a new record and equaled $7.99 each on the 65,435,474 shares outstanding at the end of the period.
The traffic paralysis on Manhattan's West Side that had been expected as a result of the Civil Defense drill in New Jersey failed to develop last evening.

Mr. Laxness has led a remarkably varied life. He is the author of many forms of literature -- novels, short stories, essays, histories and poetry. He has traveled extensively in many countries and has passed through many changes in ideas.

Mayor Wagner appealed to voters yesterday for approval of five of the ten proposed amendments to the State Constitution and for approval of the one proposition that will be on this year's voting machines.

The American Civil Liberties Union asserted yesterday that the Army's "loyalty certificate" was so broad that a soldier could be deemed a security risk for supporting the New Deal, his state or the United Nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee bowed today to a polite threat of a British walkout from one of its subordinate committees.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Sharp advances in grain prices yesterday were followed by modest gains this morning, but the demand faded and there was a recession from top prices. The market was called upon to absorb profit taking sales, while outside buying was light.

GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The United States informed other Western nations today that it is "a matter of serious concern" that Japan is still treated as in inferior member of the Western community of trading nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The United States urged today that care and caution be exercised in handling the topic of South African racial policies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A Government scientist told Congress today that this country's economic health and expansion depended on mechanization of all kinds.

TECHNION CITY, Israel, Oct. 27 -- Randolph Churchill, after having laid the foundation stone of the Winston Churchill auditorium here today for his father, told a ceremonial audience the hearts of all well-wishers of freedom "beat with you in these anxious days."

Tile National Cash ReisterI Company set a new record for) sales in the first nine monthsI this year. Volume totaled $212,-I 141.4:45, an increase of $27.822,328 or 15 per cent over the $184.319,117 volume a year earlier.', Earnings were the second high-I est on record, exceeded only by the net for the first nine rnonths of 1948.
Yesterday in the stock market was a day of dreams that didn't quite come true. Investors had expected higher dividends than were declared.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Oct. 27 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed its season today with a four-ball, best-ball tournament over the lower course of the Baltusrol Golf Club.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- A1 Feminelli of Old Oaks moved into the pacemaker's spot in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Following is the text of the eighteen-power resolution on the proposed international atomic energy agency approved today by the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:
New York's campaign to raise its $375,000 share of the $1,500,000 needed to send complete United States teams to the 1956 Olympic Games was opened last night.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Jack Kramer offered to Lew Hoad 25,000 Australian pounds (about $56,250) today to become a tennis professional. But he admitted that the 20-year-old Australian star probably would turn down the contract. Hoad will give Kramer his final decision tomorrow at Melbourne.
GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- Premier Moshe Sharett of Israel said today he hoped to God his country would not be driven to a preventive war against the Arab states.

THE Montana, a massive pile of Caen stone, Formosa marble, mosaic and fancy plaster work, has been reduced almost to street level by wreckers clearing the site for the thirty-eight-story Seagram Building at 375 Park Avenue. The apartment house's thousands of parts are to be distributed all over the United States.

The nation's vital aluminum industry is still in the adolescent stage as far as growth is concerned. That is the view, at least, of Dexter M. Keezer, vice president and economics director of McGraw-Hill Publishing Company.

Tennessee Williams is the authority for the statement that he and his alert representative, Audrey Wood, are going into the theatrical producing business with Mr. Williams' drama "Orpheus Descending." The firm will operate under the name of Williams Wood.

There will be no attempt here this morning to teach nature her business. To do so would be a waste of time, for she is as set in her ways as most charming ladies. Every now and then, for example, she must send a rainy day to coincide with a big football game, or offer a melting thaw in place of white Christmas.
Man, the soul of battle, is the major problem of the Strategic Air Command, one of the nation's first lines of defense.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The Labor party and a number of trade unions bitterly criticized today the supplementary budget introduced in Parliament yesterday by R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Suits totaling hundreds of thousands of dollars may be filed soon by seamen once barred from work by the Coast Guard on security grounds.
The Transit Authority said yesterday it would ask the Board of Estimate for $51,000,000 to buy 500 new subway cars.
A cash sale of property on the West Side owned by The New York Times was announced yesterday.
A check for $140,000 was presented to City College yesterday by an alumni group, the City College Fund, to cover the cost of decorating and furnishing the new John H. Finley Student Center.
Two veterans in marshaling labor's political forces are slated to head the political machinery of the merged union movement.

The new liner Israel, as trim and as streamlined as the new nation for which she was named, steamed proudly into New York yesterday on her maiden run from the Mediterranean. Bedecked from stem to stern with gay signal flags, the 10,500-gross ton steamship picked her way through a sunlit harbor, blending her roaring whistle salutes with the welcoming chorus from scores of harbor craft and a water-spouting fireboat.
BACK in 1948 the Cleveland Indians won the pennant with the help of as slick an infield as anyone would want to see.
CAIRO, Oct. 27 -- Egypt and Saudi Arabia signed a mutual defense treaty here today. It varied in only a few pionts from between Egypt and Syria.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Preliminary discussions of the possibility of a merger of Stewart-Warner Corporation, Chicago, and McGraw Electric Company, Elgin, Ill., have been carried on for the last three or four months. it was reported today. Officials of the companies were said to be still some distance apart on any decision.

There's a refreshing new psychological atmosphere at Notre Dame under Terry Brennan. The current coach of the Fighting Irish is no braggart, but Terry is an optimist at heart. If he believes Notre Dame has a chance to win -- and he usually thinks so -- he'll come right out and say it.

J. Irwin Shapiro, State Investigation Commissioner, said yesterday his office, had evidence that a former Suffolk County official had sold $17,000 in office furniture to county agencies in an undercover operation.
A new 36,000-ton luxury liner for the trans-Atlantic service has been ordered by the Holland-America Line as a running mate for the flagship Nieuw Amsterdam.

GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- Germany's reunification appeared more remote today after Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, had outlined Moscow's position at the opening session of the Foreign Ministers' Conference.
DENVER, Oct. 27 -- President Eisenhower did his first work today on the State of the Union Message outlining his 1956 legislative program to Congress.
Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that more funds might be forthcoming for new schools.

A two-foot bronze sculpture representing the hands of all races, creeds and nationalities reaching toward the common goal of brotherhood was unveiled yesterday at the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 27 -- United States Senator Frederick G. Payne predicted today that the United States Merchant Marine Academy here would be made a permanent institution ranking with the other Federal Service academies.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy warned yesterday that the city's police strength was down 22 per cent since 1932 in relation to population, although the force numerically was the largest in its 326-year existence.

Mme. Valentine Belova of Russia took first place in the women's challengers' chess tournament last night. She defeated Mme. Kristina Holuj of Poland in a King's Indian defense after twenty-one moves in the six- teenth round, according to a report from Moscow.

Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday that its net income for the first nine months of this year rose to $166,272,294, or $5.52 a share, from $154,920,656, or $5.15 a share, in the similar period of 1954.

The Walsh Construction Company has leased the fourteenth floor in the nineteen-story building being erected by William Kaufman at 711 Third Avenue, the east blockfront between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.

Some of our best Southern lawyers are writing editorials and making speeches trying to stir up public resentment against the United States Supreme Court. They are doing this because of their emotional displeasure at some of the decisions.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 27 (AP) -- A request that the United States offer mutual security anti-aggression pacts to both Israel and the Arab states was made today by the Jewish War Veterans national convention.
GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The Big Four foreign ministers agreed unanimously today on one point: a get-well message to President Eisenhower.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony committed itself yesterday to moving its headquarters to the new Lincoln Square redevelopment project that is being drawn up by Parks Commissioner Robert Moses. The Metropolitan Opera will also move uptown to the new project.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 -- Two new electronic developments for control of traffic were demonstrated today to the Institute of Traffic Engineers.

The Brooklyn Ice Palace at Atlantic and Bedford Avenues in Brooklyn has been sold by Lloyd E. Sampson and Henry J. Mellon to Sidney Berg, Morris Bowers and Dale Kaiser. Mr. Sampson will continue as manager of the rink, which the sellers have operated for the last eleven years.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 27 -- The First Baptist Church of this city announced today the purchase of an estate of 8.66 acres at North Street and Bryant Avenue for eventual conversion to church uses. The price was $200,000.

Nationalist China's No. 1 naval hero is here aboard his Navy's No. 1 warship. He is Capt. Chen Hsing-Kuen and his ship is the Hsien-Yang, a destroyer that earned battle honors when she was the Rodman in the United States Navy.

The Port of New York Authority announced plans yesterday for an $85,000,000 marine terminal along two miles of Brooklyn waterfront. It is the most extensive and expensive single program of pier development ever undertaken in the port.
Directors of Textron American, Inc., voted yesterday a dividend of 40 cents on the common stock, payable Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Methodist Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, struck back today at fifty Protestant ministers of the San Francisco area who have protested his scheduled speech at a religious meeting Sunday in Oakland, Calif.
I have read your editorial of Oct. 12 "The Day of the Race" and also the irritated letter sent by the Ambassador of Venezuela in Washington, published on Oct. 15.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administrator, Norman P. Mason, said today recent measures to "slow down" housing credit would be junked if the decline in home construction continued.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Coach Herb Royer today credited the Marshall College trainer, Ed Prelaz, with having saved the life of a halfback, Dyke Six, who was injured in the Marshall football game with Kent State at Kent, Ohio, last Saturday.
DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- John W. Livingston, a vice president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., was designated today as the future director of organization for the merged labor movement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Earl Mountbatten, Britain's ranking naval officer, arrived today from Canada for talks with United States defense chiefs.

The American Red Cross has made grants of more than $13,000,000 to victims of the recent floods in Northeastern states, Ellsworth Bunker, national president, reported yesterday. The grants, he added, are expected eventually to total $15,500,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Navy plans to power its new giant submarine with two atomic engines, giving the boat a speed equal to the fastest surface ships in a task force.
Electricite de France, the nationalized electric utility system, will be generating atomic power next year, according to Marcell Flouret, chairman.
MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- The Western Big Three have reiterated their contention that the Soviet Union was responsible for maintaining communications between West Berlin and West Germany.
ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- If Governor Harriman is running for President, he won't find a national campaign taxing after the warm-up he got today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 25 -- Less than a year after having deposed Premier Imre Nagy and reversed his "new course," Matyas Rakosi, Communist party boss, again has Hungary firmly in hand.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Moving day continues to be a national institution observed by almost 20 per cent of the population.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Margaret Emerson and her family have sold their 29 per cent interest in the Emerson Drug Company of Baltimore to the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company of New York.

The Coliseum, now nearing completion at Columbus Circle, will be operated by a private corporation, it was learned last night. The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, owner of the structure, will sign a contract on Tuesday leasing the convention and exposition areas to the New York Exhibition Corporation.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 27 (UP) -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, said today that Democratic charges that the Eisenhower Administration had been giving away national resources were "pure politics."

Distant cotton futures declined sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices closed from 2 points (10 cents a bale) up on December and near March to 41 points ($2.05 a bale) down on the March, 1957, delivery.

The Irish painter and author, James Reynolds, has two books on publishers lists scheduled to be issued a week apart. On Nov. 14 Farrar, Straus Cudahy will publish "Ghosts in American Houses," in which Mr. Reynolds tells the stories of "the disparate personalities whose perturbed shades still bulk large in ghostly legends of the American scene.

Net earnings of the Electro Auto-Lite Company skyrocketed to $6,797,122 or $4.25 a share in the first nine months this year from the $120,796 or 8 cents a share turned in during the similar period of 1954. This reflected in part the 59 per cent rise in consolidated net sales to $213,396,097 from the $134,326,043 volume last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The United States has begun a drive to scuttle a section of the proposed Covenant of Human Rights that poses a threat to its business interests abroad.

PRAGUE. Czechoslovakia, Oct. 27 -- Communism in Prague seems less noisy than in Rumania and Hungary. There are fewer political posters, banners and exhortations to the people on behalf of socialism and the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct 27 -- The United States will place before the General Assembly next week a resolution establishing a mechanism for review of the United Nations Charter but deferring a review conference for at least two years.

PARENTS are as completely confused about discipline these days as teachers, and have good cause to be so in the opinion of Marjorie Carr Smith, principal of the West Hill School in Ithaca. Moreover, parents are "just as sold on the need for good discipline in the school room" as are both teachers and principals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The dark horses in the Democratic contest for the Presidential nomination are now being identified, which is the second logical step in a classic political situation. The situation arises when the outlook for party success is changing from poor to promising.

THERE seemed to be something heavy about the atmosphere in the Holiday Theatre last evening. One critic slipped smoothly off into slumber during most of the first act. He had never looked so sweet, his tired face relaxed, no conscious cares troubling him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today that temporary partial embargoes have been ordered on rail shipments of cotton to compresses over a wide area of the South and Southwest.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Argentina's provisional Government devalued the peso tonight to 18 to the dollar, making it worth a little more than 5 1/2 cents. The rate has been 14 to the dollar.

DARRTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Manager Walt (Smokey) Alston of the world champion Brooklyn Dodgers said the "team spirit and cooperation of all twenty-five players" was responsible for his selection by The United Press today as National League manager of the year.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- It was a holiday at Hackley School today. But there was little rest for Coach Pete Slader's football players.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Smaller-than-expected receipts and a strong demand from Eastern buyers sent butcher hogs spinning up 50 to 75 cents today. Sows jumped 50 cents. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
The locale of the new "dream track" for thoroughbred racing will be Belmont Park, it was disclosed yesterday by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The chairman of a House inquiry panel said today he had found "no evidence of fraud or improper action" in the Navy's purchase of jet planes that could not meet combat standards.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 27 -- The number of persons in the United States more than 65 years old is increasing at the rate of 1,000 a day, the eighth annual Scientific Meeting of the Gerontological Society was told today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Friday, Oct. 28 -- An Israeli Army unit stormed into an Egyptian army camp last night at Kunteila on the border at the Sinai Peninsula, Israeli Army headquarters here announced this morning. Five Egyptian soldiers were killed by the raid.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Princess Margaret visited Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, today for a private audience lasting an hour.
Henry A. Wallace made public yesterday a statement in which he disputed former President Harry S. Truman's account of Mr. Wallace's dismissal from the Cabinet as Secretary of Commerce.
DUBLIN, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Tulyar was sold today to a five-man United States syndicate for 240,000 ($672,000).

If you have a son or daughter who has left home to go into the armed forces, then you will be glad to hear this. Your sons and daughters have "a home away from home," thanks to the United Service Organizations.
GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The staleness that often hangs over a theatrical revival tainted the opening meeting today of the Foreign Ministers' Conference.
The New York State Thruway was hailed yesterday as having brought "amazing benefits" to the entire state's economy.

GENEVA, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the addresses at the opening session of the Foreign Ministers' Conference by Antoine Pinay of France, Vyacheslav M. Molotov of the Soviet Union. Macmillan of Britain and Secretary of State Dulles:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The White House said tonight that a published report that some Cabinet members had tried to oust Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, was "not only untrue but completely unfounded."

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System trimmed their borrowings from the System by $267,000,000 on a daily average basis during the week ended on Wednesday as compared with the previous week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The New York City Opera will begin the final week of its current season on Monday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas plans a nation-wide tour next spring to line up support for the sort of "moderate" Presidential candidate he thinks the Democrats need to win in 1956.

Johnny Gonsalves, a 25-year-old Oakland (Calif.) lightweight, and Lulu Perez, 22, the Brooklyn boy with a solid punch, will meet in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. It is scheduled for ten rounds.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Three story purchases were reported today. Paramount accounted for two of the properties and Universal-International the other.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- Soviet commentators adopted a generally optimistic attitude today toward the Geneva conference. However, they asserted again that "certain circles" in the West wished to prevent improvement in the international outlook.

GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The Foreign Ministers' Conference got off to a somewhat equivocal start today when it met to give effect to the broad decisions of the Big Four heads of government who met here in July.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- It appears slightly likely that Montgomery Ward Co. will declare an extra dividend or increase the present 75-cent quarterly rate before the end of the year. In the final quarter of 1954, directors ordered an extra $1.75 a share.
Supreme Court Justice Peter M. Daly ruled yesterday that the city could not sell the site of the abandoned Neponsit Hospital in the Rockaways, Queens, to private interests.
The city of Cleveland received bids yesterday on an issue ofI !$9,000,000 of mortgage revenue i bonds to finance the revamping and enlargement of its water-I works system.

DINNER before the theatre can set the stage for a pleasant evening. It can, that is, if the restaurant is on the West Side, conveniently near the playhouse, if the meal is ordered with taste, and if the food is savored with leisure.

The nation's biggest aluminum producer, the Aluminum Company of America, set a new high for nine-month earnings at $55,779,754. This also exceeded by 14.2 per cent the highest full year's net profit, $48,848,094, attained in 1953.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The United States Public Health Service said today it expected the nation's polio rate this year to be the lowest since 1951.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Industrial stocks were buoyant today on the London stock market. It was the first day of trading after introduction of the Government's new budget. Apparently measures to curb inflation and encourage exports were less severe than investors had expected.

Loans to business outstanding on the books of leading New York City banks increased $11,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the first rise in three weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 27 -- United Jewish Appeal leaders from the United States will call upon American Jews to relieve the Israelis of their share of the burden of financing colonization of Jewish refugees from North Africa.

The Geneva conference of the Big Four foreign ministers opened yesterday with expressions of goodwill on all sides. But hopes for its success, already discounted, have been further dimmed by an immediate disagreement between the Western powers and the Soviets over the priorities to be assigned to the several issues.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 27 (UP) -- Fred Schultz of Evanston, Ill., upset the medalist, C. D. McAllister of Orlando, Fla., today in the quarter-finals of the North and South senior invitation golf tournament.
MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- For the first time since World War II major research libraries throughout the Soviet Union have agreed to exchange books and newspapers with comparable United States institutions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Labor unions may use "harassing tactics" to support lawful demands on employers without being guilty of failing to bargain in good faith, the Federal Court of Appeals ruled today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Special "anti-dumping" duties were invoked by the Government today against imports of British-made cast iron soil pipe.

The second article by Stanley Rowland Jr. on "Religion on College Campuses," carried in The Times on Oct. 24, concluded with a quotation of a student, "If I thought my church was doing a damn thing, maybe I'd go more."
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Another probable starter was listed today for the Garden State Stakes at Garden State Park Saturday, bringing the total to fourteen.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Drexel Institute of Technology dedicated its $1,600,000 basic science center today at the opening of a science convocation.
The police task force assigned to points of greatest danger in the city's traffic system was briefed yesterday at Police Headquarters by Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Donald E. Keyhoe, former Marine Corps officer who has written several books on flying saucers, accused the Air Force tonight of a "deliberate attempt to conceal facts from the public."
In the lobby of John Jay Hall at Columbia University the bulletin board's top note of the day was: "Luncheon for Athletic Press, Room 4, Mezzanine."

When the Citizens Waterfront Committee, which begins public hearings today, was created last month it seemed to be an escape hatch through which Captain Bradley and his crew of I. L. A. officials could crawl out of the hole they got themselves into by calling their stupid and illegal strike against the Waterfront Commission.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Notre Dame's football team reviewed all phases of play today in the semi-final workout before Saturday's game with undefeated Navy.

UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 27 -- The United States and Britain, the world's leading capital-exporting nations, warned today that the new International Finance Corporation would be no cure-all for the investment problems of underdeveloped countries.

The prayers of all the peoples of the world are that the Big Four Foreign Ministers meeting at Geneva reflect the peoples' will to peace, Vice President Richard Nixon said last night. Mr. Nixon spoke at a dinner of the West Side Association of Commerce at the Statler Hotel.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Government approved today a new petroleum code favoring foreign investment.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad lifted its net income in the first nine months of this year to $8,393,152 from $3,263,659 in the like period a year ago.

It seems incredible -- and certainly it is discouraging -- that we are facing the possibility of another local war. We would be blinding ourselves to realities not to see that if the conflicts between Israel and Egypt and Israel and Syria continue along present lines war is the likely conclusion.
FIFTY different points of view were advanced yesterday by part-time artists who make their living from the fashion industry and allied trades.

The one-story business building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 119 West Forty-second Street, east of Times Square, has been sold by Mrs. Sophie Samuels to Charles B. Benenson, realty operator. It is assessed at $220,000 and was sold in a deal negotiated by Frederic D. Sasse, president of George A. Bowman, Inc., brokers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A Communist party functionary who is in prison for conspiring to advocate overthrow of the United States Government by force gets an $88 Social Security check each month.
CONSTANTINE, Algeria, Oct. 27 -- French forces in the rebellious areas of eastern Algeria have been alerted for trouble.

OLIN DOWNES used to say that in opera the music should get underneath the dramatic action and lift it as if on wings. There are two reasons for recalling this in connection with last night's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall.

Answering a query concerning his reported affiliation with the forthcoming Theatre Guild production of "Valour Will Weep," Joshua Logan didn't hesitate to say it was "unofficially true." Only in a consultative capacity, though.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Don Holleder, the end turned quarterback for Army, may have better luck finding his passing target with Ralph Chesnauskas at right end for the cadets against Colgate this Saturday.
