MY third Cabinet problem of the year involved Henry Wallace. Wallace had served eight years as President Roosevelt's Secretary of Agriculture. He had been Vice President of the United States in Roosevelt's third term and had made a strong bid for renomination in 1944 which failed because it did not have the support of President Roosevelt.

SEATTLE, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Expressing concern over the increase in newsprint prices by several Canadian firms, Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, sent telegrams to all United States producers today inquiring about their intentions and their production costs.
The Ford Motor Company became a $2,000,000,000 industrial empire in 1954.
The whine of sirens sent most of New Jersey's 5,000,000 residents ducking for shelters last evening in a ten-minute air raid test that covered the state.

Futures were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Rubber, coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, lead and zinc eased; hides, wool, potatoes and onions rose, and cocoa, sugar, burlap and copper ended mixed.

Today's new film is "Illegal," at the Palace. The Warner Brothers melodrama features Edward G. Robinson, Nina Foch, Hugh Marlowe, Jayne Mansfield, Albert Dekker. Howard St. John and Ellen Corby. The film was directed by Lewis Allen and produced by Frank P. Rosenberg. W. R. Burnett and James R. Webb wrote the screen play from a story by Frank J. Collins.
President Eisenhower assured the world last night that "there is no monopoly -- and we seek no monopoly -- in the harnessing of the atom for man's benefit."
TORONTO, Oct. 27 -- The appointment of Walter Susskind as conductor of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra was announced tonight by the symphony board of directors. He succeeds Sir Ernest MacMillan.

BEILSTEIN, Germany, Oct. 21 -- A strong wind, blowing from the nearest glacier, stirred both game and hunters to activity this morning, and the rattling of branches made it possible to get much closer to the game.
No city department head will risk his job if he refuses to participate in a general program for dramatizing municipal activities on television, City Administrator Luther Gulick declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Crockett Johnson, cartoonist inventor of talking dogs and small boys with fairy godfathers, has invented an adjustable mattress. He received a patent for it this week.
A pilot survey of industries in the Rochester area will be conducted by the State Employment Service to stimulate interest in the Refugee Relief Program.
KALLE RUUSUNEN, who sang last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, seized his listeners' attention at once with the virile brilliance and resonance of his baritone voice.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Mme. Nina Sergeyevna Ratiani, who used to wield a savage red pencil in the cause of Communist censorship, has turned up in Geneva, the picture of sweet Soviet reasonableness.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- Two Columbia Pictures executives from New York testified today in Federal Court, Los Angeles, for the defense in the film antitrust trial. Five movie companies and their subsidiaries are charged with "conspiracy" and restraint of trade in marketing 16-mm. prints of theatrical features.
Today's new film is "Gentlemen Mary Brunettes," at the Mayfair. Featured are Jane Russell, Jeanne Crain, Alan Young, Scott Brady and Rudy Vallee. The comedy with music is in CinemaScope and color.

ZANZIBAR, Oct. 27 -- On the island of Zanzibar one of the chief centers of interest these days is a developing political controversy. The goal here is the same as in most other colonial territories in Africa south of the Sahara. It is self-government.

By his dispatch of Oct. 20 from Bucharest, your correspondent, Jack Raymond, has rendered a great service to all those, Rumanians and Americans alike, who for so many years have tried to discover the fate of the Rumanian democratic leaders imprisoned by the Communist administration.

The Canadian National Railways early this year announced it would cut back operating expenses by at least $5,000,000 after having sustained a $28,800,000 loss last year. In the first nine months of this year it achieved its goal twice over.

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, onions, rubber and copper rose; coffee, hides and wool eased, and sugar, potatoes, burlap and zinc were mixed.

Two tenants have leased the space formerly occupied by the Flint Horner furniture store at 62-66 West Forty-seventh Street. They are the Merchants Bank of New York and Joseph Axler, Inc., distributor of watches.

Harness racing fans at an upstate fairgrounds track witnessed a spectacular spill in the spring of 1948. The wheels of three sulkies, drawn by speeding pacers, locked on a turn. Two of the drivers rolled to the track; the other turned a somersault, landed on his feet, jumped back into his sulky seat and finished the contest.

The National Association of Purchasing Agents predicts that the business boom will extend well into 1956. That is the finding of the latest monthly survey of the organization, based on economic conditions prevailing in October.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Union Pacific Railroad streamliners legally were free today to start operating Sunday over tracks of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad.
ALBANY, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits ruled today that New York State savings banks could legally buy bonds issued by the Commissioners of the Port of New Orleans.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 28 -- Israel reported today that an army force had killed ten Egyptians and taken twenty prisoners in a pre-dawn attack. The raid was made at Kuntilla in the Sinai desert five miles inside Egypt.

Last Monday an unusual package came into New York by air from Vienna, consigned to a dealer in banknotes. The contents turned out to be about 30,000 rubles, the first to reach this country's money markets since 1939.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 111.1 (1947-49 equals 100) in the week ended Oct. 25, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products and processed foods caused the decrease, as the index for all commodities other than farm products and foods advanced fractionally.
Watchful waiting paid off yesterday in the arrest of five asserted fur thieves. They are accused of being members of a half-million-dollar robbery ring.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- A generally heavy tone was shown in the grain markets today. Corn reacted sharply from recent advances and there was considerable selling of soybeans credited to cash interests.

The new capital market is in for a continued period of activity, with the money requisitions coming largely from public utility companies selling common stock and local governments financing school, port-improvement and veterans' aid outlays.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- An investigation into the official conduct of the Federal Commissioner of Public Buildings has been started by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Following is the text of a letter from Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, to Governor Harriman urging that the validity of a 1950 Senate reservation to the Niagara Power treaty be challenged in the courts.
The Georgia Rural Roads Authority, a new state-financing agency modeled on Georgia's State Bridge Authority, will offer its first serial bonds for sale Nov. 22.

Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth lifted the curtain yesterday on techniques for overcoming two of the major obstacles to harnessing the hydrogen bomb for industrial power. The Princeton University physicist is a former member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Air Force is reconsidering the procurement schedules of several new aircraft with the view of doing its share toward achieving the $500,000,000 savings sought by Charles E. Wilson Secretary of Defense.

United Neighborhood Houses, a federation of fifty settlement and neighborhood centers in New York, will benefit from a Nov. 9 performance of "The Chalk Garden" at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre. The comedy, produced by Irene Selznick, stars Gladys Cooper and Siobhan McKenna.

The State Power Authority, headed by Robert Moses, is preparing to challenge the validity of a Senate reservation to the 1950 Niagara water diversion treaty between the United States and Canada. The challenge is awaiting Governor Harriman's approval. The authority was proceeding yesterday on the theory that this would be forthcoming.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 -- Time-honored beliefs about the aged are becoming outmoded, the Gerontological Society was told today.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Harry Weetman of the British Ryder Cup team fired a 34, 32 -- 66 today for the day's lowest practice score on the par-72 Thunderbird Country Club course.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Young People's Concert, Wilfrid Pelletier, conductor, Rudolf Serkin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; City Symphony Orchestra, youth concert, Franz Bibo, conductor, American Museum of Natural History, 3:30 P. M.; Composers Group of New York City, Mason and Hamlin Salon, 3 East Forty-third Street, 5 P. M.

The public hearings of the Tweed Commission on the Courts -- nine out of a scheduled ten of which have now been held -- have served a useful purpose. At least they have brought into the open the opposition to the commission's plan for modernizing the state's judicial structure. But the hearings have unduly magnified dissent.

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, testified yesterday that he alone was responsible for general strike orders that were sent to dock workers from Canada to Puerto Rico on Sept. 12.
DENVER, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower's first full X-ray and fluoroscopic examinations today showed that there had been no heart enlargement resulting from his illness.
OTTAWA, Oct. 28 -- The Royal Commission on Canada's Economic Prospects headed back to Ottawa today after completing a series of hearings in the Maritime Provinces.

JUST about a year ago, Mary Luisa Faini gave her debut piano recital in Town Hall. Last night she sounded like a different pianist. A year ago she was all whispers and pianissimos, archly confiding her musical secrets to the audience. On this occasion her playing had much more strength and focus.

The Texas Company, a $2,000,000,000 petroleum enterprise, attained the highest earnings for a third quarter and first nine months in its history. As a result, directors yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 90 cents and voted an extra distribution of $1.10 a share.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- Japan challenged European countries today to produce some evidence to support their claims that they cannot afford to treat her as an equal trading partner.

THE fragrant blend of yaupon, myrtle and pine rides on the wind and there is a whisper of wings from Currituck to Mattamuskeet. The wildfowler is shortly to come into his own along the Carolina outer banks.
THE STAY-AT-HOME girl is now dressing up to make "little evenings in" as important as "big nights out."

BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer entered his fourth week of illness today as a result of an attack of bronchial pneumonia. He still was running a low fever. It is understood he suffered a serious setback some days ago, with his temperature reported to have reached 104.3 degrees.
"SCIENCE-FICTION THEATRE" came up with a program about a hurricane last night on Channel 4 that would cause the true science-fiction cultist to lift his eyebrows clear through his space helmet.

The Fund for the Republic has decided to revise its "Bibliography on the Communist Program in the United States" because of criticism from scholars and writers. The critics say important anti-Communist works have been omitted.

The formation of the Mobil Overseas Oil Company, Inc., to take over on Jan. 1 a large part of foreign activities of the Socony Mobil Oil Company was announced yesterday. P. V. Keyser Jr. has been named president of the new company. He will continue as a director and vice president of Socony Mobil.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Even before the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, R. A. Butler, introduced his tough tax program on Wednesday, the influential London Economist expressed fear that he might raise the tax on "distributed profits." He did.

The establishment of an international atomic energy agency as proposed by the United Nations Assembly was hailed yesterday by Dr. Frances C. Willis, United States Ambassador to Switzerland. She said it was an important step in the survival of free nations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee seemed certain today to get most of the Morgenthau diaries that contain notes on the late Harry Dexter White.

GENEVA, Oct. 28 (AP) - Following are excerpts from the addresses at the Foreign Ministers' conference today by Harold Macmillan of Britain, Vyacheslav M. Molotov of the Soviet Union, Secretary of State Dulles and Antoine Pinay of France:
The nation's colleges and universities were warned yesterday against neglecting the needs of the intellectually gifted students.

Gay Wilson Allen will receive two honors soon for his book, "The Solitary Singer," a biography of Walt Whitman. On Dec. 3 he will receive the sixth annual Tamiment Institute Book Award, consisting of a citation and $500, for the best American biography of the year.
Protestant services will mark the Reformation tomorrow.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of the Western proposals and a translation of the Soviet plan on Germany and the security of Europe:

Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court of the City of New York is quoted in The Times of Oct. 18 as saying that there are twenty-seven vacancies in that court's probation staff. I am reliably informed that a breakdown of these twenty-seven vacancies reveals that twenty of them are in the Family Court and seven in the Children's Court (the two main divisions of this Domestic Relations Court).
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- United States and British specialists are spreading word throughout Europe that the leaders of the Soviet Union do not want a European settlement.

Officials of the New York City Center of Music and Drama expressed a strong interest yesterday in becoming part of the new Lincoln Square redevelopment project. They also pointed out some difficulties in the way.

NEWARK, Oct. 28 -- Thirty women employes were injured here today in an explosion at a plant that makes electronic parts for the Navy. One woman suffered hand burns. The others suffered shock or were overcome by the dense smoke that spread through the building at 191 Central Avenue.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -- Franz-Josef Strauss, newly named Federal Minister for Atomic Problems, outlined today West Germany's program to begin catching up with other countries in the peaceful uses of atomic energy.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 28 -- George Clough, Nassau County Fire Marshal, ordered a crackdown today on Long Island home builders who burn abandoned buildings on land they plan to develop.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- The country's major railroads and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers reached an agreement today providing for wage increases for road and yard engineers.
Toothpicks have gone high hat in certain quarters, but the plain old wooden variety is still the production item in the industry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Commissioner Norman Mason of the Federal Housing Administration has promised to loosen the curbs on mortgage credit if new home building dips sharply.

It has been a quarter of a century since the sound of new pier construction was heard along the Brooklyn shore. Shipping has gone ahead in its normal growth; new carriers emerged from the war and the old lines expanded their services and brought modern, fast tonnage into the far-reaching trade lanes that wend to the borough's shore-front. Only the terminals themselves have failed to keep pace.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 -- Bankers, brokers, business men and economists hailed today the Argentina Government's announcement that it planned to supplant the multiple rate of exchange system by a single official rate.
As the only clash between top-ten powers, the contest between Navy and Notre Dame gets first billing on today's college football program.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Observations have disclosed more electrical disturbance on the planet Jupiter that are considered the equivalent of enormous thunderstorms on earth.

MANY a husband has unwittingly supplied the raw material for his wife's book, or vice versa, though the experience has not always been conducive to domestic harmony. But husband-and-wife writing teams are rare. One of the most successful in recent years has been that of Charmian Clift and George Johnston.

Mayor Wagner joined other city officials yesterday in dedicating the new Metropolitan Hospital, third largest and most modern of New York's twenty-eight municipal hospitals. Kings County Hospital is the largest and Bellevue is second.

Midafternoon carried the colors of Mrs. Edward E. Robbins to victory in the feature at Jamaica yesterday, Favored by the crowd of 18,039, Midafternoon scored by a nose over Albert J. Mester's Power, with Elmendorf's Little Dell finishing third in the mile-and-a-six-teenth event.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 28 (UP) -- The Australian Davis Cup stars, Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall, may have endangered their amateur status regardless of whether they turn professional or not, Jack Kramer, the tennis promoter, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- William Holden will star for Warner Brothers in "Toward the Unknown" on partnership basis. The picture will bear the credit line, Tolucka Production Company production, presented by Warner Brothers.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 28 -- Today is the thirty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the Czechoslovak Republic.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union rebuffed today a Western offer of elaborate assurances that a united Germany would not be allowed to menace Europe's peace and security.

Most of the plethora of admonitions about being sure to turn back the clock one hour tonight, which will be dinned into those who read or listen or see, will contain the sugar-coating information that one is regaining the hour he lost last April.

MORE than 200 painters and sculptors are showing work in the forty-second anual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America at the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Figure and landscape dominate in this conventional show, and abstract art is almost totally absent.

Premier Faure's extraordinarily skillful political maneuvering has now brought him through another vote of confidence and closer to a decisive debate on new elections. The Premier wants to hold these general elections in December instead of waiting until the 1951 Parliament runs its full course next June.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The brother-sister team of Calvin Griffith and Mrs. Thelma Haynes assumed control of the Washington Senators today. They vowed that the club would not be sold.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Treasury rejected today a plea by domestic manufacturers to assess special anti-dumping duties against imports of bicycle pedals from Britain.

The Police Department's special traffic enforcement patrol started rolling yesterday at 2:15 P. M. Thirty-five of the forty men of the unit, riding in twenty-four new radio patrol cars and one motorcycle, be- began patrolling streets and highways designated as the most dangerous in the city's traffic system.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Frank (Bucko) Kilroy and Wayne Robinson of the Philadelphia Eagles football team today filed libel suit for $250,000 each against the publishers of Life magazine.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The United States, in the opinion of a Soviet visitor, is like a child's Christmas dream come true.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- A prominent economist told Congress today that the economy was at a critical stage.
At midnight last Sunday the Bergen Street police station, in the heart of downtown Brooklyn, failed to call out a single foot patrolman for the graveyard shift.
DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Record performances by Ford and expanded output by other producers will boost passenger car output this week to 156,952 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 -- Edwin W. Pauley, a leading independent oil operator, announced today that he had reached an agreement with the Government of Jordan giving him a fifty-five-year oil development concession there. No oil ever has been found there.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- Israel is preparing to ask the United States for anti-aircraft guns, radar equipment, anti-tank guns, jet fighters and anti-submarine vessels.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 28 -- The plans for an $85,000,000 marine terminal on the Brooklyn waterfront were hailed today as a major step toward the development of a completely modern port for the New York metropolitan area.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- By a vote of 271 to 259, the National Assembly gave Premier Edgar Faure a grudging vote of confidence today. The vote reversed a decision hostile to the Government adopted early yesterday morning.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 27 -- Premier Andras Hegedus of Hungary explained his Government's attitude toward industrialization, agricultural collectivization, relations with the Roman Catholic Church and relations with Yugoslavia in an interview today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Four more organizations were added today to the Justice Department's list of those classified as subversive. This brought to 279 the total so named by various Attorneys General in the last eight years.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- Egypt's Foreign Minister complained today that a furor was being artificially stirred up over Cairo's purchase of fighter planes and arms from the Soviet bloc.
TOKYO, Oct. 27 -- The Japanese armament industry has entered the race to sell arms to Egypt. Little success is reported so far.

Three American conductors were named yesterday winners of advance study grants from the American Symphony Orchestra League. They are Franz Bibo, conductor of the City Symphony Orchestra of New York; Donald Johanos, conductor of the Altoona and Johnstown Symphonies in Pennsylvania, and James Robertson, conductor of the Wichita (Kan.) Symphony.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Scientists at Franklin Institute reported today they had worked out the first step necessary to end air pollution and smog.
Capturing a homicide suspect should offset a failing grade in police examinations, a former patrolman contended yesterday as he sought reinstatement.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Against a background of cheers and jeers R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, engaged in a sharp exchange with a Laborite in the House of Commons today.

The open disagreement with which the new Geneva conference began has been intensified as a result of the presentation by the Western powers and the Soviets of two rival plans on the first item of the Geneva directive. This item calls for the unification of Germany within the framework of a European security system.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The political figure-skating of that agile little Premier, Edgar Faure, succeeded again today in preserving for France government and the courtesy title of Great Power, which she therefore continues to uphold at the Big Four conference in Geneva. But the ice is getting thinner all the time.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Only 5 to 10 per cent of the estimated $1.5 billion in property losses caused by the Hurricane Diane floods last August was covered by insurance, a Boston insurance executive said today.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 28 -- The Texas Turnpike Authority has authorized a privately financed traffic and revenue survey for a proposed toll highway between Houston and the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

GRANDEUR once reserved for royalty -- of blood or riches -- now graces the gathering spot of scholars on Columbia University's campus. There, in the Avery Library in the School of Architecture, an eighteenth century English paneled room has been reconstructed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California put all his prestige today behind the Administration's embattled farm program and the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson.
Directors of the Stewart-Warner Corporation yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 50 cents end a year-end extra of 20 cents, both payable on Dec. 3.
DENVILLE, N. J., Oct. 28 -- The new champion of the New Jersey Professional Golf Association is Otto Greiner of the Knickerbocker Country Club, Tenafly.
CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 28 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, vice president of The Times Printing Company, was elected president today. He succeeds Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, who died Oct. 3.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Britain declared today that the role of the 280,000 men receiving two years military training had been fundamentally changed by nuclear warfare.

Stocks drifted lower most of yesterday, with weakness showing up in Bethlehem Steel, Westinghouse Electric and du Pont. Toward the end of the day, however, support appeared and the close found the market virtually where it had been twenty-four hours before.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 28 -- Navy and Notre Dame, two of the top ranking football teams of the year, will meet here tomorrow, with the undefeated midshipmen hopeful of gaining their first victory in the rivalry since 1944.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- A new Soviet move for parallel discussion of disarmament here and at the Big Four Foreign Ministers' Conference in Geneva was rejected today in the United Nations.

Net income of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its consolidated subsidiaries climbed to a record total of $291,603,652, or $6.24 a common share, for the first nine months this year. In the corresponding period last year, the net income was $223,797,063, or $4.74 a share.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The United States equestrian team had its best day in four years at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show today. The Americans regained the No. 1 team trophy and then added another victory in the evening jump.
The high-scoring New York Rangers will conclude a three-game home stand tonight when they skate against the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

The proposal to extend Fifth Avenue by a cut through Washington Square Park was in a state of acute controversy yesterday. At the same time, it was no further from the engineers' drawing boards than it was last March.

Federal Judge David N. Edelstein signed an order yesterday directing the Panama Canal Company to show cause why a summary judgment should not be issued against it in a suit involving canal tolls. The order, is returnable on Dec. 6.

The seventy-nine-family apartment house at 445 West 240th Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been purchased by a group of investors headed by Morris Karp. The building, erected about five years ago, has a garage and a large roof garden.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Buying of industrial stocks on the London stock market contracted today. Many leaders finished with small losses. But the weakness, attributed to the trend in Wall Street and profit taking, did not cancel out all of yesterday's advances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Senator William F. Knowland, the Republican Senate leader, called on the Administration today to make no security pact with the Russians until they had liberated the European satellite nations.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 28 -- Fighting broke out in six towns on Cyprus today.
A $285,000 damage suit against Maurice Chevalier, who is appearing here at the Lyceum Theatre in a program of "Songs and Impressions," was filed yesterday in Federal Court.
Executives of 225 concerns will gather at the Palmer House in Chicago Monday for the twenty-second annual meeting of the National Association of Food Chains.
Birny Mason Jr. has been elected secretary of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

The four-story walk-up apartment house accommodating thirty-eight families at 1169 East New York Avenue in Brooklyn has been purchased by the Den Bri Realty Corporation, of which Robert Brightman is president. The seller was Malpak, Inc., headed by Sayl Kaplan.
Northerners were warned yesterday to eliminate their own race prejudice before being too critical of segregation in the South.

A five-story apartment house at 18 Kensington Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by Leo Bruck and Milton Schoenholz to the Ravena Corporation. The building contains forty-one suites with 114 rooms. It was sold through J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Harry Cooper of Metropolis captured the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today.

Representatives of the forty-seven countries that are members of the International Wheat Agreement have been meeting in Geneva to discuss the question of extending that agreement beyond the expiration date of July 31, 1956.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson will enter several state primaries in his bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Mme. Larissa Volpert of Russia drew her seventeenth-round game with Milunka Lazarevic of Yugoslavia last night to move into a tie for first place with Mme. Valentina Belova of Russia in the chess challengers' tournament, according to a report from Moscow.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 28 -- The flags in the infield at Garden State Park should be fringed with gold and bordered with dollar signs. The world's richest horse race is to be run here tomorrow.

The first contested speeding case involving the police use of radar in Manhattan was tried yesterday in Vehicle Accident Court before Magistrate Charles Solomon. The defendant, Leonard Maitland, a mechanical engineer of 680 West 204th Street, was found guilty.
GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- The most experienced observers here were impressed but not surprised tonight by the academic character of the Foreign Ministers' Conference.
Johnny Gonsalves, Oakland, Calif., lightweight, gained a split decision over Lulu Perez of Brooklyn in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- Official West German spokesmen hailed today the Western Allies' proposals for European security and Germany's reunification. They rejected the Soviet counter-proposals as outrageous and inacceptable.
Three chapels representing the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths are to be dedicated tomorrow on the campus of Brandeis University in the pleasant Boston suburb of Waltham.
Tomorrow will be a twenty-five-hour day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- A previously unknown sidelight of the 1953 Bobby Greenlease kidnapping case came to light today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- A Presidential emergency board proposed today that the Pennsylvania Railroad and 22,560 nonoperating employes split the cost of a health and welfare plan.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 (UP) -- A 27-year-old laborer, who died attempting to save an 8-year-old boy from a burning apartment in New York Christmas Day was one of twenty-eight persons cited today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Foundation commission for an act of heroism. Four others also died.
Sgt. Barney Arluck, the New York City policeman who won $50,000 last week on "The Big Surprise," will be pitted against Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas tonight at 7:30.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Jimmy Slade of Far Rockaway, Queens, scored a split decision tonight over Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson of New York in a ten-round fight that Jackson had figured would be a stepping stone to a heavyweight championship bout with Rocky Marciano. Jackson weighed 190 pounds, ten more than Slade.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28 -- Leaders representing a million adherents of Reform Judaism agreed today that the programs of many worship institutions "are inadequate for the pressing demands of modern society."
The International Longshoremen's Association opened its "case" yesterday before a group of impartial citizens bent on solving the port's chronic ills.
MODERN AMERICANS do not drink cider with the gusto of their Puritan forefathers. But the juice of the apple still is a tradition for fall festivities.
The final obstacle to a permanent stevedore license for the States Terminal Corporation appeared to have been removed yesterday.

Prices of coton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed as much as 18 points (90 cents a bale) higher on the nearby December and March contracts to as much as 12 points (60 cents a bale) lower on the other months.
There's a little room in Brooklyn, where icy breezes blow. The cold drops far past zero, and the Navy runs the show.

Today is the anniversary of a date which Wall Street would just as soon never see the likes of again. Twenty-six years ago, on Oct. 29, 1929, occurred the heaviest trading in the history of the New York Stock Exchange. On that fateful Tuesday, as the bottom was falling out of the market, 16,410,030 shares exchanged hands in a frenzied selling wave.

Knowing that your paper has always championed the United Nations and all that it stands for, I was very much surprised by the tone of your lead editorial on Oct. 5, titled "Anti-Colonial Rampage." In it the votes in the United Nations General Assembly to place the questions of Algeria and West Irian (West New Guinea) on the agenda are referred to as "reckless" and the playing of "a dangerous game."

IN century-old church within earshot of the traffic sounds of the East River, some young, impassioned actors are devoting their spare time to perfecting themselves in the art of classical play-acting.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 28 -- New types of nuclear fusion reactions will be studied with the new accelerators being built here and at the University of California in Berkeley.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Government suspended officials of all unions within the General Confederation of Labor (C. G. T.) tonight and said new leaders would be elected.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 29 -- One play, on which every Yale man handled his assignment flawlessly, led the Elis to a 20 -- 0 victory over Dartmouth before 32,000 spectators in the Bowl today.
Leland L. Tolman was appointed yesterday to be deputy administrator of the First Department of the Judicial Conference of the State of New York. This department embraces New York and Bronx Counties.

HERE is an American historical novel by an English writer that will almost curl your hair. It was inspired by the tribulation and degradation of the Donner Party which wagoned westward from Missouri in 1846 and hit the worst run of luck that ever tested the souls of pioneers.

VIENNA, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- A Dominican monk who escaped from Communist Hungary said here today that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, primate of Hungary, was living in the summer palace of the Bishop of Pecs at Puspok-szentaszlo, in southern Hungary.
ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Quarterback Jimmy Harper passed for one touchdown today, set up another and had a hand in the rest as Georgia routed Alabama, 35 -- 14.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 29 -- All Moroccans, from the illiterate Berber sheepherders in the rugged Riff region to the French-educated Arabs in urban centers, seem today to be united by a common aspiration -- their country's independence.
Snuff-takers of a bygone day were particular about the freshness of the tobacco product they inhaled. Their standard dear included snuff rasps, which insured a fresh, pungent sniff.

A twenty-four-foot assembly line in Brooklyn is the source of considerable advertising appearing in newspapers in this area. At a long table littered with proofs, artists' sketches and photographs of appliances, television receivers and the like, copy is prepared for the Vim chain of fifty-six retail outlets selling consumer appliances.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 29 -- First-ranked Maryland, with Ed Vereb's three touchdowns setting the pace, rolled to a 27-0 football victory over South Carolina today.

AN exhibition of photographs appropraite for Christmas giving will open next Sunday afternoon at A Photographer's Gallery, 48 West Eighty-fourth Street, with a reception from 2 to 6 P. M. which most of the photographers represented will attend.

A group of twenty-seven newspaper circulation executives from eighteen states will discuss sales and distribution problems this week at the American Press Institute, Columbia University. The institute's fourth circulation seminar in its ten years of operation will open this evening and continue through Friday.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- According to British Government officials, Group Capt. Peter Townsend is expected to resume his post as air attache in Brussels Nov. 7. That day will mark the end of his twenty-six-day leave.

AUTUMN'S early frosts have cleared the air and swept the color from the fields and in the Midwest the harvest is ended. This should be a time when farmers fill their barns, sell their fattened livestock, and sit back quietly to wait out the winter.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Outgunned for three quarters, Arkansas staged a 79-yard drive in the last five minutes to tie the favored Texas Aggies, 7 -- 7, before a homecoming crowd of 27,000 today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Weather-hardened Minnesota reveled in a swirling snowstorm today to beat heavily favored Southern California, 25 -- 19, behind the sledgehammer blows of a sophomore fullback, Dick Borstad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Twenty-two young women will be presented by their parents at the annual Washington Debutante Ball to be held on Dec. 19 in the ballroom of the Mayflower Hotel. In advance of the ball, there will be a dinner at the hotel for the debutantes, their parents and escorts.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Mike Sommer and Len Ciemniecki, George Washington University halfback, ruined Virginia Tech's homecoming today by leading the Colonials to a 13 -- 7 Southern Conference victory before a crowd of 10,000.

A NEW line of German 8mm movie cameras was introduced here last week by Intercontinental Marketing Corporation, 251 Fourth Avenue, the importers. The cameras are made by the Bauer Camera Works in Stuttgart, Germany, manufacturers of professional 35mm and 16mm motion picture equipment for half a century.

A young New York City family returned yesterday from a two-day visit to a Vermont farm. It was the first time they had ever been on a farm, but they enjoyed it so much that they would like to move up there for good.

VISION BOOKS is a new series of lives of saints, martyrs and heroes addressed to young Roman Catholic readers. The first volumes fulfill the basic purpose of biography in that they are accurate and sufficiently factual for readers in the upper elementary grades and junior high school.

IN retrospect, the Conference at Geneva in July of President Eisenhower, Premier Bulganin, Prime Minister Eden and Premier Faure was an international Mardi gras -- a sunny week in which national positions were stated with the utmost delicacy with many a hint that adjustment might be easy.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 29 -- Supporters of the Tennessee Valley Authority soon will begin a nation-wide campaign to obtain United States Senate approval for a serf-financing plan under which T. V. A. could expand its generating capacity.

THIS highly diverting treatise is dedicated "to all true pipe smokers." It is the result, says the author, Georges Herment, a Frenchman, of twenty years of meditation. Mr. Herment himself is a dedicated man, a true, perhaps a born, pipe smoker: calm, methodical, philosophic, mingling ironic humor with serious observations.

President Eisenhower, in a letter made public last week, thanked the children of the arts and crafts department of Jewish Memorial Hospital's out-patient department for a "get well" message on a copper plaque. The hospital is at Broadway and 196th Street.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its long-lines employes continued negotiations yesterday although their contract had expired Friday at midnight.
Visions of Russian-style Fuller Brush men and ruble-down, ruble-a-week plans are being conjured by preparations for a visit to Moscow by a team of American sales executives.
One-man shows, a number of them by well-known European and American artists, dominate this week's list of attractions in New York Galleries.

EXPERIENCED American observers of the world philatelic scene are unwilling to regard seriously the recent suggestion by Edouard Bonnefous, France's Communications Minister, that the nations of Europe "issue a series of European stamps" as part of his proposed plan "for dovetailing national postal services.
About 140,000 men will move into bivouacs in Louisiana pine forests this week as the Army and Air Force open their largest joint maneuver since World War II.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Striking for two touchdowns in the first quarter, Penn State subjected Pennsylvania to its fifteenth straight football setback today. The Nittany Lions ground out a 20-to-0 triumph before 28,206 onlookers at Franklin Field.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Oct. 29 (UP) -- The Saar's pro-French Legislature today scheduled new elections for Dec. 18 in this disputed border area, and appointed Heinrich Welsch to govern the Saar until then.

FOR one week-end out of the year, a heady sort of frontier adventurousness enlivens the atmosphere of this pleasant little Black Forest town. For thirty-six brave, intense hours, the eyes and ears of Europe's more thoughtful musicians and critics are directed here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The trustees of American University decided today to drop Prof. Herbert Fuchs, an admitted former Communist, from the school's law faculty.

URSULA HOPKINS puts her man of honor between two loves as flamboyantly unlike as possible, and lets the comparison between them tell its own highly tinted story. Jan Hegan, British newspaper man, has the sort of compassionate sensitive mind which is bound to steer him toward vicarious suffering.
Halloween festivities got off to a two-day head start yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The Saar referendum, in which the voters rejected on Sunday a proposed "European" statute for the territory, threw a scare into some people both before and after it took place.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Wesleyan swept to a 26-7 football victory over Swarthmore today on Andrus Field.

WHEN modern city dwellers go down to the sea in bathing suits they see few sea creatures except gulls and Jellyfish. The clean, wave-pounded sand of bathing beaches is comparatively barren. Yet even such beaches have life, and readers of Rachel Carson's "The Edge of the Sea" will learn how to find their blue-eyed sand fleas, each walled in its tunnel waiting for the night.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 -- Leaders of the nation's largest Indian tribe, the Navajos, have rebuked sharply four of the principal national organizations dedicated to the "defense" of the American Indian.

DALLAS, Oct. 29 (UP) -- An aroused band of University of Texas ballhawks turned three Southern Methodist fumbles into springboards for touchdowns today and rode to a 19-18 upset football victory. A conversion by Joe Youngblood provided the winning margin.
Being a woman almost disqualifies me from commenting on John McNulty's definitive essay on what a perfect bar is not -- ("Search for the Perfect Bar" -- Oct. 18 ).
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 27 -- In few satellite countries has realization of the usual Communist policy of rapid industrialization presented more difficulties than in Hungary.
The writer's directorial credits include such fine Italian films as "The Bicycle Thief ," "Shoeshine" and "Miracle in Milan." "Umberto D" opens Nov. 7 at the Guild.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 29 -- The United States' most ambitious expedition to Antarctica, the world's least known continent, gets under way tomorrow.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 29 -- The Navy-Notre Dame game today was dedicated to Knute Rockne and the mention of Rock's name on this campus automatically causes a cathedral-like hush and reverent baring of heads It's probable that no football coach in history ever left a more profound mark on an institution of higher learning than Rock left on Notre Dame.

A NEW life of Longfellow was long overdue, and for that reason it is the more gratifying to report that Edward Wagenknecht, who has previously written biographies of Dickens and Mark Twain, has done an excellent job.

EVERYONE is growing African violets, at least so it seems. While the statement may be exaggerated in the literal sense, it will remain unchallenged, it is certain, among the indoor gardeners, who have become so fond of them.

How to interest more high school students in mathematics as a stepping stone to careers in science and engineering has been the subject of intensive study by thirty-two high school teachers of six Western states who spent two weeks at San Jose State College, California.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Pass-minded Purdue turned to a ground attack in soggy going today and made two touchdowns on short plunges to down Illinois, 13 -- 0, before 61,262 homecoming fans.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (UP) -- A safety proved the margin today as Villanova broke through the pain of five straight defeats for a 16-14 triumph over Richmond.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 29 -- Adlai E. Stevenson accused the Eisenhower Administration today of deliberately creating an illusion that all was well with this nation, both in its affairs abroad and at home.

The annual fall blending of sport and society will occupy Madison Square Garden this week and part of next. The medium will be the sixty-seventh National Horse Show, which will open Tuesday and run for eight days through Nov. 8.
TIFLIS, U. S. S. R., Oct. 14 -- The supermarket, Soviet style, has come to this ancient capital and it's a hit.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Aeschylus, a 3-year-old gelding owned by Douglas R. Small of Monkton, Md., set a course record of 1:47 1/5 for a mile and a furlong in the $25.150 Laurel Turf Cup today.

I find it difficult to understand your critic's appraisal of "Trial." Usually in agreement with the general trend, if not always the specific detail, of his reviews, I am at a loss to agree with anything he has to say about this fine, sharp picture save one matter: that the answers the Mexican boy gives to the Communist lawyer "would not seem to incriminate him."
GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- More than 600 additional civilian employes will be hired by Sampson Air Force Base here in the next eight months.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- The United Nations General Assembly, nearing the half-way mark of its current session, still faces perhaps the heaviest part of its task.

Many prominent patrons are supporting the benefit performance of Enid Bagnold's "The Chalk Garden" at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre the evening of Nov. 15. Gladys Cooper is starring in the play, which will aid the work of the Homemaker Service Committee of the Children's Aid Society.

WESTFIELD, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- A vast motorcade of passenger and sports cars, trucks, buses and firefighting equipment is scheduled to start here Thursday over State Route 17 to Triborugh Stadium in New York.

THE Fund for the Republic, which conducted a television script-writing contest earlier this year, placed its initial prize-wining script last week for use on the "United States Steel Hour." The significance of the sale was this: A commercial sponsor had accepted a script from a contest that was limited to plays about civil liberties and racial and religious discrimination.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Back in 1934 a farmer borrowed $125 from the Government to buy seed. He did not repay the loan.
GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, warned Vyacheslav M. Molotov today that the flow of Soviet arms to Egypt was a serious threat to peace in the Middle East.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 29 -- County, city and school administrators in this gambling resort are struggling with the worst governmental budget problems in recent years. This has resulted from a rapid population growth and an archaic tax assessment system.

The new, 10,500-gross-ton liner Israel will be equipped with Denny-Brown stabilizers -- vanes similar to airplane wings that are extended from a ship's side below the waterline to control rolling in heavy seas.
I agreed with practically everything Professor Morrison had to say, but I thought that he might have stressed a sense of humor as desirable equipment for the teacher more than he did.

Traders apparently were more anxious to cash in on profits last week than to extend market commitments. The week's extraordinarily large flow of favorable earnings and dividend announcements had been anticipated, it would seem.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Country living generally means relaxed living, much privacy and freedom of movement.
Two critics of the Fund for the Republic's "Bibliography of the Communist Program in the United States" were in turn criticized yesterday as "irresponsible."

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The prospect of early general elections has fired a new controversy around one of the most vital and complicated features of the French political system -- the electoral law. The controversy runs to the basis of French politics and it figured importantly in the confidence vote which narrowly sustained the Faure Government on Friday.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Intermittent deliberations for twenty-four hours by a French parliamentary committee on the subject of electoral reform left the status of that vital question today more confused than before.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Oklahoma mowed down Kansas State, 40 -- 7, today for its twenty-fifth straight victory and another stride toward the Sooners' eighth straight Big Seven Conference title.

SAIGON, Oct. 29 -- When Ngo Dinh Diem arrived here from Europe in the summer of 1954 to assume the Premiership of Vietnam few thought he had much chance to succeed. There was a fairly general belief, in fact, that he had been picked as the "fall guy" in a situation going from bad to worse.

THIS is the sixth of Mr. Lewis' stories about the mythological land of Narnia. When the fifth appeared, I suggested that this field should lie fallow a while; it seemed to me that Mr. Lewis was working it thin.
HARTFORD, Oct. 29 -- The two major political parties, one openly and the other behind the scenes, have thrown their forces into the local nonpartisan election campaign.

FOR four of the past five years, the exodus from this tiny island to the State has been increasing. Of 650,000 Puerto Rican Americans on the mainland today, some 500,000 have made their homes in New York City. Last year, the migration slowed down somewhat, reflecting the drop in employment opportunities on the mainland, which apparently made the overseas pastures seem less green.
Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended Oct. 21 was the lowest for my five-day week this year. Last week's volume wasn't much better.

In his journey back to health and a full-time job, the President logged a good many steps and several hours last week. Cabinet members and personal advisers continued to fly out to Denver to lay before the President ideas for the State of the Union message, and the President began to rough in the outlines of the speech. This was the diary of the week:

It is common knowledge that if the commercial supersonic plane of the future is to be a success the heat barrier must be crossed. This means that skin friction goes up with the speed, and skin friction generates heat.

THESE two books tell us a true story that is stranger by far than anything a fiction writer would dare try to make us believe. The first book, "K: Krebiozen -- Key to Cancer?" is written by a Chicago newspaper man.

TOO many people think that cacti are only at home in the desert. But the truth of the matter is that they can be perfectly beautiful and flourish indoors, even bloom, if they are given the proper care and atmosphere.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 29 -- In simple sidewalk ceremonies on what is now a busy local street, Utahans last week marked an anniversary of the completion of the first transcontinental telegraph line. They dedicated a modest granite monument and bronze plaque to the event.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Cigarette smoking has been indicted again by two British medical researchers as one of the most likely causes of cancer of the throat and lungs. More evidence has been obtained that something, probably the chemical, benzpyrene, in the smoky air of towns accounts for an increase in the cancer rate.
Millions of Americans will be dunned by youthful Halloween extortionists tomorrow night to provide a "treat" for needy children in other lands.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- The check-writing pace in the Mid-west spurted sharply in September, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago reported. The total of $1,092,519,000 for the daily average, compared with the same month last year, rose 16.6 per cent, while a rise of 7 per cent was recorded compared with August.
Several distinguished private art collections will be opened to the public on the afternoon of Dec. 3 for the benefit of the Radcliffe College Scholarship Fund of New York.

THREE of the newly opened exhibitions, quite separate in purpose, are pertinently related by coincidence. One is the big retrospective display of sculpture by Brancusi, a controversial figure in the art world since the early years of the century.

At last week's meeting of the American Heart Association in New Orleans, La., Drs. Richard J. Jones, Oscar K. Reiss and Eugene L. Balter of the University of Chicago, came forth with the announcement that an extract of powdered animal brains lowers the deposition of blood cholesterol, a complex compound which probably causes hardening of the arteries.

With the alarming reports of raids and counter-raids and the multiplicity of charges and countercharges, it is easy to see why the present Israeli-Arab conflict should be regarded as one of the world's most dangerous powder kegs. The massing of forces on national borders is always the signal for apprehension, and it should be.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 26 -- The Mennonite religious sect in Mexico, which has been under criticism from nationalist elements virtually ever since its advent here in 1921, is again facing something of a crisis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- In the competition with the Communists for the loyalties of the peoples of the Far East, the free world is holding its own, but no more, according to reports reaching Western diplomatic missions here.

Earl W. Smith, president of the National Association of Home Builders, advocated yesterday the rescinding of restrictions placed on home buying last July. This should be done, he said, to prevent a slump in the building industry.

AFTER frost has killed flowers and plants in the garden, house plants take on new significance. This is the time when they instead of bouquets, are used to decorate the home. Therefore, a few rules of maintenance are necessary to keep house plants growing and looking their best.

THE Noel Coward-Mary Martin spectacular for two was a television event of more than passing moment for several reasons. First and foremost, of course, in its brightest moments it was entrancing entertainment, something at long last decidedly different on the home screen.

THIS collection of thirty-one essays marks the twentieth anniversary of the wedding between the seat of Mr. De Voto's pants and the Easy Chair of Harper's magazine. It is an occasion for general rejoicing and a few judicious huzzas.
TELEVISION came up with a giant-quiz type of poser for New York's City Hall last week and the municipality took a long, deep breath to find the answer.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Japan's shipbuilding industry, virtually wiped out by United States bombs in World War II, is enjoying a spectacular boom. Orders on hand are enough to keep all the yards busy for the next two years. They place Japan third -- after the United Kingdom and West Germany -- in construction of vessels for export.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Senator Lehman called the proposal to test the Senate reservation "untimely, unwise and unsound."

IN his review of my book "The Fifteen Weeks," James Reston says among other things: (1) that I "obviously" have not had access to anything like the range of documents necessary to record the full story; (2) that I tell "nothing about the months before the Fifteen Weeks"; that I have only "bits and pieces of Vandenberg's role"; and finally that I distort the history of 1945 to 1955.

GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- As this is the season for football metaphors it can be reported from Geneva that the Soviet Union's diplomatic backfield is still bucking the line, driving straight down the field as before.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 29 -- Jim Maddock, the Wolverine quarterback, fired touchdown passes to his ends, Ron Kramer and Tom Maentz, in the final nine minutes today to lead Michigan to a 33-21 victory over Iowa in a nationally televised Big Ten battle before 72,096 at Michigan Stadium.

IT it frustrating to attempt to argue with or criticize a professional critic, for more often than not he will complacently retreat behind his very special Fifth Amendment which proclaims that everyone is entitled to his own opinion Still, I cannot refrain from calling Bosley Crowther to task for his thoroughly astounding and no less disturbing appraisal of the Music Hall's current screen attraction, "Trial."

AS a recent liberal arts graduate, I should like to applaud Donald H. Morrison's thesis in "The Test of a Good College Teacher" (Oct. 16). It is true, as he says, that the good teacher is the creative thinker who can listen to all ideas, patiently, with an open mind; who questions currently prevailing hypotheses and who likewise encourages his students to question them; and who inspires in his students the quest for self-education.

IN English there is no equivalent to the institution of the Comedie Francaise. It has been continuously in existence as an acting company since 1680. Moliere died in 1673. Seven years later Louis XIV officially founded the Comedie Francaise by uniting a rival troupe of actors with the company that Moliere had led.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 -- The coming year will be an auspicious one in which to concentrate on influencing Congress to pass legislation to help the aged, Albert J. Abrams told the Gerontological Society today.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the sixth annual Fan Ball for the benefit of the Children's Cancer Fund of America, Inc., formerly known as the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund. It will be held on Nov. 18 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 29 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem, South Vietnam's new Chief of State, reappointed his former Cabinet today to carry out the mission of formulating a republican constitution and establishing an elected National Assembly before the end of this year.
The opening of a new ship lane to the principal travel centers of Spain and other European countries was announced last week by John E. Slater, president of the American Export Lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Plans for a series of hearings on proposed legislation to provide Federal insurance against losses resulting from floods and other disasters were announced today by the Senate Banking Committee.
HELSINSKI, Finland, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet Union is trying to gain a television monopoly in Finland.
DENVER, Oct. 29 -- President Eisenhower gave his complete endorsement today to the farm program of Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture.

A 3 1/2-year-old red Pekingese, Chungking Tino, here from England about six months, became best in show yesterday in the thirty-fourth event of the Bronx County Kennel Club. The dog was from the Seafren Kennels of Devon, Pa.
The excitement of discovery filled Carnegie Hall yesterday morning as the Philharmonic-Symphony opened its season of Young People's Concerts under the direction of Wilfred Pelletier.
DENVER, Oct. 29 -- None of the nine official visitors President Eisenhower has seen since Oct. 8 has failed to give a glowing account of his physical appearance.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Don Holleder may not be the most polished quarterback in the land but he was a completely devastating performer today. Running for one touch down, passing for three and otherwise distinguishing himself, the rangy first classman from Webster, N. Y., paced Army's resurgent football forces to a decisive 27-7 victory over a good Colgate team.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Seasonal factors together with mounting production have accounted for goodly gains in the employment and weekly earnings in this metropolitan area. The Pennsylvania State Employment Service estimated employment at 1,650,700 as of mid-September, an increase of nearly 22,000 over July.
American ship operators like the quality of the officer graduates produced by the country's five maritime training schools. They also believe that the schools should be continued without curtailment.
Georgian furniture and decorations that include old English and Continental porcelains will be auctioned on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke- Bernet Galleries.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Lehigh did all of its scoring in the first three periods today as it defeated Temple, 27 -- 14, at Taylor Stadium. The victory was Lehigh's fifth in row after an opening game loss to Cornell.
Governor Harriman refused yesterday to let the State Power Authority challenge the validity f a Senate reservation to a treaty governing development of Niagara hydroelectric power.

THE recognized increase in the number of youngsters in our society who are emotionally disturbed and who manifest their disturbance in various manners, including delinquency and crime, offers a strong temptation to film makers to move in on that theme.
THE National Association of Travel Organizations will present several Awards of Merit for advertising and promotion work at its annual convention opening tomorrow in Chicago.

RECENT severe floods in the Northeast have spotlighted a problem that is bad enough in normal seasons -- the wet basement. In today's modern home, a dry basement is an absolute necessity not only to protect the automatic washer, ironer, power tools and other valuable equipment normally stored there but also to provide the family with a safe and healthy house.
PERRY COMO, an easy-going man who is accustomed to getting along nicely with just about everyone he knows, finds himself a central figure in a major television conflict these days.

DALLAS, Oct. 29 -- Southwestern business during September continued to gain over last year, the University of Texas Bureau of Business Research reported this week. Business in Texas was 8 per cent better than in the same month last year, and in Dallas the gain was 12 per cent.

Marybeth Weinstein's article about the falcon -- "A Falcon Flies for the Air Force" (Oct. 9) -- was so informative as to be, indeed, a rarity. Her descriptions of the various falcons, what they look like, what they do, were indeed accurate.

TOWARD the end of 1955 I find myself on two committees, each one to honor the 100th anniversary of the birth of an outstanding American. The two Americans are Eugene V. Debs, born in 1855, and Woodrow Wilson, born in 1856. They died with no love at all for each other. The crossing of their paths is part of our American history.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Eisenhower this week approved a new approach to an old paradox -- the existence of chronically depressed industrial areas in the midst of general prosperity.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 29 -- A 15-yard field goal by Jim Soltesz gave Gettysburg College a 15-14 victory over Lafayette College today.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 29 -- About 90 per cent of the country's teachers colleges are reporting enrollments of 5 to 54 per cent more than that of last year.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 29 -- Dr. George Baehr turned the first spade of earth and was the principal speaker today at ground-breaking ceremonies for the new Hempstead Medical Group center at 226 Clinton Street.
CAIRO, Oct. 29 -- Egypt has informed Britain of her approval of the principle of a plebiscite in the Sudan to choose between full independence or link with Egypt, a Government spokesman said tonight.
Although China, India, Japan and the other Far Eastern lands are of growing importance to this country, the Asian nations remain an enigma to most Americans
Lingerie and accessory business is picking up in anticipation of excellent Christmas sales, resident buying offices reported yesterday.
TAMPA -- A Florida citizen and a Florida orange have this in common in California: there are very few of them.
Last week more than 2,000 business men, scientists and Government officials got together at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to talk about "Atomic Energy in Industry."
BERN, Switzerland, Oct. 20 -- Keeping them down, or rather up, on the farm has become a tough problem for the Swiss.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Tulane cashed in on the magic ball handling of Quarterback Gene Newton, fumbles and pass interceptions today to upset Auburn, 27-13, before 35,000 fans.

THE last ten years have witnessed an important reappraisal of Civil War and Reconstruction history. This process, which is doubtless a reflection of the strong trend toward conservatism in recent American thought, has attempted, with partial success, to recast certain concepts concerning the troubled years between 1860 and 1877.
GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- Secretary of State Dulles accused the Soviet Union today of flouting the orders of the heads of government on German reunification and European security.

THE illness of President Eisenhower has brought the Democrats out of the political shadows. Just a few short weeks ago they had trouble getting on the front pages; they were not prominent in policy-making or even on the embassy dinner circuit, and their books were treated as historical documents or as political philosophy without much news value.
One hundred years ago, come Tuesday, one of the nation's most famous contraptions began a curious transformation into a chore for generations of American schoolboys.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Miami's Hurricanes struck twice within two minutes for touch-downs in the first period and got a third tally in the last eighteen seconds today to defeat Pittsburgh's Panthers, 21 -- 7, in an intermittent hut driving rain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- As the Democrats shape their strategy for the coming campaign, they are faced with an unusual dilemma.
RICHMOND. Va., Oct. 29 -- A financial crusade by graduates to help the nation's private colleges was urged here today by G. Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange.
An Iowa City, Iowa, woman filed suit seeking to collect $1,196 from a local man, asserting that she had done his laundry every week since 1924 and never been paid.

FLOWER arrangements, like current fashions and interior decorations, can be created to reflect the latest vogue, as well as to make use of cut flowers in season. Today's mode dictates a heavy accent on all things Oriental.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 29 -- Holy Cross ran head-on into its old jinx, Syracuse, before a sellout homecoming crowd of 24,000 at Fitton Field this sunny afternoon.

" Six months is better than two years" was the note of agreement on which twenty-one youths left the city yesterday for half a year of active Army duty at Fort Knox, Ky. The group was the second to depart this month under the new training program for youths between 17 and 18 1/2 years.

The 1955-56 dramatic season has only recently begun but has already provided us with two of the most memorable characters of the modern theatre. I am referring to Anne Frank from "The Diary of . . ." and Hector of Troy from "Tiger at the Gates."
TRENTON, Oct. 29 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad and the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Lines were authorized today to increase commutation fares on four of their routes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- The Labor Department estimated today that almost half the aircraft industry was suffering from a shortage of engineers, highly skilled production workers and managerial personnel.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 29 (AP) -- A Tufts halfback, Dave Wells, dashed 98 yards with the opening kick-off and scored twice more in the first six minutes today as the Jumbos walloped Amherst, 46 -- 26. Tufts scored 33 points in the first quarter.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 29 -- The proud record and fond hopes of a Navy football team crumbled once again today against Notre Dame. Before a record gathering of 59,475 spectators, Terry Brennan's Fighting Irish overpowered the midshipmen for Notre Dame's tenth successive triumph in this oldest continuous intersectional rivalry.

THE profit picture looks good for those who confine their reading to corporation reports. Third-quarter earnings are showing the same lusty increases as those in the first half of the year, and predictions generally are that earnings for the fourth quarter will continue high.
SARASOTA, Fla., Oct. 29 -- The opening of the $500,000 Circus Hall of Fame is set for Dec. 15, John L. Sullivan, supervisor, has announced.
LOS ANGELES -- Connoisseurs of old beer cans, and fanciers of landscapes dotted with paper bags and sandwich wrappings are finding increasingly slim pickings on California's highways these days.
I HAVE always loved musical comedies and revues; they are the last stand of glamour in a bedeviled world. I know that they have now become important, significant and profound, but I still like them.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 -- Fullback Bob Ford scored three touchdowns today as Bucknell gained a 26-26 tie with Harvard before 9,000 fans.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- Formal retirement ceremonies honoring Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, deputy commanding general of the Sixth Army, will be held here Monday at the Presidio.

ANYONE who thinks that lion tamers went out with the handle-bar mustache should get acquainted with Alfred Court. His profession was not merely a matter of handling lions with whip, pistol and chair. He was an artist, a designer of dangerously graceful and breathtakingly improbable acts.

Committees have been meeting at Carlton House to carry out plans for a theatre party on Dec. 8 for the benefit of the Manhattan School of Music. The play chosen is "The Matchmaker" by Thornton Wilder, starring Ruth Gordon at the Royale Theatre.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The bones of a baby dinosaur are now being reconstructed at the Natural History Museum here. It is a creature known as a Scelidosaurus and was one of the fore-runners of the fearful and fantastic prehistoric reptiles that flourished 100 to 150 million years ago in the Mesozoic or Middle Age of animal evolution.

ALL sorts of activity will buzz this week. Chrysanthemums will reign at flower shows, horticultural ideas will be aired at several short courses and two colleges will open campus horticultural exhibits.

LONDON, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- Manchester United gained a one-point lead in the first division of English League soccer by defeating Cardiff City, 1 -- 0, today. ter on points but the leader on goal average last week, was held to a 0-0 draw by Everton.

THE discovery that his adoptive Uncle Dill had been a puppet master and owned a whole trunkful of marionettes opened a new world to 12-year-old Gilliam Paris. Gilly's enthusiasm inspired Uncle Dill to carve his hundredth puppet, boy-size, and shortly thereafter Gilly brought home Johnny, a forlorn young acrobat who was the amazing counterpart of the marionette.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Clean up is in order. Cut down peony plants and burn the stalks. Cut down yellowing top growth of other perennials and add to compost pile, if healthy. Headed for the same place are frostbitten annuals and exhausted vegetable plants. Remove stalks, clean and dry before storing.

The American Friends of the Middle East, Inc., stated last week that certain views of the organization's executive vice president, Garland Evans Hopkins, had been inaccurately reported in The New York Times of Oct. 20.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Post-war prosperity has done little to cut the number of low-income families. On the other hand, the proportion of families with higher levels of income has risen.

GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- The worsening weather that signaled the end of Europe's warm and fruitful summer and fall mirrored the changing atmosphere of the opening sessions of the Foreign Ministers' conference. At first the weather was sunny, warmly reflecting July when the heads of government met here.
Two of five men charged with the theft of $185,000 in mink furs were held without bail in Felonly Court yesterday. Magistrate Neal P. Bottliglieri set a hearing for all five defendants for tomorrow.
HONG KONG, Oct. 23 -- In the United States it used to be: "Go West, young man, and grow up with the country."
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the Bloomington poet, was riding down Michigan Boulevard with a lady Democrat the other day when a citizen shouted from another car, "Hello, Adlai."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- The drafting of a code of ethics for producers of television films was initiated last night at a meeting of the National Society of Television Producers and the National Audience Board.

The theatre benefit committee of Greenwich House reports an encouraging subscription for the Nov. 2 evening performance of "A View From the Bridge." Five hundred orchestra seats have been taken by the settlement at the Coronet Theatre for the Arthur Miller play.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The United States has $123,900,000,000 tied up in armed forces properties and goods.

THERE are two approaches to learning flower arrangement. One is to collect the necessary materials and begin, and the other is first to consider underlying esthetic principles and accepted techniques.

STATE development of more ski centers like that at White Face Mountain, the state reservation in the Adirondack Mountains, was the keynote of the tenth annual Winter Sports Forum at Turin, New York State, last week-end.

TENS of thousands of tourists must have visited Mikimoto's pearl farm at Toba, in Japan. Some of them got to see the Pearl King himself, with his heavy, dark kimono, his tall staff, a gift of the Dowager Empress and the bowler hat that was his trademark.

More than 125 Great Books discussion groups will operate in the metropolitan area this year. The groups will meet for two hours twice a month to discuss books on the list of the Great Books Foundation. The foundation is a non-profit corporation designed to promote adult liberal education through reading and group discussion of selected writings.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- The elevated tracks of the Sixty-ninth Street-Frankford elevated-subway lines were closed above Market Street today from Twenty-second to Forty-sixth Street. They will never reopen, open.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board Monthly Bulletin reports that net profits of member banks fell $75,000,000 or about 13 per cent, in the first half of this year.

The Emmett Till case in Mississippi is "a grim reminder" that the American Negro was not automatically emancipated by the Supreme Court decision on segregation in the schools, Rabbi Edward E. Klein said yesterday.
No matter what the Giant and Redskin punters do in the football game at the Polo Grounds today, the Hempstead (L. I.) High School band show at half-time is sure to provide the most kicks.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Economics Minister Ludwig Erhard warned the Ruhr steel industry today that anti-inflation measures would be imposed if steelworkers' demands for higher wages were granted.

AMERICAN manufacturers may have been late starters in the jet and turboprop airliner competitions, but recent astronomical sales figures demonstrate that, when the turbine era matures in the Nineteen Sixties, American-made planes almost certainly will retain their commanding position on the world's airways.

WHAT will the five-day week mean to motion-picture companies in production costs? No studio executive has figured out the answer yet, and most are of the opinion that they won't begin to get a clear statistical picture until about three months after the six-day work week is abandoned on Jan. 30.

ON page 1 the reader will have seen The Book view's version of the double-play: an appraisal of MacKinlay Kantor's "Andersonville," and a kind of miniature confession of the author's love affair with the ghosts of that forlorn place.

CLEMSON, S. C., Oct. 29 (UP) -- A fast backfield led by Billy O'Dell, Joe Pagliei and Joel Wells carried Clemson to a 19-13 victory over tricky Wake Forest today in an Atlantic Coast Conference game before 20,000 fans.

NO doubt ten times as many people play rubber bridge as play duplicate bridge, but that does not necessarily mean rubber bridge is played ten times as often. The true addict is usually a duplicate player, and he may play several times as often as the average rubber-bridge player.

If daylight saving had not ended, or been scheduled to end, at 2 A. M. this morning, and if a given baby were to be born at one minute after midnight tonight by the clock as the clock was yesterday, then each such baby's date of birth would be Oct. 31 rather than Oct. 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Republican National Committee plans to sign contracts soon with the major radio and television networks for $2,000,000 in campaign broadcast time.

IT is now ten years since Ellen Glasgow's death. In common with greater and lesser writers she has already been subject to the ordinary vicissitudes of literary reputation. One observes, for example, Mr. Alfred Kazin, in his current collection of essays, "The Inmost Leaf," conspicuously retreating from his earlier estimate of her work.

EDUCATION by television is getting to be a regular habit for Los Angeles video viewers. "Spotlight on Opera," the seventh college credit course to be televised by KNXT-TV, the Columbia Broadcasting System outlet, will be seen next Saturday for the first time on a local telecast.

GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- The United Nations' highest administrative tribunal ordered the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today to reinstate four Americans discharged for failure to cooperate with United States loyalty board investigations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The new phase in relations with the Soviet Union is causing State Department officials to consider increasing United States Embassy facilities in Moscow.
Dr. Jonas Salk, developer of the anti-polio vaccine, and three other City College alumni have been named to receive the college's 1955 Townsend Harris Medals, it was announced yesterday.
DENVER, Oct. 29 -- The White House has successfully weathered the first political crisis growing out of President Eisenhower's illness.

IN Karinska's purposefully cluttered theatrical costume shop on West Forty-fourth Street, Martial Singher was being fitted for the four costumes he will wear in the Metropolitan's opening night production of "Le Contes d'Hoffmann."
CHICAGO. Oct. 29 -- Substantial increases in traffic fines here were approved late this week by Municipal Court judges in a move to reduce violations by motorists.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 29 -- The plumpest purse in the history of horse racing was won today by Elmendorf Farm's Prince John. He collected first money of $157,918.50 in the world's richest cavalry charge -- the $282,370 Garden State Stakes.
