GOOD food like good company is a requisite for a successful party. And good food means a well-balanced menu in which each dish complements and enhances the others.

INHERENT in everyone is a strong desire to be surrounded by stately trees, green carpets of lawn, graceful shrubs and colorful flowers. While the full beauty and tranquility of a garden cannot be duplicated in the home or office, it is possible, by means of living green plants, to capture for the indoors a measure of nature's charms.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Needing a perfect performance to win, Lieut. Patrick J. Kiernan produced it to give the Irish Army the final international jumping victory of the 1955 Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
Mayor Wagner's executive order directing city department heads to aid a commercial producer of television films was denounced yesterday as a breach of public trust.

PRETORIA, South Africa. ONCE a year, this South African administrative capital, thirty-six miles south of Johannesburg, is the scene of one of the strangest conventions in the world -- the meeting of the African Dingaka Association, the organization of South Africa's witch doctors.

High school drop-outs can be greatly reduced, an Oregon State College study, made public last week, points out. It is necessary, said the study, for teachers, parents and public to pay more attention to the needs of problem students.

The annual card party for the benefit of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service be held tomorrow afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club. Mrs. Bedell Holmes Harned is president of the beneficiary.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 29 -- At the request of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's ailing Chancellor, the annual convention of the Christian Democratic Union, of which he is the leader, was postponed today until early next year.

SHOW trains, the latest fad in long-distance theatre-going, are bringing so many thousands of persons to New York from inland cities to attend Broadway hits, showmen are asking themselves why no one thought of this long ago. Well, someone did.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Air Force officials said this week the hiring of additional civilians at Sampson was part of Operation Home Front.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California said today that President Eisenhower would veto any measure to restore rigid farm price supports.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 29 -- Princeton remained in front in the Ivy League race after beating Brown, 14 to 7, today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Grimfaced and curt, Adlai E. Stevenson brushed aside political questions today, after a forty-five minute private conversation with Harry S. Truman.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Freddy Wyant, West Virginia's quarterback, sparked the Mountaineers to their sixth straight victory of the football season today with a 39-0 rout of Marquette University.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 24 -- The third balsa raft expedition to depart from Peruvian shores in modern times for the South Seas is expected to get under way next Sunday or Monday. The raft, La Cantuta, will be towed out from the northern port of Talara some 15 to 18 miles until it reaches the Humboldt Current.
TROY, N. Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- A medical researcher predicted today that advances in treatment and drugs would make a life expectancy of 100 "a distinct possibility by the end of the century."

Marking its thirtieth year of aid to needy musicians, the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation has announced plans for the 1955 Bagby Concert. It will be given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria the afternoon of Dec. 2.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Mississippi used the pinpoint passing of Quarterback Eagle Day and the kicking of Halfback Paige Cothren to by-pass a stubborn Louisiana State University line tonight for a 29-26 football victory.

The Patent Office has been running behind for years, so that its backlog is disturbing the Commissioner of Patents as well as patent attorneys. The office now has an appropriation which enables it to expedite its processes -- provided it can find qualified examiners of applications for patents and the specifications that accompany them.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The royal romance between Princess Margaret and Group Capt. Peter Townsend has now reached the stage where grave, far-reaching issues of State, Church and Commonwealth policy alike threaten its very existence.

October changes in the woodland are even more amazing, once you analyze them, than those that come in May. A month ago they were green woods, tired and a little dusty and varied in tone, but definitely green. Then the first flashes of gold and crimson appeared, on a lone limb, over a single tree.
During the past two decades Elizabeth Corbett has had published well over thirty novels -- proof enough of the popularity she well deserves.

The President's recent heart attack has quite naturally emphasized the seriousness of this most common of the important illnesses of the middle-aged and older male in the United States of America today.

The Radical Socialist party represents a wide segment of the French electorate ranging from the moderate left to the moderate right. For its first forty years, up to World War II, it dominated the French political scene. Though it came out of the war weakened in numbers, its prestige continues high.

A year ago last week this newspaper, commenting on the latest Russian offer to the Big Three powers, said there was "nothing new in the Soviet note, nothing that a thoughtful student of previous Soviet notes could not have written out of memory."

DISCOMFORT in hunting attire was dictated by necessity and tradition when Grandpa was a young man, as the prints by Mr. Currier and Mr. Ives so clearly indicate. But today there is no excuse for such discomfort.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 (AP) -- L. G. Dupre joined his rookie teammate, Alan Ameche, to spark the Baltimore Colts to a third-period touchdown tonight for a 14-10 victory over the Green Bay Packers. The victory earned undisputed second place in the Western Conference of the National Football League for the Colts.

THE statement in my book referring to Sunday's being rated by Dun Bradstreet was prefaced by the words, "According to Rodeheaver," and referred to Rodeheaver's book "Twenty Years With Billy Sunday." In it he cited an article in The Tulsa Tribune as source for the statement of Sunday's rating.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- "Great Russian chauvinism" has become the increasingly frequent target for Soviet commentators bent on presenting the Soviet Union as the champion of equality among peoples.
The nation's oil producers have accepted the challenge of the steadily rising fuel demands to power this mechanical age.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Princeton University will open its seventeenth annual giving campaign next Tuesday with a goal of $1,000,000.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 29 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry charged today that the Egyptian command had "apparently decided to extend the front."

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 29 -- Life imprisonment is the sentence that the National Investigating Committee has asked the criminal courts to impose on former President Juan Peron. It would have the same sentence imposed on former Vice President Alberto Tesaire and nearly two hundred and fifty former Senators and Deputies who held office during the ten years of the Peron regime.

THE advent of long-playing records happened to coincide with a greatly increased interest in the vast expanse of music that stretches from the early Middle Ages to the end of the eighteenth century. This fortunate combination of circumstances has resulted in many individual disks and a few series of records that represent, more or less successfully, some of the high spots in this enormous and little-known repertory.

IT will be fifty years tomorrow since the convocation ceremonies for a new Institute of Musical Art were held in a building at Fifth avenue and Twelfth Street. The speakers that day were Cornelius C. Cuyler, Frank Damrosch, Felix Adler and Woodrow Wilson, president of Princeton.
The Geneva spirit was put to the test last week, and the first results were not encouraging.

AUSTRIA is providing a shining example of how a nation, even a small one, can use its musical resources to win the interest, respect and attention of the world. And it should be noted that not all the credit should be given to performances of high standard, long-range planning and extensive capital investment.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 29 -- Various forces defeated in the Oct. 3 presidential elections are trying to unite in efforts to set aside that balloting on the ground of fraud. The principal one is the National Democratic Union.

MR. SCHOONOVER'S new novel is not quite up to his "The Spider King." That was outstanding -- this is merely good. But what it loses in intrinsic merit it gains in subject appeal. The tale of the beautiful and able young Isabella of Castile should be more sought after than the story of a bloodless and crafty king.

In your issue of Aug. 24 Kennett Love, writing from Palestine, quoted Professor Nelson Glueck, who credited the Point Four organization with discovering water spreading as an agricultural device whereby water that might have gone down as a gully to some lower place was detained by man, spread over the ground and absorbed for the benefit of the crops.

Broadway, always eager for new young talent, is waiting with interest for the premiere of "A Hatful of Rain." It is the first play by a promising writer, Michael V. Gazzo, and it gives a major opportunity to a new director, Frank Corsaro, who has acquitted himself well off Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Harold E. Stassen, special assistant to President Eisenhower on disarmament, said today that several of the major proposals worked on by his office grew out of letters sent him from many parts of the world.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 29 -- Delaware displayed a well-balanced attack in beating Rutgers, 33 -- 7, today before 7,000 fans. The Blue Hens, sparked by the excellent quarter- backing of Bob Hooper and the running of Halfback Johnny Oberg, triumphed easily after permitting Rutgers to score first.
A New York police sergeant struck out last night on a $100,000 question pitched by Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, but retired with $50,000.

WITH the 1956 cars coming into the market equipped with safety devices ranging from seat belts to crash padding on the dashboard, the effect of the human element on highway accidents is moving more to the fore.

AMONG many hundreds of research projects currently being carried on in this country in an attempt to learn more about children and the way their wheels go around, there's one, we understand, set up to analyze youngsters' emotional reactions to getting the Salk anti-polio vaccine.

Howell E. Jackson's Nasrina came in for a goodly portion of the big money that was distributed among 2-year-old thoroughbreds yesterday. Competing in the $86,700 Frizette Stakes at Jamaica, the Jackson representative took the mile and a six-teenth event by almost two lengths, and with the victory picked up a purse of $55,525.

IT looks like another lively season for the ballet of the Metropolitan Opera. Zachary Solov, ballet director and choreographer, will produce a new work, sponsored by the Metropolitan's National Council, which will share the bill with the revival of Donizetti's opera "Don Pasquale." This will be "Soiree," set to Benjamin Britten's two suites of arrangements of various short pieces by Rossini called "Soirees Musicales" and "Matinees Musicales."

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy shook up the sergeants yesterday. He transferred 189 "old-timers" from precincts where they had worked five to fifteen years to precincts where they were unknown.

Last September Dr. Harry Commoner of Washington University, St. Louis, Mo., rose at the Minneapolis meeting of the American Chemical Society to relate how he and his colleagues, Eddie Basler Jr., Tung-Yue Wang and James A. Lippincott, had torn a virus apart, put the dead parts together again and restored infective activity.
Canada House, first projected here by Canadian Consul General Ray Lawson in May, 1954, will be a twenty-seven-story skyscraper at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- Leaders of the organized birth control movement of the world solicited the United Nations' support today in a universal attack on problems of overpopulation, particularly in the crowded and hungry countries of Asia.
MINOT, N. D., Oct. 29 -- Raw material for a political revolt abounds in the Midwestern farm belt today.

IN no other age but ours would it have been possible for the art-lover to find pleasure in all the kinds of art represented by these four books. What other age could have accepted as art both the hieratic, essentially two-dimensional, other worldly Byzantine and Serbian frescoes and the diametrically opposed dazzling, aerial perspectives of Tiepolo's frescoes, triumphs of illusionism and enchanted materialism?

The Village Voice, a weekly newspaper, made its first appearance last Wednesday when copies of the twelve-page tabloid were distributed throughout the city. Hereafter, on Wednesdays, circulation will be concentrated in Greenwich Village, the Gramercy Park area, Peter Cooper Village, Stuyvesant Town and the lower East Side.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 29 -- Two American political expatriates said today they would return to the United States if they thought they could obtain employment in their professions.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- A team that frittered away chances and a hard-running back who didn't let a good chance go by told a big part of the story today as Cornell's eleven defeated Columbia by 34 to 19.
ONE of the most lavish packages yet to appear on the record market is available from London. It is a four-disk recording of Don Giovanni, with which is packaged a vocal score of the opera.
Ken MacAfee's presence at offensive right end for the first time this season will strengthen the New York Giants for their game with the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds today.
BONN, Oct. 29 -- Standing amid the ruins of the Saar statute, the French and German Governments embraced each other this week and said, in effect, that all problems could be solved between friends.
David Taylor, No. 13 on a New York City police list of thirteen "most wanted criminals," was recognized and arrested on the street last night by an alert patrolman in East Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A "routine" action in 1953 by the retiring Commissioner of Internal Revenue has led to a Congressional demand for an investigation of his plan to join an insurance concern whose tax case is still pending.

LE MANS, France, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Automobile Club de L'Ouest; which organizes the twenty-four hour Le Mans race, has asked insurance companies for a ten-year loan of 250,000,000 francs ($714,285) to rebuild the track.
Americans may pay less for carpets next year if last week's plan to set up the latest and biggest carpet manufacturing operation in the country bears fruit.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 29 (UP) -- A pair of Western Maryland halfbacks, one with a slingshot arm and the other with radar pass-catching abilities, led their team to a 13-9 victory over Franklin and Marshall today before 5,000 homecoming fans.
" I will never forget that I am an American fighting man, responsible for my actions and dedicated to the principles which made my country free." So says the new Code of Conduct for our service men.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Interior Department plans an experimental solar distilling device that would work around the clock transforming salt water into fresh water.
CAIRO, Oct. 29 -- Large Israeli troop movements in the Gaza and El Auja areas were visible today from Egyptian positions, a Defense Ministry spokesman announced tonight.
Theatre people who are also art collectors have lent paintings for a benefit show at the City Center Gallery, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street. The exhibit will open on Wednesday.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Xavier of Cincinnati spotted Boston College 12 points today and came back with three touchdowns to score a 19-12 homecoming victory.

BAWDY SONGS: Oscar Brand, folk singer (Audio Fidelity). Listeners of broad culture probably can supply the original texts of which these songs represent slightly cleaned-up versions. Not recommended for children.

DISCRIMINATION rears its shrewd head in the present group, "New Arrivals From France, at the Janis Gallery. Present here is work by proven twentieth century masters, including Picasso, Leger, Klee, Mondrian and de Chirico -- the great innovators -- and some paintings by near-winners, Vlaminck, Gleizes, Kupka and Schwitters.

S. J. PERELMAN must be one of the most assiduous readers of newspapers and periodicals on record. On the prowl for a subject, he turns over the pages, eyes some innocent frailty and is off like a pinwheel. Puns, gargantuan metaphors, plausible impossibilities -- also a style -- are there, tossed in without haggling.

This seems sometimes less an Age of Anxiety than an Age of Anthropology -- of documentation, analysis and classification. Characters in books have left off being individuals and become Types. And writters have stopped examining people to peer at the Group -- not at man but at a Man in a Gray Flannel Suit and a buttoned-down collar.
The paradox of Western man is his believing in the sacredness of human personality and practicing a way of life based on technology, Dr. Arnold J. Toynbee said here yesterday.

Germans must have felt a certain nostalgia when the Bundestag moved recently from Bonn to Berlin for a special two-day session. The thought, of course, was that the meeting would be symbolic and would serve to demonstrate the Federal Republic's continued interest in German unity.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Mister Gus, a son of a Nasrullah and ridden by Willie Shoemaker, won the $100,000 William P. Kyne Handicap at Bay Meadows today. He set a track record for a mile and a furlong at 1:47 4/5.

Forty million persons in the northeastern states and some Midwest communities should have had an extra hour of sleep this morning. For, having paid attention to the many reminders, they would have turned their clocks back an hour before retiring last night.

THE reading public may have come to believe that Vermont, by now, has been rediscovered often enough. It has sat for its portrait frequently and patiently in the last twenty years, yet, if the opinion of a "permanent summer resident" has validity -- and usually it hasn't much in my home state -- W. Storrs Lee's interpretation of a people and their background is better than any of its predecessors.

A FORMER child psychologist who turned child photographer and made it pay so well that he is now one of the top men in the field in this country, has just introduced a new idea in photography correspondence courses.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Ohio State sent six different men across Northwestern's goal line today to blast the Wildcats, 49 -- 0.
GREENWOOD, Miss., Oct. 20 -- A grand jury will convene in this Leflore County seat Nov. 7 to study evidence in the alleged kidnap-murder of Emmett Louis Till, 14-year-old Chicago Negro.

IT is nice to believe that the army that carries classics in the duffel bag eventually triumphs. The trouble with the Germans was that their cause perforce quoted Goebbels, not Goethe. Not so with the British. The author of this neat little (the storyteller has no pretensions) book was commanding officer of a small military operation around the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The sixth annual Debutante Cotillion and Thanksgiving Ball will be held on Thanksgiving night in the ballroom of the Sheraton- Park Hotel. Debutantes from Washington, Baltimore, Wilmington, Del.; Norfolk, Va.; Philadelphia and New York will be presented to society.
From herring scales to pearl essence: that is the success story of one of the nation's fast-growing but little-known industries.

UNCLE Ben, a canal boat skipper in the heyday of the canallers, was "kind of a dingy old coot" and henpecked too, but he still had a remnant of spunk. While Aunt Em was away on an errand of mercy, Uncle Ben fortuitously killed a whale in New York harbor, hoisted the carcass on his boat and started up river.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Oct. 29 -- One of the important questions confronting Tanganyika, Kenya and Uganda is the role to be played in their future devlopment by the East Africa High Commission.

It costs a minimum of 8 cents to send a letter overseas by steamship and a minimum of 15 cents to send one overseas by air. On the other hand, the annual cost of sending Congressmen, Senators and possibly Congressional clerks and Congressional wives overseas during a fiscal year on legitimate errands seems to come to about 3 cents for each American man, woman and child.

Since it also runs within a hundred miles of Bogota it sounded like the route for us.

Catholic Youth Organization Week will be nationally observed from today through next Sunday by 7,000,000 members. In this city, 228,000 youths will participate in the observance under the leadership of Cardinal Spellman, who is honorary chairman of the New York organization.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 -- California Democrats headed in several directions this week in 1956 Presidential maneuvers. But with more cohesion they fired an opening barrage at one of the Republicans' less secure Senate seats.

OUTDOOR gardeners are legion, and so too are the indoor gardeners. Of the latter group, only a comparatively small number have greenhouses. There is, however no better way to extend the flower season through every month of the year in cold climate.

FOR the past several weeks this bemused listener has been dipping into a London - Oiseau - Lyre set, a massive album built along the lines of an M-3 tank, containing sixteen LP disks and all the harpsichord music of Couperin. Ruggero Gerlin is the brave instrumentalist who has attempted the task. It is probably unparalleled in the history of recorded music.

THESE two volumes are the outcome of several years activity of the American Academic Freedom Project operating under a grant from the Louis M. Rabinowitz Foundation. Dr. James S. Watson, radiologist, and Sidney A. Weinberg, associate in radiology of the University of Rochester Medical Center, have developed and designed an X-ray motion picture camera which is about to be introduced commercially. The new apparatus is used with regular X-ray equipment to take pictures with the patient in any position.

Tomorrow evening millions of American homes will be visited by young witches, spooks and goblins observing the Traditional Halloween "Trick or Treat." But rather than threatening destructive action if they do not receive candy, cookies and small gifts, many children this year will be soliciting contributions for the United Nations' International Children's Fund.
MUSKEGON, Mich., Oct. 29 -- Senator Estes Kefauver charged today that the Republican Administration had been catering to special interests rather than to the American people as a whole.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 29 -- Flood-damaged Fairfield County has come a long way on the road to recovery.

All good things come to an end sometime, and it happened to the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The Boston Bruins defeated the New Yorkers, 1 -- 0, in their National Hockey League encounter before a crowd of 13,509.
Two major universities announced yesterday that they were making it financially easier for their students to pay for the cost of their education.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Quarterback Bob Hardy twisted through the Rice line for dramatic 12-yard touchdown run that gave Kentucky a 20-16 victory today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Republicans and Democrats today squabbled over a recent article in The Democratic Digest that criticized the power, oil and public land policies of the Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 29 -- The globe - trotting company of "Porgy and Bess" ended an eighteen - day engagement in Mexico tonight and thus ended, too, a tour of Latin America that began July 5 in Rio de Janeiro.

Within the past few months you have carried several letters from former Foreign Service and State Department officers criticizing the program under which a number of the department's Civil Service officers and Foreign Service reserve and staff officers are being integrated into the Foreign Service Officer Corps.

" NO wonder she was happy; using her mind, filling it with fresh knowledge and new beauties -- is there any more stimulating pleasure?" Ann Bridge asks the question in this portrait of her mother.

SOMETHING in or about the house always is in need of repair. And always there is some way to do it. More often than not the method involves know-how rather than any elaborate investment in tools or equipment.
DUBLIN, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Students seized the 134-foot Lord Nelson column in mid-Dublin today and covered the British naval hero's bronze statue with a portrait of an executed Irish-man.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations criticized the Administration today for taking steps to restrict housing credit. It said at least one out of every three families still needed "a decent home."

MONTREAL, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Dickie Moore of the Montreal Canadiens was Johnny-on-the-spot tonight. He scored a third-period goal to beat the Detroit Red Wings, 2 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 13,802.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens said yesterday he expected important work on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in the Woodside-Jackson Heights area to be completed by Jan. 1. This would be between two and three months ahead of schedule.

HONG KONG, Oct. 22 -- One of the major problems now confronting Communist China's industrialization program is an acknowledged shortage of well-trained technicians. This problem, as discussed in the mainland press, is one of quality, as well as quantity.

THE history of art criticism is a story of the absurd errors in judgment made by critics of the past. Nothing is easier than to laugh at what was said about Courbet, Manet, Cezanne or Van Gogh by their contemporaries.
MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 28 -- The West German Government has given the United States Crusade for Freedom permission to continue its balloon propaganda campaign behind the Iron Curtain.
GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov's exposition of his Government's latest price for Germany's reunification is making a heavy impact on West German officials.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Union scored on the last play of a tight football game today and upset highly favored Williams, 14 -- 6.

Riding the crest of a war-born trend, the Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation has lifted its sales in the last decade by some eightfold to $50,000,000. More recently, the business boom has solidified the company's position as the leader in a highly specialized field.

A PLACE to work is essential for any hobby as well as business, and the workbench is the heart of any home workshop. The top of the workbench will be used by the home craftsman, whatever his bent, to lay out project cuts, as a flat surface when measuring and as an assembly area.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 29 -- The largest international industrial fair ever held in Asia opened in New Delhi today, a sales center for politics as much as for machines.

Forty years ago the retail merchant found out what his customers wanted by standing at the door of his store and greeting each one personally. In the giant department store of today that method is out of the question. But four of the nations leading retailers, located in as many cities, are employing a new means of determining their customers' wants, and are guiding their own buying accordingly.

The Will Rogers Memorial Hospital will be the beneficiary of the premiere showing of the motion picture "Guys and Dolls" on Thursday night at the Capitol Theatre. Gustave S. Eyssell, president of Rockefeller Center, Inc., and Mrs. Paul Ames of 885 Park Avenue are co-chairmen of the ticket committee for the event.

I have noted in the Oct. 15 issue of The Times the letter from Rabbi Irving Miller in which he accused me of having injected the threat of anti-Semitism in the United State into the discussion of issues involved in the Middle East. This followed published report of a statement made at a press conference on Oct. 10.

MEXICO CITY , Oct. 30 -- Mexico, through an expansion of exports and slackening of imports, finished the first six months of 1955 with a foreign trade deficit of $53,100,000. This was $78,900,000 less than the deficit for the same period in 1954.

The Juilliard School of Music, one of the most distinguished in America, celebrates today its fiftieth anniversary. It was just half a century ago that the first Convocation of the Institute of Musical Art, parent body of the Juilliard, was held. These fifty years have seen a tremendous growth in musical interest and activity and in that growth the Juilliard has played an ever-widening part.

Two former collegians from New York who are coaches at Portsmouth Priory School in Portsmouth, R. I., were discussing their problems the other day in the gymnasium office. They were Ralph Hewitt, the Red and Black's football coach, and Father Bede Gorman, athletic director and basketball coach.

The steamship charter market maintained high-level activity last week but rates generally dropped slightly. The weekly survey of the field showed the first decline in the over-all freight rate index since mid-August.

Kawneer Company of Niles, Mich., producing aluminum products, has acquired Weatherstone Windows, Ltd., of Toronto, which makes aluminum windows and curtain walls. The latter concern, with its 200 employes, will continue as an operating organization headed by Allan Weatherstone, founder and president.
GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- The Swiss people went to the polls today and expressed their satisfaction with things as they are. The changes in representation of the three dominant parties were slight.
The joint venture of American President Lines and the Pacific Far East Line into the bulk carrier field appears assured of Government approval.

When it completes its local season on Sunday, the New York City Opera will leave for a three-week tour that opens in Boston the next day, Nov. 7. After seven performances in Boston, the company will give nine in Detroit, two in East Lansing, Mich., and four in Cleveland.

CAIRO, Oct. 30 -- Decisive negotiations on financing Egypt's vast Nile irrigation and hydro-electric project are scheduled to begin between representatives of Egypt and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in Washington Nov. 21.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The City's initial reaction to the budget has been quite the opposite of what had been generally expected. Instead of the grim measures that had been looked for to curb the rising tide of inflation, the budget proposals are as soft relatively as those embodied in last April's budget.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears, with a 17-point first half and an 86-yard scoring pass in the second half, gained a 31-20 victory over the Los Angeles Rams today. The loss knocked the Rams out of the undisputed lead in the Western Conference of the National Football League.

Wherever newspaper men of the Western Hemisphere meet nowadays the talk turns inevitably to the two great newspapers of Latin America now silenced -- La Prensa of Buenos Aires and El Tiempo of Bogota.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Wes Santee, America's greatest miler, today was suspended by the Missouri Valley Amateur Athletic Union for accepting "excessive expense" money for three track meets in California in May.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 30 -- The New Jersey State Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., today pledged full support to three teachers who were dismissed after they had refused to testify last spring before a unit of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson received today a formal invitation to enter the Minnesota presidential primary.
Quarterbacks were solidly in the football picture as Navy and Auburn fell from the heights Saturday.

The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company announced over the week-end sales of $435,00O,000 in the first nine months, 9.5 per cant over the last year's record pace. The average new policy also reached a new high of $8,608 resulting in a 4.8 per cent increase insurance in force, with 1,556,624 policies worth $7,826.892,608.
A 71-year-old former Baltimore cook who turned to sculpture five years ago presented "a piece of my work" yesterday to Mrs. Ann Arnold Hedgman, assistant to Mayor Wagner.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Ted Wegert, back in action after a month's absence nursing a broken foot, ran 29 yards for the game's first touchdown today and then scored another in the final minute as the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 24-0.

The Port of New York has lost more than $1,000,000,000 in export-import shipments in the last four years largely because rail rates favor Baltimore and Philadelphia, the New York Chamber of Commerce estimated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Gov. George M. Leader of Pennsylvania described Adlai E. Stevenson today as "the right man in the right place at the right time for 1956 for the Democratic party."
Jose Maza of Chile, president of the United Nations General Assembly, and United Nations delegates from nine other countries attended the Mass of Christ the King in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation has thrown its resources into a long-term quest for columbium -- an obscure metal believed to hold promise for high-temperature uses in jet engines, gas turbines, rockets and nuclear power equipment.

In the great drama of New York City's shifting populations Negroes and Puerto Ricans are playing crucial roles. Both face much the same kind of discrimination in employment, housing and education. Even though they live, work and grow up side by side they frequently are victims of some misunderstanding about one another.

The International Chamber of Commerce warned the United Nations over the week-end that adoption of a section of the proposed Covenants on Human Rights would hinder the economic growth of the underdeveloped countries.

In the dimly lighted pubs of Dublin the old-timers still speak in awed tones of the legendary horse named Barcaldine. From the time he was foaled in 1878, through his reign as champion of Ireland and Britain in the Eighteen Eighties, the Irish speedster, never lost a race.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- French Government experts have begun to examine the economic and financial consequences of the referendum vote of the inhabitants of the Saar last Sunday, rejecting the "European" status proposed for their territory.

Rare is the man, no matter what age he achieves, who distinguishes himself in three careers. Such a man is celebrating his eightieth birthday in Washington today; and he is now, as he has been for a generation, one of this nation's leading citizens.

Dewey Johnson, former Drake University star, captured the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Johnson covered the muddy four-mile course in 20 minutes 42.1 seconds.

LENORE PORTNOY; soprano, made her recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. Miss Portnoy has sung eight seasons with the New York City Opera Company and has given concerts extensively outside New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Henry Wallace said today he was not aware of the "character" of the Soviet Union and her leaders until 1949.
OAKLAND, Oct. 30 -- Methodist Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam appealed today to the Roman Catholic Church to join Protestantism in "a first step toward reconciliation" and a unified stand against Communism.

WIKTOR LABUNSKI, director of the Conservatory of Music in Kansas City, Mo., gave a piano program yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It was the Polish-born musician's first New York recital since his debut at Carnegie Hall in December, 1928.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- The men who made "Marty" one of the year's memorable movies -- Paddy Chayefsky, author; Delbert Mann, director, and Harold Hecht, producer -- will team again to film another of Mr. Chayefsky's television dramas.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Two American swim records were broken today. Yale set a mark for the 200-yard medley relay and the Walter Reed Swim Club of Bethesda, Md., cracked the women's record for the 150-yard medley relay.
The Small Business Administration was accused yesterday of having offered a $65,000 loan to a New York leather goods factory only on condition that it move to Maine.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 30 -- Back in the old days, when the Chicago Bears were the terrors of the gridiron, someone asked Jimmy Conzelman a question. These were the Bears of Sid Luckman, George McAfee, Bill Osmanski and the other fabled heroes who made the Monsters of the Midway almost invincible.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Scoring 31 points in the first half, the San Francisco Forty-Niners walloped the victoryless Detroit Lions, 38 -- 21, in a National Football League game today before 47,431 fans at Kezar Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A picket line may mar the dedication of the $5,000,000 home of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers Friday.
New regulations to protect workers in New York State from on-the-job hazards of atomic energy and other radiation have been adopted by the State Board of Standards and Appeals.

The results achieved in the first three days by a special police traffic unit were announced early today at Police Headquarters. The number of tickets issued from last Friday until last midnight was 458.
VALHALLA, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- A new laboratory here is guarding the purity of New York City's billion-dollar water system.

Mayor Wagner hinted strongly yesterday that he would use his influence as titular head of his party in the city to help Adlai Stevenson win the Democratic nomination for President. He reiterated his belief that Mr. Stevenson would be the party's strongest candidate.
Queens County, politically one of the most jagged terrains in this area, is the scene of the outstanding local election fight of the year.
PARIS, Monday, Oct. 31 -- France's Parliament began yesterday a three-day debate on electoral reform as a prelude to new elections in December.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- The Soviet press continued today to take a strongly critical attitude toward the Western position at the Geneva conference.
NICE, France, Monday, Oct. 31 -- The exiled former Sultan of Morocco, Mohammed ben Youssef, returned from exile in Madagascar today amid swelling Nationalist sentiment to return him to the throne.
AMSTERDAM, Oct. 30 -- The general opinion here is that a milestone has been reached in the post-war development of Amsterdam stock prices.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Ohio State Journal reported tonight it had learned an "innocent" violation of Big Ten and National Collegiate Athletic Association football rules involving gifts to players would hasten an investigation of Ohio State University's athletic program.
PHILIPPEVILLE, Algeria, Oct. 30 -- In Algeria, as elsewhere, the hopes of the many have been placed in the hands of a few.
Merchant Marine Industries Week opens today in the city.

Election of Thomas S. Tolar and W. C. Harris as executive vice presidents and directors of Pacific Mills, a member company of Burlington Industries, was announced over the week-end by Spencer Love, board chairman of the parent and subsidiary company.
CLEMSON, S. C., Oct. 30 -- The textile industry in South Carolina is booming. Mills turning out a wide variety of yarns and cloth are working around the clock six and seven days a week.

Beverly Sills made her debut with the New York City Opera Saturday evening, singing the role of Rosalinda in Strauss' "Fledermaus." Miss Sills comes to the company with an operatic background that extends from San Francisco to Munich, Germany.

AROUND 10 o'clock yesterday morning the first of a seemingly endless line of glistening horse vans pulled to the curb at the west end of Madison Square Garden in West Forty-ninth Street. They were wet with rain.

NISHINOMIYA, Japan, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Outfielder Bob Cerv blasted a three-run homer and a double today to account for all of the New York Yankees' runs in a 4-2 victory over Japan's All-Pacific League team today.

"If we do not go out into the world and call every man our brother, there are those who will go out and call him comrade,'" the Rev. Albert F. Ciarcia declared yesterday. He preached at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West at Seventy-sixth Street, on "The Church Against Communism."

AN uncommonly sensitive and enlightening insight into the world of teenagers is being offered in a new program entitled "Talkaround," presented at 3 o'clock on Sunday afternoons over Channel 2. The presentation should have no difficulty in winning a prize or two by the season's end.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- This year's grain harvest will be the largest in Soviet history, the official organ of the Agriculture Ministry reported today. It did not give any statistical estimate of the size of the crop.
With one more round and four unfinished games remaining, Mme. Olga Rubtsova and Mme. Larissa Volpert of Russia tied for first place last night in the women's challengers' chess tournament at Moscow.
The city school system is defending the use of "faceless informers" against teachers in pre-trial interviews on the ground that its ex-Communist informants otherwise would "suffer condemnation."
Rockwell Kent, the artist, announced yesterday that he would sue in Federal court in Washington Nov. 9 to compel the State Department to grant a passport to him.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 30 -- While the Catholic Mission in Jesuit Bend, La., stood silent Sunday, a priest in a parish fifty miles up the Mississippi River censured the men who had caused the little church to be locked.
WALTHAM, Mass. Oct. 30 -- Three chapels of similar design were jointly dedicated today in academic ceremonies at Brandeis University.

Seventy years ago our people created the Forest Preserve of New York State after a long struggle against the selfish interests that were despoiling this great natural resource. Under the leadership of men like Verplanck Colvin and with the aid of the great newspapers of the state our people voted to halt the sale of state-owned forest lands and preserve this heritage for future generations by erecting a constitutional barrier against further invasion.
Governor Harriman appealed yesterday to the state's voters to approve the proposed $750,000,000 state highway bond issue and to authorize $50,000,000 in state loans for middle-income housing.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared last night that the Soviet Union's "cynical new invasion of the Middle East" was a direct violation of all the pledges it had given at Geneva.

A few weeks before Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, R. A. Butler, introduced his revised budget in Parliament last week, The Commercial and Financial Chronicle published a dispatch from its London correspondent, Dr. Paul Einzig.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 30 -- Leaders of American Reform Judaism today praised President Eisenhower for initiating the heads of government talks. They asked Secretary of State Dulles to carry out the discussions at Geneva in the "manner so inspiringly initiated" by the President.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman, feeling "fine" after his latest speaking trip, said today that Russia was to blame for troubles in the Middle East. He said the present Administration should have done something about it.
Three leading figures in the world of horse racing expressed shock at the death yesterday of William Woodward Jr. They asserted it would mean a severe loss to the sport.
The New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association broke even in two games with the College All-Stars at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Secretary of Welfare said today he would submit to Congress in January a program to relieve school classroom shortages.

Studies of what consumers think they will buy and why they think the way they do continue to be made. Articles on the findings of the researchers continue to be published. Now fourteen of these have been gathered between attractive covers by Lincoln H. Clark of New York University and given the title "The Life Cycle and Consumer Behavior."*

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 28 -- The Government, which has been trying to grow more food on less land and simultaneously to collectivize agriculture, has been using the stick-and-carrot method on the farmer this year to attain both ends.

Net sales of the United States Rubber Company reached a record $688,775,620 in the first nine months of this year, and despite flood losses of nearly $12,000,000, earnings were the second highest for any similar period in the company's history.

I should like to call to your attention a minor error of historical fact which has been repeated on a number of occasions in the columns of your newspaper during the past several months. The last of such occasions was the dispatch to The New York Times from Harold Callender in Saarbrucken published in the Review of the Week of Oct. 23.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Budget Bureau is being flooded with requests, many virtually undeniable, for heavier spending next year on nondefense programs.

The differences between Protestantism and Roman Catholicism must be reiterated periodically, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken declared yesterday in a Reformation Sunday sermon at Riverside Church. He said Protestantism might only be defined in relation to the Church of Rome "from which it sprung and with which it broke."

The National Jewish Walfare Board adopted yesterday a $2,247,000 budget for 1956. The directors, holding their quarterly meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel, called on Jewish community funds to allot more to the board. In New York it shares in collections by the United Jewish Appeal.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 30 -- A shotgun blast early this morning took the life of William Woodward Jr., 35-year-old financier, sportsman and owner of the great racehorse Nashua.

Chungking Tino a brillianted Pekingese owned by the ceafren Kennels of Devon, Pa., snapped a week-end of excellent performances by taking best in show at the Progressive Dog club's twenty-third annual toy breed fixture yesterday. The show was held at The Livingston in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Government announced today that it approved fifty-five rapid tax write-offs for $507,156,125 worth of new industrial facilities between Oct. 6 and 19.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- An early plebiscite in the British Togoland trust territory of West Africa was recommended today. The voting, under United Nations auspices, would be the first step in determining the region's future.
SONIA VARGAS, the Peruvian pianist who made her New York debut five years ago, returned for her second Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon.
YONKERS, Oct. 30 -- An off-duty policeman assertedly caught a man turning in a false alarm early today. But, strictly speaking, the police could not say the suspect was caught red-handed.
HONG KONG, Monday, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Harriet C. Mills of New York, who was arrested by the Chinese Communists more than four years ago, was released today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The President's Commission on Veterans Pensions has received White House approval to delay filling of its report until about the first of next year. It had been scheduled to report Tuesday.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Floyd Curry and Bert Olmstead banged in goals 40 seconds apart in the third period tonight to lift the league-leading Montreal Candiens to a 2-2 tie with the Detroit Red Wings before 14,286 fans.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 30 -- The Israeli Army reported three shooting incidents today along the southern half of the Gaza strip.

Three New York blouse manufacturers have been ordered to pay the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., a total of $60,000 for importing blouses from Japan. The unusual award was made by F. Nathan Wolf, impartial chairman of the New York women's neckwear industry.
The city's revenues for the current fiscal year are, like those of the state, running ahead of expectations.

Members of President Eisenhower's "team" may be pleased to know they may now express their political sentiments in their home furnishings. Abraham Straus is now offering a cotton fabric, suitable for slip covers and draperies, that is printed with symbols and pictures from the life of the President.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Red-faced Harvard officials admitted tonight that Bucknell was short-changed two downs in the closing moments of yesterday's game.
Four teen-agers who had been committed to institutions as delinquents advised their elders last night on how to deal with the problem of errant youth.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Floods in the northeastern United States last August killed 179 persons, seriously injured 6,992, destroyed 813 homes and caused damages of $457,674,044.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- One of the most prominent figures in post-war Soviet agriculture has apparently been reinstated in Communist party councils.
THE young instrumentalists who have been playing for the last five years under the name of the Collegium Musicum opened a new season yesterday. But they began with a new name and in a new home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- John B. Hollister, director of the International Cooperation Administration, said today that in visits to nine Far Eastern capitals he had studied possible reductions in foreign aid expenditures.
DENVER, Oct. 30 -- At the behest of his Secretary of Agriculture, President Eisenhower substituted pork bacon for beef bacon in his breakfast this morning.

Geneva talks about the reunification of Germany may mean life or death to the hopes of prewar investors. These investors hold more than $160,000,000 of defaulted dollar bonds owed by interests in the Russian-dominated East German state.
Two hundred thousand General Electric workers and their families will get relief tomorrow from the fear that a sudden major illness might wipe out their life savings or leave them heavily in debt.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 30 -- The founding of an organization designed to draw a large segment of the West German Labor movement into an anti-Socialist federation was announced in Essen today.

PENDLETON, Ore., Oct 30 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, is under increased pressure from Republicans to beat the Democrats to the punch with a program for Government rental of land to bolster farm income.

BEVANS, N. J., Oct. 30 -- The Sussex County Field Trial Club completed its inaugural program today at the Flatbrook Valley tract with the open gun dog stake. The winner was Rumson Farm Bulldozer, 5-year-old pointer owned by Ralph Fritsche of Matawan, N. J., and handled by George Stymiest of Lambertville, N. J.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Policemen equipped with walkie-talkie radio sets and aided by at least one police dog assured Princess Margaret's privacy today.
Fifty boys and girls had a roaring good time yesterday noon at a block party at the corner of Nineteenth Street and Seventh Avenue.

Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to move irregularly last week. At the close of trading Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 38 points to down 108 from the close of the previous week.

GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- West German observers in Geneva feel that some formula should be found to hasten the end of the Foreign Ministers' Conference before irreparable harm is done to the cause of the reunification of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Americans borrowed $500,000,000 more than they saved or invested in the second quarter of this year. The Securities and Exchange Commission ascribed this today chiefly to "exceedingly large sales" of autos bought on time.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -To be successful today, dress designers must be early birds willing to fly a long, tortuous, and backtracking route to get their worm.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- Whether state maritime schools should continue competing with the United States Maritime Academy at Kings Point, N. Y., will be one of the issues at a senate subcommittee hearing that opens here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- World corn production in 1955-56 appears likely to set a new record, the Department of Agriculture said today.
GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- For the news correspondents reporting the Big Four foreign ministers' meeting in Geneva it is a waiting game.
GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov is now saying it with a smile -- but he is still saying it.
Protestants and Roman Catholics were called upon yesterday to "deplore together the denial of the spirit of Christ too frequently evident on both sides."
PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Oct. 30 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands is exploring this rich but underdeveloped member of her kingdom.

Melvin J. Mitchell and Albert Harrison, builders, who recently took title to a plot 100 by 100 feet at 337 to 345 East Fifty-second Street, have enlarged the plottage by buying a lot 20 by 100 feet at 335 East Fifty-second Street.

A popular Irish play will open on Broadway in December as a direct result of the favorable notices received last week by "The Chalk Garden." The connection was explained yesterday by Siobhan McKenna, the Irish actress who co-stars in the Enid Bagnold comedy.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 30 -- Traffic and toll collections on the New Jersey Turnpike continue to mount, the Turnpike Authority said in its third-quarter report to bond-holders.

The retirement of Mrs. Aida de Acosta Breckinridge, executive director of the Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc., was announced yesterday. A report on the organization's first ten years of operations was made by Walter C. Baker, the president.

"Highway of the Sun," a new book by Victor Wolfgang von Hagen, will be issued Nov. 7 by Duell. Sloan Pearce-Little, Brown. It is about exploring 10,000 miles of Incan roads that made it possible for the Inca Empire to dominate a fourth of South America and also facilitated the Spanish conquest. The author led the expedition, which had been organized in association with the American Geographical Society.

Both William Woodward Jr. and his wife, the former Ann Aden Crowell, were well known in international sporting circles. Mrs. Woodward often accompanied her husband to the winner's circle after a race in which the white-and-red-dotted silks of the Belair Stud were triumphant.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Mario D'Agata of Italy became the bantamweight boxing champion of Europe last night. He scored a fifth-round technical knockout over France's Andre Valignat and his fists wrote the happiest chapter yet in a Cinderella story rarely equaled in sport.

GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- As everybody expected the latest Big Four conference opened dismally. With only slight variations, the same familiar figures seem to be executing the same familiar steps in a formal Byzantine ballet. Stars who had temporarily livened the Geneva stage are gone: Chou En-lai, Mendes-France and Eden; Eisenhower, Khrushchev and Bulganin; the extraordinary group of atomic scientists with their visions of heaven and hell.
Pelting rains, whipped by strong easterly winds, soaked the city and its environs yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that 69.9 per cent, or 39,125,000, American males over 14 years old were married as of April 1. This compared with 68.2 per cent, or 37,022,000, five years previously.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- J. Haden Alldredge, who retires as a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission tomorrow, is an amateur farmer who grows just about everything -- except grass under his feet.

PARIS, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Following are the text of Sultan Mohammed ben Arafa's letter to President Rene Coty of France and the partial text of a French Government communique on the Sultan's abdication:

New York State savings banks are expected to have used about $100,000,000 of a $250,000,000 line of credit set up by the Chase Manhattan Bank through the Institutional Securities Corporation for mortgage lending purposes.
Net income of the United States Government-owned Panama Canal Company for the year ended June 30 decreased to $581,134 from $4,160,010 the year before.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 30 -- Bill Agnew, Princeton's first-string wingback, will be out of action for a week to ten days with a pulled rib cartilage, Dr. Harry R. McPhee, the team physician, said today.

A Negro physician and the editor of a Roman Catholic newspaper received the 1955 James J. Hoey Awards for Interracial Justice yesterday. The awards are presented annually to Roman Catholic laymen by the Catholic Interracial Council.

An inventory of our national defense system brings up the astonishing figure of $124 billions as the current level of our military assets. This, of course, is still not the total figure. It does not include the atomic energy establishments, nor by any means all of the military materials now in use.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Grain and soybean futures came back quite actively last week from early declines.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns squeezed by the Chicago Cardinals in mud and rain today, 26 -- 20, to take first place undisputed in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League.

VICENTE ESCUDERO and a little company of Spanish dancers and musicians gave a program last night at Carnegie Hall, opening a brief farewell tour before the departure of the great flamenco dancer for his home in Madrid.
Industrial and store realty figured in transactions reported in New Jersey over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today that 14,350 banks were operatng in the United States on June 30. This was 157 fewer than a year earlier.

YOUNG HOUSEWIVES planning their first parties this season might turn for guidance to a Louisville, Ky., matron, Mrs. Marion W. Fiexner. This pretty wife of a physician, who long has written and spoken (on a Louisville television station) on food, has compiled a practical volume on entertaining. "The Cocktail-Supper Cookbook" (Barrows, 255 pp., $3.95).

The owners of Electronicam, who favor a Screen Actors Guild contract over that of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, will seek a jurisdictional ruling from a board of arbitrators.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said tonight this country was lagging behind the Soviet Union in the race to develop an inter-continental ballistic missile. The Wisconsin Republican asked whether Communist subversion might be to blame.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (AP) -- America's Protestant churches are spending more than a billion dollars a year to provide 11,000,000 persons with food, clothing, shelter and other health and welfare services, according to a new study disclosed today.

The New York Central System yesterday announced that the olive drab and mustard brown combinations of its suburban stations would soon disappear. The railroad is repainting twenty-six passenger stations in modern color schemes.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The board of directors of the Inter-American Press Association voted today to fly a gold medal to the editor of an Argentine newspaper confiscated by former President Juan D. Peron.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 -- In an effort to straighten out delivery problems, many steel companies decided last week to slash "overdue" tonnage before the end of the year. This whittling of carry-overs will mean that many steel users will start anew on steel orders, which will reflect realistic delivery promises.

GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- The Big Four Foreign Ministers Conference resumes here tomorrow where the heads of government left off last July, with the Soviet reluctantly accepting the "close link" between the unification of Germany and European security.
Four churches in the east midtown area of Manhattan will conduct a series of evening meetings in November on problems of church concern.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Representative Brooks Hays, a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, warned tonight that the Egyptian-Soviet bloc arms agreement "bodes little good even for the Egyptian Government, let alone the entire area."
UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Duncan Black of Parkton, Md., won the twenty-five-lap Congressional Cup feature race today in the national MG races at the Marlboro Motor Raceway.
The radio patrol car is an "impersonal" weapon in the fight against crime, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday in renewing his plea for more foot patrolmen.
GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- Israel has been informed by a Soviet satellite Government that in the event of war Egypt would not honor her obligation to readmit Britain to the Suez Canal base.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Sultan Mohammed ben Arafa abdicated the Moroccan throne today and urged support for his exiled predecessor, Mohammed ben Youssef.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Dr. T. R. M. Howard, Mississippi Negro physician and surgeon, will receive the American Veterans Committee's first A. V. C. Citizens Award.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- The Soviet Union plans to develop the hydroelectric power potential of its major Siberian rivers by building stations with a total capacity of 3,000,000 to 5,000,000 kilowatts on the Ob, the Yenisei and the Angara.
NEWARK, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A two-day strike of 200 Public Service Electric and Gas Company workers in Bergen County ended tonight.

On Election Day next week the people of New York State will have the opportunity and responsibility to express their opinion on ten proposed constitutional amendments, which have been forwarded to referendum by favorable action in two separately elected Legislatures.
The Republican candidate for District Attorney of Bronx County accused the Citizens Union yesterday of making "damaging, libelous, malicious and defamatory statements" about him in its voters guide.
An exiled Chinese prelate of the Roman Catholic Church declared yesterday that the free world must maintain an aggressive anti-Communist attitude or suffer the fate of his countrymen.

Both sides hit for distance, but the Giants connected more consistently and gained a 35-7 victory over the Washington Redskins yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Six touchdowns, five by the Giants, were tallied and the shortest scoring play covered 36 yards.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- The supertanker New Jersey Sun, of the Sun Oil Company, is scheduled to sail from Perth Amboy, N. J., tomorrow on a 23-000-mile trip around the world.
The following book, published this week, is intended for children aged 9 to 14:

According to The Times of Oct. 27, Dr. Luther Gulick, City Administrator of the City of New York, commented upon Police Commissioner Kennedy's reply to Mayor Wagner's amazing order to the city department heads to open their files to one television producer as follows:
Newspaper advertising is making bigger advances over 1954 as the year goes on, and a new high record is likely.

The Railway Express Agency's expedited courier-type service between railroad depots, called "SPED," will be extended from New York to Boston, and from Chicago to nine key midwestern points, K. N. Merritt, vice president in charge of traffic, announced yesterday.
Ed Aubel is a constant clock-watcher, but his sports bosses are eager to keep him on the payroll.

TWO young composers with styles as far apart as their homes, Los Angeles and New York, were presented at the first Composers Forum of the season Saturday night in the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Nina (Honey Bear) Warren, daughter of Chief Justice and Mrs. Earl Warren, and Dr. Stuart Brien of Beverly Hills, Calif., obtained a marriage license today.

Frederick Brown has sold the twelve-story office building at 9-11 East Forty-first Street to an investing customer of William Bialek, broker. Rosenman, Goldmark, Colin Kaye were attorneys for the buyer and Joshua Bernstein acted for the seller.
Consumption of magnesium will be at a peacetime high this year as a result of a steady increase in civilian uses for the lightweight metal.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The United Nations' Palestine truce chief said today he favored action by the United States, Britain and France to cope with the present Egyptian-Israeli crisis.
Shocking pink tennis racquets may be Doris Hart's answer to Gussie Moran's recent beautification of the tennis courts.

The "kick-off" for the National Horse Show occurred at City Hall yesterday when Mayor Wagner extended the city's greetings to the jumping teams of Canada, Ireland and the United States. The event will begin its eight-day run today in Madison Square Garden.
Prices at which food stores buy coffee dropped yesterday, but this may not mean much to the housewife.

Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it had obtained a twenty-year, $90,000,000 loan from the Equitable Life Assurance Society. It will be used largely to help finance Eastern's $350,000,000 program for new turboprop and jet airliners.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Britain is pursuing a cautious, middle-of-the-road policy in the Middle East and will not give Israel a special territorial guarantee against attack at this time.
THOSE starved-looking sheath dresses women are supposed to be wiggling into nowadays present a grisly problem for the tubby ones who like an extra dollop of whipped cream.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- The French Government moved ahead tonight to put its former adversary, Mohammed ben Youssef, back on the Moroccan throne.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The battle between those who want to enliven and expand the historic shrines of Sleepy Hollow and those who want to keep them "unspoiled" ended today in victory for the enliveners.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 31 -- Premier-designate David Ben-Gurion's new fifteen-man Cabinet was ready tonight for submission tomorrow to the Knesset (Parliament) for a vote of confidence. The proposed Cabinet is the most leftist in modern Israel's history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Short-term borrowing costs of the Government are decreasing. The Treasury announced today that its latest offering of ninety-one day bills was sold at a price equal to an annual interest rate of 2.179 per cent. Last week it was 2.231 per cent.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 1 -- Ancient Shinto purification ceremonies yesterday welcomed the atom back to Japan, the only country that has felt its full destructive power.

Wilbur Wright, co-inventor of the airplane, Gen. Thomas Jonathan (Stonewall) Jackson, Confederate Army hero, and George Westinghouse, inventor of the airbrake, were added yesterday to New York University's Hall of Fame.

THE Blackfriars Guild, determined that nothing should mar the celebration of its fifteenth anniversary as an off-Broadway company, opened its new season last night with a revival of one of its early successes.

The American Enka Corporation has leased the tenth floor in the twenty-five-story Bank of New York Building to be erected at 530 Fifth Avenue, the east blockront between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.
SEVELEN, Germany, Oct. 24 -- Except for the greater abundance of game and the presence of the inevitable "jager," or gamekeeper, the shooting here is quite similar to that at home.

On Oct. 16 you published a letter by Herbert Pell, a former Congressman and diplomat. Mr. Pell suggests in his letter that the Vice President be allowed "to hold any other office to which he might be elected or appointed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Edmund F. Mansure, General Services Administrator, defended today his aide and appointee, Peter A. Strobel, from charges that Mr. Strobel had carried on "improper" business activities.
The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three and twelve months ended Sept. 30.

A registration statement covering the proposed offering of $100,000,000 of twenty-five-year convertible subordinated debentures of the Radio Corporation of America was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on last Friday, the company reported yesterday.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- A Soviet proposal to invite the Premiers of both West and East Germany to the Foreign Ministers' Conference here was immediately rejected by the West today.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Princess Margaret announced tonight that she had decided not to marry Group Capt. Peter Townsend.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Human blood contains a powerful agent called properdin, which may be harnessed by medical science as a new means of protection against disease and infection.

Atomic power will become generally economic throughout the United States only "sometime after the middle of the next decade," according to the head of the wartime Manhattan District atomic bomb project.

Yoshie Harada and Mitsuko Kuramoto, two of the twenty-five young women brought here from Hiroshima for plastic surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital, yesterday thanked the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York for having made the project possible.

A short dispatch in The New York Times, Oct. 12, entitled "Pope for Coexistence," prompts correction. It will be remembered that the Pope in his Easter message for 1955 specifically condemned coexistence as an evil in itself, and as a fruitless means of international relations.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Wes Santee, the nation's top mile runner, today was advised he had "five days" to appeal a "permanent suspension" handed to him by the Missouri Valley Amateur Athletic Union registration committee at a secret meeting here yesterday.

Michigan, which thrilled a national television audience by rallying for victory last Saturday, retained the No. 1 United Press College football rating yesterday. Oklahoma edged Maryland for the runner-up spot.
A record offering of highway bonds and large flotations of housing issues lifted the total of new bonds publicly offered here last month to a new high for an October.
With a victory in the nineteenth and final round, Mme. Olga Rubtsova of Russia won the women's chess challengers' tournament, according to a report received from Moscow yesterday.

One of the most famous vehicles in American literature is two hundred years old today -- or, rather, it would be if it had not fallen apart and gone to pieces at the end of exactly one century of hard service, "

New product on the way: Armour Co. is testing a ready-sliced margarine in twelve markets in Louisiana, Texas, North Carolina, Missouri, Ohio, Colorado and Florida. Full pages in newspapers and television spots are being used, with merchandising material, including retail advertising mats, supplied to retailers.
President Eisenhower, in a message to the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation that was made public yesterday, supported the group's emphasis on children as victims of crippling arthritis.

CORNWALL - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Bob Trocolar, the former Giant halfback now in his first season as head football coach at New York Military Academy, was downcast today. He had just been told he was losing two players.

Bonds called for redemption in October before maturity dropped to $73,864,000 from $235,241,000 in the preceding month and from $183,220,000 in October, 1954. The total last month was the smallest for an October since 1953, when $13,506,000 was redeemed.
A goal of $600,000 for the current campaign of the Young Men's Christian Association of New York City was announced last night.

CAIRO, Oct. 31 -- An Egyptian spokesman characterized as "malicious nonsense" today a report from Geneva that Egypt had promised the Soviet Union she would not honor her agreement to readmit Britain to the Suez Canal base in the event of war. The report appeared in The New York Times this morning.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 31 -- Israeli forces repelled an Egyptian raid today on a post in the Gaza strip area, an Army spokesman said here.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. L O., proposed yesterday a meeting of all unlicensed seamen's unions to work out a program of labor unity in the maritime industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Erich Maria Remarque's novel "A Time to Love and a Time to Die," will be made into a motion picture next year by Universal. Twenty-five years ago the company produced the memorable movie of the author's "All Quiet on the Western Front."

AGE cannot wither nor custom stale Bernard DeVoto's infinite pugnacity. Every month he comes out of "The Easy Chair,"* his corner of Harper's Magazine that is forever Benny, swinging a great brick and looking for a plate glass window to throw it through dramatically. And every month the howls go up as he finds his target.

The Maryland State Roads Commission plans to sell $15,000,000 of bonds on Nov. 15, it was announced yesterday. The offering will consist of State Highway Construction second issue, Series H securities, maturing from Nov. 1, 1956, to 1970.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- George Preston Marshall, owner of the Washington Redskins, today accused New York newspapers and radio and television stations of killing sports in the world's biggest city.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The sizzling production pace expected for the early stages of the 1956 model year in the car industry is beginning to take shape.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 31 -- Indochina's leading department store, the French-owned Grands Magasins Charner, is preparing to close down here some time next month.

A muscle research center is planned at 510-16 East Seventy-second and 511-15 East Seventy-first Streets by the Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America, Inc. The organization has purchased the property there from the Nansal Corporation. It plans to raze the present structures and erect a five-story building.

Mrs. Ann Eden Crowell Woodward was questioned for half an hour last night in Doctors Hospital about the fatal shooting of her husband in their Oyster Bay home early Sunday morning. She revised one key particular in her story.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- An atomic world war was rated today by the Army Chief of Staff as "increasingly improbable."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Small Business Administration denied today that it had conditioned the approval of a loan to a New York leather goods company on its removal to Maine.
Prices of cotton futures rose 2 to 41 points (10 cents to $2.05 a bale) yesterday in a moderate volume of business.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Independent Petroleum Association of America was told today by its leaders that the Government, if sustained in its present course, would have the power to determine prices and other terms of all natural gas sales contracts.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., Oct. 31 (UP) -- An enlisted man pinned the stars of a lieutenant general on the tunic of a crusty old leatherneck today. Thus did Gen. Lewis B. (Chesty) Puller bow out of active service with a final defiance of tradition.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- A United States delegate was accused here today of speaking only for the business interests of the country and ignoring the views of other groups.
Intricate equipment used by industry is largely responsible for one of America's fastest growing businesses -- the publication of technical manuals.

Employes of member concerns of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York will begin today a two-day donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street.

The First National City Bank announced yesterday an increase in interest rates on personal and consumer installment-type loans, effective on new loans today. Other leading banks in this field of lendig here indicated they would make similar increases.
A skeleton of a man was discovered yesterday afternoon in a shallow grave on the Fordham University campus in the Bronx.

Moss Hart and Harold Rome, two of the legitimate theatre's top-notch craftsmen, have completed a new musical comedy bearing the working title of "In the Pink." It will be brought to Broadway early next season by the producing team of Joseph M. Hyman and Bernard Hart.

In the definite renunciation of Sultan ben Arafa of any claims to the throne of Morocco a forward step has been made. This was supposed to be a part of the plan for a Council of Regency under which the eventual status of the Sultanate would be determined, but it is not working out that way.

Publicity men rarely are called upon to speak at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association. You must be at least a scout or an assistant coach to be singled out by Joseph M. Sheehan, the chairman. Ted Emery, Dartmouth's public relations director, was given the chance that many other press agents would have relished -- an audience of metropolitan scribes -- yesterday at Toots Shor's.

The proposal to cut a four-lane highway through Washington Square Park, the smallest park in the city, as reported in The New York Times, is clearly the brainchild of Park Commissioner Moses and the Department of Parks itself.

The engine horsepower of the 1956 Oldsmobile line has been increased and a new automatic transmission has been added. The cars in three series, the 88, the Super 88 and the 98, were announced yesterday by Oldsmobile division General Motors Corporation.

How others conduct the business of homemaking will he revealed at a tour of seven private and three professional kitchens the afternoon of Nov. 15. Proceeds will be divided between the Yorkville Youth Council, Inc., and the Parents League of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Senator William F. Knowland very likely will become an active aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination within three or four months.
Sale of the physical assets, inventories and business of the Continental Foundry and Machine Company to the Blaw-Knox Company of Pittsburgh was approved yesterday by stockholders of Continental.
Army marches on the Yale Bowl this week and Notre Dame, reinvested with its glamor of old under its young head coach, Terry Brennan, makes its only Eastern appearance, against Penn.

Short covering firmed copper prices yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The near-by positions were strongest. Trading was influenced by a strike in the Chilean mines. Profit taking and dealer selling supplied the contracts.

Completely deadlocked over the interdependent main issues of German unification and European security, the Big Four foreign ministers have set aside for the moment the equally difficult problem of disarmament and have tackled the third and last item on their agenda.

Chemstrand Corporation announced yesterday a reduction of 20 per cent in the price of Acrilan acrylic fiber, effective today. Trade observers believe the move might give impetus to a general reduction in prices of acrylic and competing fibers.
THE Midas touch has magically transformed a corner of Bloomingdale's Basement into the "Pavillon d'Or," the store's newest import shop.
