PENDLETON, Ore., Oct. 31 -- An Oregon farm leader proposed today that Congress delegate legislative authority and allot $500,000,000 to a farmer-operated milk board to help solve problems of the dairy industry.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- Moshe Sharett made a Russian-language appeal to Vyacheslav M. Molotov this evening not to ignite a war in the Middle East by arming the Arab states.

DENVER, Oct. 31 -- The Eisenhower Administration again will seek increased postal rates. Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, said today that the Administration probably would ask the next session of Congress for rate rises in all classes of mail, including an increase to four cents for first class and seven cents for airmail. The Administration failed in a similar attempt in the last session.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney announced today an inquiry beginning Nov. 8 into the "structure, policies, practices and operations" of the General Motors Corporation.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was allowed to "carry the ball" alone in his search for Communists during 1953 and 1954, three subcommittee colleagues testified today.

One day soon, a woman wearing the sash of the United Hospital Fund will ask you to drop a contribution into her blue collection box. She is one of several thousand volunteers in the city who will seek contributions for the benefit of the eighty-two voluntary, nonprofit hospitals that are members of the fund.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The House of Commons rejected tonight a motion castigating the Government for its economic policies. The vote was 329 to 261.

TORONTO, Nov. 1 (Tuesday) (Canadian Press) -- The Globe and Mail says today that the Dominion Government has approved a plan for an all-Canadian natural gas pipeline that involves construction by a Government company of the section through northern Ontario.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- With Maria Meneghini Callas and Bellini as principal ingredients, the Lyric Theatre of Chicago opened its second season here tonight in the opera house that Samuel Insull built in another boom era.

Directors of Bellanca Aircraft Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of twenty-four shares of common stock of Glenn Uranium Mines, Ltd., of Canada for each 100 shares of Bellanca common held, payable on Dec. 12.
Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New Haven Railroad, was an hour and nine minutes late getting to work yesterday morning on his own railroad.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- A top-ranking Protestant leader proposed tonight that a United States interfaith conference be called immediately to seek a solution to the Arab-Israeli crisis.
Claims for tax refunds totaling $117,559,426 were filed yesterday with the United States Internal Revenue Board by Schenley Industries, Inc., the second largest company in the liquor industry.
The Lincoln Hotel was warned by Magistrate Jack L. Nicoll yesterday to clear up a series of building violation by Nov. 21 or "you'll have trouble."
Events today: Herbert Burtis, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Walton's "Troilus and Cressida," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15 P. M.
Robert Moses accused Senator Herbert H. Lehman yesterday of being more interested in fomenting a political issue than in getting additional public hydroelectric power for New York.
A plan whereby large hospitals would pool their resources in a cancer treatment research project was outlined before the American Cancer Society here yesterday.

No matter how little or how much the second Geneva conference accomplishes, it will not establish one of the fundamental prerequisites for a genuine and lasting world peace: the re-establishment of a dependable balance of strength in Europe.

High Voltage of the Wheatley Stable received the decision by photograph over Howard A. Flanigan's Two Stars at Jamaica yesterday. The race, called the Stamford Handicap, was a stiring one, and the winner was the 21-20 favorite with the crowd of 20,773.
The advancement of the scientific departments of the American Museum of Natural History, with emphasis on research, was advocated yesterday in the institution's eighty-sixth annual report.

States Marine Lines has become the second private American steamship line within a month to consider the Maritime Administration's new Seafarer-type cargo vessel for future fleet replacement and expansion.
Stock prices dropped sharply last month, with the averages registering the largest monthly decline since August, 1953.
BERLIN, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Gian-Carlo Menotti's modern opera, "The Saint of Bleecker Street," had a moderate reception at West Berlin's City Opera House last night.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- France's Parliament bowled over six more proposals for changing the election law today without moving appreciably closer to a compromise.
" The Tender Trap," the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer version of the stage play, starring Frank Sinatra and Debbie Reynolds, will have its premiere here on Nov. 10 at the Radio City Music Hall.

The Colgate-Palmolive Company announced yesterday the formation of Premium Associates, Inc., an independent company that will take over the function of the Octagon premium plan, cooperative coupon-redeeming organization.
The chief steward of a cargo ship was held in $75,000 bail yesterday on a charge of smuggling $75,000 of "exceptional cut and polished diamonds" into this country.

SEYMOUR FRANKS' abstractions at the Peridot Gallery, 820 Madison Avenue, are more robust and confidently constructed than ever before. In his most recent canvases, Franks uses a glistening white ground as foil for the powerful movements of short, curving forms applied with the flat of a broad brush. Franks' high-color gamut keeps many of his compositions near the surface, with interest focused in the diagonal thrust of forms.

GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- West German spokesmen in Geneva and Bonn described as "unacceptable" today the Soviet proposal to invite the heads of West and East German Governments to participate in the discussions on Germany.
TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 31 -- Sun power still is a losing proposition in dollars and cents. But experts agree that its prospects never have looked so good.

Recommendations that top management should stop considering advertising a stepchild and that advertising executives stop considering their work as an only child were put yesterday before the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers.

THE BIG of heart and small of pocketbook may want to take a look at Macy's knitwear show, being presented Wednesday at 3:30 P. M. and Thursday at 3 P. M. and 7 P.M. It offers good ideas for Christmas giving -- if not this year, then next. Most of the designs are creations of Macy's young art needlework buyer, and are as cheerful as Santa Claus.

Yesterday marked the tenth annual presentation of the Lasker Awards by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation to individual physicians and groups for outstanding contributions to medical knowledge and for distinguished service in public health administration.
Packaging -- now a $12,000,000,000-a-year item -- is becoming increasingly decisive in business success or failure, the seventeenth annual forum of the Packaging Institute heard yesterday.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 31 -- The Foreign Commerce Committee of the American Association of Port Authorities reported here today that "the national Administration has created a new feeling of confidence among traders at home and abroad."

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A military court of honor expelled Juan D. Peron today from the Army from which he had risen to dictatorship. The tribunal declared him guilty of "the gravest offenses," including an affair with a teen-aged girl.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Defense Mobilizer Arthur S. Flemming told importers of crude oil from the Middle East today that they must cut imports about 7 per cent over the next few months, or face the possibility of Government curbs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Eugene Meyer's eightieth birthday was celebrated by his friends and relatives today. They established a chair of medicine in his honor at George Washington University here.

GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- Secretary of State Dulles announced today that the State Department would lift its restrictions on travel by United States citizens to the Soviet Union and all but two of its East European satellites.

The domestic steel industry set a production record last week. Operating for the first time this year at 100 per cent of rated capacity, the steel-makers turned out 2,413,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The State Superintendent of Insurance has urged Governor Harriman to propose the creation of an unsatisfied-judgment fund as a substitute for compulsory automobile insurance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee today began examining proposals for disaster insurance. Plans to insure, with Government help, home owners, businesses and farmers against severe losses from such disasters as floods, military attacks and smogs, are to be investigated.
LONDON, Oct 31 -- Princess Margaret's decision not to marry Group Capt. Peter Townsend has been received here with sympathy and admiration approaching awe.

TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 31 -- A single-celled plant, using solar energy for growth, has been found to produce proteins "equal to the best animal protein of milk and eggs," it was reported today at the University of Arizona symposium on solar energy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Warner Brothers has no set policy at present about putting its feature pictures on television and "will entertain any offers for selling to television." This statement was made today by Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Irving Asher, veteran film producer and production executive, today was named general manager in charge of all Twentieth Century - Fox's television activity. His appointment is designed to lessen the work of Sid Rogell, the company's executive production manager, who established T. F. C. Productions, Fox's television subsidiary, as an operating outlet.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 31 -- Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney was installed today as twelfth president of Brown University at ceremonies in Sayles Hall.

GENEVA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Following are remarks by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, today on the question of European security and the text of a Soviet proposal for a European security pact and a disarmed zone:
WITH technical glitter unabated and with musical gifts that are still a puzzle, Leonard Pennario returned to Town Hall in a piano recital last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The United States called on the General Assembly today to set up a special committee to collect information on the production of radioactive materials from nuclear materials.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The American medical profession was urged tonight to persuade Arab physicians to cooperate with Israeli physicians on mutual health problems that can result in the "saving of thousands of lives annually" in the Middle East.

Stockholders of the American European Securities Company are being offered subscription rights for 91,875 additional shares of common stock, no par value, at $28 a share, in the ratio of one new share for each four held. The subscription offer will expire Nov. 22.

We discussed yesterday six constitutional amendments and one proposition that, in our opinion, deserve a Yes vote in referendum at next Tuesday's election in New York State. Four other amendments we oppose for the reasons offered here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The United States eased restrictions on travel behind the Iron Curtain today. But it will continue to withhold validation of passports for visits to Communist China, North Korea, North Vietnam, Bulgaria and Albania.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- A generally stronger trend developed in grain and soybean futures today, without anything special in the way of bullish news to stimulate the demand.

When the U. N. Assembly's First Committee finished with the atoms-for-peace resolution last week the British spokesman, Sir Pierson Dixon, suggested that it proceed with a discussion of atomic radiation. As he put it, "We are, so to speak, in an atomic mood."

IN FRANCE, tourists rely on the famous Guide Michelin for accurate, impartial appraisals of restaurants throughout the country. Within two years Italy, which till now has lacked a comparable handbook, hopes to have an equally honest, if somewhat less comprehensive, guide.

The Pittsburgh Steel Company in the first nine months this year cleared a net income of $4,720,760, an increase of 490 per cent over the $800,310 earned in the 1954 period. As a result, directors yesterday declared a 25-cent cash dividend and 1 per cent in stock on the Common, payable Dec. 1.
City improvements costing a record $791,736,038 are proposed in the 1956 capital budget approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The issue of what is bargaining collectively "in good faith" was posed in new and curious form last week by the split decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals here in a case growing out of a deliberate slow-down of work by a union during the process of bargaining with an employer.

A former commissioner of the State Liquor Authority was accused yesterday as the "chief fixer" in corrupt activities of the department here. J. Irwin Shapiro, State Commissioner of Investigation, linked him and other officials to irregularities occurring in the department from 1950 to the beginning of this year.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- Governor Harriman called today for a congressional investigation of charges that a New York City leather goods factory had been asked to leave the state to qualify for a Federal loan.

The political device known as the trial balloon is not exactly a new one; there is reason to believe that nearly every government has employed it at one time or another when it wished to know, without committing itself, what the public's reaction would be to a certain course of action.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The Soviet Union accepted under protest today a 0.2 per cent increase in its share of the United Nations budget. It then voted approval of the new scale of dues for the first time in United Nations history.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 31 -- A gift load of equipment sent here from Miami Beach, Fla., as a "two-thousand-mile message of mercy" for Fairfield County flood victims, was identified today as junk by Francis H. Delaney, executive director of the Stamford Red Cross.

John Singer Sargent is the subject of a biography by Charles Merrill Mount, also a portraitist, which Norton will publish next Tuesday. "John Singer Sargent" is based on the author's research of five years and the assistance of members of Sargent's family and of friends and sitters who were close to him during his lifetime.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- Secretary of State Dulles and Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, dined tonight with Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister.
A gunman held up a salesman and a jeweler yesterday in the Jewelry Mart Building, 83 Canal Street, near Eldridge Street. He escaped with $25,000 worth of cut diamonds.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers wrote he apparent end to an illustrious football career today by reeasing Fullback Marion Motley, he one-time terror of the Naional Football League.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean received the Combat Infantryman's Badge today, his last day as an American fighting man.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Representative John W. McCormack warned here tonight that the "world situation has worsened considerably" since the meeting of the Big Four at Geneva. He urged an immediate return to what he called the "Roosevelt-Truman policy of peace through strength."

The Fruehauf Trailer Company realized a 71 per cent increase in earnings in the first nine months of 1955 on a sales gain of 45 per cent compared with last year, according to the report of Roy Fruehauf, president, released today.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Cooperation between publishers of news in the United States has been emulated almost everywhere in the world, the annual meeting of the New York State Associated Press association was told here tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told the Inter-American Press Association today that its 11th annual meeting "augurs well for the future friendship and progress of all of us who live in the Western Hemisphere."

Gen. Mark W. Clark, retired, warned the Western democracies last night against being "anesthetized" by Russian smiles at Geneva or elsewhere. He suggested that they find "some new methods" of getting "ironclad guarantees" that the Soviet Union would live up to its agreements.

THE National Broadcasting Company's "Matinee Theatre" had its debut yesterday afternoon. It is quite probable that housewives could not believe their eyes. For here is a presentation that has nothing whatsoever to do with "daytime television" as the phrase is commonly understood. "Matinee Theatre" could give an evening's performance on anybody's network.
The International Longshoremen's Association entered three new charges yesterday against the Waterfront Commission in the second day of hearings before the unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- D. B. Sole of South Africa denied today that his Government had incorporated into its area the territory of South-West Africa.

ANYONE who thinks that Halloween no longer produces strange and weird events should have been in St. Marks Place last night in the vicinity of Cooper Union. There, the Tempo Playhouse, off-Broadway's off-beat theatre, introduced Eugene Ionesco's "Amedee," subtitled "How to Disentangle Yourself."
Danny Giovanelli of Brooklyn made a successful return to the welterweight division last night at St. Nicholas Arena.

Plans have been completed for Pets on Parade Festival in St. Moritz, a dinner-dance for the benefit of the Mobile Clinic of the Speyer Hospital for Animals. Mrs. Robert H. Minton is chairman for the event, which will take place Thursday on the St. Regis Roof.

Sales and earnings of the Armco Steel Corporation in the first nine months of this year topped all previous records for any similar three-quarter period, Charles R. Hook, chairman, reported yesterday.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Four of the seven foreign thoroughbreds entered in Laurel's $65,000 Washington, D. C., International on Nov. 11 arrived by chartered airplane today.

Exhibitors, judges and members of international jumping teams who will participate in the National Horse Show were the guests yesterday at a reception and cocktail party in the Serf Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The party was given by Walter B. Devereux, president, and the other officers of the National Horse Show Association.
Plans to stage a high school track meet at Madison Square Garden the afternoon of the Millrose Games on Feb. 4 are stymied for want of $1,600.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Clarence G. Morse, Federal Maritime Administrator, and spokesmen for ship operators today endorsed legislation to make the United States Maritime Academy at Kings Point, N. Y., a permanent institution They also favored continuing Federal aid to similar state academies.

VIENNA, Oct. 29 -- One of the problems to which the Hungarian Communists have devoted most effort and attention has been how to enlist intellectuals in their cause. Their success has worried the West.
Milky neon intermittently emblazons the night over No. 888 on Grand Concourse in the Bronx, blinking: "SULLIVAN'S HEADQUARTERS."

A team of doctors that advanced cardiac surgery, a group of tuberculosis researchers and the discoverer of the anticoagulant dicumarin were among the recipients of Albert Lasker Awards in medical research and public health administration, announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- Soviet national income is running 10 per cent above last year's level, according to an editorial published today in Pravda.

Two six-story buildings containing a total of three storeis and sixty-six apartments at 329-335 East Ninety-fourth Street have passed to new ownership. Fred H Hill, as president of the Karyvon Realty Corporation, had contracted to buy the property from Helen Goldman and Elizabeth Skoluda, but he has resold the realty to the Phoebe Corporation and Associates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas of Guatemala arrived here this afternoon for a state visit.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- Well - informed circles believe there has been a tacit agreement that Fritz Schaeffer, Minister of Finance, should succeed Chancellor Konrad Adenauer if his post becomes vacant.
The Jacob Ruppert brewery, whose late owner made the New York Yankees a power in the baseball world, made a deal yesterday to sponsor the New York Giants radio and television broadcasts.
HONG KONG, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Four United States civilians came out of captivity in Communist China today. One, a woman student, promptly said she wanted to go back as a "friend."
The Jacob Ruppert brewery, whose late owner made the New York Yankees a power in the baseball world, made a deal yesterday to sponsor the New York Giants radio and television broadcasts.
HONG KONG, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Four United States civilians came out of captivity in Communist China today. One, a woman student, promptly said she wanted to go back as a "friend."
NEPTUNE TOWNSHIP, N. J., Wednesday, Nov. 2 -- A man suspected of the fatal shooting of a state trooper on the Garden State Parkway last night was shot to death here early today.

ATHENS, Nov. 1 -- Press reports from Patras, in the northern Peloponnesos, said that several score high school boys fought the police today in an attempt to attack the premises of the United States Information Service and the Institute of English Studies, a British concern.

Many new technical terms have crept into football's vocabulary while some fans weren't listening. Among them is "ride series." That's the designation for one of the most effective play sequences of the modern T formation.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The American College of Surgeons said today it would investigate to determine whether its members were charging too much for operations.

The voters of New York City at next Tuesday's election will elect thirty-three judges of our courts. The layman is ill-qualified to choose among candidates for judicial posts. Certainly the political affiliation of the candidate is an untrustworthy or insufficient criterion of judgment.
Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, offered yesterday the "fullest cooperation with any Senate investigation of company operations."
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 1 -Two of New Jersey's oldest weekly newspapers, The Princeton Packet and The Hopewell Herald, announced their merger today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon denounced the Soviet Union today for surrounding itself with satellites. He called on all the Americas to band for peace and progress in the Western Hemisphere.

THE British motion picture industry's invasion of American television would hardly seem a laughing matter for Hollywood. This coming Sunday, in choice evening time, the facilities of two coast-to-coast chains will be turned over to the exhibition of English films.

AT WEEK'S end the old frame farmhouses and the yellow-brick chateau-style retreat house of the Cenacle of St. Regis, on Riverside Drive between 139th and 140th Streets, will go dark, probably forever.
A memorial fund honoring Neysa McMein, painter, illustrator and writer, has been established at the Whitney Museum of American Art for the annual purchase of work by living American artists.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 1 -- The chief of mobilization planning for the Interstate Commerce Commission revealed today plan for utilizing ports during wartime emergencies.
ALBANY, Nov. 1 -- Governor Harriman predicted today that the state would close the current fiscal year on March 31 with a surplus.
Confronted with several sharp increases in the cost of scrap steel over the last several months, a small New England steel mill has decided to reflect those advances in its price of finished steel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The food industry is on the threshold of packing developments which will shift store level processing and packaging of perishable commodities to a centrally located operation in a factory or packing plant, a grocery executive said today.

THE Brooklyn Philharmonia, which gave three concerts last May, opened its second season last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Again the orchestra was led by Siegfried Landau. The program was devoted to Mozart in honor of the bicentennial of the composers birth.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Nov. 1 -- The disappearance yesterday of 3-year-old Stephen Damman assumed the outlines of a kidnapping tonight. The Federal Bureau of Investigation entered the case and Nassau County's biggest search was called off at nightfall.
Governor Harriman said yesterday he was "very much" satisfied with the State Liquor Authority report by his Commissioner of Investigation but had no plans for any further inquiry upstate.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- Responsible unofficial sources said today that Vyacheslav M. Molotov had told Premier Moshe Sharett that in arming Egypt the Soviet Union intended not to harm Israel but to undercut the Western-sponsored Middle East alliance.
A convicted burglar admitted last night that he had broken into the garage and bathhouse of the Woodward estate at Oyster Bay last Friday night.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 1 -East Germany's Communists issued a policy declaration today calling for increased work norms in industry and setting forth conditions for German unification.
A recent substantial decline in the price of fresh butter-fish has brought it to the moderate level of 40 cents a pound, according to the City Department of Markets.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- If you want to know when Odorless Decoration Week is (Jan. 1-7), or possibly even One Dish Meals With Cheese Week (in Lent), the United States Chamber of Commerce can tell you.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges were dull and generally lower yesterday. Cocoa, coffee, rubber, hides, zinc and copper eased; cottonseed oil, potatoes and onions rose, and sugar, soybean oil and wool closed mixed.

Dot and Dash all but spelled out an SOS for a keeper at the Bronx Zoo yesterday. The two Ds are cheetahs. Usually they are quiet and gentle, but yesterday they were in high spirits and seemed to take Keeper Fred Martini's' entry into their cage as a signal to "get the show on the road."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Stockholders of The Cincinnati Enquirer of record of Nov. 28 will receive a dividend of 30 cents a share on Dec. 14. The newspaper has paid a 30-cent annual dividend since employes sparked a drive to purchase the publication in 1952.
The State Rent Administrator yesterday called for a deeper understanding of the status of immigrant minority groups here.
CAIRO, Nov. 1 -- Afghanistan will seek arms from the Soviet Union if she cannot obtain them from the West, according to Salaheddin Salgooky, Afghan Ambassador to Egypt.

Miss Weesie handled the top weight and an odds-on opponent with equal ease in the feature at Jamaica yesterday. The 5-year- old owned by Thomas White engaged five rivals, including the 7-to-10 Another World, in the mile-and-a-sixteenth event for fillies and mares, and she won by a length.

Northern States Power Company (Minnesota) and subsidiaries achieved in the third quarter of this year "the greatest percentage increase experienced in operating revenues in any quarter in the past twelve months," according to Allen S. King, president.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Studies that appear to establish "normal" values for twenty-three vital factors in the body's chemical composition were reported today at the annual meeting of the American College of Surgeons.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- Measured by achievements, the Foreign Ministers' Conference here is not expected to move very far or very fast. But the officials of foreign ministries who help guide it are in almost constant motion.

MUENSTER, Germany, Oct. 25 -- German hunters are few in number compared to the millions who follow the sport at home. This may account for the formality of method and attire that is practiced almost to the point of ritual.
The New York City Anti-Crime Committee announced yesterday the appointment of William A. Giustiniani as senior staff investigator, replacing William J. Keating, who was forced to resign last spring.
The sixty - seventh National Horse Show began in Madison Square Garden yesterday with splendor inside the ring and out and with victories for Ireland and Mexico in the international team jumping.
Mayor Wagner repeated yesterday that Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy would have a free hand in running the Police Department.
NEWPORT, R. I., Nov. 1 -Capt. Liles W. Creighton, commander of the Newport Naval Station, outlined proposals today for developing the base to a comparable position with that at Norfolk, Va.

BELGIAN endive now can be purchased for as little as 20 cents a pound in some stores. Certainly this is a reasonable price for the imported vegetable, which adds crispness and distinctive flavor to salads.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Toparoa, lightly weighted at 106 pounds, today beat off the challenge of the heavily favored Rising Fast to win the Melbourne Cup, Australia's racing classic, by three-quarters of a length.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Blasts from an air-raid siren nearly silenced United States-Russian housing talks today. The Soviet delegates did not like it.

Wanted: Mature women to work in corset departments. When corset buyers, store personnel executives, and industry figures met yesterday at the Fashion Institute of Technology to discuss a program of corsetiering education, the central fact that emerged was that corset departments were finding it exceedingly difficult to attract new personnel.
DENVER, Nov. 1 -- President Eisenhower is expected to leave the hospital and return to Washington Nov. 11.

The indefatigable mayor of San Juan is in town for a day, keeping a round-the-clock schedule just as on the island, hoping to raise a loan for municipal improvements for San Juan, visiting New York schools of Puerto Rican density to talk to the Spanish-speaking youngsters, earnestly talking with New York leaders in many walks of life to help correct distorted views that many New Yorkers have about the Puerto Rican newcomers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- The seven-week-old trial of the Government's 16-mm anti-trust suit against five motion-picture companies ended today in Federal Court in Los Angeles.

Richmond is the city's only county where voters next week will choose a Borough President and City Councilman in an election that ordinarily would include only the District Attorney and judicial posts.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, has been designated by the Government as the central agency for the distribution of surplus American food in Israel.
Countless premium payers may take heart from an announcement yesterday by one of the nation's biggest mutual insurance companies.

A radically new synthetic base for photographic film has been developed to make it tougher and more durable. Only two-thirds as thick as the present cellulose triacetate bases, it is soon to be put on the market by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.
Former Iron Curtain diplomats should not be granted American citizenship unless they make a clean breast of their past, Representative Francis E. Walter said here yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- The Girl Scouts' national president urged 6,000 scout leaders today to tell young persons "how to lose" along with exhorting them to play to win.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Willie Hartack returned to action today after a ten-day suspension and rode three winners at Laurel to lift his leading total in the country to 357 for this year.

Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and associates will offer today 40,000 shares of outstanding capital stock of Houdry Process Corporation petroleum refining research company. The stock will be priced at $35.50 a share.

Directors of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, Inc., yesterday elected Walter E. Branson vice president in charge of distribution, Daniel T. O'Shea, president, announced. Formerly world-wide sales manager, Mr. Branson began his film career in Omaha in 1922 as a booker for Pathe, Inc.
Following is the text of the reply of the American Newspaper Publishers Association:

Buick has built eighty-eight engineering and styling advances into its 1956 line. Among these are a redesigned chassis to add to riding ease and increased horsepower for the V-8-type engines. The eighteen new models were announced yesterday by Ivan L. Wiles, general manager, Buick division, General Motors Corporation.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- Statesmen are today so agitated that one might think perpetual motion is diplomacy. Mr. Sharett flew back to Jerusalem to hand over the Israeli Government and a valise full of vague big-power promises. His envoys are skittering off to Western capitals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Consumer credit in September moderated somewhat its tremendous upward surge.

IN celebration of the silver anniversary of American Art Week, the American Artists Professional League is holding an exhibition at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. In the division of paintings, the first, second and third prizes were bestowed in order on Walter E. Baum, Dahli-Sterne and Grace C. Solman.
Thirty candidates were on hand for the opening of practice yesterday as Nat Holman started his thirty-fifth year as City College basketball coach.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -Calvin R. Griffith today gained the position for which his foster father had groomed him -- president of the Washington Senators baseball club.

Directors of American Machine and Foundry Company yesterday declared a stock dividend of one share of common stock for each fifty shares of common, payable on Dec. 15. The board also voted the regular dividend of 25 cents a share on the common, payable on Dec. 10.
Net shipments and earnings of the Gaylord Container Corporation and its subsidiaries in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 increased over the corresponding periods last year.
RATON, N. M., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Liquidation of the St. Louis, Rocky Mountain and Pacific Company was voted today by its stockholders in a special meeting.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -Expansion of social welfare services, both public and private, "at least" 15 per cent in the next ten years, was urged tonight.

DEAR Mother, Mary, Anne, Barbara, Gan-Gan, Spike Susan: How are you my beloved family? I am fine, I have been reading in book form "Year of Decisions,"* President Harry S. Truman's splendidly informal memoirs, the most readable Presidential volume about what really goes on in the White House that we have had since Polk's diaries were published a long, long time ago.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- The French Government and the exiled Sultan of Morocco, Mohammed ben Youssef, effected a formal reconciliation today.
Almost from the introduction of scrimmage in place of the rugby "scrum" and the creation of his position in 1880, the quarterback has been the glamour boy of football.
Cotton futures fell 1 to 34 points (5 cents to $1.70 a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. December showed relatively greater strength than other months.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 1 -- President Izhak Ben-Zvi tried today to bring about a broadly based new Government.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Nov. 1 -- Gov. Robert E. Meyner today envisioned a chain of parking lots on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River connected to New York City transportation facilities by express bus service. As a starter, he dedicated the first such lot on the Lincoln Tunnel approach highway here.

The women's challengers' chess tournament ended in Moscow yesterday with the completion of four adjourned games, according to a Soviet report. Mme. Olga Rubtsova of Russia already had clinched the title and Mme. Larissa Volpert, Russia, finished as runner-up.

MADRID, Nov. 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles surely would have been astonished to hear before his arrival in Madrid today that many Spaniards thought he was coming as the envoy of Vyacheslav M. Molotoy, the Soviet Foreign Minister.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- The United States indicated tonight it was trying to persuade the Soviet Union to lift the veto power paralysis that has barred United Nations membership to new countries.

The Inter-American Press Association, which will conclude its eleventh annual meeting tomorrow in New Orleans, has grown steadily in influence and become an effective champion of freedom of the press in the Western Hemisphere. It plays a useful role in bringing together editors and publishers from all twenty- one countries of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- House investigators today summoned Defense Mobilizer Arthur S. Flemming to explain how crude oil companies are expected to comply with an Administration request that they voluntarily cut imports.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- Army expects its passing attack to be a valuable part of its offense from now on. Coach Earl Blaik believes the cadets will have an adequate aerial attack to supplement the football team's strong ground game when the squad meets Yale in the bowl at New Haven on Saturday.

TEEN-AGERS often have as low an opinion of their mothers' telephone conversations as the mothers have of theirs. Whereas grown-ups complain that the young people talk too long -- and to friends they last saw only an hour before -- the adolescents hold that adult telephone talk is often fruitless and meaningless.
ALBANY, Nov. 1 -- Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays resigned today as New York's representative on the bi-state Waterfront Commission. He did so at Governor Harriman's request.
MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- One of the Soviet Union's leading film scenarists has emerged from long years of obscurity to write the first post-war Soviet film with a contemporary French setting.
It is costly to keep hospitals ready to serve you and your family twenty-four hours a day. The antibiotics that effect cures so miraculously are expensive.

If the matter were not so serious it would be amusing to watch Foreign Minister Molotov, the "old Bolshevik," squirm and twist to escape from the binding Geneva directive calling for German unification within the framework of European security to which the newer Soviet rulers, Messrs.

Two large offerings of new public utility common stock will be offered to investors today to expand the equity base of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and the Southern Company, a holding company enterprise.
A possibility was raised yesterday that the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus might open next spring at the Polo Grounds instead of at Madison Square Garden.
Two sopranos, Madelaine Chambers and Emilia Cundari, have been engaged by the Metropolitan Opera for the current season.

The Long Island Rail Road -- the nation's most heavily traveled passenger carrier -- had total revenues of $45,659,022 in the first nine months this year. The company was able to retain a little more than 3 cents of every dollar collected.

TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 1 -- The current general belief that the single-celled green plants, named algae, are efficient producers of food and other products with the aid of solar energy is based on an illusion, it was declared here today.
NAGOYA, Japan, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The New York Yankees defeated the Chunichi Dragons, 1954 professional league champions of Japan, 7 -- 0, today before 30,000 fans.
MONTREAL, Nov. 1 (Canadian Press) -- R. M. Fowler, president of the Newsprint Association of Canada, today sounded a warning of an immediate shortage of newsprint.

The State of Florida Board of Education sold bond issues totaling $10,567,000 yesterday to finance the construction of schools in six counties. The money was borrowed on serial bonds maturing from 1973 to 1976.
The formal opening of the sixty - seventh National Horse Show took place last night at Madison Square Garden before a distinguished audience.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -The Department of Commerce reported yesterday that manufacturers' sales totaled $27,700,000,000 in September, slightly higher than in August and $4,000,000,000 higher than September, 1954.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- After the first round of discussions at the world wheat conference, which ended here today, the prospects of a renewal of the International Wheat Agreement have considerably improved.

I have read with interest the various suggestions published in your paper to improve the city's transit system. But it surprises me not to see anyone referring to one step which is so obvious and practicable, easy and consequently relatively cheap, and at the same time so important to supply the city with another crosstown and interborough link in the rapid transit system.
The Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration announced yesterday that it had scheduled nineteen flights this month for more than 1,200 immigrants to the United States.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Prime Minister Eden conferred with leaders of the Trades Union Congress today on the economic situation and the supplementary budget given to Parliament last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, ordered today an honorable discharge for former First Lieut. Walter K. Novak. Mr. Novak, 28 years old, had received a "general discharge" in a guilt-by-kinship security case last August.

Cardinal Brush Co., painters' supplies; Senior Paper Products, in 37 E. 28th St.; Millie Garment Co. Inc., women's wear; Stan Wanderman Inc., women's wear, in 1359 Broadway; Contessa Inc., women's wear, in 501 7th Ave.; William Skora, artist, in 55 W 44th St.; Semigran Lingerie Co. Inc., children's underwear, in 599 Broadway; Chase Manhattan Bank, in 200 4th Ave. -Helmsley-Spear Inc., brokers.
Ann Harding and Wendell Corey have read the script of "The Morgan Rock," the new drama by Phillip Pruneau, and have promised producers Paul Vroom and Adna Karns to co-star in it.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle, star outfielder for the New York Yankees, left for the United States today.

Nearly forty-four years have gone by since Roald Amundsen reached the South Pole; a little less than that time since Captain Robert Falcon Scott and four companions gained it, only to die on the cruel return journey; more than a quarter of a century since Admiral Richard E. Byrd and his crew flew from Little America to the South Pole and back.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 1 -- The projected $5,800,000 plant of the Westchester Community College will have a campus of at least 100 acres, County Executive James D. Hopkins reported today.
Money draws interest in advertisements. Advertisers evidently believe so, judging from the increasing use of coin photographs in advertising.

'Archbishop S[epinac .High ofI White Plains'. swept individual and team honors yesterday in the twentieth R-,ual ' Bronxlvranhat{anWestchester cross, country championship of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Vn Cortlandt Prk.

MARGARET STERN, who last played in this city in 1951, gave a Town Hall piano recital last night. She impressed as a vigorous young artist whose performances need more thought and finish, but who has plenty of talent.
VIENNA, Oct. 30 -- The seven-year struggle between communism and religion in Hungary has become a sort of siege warfare.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 1 -- The Democratic party is engaged in an all-out drive to alter the political complexion of South Jersey. The area, with the exception of this city, has been a Republican stronghold for more than sixty years.
Three new film programs open at first-run theatres today.
Robert Moses made a conditional offer yesterday to sell the Coliseum and its integrated office building to speculators at its $35,000,000 cost.

"How Communists Negotiate," by Admiral C. Turner Joy, U. S. N. (Ret.), will be published by Macmillan on Nov. 22. For two years as senior delegate of the United Nations Command at the Korean armistice conferences, Admiral Joy observed the bargaining methods of the Communists. His book is a record of what he saw and learned.

The Marris Steel Company has leased a one-story industrial building at 120 Fiftieth Street, in the Bush Terminal section of Brooklyn. The building, containing 20,000 square feet of space, will be used by the lessee for the manufacture of steel kitchen cabinets and related items.
CAIRO, Nov. 1 (UP) -- United States Ambassador Henry A. Byroade and seven visiting members of the United States Congress held separate conferences with Premier Nasser today.

An option for acquisition of a leasehold interest in the office building at 370 Lexington Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-first Street, which was granted early this year, has been exercised, it was announced yesterday.

The average price of realty sales in the Bronx during the third quarter of this year showed a decrease of two points to 111 per cent of assessed valuation. As was the case in the second quarter, the decline was the net effect of relatively minor increases and decreases among the more numerous types of property.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association asked the Federal District Court here yesterday to dismiss a complaint charging it with violations of the Sherman anti-trust act.
MRS. GERTRUDE FRANKEL committed herself in her youth to do "what fascinates me" -- and she is still holding to her bargain.

LONGMONT, Colo., Nov. 1 -- A United Air Lines four-engined DC-6B caught fire in flight and crashed near here in a blinding explosion tonight. All forty-four persons aboard were killed and wreckage was scattered over a half-mile area.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Diplomatic officials said today Afghanistan was expected to accept a Czechoslovak offer of arms.

Senator Lehman deserves public support for his forthright efforts to get the Federal Government to come to grips with the problems of disaster relief. It is he who has sparked the hearings on the subject by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- The Soviet Union's campaign to win friends in Asia and Africa moved another step forward tonight.

A 40-year-old treasurer of a stationery supply house who liked to "live beyond his means" was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court. He was charged with the theft of more than $100,000 from his company since August, 1948.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Nov. 1 -- Plans are being made to hold Tanganyika's first election within the next few years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- The United States, Britain, Australia and Canada proposed today that the General Assembly establish a special committee to collect information on the amount of radiation that is given off by nuclear materials.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The British people paid tribute today to the example of courage given by Princess Margaret.

Not even higher earnings and increased dividends could shatter the lethargy of the stock market yesterday. On the smallest turnover in two weeks -- 1,590,000 shares, against 1,800,000 on Monday -- stocks made small changes, for the most part in the small fractions.

Pasquale Ferrone, 48 years old, business agent of Local 1235, International Longshore-men's Association, pleaded guilty yesterday to attempted extortion. The case involved the unloading of furs, boycotted by the dockmen's union, at Elizabeth. N. J., five years ago. General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen continued Ferrone in $10,000 bail for sentencing Dec. 16.

The most important internal problem confronting the nation today is "the race toward bigness," according to Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee.
DENVER, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Two executives of the Oldsmobile Division of the General Motors Corporation, were aboard the plane that crashed near Longmont tonight.

An automatic assembly machine that Plymouth, a division of the Chrysler Corporation, has been using for two months was reported yesterday to have cut its engine assembly costs by 50 per cent and reduced by 20 to 25 per cent the amount of labor required.

New York City's department stores came through with a solid 9 per cent increase in sales for October, compared with year-ago figures. Except for last March, which benefited from a shift in the date of Easter, October volume showed the greatest improvement of any month this year.
A $45,000 Calcutta pool golf tournament at a Long Island club last Sept. 18-19 was won by a team of New England "ringers" -- a factory worker and a laundry employe -- it was asserted yesterday.

The country's top advertisers and their agencies joined yesterday in a broad "platform" for better marketing. The aim is to find buyers for the nation's potential output and put an end to fears of overproduction and unemployment.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Wheat opened strong this morning on the Board of Trade, especially the May contract, which was as much as 1 cent higher. But the demand did not last long, and there was a recession from the early highs as other grains sagged.

The American Jewish Congress has protested a ruling that will bar the public and the press from a State Probation Commission hearing here next Friday. The hearing was called to discuss the practice of hiring probation officers on a religious quota basis in the Children's Court Division of the Domestic Relations Court.

The letter of William J. Levitt which appeared in The Times on Oct. 27, taking issue with your Oct. 17 editorial concerning housing economics and production, contains a profession of faith by Mr. Levitt in the social utility of sharing the nation's output.

A program to help provide more qualified elementary school teachers has been undertaken by two Columbia University schools -- Teachers College and the School of General Studies. The two schools will cooperate to prepare for teaching persons who are unable to undertake a full Teachers College course.
October's blood donations to the regional Red Cross totaled 9,995 pints. Monday's total was 113 pints, given at the New York Chapter House, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Three pro-segregation organizations and their leaders were enjoined by Federal Court today from interfering with the racially integrated public schools at Hoxie, Ark.

TO benefit its exhibiting program, the New York City Center Gallery, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, has organized a display of paintings belonging to collectors with stage connections. Admission is 50 cents and the show will continue until Nov. 20.
GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- West Germans here feel that the Foreign Ministers' Conference has emphasized that they are "second-class" allies of the West.

Michael Todd, stage and screen producer and an originator of the Todd-AO wide-screen process in which the motion picture "Oklahoma!" was filmed, yesterday sold his holdings in the Magna Theatre Corporation, which controls the process.

THIS is an era in which the fundamental principles of amateur idealism have been warped beyond recognition. The totalitarian nations have their "state amateurs," the muscular gents who hold token jobs but actually work at being athletes.

Paperbard production in theI week.ended-..last Saturday rosei 10.8 per cent above the like week of'last year, 'th Natfoii{l Paper-I board Association-reported' yesterday. New orders were up 11 per cent and unfilled orders 51.4 per cent. The weekly statistics in tons follow:
An assertion that "the day of the pioneer in advertising" is over was made yesterday by Thomas B. Haire, president of the Advertising Club of New York.
The controversial National Council of the Arts, Sciences and Professions may be going out of business.

As a faithful reader of your paper during my fifteen years of representing Iceland in the United States I regret to have recently found two incorrect statements regarding my country in your paper. Both concern my delegation's vote in the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 30 on the question of Algeria.

The nation's biggest copper producer, the Kennecott Copper Corporation, attained the highest earnings for any first nine months in its history. The net income of $81,989,463 rose 41.4 per cent over the $57,973,302 net for the similar period last year and exceeded the $77,906,000 earned in all of 1954.
Davy Crockett makes what presumably will be a triumphant return over the American Broadcasting Company television network on Wednesday, Nov. 16, from 7:30 to 8:30 P.M.
MADRID, Nov. 1 -- Following is the text of a communique issued from the Spanish Foreign Ministry today:
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1 (AP) -- New Government steps aimed at reducing oil imports from the Middle East were hailed today at a convention of the Independent Petroleum Association of America.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Bryna Productions, the Kirk Douglas producing company, has bought for $100,000 motion picture rights to the television play "Shadow of the Champ," written by Robert Alan Aurthur. The price is said to establish a new high in TV-to-movie sales.

MADRID, Nov. 1 -- In a display of great cordiality, Secretary of State Dulles and Generalissimo Francisco Franco reaffirmed today the "spirit of collaboration" between the United States and Spain. Leaving Madrid after a six-and-a-half-hour visit from Geneva, the Secretary of State pledged his efforts for still closer relations in the future.

ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 1 -Joseph Weintraub, New Jersey member of the two-state Waterfront Commission, issued a statement tonight declaring that he and Gov. Robert B. Meyner deeply regretted General Hays' resignation.

The seven touring Soviet journalists spare no effort trying to prove there is a free press in today's Russia. At a press conference in Cleveland, asked whether Soviet editors had a voice in the text of their publications, Boris KampovPolevoy, head of the group, replied: "The editors make their own decisions."

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and subsidiaries today announced consolidated earnings of $102,783,318 for the first nine months of 1955, an increase of 26.2 per cent over those of a year earlier.
A cruise from New York to California involving the services of three passenger liners will begin with the sailing of the Ancon from here on Nov. 25.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Premier Edgar Faure asked the French National Assembly tonight to choose between a government crisis and new elections in December.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -The Eisenhower Administration, spurred by increased Communist offers of foreign aid and technical assistance in Asia and Africa, is reviewing its entire policy of overseas aid.
Beset by a constantly increasing need for new policemen, the city will open a civic drive tomorrow for 20,000 applicants for the job of patrolman.

The song program offered by the soprano Berenice Bramson at Carnegie Recital Hall last night was of the sort technically classified as "an interesting program," often an advance tip-off that the evening's rewarding aspects will be musical rather than vocal.

AN important pianist, an unimportant symphony and a bloated Bach orchestration -- these were the gifts brought to New York by the Philadelphia Orchestra and Eugene Ormandy at Carnegie Hall last night.
BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The provisional Government of President Eduardo Lonardi announced today that it had taken over temporarily the newspapers La Prensa and El Lider.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1 -- The Ford Motor Company's earnings before taxes this year "will surpass the aggregate earnings of the company for the entire twenty-one years prior to World War II," Ernest R. Breech, chairman, said tonight.

The Federal Home Loan Banks -- a source of credit for member savings and loan associations -- are offering $295,000,000 in notes in two issues today through Everett Smith, fiscal agent. New York City.

The morning of Nov. 1, 1952, dawned clear and warm upon a tiny coral island in a desolate section of the stark blue Pacific. The only intrusion on the softly rounded lines of palms was the glint of a man-made structure of steel and rock.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- A plan for the phased reunification of Germany was circulated today by the East German Government to the four powers participating in the Foreign Ministers' Conference. Under the plan a unified Germany would be armed but neutral.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 1 -- Don't plan to air-condition your house by sun power in the near future, unless you have money to burn.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Nov. 1 -Deerfield Academy's student body of 425 trooped into the auditorium of Memorial Building tonight for the regular school meeting. The feature was the showing of motion pictures of last Saturday's football victory over Cushing.

Net income of the United Aircraft Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries climbed to $22,732,949 in the first nine months of this year from $18,804,884 in the corresponding period last year, the report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A Senate committee's exploration into ways to provide insurance protection to victims of flood and other disasters touched off a controversy today.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 1 -- The Israeli Army announced today three Egyptian marauders had been killed near Mishmar Hanegev, a settlement eight miles northwest of Beersheba.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -A sharpshooter on the White House police force today received the William Randolph Hearst Trophy for winning the twenty-fourth annual international pistol tournament.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The peace and prosperity achievements of the Eisenhower Administration were approved in a nation-wide poll taken on Sept. 29 of 250,000 Americans by 10,000 Republican women.
FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Maj. Ronald E. Alley, 33-year-old career officer, was convicted by an Army court-martial today of collaborating with his Red Chinese captors while a prisoner in Korea.

Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore started yesterday the $100,000 survey on the proposed rehabilitation and modernization of a 500-acre neighborhood surrounding the Flatbush Avenue terminal of the Long Island Rail Road.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- A new company, Harmony Productions, has been formed by Lee Loeb to produce films for television. The first undertaking is scheduled to be "The Court of Human Relations," a series of half-hour films that will deal with actual cases brought to various courts of domestic relations.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Frankie Ryff of New York increased his chances for a light-weight title fight tonight by flooring Paddy De Marco, a former champion, once and beating him with left hooks for a unanimous ten-round decision in a rough fight at the Baltimore Coliseum.
PARIS, Thursday, Nov. 3 -- Premier Edgar Faure, with the decisive support of eighty Communist votes, won parliamentary approval early this morning for his plan to hold new elections in December.
Two of the large roles and two of the small ones in "The Golden Slippers" were in new hands last night when the Tchaikovsky fairy-tale opera had its third performance by the New York City Opera.

Columbia University marked its 201st anniversary with Charta Day exercises in the rotunda of the Low Memorial Library yesterday. Dr. I. I. Rabi, Higgins Professor of Physics and 1944 Nobel Prize winner, spoke on "International Cooperation for the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy."
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Former President Truman braved writer's cramp and flood-lights today to help start the sale of his memoirs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Lawrence Baker Arguimbau, a former teacher at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was found guilty today of contempt of Congress.
DENVER, Nov. 2 -- The Secretary of Labor said today he had no hope that the Taft-Hartley Act could be amended in the next session of Congress.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 2 -- Recent Communist attempts to foment unrest among United Fruit Company banana workers received a setback today when the concern announced a new three-year wage agreement.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 2 -- The Indian Government is expected to decide soon whether it will go along wkith a plan to guarantee United States private investment here.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- Protestantism in the United States is fleeing to the suburbs at an "alarming" rate.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Nov. 2 -- Queen Juliana of The Netherlands was moved from profound seriousness to laughter today by the demonstrations and antics of scores of Surinam children -- gay and graceful but also deaf or blind.
BATNA, Algeria, Nov. 1 -- The Algerian rebels suffered a setback today.

TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 2 (AP) -- An autopsy was ordered today in the death of Lieut. Col. Dean Lamb of New York City. The body of the 69-year-old pioneer aviator was found Tuesday night in his hotel room here.
Negotiations toward construction of fifteen special service tankers for the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service have been nullified, putting the project back at its starting point.
The State of California borrowed $60,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance benefits to war veterans and the construction of public schools.

Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday. The old December contract was 5 points (25 cents a bale) higher than Tuesday. Other deliveries ranged from 8 to 51 points lower.

May I express my appreciation for the splendid work which my fellow-American, Jesse Owens, has done recently as an ambassador of goodwill to the athletic circles of India. I had occasion to be in Delhi and Madras during Mr. Owens' visit, when he was holding his "track clinics" and fulfilling a heavy schedule of appointments with Indian athletic committees.

It is increasingly clear, as events unfold at Geneva, that the United States, in close cooperation with its friends and allies, has won command of the initiative in the global "war for peace." In point of fact, this is no new or even recent development.
SAMUEL PEPYS records that he bought himself a wig for 3 and was relieved, on wearing it, to find "it did not prove so strange as I was afraid it would."
LONGMONT, Colo., Nov. 2 -- United Air Lines engaged an explosives expert today to investigate the crash of a DC-6B near here last night. Forty-four persons on the Seattle-bound plane were killed.
SPERRY, Okla., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Are you a football parent? Do you have a boy on the team? Do you worry about your boy at times?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Only a rare type of pacifist would oppose instant and massive nuclear retaliation by the United States for an armed attack by another nation. That would be a simple act of self-defense. But "massive retaliation" as basic and limiting American military policy has many critics, including countless members of the armed forces.

TULSA, Nov. 2 (UP) -- A visibly tired and preoccupied Mickey Mantle won his race with the stork today. He boarded an air taxi here shortly after 3 P. M. bound for Commerce, Okla., where his wife was expecting a baby "at any time."

Rubber futures tumbled 2.3 to 2.75 cents a pound yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The decline was the sharpest price movement of the year. The volume, 6,020 tons, was the third largest since trading reopened after World War II.

AND still another pianist whose reputation has been derived from phonograph records arrives on the local scene. Joerg Demus, who made his debut last night in Town Hall, is a young German whose disks of the classic repertoire, mostly on the Westminster label, have been circulating in America since 1950.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The gold and dollar reserves of the sterling area declined $48,000,000 last month. This was a marked improvement over the record for the previous few months.
BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- Eighty-two members of the Harvard College Class of 1900 asked President Eisenhower today to appoint a commission to study the problems for a durable peace.
KARLOVY VARY, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 31 -- Ten years after the expulsion of 3,000,000 Germans from the Sudetenland a substantial part of this region lies desolate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged today that the National Labor Relations Board harbored a "Communist cell."
Hume Cronyn and Jessica Handy will star in a one-hour television play based on an episode in their former radio series titled "The Marriage."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Government agencies say they believe in the fullest possible disclosure of information. But they do not always tell all.

Chile's largest pharmaceuticals manufacturer announced yesterday it had received an interest-free loan of machinery and equipment valued at $100,000 from an American chemical concern to help establish a plant at Santiago for making antibiotic drugs.

The George Eastman House of Rochester, N. Y., yesterday announced the names of film personalities still living who were adjudged to have made "distinctive contributions to the American cinema within the memorable period from 1915 to 1925." The winners will be honored during the museum's Festival of Film Artists Nov. 19.

TWO artists who have not shown for several years are among the exhibitors this week. At the Alan Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street, Julian Levi is showing some of his characteristic seacoast themes, resonant in color albeit basically somber in mood. His portentous overcast skies are offset by touches of bright color in landscape elements.

IN PAYMENT of taxes to King David in Biblical times, a subject once presented "asses laden with cheese and raisins." The raisin industry was flourishing in 400 B. C. in the region that later was to be Armenia. Drying grapes and other fruit is, in fact, the oldest example of food processing, one that neither canning nor freezing has supplanted.

A luxury-styled apartment house is planned for the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street, where a 15,000 - square - foot plot has been purchased by the 33 East Seventy-fifth Street, Inc. The buying group is headed by Henry H. Minskoff, president of Sam Minskoff Sons, Inc., builders.
GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- The unwonted optimism of Secretary of State Dulles at today's meeting of the Foreign Ministers' conference surprised many observers.

TORONTO, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Toronto Maple Leafs vault from fifth place to second in National Hockey League tonight. They dropped the Detroit Leaf Wings deeper into the cellar with a 3-1 victory before 13,014 persons.
A 138-foot naval minesweeper, the MSC 131, was transferred to the Belgian Government yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- German scientists reported today they had developed a dramatic new form of streptomycin. They said it was far safer than the drug now generally used in the treatment of tuberculosis.
Education is more important than enforcement in dealing with traffic safety, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh said yesterday.

" The Right to Read," a new book by Paul Blanshard, has been scheduled for Nov. 16 publication by Beacon Press. Subtitled "The Battle Against Censorship," the work examines the censorship laws and pressure groups.
VIENNA, Oct. 31 -- United States authorities in Hungary think that, in implementing the relaxation of tensions between East and West, Hungary has been dragging her feet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization will not hesitate to urge a Government curb on oil imports if oil companies fail voluntarily to reduce them by 7 per cent this quarter, Arthur S. Flemming, director of the O. D. M., said today.

The re-election of James T. Farrell, novelist, to a second term as chairman of the American Committee for Cultural Freedom was announced yesterday. Mrs. Diana Trilling, critic, continues as chairman of the administrative committee.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits announced yesterday that he would ask thet next general session of the New York Legislature to require registration of securities salesmen.
The 1956 Thunderbird series was announced yesterday by the Ford Motor Company. The new cars will go on display in dealer showrooms here on Nov. 15.

Buyers of the old Tenth Street Studio Building, a Greenwich Village landmark for almost a century, announced yesterday the letting of a contract for demolition of the building. The razing is to start next Monday. A ten-story and penthouse apartment building for ninety-three families will be erected on the site.

Robert Moses, who in addition to his other duties is chairman of the State Power Authority, is nothing if not ingenious. Latest example is his tactic in trying to expedite action on the development of the United States share of hydroelectric power from the Niagara River under the treaty signed with Canada in 1950.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday on the petition of the Sands Point, L. I., Community Synogogue to direct the Village of Sands Point to permit the congregation to use its own property as a temple and religious school.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- A spokesman for the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation here said tonight that the utility company will go to court, if necessary, to win the right to transmit power from the St. Lawrence project.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov, 2 -- Over the years the Yale-Army game has been one of college football's favorites. The last game under contract between them is no exception.

Five persons were held in $5,000 bail each when arraigned yesterday before Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz on charges of defrauding the state of more than $9,500 in unemployment insurance funds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- The Soviet Union proposed Communist China and Rumania today for a special committee to study atomic energy. The proposed group is to collect information on the amount of radiation given off by nuclear materials.

HILLSIDE, N. J., Nov. 2 -- There was a one-minute interruption in calisthenics today. The lull in the Pingry football squad's preparation for its contest with Bayley-Ellard of Madison next Saturday was caused by a small fifth former who engaged in a hurried conference with Coach Vince Lesneski.

Directors of the Phelps Dodge Corporation declared yesterday a fourth quarter dividend of 75 cents, payable Dec. 9, and a year-end extra of $1.30, payable Jan. 6. The company paid 65 cents in previous quarters.
Former Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams knows now how it feels to have his automobile tagged for a traffic violation.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- Portraits of the Soviet leaders were hoisted on Moscow's public buildings today to mark the thirty-eighth anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution Nov. 7. They were arranged in approximately the same order as for May Day.

Dr. Vincent du Vigneaud was a bit reluctant yesterday to believe that he had received the Nobel Prize for chemistry. Nevertheless, on the basis of press reports, he consented to pose for photographers in his office at the New York Hospital -- Cornell Medical Center.
I have read the letter of Dean Kenneth D. Johnson of the New York School of Social Work published on Oct. 29.
REHOVOTH, Israel, Nov. 2 -- Israel tonight marked her third Chaim Weizmann Memorial Day with this prayer from President Itzhak Ben-Zvi:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired, was placed in charge of all Antarctic activities of the United States today.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Thursday, Nov. 3 -- The Israeli Army announced today that it had attacked and occupied a position established by Egypt inside El Auja (Nitsana) demilitarized zone.
Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington said last night that he still hoped President Eisenhower could and would run again next fall.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Wheat and corn futures responded briskly to professional buying support for a time today, but reacted from the top levels when the demand fell off. Prices for soybeans and most grains closed above yesterday's final levels.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov 2 -- Provisional President Eduardo Lonardi took personal charge of negotiations with the General Confederation of Labor today to put an end to a major strike that labor leaders said they had called off.
Three gunmen terrorized a Queens family early yesterday before they left in anger and disillusion over the contents of the family's safe.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer has signed Bette Davis and Ernest Borgnine to co-star with Debbie Reynolds in "The Catered Affair."

BOB BROWN, man of many facets, who once wrote a best-selling book ("What Happened to Mary") that became the first five-reel movie, has now edited "The Complete Book of Cheese" (Random House, 314 pp., $4.95).
LAS VEGAS, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren's youngest daughter eloped late last night with her fiance, a surgeon.

Expert nonpartisan study has reported a need for spending $2,100,000,000 on New York State highways in the next seven years, and Amendment No. 1, on which we strongly urge a Yes vote next Tuesday, would permit bond-issue borrowing of $750,000,000 of this sum.

ALBANY, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Republican legislative leaders accused Governor Harriman today of producing "fiscal nonsense" in holding that only once since World War II had the state ended a fiscal year with a "real surplus."
Lehman Brothers and underwriting associates will place on the market today a new issue of $4,125,000 of 4 3/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures of Continental Air Lines, Inc.

The representative assembly of the Newspaper Guild of New York rejected early today a proposal for a membership referendum on whether to arbitrate the dismissals of Melvin L. Barnet, a New York Times copy editor, and David Gordon, a Daily News reporter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 26:

AN exhibition of paintings featuring sporting topics, organized by Sports Illustrated and the American Federation of Arts, is on view in the lobby of the Time and Life building, Rockefeller Plaza. The exhibition, which later will travel to museums throughout the country, has the widest possible range, including paintings from the seventeenth to the twentieth century.

WHAT makes a style stay in style is a nagging question for every homemaker about to make a major purchase. The fact that even the experts disagree may not be much help, but it should provide some consolation to her.

Mayor Felisa Rincon de Gautier of San Juan, P. R., had a heart-to-heart talk with fifth graders in a predominantly Puerto Rican school in Manhattan yesterday. She urged them to be good, to learn English and to mix with native New Yorkers.

THE stuff that Noel Coward made into a glittering comedy in "Private Lives" Mary McCarthy makes into a glittering tragedy in "A Charmed Life."* There are, of course, differences. Mr. Coward told his chattering story as a play; Miss McCarthy tells her shattering fable as a novel. The play's scenes were opulently on the Riviera and in Paris; the novel is set with studied seediness against Cape Cod's forlorn seacoast Bohemia.
The Metropolitan Opera Guild celebrated its twentieth anniversary last night with an "open house" for members at the Metropolitan Opera House.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 2 -- Sir Edward C. Bullard, noted British geophysicist, declared at the first world symposium on applied solar energy here today that it was unlikely that large electric power stations operating on solar energy could be developed soon.
The stock market largely marked time yesterday, for the fourth straight trading session. Volume was comparatively light in the narrowest market since mid-October.
Wheat is the only disquieting feature on Canada's economic horizon, Finance Minister Walter E. Harris said here yesterday. Speaking at a luncheon in the Canadian Club, he said:

The Chevrolet 1956 line has two nine-passenger station wagons and two four-door hardtop sedans as newcomers. With these there are nineteen body styles in three series, or four more models than in 1955. The cars go on display in dealers' showrooms here tomorrow.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Dr. Geoffrey F. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of the Anglican Church, said today there had been no church or state pressure on Princess Margaret. Two days ago she announced she would not marry Group Capt. Peter Townsend.
A Brewster, N. Y., commission broker was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of smuggling $85,000 worth of watches, watch movements and perfume into this country.
American blouse manufacturers planned yesterday to petition the Government to impose an import quota on Japanese-made cotton blouses and to raise the tariff from 20 to 56 1/4 per cent.

Kohlrabi is abundantly available now though mostly in markets catering to shoppers of foreign background. The vegetable, a member of the cabbage family, looks and tastes something like turnip. But it has a distinctive delicacy with which more cooks should become familiar.
GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, set the presence of East and West Germany at the conference table today as the price of German reunification.

A five-story and penthouse apartment building for ten families on lot 20 by 98 feet at 32 East Thirty-ninth Street has been sold by Max Bregman to Joseph L. Ennis Co., realty operators, in a deal negotiated by Harold M. Silverman, broker. It is assessed at $125,000 and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $100,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Administration is planning a series of administrative and legislative changes to ease President Eisenhower's burdens when he returns to active duty at the White House.

President Castillo Armas of Guatemala will be our guest in New York from today until Monday. He is a welcome visitor who will learn that Americans of goodwill are his friends and want to help him in his extraordinarily difficult task of bringing order and prosperity to Guatemala after its almost disastrous period of fellow-traveling.
Some large-space national advertising is in the making for early next year to promote the idea of taking the family out to dinner.
A policeman shot and seriously wounded his estranged wife yesterday in the presence of seventy spectators in a second-floor waiting room of Brooklyn Domestic Relations Court.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of Central New York, with headquarters in Syracuse, has withdrawn its proposed plan to merge with the Auburn Trust Company of Auburn, N. Y. This was announced yesterday by George A. Mooney, New York State Superintendent of Banks.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- The first known case in medical history in which a man's life was saved because he happened to be one of a set of identical twins was reported here today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 2 -- Premier-designate David Ben-Gurion offered today to meet leaders of Arab states to avert "dangers inherent in the present unstable situation." The proposal came during a speech in which Mr. Ben-Gurion presented his new Government to the Knesset (Parliament).
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A former Costa Rican President warned today that democracies were putting human freedoms in peril by making too many concessions to dictators.
