ASBURY PARK, N. J., Nov. 2 -- The New Jersey Welfare Council called upon Gov. Robert B. Meyner today for assistance in organizing integrated public medical care.

IF you let your imagination roam ever so slightly, it's possible to visualize Bertelan de Nemethy kissing the hand of a countess in Budapest to the tune of gypsy fiddles or leading a daring cavalry charge with saber flashing. But this one-time Hungarian cavalry officer won't let his mind wander in that direction any more.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 2 -- After being notified early this morning of his selection as one of the two Nobel Prize winners in physics Prof. Willis E. Lamb snatched two more hours' sleep and conducted a class in advanced quantum mechanics for upper division students.

The coach of a team that is credited with having thrown the first modern forward pass in college football will be honored between the halves of the Wesleyan-Williams game at Middletown, Conn., on Saturday.

An honored and cherished name will be given the new luxury liner ordered by the Holland-America Line for the Atlantic lanes. She will be the Rotterdam, the fifth of this name in the long history of this popular trans-Atlantic operator.
State Republican legislative leaders opened a blistering attack yesterday against Governor Harriman's dropping of Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays from the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen threatened today to call a strike that would shut the entire system of the world's largest railroad.
The Gotham Hotel here and the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Beverly Hills, California, were sold by Webb Knapp and Roger Stevens to an investor in an $11,000,000 deal reported yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 2 -- A parchment sheet of a Merovingian Bible which had lain forgotten in the library of Yale University's Branford College, has been authenticated by the world's leading music historians and scholars as the earliest known Christian music manuscript.

Today's new film is "Guys and Dolls," at the Capitol. Samuel Goldwyn's production of the musical play in CinemaScope and color is released by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. Marlon Brando, Frank Sinatra, Jean Simmons and Vivian Blaine head the cast.

A pre-trial hearing of a principal and four teachers, all admitted ex-Communists, was postponed indefinitely yesterday when counsel challenged the right of former City Judge Louis Goldstein to sit as trial examiner.

The books all say that this is an excellent time to put up the bird feeding station. To be sure, the ice and the snow are some distance away -- at least that is to be hoped -- and so a good deal of natural food still is available.
A guarantee by the Big Four to Israel and the Arab nations against "aggression from any source" was advocated yesterday by Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress.

Operating revenues of Trans World Airlines, Inc., in the first nine months this year reached a record $163,433,000 for the period, an increase of 5.2 per cent over the $155,267,000 revenues for the similar period last year.
An unidentified manufacturing company thinks the services of its top man are worth $2,100,000.

Yogi Berra, Mickey Mantle and Nellie Fox led the ticket yesterday on the United Press American League all-star team. The selections were made by fifty-six baseball writers from the eight league cities.
ARTHUR GODFREY may take a little more kindly to television critics after he hears about the WPIX broadcast of the opening of the Sixty-seventh National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2 -- Argentina will be ready to import an estimated $80,000,000 worth of foreign goods next year under its new exchange regulations, the Ministry of Finance announced today.
In the last thirty years whole sections of New York have become unsafe for the average citizen, Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson said yesterday.

A year ago W. R. (Bob) Ballard, captain of Canada's equestrian team, bought the chestnut gelding Oregon Duke from the Millarden Farm of Annville, Pa. Last night at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden the investment paid off.
PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Mohammed ben Youssef, exiled Sultan of Morocco, received today the resignation of the four-member Council of Guardians of the throne. The council holds the royal power in Morocco.

CHARLTON ABBOTS, England, Oct. 29 -- Those who scoff at the easy shooting provided by "driven" birds might have a change of opinion if confronted with the fast, highflying pheasants we encountered today at Charlton Abbots Manor.
Still aglow over their first world series victory, the Dodgers yesterday announced a novel plan for making a big occasion of the formal raising of the world championship banner at Ebbets Field.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Nassau County's baby hunt became a manhunt this afternoon as the police began a search for the kidnappers of 3-year-old Stephen Damman.

An increase of 71,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 151,607,000 barrels, compared with 151,536,000 a week earlier and 149,789,000 a year ago.
Stewart Chaney, who has designed scenery and costumes for scores of Broadway attractions, is back from Europe after a two-year absence with plans for producing a historical drama.
A realignment of the top officials of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., took place yesterday, occasioned by the withdrawal from board posts of George Whitney, chairman, and three others.
A blueprint for education in New York State was presented yesterday.
Stainless steel is appearing in more built-in appliances, cookware and tableware than ever before. This durable, handsome material is easy to clean but does require a little special care.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 2 -- Ships with "roll on-roll off" cargoes were described today as the best way to breath life into coastwise shipping.
Knowing you have editorially spoken out against the so-called Panther Mountain Reservoir Amendment 7, I beg a little space to tell your readers why we in northern New York favor this project.

Field Marshal Viscount Bernard Law Montgomery of Alamein arrived here from England yesterday on a three-fold mission.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- A Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had no right to engage in a "fishing expedition," a Federal judge said today in dismissing four of six counts against Leon J. Kamin.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta of Nassau County said yesterday that the November grand jury would have to decide whether Mrs. William Woodward Jr. should be required to re-enact the shotgun slaying of her husband. Mr. Woodward was buried yesterday.
A comprehensive appraisal of progress in cancer control in the last ten years will be made by fifty American and European scientists.

Entirely apart from the well-recognized integrity and ability of John P. McGrath, his appointment by Governor Harriman to the Waterfront Commission has unfortunate implications -- especially at this particular time and without any frank explanations from the Governor.

GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- The political division of West Germany between the Adenauer Government and the Social Democrats was emphasized by the arrival here today of Herbert Wehner, Socialist foreign affairs expert.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Nov. 2 -- An Air Force B-26 crashed in a street of a thickly populated residential district here at 4:15 P. M. today, killing the two crew members. The plane missed plunging into a tight row of houses. However, flaming debris did set fire to one.
YONKERS, Nov. 1 -- A king-size traffic bottleneck is about to be generated on Central Park Avenue here.

LAKE MAHOPAC, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- There was a time, and not too long ago, when the creation of a golf course could be compared with the building of a forest. It was a job requiring many hands, countless man-hours of labor, and months, sometimes years, of cultivation.

The second evening performance of the National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden attracted another large gathering of prominent persons. Many dinner parties were given at hotels and private homes before the show.

The New York Central Railroad is embarking on one of the most ambitious modernization programs in its history. Alfred E. Perlman, president, announced yesterday that the company plans to spend $117,855,000 for a fleet of 14,750 new freight cars.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas of Guatemala said today that a new democratic constitution would be placed in effect shortly after he returned from his visit to the United States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, adopted a budget of $9,000,000 for next year. The money is used to support the group's extensive network of medical and public-health projects in Israel and programs in the United States.
GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- United States correspondents were encouraged tonight to accept the thesis that the Foreign Ministers' Conference was on the high road to success.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Three United States scientists today won the 1955 Nobel prizes in chemistry and physics.
WHY do women wear hats? Or why don't they? Most men would be baffled at these question. No so Samuel Finkelstein.

The Committee for the Rehabilitation of Crippled Children, sponsors of the Cerebral Palsy Recreation Center at 652 West 117th Street, will hold a benefit card party in the ballroom of the Pierre on the afternoon of Nov. 14. The event will mark the committe's sixth anniversary.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates picked Bobby Bragan as field manager today. The move started a National League guessing game: is Bragan a "Rickey man" or a "Brown man."

Even if the United States should win its antitrust s against the American Newspaper Publishers Association, "severe derangement" is like in the present financial relationships between individual advertisers and their agencies. The opinion was announced yesterday by Gilbert H. Weil, general counsel of the Association of National Advertisers.

Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, chess champion of the United States, defeated Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia in the first round of the international chess masters tournament at Zagreb, according to a report received last night from Belgrade. Twenty players' representing nine countries are competing.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Two of the most influential Republican State Senators in New Jersey are engaged in struggles for political survival. They are Malcolm S. Forbes of Somerset County and Wayne Dumont Jr. of Warren County.
Squared Away, one of the better-liked campaigners on the New York thoroughbred scene, demonstrated the reason for this popularity yesterday at Jamaica.
Western Canada's first lubricating oil plant was opened officially yesterday near Edmonton by Premier E. C. Manning of Alberta.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 2 -- The ousted Argentine dictator, Juan D. Peron, ended his exile in Paraguay today and left by plane for Nicaragua.
QUEBEC, Nov. 2 -- A 14,000-square-mile mineral exploration concession in the James Bay area of northwestern Quebec has been offered to the Henry J. Kaiser organization, it was learned here today.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 2 (UP) -- The Darby Dan Farm's Skipper Bill won today's $24,550 Princeton Handicap at Garden State Park, surviving a driving finish with the Jet Stable's Weal or Woe.
The New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N. J., which will build the fifth aircraft carrier of the Forrestal class, announced yesterday the promotion of two members of its technical staff.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The stock market brightened considerably today under the lead of British Government securities. The gilt-edged stocks rose as much as 15 shillings ($2.10) on the 100 unit. They were helped by strength in the pound sterling against the dollar.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation had a consolidated net profit of $6,918,211 in the first nine months on gross revenues of $268,298,948, Louis E. Wolfson, president and chairman, reported yesterday.

All of us have been startled in the night by the wailing of an ambulance siren. Dominating the fear that grips us when we hear the siren is the reassuring thought that the best hospital care in the world will be made available to the sufferer.

The consolidated net income of the Sinclair Oil Corporation for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 was announced yesterday as $56,137,940, or $4.24 each on the average of 13,214,227 shares outstanding in the period. This compared with a net income in the first three quarters of 1954 of $52,896,384, or $4.29 each on the average of 12,315,348 shares then outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3--The American Civil Liberties Union attacked Government secrecy under the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations today. It said abuses of authority to withhold news "were never so rampant as now."
New York University will soon be the first college in the New York metropolitan area to produce a limited nuclear fission chain reaction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Public Health Service has developed a vaccine that promises substantial immunity against "cold-type" diseases that affect millions of Americans every year. The vaccine does not stop the common cold, loosely defined as a non-feverish runny nose or stuffed head.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 (UP) -- A tape recording was admitted in evidence today to "impeach the credibility" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, witness "in the contempt of Congress trial of a former Harvard research assistant.
A. L. Alexander protested yesterday against reported plans by Lee Loeb of Hollywood to produce a series of television films under the title "The Court of Human Relations."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Government disclosed today that it planned to ease regulations applying to exports of non-strategic goods to the Soviet Union and its satellites in Europe.
OSLO. Norway, Nov. 3--The Nobel peace prize was awarded today to the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 3 -- The opening of the Big Three round-robin football series on Saturday will find Princeton the favorite to defeat Harvard's defending champions at Cambridge, and rightly so on the record.
Vincent A. G. O'Connor, the city's Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, acted yesterday to prevent the shift of the city's rubber importing business to Port Newark.
The Transit Authority stepped up yesterday its war against crime in the subways.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A committee of American Federation of Labor officials was reported agreed today to recommend the expulsion of the Air Line Pilots Association from the federation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- In the last few days the issue over the use of informer witnesses by the Government in matters affecting the national security has been illuminated by several events. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, in a split decision, held unconstitutional the Coast Guard's security code that depends in part on the testimony of witnesses whom the accused are not permitted to confront.
GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, has replied to the Soviet Foreign Minister in rather sharper tones in the Foreign Ministers' Conference than have his Western colleagues.

OVERBROOK, Pa., Nov. 3 -- As his young and green football team will be confronted by the single wing tomorrow. Coach Johnny Orsi today gave his Episcopal Academy outfit some new plays designed to combat Germantown Academy's attack.
A year-long science workshop for educators, financed by industry, is being planned at Teachers College, Columbia University, as one measure to help fill the nation's need for scientists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Federal Court of Appeals upheld today Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield's right to enforce increased parcel post rates on certain fourth-class mail. It upheld a lower court dismissal of a suit to enjoin him from doing it.
The Port of New Orleans borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of serial bonds secured by a pledge of the faith and credit of the State of Louisiana.
Amendment 7, which will come before us voters on Election Day, is a bad amendment and should not be adopted by default.

AT this time a year ago Yale was not only the acknowledged powerhouse of the Ivy League but was deemed strong enough to hold its own with the muscular citizenry of the Poison Ivy League. The Ivies are greenhouse plants, carefuly tended and watched. The Poison Ivies grow wild and, in some sections of the country, attain prodigious size and strength.

When the late Alfred B. Nobel set up his famous awards for the men and women who had done most for humanity he could not have foreseen the one announced yesterday in Oslo. Yet this peace prize, going to no man but to an agency of the United Nations devoted to the care of refugees, is deeply moving.

A gypsy became the city's new "scofflaw king" yesterday. The successor to the scofflaw throne is George Lee, 45-year-old owner of three automobiles, who pleaded guilty to 118 parking violations -- a record. The previous record holder was Mrs. Dana Miller of 65 East Eightieth Street, who had received eighty-six summonses.

Walter F. Tellier, one of the country's largest originators of "penny" uranium stocks, had his day in the sun of Congressional inquiry yesterday. It was a day of startling developments, for it brought, among other things:
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 3 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced today proposed passenger car tolls for two extensions it plans to open next spring.
GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- The two most important economic events of 1955 in the Soviet Union and East Europe have been the good harvests and the decisions to reduce the size of armed forces.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Allied Artists announced today that it was handling financial details and distribution of a theatrical feature of "Medic," the TV medical series. In addition, the company confirmed that negotiations were nearing completion for Hal Roach Jr. to make a theatrical feature of his TV series, "Racket Squad," for Allied distribution.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Reorganization of thousands of school districts was suggested officially today as a possible main solution to the critical shortage of school rooms.
GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- European steel production in the third quarter of this year broke all previous records for comparable periods.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A group of Russians visited the White House today for the first time since the start of the "cold war." They almost collided with a leading crusader against Communism.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Syrian Government said today two frontier clashes occurred last Sunday between Turkish and Syrian soldiers.
A group of Belgian department stores yesterday announced plans for the largest promotion of American-made products yet attempted by a foreign retail organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The highway committee of the United States Governors Conference split today on methods of financing the proposed multi-million dollar national highway program.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation more than doubled its earnings in the first nine months this year, compared with the period a year ago. Consolidated net profit climbed to $24,012,833 from $11,454,782 for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1954.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today announced state acreage allotments for the 1956 cotton crop. Four states received increases: Arizona, California, Florida, and Illinois. Fifteen received cuts, among them all of the southern states but Florida.

Governor Harriman struck back angrily yesterday at what he termed "cynical" Republican criticism of his dropping of Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays as this state's member of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.
When Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court was in Russia last summer, he was "cross-examined about the treatment of Negroes in this country," he said yesterday.

Two new films open at first-run theatres today. "The View From Pompey's Head" is at the Roxy. Twentieth Century-Fox' adaptation of the Hamilton Basso novel is in CinemaScope and color. Richard Egan, Dana Wynter, Cameron Mitchell, Sidney Blackmer and Marjorie Rambeau head the cast. The film was produced and directed by Philip Dunne.
Mayor Wagner, rebuffed by his Police Commissioner two weeks ago, won a victory yesterday over an equally independent member of his official family -- Park Commissioner Robert Moses.
HUE, Vietnam, Nov. 2 -- After fifteen months of peace in Indochina, the situation remains generally quiet along the line separating South Vietnam from the Communist-ruled North.

The voluntary nonprofit hospitals, organized by groups of civic-minded members of the community to provide the best possible hospital care for all who need it regardless of ability to pay, are the heart of the American hospital system.

Sales and earnings of the American Tobacco Company reached new highs for the first nine months of this year. Net income climbed to $38,440,000, or $5.54 a common share, from $31,735,000, or $4.51 a share, for the nine months of last year.
The Casita Maria Settlement House will be the beneficiary of an entertainment known as the Casita Maria Fiesta. It will be held on Nov. 30 in the ballroom of the Ambassador.

CHANNEL 2's "Shower of Stars" came up with a dreary innovation last night, an hour-long commercial interrupted at times by minor items having nothing at all to do with the automobile concern sponsoring the show.
The stock market broke loose from the doldrums yesterday. Gains were the largest since Sept. 28 and volume the heaviest in more than three weeks.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 3--Protestantism in this country is more concerned with the "safe and secure" segments of humanity than the "suffering and submerged," a prominent sociologist declared today.

Television station WNBQ in Chicago, which is owned and operated by the National Broadcasting Company, will broadcast in color all live programs originating in Chicago beginning about April 15. It is the first station in the country to plan such a schedule.

An insurance expert proposed to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency here yesterday that the cost of damage by floods or nuclear explosions be met with a Federal "disaster tax" added to income tax returns.

Two reportedly mysterious telephone calls were being checked into yesterday by Nassau County authorities investigating the shotgun-slaying of William Woodward Jr. Mr. Woodward was shot by his wife at their home in Oyster Bay last Sunday morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States Government is taking a most serious view of the Soviet Union's diplomatic, economic and military penetration of the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Senator Dennis Chavez returned from Europe on a regularly scheduled Military Air Transport Service plane today and insisted he never ordered a special Air Force plane for the flight.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 -- Judge Leon R. Yankwich has set Tuesday and Wednesday for the hearing of arguments in the 16-mm. movie anti-trust suit being heard in Federal Court here. Thursday will be available if additional time is needed.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A barren mare brought $60,500 today, the top price as Henry H. Knight's Almahurst Farm sold sixty-eight thoroughbred broodmares for $1,035,800. The average of $15,232 probably was the highest ever posted on such a large dispersal.

A THOUGHTFULLY organized exhibition of the late Max Beckmann's paintings spanning more than twenty years at the Catherine Viviano Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, stresses neglected aspects of this German-born artist's work, five years after his death.

Reflecting record sales, net income of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation rose to $13,637,000 in the first nine months of this year. In the same period a year ago earnings of $12,272,000 were recorded.

Six nations now have a million gross tons or more of ships under construction or on order, whereas a year ago only four countries were in that class, the Shipbuilders Council of America said yesterday.

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- There is at least one man in Geneva who shares the optimism of Secretary of State Dulles about the prospects for an agreement here on European security. His name is Vyacheslav M. Molotov.

Coming down to brass tacks, the Western Powers have in effect challenged Foreign Minister Molotov to produce a genuine plan for German unification in conformity with the Geneva directive or else explain for all the world to hear and judge why he opposes such unification and thereby defaults on a directive agreed upon between his new superiors and President Eisenhower.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Duquesne Light Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for three, nine and twelve months ended Sept. 30. Operating revenues for twelve months totaled $86,549,942, against $81,065,095. Net income of $17,202,262, equal to $2.25 a share on 6,600,000 shares compared with $16,004,696, or $2.29 a share on 6,150,000 shares a year ago.
The American Cancer Society heard yesterday that its new emphasis on running its own fund-raising campaigns was paying off.

FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 3, (UP) -- An Army court-martial sentenced Maj. Ronald E. Alley, career officer, to ten years at hard labor today for having collaborated with the Chinese Communists while a prisoner in Korea.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, off Florida, Nov. 3 -- This ship, the Navy's newest icebreaker, steamed south today on her first assignment, a 10,500-mile journey to Antarctica on behalf of science.

The letter to The Times on Oct. 15 of Jose Ma.de Areilza, the Spanish Ambassador, protesting against an editorial on Jose Ortega y Gasset, makes some observations that do a grave injustice to his memory.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas of Guatemala, leader of a revolution against a pro-Communist regime, called today for peaceful coexistence among all nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UP) -- House investigators were told today that dollar-a-year men had helped the Republican National Committee decide who should be hired or dismissed by the Commerce Department after the Eisenhower Administration took over in 1953.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN was playing an odds-on favorite when he plunked to make a film of "Guys and Dolls"--and, as any smart horse player will tell you, an odds-on favorite is a more than somewhat tricky thing.
The 757-foot tanker Spyros Niarchos, the world's largest oil carrier, will slide down the ways of the Vickers-Armstrongs yard at Barrow-in-Furness, England, on Dec. 2.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Prime Minister Eden called on all Britons today to join in a common effort to improve the nation's economic position.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 6 to 31 points (30 cents to $1.55 a bale) yesterday.
Nov. 8 is Election Day. No President of the United States comes before the voters, and so it may be called an off-year. Locally, at least, no Governor is running, so the off-year is twice compounded.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- The proposed merger "in principle" of the Crocker First National Bank of San Francisco and the Anglo California National Bank of this city, with total resources of nearly $1,500,000,000, was announced late yesterday.

A decision that three American blouse manufacturers should pay substantial penalties into union funds here for importing low-cost Japanese blouses -- in apparent violation of agreements -- points up the problem of Japanese competition. The method here employed is to recognize the character of that competition and to make an attempt to adjust to it.
An outline of dismal conditions in the world's largest public school system was presented yesterday to members of the Board of Education.
HARTFORD, Nov. 3 -- The Connecticut Flood Recovery Committee recommended to the General Assembly today that it appropriate $35,221,000 for flood relief to cities and towns in the state.
Senora Odilia Castillo Armas, wife of the Guatemalan President, on her first official visit to New York yesterday equaled her husband in distance covered and places visited.
GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- The Danish economy has reacted to anti-inflationary treatment in a manner to encourage Western European economists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Seventy-first Infantry Division will be retired from the active Army next year, when another rotation of overseas units is carried out.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Al Kaline, baseball's leading hitter in 1955, signed his 1956 contract with the Detroit Tigers today, then moaned that being a batting champion can have its shortcomings, too.
Employes of Pan American World Airways, represented by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., will vote today on a contract settlement.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, Nov. 3 -- Details of a fierce desert battle in which Israeli infantrymen drove one of Egypt's crack battalions from a heavily fortified hill and routed a column of heavy tanks were given today at Israel's Southern Command Headquarters.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Willie Hartack added three more victories today to lift his pacesetting total in the nation to 360 for the year.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 3 -- Emperor Haile Selassie celebrated today with prayers and pageantry the twenty-fifth anniversary of his coronation.
The telephone subscriber who picks up a receiver and dials a number probably has no conception of the mass of complicated equipment behind the remote switchboard that makes this modern marvel work.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Gov. George Bell Timmerman Jr. said tonight the Justice Department had refused to help the state return a Negro minister from New York on an assault charge.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold made new proposals tonight to Egypt and Israel aimed at restoring order in the Sinai desert.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- More than 200 Girl Scouts of this country and Girl Guides of twenty-nine other countries have participated this year in the exchange program instituted a number of years ago.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 3 (UP) -- Two University of California scientists have succeeded in crystallizing pure polio virus. This was hailed as a large step toward eventual elimination of all types of virus infections.
The horses and riders of the United States equestrian team were best in the international jumping of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

PARK AVENUE'S skyline seems to change as fast as a man can get around the block. The hulking Montana Apartments, from Fifty-second to Fifty-third, are almost to the final rubble stage, and wreckers already have their sights on the three comparatively new apartment houses, 381-399 Park Avenue, in the next block north.
The nation's banks experienced a sharp squeeze on their supply of lendable funds in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Two high Government officials made an effort today to ease the mortgage money squeeze without actually changing any Government policies.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A former employe of the Frankfort Army Arsenal here said today he had purposely taken documents from supposedly secured files to demonstrate to his superiors what he felt were lax security measures.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Britain's Atomic Energy Authority said today the chief threat to the fulfillment on schedule of its programs was a lack of skilled manpower.

DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A wintry storm blasted Michigan today, disabling one Great Lakes freighter and stranding others, knocking down power and telephone lines, tumbling temperatures and blanketing the state with snow ranging up to eight inches deep.
The American people are repaying their home mortgage and installment debts at the rate of $1,200 a second, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Army awarded a $73,000,000 contract today for more than 600 forty-nine-ton M-48 Patton medium tanks to Alco Products, Inc., Schenectady, N. Y.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- After a buoyant start, demand petered out on the London stock market today. Most sections closed with small irregular changes. The hesitancy was ascribed to the troubled situation in the Middle East.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 3 -- A World Energy community underwritten by all nations was proposed here tonight by a United States industrial leader.

Futures prices were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges in generally dull trading. Rubber, potatoes, cocoa, hides and copper rose; cotton-seed oil, coffee, sugar and onions eased, and soybean oil, lead and wool closed mixed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Television production on the West Coast is continuing to court that sturdiest of entertainment staples -- the Western drama. Two major networks are thinking about "Duel in the Sun," one of the king-sized six-gun and sage sagas.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Nov. 3 -- Leading French and other European business interests here seemed today to have decided to collaborate with former Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef and his future Moroccan Government.

A three-story industrial building at Third and Grand Streets in Hoboken, N. J., has been sold by the Keuffel Esser Company to the Bergrand Realty Corporation. The building contains about 110,000 square feet of space.

"Communist China Today: Domestic and Foreign Policies" by Peter S. H. Tang, has been scheduled by Praeger for January publication. It is a study of all major aspects of Communist China -- its political structure and history, personalities and plans.

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, lectured his Western counterparts at the Foreign Ministers Conference today on the superiority of single-list elections. Such voting practices are the role in countries containing more than half the world's population.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 3 -- Despite the problems inherent in the script, the Yale School of Drama has staged Sean O'Casey's Cock-A-Doodle-Dandy" in the refurnished University Theatre. The engagement, which opened Tuesday, will conclude on Saturday night.
Directors of Chas. Pfizer Co., pharmaceuticals manufacturer, yesterday voted a quarterly dividend of 35 cents and an extra of 45 cents on the common shares, both payable on Dec. 9.

Andrija Fuderer and Dr. Peter Trifunovic of Yugoslavia, Nikolaj Minev of Bulgaria and Vassily Smyslov of Russia were tied for first place after the second round of the chess masters tournament in Zagreb, according to a report from Yugoslavia last night.

City police and Federal narcotics agents seized 30.8 pounds of pure heroin in an upper west side apartment last night. The drugs were "conservatively" estimated to be worth $1,500,000 on the illegal retail drug market and were said to be the largest amount of heroin ever seized in the United States.
WALLA WALLA, Wash., Nov. 3 (UP) -- Ten convicts escaped through a thirty-foot tunnel under the west wall of the state penitentiary here tonight. The escape was discovered at the night roll call.
Further tightening of credit is unnecessary at this time, a leading New York City banker and adviser on Federal Reserve policy said yesterday.
AS has been constantly reiterated but is still not too well understood, juniors are a size and not an age.

Weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased their debt to the system by $182,000,000 on a daily average basis during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- A nationwide survey of the germs carried by surgeons started here today at the annual meeting of the American College of Surgeons.
Christianity must be purged of its "self-centeredness" and the idea that it has exclusive revelation from God, Dr. Arnold J. Toynbee asserted yesterday.

A class of teen-agers crowded yesterday into a school house built in 1696 to take a backward look over the centuries. They were learning a history lesson at old Richmondtown, on Staten Island, which the Park Department plans to restore as it was in the days of French Huguenot and Dutch settlers.
The nation's largest oil company soon may rise to the second largest corporation in point of the number of shares outstanding.

The camera was resorted to three times yesterday at Jamaica to decide race winners. But in the feature, a mile-and-a-furlong purse, the finish was so close that there was no means -- mechanical or otherwise -- of separating the first two under the wire.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- William G. Lias, operator of the Wheeling Downs race track at Wheeling, W. Va., lost the second round today of his fight to escape deportation.

Residents of New York City, as well as those of every other community in the state, have a deep interest in the defeat next Tuesday of Amendment 7. This is the proposal to authorize private construction of Panther Mountain Dam in the Adirondacks primarily for the provision of hydroelectric power.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 3 -- Billions of dollars will be needed for increased public school enrollments, additional buildings and a larger teaching staff, it was agreed here today by authorities on taxation and school administration. But they disagreed, sometimes bitterly, as to who should pay the bills.
A GOOD many people are concerned about the poor breakfasts eaten in this country, and not all who would like to see an improvement in the first meal of the day are cereal manufacturers.
Notre Dame startled the football world a couple of weeks by attacking occasionally an unbalanced line against ue. The Irish successfully ted the maneuver against last Saturday.

When Major General Remer was released from prison he was greeted as a hero by the people in the small North German city to which he returned. Other German generals and officers have been granted munificent pensions by Adenauer's Government.

Dartmouth can be expected to use a "tricky" offense against Columbia's football team tomorrow at Baker Field. An analysis by Lion scouts indicates that the Hanoverians may interest the spectators with their maneuvers.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Argentina's free foreign ex- change market opened today with hesitant trading. The dollar commanded roughly the same 30 pesos it obtained in the black market when the Peron regime fell.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor, Pietro Scarpini, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "LaTraviata," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15 P. M.; Marian Anderson, contralto, Carnegie Hall, 8:40 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3--Expenditures for new buildings this year will reach $42,000,000,000, making 1955 the greatest year in this country's construction annals, the Government said today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 3 -- Here in Union County, a Republican stronghold since the turn of the century, the Democrats are waging their most intensive campaign in recent years. Their objective: representation in the State Legislature and on the county's Board of Freeholders.

It may be that where there's a will there's a way, but what happens when there are two wills and one is missing? The mystery deepens when the deceased, a spinster, is reported to have told a servant that she was the mother of a baby girl, who also cannot be found. Many persons claim kinship as cousins to the dead woman, who was generally supposed to have no living relations.

Operating revenues of the New York Central Railroad rose to $627,132,387 in the first ten months this year. This was $42,232,923 above the 1954 figure. Reflecting this and the management's rigid watch over operating expenses, net income soared to $43,593,943, equal to $6.70 a share.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Rev. Louis F. Dion, an Assumptionist priest of Worcester, Mass., has received a Soviet visa. He intends to go to Moscow to minister to the spiritual needs of United States residents there.

In your issue of Nov. 1 you recommend that the electorate vote against Amendment No. 5. This amendment would exempt the construction of sewage treatment facilities from debt limits of counties, cities, towns and villages on the same basis that indebtedness for water supply is so exempted.

A shake-up of the Police Department's detective division was reported imminent yesterday as part of Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy's "produce-or-else" policy. The shake-up would entail the demotion of at least thirty detectives and perhaps a few commanding officers.

CAIRO, Nov. 3 -- An Egyptian War Ministry spokesman said today Israel had employed three infantry battalions aided by armored vehicles and heavy artillery in the El Auja battle. Israeli troops taking part in this offensive numbered 3,000, according to him. This big force attacked an Egyptian reconnaissance post manned by 100 soldiers, it was said here.

DETROIT, Nov. 3 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings and the New York Rangers battled to a 1-1 National Hockey League tie tonight on second-period goals by Len (Red) Kelly of the Wings and Wally Hergesheimer of the Rangers.

"EAST, west, home's best" is a moss-grown saw, but we are glad to return at a time when ducks are flying, woodcock are beginning to move, deer are becoming legal game and to a country where hunting is open to all (bar "No Trespassing" signs).
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Nov. 3 -- News that the Nobel peace Prize had been awarded to the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees was applauded here today.
GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- The Soviet proposals for reunifying Germany are an attempt to communize the whole country, Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, told the Foreign Ministers' Conference today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Nov. 3 -- Shellfire continued intermittently today in El Auja (Nitsana) demilitarized zone, scene of a battle during the night. The Israelis said they had killed fifty Egyptians and taken forty prisoners.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Nassau County Republican and Democratic leaders joined today in new demands that Mitchel Air Force Base be moved.
James F. Byrnes took issue yesterday with former President Harry S. Truman's account of the events that led to Mr. Truman's nomination by the Democrats for Vice President in 1944.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Rudolph Halley turned up today as one of the promoters of a jai alai stadium in Puerto Rico, complete with pari-mutuel betting.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Grain and soybean futures had a heavy un-detone during much of today's session on the Board of Trade. But, as usual, they ran into commission support on the setbacks.

"EAST, west, home's best" is a moss-grown saw, but we are glad to return at a time when ducks are flying, woodcock are beginning to move, deer are becoming legal game and to a country where hunting is open to all (bar "No Trespassing" signs).
Fashion is to be heavily pro-noted in the men's wear field in the months ahead.

In its first change of ownership since 1909, the twelve-story loft building on plot 100 by 98 feet at 31 to 37 West Twenty-seventh Street, west of Broadway, has been purchased by Edwin S. Lowe, president of the E. S. Lowe Company, which will occupy part of the property.
"The Heavenly Twins," an adaptation of Albert Husson's French comedy hit, "Les Paves du Ciel" (The Pavements of Heaven), will have its local premiere at the Booth Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Following is the text of a summary of facts and recommendations by the American Civil Liberties Union in the field of government information. The report was prepared by Allen Raymond, a newspaper man, in connection with a House inquiry.
DENVER, Nov. 3 -- President Eisenhower, now completely free of his wheel chair, took his first convalescent walk in the sun today.
Three vital additions to the city's $800,000,000 arterial highway system will be opened formally tomorrow by Governor Harriman.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3 -- The Mexican Light and Power Company announced today that it will have operating capacity of 1,000,000 kilowatts when its present expansion program is completed early in 1958.
Diametrically opposed points of view on the battle between Egyptian and Israeli forces in the El Auja demilitarized zone were expressed here yesterday by spokesmen for Israel and the Arab states.
Mrs. Theodore W. Hawes was re-elected president for one year at the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Sheldon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Senate investigators said today that the Navy's controversial jet Demon fighter still has not fully proved itself despite being equipped with a more powerful engine.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Nov. 3 -- Inequities of payments to state institutions for support of mentally retarded children were assailed today at the New Jersey Welfare Council Conference.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Following is a translation from the Spanish of the address of President Carlos Castillo Armas of Guatemala before the General Assembly today:

Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein declared yesterday that the real danger for the West in the new Russian attitude lay in losing perspective and letting the cold war initiative pass to the Communist bloc.

More than 800 persons are expected to attend the Horse Show Ball tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria. For the first time in its history, the ball, always one of the outstanding events of the social season, will have a philanthropic purpose.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Two officials of the General Accounting Office investigations division have been transferred, partly because of inaccuracies in a report on a Government aide last July.

BEN WEBER, 39 - year- old American composer, is a man who may produce something distinctive before long. His Prelude and Passacaglia, Op. 42, which was introduced to New York by the Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall last night, is a work that merits respect. It has a point of view and a touch of personality.

CAIRO, Nov. 3 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser said today that Israel's pre-dawn attack on the Egyptians had determined his answer to Premier David Ben-Gurion's invitation to meet for a discussion "of means of reaching a mutual settlement of the Palestinian problem."
New York is slated to have an anti-jaywalking law by next summer.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- U Nu, Premier of Burma, and Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin joined tonight in denouncing the "policy of creating blocs." They demanded disarmament and prohibition of nuclear weapons. They insisted that Formosa be turned over to Communist China and Peiping be seated in the United Nations.
Plans for a $6,090,000 project for widening Water and Pearl Streets in lower Manhattan were announced yesterday.

IMBIBERS at the Parade, the premier bistro of Tangier, have had occasional glimpses of Paul Bowles in recent years when the American Loti was not in the throes. Explorers of the Casbah in that same international city (after they had skirted the ramparts of Barbara Hutton's hideaway) were usually conducted to the alley where Mr. Bowles' work-room-dwelling stood.

The New York Society of Kentucky Women will hold their annual card party in the ballroom of the Pierre next Thursday. The proceeds will go to the support of Kentucky's mountain schools and to college scholarships for outstanding graduates from these schools.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Nov. 4 -- Thami el Glaoui, Pasha of Marrakesh and Morocco's most powerful tribal chieftain, was summoned today to Paris by former Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef. He left aboard a French steamship that will dock in Marseilles Monday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose, 6 to 21 points (30 cents to $1.05 a bale) yesterday, with the March delivery the strongest.

GENEVA, Nov. 4 -- The Western powers' arguments at the Foreign Ministers' Conference have made a powerful and favorable impression on public opinion in Europe, a member of the United States delegation said tonight.

Distillers Corporation - Seagrams, Ltd., announced yesterday that it had acquired control of three distilleries from National Distillers Products Corporation and bought more than 50,000 barrels of whisky. The purchase price was reportedly about $6,000,000.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The Federal Government was urged here today by the State Housing Commissioner to provide below-cost disaster insurance at rates all people could afford.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Nov. 4 -- Members of Congress from four Western states predicted today early approval by Congress of the multi-million-dollar Upper Colorado River development program.
GENEVA, Nov. 4 -- Washington is under friendly but strong pressure from Madrid and Rome to achieve the admission of Spain and Italy into the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Senator George H. Bender called on President Eisenhower today to "wear out rather than rust out" and thus to consent to be a candidate again despite his heart ailment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- George Meany laid down a policy of militant political action today for the combined American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, which he is slated to head.
Chrysler Corporation earnings in the first nine months of the year soared to $70,637,012 from the $3,724,383 earned during its sinking spell in the similar period of 1954.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The American Bar Association asked the Supreme Court today to uphold an order of the Subversive Activities Control Board directing the Communist party to register with the Attorney General as a Communist-action organization.
DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Passenger car output this week will rise to 174,097 units, compared with 158,430 last week and 93,162 in the comparable 1954 week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Archbishop Boris, titular head of the Russian Orthodox community of North America and the Aleutians, has been granted a visa to reside in the United States, the American Embassy announced today. He will be accompanied by his private secretary, Dr. A. Shishkin.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 4 -- August Vollmer, known as the father of modern police science, shot and killed himself this morning in the garden of his home. He was 79 years old.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 3 -- At the pivot of the struggle to save Singapore from communism is a 47-year-old criminal lawyer who compares his plight to that of man going to the riding stable for the first time.
J. J. Kruger, in his letter in your issue of Oct. 13, asks me certain questions and I am happy to answer them.

ROME, Nov. 4 -- The United States is pressing for international action to facilitate distribution of farm products in the world, Representative Clifford R. Hope of Kansas said today. He addressed the opening session of the tenth anniversary meeting of the Food and Agriculture Organization.

HARTFORD, Nov. 4 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that he would ask the General Assembly to approve a $30,000,000 program to assist Connecticut communities that suffered damages to schools, bridges and highways in the two recent floods.

DENVER, Nov. 4 -- Chest X-rays taken of President Eisenhower today showed that increasingly heavy physical exercise has apparently not damaged his heart. His physicians were described as "very pleased" because the X-ray pictures showed no evidence of heart enlargement even though he has been walking at will on one level of the hospital.

THORSHAVN, Faeroe Islands, Nov. 4 (AP) -- New violence erupted today on Bordo Island -- home of Faeroe Islanders who have been defying the Danish Government. A bomb was thrown at the Klaksvig Hospital's storage building. No one was injured, but the building was damaged.
Ground was broken yesterday morning for the construction of the new High School of Aviation Trades on Queens Boulevard between Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets, Long Island City, Queens.
Every time it rains, Dr. Herman P. Mantell, principal of Public School 87, can count on getting some telephone calls or letters advising him that the school's roof is flooded.
NEWARK Nov. 4 -- Primary interest in the New Jersey legislative campaign is centered here in Essex, the state's most populous county.

New York gave its traditional ticker-tape parade welcome yesterday to President Carlos Castillo Armas of Guatemala. For good measure, the city also serenaded him with "Happy Birthday" on his forty-first birthday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is enlisting the aid of a cereal company in an effort to get the kiddies out of the home -- away from television, of course -- and into theatres.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4--Two Dutch concerns were deprived today of all export dealings with this country.

MARGARET HILLIS is a musician with curiosity and generous frame of reference. She has proved in the past that a woman can hold her own as a conductor, and last night at Town Hall she gave further evidence that she can build more arresting programs than most conductors.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Mutual insurance companies are opposed to a proposal that New York State set up an "unsatisfied judgment fund" to pay for damage done by uninsured motorists.

A FRESH, lively and cutting satire called "Trouble in Mind" is being played downtown by an inter-racial group of Equity members. Their base of operations is the Greenwich Mews Theatre, a cultural adjunct of the Village Presbyterian Church and the Brotherhood Synagogue.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said tonight that President Eisenhower's "great crusade has bogged down in a sorry mess of deals and favoritism."
PILSEN, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 1 -- The stone base for a projected United States monument is no longer in this famous Czech city of beer and steel.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 4 -- Willie Bioff, former Hollywood labor racketeer, died today in a gangster-type explosion at his Phoenix home.

Mike Higgins, whose life has been "all baseball" ever since he was an 11-year-old third baseman for the Tyler Street Methodists in the Dallas Junior Church League, was named American League manager of the year yesterday by the United Press in balloting by fifty- six sports writers.

MIAMI, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Jack Losch broke away for two brilliant first-half touchdown runs tonight, but it took luck and desperate defensive play for Miami's Hurricanes to salvage a 14-7 victory over Boston College.
The delightful news about the dog fashion show at a swanky New York hotel has just reached me.
National Broadcasting Company television has come up with nine young writers and four comedians as a first result of the talent search it began last May.
If the weatherman will only cooperate, the largest college football crowds of the season in the East thus far will turn out today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- West Virginia rallied from a 7-0 half-time deficit tonight to grind out a 13-7 victory over a stubborn George Washington team that narrowly missed the upset of the year. The Mountaineers' eleven ranks seventh nationally.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Juan D. Peron landed here late today for an overnight stop on his flight to Nicaragua. He said at a news conference that he did not plan to go to Europe. "Too far," he said.
Help for the city's overworked and harried courts may be on the way.

Few investors are conscious of it, but they will pay more in fees to the Government this year for the privilege of trading than in any other year since the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 went into effect.
TRENTON, Nov. 4 -- The Navy dedicated a $41,000,000 laboratory here today that will enable it to find most of the flaws in new turbine engines without risking pilots and planes.
PAINTINGS and sculpture by prize-winners at the Village Art Center, a proving ground for artists who may move elsewhere, are being shown at the New School, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Dr. Peter Trifunovic of Belgrade assumed the lead yesterday in the international chess masters tournament in Zagreb. He defeated Nikolaj Minev of Bulgaria in the third round, according to a report received through Yugoslav news sources.
A hitherto unknown painting of Mozart has come to light. It has been authenticated in Germany by Robert M. Haas, the Mozart specialist, and Bruno Grimschitz, the art historian.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 4 -- The Protestant churches of the United States were called on today to match traditional deeds of Christian charity with a "highly organized system of social and health services."
The teams of the United States and Mexico came into focus as the best in the international jumping of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.
Rudolph Halley said yesterday he had accepted stock in the $1,150,000 jai alai pari-mutuel operation in Puerto Rico as a guarantee to the public that it would be run in a proper and legal way.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United States and Britain today opposed the enlargement of the proposed international committee to study the effects of atomic radiation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4 -- A capacity crowd of 70,000 is expected to watch Yale meet Army in the Yale Bowl tomorrow. The cadets are heavy favorites in the last game of the current football series between the schools. The kick-off time is 1:30 P. M.
Nassau County authorities said yesterday they had found nothing to alter their belief that the shotgun slaying of William Woodward Jr. by his wife was accidental.

The stock market surged ahead yesterday for the second straight session. As measured by the averages, the advance resulted in wiping out last month's entire loss. It brought the week's gain to the largest of any week since that ended June 25, 1938.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Danny Williams Jr. of The Knoll and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair won the qualifying medal in the ninth annual Frank J. Cloran Memorial pro-women's mixed Scotch foursomes today.

VICENZA, Italy, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Barely a month after the first U. S. troops moved into northern Italy from Austria, a big war started among Italian sports clubs over the services of American soldier basketball players.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The discovery of a new antibiotic -- derived from a microbe unearthed "in an old sod pasture" -- was reported today to an international conference on the antibiotic "wonder drugs."

Heavy rain caused minor floooding in Queens, Westchester and Connecticut yesterday and early today. A cold wave rode the heels of the storm, and the first hard freeze of the season threatened northern suburbs.

One of the keenest passing duels of the 1955 college football season is in prospect today when Columbia faces Dartmouth at Baker Field. The twenty-sixth contest between the old Ivy League rivals is expected to attract about 20,000 spectators. Kick-off time is 1:30 P. M.
Despite the building boom of recent years, more than a million couples are still "doubled up" and living with the parents of one of the partners.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The stock market finished the week on a dull note today.
GENEVA, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Western proposal, made today, on free German elections:
The swindling of $423,771 from a 77-year-old upstate industrialist was disclosed yesterday by postal inspectors.

A three-acre tract on the north side of Suffolk Avenue, between Jefferson and Reese Avenues, in Brntwood, L. I., has been purchosed by the Berger-Tilles Projects for a new shopping center. To be known as the Brentwood Shopping Center, the development will have a frontage of 335 feet on Suffolk Avenue.

AUDIENCES who like their police drama neat and realistic might do well to rest their home screens for a while on Friday evenings and tune in on the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio program "Twenty-first Precinct."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Sales volume of wholesalers in September totaled $10,700,000,000, a gain of more than $200,000,000 compared with August, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce announced today. After adjustment for seasonal and working day variations, the agency said, September's sales were 1 per cent above those of the preceding month.

Stockholders of the Associated General Utilities Company voted yesterday at a special meeting to dissolve the company. This marks the start of final liquida tion of at once mighty Associated Gas and Electric System of the late Howard C. Hopson. At the height of its power, Hopson's

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 4 (UP) -- Chandler Harper and Jerry Barber were named to the No. 1 American team position for the Ryder Cup matches opening here tomorrow. They will oppose John Fallon and John Jacobs of the British golf team.

The off-stage activities of famous stars of the Metropolitan Opera Company are the subjects of a book by Mary Jane Matz, assistant editor of Opera News, the publication of the Metropolitan Guild, Inc. It is called "Opera Stars in the Sun." Sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, it will be published Nov. 14 by Farrar, Straus Cudahy.

The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind aims to help sightless persons help themselves, to prevent blindness as far as possible through research and study into its causes and prevention and to increase the public's understanding of blindness and of the problems of blind people.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Quality versus quantity was called today the greatest issue facing American education.

Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, warned yesterday that the Western powers must restore a balance of power between Egypt and Israel. The Brooklyn Democrat underscored the imbalance of power, asserting that "Egypt's military budget alone is equal to the entire Israeli budget.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 4 -- Heavy rain, which began early this morning, forced the Harvard and Princeton football teams into Brigg's cage for their last workouts in preparation for tomorrow's forty-eighth game of their series.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 4 -- The United States has received Yugoslavia's consent to increase the size of the American military mission here. This was part of a recent agreement that ended the dispute over the implementation of the United States military aid program.

Readers of the financial pages were treated this week to what must have seemed at first blush to be at least a highly eccentric performance in the money market. On the same day that one of the country's largest banking institutions was announcing an increase in the discount rate on consumer loans -- the first since 1937 -- dealers in bankers' acceptances were announcing a reduction of their rates by one-eighth of 1 per cent.
Seaport officials will convene at the Hollywood-Roosevelt Hotel in Los Angeles Monday through Thursday for the second International Port and Harbor Conference.
Events today: Philharmonic- Symphony, Max Rudolf, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Thomas McIntosh, pianist, Town Hall, 2:30 P. M.
EXCEPT for the early season shooting on native birds, the progress reports on the woodcock have been rather disappointing, which is something of a reprint of the 1954 picture.

There appeared in The Times of Oct. 28 a letter from Yandell Boatner of Louisiana concerning the Supreme Court of the United States. Mr. Boatner deplores recent criticism of the court by certain Southern lawyers.

NEWARK, Nov. 4 -- The New Jersey Public Utility Commission denied today a request by the New York Central Railroad to discontinue its West Shore Division passenger train service within the state. However, it did offer an alternative of reducing service.

It was wet and it was chilly at Jamaica yesterday. It was no day for having fun outdoors. But there were 13,489 customers at the track. The New York racing season ends a week from Tuesday, and local horse players are well aware that the days are running out on them as they try to get even on the year.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Pravda, official voice of Soviet communism, spoke out today for the first time against the views that Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov publicly recanted last month. Pravda bitterly assailed those who held opinions of such "theoretical baselessness and political harmfulness."

A six-story building containing two stores and fifty-five apartments at 574 St. Nicholas Avenue has been sold by the Wintom Realty Company to the 80 St. Nicholas Place Corporation. The property, assessed at $175,000, occupies a plot 111 by 101 feet comprising the entire blockfront on the south side of 139th Street between St. Nicholas and Edgecombe Avenues.

The State Probation Commissioner heard mixed opinions yesterday on the practices of appointing probation officers on a religious quota basis to the Children's Court division of the Domestic Relations Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Congressional investigators received testimony today that a former Government official had switched from his Commerce Department job to a private industry payroll without leaving his desk.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- New York City, along with neighboring communities in New Jersey, has had the country's lowest vacancy rate in large apartment houses, the Bureau of Census reported today.

TRUE, Rodgers and Hammerstein have almost convinced the civilian population that "dames" are the only luxuries a service man overseas "ain't got." But what family could see Christmas approach without sending the traditional package?

John P. McGrath, former New York City Corporation Counsel and Governor Harriman's campaign manager last fall, will take the oath of office at 10:30 Monday morning as this state's member of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.
Earle Hyman is set for the title role in "Mister Johnson," the Norman Rosten adaptation of Joyce Cary's novel of the African bush.
HOLYOKE, Mass., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A C-47 plane crashed into the rain-swept Connecticut River tonight and five persons are reported missing. Three others were saved.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4--The old, old mother-in-law problem stumped a Russian housing expert today.
The Western powers were trying to make progress at the Geneva conference this week without endorsing or strengthening the military-political status quo in Europe.

AUTUMN brings one of the rarer and certainly one of the most delicious of fruits -- the pomegranate. Big, handsome specimens with thick red rinds and luscious ruby flesh sell in markets now for 15 to 20 cents each.

With four of its runners finishing in the first eight, Cornell won the team championship for the third straight year at the Heptagonal Games Association's seventeenth annual cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

Something is missing in what, in borrowed words, this corner the other day called the townscape of New York. Since it is the last remnant of a feature of that townscape familiar during the lifetime of most New Yorkers, comment on the loss of it has sometimes been touched with nostalgia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. (AP) -- Britain's Ambassador, Sir Roger Makins, announced today that his country had conferred honors upon forty-six Americans, from G. I's. to generals, who fought in the Korean war.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 15 -- The Communist factory work system is illustrated at the giant Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej clothing factory, probably the biggest of its kind in the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission permitted the Idaho Power Company today to construct the controversial Oxbow and Brownlee Dams in the Hells Canyon area of the Pacific Northwest.

The thirty-three-family apartment house at 812 Fairmont Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Edward Maltz, operator, to the Syndicated Realty Investors, headed by Irving Walsey. Schiffman Goldkopf were the brokers in the sale, which was subject to mortgages of $60,000.
Carmine G. DeSapio went to traditionally Republican Queens last night to make a major plea for a Democratic victory in next Tuesday's election.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Egypt is expected to seek changes in the new proposals by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold for restoring peace in the Sinai Desert.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 4 -- Studies to find means for splitting water with the energy of sunlight are being intensified, it was indicated here today at the closing sessions of the First World Symposium on Applied Solar Energy.
Governor Harriman said last night that the free world Would never have real security until the Soviet Union "allows the captive peoples of [Eastern] Europe both internal and external freedom."
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Representatives of the provisional Government are checking page proofs of La Prensa and El Lider, morning newspapers run by the General Confederation of Labor.
The American Cancer Society yesterday urged the formation of state agencies to combat the problem of cancer quackery.
The Amerada Petroleum Corporation realized a 54.6 per cent increase in nine-month earnings on a 21.6 per cent gain in gross operating income over the period last year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Commission house buying again cushioned selling of wheat and corn today, resulting in good recoveries from early low spots. December wheat showed relative strength, as receipts here are extremely light and the opinion prevails that red winter wheat holdings are concentrated in a few hands.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Mayor Edith Greenan of near-by Avalon was acquitted today of charges that she conspired to have twelve persons vote illegally in the April, 1954, primary election.
DETROIT, Nov. 4 -- At least two items of controversy must be faced and resolved here during the three-day annual meeting of the American Power Boat Association.

Four hundred persons attended the seventeenth annual showmanship dinner of the Motion Picture Pioneers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. Herman Robbins, chairman of the board of the National Screen Service Corporation, was honored as "pioneer of the year."

Service on the Flushing line of the I. R. T. subway was disrupted during the rush hour last night when a train bound for Times Square broke down at the Court House Square sta tion in Long Island City, Queens. Between 5:58 and 6:37 P. M., service to Queens was discontinued because no trains were available.

The United Nations, both on the ground in the Negev and through the medium of its Secretary General in New York, is redoubling its efforts to ease the present tension between Israel and Egypt. This is imperative.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended last Tuesday to 111.0 (1947-49=100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics Lower average prices for both farm products and foods accounted for the drop as the index for all commodities other than farm and foods remained unchanged.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The reports of The Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follow:
Three men and two women were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of stealing and cashing 300 checks totaling $15,000.
A little known device used to finance shipments of everything from goose feathers to station wagons, chiefly in foreign trade, stirred Wan Street this week.
IN "The Heavenly Twins," which opened one eye at the Booth last evening, Faye Emerson plays a French- woman who shoots her husband for infidelity.
Congress will look into the possibilities of a subsidy for the newsprint industry, according to Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat of New York.

What might be termed an auxiliary approach to the problem of reducing pollution in our city's air was inaugurated the other day at City Hall when Mayor Wagner awarded to a Brooklyn real estate concern and to the New York Coffee Roasters Association the first two clean air citations issued by the Department of Air Pollution Control.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 4 -- Official West German quarters indicated today that Valerian A. Zorin would be accepted as Moscow's first Ambassador to Bonn.
VIENNA, Nov. 1 -- Hungary's Communist Government would like to increase its trade with the West. It believes none of the changes it has made in the national economy need hinder such increase.
Ben Agajanian, the kicking specialist of the New York Football Giants, is a man with an unusual right foot and there's a story of courage behind it.
MINSK, U. S. S. R., Oct. 9 -- Minsk, almost totally destroyed in World War II, is re-emerging as a larger and more beautiful city. But much still remains to be done.
In a colorful setting of flags, bunting and blue ribbon, the annual Horse Show Ball was held last night in the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Bobby Boyd, a Chicago middleweight with a dynamite punch, stopped George Johnson of Trenton, the New Jersey 160-pound champion, on a technical knockout at 2:55 of the eighth round tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United States and five other member states circulated a resolution here today that would set up machinery for review of the United Nations Charter, but would defer action for more than two years.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 4 -- Emperor Haile Selassie promulgated today a new Constitution for Ethiopia. It grants the people the right to vote for the first time in their 3,000 years as a nation.
GENEVA, Nov. 4 -- Free elections next September to reunite Germany were proposed to the Soviet Union today by the Western Big Three and West Germany.
Directors of the M. A. Hanna Company declared yesterday the usual quarterly dividend of 50 cents and an extra $1 on the common stock, both payable Dec. 13.

Although the Philharmonic-Symphony Society has announced its desire to move from Carnegie Hall to new quarters in the planned redevelopment of the Lincoln Square area, the Committee to Save Carnegie Hall has voted "to accelerate its program to save the landmark from demolition."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee approved three resolutions today rebuking the Union of South Africa for having failed in its obligations as the trustee nation governing the South-West Africa territory.

Under the Bi-State Compact the Waterfront Commission has been set two principal objectives. The first is to clean up corruption and labor racketeering on the docks and to set up practices that will keep them so. Naturally enough the commission has been almost exclusively concerned at first with its function of waterfront policeman and dockside judge.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 4 -- The Russians have designed the biggest power generator yet to emanate from the field of solar energy research.
The complete coverage of the delicate and complex situation in the Middle East by your distinguished paper is cause for admiration and appreciation on the part of your readers.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday directed its counsel to institute contempt proceedings in the State Supreme Court against an official of the New York Boxing Managers Guild who refused to testify at the commission's general inquiry into boxing.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- Much recent criticism of the Ford Foundation and the Fund for the Republic has been based either on misunderstanding or plain silliness, Paul G. Hoffman declared here today.

It is clearly in the public interest that the tendency in official quarters in recent years to tighten up on news sources be most critically examined by the press as well as by Congress and by private agencies. The Raymond report to the American Civil Liberties Union on this subject, published yesterday, is a prelude to the opening next week of a Congressional inquiry into the whole question.

Brooklyn's immense experiment in cooperative redevelopment -- its $80,000,000 Civic Center -- has reached mid-point. This is the belief of Borough President John Cashmore, in whose tenure the project was begun and has grown.
A motorcade campaigning for the adoption of Amendment 1 at next Tuesday's election arrived here yesterday after a two-day trek from upstate.

The insistence of the Waterfront Commission on a free hand in the fight against pier crime was a major factor in the dispute that led to the resignation of Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays as New York's representative in the bi-state agency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Equipment that puts a propeller on a skin-diver became known this week through a patent issued to Walter C. Keogh-Dwyer, owner of the Suburban Radio Company, Rochelle Park, N. J. The trade name is Aquahomotor, but the patent calls it a "surface and subsurface human being propulsion device."
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 4 -- President Jose Figueres will resume the Presidency Dec. 5. He made the announcement in a broadcast to the nation last night.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 4 -- Senators Herbert H. Lehman of New York, Warren G. Magnuson of Washington and Wayne Morse of Oregon, all Democrats, have been marked by Republican party leaders for political oblivion after the 1956 election.
"Freedom of the Press Sunday" will be observed for the first time tomorrow in liberal churches across the nation.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- French Premier Edgar Faure battled today to stave off repudiation by his Radical party on the issue of electoral reform.

The threatened contest for control of Anglo-Ecuadorian Oilfield, Ltd., between the South American Gold and Platinum Company, an American concern, and Lobitos Oilfields, Ltd., a British company, has been settled.
GENEVA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Union called today for French help to obtain the release of a Soviet tanker and crew members long held by the Chinese Nationalists on Formosa.

TOKYO, Nov. 4 -- Martha Graham and her troupe, here as official cultural goodwill ambassadors from the United States, have scored a noteworthy success in introducing the "modern" school of the dance to Japan.

A dispatch to The Times from Leningrad by Welles Hangen, published on Oct. 13, describes the feverish enthusiasm of a crowd of more than one million Soviet citizens who turned out to greet the visit of the British fleet.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- October's employment will show "another sizable increase in jobs," exceeding September's 64,733,000, a record for that month. The Secretary of Commerce gave the estimate today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The possibility of sending a United Nations peace preservation force to the Middle East may be explored if the crisis there worsens.
The proposed sale of the operating assets of the Mojud Company, manufacturer of women's hosiery and lingerie, was canceled yesterday by the company's directors.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 4 -- United Nations truce officials were attempting tonight to arrange a cease-fire between Egypt and Israel along the southwest border of the El Auja (Nitsana) demilitarized zone.
TO hear Marian Anderson sing last night in Carnegie Hall was to realize afresh that greatness is, among other things, an infinite capacity for growth.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Emergency medical treatment for the injured, particularly for victims of automobile accidents, is one of the major weaknesses in modern medical practice.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 5 -- The president of the National Association of Home Builders predicted today the Eisenhower Administration would act "within the next two or three weeks to assure a steady flow of mortgage funds."
