THERE has been an overturn in the nomenclature department in Argentina since Peron was thrown out. Not long after that an Argentine ship reached London and went into drydock. "Before you do anything else," the captain earnestly told the shipwrights, "take off that name and put on a new one."

IN "Burma Surgeon" millions over the world were thrilled and inspired by the story of Gordon S. Seagrave, the dedicated missionary doctor of Burma. "Burma Surgeon Returns" told the story of his return to Burma at the end of World War II, after serving with General Stilwell, and the hard-fought road leading back to his "hospital in the hills."
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 5 --United States Army and Navy officers today completed preliminary negotiations with the Thai Ministry of Defense for American -financed military projects here.

LESS a novel than a book of visions, "The Prophet" is offered as the culminating work in Sholem Asch's series of evocations of Biblical personages. After drawing upon the New Testament for Mary, Jesus and Paul, the author returned to the Old Testament for Moses.

Many developers of home communities in the metropolitan area are being attracted to New York State's Hudson Valley area by its gradual transformation from a farming region into an industrial center, a recent survey shows.

AMONG the numerous able modern writers of historical fiction, there are few with a surer hand than the late Samuel Shellabarger, that versatile former headmaster of a girls' school who besides his fine novels could and did (under a nom de plume) write acceptable mystery stories and whose biographies of the Chevalier Bayard and Lord Chesterfield were as readable as his romances.
American Education Week opens tomorrow. Before the week ends, some 20,000,000 parents and other interested citizens are expected to visit the public schools of the nation.

BATTLE art is seldom great art, but some very good artists have tried the subject, and Roy Meredith has assembled much of the best in "The American Wars." This pictorial history runs from the French and Indian Wars (1689-1763) to Korea (1950- ?), and makes a valuable addition to the military bookshelf simply because nothing quite like it existed before.

HAMILTON, Bermuda-- There is an impending boom in surf-casting, called shore fishing here --not hitherto much practiced on these beaches--and the coming season will find this sport lining up beside the regular Bermuda stand-bys, swimming, sailing, golf and tennis, as diversions for the visitors and residents.
LONDON, Nov. 4--British sound engineers say they have found out what makes people stammer and how stammering "may" be cured.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 5 (UP) --Investigators of the car-bomb slaying of Willie Bioff, former labor racketeer, turned to Mafia operations in Los Angeles and New York today for clues.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad --Down here in the West Indies where pirates once flourished, and where, up to within ten years, trading schooners were still the only means of transport among many of the smaller islands, a phrase made famous in the Pacific in World War II has been adapted to the ways of peace here.
Reorders on holiday apparel and accessory merchandise dominated the New York markets last week, resident buying offices reported yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 5--The French Radical party demanded today that Premier Edgar Faure achieve immediate electoral reform. But the Radicals dropped a proposal for an ultimatum to the Premier that threatened to split the party.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican, Republic--"United for Peace and Progress" is the theme and "International Fair for Peace and Brotherhood of the Nations of the Free World" is the title of the World's Fair which is to open here on Dec. 20.

SOMETIMES I marvel at the devotion with which the translator of the classics sticks to his ungrateful job. His efforts, his temporary successes are taken for granted if they are considered at all; but what a chorus of catcalls attends his lapses and collapses!

IN "Judaism for the Modern Age" Robert Gordis, who teaches at the Jewish Theological Seminary and Columbia, has written a thoughtful and provocative book. To the practical experience of twenty years in the rabbinate he joins a scholar's familiarity with the history and philosophy of Judaism.
AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 1--A conservation law sponsored by Maine sardine packing interests has come back to haunt the industry in economically blighted Washington County.

A NOTED Broadway director, an earnest individual who has experienced several types of cafard under the pitilessly burning egos of at least a generation and a half of actors, complained morosely not long ago that he was good and fed up with the notion that a performer, in order to be outstanding, must be what he called "a total neurotic."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- When hurricane-propelled floods brought disaster to northeastern states this year, a dozen Federal agencies dispatched specialists to the area. Their part in relief and rehabilitation has not been told in full.
Col. Alexander J. Macnab, U.S.A., retired, noted big-game hunter and marksman, died Friday at Tripler Army Hospital in Honolulu of a heart ailment. He was 77 years old.

The work of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center in the East Harlem area will be furthered as a result of the Jan. 16 performance of the new Lindsay and Crouse play "The Great Sebastians." Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne are starred.

SARASOTA, Fla.--Here, on Florida's Gulf Coast, as elsewhere in the state, the citizens are anticipating none too soon the pre-winter tourist season. They confidently expect the November and December pickup to roll smoothly into the big bonanza-time starting about Christmas.

AN unusually large part of the recently opened oneman shows helped to raise considerably the average of attractions in the galleries' crowded programs. Special interest attaches to a show of paintings by the late Nicolas de Stael, who achieved sensational success in Paris in the years after the war.

New Look in Fund-Raising There's a new look this season in fund-raising for health and welfare agencies across the country. The familiar red feather, for many years the national symbol of the Community Chest and its principle of coordinating fund-raising so that no worthy agencies are forgotten, is now combined with the letter "U."
Two noted tuberculosis experts from the Pasteur Institute in Paris have arrived with extensive reports on treatment of a stubborn form of the disease.

AN Atlanta real estate broker, Charles F. Palmer, owned some office buildings near a sordid slum made up of wooden shacks when the New Deal's experimental housing program sparked his interest in the potentials of slum clearance.

PARIS. TWO of the bills tabled at the National Assembly last January have once again drawn attention to the difficulties experienced by the majority of artists in France. Their text provides for the allotment of a part of the credits earmarked for the construction of public buildings to the decoration of the buildings.
Free inoculation of children with the Salk anti-polio vaccine has been put off in a New Jersey suburb because of fears that the program might lead to socialized medicine.

ONE may rephrase the old saw about truth being stranger than fiction by saying that not infrequently history is more absorbing than the best adventure story. Richard Hakluyt knew this when, in the late sixteenth century, he successfully catered to the appetite of the English people for stories of adventure by publishing his famous collection of the voyages and discoveries of the English seamen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)-- Republicans accused Democratic Congressional leaders today of using 167 investigations to further "a smear campaign of immense proportions."
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 5--The American Ryder Cup golf team, sparked by some fine performances, took a 3-1 lead over the British today in the scotch foursome matches.

THE coming winter vacation season promises to be the best for motor travel of any since the automobile became a major vehicle of tourism. Many new and improved highways criss-cross the country and more accommodations dot the roadsides than ever before for what the American Automobile Association expects to be a heavy flow of motoring vacationists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--The Library of Congress has found it necessary to do something about a hold new search for buried and sunken treasure.

MEXICO CITY-- Despite rains and winds and minor irritations, the Mexican tourist industry this year will almost certainly exceed its goal of playing host to 500,000 visitors. According to the best figures available here and in the United States, where the American Automobile Association keeps close check on such things, something in excess of 550,000 visitors will have come to Mexico by the end of the year.
THE airlines, while revealing distracting plans for six-hour jet flights to Europe in 1959, have some attractive new services for the tourist who is ready to pack right now.

The merited recognition given a distinguished group of scientists last Monday as the 1955 recipients of the Albert Lasker Awards has highlighted the tremendous gains made in medical research in the last decade.
WHEN Lillian Roth plays a starring part in a television drama this week, she will, in some measure, be reliving incidents from her own life.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 5--The only close race expected in next Tuesday's elections in Nassau County is for Mayor of the City of Glen Cove.

PARIS--The man who has been trying to get to Europe for the past five summers and has never quite made it has something to be thankful for. That is, provided he can make it, finally, in one of the other eight months.

The Yorkville Community Association will hold its annual Yorkville dinner dance on Jan. 13 in the grand ballroom of the Plaza. The association supports a summer camp for children from the Greater New York area in the Bear Mountain-Harriman section of the Palisades Interstate Park.
"WHY do you suppose Wagner wrote one whole sixteenth note followed by a triplet?" groans Leon Barzin. He waves his arms in mock despair.

TOPEKA, Kan. THERE is a pleasant, mild joke around these parts to the effect that "Topeka's second largest industry, after railroading, is psychiatry." It probably isn't true because, after all, Topeka is the state capital, and government is a pretty big business these days.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 5 -A $2,000,000 aeronautical research and instructional laboratory is nearing completion on the University of Michigan's new north campus here.
Shoe producers are studying the hide market with unusual care these days. The price of spring footwear hinges on the direction hide prices take.

BEFORE and after his death in 1952 it was widely rumored that Maxim Litvinov, former Soviet Foreign Minister, had deposited outside Russia a diary or a collection of documents, to be released only after his death.
An eleventh-hour appeal for adoption of the $750,000,000 highway bond issue was made yesterday by Governor Harriman.

Vyacheslav M. Molotov, a Russian philosopher now visiting Geneva, was explaining the virtues of the "single-list" election system on Thursday. He thought the Russians had shown their strength and unity by being allowed to vote for only one set of candidates.

WHILE "The Spider's House," like Paul Bowles' two previous novels, has North Africa as its setting, it is distinctly different in character from Mr. Bowles' earlier work. "The Sheltering Sky" and "Let It Come Down" were novels of extreme subjectivity pinpointed on the solitary drama of the Hollow Man--withdrawn from the events of his time, passive and purposeless--who somnambulistically drifted through a nightmarish cosmos toward inevitable disaster.

Among this week's events in museums and galleries are the annual exhibition of contemporary American painting and sculpture at the Whitney Museum and a retrospective exhibition of prints by two masters of German expressionism-- Kirchner and Nolde--at the Museum of Modern Art.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- Twenty years ago next Friday two Army Air Corps captains rose to record heights.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 5-- The defending champions, Frank Vileno and Judy Frank of Alderess, entered the semi-final round of the ninth annual Frank Cloran Memorial pro-lady golf tournament today at the Forest Hill Field Club.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Nov. 5 (AP)--At Federal Civil Defense Administration headquarters here Harry E. Roderick is fashioning an intricate alarm system he hopes never will be used.

FOR most persons the business world is a place where the head of the house makes the money to pay for items in the family survival kit. But Cameron Hawley thinks of it differently; to him, it is the center ring of the biggest show on earth.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 5--The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee observed this week that he had heard "more about farmers' troubles than remedies."

IN a succession of novels and short stories Mary McCarthy has conducted a penetrating and frequently contemptuous analysis of the contemporary intellectual, or, more expediently perhaps, quasi-intellectual. This poor beast she has mercilessly divested of intellectual glamour and psychic shelter, thanks to an icily honest eye and a glacial wit.

RETAIL merchants are welcoming the frosty touch of fall. Seasonable weather will put the whipped cream on the Christmas cake which so far is stacking up very well indeed. Department store sales for the four weeks ended on Oct. 29 showed a 7 percent increase nationally compared with the similar period last year.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said today he was positive Southern Democrats who left the fold in 1952 would come back in 1956. They are "very sorry for what they did last time," he explained, adding: "I didn't come down here to teach the Southerners what to do, but to teach brotherhood."

PORTLAND, Ore, Nov. 5 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight of California announced today that he intended to release the California delegation to the 1956 Republican National Convention after the first ballot. The seventy members might then vote individually or as a unit for the Presidential candidate they preferred.

Col. Max Oboler, former assistant chief of staff of the Atlantic Transportation Terminal Command, has replaced Lt. Col. Mark D. McDonough as director of administration of the Brooklyn Army Terminal. Colonel McDonough is being transferred to Heidelberg, Germany.

TRENTON, Nov. 5--Gov. Robert B. Meyner named fortyone persons today as delegates from New Jersey to the White House Conference on Education in Washington Nov. 28 through Dec. 1. The parley was suggested by President Eisenhower in his State of the Union Message on Jan. 7, 1954.

ANYONE who knew a small Midwestern town at the turn of the century knows there were only two important elements in the population--small boys and dogs. No one ever took an accurate census, but the dogs undoubtedly outnumbered the boys; and between them they kept the town jumping.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 5--A Roman Catholic drive to continue mission schools in South Africa despite the withdrawal of a Government subsidy has succeeded.

A great barrage of advertising for holiday cheer is almost ready to break on the American public. All but a fraction will appear in newspapers, and magazines as a result of the industry's strict self-regulation.
The insurance industry is still not ready to insure peace- time atomic energy plants.

MYSTERY WRITERS OF AMERICA have come up once more with a novel and ingenious gimmick for their annual anthology. This time it's about dual detection, solution by collaborative teamwork, and is fittingly titled CRIME FOR TWO (Lippincott, $3) and appropriately edited in collaboration by Frances and Richard Lockridge.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5--A curious campaign for Mayor, with the odds on George Christopher, a Greek-born dairyman making his second try for the post, will be concluded with Tuesday's election.

The waterfront Commission of New York Harbor was created in 1953 by the New York and New Jersey legislatures. It has two members--one for each state. It has wide powers to "clean up the docks." All longshoremen and ship company representatives--pier superintendents, hiring bosses, etc.-- must register with it to get work.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 (UP)-- Quarterback John Brodie's passing arm led Stanford to a 28-20 upset victory over Southern California before 63,222 fans in Memorial Coliseum today.
DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP)--Doak Walker scored twice in the final four minutes as the Detroit Lions beat the Baltimore Colts, 24--14, before 53,874 in Briggs Stadium tonight.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 5 (AP)--The New York Knickerbockers spoiled the home opening for the Rochester Royals and 6,123 fans in their new $7,000,000 War Memorial tonight by nipping the Royals in overtime, l00--98.
Thirty-seven boys between 14 and 16 years old were arrested in the Astoria section of Queens last night as they were about to take part in gang fights.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 5-- In spite of a particularly vigorous Democratic campaign, Republicans are expected to retain control of Suffolk County in next Tuesday's election. They appear likely to hold their present 7-to-3 advantage on the Board of Supervisors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5-- President Eisenhower is scheduled tentatively to meet the week of Dec. 12 with Congressional leaders of both parties on his legislative program.

ALMOST an exact contemporary of Velazquez, the seventeenth - century painter, sculptor and architect Alonso Cano is now for the first time in English made the subject of a substantial study. He deserves it and Harold E. Wethey, known already for his researches on individual aspects of this most versatile master, has worked tirelessly in the mills of scholarship to establish his hero's identity.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30-- In New Delhi this week-end university students from many parts of India met to try to find out what was at the bottom of one of the country's serious problems: trouble on the campus.

LONDON. AT 75 Sir Jacob Epstein is enjoying his new position as the Grand Old Man of British sculpture. Until a few years ago he was still the enfant terrible of London art, shocking the esthetic sensibilities of the ordinary citizen with his incomprehensible distortions of the human form.
President Carlos Castillo Armas of Guatemala received two honorary doctorates of laws yesterday, one from Columbia University and the other from Fordham.

THE presence of Samuel Goldwyn's bright production of the musical "Guys and Dolls," which grew out of the Broadway stories of Damon Runyon and was delivered to the street of its origin the other night, has started some wistful speculation on the nature of Runyon's raffish tales and the few occasions on which their special flavor has been captured on the screen.

THE historical novel (at the strictly popular level) usually manages to reduce the complexes of the past to popular simplicities in the present. Measured by the unpretentious standards of this genre. Mr. Graves' tale of the recovery from Rhine tribes of three eagle standards for Augustus and Tiberius Caesar succeeds admirably.

ALBANY, Nov. 5--Every voter in the state who goes to the polls next Tuesday will see across the top of the ballot a row of concise blocks of small type, each one with a "yes" and a "no" level above it.

The American Cancer Society must be applauded for its decision to engage an international committee of fifty authorities in an appraisal of what has been accomplished in cancer research in the last ten years. Bishop Loughlin continued its domination of schoolboy crosscountry competition yesterday by winning the Catholic High Schools Athletic League city team championship at Van Cortlandt Park. The victory was the undefeated Brooklyn school's sixth this season.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5--A light vote of 2,195,000--less than half of Ohio's potential voting strength--is expected Tuesday in an "off-year" election. The highlight of the state-wide vote is a labor-sponsored proposal to increase unemployment compensation and permit supplemental payments to workers covered by guaranteed period wage contracts.

DOWN Mobile, Ala., way lives a man to whom the devotees of camellias owe a great deal. He is Koseku Sawada, a jolly person, who with a humble philosophy of "plan and pray," has developed some of the most famous hybrid camellias known today.
DENVER, Nov. 5--President Eisenhower began the closing phase of his hospital treatment today with his first walk up and down stairs.

Plans have been made at frequent meetings for the thirtyfifth annual bazaar, known as Ye Olde English Faire, to be held by the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York. The event will be held on Nov. 21, 22 and 23 in the ballroom of the Biltmore.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Really fallen are the leaves from deciduous trees, except apples and willows, One thorough raking now should suffice. To burn these leaves is wasting plant food. Pile the leaves in an out-ofsight corner to become compost, which can be spread over lawns or flower borders next fall.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 5 (AP) --Quarterback Earl Morrall of Michigan State galloped 90 yards with an intercepted Purdue lateral pass and his mates added three more touchdowns to walp the Boilermakers today, 7--0.

Sidney M. Barton, New York realty investor, announced yesterday his purchase of nine properties in East and West Coast cities from the Mutual Life Insurance Company. Sears, Roebuck Co. the retail chain, occupies the buildings in their entirety under ninety-nine-year leases.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- This island, six hours by air from New York and ages old in charm, is a happy paradox. It belongs to the United States and it looks and acts like a foreign country.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti-- The biggest news in the Haitian tourist picture is the recent inauguration of free port prices on luxury goods from Europe and hard liquors. Despite the fact that the small Caribbean Republic depends upon import duties for 50 per cent of its annual revenue, the Haitian Legislature courageously slashed its tariff on a long list of items generally sought by American visitors, and thereby cut retail prices approximately one-third.

HAIFA, Israel, Nov. 1--This city of 200,000 population is going to build a subway. To a shipboard traveler who has seen all Haifa in one sweeping glance, the idea may appear preposterous. Another surprising detail is that the subway will run up Mount Carmel.

Monte W. Sohn of Hillsdale, N.Y., who helped to develop the advertising trademark "Elsie the Cow," died yesterday at Midtown Hospital after a long illness. His age was 64.

ONCE upon a time, when life was much simpler, it was possible to open a movie, a hotel or a dry cleaning establishment without a premiere or a preview. But those days have gone, and in keeping with the times, we offer this morning a preview of the coming winter travel season.

AT last Benjamin Henry Latrobe has come into his own. Scholars have suspected for a long time that the coming of this English-born architect and engineer was a godsend to the nation in the Age of Jefferson.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 3--A Denver engineer is about to make his family the "guinea pigs" for the 13,000,000 families that, scientists say, may be living in sun-heated homes by 1975.

"When, a racing strip is watersoaked, as Jamaica's was yesterday, a jockey's best friend is a front-runner. Hedley J. Woodhouse had an extra-special fourfooted friend in the $58,600 Roamer Handicap for 3-yearolds.

LOS ANGELES--Next weekend several thousand people will, with characteristic human perversity, converge in festive mood on the spot that is the continent's most notoriously inhospitable site for human habitation or even survival --Death Valley.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 5 --A fired-up Wesleyan eleven won its first Little Three title since 1948 today by defeating Williams, 40--21, on muddy Andrus Field.

THE rare combination of a writer deeply involved in research and a scientist capable of explaining his findings in everyday language is offered in W.F. Berg's "Exposure" (London: Focal Press Ltd.; New York: Amphoto, Inc. $5), the up-dated second edition of which is now available.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 5 (UP)-- Halfback Eddie Vincent ran for two touchdowns and passed for another before he was carried from the field on a stretcher to give Iowa a 26-0 Big Ten victory over Minnesota today.

GENEVA, Nov. 5--America's secret weapon is a blue note in a minor key. Right now its most effective ambassador is Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong. A telling propaganda line is the hoppedup tempo of a Dixieland band heard on the Voice of America in far-off Tangier.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct 31-- The Brazilian Government has revealed some details of two moves to maintain its status as the United States' strongest military ally on this continent.

Two contests are taking place there at the same time, and they interact upon each other. ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.-- For so long most tourists and aspirant tourists have associated Florida with sunshine and fishing, skin diving, water skiing, and pretty girls beside palm trees on wide, sandy beaches that any serious aspect of life in this holiday state appears as an anomaly, something that somehow occurred by mistake and soon will be forgotten in routine Chamber of Commerce propaganda.

YONKERS, Nov. 5--A 4-yearold white miniature poodle, Ch. Adastra Magic Fame, became best in show today at the eighth event of the Yonkers Kennel Club at the State Armory. The dog is owned by Marguerite S. Tyson of Washington.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 5--The swiftness of Lenny Moore, a star for the first time this season, and the accurate placements of Milt Plum carried Penn State to an uphill 21-20 football victory over powerful Syracuse today.

GENEVA, Nov. 5--It was assumed here Mr. Dulles' visit to Marshal Tito would be too brief to permit the negotiation of questions pending between the United States and Yugoslavia. The visit is nevertheless of some importance when considered against the background of events since Washington reversed its policy and undertook to support Marshal Tito after his expulsion from the Cominform in June, 1948.

NO sportsman who visits Florida in the winter should pass up the bridge fishing there. This inexpensive type of fishing gets little publicity, yet notable catches are made, of large fish as well as small ones.

JOHN RUSKTN, typically Victorian classic in his own time, is, to ours, sharply uneven as a critic and baffling as a human being. Although this new publication of his subtly self-revealing letters is clearly not intended for a broad public, yet it may be enjoyed by many outside the restricted circle of specialists and researchers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--The Voice of America and other United States propaganda mediums are taking a line of "qualified hope" toward the Geneva discussions of the foreign ministers.

At a meeting of the National Academy of Sciences held last Friday at Pasadena, Calif., Drs. C.E. Schwerdt and F. Schaffer of the University of California announced that they had succeeded in crystallizing the virus of poliomyelitis. The achievement is important.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (Reuters)-- Results of today's British soccer and rugby games: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Birmingham City 3. Chelsea 0. Burnley 2. Aston Villa 0. Charlton Athletic 5. Manchester City 2.
Lafayette High registered a 34-19 triumph over New Utrecht in a Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League football game yesterday. The contest was held on Lincoln Field in Brooklyn.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 5--After waiting forty-one years to get together again on the gridiron, Cornell finally clashed with Brown today. The meeting resulted in a well-earned 20-to-7 triumph for the Big Red.
New York State has been advised to spend an extra $10,470,000 a year to reduce its skyrocketing mental health budget.

FORTIFIED by an unusually good summer business to Florida, the Seaboard and Atlantic Coast Line railroads are offering improved service for the coming winter season. Passengers on Seaboard's streamliners Silver Meteor and Silver Star will find a total of twenty-seven new stainless steel passenger cars in service, representing the latest in comfort and design to come from the shops of the Budd Company and the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company.

The importance of a well-rounded college program for students in specialized fields is stressed in a study made by Dr. Daniel Thomas Saint-Rossy of the chemistry department at Seton Hall University (South Orange, N.J.).
Training of parents to recognize the needs of exceptional children was urged here yesterday at the final session of a two-day conference on problems in special education.

Dartmouth rallied to beat Columbia, 14--7, on the muddy turf of Baker Field yesterday. The sun broke through the dark skies during the second period after a gathering of 10,000 had watched the game begin in rain. But there was no silver lining for the Lions, who went down to their sixth straight defeat after enjoying a 7--0 lead at the half.

GENEVA, Nov. 5--Another chapter in the post-war history of West Germany is drawing to a close with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's illness and the foreign ministers' deadlock on the question of Germany's reunification.

THE Lyric Theatre of Chicago has caught the imagination of its public. Judging by what could be heard and seen in a flying overnight visit for the opening "I Puritani" last Monday, this observer would say that Chicagoans are happy with the company.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla.--Florida's Legislature this year has adopted several new laws of vital interest to tourists. Their enforcement has only recently started. They cover such subjects as advertising of room rates in print and on signs, discriminatory advertising based on religion, regulation of speeds on major highways and financial liability in case of automobile accidents.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 5-- A West Texas cattleman, who said he owed $129,000 at 5 1/2 per cent interest, called today for a national referendum to let farmers decide their own farm program.
NOBODY on the stage at the Alvin seems to realize that "No Time for Sergeants" is the funniest comedy so far this season.

AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 5 (UP)-- Auburn combined a 75-yard run with an intercepted pass and a 56-yard pass of its own today to beat Mississippi state, 27--26, and send its bowl and Conference title hopes soaring.
As the onus of a defeated Japan slowly dims in the minds of the Japanese, the continued birthrate of occupation babies is causing bitter resentment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5-- An intriguing new chord was added to California's political symphony this week with word that Senator William F. Knowland might be expected to campaign actively for the Republican Presidential nomination in the event of President Eisenhower's retirement from the political scene.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 5 (AP) --Colgate ran up and down Memorial Field with ease today to beat Bucknell University's football team, 35--7.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 5--Unbeaten Maryland's big line wore down fighting Louisiana State in the second half today as the Terrapin eleven swept to a 13-0 victory before 28,000.

The Wednesday music program from noon to 2 P.M. in the Central Building of the New York Public Library will bring to listeners this week such old favorites as Chopin waltzes and one of Arturo Toscanini's first electrical recordings.

THE fabulous countries of southeastern Asia, one of which is the scene of Victor Chapin's second novel, are associated with a number of disparate things in the Western mind, not the least of which is the luxurious hedonism and sexual indulgence that lingers in some minds like Paradise enow.
BERRYVILLE, Va., Nov. 5-- It's apple-picking time in the Valley of Virginia, and the sprawlling orchards, the packing houses and the cannery of Senator Harry Flood Byrd are alive with activity.

MONTREAL, Nov. 5 (UP)-- Jean Beliveau scored three goals only 44 seconds apart in the second period and added a fourth tally in the final period tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-2 victory over the Boston Bruins before a crowd of 13,799.

THE American child's conception of the past is largely determined by chance-- the color of his skin or the recency of his arrival or his side of the railroad tracks or even the talkativeness of a grandfather with a well-stocked memory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--A high-ranking member of the House Banking and Currency committee charged today that a shocking scandal" was developing in Federal Housing administration and veterans' home-making programs.
VIENNA, Nov. 5--Austria formally opened the reconstructed Vienna State Opera tonight and at the same time celebrated her liberation from seventeen years of occupation.
LIDICE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 26--Among the first victims of atrocities of World War II was Lidice.

AFTER two productive years in seclusion in the south of France, Bohuslav Martinu is back in this country. He still has not found an apartment in which to live, but he already has started work on one of his largest projects.

The Temporary State Commission on the Courts completed last week a series of ten public hearings throughout the state on the Loeb plan to reorganize the state's judicial system.

ORIENTAL crabapples area the most popular of the small ornamental trees used to American landscapes. This is easy to understand, for aside from their beauty, they are thoroughly hardy in all but the coldest parts of the United States--and at least one Canadian-bred variety will withstand winter temperatures of 45 degrees below zero, an acid test for any tree.
A heavy volume of scrap iron and steel is being exported from the United States this year.

HAVANA--"The night before Christmas" hasn't arrived as yet but "visions of sugar plums"-- in the form of American dollars-- are already dancing in the heads of Cubans looking forward to the winter tourist season.

GENEVA, Nov. 5--Western experts have concluded that the Soviet Union will not budge from its insistence on keeping Germany divided. The experts, who sit at the elbows of their foreign ministers while the Big Four conference is in session, were able to take stock today in unaccustomed leisure.

Thomas Mclntosh, the 16-yearold pianist who made his debut in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, played as if he thought his strongest point were his big technique.

D.E. STEVENSON needs no introduction to readers in this country. Her "Miss Buncle" and "Mrs. Tim" stories have given her a devoted following. She writes of places, people and a way of life with which she is thoroughly familiar.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 5--Spirited contests for the nine seats in the City Council and for the three places on the seven-member Board of Education mark the closing days of the local political campaign, which is to end at the polls next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--A new struggle between the Soviet Union and the United States is now unfolding on a 7,000-mile front in Asia--the struggle for the "uncommitted third."

COMMENTING recently on his art, the veteran French painter Jacques Villon observed, "I was the impressionist of Cubism and I think I still am." However strange may be thought a combination of these two antipathetic styles, there is some truth in this self-identification as the present selection of Villon paintings, 1912-55, at the Borgenicht Gallery demonstrates.

SWEET potatoes bruise easily when harvested. If they are injured while they are being dug or in the preparation for drying and storing, they will rot very quickly. Therefore, in my New Haven, Conn., garden I make it a point to harvest them with tender care and only on sunny days so the sun's heat can dry the skin.

"NEARLY every crisis seems to be the worst one," wrote Mr. Truman to his wife and daughter just after Potsdam and Hiroshima, "but after it's over it isn't so bad." Then but a few months in the White House, he was already learning to ride the heaving swell of events.

A model house has been opened at the 276-family Oak Ridge Heights development on Inman Avenue in the Colonia section of Woodbridge, N.J. Priced at $14,590 and up, the dwellings were designed by S. J. Glaberson, architect, and are being constructed by Lester Robbins.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy demoted thirty detectives yesterday in pursuing his policy of "produce or else."

Forty-seven Protestant and two Eastern Orthodox bodies with a combined membership of 34,000,000 had contributions of $1,687,921,729 last year--an increase of $145,000,000 over 1953. THIS account by a veteran travel writer of a six months' journey by plane, sail and outrigger canoe in the South Seas is the best of fun to read--a book that dances and sparkles as it moves liquidly along. It is also a mine of information on the customs, flora and fauna, and history of the Polynesian world.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses defended himself yesterday against charges of unfair labor practices within the department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--The President's heart attack created many uncertainties. But it increased the likelihood that both the Republican and Democratic national conventions of 1956 will apply standards of selection to their Vice Presidential nominees almost, if not wholly, equal to those applied to aspirants for first place on a national ticket when the current incumbent of the White House is not available for renomination.

They feared that war had started-- and the fear was undoubtedly duplicated on the other side of the deep-plowed furrow that marks the troubled border.
