HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- A group of fifteen Hollywood personalities has been named by the University of California at Los Angeles as contributors to a fund that is to be used to purchase raw film stock for motion pictures made by student members of the university's Theatre Arts Department.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Four contracts, one involving only $2,000, are to set the pattern for awards of an estimated $100,000,000 worth of Government business annually to foreign bidders.

ZURICH, Nov. 6 -- White, Weld Co., New York investment banking house, received a charter here last week to operate as underwriter and securities dealer in the Canton of Zurich, leading European financial center.

CAMERON HAWLEY, who proved in "Executive Suite" that the problems and personalities of corporation management make fascinating material for fiction, has done it again. In his second novel, "Cash McCall,"* he has written a novel that is nearly twice as long and just as entertaining. A larger package with no decrease in value of the product -- what more could satisfied customers ask?
Pioneer Youth Camp, where children with different racial and religious backgrounds play and work together, will benefit from the Dec. 1 performance of "The Desk Set."
The words "mass" and "production'' are separated by 464 pages in Webster's Unabridged Dictionary. Henry Ford put them together and so helped to change the economy, look and habits of the nation.

GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- Harold Macmillan of Britain is the only Western foreign minister who has been able to get under the skin of Vyacheslav M. Molotov sufficiently to disturb the deadpan facade. His Soviet opposite number scowled and squirmed in his chair, say those who witnessed Mr. Macmillan's deft injection of the blunt needle the other day.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- For the first time in a year, France had a deficit in the European payments union last month.

Four floors in the building under construction at 625 Madison Avenue, at Fifty-eighth Street, have been leased by Compton Advertising, Inc. The lease is for fifteen years and starts with completion of the structure early next year, according to Collins, Tuttle Co., agent for the building.
DENVER, Nov. 6 -- Dr. Paul Dudley White began lengthy medical consultations here today to determine how active President Eisenhower could be when he returned to duty.

After many bitter months of disorder and strife the situation in Morocco appears to be approaching a satisfactory solution. The French have formally agreed to let Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef return to the throne. Embittered and often embattled nationalist factions in Morocco have now united behind the returning Sultan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The household food bills in 1956 will be about the same as for this year. Farmers will grow large food crops again next year. These forecasts were made today by the Agriculture Department.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- For the first time, an official French document mentioned independence today as an accepted goal for Morocco. However, the goal was limited by insistence on permanent and "interdependent" links with France.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 6 (UP) -- America's superlative golfing contingent, playing best when the chips were down, retained the Ryder Cup, emblem of international golf supremacy, today. The team defeated the British profesisonal challengers, 8 -- 4.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Students have crossed the color line in both directions in the second year of racial integration in West Virginia colleges.
In an off-year election in which county and municipal contests hold the spotlight, 3,600,000 to 3,800,000 persons will vote in New York State tomorrow. The polls will be open from 6 A. M. to 7 P. M.

Your Nov. 1 issue reports the latest in a series of efforts by the Defense Mobilizer, Arthur S. Flemming, to cut back imports of crude oil from the Middle East in the name of our national defense. These efforts are not a personal whim; they have the full backing of the United States Cabinet.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- Following, in translation from the Russian, are excerpts from a speech in Moscow today by Lazar M. Kaganovich, a First Deputy Premier, as broadcast by the Moscow radio.
Many a man who dreams of striking oil envisions it gushing skyward in a roaring fountain of black gold.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Reuben B. Robertson Jr., Deputy Secretary of Defense, said today that defense spending in the coming fiscal year might be "a little higher" than the $34,500,000,000 estimated for this year.

AN ELEGANT dinner party may be likened to a good play -- the setting is appropriate, the food furnishes drama, and the whole thing has pace, moving from cocktails through coffee as if it had been rehearsed many times.

Dr. Petar Trifunovic of Yugoslavia defeated Gedeon Barcza of Hungary, in the fifth round of the international chess tournament at Zagreb yesterday, according to a report from Belgrade. Trifunovic won in thirty-six moves and tied at 3 1/2 -- 1 1/2 for first place with Vassily Smyslov of Russia.

Plans for erecting a two-story taxpayer building at 462-4 Avenue of the Americas, northeast corner of Eleventh Street, have been announced by Jack Brause, realty operator. Mr. Brause has contracted to sell the plot of 45 by 69 feet to a client of Bernard C. Wolper, who is associated with Newmark Co.
Journalistic irresponsibility and the drive toward conformity were denounced here yesterday in two sermons commemorating Freedom of the Press Sunday.
For some time our friends in other countries have been growing increasingly puzzled over the foreign trade policy of the United States.

In the course of recent weeks Pakistan has quietly put through a monumental political reorganization in the West. A complex map has been redrawn, old structures have been discarded and a new provincial framework has been set up. The three previous provincial administrations, plus the various state and special territorial bodies -- ten in all -- have been put together into one provincial government for West Pakistan.
The National Broadcasting Company will spend $12,000,000 to expand color television facilities here and in Hollywood and Chicago.
While thousands in the vicinity of New Haven, Conn., last Saturday headed for the Yale Bowl, one particular automobile headed for New York. At the wheel was Albert J. Booth of New Haven.
SHIMONOSEKI, Japan, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The New York Yankees, with five home runs for the second straight day, crushed the Japanese All-Stars, 12 -- 2, today.

There are no nation-wide, statewide or city-wide offices to be filled at tomorrow's election. New York State's voters will, however, have ten constitutional amendments and one proposition to pass upon, and some of these are important. We summarize below our advice on these issues, found at the top of the voting machine, issues which we discussed at some length last week:

THE fourth annual "Cook's Tour" of the Yorkville Youth Conference and the Parents League of New York takes place next Tuesday, Nov. 15. On that date ten New York kitchens will be opened for viewing between the hours of 2 and 5 P. M.

THE N. B. C. Opera Theatre made another substantial contribution to television and to opera yesterday afternoon. It presented the world premiere of "Griffelkin," an opera by Lukas Foss with a libretto by Alistair Reid.
DETROIT, Nov. 6 -- The Ford Motor Company stands today as one of the giants of American industry.
Following is the statement by trustees of the Ford Foundation concerning plans to sell Ford Motor Company stock to the public:

United States growers of hops, the world's leading producers, have harvested their smallest crops since 1935. This is welcome news for an industry plagued by overproduction. It also reflects a change in America's beer-drinking taste.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Donald A. Quarles, Secretary of the Air Force, said today that the Russians were "seriously challenging" America's lead in the air.

THE egg jewelers of Little Ukraine, just east of the Bowery around Cooper Square, will show their gemmed eggs all this week at the Women's International Exposition in the armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The show opens today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- The public service role television can perform in disseminating information about social problems will be demonstrated at a three-day meeting of the Institute of Juvenile Court Judges to be held at Pittsburgh, starting Nov. 27.

GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- The Soviet Union may confront the Western foreign ministers with a proposal for a joint East-West study of free elections in Germany when the Big Four conference reassembles here on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears romped to their fourth straight National Football League victory today. They routed Green Bay, 52 -- 31, to match the greatest point total ever run up against the Packers.

As with many a good crusade that has somewhat mellowed with age, slum-clearance housing is suffering, it seems to us, from the lack of strong dedicated leadership. A book recently off the press, "Adventures of a Slum Fighter," by Charles F. Palmer, reminds us of this by recalling the zeal that created the public housing movement in this country in the depression days of the Nineteen Thirties.
American gifts to philanthropy through united funds and community chests are running 9.1 per cent larger than a year ago, it was reported yesterday by the Community Chests and Councils.
Five new films, including an import from Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 6 -- Mrs. Marguerite S. Tyson of Washington added another best-in-show ribbon to her collection today as her miniature poodle, Ch. Blakeen van Aseltine, captured the top prize at the seventeenth annual event of the Union County Kennel Club. The show was held at the Elizabeth Armory.
Disaster finally caught up with the team that had ranked at the top of the college football heap for most of the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Dave Beck, president of the A. F. L. Teamsters Union, said today he had voted for President Eisenhower in 1952 and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in 1948 despite A. F. L. endorsement of the Democratic Presidential candidates.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Attorneys for Jack Benny announced today a decision favorable to the comedian in a seven-year-old tax case involving approximately $1,000,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Jean Beliveau, who scored all four Montreal goals against Boston last night, tallied with less than two minutes to play tonight to earn the National Hockey League-leading Canadiens a 3-3 tie with the Bruins before 13,634 Garden fans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A private research organization urged the United Nations today to increase its study of the problems of the mounting world population.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Led by Queen Elizabeth II, Britons honored their dead of two World Wars at Remembrance Day ceremonies today.

A strong undertone for the British pound sterling and a sharp turn to the easier side for the Canadian dollar marked the trading in the foreio'n exchange market during the last Week. Turnover of business picked up considerably over what had prevaiIed in the previous weeks.
Ten Soviet housing experts returned to New York yesterday after a month-long tour of fourteen United States cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Personal income in September set a record annual rate of $307,500,000,000, the Government disclosed today. The figure was $2,000,000,000 higher than the level set in August and almost $20,000,000,000 above that for September, 1954.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The Secretary of the Army, Wilber M. Brucker, approved today a report urging development of a complete family of chemical, biological and radiological weapons for "actual use" if necessary.
The president of the Board of Education, Charles H. Silver, expressed concern yesterday about parents who looked upon teachers as "glorified baby sitters" and schools as "custodial institutions."

Election of Dr. Douglas H. Ewing as vice president, R. C. A. Laboratories, Charles P. Baxter as vice president and general manager, R. C. A. Victor Television division, and James M. Toney as vice president and general manager, R. C. A. Victor Radio and Victrola division, was announced over the week-end by the Radio Corporation of America.
Ground was broken yesterday for a $1,500,000 medical research building for the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
" Highway Robbery," a comedy about a group of new settlers in an Israeli village, will open at the President Theatre at 8 o'clock tonight.

DENVER, Nov. 6 (AP) -- White consulted with President Eisenhower's personal physician, Maj. Gen. Howard McC. Snyder; Col. Byron E. Pollock, chief of the Fitzsimons cardiology service who is in charge of the Pres ident's case; Col. George M. Powell, chief of the medical department as the hospital; Lieut. Col. John A. Sheedy, chief of the general medicine service, and Maj. Gen. Martin E. Griffin, hospital commander.
Dr. Clark G. Kuebler, educator and religious layman, was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a morals charge and one of felonious assault on the detective who arrested him.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- The Convent of Our Lady of the Retreat in the Cenacle resettled today on a 130-acre woodland estate opposite Wampus Lake on the Mount Kisco-Armonk Road.
The New York City Opera Company ended its fall season at the City Center yesterday with a matinee performance of "Carmen" and "Madama Butterfly" in the evening.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 -- Steel users were straying from regular channels last week in an attempt to get more steel and thus insure that the current steel shortage will not adversely affect their operations. It was generally reported that conversion steel orders and steel purchases through brokers were becoming more frequent in the tight steel market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler called today on Edmund F. Mansure, head of the General Services Administration, to say by Nov. 22 whether he planned to take any action in the case of a top aide, Peter A. Strobel.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Grain and soybean futures made a strong showing last week.

Fifty years ago Sir James Barry's "Peter Pan" was introduced to the American public with Maude Adams in the title role of the play. When she died two years ago at the age of 81 she bequeathed to Phyllis Robbins of Boston, her friend for fifty years, all her writings, letters and photographs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- A House subcommittee opens hearings tomorrow on charges of suppression of information by the Government.

In 1898 the Detroit Automobile Company was organized by a group of Detroiters. Henry Ford was chief engineer and general manager. However, few automobiles were sold, and after three years Mr. Ford was replaced by Henry Leland.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams turned two second-half pass interceptions into touchdowns today for a 27-14 victory over the San Francisco 49ers and undisputed possession of first place in the National Football League's Western Conference.

John Sloan Dickey, in reviewing on Saturday the accomplishments of his first ten years as president of Dartmouth College, was able to point to substantial growth and gain at a number of points. The college has been strengthened physically, financially and intellectually under Mr. Dickey's imaginative leadership.
ATLANTA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell predicted that Adlai E. Stevenson would to the next President.
The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday the election of three new general counsels. They are Edward J. Ennis, Osmond K. Fraenkel and Barent Ten Eyck.
BRIONI, Yugoslavia, Nov. 6 -- Marshal Tito and Secretary of State Dulles agreed today on the importance of the independence of the Soviet-led Communist states of Eastern Europe.

The thing that is farthest outside the comprehension of any lowly man is the insistence upon washing windows at this time of year. He is of course aware of a systematic disturbance called fall housecleaning, which takes place about now.
An industry -- wide shipboard safety and health program has been negotiated by the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L.

The Royal Danish Ballet, from the Royal Theatre in Copenhagen, will make its first American tour beginning next September, under the sponsorship of Columbia Artists Management in association with Howard Lanin. It will open a two-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House and afterwards will appear in Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, Detroit, Cleveland, Montreal, Toronto and Newark.

Last year Andover beat Exeter in what the winners claimed was the diamond anniversary football game between the schools. This Saturday at Plimpton Stadium in Exeter, N. H., the teams will meet in Exeter's version of the anniversary test.
CHICAGO, Nov 6 (UP) -- The New York Rangers defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 2, tonight to strengthen their hold on second place in the National Hockey League.

ROME, Nov. 6 -- With the approach of the crucial stage at the East-West meeting in Geneva Pope Pius XII made a passionate peace appeal today. Vatican sources said it reflected the grave concern the Pontiff felt over tension between Israel and the Arab countries.
The religious "quota" system of hiring probation officers for the Children's Courts was deplored yesterday as a violation of "basic American constitutional principles."
Unionized hatmakers declared war yesterday on what they called "the dumping of cheap foreign-made hats and hat bodies on the American market by unscrupulous sweatshop manufacturers abroad."

GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- Trade Policy officials of the principal Western countries have begun to see a little glimmer of hope ahead of them in their struggle to cope in an orderly manner with the problem of low-cost Japanese competition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The President may wait until spring, probably April, to decide on whether to propose a tax cut. This word comes from generally well-posted Administration sources.

GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- Much comment has been made this weekend on the speech of Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, pleading for a united and strengthened Germany, which Frenchmen have traditionally feared.

All the intricate machinery of investment banking business will be utilized in distributing 6,952,293 shares of Ford Motor stock to the public. From present indications the demand for the stock will be world-wide.
DETROIT, Nov. 6 -- The Ford Motor Company, which expects to sell 2,500,000 cars this year, sprang from a small beginning.

Cotton prices in the domestic market were again mixed last week. Spot and the nearer future contracts showed relative strength while the distant months weakened. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 38 to down 24 points for the week. The three most distant months again made new life-of-contract lows.

The financial community will have its own quiz contest this week. And the $500,000,000 final question, with everyone trying to answer it is: "Who will the syndicate managers be for the Ford stock issue?"

Four teen-agers on the New York Times Youth Forum agreed yesterday that parents should not practice "absolutism" over their children's lives. They argued for family conferences when children and parents reach an impasse on matters of importance.

Following is a list of the candidates for public office on the ballot to be voted on in New York City at tomorrow's election. An asterisk indicates incumbent. Abbreviations used are R. for Republican, D. for Democratic, L. for Liberal, and S. D. for Square Deal.

I am one of those who shouted a loud if ineffective "No" upon the motion to adopt the report of the joint committee at the recent national convention of the American Legion at Miami, directing the Legion to withdraw its participation in the United States Commission for UNESCO and urging the Congress to repeal the laws creating the commission.
Recommendations for alleviating the danger of mid-air collisions between aircraft have been agreed on tentatively by a Government group.
SINCERE feeling and a highly subjective sense of poetry were the finest assets of John Chagy, pianist, who played yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Housewives are obtaining more passports to travel overseas than any single group of Americans. Of the 334,284 United States citizens who got passports during the first half of this year, 56,790 were housewives. Students followed with 22,856 passports. Teachers were next with 21,682.

In his letter published Oct. 31 Garland Evans Hopkins, executive vice president of the so-called "American Friends of the Middle East," writes: "I * * * loathe * * * both anti-Semitism and anti-Arabism," the implication being that Zionists are anti-Arab.
An operatic program was offered at Hunter College Saturday evening by members of the Metropolitan Opera Association as the second event of the college's subscription concert series.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy warned members of his department yesterday not to use firearms in enforcing the law in trivial offenses. He spoke at the annual memorial service held at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, by the Shomrim Society, a Jewish organization in the Police Department.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Two union leaders took exception today to remarks made by Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, in a recent New Orleans speech.

The 54-year-old Jewish National Fund of America opened its new headquarters yesterday at 42 East Sixty-ninth Street. The organization is the land-purchasing and land-development arm of the World Zionist movement.

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that 1956 "is an ideal test year for rewriting of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act and the Refugee Relief Act. and modernizing the immigration policy of the United States."

National Airlines announced details yesterday of its order for six Douglas DC-8 jet airliners. The planes will be put into service on the New York-Miami route by the fall of 1959, the airline's president, G. T. Baker, declared.
Yeshiva University marked its tenth anniversary last night with a dinner and ceremony at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel. One thousand persons attended.
The Soviet "new look" appears to have brought with it the problem of how much freedom can be granted in an authoritarian, dictatorial regime.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- The Soviet Union reiterated tonight that this century would see the triumph of communism, whose ideas are spreading throughout the world "without visas and without fingerprints." On the thirty-eighth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution the Soviet Government said there was no need to export revolution because revolutionary ideas were exporting themselves to all parts of the world.
DETROIT, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings tonight flashed championship form in drubbing the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 1, for their first victory in their last nine National Hockey League starts.

One of the devil's most effective devices is to "keep people content with their little churches," the Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner said yesterday in his sermon at the Broadway Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A national art contest for the handicapped, first of its kind, was opened here today.

Home furnishings will get a good play in Christmas advertising. The Kroehler Manufacturing Company of Napierville, Ill., will run heavy national advertising on the theme, "Give a Chair for Christmas." The American Viscose Corporation will join with J. C. Penney stores in Upper Darby, Pa., and San Bernardino, Calif., this week, and later on throughout the winter in other stores, to show how Avisco rayon rugs are made.
Fighting on the Egyptian-Israeli frontier increased last week, but there seems to be no imminent danger of a full-fledged war.

The world's shipyards have a backlog of orders aggregating 17,416,000 deadweight tons, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday. The total is 16.7 per cent larger than that at the start of the year.
President Carlos Castillo Armas of Guatemala was honored yesterday by Cardinal Spellman and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
The steamship charter market has come through another soft week, with another drop, although still fractional, in the index of freight rates.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has found its assets growing faster than its spending.

MANILA, Nov. 6 -- President Ramon Magsaysay in a nationwide broadcast this evening made a final personal appeal to the people of the Philippines to vote for his party's candidates in Tuesday's election. The voting could have a crucial effect on the President's own political future.

Two men were most influential in bringing the Ford family to its decision to sell voting stock control -- Charles E. Wilson, former president of the General Electric Company, and Sidney J. Weinberg, senior partner in Goldman, Sachs Co.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 6 -- Historians have an opportunity to "spin mental webs that will weave the tribes of man together into a single world-wide family," Arnold Toynbee, British historian, said here today.
ZURICH, Nov. 6 -- After weeks of indecision lasting since President Eisenhower took ill, the Zurich Stock Exchange suddenly recovered its independence and elasticity on Friday.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., Nov. 6 -- Senator Allen J. Ellender branded as "asinine" today a Republican charge that the Senate Agriculture Committee was playing politics with the farm situation to reap votes in 1956.
PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Nov. 6 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands, game but weary, flew back toward home today after a three-week tour of her Kingdom in the New World.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 6 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry asserted today that Egypt was maintaining troops in "prohibited numbers" in the area west of the El Auja (Nitsana) demilitarized zone.

MAX RUDOLF, known primarily in these parts as the artistic administrator of the Metropolitan Opera and as a conductor of opera, made his debut with the Philharmonic-Symphony Saturday evening in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A liberal import policy is bound to bring distress to some communities, industries and workers, a Duke University Professor of Economics said today. However, it must be attained even at the expense of extending Federal aid to those injured, he said.
The Citizens Union has called on Governor Harriman for "strong, definite reassurances" that there will be no relaxation of the war against corruption on the New York waterfront.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 6 -- The Netherlands Bank again has converted dollars into gold. Last week it converted 36,000,000 guilders worth of dollars into gold, raising its gold stocks to a new high of 3,166,000,000 guilders.

Dr. Adele Franklin, developer of the All-Day Neighborhood Schools program of the Board of Education, was honored yesterday at a luncheon in the Sheraton-Astor Hotel. The event was arranged by the Citizens for the All-Day Neighborhood Schools with a $1,000 award from the Edward L. Bernays Foundation.
PANAMA, Nov. 6 -- Juan D. Peron said here today that the revolt that ousted him as President of Argentina had been financed in Montevideo, Uruguay, by the old Argentine "oligarchy."
Horace Ashenfelter took individual honors for the third time in the last four years yesterday in the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman clashed yesterday with critics who had charged that he "swallowed" propaganda in making an about-face on the controversial Panther Mountain Dam.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Jack McGrath of Inglewood, Calif., who lapped the Indianapolis Speedway faster than any other man, was killed today in a spectacular flip on the eighty-fourth lap of the 100-mile Bobby Ball Memorial championship auto race.
GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- Following are excerpts from an address to the Foreign Ministers' Conference Friday by Antoine Pinay of France on the problem of Germany.
Wit and erudition are rare companions. But in his lecture recital last night in Town Hall the well-known English accompanist, Gerald Moore, combined both with sensitive musicianship.

The old adage, "fight fire with fire," has found new application in the paper industry. The result is a technique of silencing sound with sound that will soon make possible the muffling of paper - machines' ear - splitting noises.

THE Knickerbocker Chamber Players, who gave six concerts last season at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, opened their second season yesterday in a new auditorium. They have moved to Town Hall and have taken the 5:30 hour made familiar by the New Friends of Music.
THE National Broadcasting Company and Max Liebman spent an hour and a half in three-quarter time Saturday evening with "The Great Waltz."
Net sales and earnings of the Borg-Warner Corporation and its subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year set new records and exceeded those of all last year.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 6 -- Archbishop Patrick A. O'Boyle of Washington, warned today against any future extension of governmental social services that might smother works of Christian charity.
A newly staged revival of Offenbach's "Les Contes d'Hoffmann" will open the seventy-first season of the Metropolitan Opera at 8 P. M. next Monday.

The Ford Foundation is the nation's largest foundation. The private philanthropic organization operates independently of the Ford Motor Company. Its assets, however, are principally in Ford Motor Company stock.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Dale Hohl clutched Tom Roberts' pass on the 2-yard line and stepped across with fifty seconds remaining for a 13-7 Holy Cross victory over Dayton today.

Basic agreement has been reached between the Maritime Administration and the Pan Atlantic Steamship Corporation for the construction of seven "roll-on-roll-off" ships of a new type. The vessels may lead the way to a revival of coastwise shipping.

Billy Steinkraus of the United States equestrian team and Brig. Gen. Humberto Mariles of Mexico scored victories in international jumping events at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday. The triumphs were the fourth each for the nations at the show.
Henry Ford was an inveterate critic of banking, of profit-taking by stockholders not active in a business and of what he at least once called "financial interests from New York."
Prospects for the real estate industry in 1956 are favorable and there are signs that mortgage money will be more readily available in the coming twelve months.

JOHN KNIGHT, Canadian pianist who made his New York debut in 1949, played again last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. His program included the first performance here of Four Fugues by his compatriot, Harry Somers.
GENEVA, Nov. 7 -- Erich Ollenhauer, leader of the West German Social Democrats, submitted to Secretary of State Dulles today his party's formula for breaking the deadlock on Germany's reunification.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the transactions of the Corn Products Refining Company in corn futures did not involve capital assets but were subject to ordinary income taxes.
TOKYO, Nov. 7 -- Gaiety in the traditional Japanese fashion has come to an abrupt halt in Omiya, about 25 miles north of Tokyo.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Television commercials will have to shed gewgaws, glitter and hyperbole if they hope to get and keep the attention of viewers, according to a survey taken by the American Broadcasting Company.

A community blood collection for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will be held from 3 to 8:45 P. M. today at the Kings Highway Savings Bank, 1602 Kings Highway, Brooklyn. Appointments there may be made by calling DEwey 9-9000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Racial segregation in public parks, playgrounds and golf courses was outlawed by the Supreme Court today.

Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Fund for the Republic, called the Communist party "a danger to the United States" yesterday. He said he personally would be willing, however, to employ a Communist for a specific job.

DENVER, Nov. 7 -- President Eisenhower will return to the White House Friday, but it will be late January or February before he knows whether he can stand the strain of living there another four years.
DEER hunters make a number of resolutions which, like the New Year variety, are never kept.

RALPH ROSENBORG, whose recent oils are exhibited at the Delacorte Gallery, 822 Madison Avenue, always has been attuned to the finely balanced relationship of man to nature. It is at that moment when the individual observer, or rather participator, merges with the observed that Rosenborg is transported and registers with fidelity the visual and psychological effect.

The impending sale to the public of the common stock of the Ford Motor Company will, it is said, be the biggest equity financing in all history. The initial offering is expected to bring in almost half a billion dollars. And the size of the deal is rivaled in importance by its meaning -- for both business and philanthropy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -Top Republicans -- including the G. O. P. National Chairman, Leonard W. Hall -- hammered out a program today aimed at mending what was frankly described as a Split in ranks in Michigan.
BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- Judge Bailey Aldrich today set Nov. 18 for hearing final arguments in the contempt of Congress trial of Leon J. Kamin, a researcher in psychology.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 7 -- A New York philanthropist announced today the establishment of a scholarship fund to enable talented Arabs of the Middle Eastern countries to study in Israel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Friends and admirers of France decided today to try to take the Algerian question off the General Assembly's agenda.
The vanguard of more than 50,000 equipment buyers for hotels, motels, restaurants and other mass feeding establishments converged on the Kings-bridge Armory in the Bronx yesterday.
A year-end dividend of $1 a share on its new stock was announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation. The dividend is payable Dec. 10 to holders of record of Nov. 18.
Danny Giovanelli, a Brooklyn welterweight, won his second fight in eight days last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is thinking of adding a new television drama show on Sundays from 4 to 5 P. M.

" THE WORLD TO NOTHING," last night's presentation on the Robert Montgomery program over Channel 4, contained the germ of a play in its third act: the tragedy of the star who is content to appear in motion-picture trash and forego the satisfaction that comes from constantly advancing his acting art.
ALTHOUGH airline tickets are almost as ordinary as subway tokens, and stewardesses seldom marry pilots or wealthy passengers, there's still a lot of romance in flying.

A speaker at the United Nations in a current discussion asked, "Can we reasonably allow that one-third of the human race should control about 85 per cent of the world's income, leaving only 15 per cent for the other two-thirds?" This speaker was Raymond Scheyven, chairman of a special study group assigned to look into a phase of the problem of the so-called underdeveloped countries.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The United States and Britain split today over a new formula designed to break the Philippine - Yugoslav deadlock over a seat in the Security Council.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Defense Department took another step today toward solving the great complexities of buying the thousands of items used by the armed forces.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7 -- The Air Force's request to use part of the Westchester County Airport in Purchase for a Flying Box Car training unit was rejected today, 37 to 2, by the County Board of Supervisors.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- With an average output of 30,000 cars a day, the nation's auto assembly plants moved today into the highest production ground ever attained. They passed the total output mark of all 1950 and roared on to what promises to be on eight-million-car year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A revolutionary change in the procedure of Democratic political conventions is being pondered by several influential members of that party, including Stephen A. Mitchell. None has sponsored the idea as yet: it is too drastic for less than lengthy consideration.

Gifts to please a variety of tastes will be offered for sale at the twelfth annual Christmas Fair arranged by members of the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church. It will be held in the recreation hall of the church Nov. 17 from 6 to 10 P. M. and on the following day from 10 A. M. to 6:30 P. M.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation declared yesterday the first quarterly dividend of 59 3/8 cents a share on the company's new $50 par 4 3/4 per cent dividend preferred stock. The dividend is payable on Dec. 1 to holders of record Nov. 21.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that its nine-month net sales had crossed the billion-dollar mark this year for the first time.
Thirteen persons and a corporation were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy to operate a huge illegal distillery in Orange County, N. Y.

Taking another stride in his effort to lead his country from medievalism to modernity, Emperor Haile Selassie has promulgated a new Constitution for Ethiopia. With this Constitution he initiates a revolution from above by voluntarily stripping himself of a good deal of his hitherto autocratic power and transferring that power to the people.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (UP) -- A police marksman shot and critically wounded today a county prison inmate who was holding a social worker in his cell with a razor at his throat.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- Two new harbors now being built in Istanbul, largest port in Turkey, will play an important part in the country's import and export trade.
VIENNA, Nov. 7 -- The Austrian oil industry is stymied in its effort to sell its products at home or abroad.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -The Department of Commerce said today that stocks of unsold goods held by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers totaled some $79,600,000,000 at the end of September.

The four-story business building at 207 West Thirty-eighth Street, adjoining the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue, has been sold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to a customer of the Jay R. Braus Company, broker in the transaction. The property, on plot 20 by 90 feet, has an assessed valuation of $80,000.

GENEVA, Nov. 7 -- Only the presentation tomorrow of negotiable Soviet proposals on German reunification can avert the final deadlock of the Foreign Ministers' Conference on its most important issue, authoritative Western sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, retired Army Chief of Staff, is writing his memoirs. Persons who have seen the manuscript say it contains political high explosive.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- A generally firm undertone was shown in grain futures today, while there was moderate pressure on soybeans. There was no special news to explain the firmness in grains, but there was only moderate selling pressure and there appeared to be some local as well as commission buying.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced plans today to close down thirty-two military facilities that compete with private business.
The ballot box is one of several important reminders of a citizen's responsibility.

DENVER, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board's chief investigator confirmed tonight that evidence has been found of a "bomb-like explosion" in the United Air Lines DC-6B that crashed near Longmont, Colo., last Tuesday. Forty-four persons were killed in the crash.

Gross operating revenues and net earnings of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., for the first nine months of this year were at record levels, according to the report released yesterday by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, chairman, and Thomas F. Armstrong, president.

Money for mortgage loans next year will be adequate to meet the country's needs, according to Miles L. Colean of Washington, D. C., economist and consultant, who spoke at a meeting of the Mortgage Council of the National Association of Real Estate Boards yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Forty former political prisoners in Nazi and Soviet concentration camps marched in the rain yesterday in honor of the Unknown Political Prisoner.
The duel for most first places in the international jumping at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden between Mexico and the United States continued with remarkable intensity yesterday.

MARGARET TRUMAN joined the ranks of regular radio personalities yesterday. She began her assignment as hostess of the National Broadcasting Company's new daily radio show called "Weekday." The daughter of the former President acquitted herself with charm and naturalness.
Benjamin Fine's article headlined "U. S. Aid for State Schools Asked in Plan That Would Double Costs," appearing in The Times of Nov. 3, is unfortunately somewhat misleading.

This century is the "century of the triumph of socialism and communism," Soviet First Deputy Premier Lazar M. Kaganovich confidently assured his Moscow audience on Sunday. Such assertions are easily made. Hitler used to speak confidently often of the "Thousand Year Reich."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -The Supreme Court today declined to review efforts by eight utility companies in Kansas, Missouri and Arkansas to block Rural Electrification Administration loans to five electric cooperatives.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP)--Corporate dividend payments continued their sharp 1955 rise through September, the Department of Commerce said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Newspaper men told Congress today that official suppression of news was seriously endangering the public's right to know the facts about Government activities.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Nov. 8 -- Vyacheslev M. Molotov flew back to the Geneva Foreign Ministers' Conference early today with what he described as "better baggage" following two days of consultations with Soviet Government leaders.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery said today the Soviet Union was putting the "heat" on in Egypt and would extend its anti-Western pressure toward turbulent French Morocco.

RAHWAY, N. J., Nov. 7 -- The conviction of former Police Chief Clifford W. Dunphy of this city on neglect of duty charges was set aside today in a unanimous decision by the State Supreme Court. The court also granted the defendant's request for a new trial.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Treasury Department reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had dropped again.
An art deal consummated Saturday between a "museum director" and a New York gallery owner proved artfully fraudulent when the banks reopened for business yesterday.

The International Longshoremen's Association continued its attack yesterday on the Waterfront Commission. The pier group charged "fraud" and "cynicism" to the bi-state agency at the third hearing of the unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 7 (AP) -- One Government agency is seeking to reduce the amount of credit available for home mortgages while two other agencies are increasing the credit demand by their policies, an economist said today.

St. Cecilia of Englewood captured a football crown yesterday without putting a man in uniform. The School gained the 1954 North Jersey Catholic Class A championship in a conference room at the Newark Athletic Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has given Susan Hayward her first work assignment for 1956. This will be the starring role in "Hilda Crane," the Samson Raphael son drama, which was staged on Broadway five years ago this month.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Daily News said today an engineering concern has recommended a merger of the Chicago and North Western Railway Company and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company.
PANAMA, Nov. 7 -- Juan D. Peron plans to establish his residence in exile in Panama, a spokesman for the deposed Argentine dictator announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7, (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies today signed Wally Westlake, an outfielder, as a free agent.

The minesweeper Skill, representing the Navy's most recent efforts to achieve a non-magnetic hull, was commissioned yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn. The 165-foot vessel, built by the Luders Marine Construction Company of Stamford, Conn., was constructed throughout of materials as low in magnetic attraction as could be used.

Maurice Evans has signed contracts to star on Broadway next season in a new production of Bernard Shaw's fable, "The Apple Cart," under the auspices of Charles Adams and Joseph Neebe, a new producing team.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 7 -- Virginia, seeking a legal means of avoiding racially integrated schools, was told today that it could not use public funds to educate children in private schools under existing law.

Golda Myerson, the American who became Israel's first Minister to Moscow and her Minister of Labor, is the subject of a biography by Marie Syrkin. In "Way of Valor," Miss Syrkin tells the story of the rise of Israel through the life of Mrs. Myerson.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7(AP) -The Supreme Court called today for arguments on California's request that Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming participate in a suit over use of waters of the Colorado River system.
A key section of the financial district will be refashioned into a downtown "Rockefeller Center" -- plaza and all -- if plans of the Chase Manhattan Bank are realized.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Sharp criticism of Federal agencies, especially the military, for closing large tracts of Western land to prospecting and mining marked the opening today of a Western Governors conference on mineral policies.
" HIGHWAY PATROL," seen last night from 7 to 7:30 o'clock on Channel 4, is a different kind of cops-androbbers series.

Pedestrians violating an anti-jaywalking law in New York City would be subject to maximum penalties of $50 in fines or thirty days in jail, or both, under a suggestion offered yesterday by the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced tonight that a group of its experts would meet Dec. 12 to lay out possible testing requirements for the four-engined Boeing 707 jet transport.
Radio Free Europe is arranging for "Stardust" to fall in Bulgaria tonight.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 (AP) -Clarence W. Miles today said the "impelling reason" in his decision to quit as Orioles' president, "is my deep-rooted conviction that the services of an experienced baseball executive brought to Baltimore at this time would greatly improve the chances of the Orioles for rapid advancement."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Three of twenty-two Polish seamen admitted to the United States have returned to their Communist homeland after having been approached by representatives of the Polish Government.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Nov. 7 -- The Earl of Hume today told the Junior Chamber of the International World Congress that great opportunities for British and foreign industrialists lay in the markets of the British Commonwealth.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

This is the week of that old Down East football thriller, the Yale-Princeton game. The Bulldog and the Tiger tangle in Palmer Stadium Saturday before a sellout crowd of 46,000 and the fans are warned to be prepared to hold on to their hats.
Off-year elections in New York and eleven other states today will turn chiefly on local and state issues.

AN admirable virtue of individuals and nations is the ability to laugh at their foibles and their problems in the midst of strain and tribulation. That virtue apparently is possessed by Moshe Shamir and his native country, Israel, about which he is writing in "Highway Robbery," the new comedy presented last night at the tiny President Theatre by the recently organized Heritage Group Players.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- The Soviet armed forces will go on mastering the latest weapons and techniques despite Moscow's efforts to relieve international tension, it was announced today by Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Soviet Defense Minister.
Following are the texts of the statement by Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays and the joint statement of Governors Harriman and Meyner:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The United States will agree to sell Israel a "significant" quantity of arms, United States officials said this afternoon. The announcement followed a visit by Israeli Ambassador Abba Eban to George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State.
Dean Courtney C. Brown of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business has been appointed vice president of the university in charge of business affairs.

There were many references to Brownie, Wait A Bit and Bossuet when the Marine Parkway Classified Handicap at Jamaica was concluded yesterday. The subject was brought up by First Aid, Bertie and Mandingo, who finished so close together that a triple dead heat would not have been a bad call.
The explosive issue of segregation in New York City's own schools has now been put to the test of scientific study.

Danneman Printing Co, floor in 161 Variek St from Oxford University Press; Universal Ribbon Co, floor in 112 E 129th St; Regent Belt Co, floor in 138 W 14th St; Associated Book Service, additional floor in the Terminal Warehouse, 600 W 28th St--Robert Joseph Co Inc, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Following are the text of the Supreme Court opinion written by Justice Hugo L. Black, striking down as unconstitutional certain provisions of the Uniform Code of Military Justice, and excerpts of dissenting opinions.

THE Texas sculptor, Charles Umlauf, whose work has not been shown in New York for several years, is exhibiting figures, portrait heads and animals at the Passedoit Gallery, 121 East Fifty-seventh Street.

TORONTO, Nov. 7 -- When all nations live in accordance with international law and righteousness, then peace and order will prevail, Herbert Brownell Jr., United States Attorney General, said here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee voted unanimously today to establish an international scientific body to study the effects of atomic radiation on man's health and environment.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Five judges in the House of Lords held today that a person wrongfully expelled from a trade union could sue it for damages.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that civilians could not be tried by court-martial for crimes committed while in military service. Justice Hugo L. Black wrote the 6-to-3 opinion. He held that Congress had invaded the Constitutional powers of the Federal judiciary in adopting a key provision of the 1950 Uniform Code of Military Justice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon went to school today and did a little apple-polishing for the teacher.

Steel production declined slightly last week to 2,400,000 net tons, with the industry operating its steel-making facilities at 99.4 per cent of rated capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. That compared with the record output of 2,413,000 tons and operations of 100 per cent, reported for the previous week.

Shrimp, most abundant of shellfish now, varies considerably in price, depending on size. In one chain store the largest specimens sell for 20 cents a pound more than the medium size. Yet the only advantage of the big shrimp is that they are easier to clean and peal.

A reception and sale for the benefit of the St. Luke's Home for Aged Women will take place at the Home tomorrow and Thursday from 11 A. M. to 5 P. M, The board of managers and the residents of the Home at 2914 Broadway have planned a luncheon on the opening day and a tea Thursday afternoon.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 7 (AP) -- In a surprise move late today Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt entered his Social Outcast in next Friday's Washington, D. C., International.
Leslie H. Warner was elected yesterday president of Automatic Electric Company, a subsidiary of Theodore Gary Co. The Gary organization was recently merged into General Telephone Corporation.
All that kept Wall Street from being flooded yesterday with orders to buy Ford stock on a "when, as and if issued" basis was the little matter of Section 5 of the Securities Act of 1933.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Mohammed ben Youssef, newly recognized as the Sultan of Morocco after two years in exile, devoted his time today to ceremonious visits with French leaders.

Trading in commodity futures was dull yesterday on the New York exchanges. Most markets will be closed today for Election Day. Price changes for rubber, coffee, cottonseed oil and sugar were mixed; potatoes, hides, wool and burlap rose, and cocoa, soybean oil, onions and lead declined.
MANILA, Tuesday, Nov. 8 -- Philippines voters go to the polls today in an election that puts to the test the pro-Western policies and personal popularity of President Ramon Magsaysay.

According to reports to this newspaper, the Government of Premier-President Diem in South Vietnam has struck a telling blow against one of the dissident sects, the Cao Dai. The head of the sect is presumably under some sort of detention and his staff has been dissolved or is in flight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Employment in the United States last month reached a record level for October. There were 65,161,000 jobs.
DENVER, Nov. 7 (AP) -- There's a new putting green at President Eisenhower's farm in Gettysburg, Pa. He probably will be able to try it out next month, weather permitting.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7, (UP) -- Now they're "hanging"I pro football coaches.
Les lVlillington paced Boys High's attack with :four touchdowns as the Reel andBlack defeated Tilden Higb of B rooldyn, 34--0, o the winner's field in Br,oklyn yesterday.
A group of Fordham College students has voted President Eisenhower the most able Republican candidate for 1956 and the one most likely to win that election.

WHAT makes a man great and which historical personages were truly great are bothersome questions, not to be settled in an evening or two's conversation. Whether Shane, the O'Neill, chief of the clan O'Neill and Prince of Ulster, was a genuinely great man I doubt now that I have finished reading Elizabeth Linington's thumping historical romance, "The Proud Man."*

The Council for Independent Distribution, an organization of independent wholesalers of magazines, newspapers, comics, paper-bound books and other periodicals, has completed its formation. The development is announced in a bulletin in the mail to some 850 independents in the field, distributing 80 per cent of the country's magazines.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 7 -- The impression was manifest today that Secretary of State Dulles and President Tito might not have had the same considerations in mind when they reached a "common accord" yesterday on the problem of East European states.
Bowater Paper Company announced yesterday a $4 a ton increase in the price of its newsprint, effective on Dec. 1. This would bring its price then to $131 a ton delivered in New York.

LONDON, November 7 (Reuters) -- The Communist world was represented tonight for the first time at the annual Royal Variety Performance, one of the biggest and most glittering events of Britain's theatrical year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- An investigator for a House Armed Services subcommittee is investigating complaints that Navy Reserve pilots are required to fly unreliable jet planes.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Most prices fell in the stock market here today under the influence of British Government securities, which were sharply lower despite the strength of sterling against the dollar. Some gilt edge issues lost more than 1 ($2.80) on the 100 unit.
TOKYO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, recuperating from a heart attack, sent to the Japanese Prime Minister, Ichiro Hatoyama, a message that said:
Complete agreement on the basic objectives and purposes of the Waterfront Commission was announced yesterday by Governor Harriman of New York and Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey.
The appointment of Capt. Olaf Bjornstad as master of the new 18,500-ton Norwegian America Line passenger vessel Bergensfjord was announced here yesterday.
HUTCHINSON, Kan., Nov. 7 -- Farmers in traditionally Republican Kansas demanded today a new Government program for wheat, the Administration's biggest surplus problem.
The Committee of American Steamship Lines took issue here yesterday with a recommendation by the National Planning Association that the United States eliminate its cargo-preference legislation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Eisenhower's Cabinet sent regrets, but that did not seem to dampen the "spirit of Geneva" at the annual Soviet Embassy reception tonight. It marked the thirty-eighth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -The Supreme Court turned down today the appeals of the editor of The China Daily News and two stockholders who were sentenced to prison for transactions with Red China. It gave no reason for its action.

In its editorial of Nov. 2 entitled "The Choice of Judges" The Times presented to its readers a list of judicial candidates "as qualified and, where bar associations make a distinction, most deserving of election."

WHEN Bobby Bragan was playing ball for the Dodgers, he was a reasonably quiet guy who delighted at leaping to any unoccupied piano and leading the boys into harmony. This virtually was the only time he raised his voice.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov, 6 -- Brazil's political temperature has suddenly risen again to the fever point. For the first time there are signs of serious disagreement in the higher ranks of the armed services.
The tots who toddle off to school get younger every year, and not just in the imagination of oldsters.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. proposed today that the United States Senators from Pennsylvania and New Jersey get together with local government, civic and workers' representatives to discuss projected lay-offs for the Philadelphia naval shipyard.
Was the Soviet Union's easing of restrictions since Stalin's death born of economic strength or weakness? The answer seems to depend on the part of the Soviet economy and system being examined.
DEMONSTRATIONS of carding and spinning on an old spinning wheel are being given afternoons this week at the Rabun Studios, 31 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Today's new film is "The Big Knife," Robert Aldrich's production based on the Clifford Odets play, from a James Poe screen adaptation, at the Victoria. Heading the cast are Jack Palance, Ida Lupino and Wendell Corey, Mr. Aldrich also directed the drama, which is being released by United Artists.

Coach Bud Wilkinson's speedy Oklahoma Sooners finished a shade ahead of Jim Tatum's Maryland Terrapins yesterday in the national football rankings based on The Associated Press' poll of sports writers and broadcasters.
DETROIT, Nov. 7 -- H. Rowan Gaither foresaw today a future of greater national service by the Ford Foundation as a result of the projected sale of the Ford Motor Company stock.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Prime Minister Eden told the House of Commons today that he was convinced the Foreign Office was now following correct and careful security procedures. He spoke in debate on Government handling of the case of Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean, British diplomats and Soviet spies, who disappeared in May, 1951.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Nov. 7 -- Harry H. Uhlfelder, vice president of the Long Beach City Council, who was a candidate for re-election tomorrow, died yesterday at his home here. He was 61 years old and had been seeking a fourth term as Councilman. His funeral will take place on Election Day.
The admission of new members to the United Nations will come up very soon for its annual examination.

GEORGE BALANCHINE, who has been called the finest choreographer of our time, in his spare moments is an excellent cook. But as artistic director of the New York City Ballet, which opens tonight at City Center, he has been much too busy lately to do any cooking.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 (UP) -Clarence W. Miles, the man who had hoped to transform Baltimore into a baseball winner, resigned as president of the seventh-place Orioles today. The action was taken in an atmosphere of dissension created by his policy of free spending for untried young ball players.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Surgeon General of the Public Health Service estimated today that there was 67 to 90 per cent less paralytic poliomyelitis among children who had received Salk vaccine than among those in the same age groups who had not received it.
Two blank spaces -- one on a check, the other on a patrolman's complaint -- won the dismissal yesterday of a case against a Brooklyn dog owner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a ruling of the Wisconsin Supreme Court that tenants of a Federal low-rent housing project cannot be required to take a loyalty oath.

Banks serving the New York area are beginning to feel the money pinch that usually heralds the approach of the holiday season. As a result of the flow of bank funds in and out of the metropolitan area, the New York banks last Friday increased their borrowing from the Federal Reserve by about $130,000,000, bringing the total of such debt to $400,000,000, the highest level in several weeks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Octagon House, started after the White House but finished first, will reopen to the public Thursday after an extensive restoration.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 11 to 30 points (55 cents to $1.50 a bale) yesterday. The close was at the lowest levels of the day.

RICHARD KILEY ought to be glad to be breathing this morning; he had a rugged hour last night. Mr. Kiley played the part of a submarine skipper in Loring D. Mandel's drama, "Shakedown Cruise," on "Studio One" over Channel 2 last night.

A changed story by a convicted burglar provided last night what Nassau County officials tended to accept as confirmation of Mrs. William Woodward's account of the fatal shotgun blast she fired at her husband.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Churchmen and educators tried today to find an answer to the question of how much religion could be introduced into public school classrooms without teaching the beliefs of a particular faith.
What does it take to field an unbeaten football squad?

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 7 (UP) -- The State Supreme Court, restating constitutional guarantees of press freedom, overruled today an editor's conviction for criticizing a sheriff who allegedly abused a Negro.
Stocks made a strong advance in yesterday's early hours, lost a portion of the gain in the fifth hour and then rallied in the final thirty minutes to close on an optimistic note.

IN George Kleinsinger's "Tubby the Tuba," Tubby's great complaint was that no one ever wrote anything for him to play except oompahs. But now the ground has been cut from under Tubby's feet. Vaughan Williams has written him a peach of a concerto.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Britain is said to be urging the United States to participate as soon and as fully as possible in the five-nation Baghdad defense alliance in the Middle East.
Rapidly growing Nassau County and East Brooklyn will soon have a vast new supply of natural gas.
The Rev. John La Farge has been a thoughtful optimist for most of his seventy-five years.

TRENTON, Nov. 7 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court, in a 5-to-2 decision, ruled today that an eligible employe might receive simultaneously full state disability benefits and Federal Social Security payments.

Jack Brause, real estate oper-[ ator and investor, has contracted l to purchase the one-story ilustrial building at 48-20 Thirtieth Avenue in Long Island City, Quens, from the Universal Glass Products ComPany of West Virginia.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- Representatives of seventeen nations and territories met here today to form a permanent organization on shipping. It would be nongovernmental but quasi-official in that many of participants are shipping and port officials.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Thirty-two Governments submitted a resolution today aimed at pushing the establishment of a special United Nations fund for economic development. The prospective fund would finance the construction of roads, schools, railways and similar operations necessary to speed economic development in industrially retarded countries.

For the last month patrolmen have been issuing more and more summonses for traffic and parking violations. As a result, yesterday became a record day for the number of summonses returnable in the city's five traffic courts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Republican National Committee dressed up and expanded today its publication Straight From the Shoulder, described as "a journal of political fact."

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 8 -- The Catholic Relief Services reported today that it had distributed $100,000,000 worth of surplus food and $15,000,000 worth of clothing in all parts of the world in the year that ended Oct. 1.

A shopping center is to be built in the Gentilly Woods section of New Orleans, La., by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company of New York. The site, acquired through Tom Rice of the Rex Levy Company of lqev York as broker, will be developed by the Tishman interests in association with Hogan Brothers, Inc., New Orleans building concern.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 -- Three thousand members of the United Church Women were present as the seventh national assembly began today.

Directors of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., yesterday declared a year-end dividend of $1.35 a common share and a quarterly dividend of 65 cents on the common, both payable on Dec. 20.
Three of the thirty detectives who were demoted Saturday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy applied for retirement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The administrative council of the International Federation of Film Producers Associations voted unanimously today to continue to bar from membership countries in which motion pictures are state controlled. This would include the Iron Curtain countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- United States officials said today that Communist China had proposed to the United States a joint declaration renouncing the use of force as an instrument of national policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -Senator John L. McClellan called today a special meeting of his Senate investigating subcommittee next Monday. It will hear Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges of alleged communism in the National Labor Relations Board.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Jess Hill faced the University of Southern California's strongest alumni group today to defend his football coaching methods. He received a standing round of applause.
The next to the last night of the sixty-seventh National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden was attended last night by persons prominent in society and the armed forces.

Appearance in the public press of the annual Christmas cards being offered around the world by the United Nations Children's Fund is a gentle first reminder that the joyous holiday season is not far off.
