DENVER, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of a news conference today at which Dr. Paul Dudley White, the heart specialist, and other physicians discussed President Eisenhower's condition. The other participants were Maj. Gen. Howard McC. Snyder, the President's personal physician; Maj. Gen. Martin Griffin, commander of Fitzsimons General Hospital; Col. Byron E. Pollock, chief of heart services there, and James C. Hagerty, the White House press secretary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson said today he would favor another meeting of Big Four heads of Government if necessary to continue progress toward peace.
A test of the validity of the Emergency Business Space Rent Control Law got under way yesterday in Municipal Court.

Appearance in the public press of the annual Christmas cards being offered around the world by the United Nations Children's Fund is a gentle first reminder that the joyous holiday season is not far off.

An advertising program designed to tell farmers how to make money despite the current farm cost-price squeeze by the use of fertilizer is planned by the Nitrogen division of Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation. "Fertilizer Grows Farm Profits" is the drive's theme, and material for it is based on studies by government and industry groups.

It is axiomatic in modern penology that the purpose of correctional institutions is to correct -- to help rehabilitate the men and women under their care, to correct their ways and help them to useful, healthy lives again with their families and the community.

New Jersey Republicans have retained control of the State Assembly. However, as a result of yesterday's balloting Democrats increased their representation in the Senate by at least three and possibly four seats.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -Moving swiftly to rebuild the Washington Senators. the club's new president, Calvin Griffith, today acquired five young players from the Boston Red Sox. But he had to surrender two of Washington's stars, Mickey Vernon and Bob Porterfield.
CAIRO, Oct. 29 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran has inaugurated Teheran's first piped pure water system, according to dispatches from the Iranian capital.

FOUR new cake mixes now are appearing on grocery shelves, all in packages with appetiteprovoking illustrations of the finished cake on the front. Pillsbury Mills is introducing three of the products and General Mills the fourth.

The United Fruit Company will withdraw from the East Coast Colombia Conference Nov. 19. It is resigning, the company said yesterday, because adequate steamship service cannot be maintained to Colombia's east coast ports within the framework of the conference.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 8 -President Joao Cafe Filho turned over his high office today to the Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, Carlos Luz, because of ill health. The move was stated to be temporary.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 8 -- The Strategic Air Command is plagued by an increasingly serious mid-air collision problem.
Maria Meneghini Callas, soprano, will make her debut with the Metropolitan Opera next season.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Thami el Glaoui, Pasha of Marrakesh, who led a successful move in 1953 to oust Mohammed ben Youssef as Sultan of Morocco, groveled before the reinstated ruler today and asked his pardon.

The American Hardware Corporation, New Britain, Conn., has offered to buy the assets of Henry Disston Sons, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Evan J. Parker, American Hardware president. Disston, a Philadelphia concern, always closely held, is 115 years old.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The Attorney General made clear tonight that the Administration would renominate the Solicitor General to a Federal judgeship despite opposition from two Southern Senators.

Nash is turning on the power in its 1956 models. The lead engine, a V-8, has been stepped up to 220 horsepower, against 208 in the 1955 cars, while the six-cylinder engine has been increased from 110 to 130 horsepower.

The "spirit of Geneva" drooped still lower yesterday when Foreign Minister Molotov, on his return from Moscow, again repudiated the Geneva directive of the heads of government. This directive called for the unification of Germany by means of free elections and within the framework of a European security system that recognizes the right to individual and collective selfdefense.

The plant of the StudebakerPackard Corporation in North Brunswick Township, N. J., was sold yesterday to Volkswagen of America, Inc., a new subsidiary of Volkswagenwerk G M B H of Wolfsburgh, Germany, manufacturer of automobiles.
Two University of Minnesota scientists reported here yesterday on research findings that they believe may open the way to a new attack on human disease.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8(UP) -- Argentines felt the full impact of the new Government's austerity program when the price of coffee rose nearly 100 per cent overnight.

Of the three coordinate branches of government it is the judiciary that has in recent years shown the strongest interest in the protection of individual rights and civil liberties and has done the most effective work in their defense. The Supreme Court has illustrated the point again this week.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich, Nov. 8 -- American Catholics have contributed $367,000,000 in money and goods for foreign relief in the last twelve years, Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom of Brooklyn, N. Y., said here today.

AUTUMN in New England is so beautiful we wondered if a vacation in the last two weeks of October and the first week of November was a good idea. It was. On Saturday morning, when we flew to the dry Southwest, we had no notion that by nightfall our home town would be wetter than it ever was before and that melodrama and disaster heroically met would be the order of the night.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organization conceded last night that it had lost its fight in Ohio to win approval at the polls for supplemental layoff pay and increased state unemployment benefits.
GENEVA, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -Following is an official translation of excerpts from Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov's speech today to the Big Four Foreign Ministers' Conference.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 8 -Virginia Democrats overcame independent and hopeful Republican competition in most legislative contests today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The January-February target date for a definitive medical report on President Eisenhower's future physical capabilities gives time for a political holding operation by Eisenhower forces within the Republican party.
The automatic merchandising industry was told yesterday by Robert Z. Greene, one of its pioneers, to revise its business methods and thinking lest it destroy its future.

VERSAILLES, France, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Barbara Hutton, who has been a princess and a countess, became a baroness today when she married Baron Gottfried von Cramm, former German tennis star. Baron Von Cramm is the sixth husband for the five-anddime-store heiress.

In Monday morning's papers the public was informed that the monthly test of the city's 716 air-raidwarning sirens would occur at 2 P. M. on Wednesday. The announcement by the Civil Defense director said that the public would not be required to take shelter.

STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 8 (UP) -- A crowd of 400 Oklahoma farmers attending a Senate Agriculture Committee hearing here today applauded the demands by a farmer and a housewife for the removal of the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra T. Benson.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Alarmed by the prospects that American industries will use the amended Anti-Dumping Act of 1954 as a device for increasing tariff rates, a group of foreign traders has formed the National Anti-Dumping Committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A Senate monopoly subcommittee opened a study of the General Motors Corporation today with renewed assurances that no "prosecution" was contemplated.

DENVER, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation today to help in its investigation of possible sabotage in the explosion of a United Air Lines plane Nov. 1. The explosion occurred in flight near Longmont, Colo. Forty-four persons perished.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (AP) Democrats upset incumbent Republican Mayors in Indiana today. They scored sweeping victories in Indianapolis, South Bend, Hammond and other major cities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Civil Service Commission said today that it had an "inherent" right to withhold information from the public.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Israel will submit her formal request to the United States for arms before this week-end, it was said tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The stock market continued dull today in virtually all sections. By the close, however, it looked slightly firmer and many equities closed above their worst levels of the da'y
Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation disclosed yesterday that, aided by a $79,000,000 tax-easing certificate of necessity, it is ready to build a major aluminum plant in the Ohio River Valley.

A two-day drive for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program wil begin today at 488 Madison Avenue, with employes of concerns in the building the contributors. Bloodmobiles also will visit 477 Madison Avenue for donations from employes of companies there, as well as Temple Beth Sholom, 171-39 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 4 Irving Place.
The incandescent name of Helen Hayes will glow permanently on the marquee of a Broadway playhouse starting Nov. 21.

Robert W. Dowling, chairman of the board of the American National Theatre and Academy, announced yesterday that ANTA's international exchange program will sponsor overseas tours next spring by the New Orleans Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra and the Robert Shaw Chorale.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 8 -- The Democratic party scored its greatest victory in the history of the city today. It elected a Mayor, a complete slate of city officers and thirty-one of thirty-three Aldermen by staggering majorities.

Brazil is having a case of the jitters these days. A new President and Vice President, Juscelino Kubitschek and Joao Goulart, were elected in October but do not take office until Jan. 31. They have enemies who want to invalidate the election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Renato Gualino of Rome, president of the International Federation of Film Producers, was authorized today to approve film festivals at Locarno, Switzerland, and Brussels, Belgium, "when further assurances have been given."

One of the most ambitious ship construction programs in history has resulted in the delivery of fifty-one new vessels to the A. P. Moller shipping interests since the end of World War II. The craft aggregate 600,000 deadweight tons.

Paul W. Wirths, confessed prowler-burglar, disclosed yesterday that a detective who visited him in the Mineola County jail last week had urged him to shed any light he could on the shooting of William Woodward Jr.

On Oct. 6 Amelia Igel, director of the Child Adoption Service, wrote a letter to The New York Times concerning the difficulties in placing certain children for adoption. Among this group Miss Igel described children from mixed minority and ethnic backgrounds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- United Artists made it clear today that its membership in the Motion Picture Association of America would not deter the company from releasing "The Man With the Golden Arm," if the picture fails to receive the association's Production Code seal of approval.

Randolph Sevier, president of the Matson Navigation Company, said here yesterday that British shipping lines shared his views that the Pacific area was underdeveloped. The West Coast shipping executive was returning aboard the Queen Elizabeth from a business trip to Europe.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 8 -- Political upsets in Westchester today stripped Republicans of some local jobs but the party continued its control of the county government and most city and town councils.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Prices were largely unchanged to slightly higher today on the Midwest Stock Exchange.
MYSTIC, Conn., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Control of the J. Rossie Velvet Company, '56-year-old Mystic mill. has been acquired by Harry W. Baumgarten of New York, it was announced today.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 8 -- The Republicans continued their traditional hold on Nassau County today but had to turn over the Mayor-Supervisor post in Glen Cove to the Democrats.
WILLIAM and Elizabeth Phelps are a charming and enviable couple. Mrs. Phelps is gentle and beautiful, Mr. Phelps keen and kind.

CAIRO, Nov. 8 -- Four Israeli soldiers were killed and eight wounded at noon today when a small Israeli armored column attacked an Egyptian frontier post near Elath, according to an Egyptian Army communique. One Egyptian was reported wounded in the clash.
A life of Henry Adams will be published Nov. 29 by Macmillan. The author is Elizabeth. Stevenson, whose previous writing includes a biographical study of Henry James.
Rare Treat proved to be the winning ticket in the eighth running of the Firenze Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 8 -- As a security measure, the Moroccan people will be informed of the return of their Sultan, Mohammed ben Youssef, from two years of exile only after he has been installed in Rabat's Imperial Palace.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 8 (UP) -- The California Third District Court of Appeals upheld today the legal principle that a news reporter does not have to reveal the source of his stories.
Charley Johnston, president of the International Boxing Guild, yesterday ordered the Guild's New York chapter to deliver its records to the New York State Athletic Commission.
A trusted clerk at the Barnes Noble book store at Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street suddenly turned robber there yesterday, according to the police.

The Nov. 3 report in The New York Times of the New York State Committee for the White House Conference on Education represents a bold step forward in our approach to the growing crisis in American education. The framers of the report are to be congratulated particularly for their recommendation that the forthcoming conference's agenda be broadened to include the much neglected area of adult education.
A member of Congress proposed yesterday that 5,000 members of the armed forces be assigned to customs duty to help combat the smuggling of narcotics into the country.
ATLANTA, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Gov. Marvin Griffin said today that Georgia would abandon all state parks before "co-mingling of the races" would be allowed.
Bishop Fulton J. Sheen told a group of broadcasting executives yesterday that in his opinion television viewers tended to judge a sponsor by the type of program he presented.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -Washington prepared today to welcome its most distinguished convalescent, President Eisenhower, on Friday.
MARLIN, Tex., Nov. 8 (AP) -A B-47B, currently the nation's best general-use atomic carrier, exploded in the air near here tonight and crashed in four widely separated pieces of wreckage.
Democrats made a clean sweep of all contested offices in New York City in yesterday's off-year election.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 8 -- The Democrats scored impressive victories in Fairfield County voting today.

State Republican leaders said yesterday they were pleased that Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey had "convinced" Governor Harriman that a "soft attitude toward disruptive elements was not the most effective way to establish the supremacy of law and order on the docks."
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- More than 400 buyers from Great Britain, the United States, Canada and the Continent bought 300,636 Southwest African Persian lambskins at a Hudson Bay Company auction here today.

RICHARD TURNER, an English teacher in a Brooklyn junior high school, had his first television play produced last night on "Playwrights '56" over Channel 4. His ambition unfortunately rather overreached his experience.

CHANNEL 7 came up with a football story last night on the "Cavalcade Theatre." The production was more or less a television version of a slick magazine type of sentimental yarn that did not come off as well as it should have.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The United States advised the United Nations today to lay aside hopes for a massive aid program for underdeveloped countries until a more favorable "economic and political climate" was achieved.
In a little over a month, a pilot project in Federal Court here has reduced the congested trial calendar to assure early trials to all litigants.
DENVER, Nov. 8 -- President Eisenhower will probably make two short informal speeches Friday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- United Nations security forces had their hands full today, as on every Election Day, keeping the public away from the only alcoholic oasis in an otherwise legally dry city.
Republicans and Democrats traded mayors in upstate New York yesterday, with the Democrats coming out a hair's breath ahead.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -A big hunt for a little snake took place today in the Library of Congress.
Illness is no respecter of age, or social position. It strikes indiscriminately. It is a comfort to know that our voluntary, non-profit hospitals stand ready to help us in emergencies.
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The New York Yankees spotted a star Japanese team two runs in the first three innings today and then breezed ahead to win, 6 -- 2, before 30,000 fans.

As general counsel of the Textil Workers Union of America, C. I. O I must observe that Arthur Krock' Nov. 1 column on the District o Columbia Federal Appeals Court' decision involving this union's partial strike tactics shows an astonishing misunderstanding of the opinions in that case and a failure to realize that the problems of ethics in labor relations today arise from opportunities the Taft-Hartley Act provides employers to destroy unions.

MONTREAL, Nov. 8 (UP) -The Arctic Institute of North America disclosed today that mummified insect specimens, 60,000,000 years old and still in a "fine state of preservation,'' have been discovered in Alaska, 150 miles above the Arctic Circle.

The head of the house has a desk, just an ordinary desk of the type designed at Grand Rapids. It has a wide center drawer, banks of drawers down either side, and an uneasy do-it-yourself set of pigeonholes set at the back of the top. It has a pad with blotter, a pen, a letter opener and a small tray for pencils.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -As far as the race for the Big Three football title is concerned, Harvard is one up and one to play.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 (AP) -Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt warned tonight that "unless we constantly fight communism on the economic, cultural and spiritual front we are apt to wake up some day and find a Communist world."
"He is vigorous and he has the goal-line fever."

GREENWOOD, Miss., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A Negro farm youth and an elderly Negro sharecropper testified today before the grand jury that will decide whether two white men will stand trial in the Emmet Till kidnaping case.

Your editorial of Nov. 3 discussed the Power Authority's proposal to apply to the Federal Power Commission for a license to develop the Niagara without further action by Congress. You correctly stated the authority's conviction that it is presently entitled to the license because the reservation requiring such action attached to the 1950 treaty with Canada is invalid.
New York department stores played host yesterday to crowds reminiscent of the Christmas rush, as shoppers thronged the city's retail centers to take advantage of Election Day bargains.
HARTFORD, Nov. 8 -- Democrats scored an upset victory today in the Waterbury municipal election.
OPENING today at the Museum of Modern Art is an exhibition of eighty-five prints by two leading pioneer German expressionists, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner (1880-1938) and Emile Nolde (born 1867).
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A group of Protestant church men and educators suggested today five basic principles as a guide to public schools in dealing with religion.

A prominent football official was wondering out loud the other day whether a couple of rules that are being honored more in the breach than in the observance shouldn't be stricken from the book, modified or perhaps made even more stringent.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 -- Christianity must beat communism by dedicating itself to the needs of depressed peoples, two clerymen from New York and India stressed today.
President Eisenhower was not eligible to vote yesterday. He had not registered either in New York, his former home, or in Gettysburg, Pa., site of his new farm.

New York University won the varsity honors and St. John's University of Brooklyn took the freshman crown at the twenty-ninth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association cross-country championship yesterday. The runs were held at Van Cortlandt Park.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 8 (UP) -Willie Hartack, who had scored ten victories in his last two riding days, added a triple at Laurel Park today to increase his nation-leading victory total of 376.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Wednesday, Nov. 9 -- Albert B. (Happy) Chandler was elected Governor of Kentucky yesterday in a landslide victory over his Republican opponent, Edwin R. Denney.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A Senate committee will inquire into the Post Office Department's dealings with an accounting concern headed by Maurice H. Stans, new Deputy Postmaster General.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- "My Favorite Husband" will be divorced from the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network on Dec. 27. On that date, it became known today, the end of the thirteen-week cycle for the filmed situation comedy will be reached, and the run terminated.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8 -- Albert Benjamin (Happy) Chandler will return to the state capitol at near-by Frankfort next year as Governor of Kentucky. Virtually everyone in the state looks forward to four years of colorful, free-swinging politics.
Home building and buying will be maintained at high levels in 1956, Henry G. Waltemade of New York, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, said yesterday.

St. Francis Prep took team honors and Joseph Carney of Brooklyn Prep won the individual title yesterday in the thirty-third annual cross-country championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at Van Cortlandt Park.

Events tonight: Telemann Society, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 6:15 o'clock; Symphony of the Air, Leonard Bernstein conducting; Frances Yeend, soprano; Martha Lipton, r ezzo-soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Eunice Podis, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30, and Karl Kraeuter, violinist, and Phyllis Kraeuter, 'cellist, National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, 8:30.

THE stately Plaza Hotel has a new sign on the outer wall of its Fifty-eighth Street service entrance. It offers: "Tricycle Garage. Rates 15 cents per day. Three Dollars per month." Service closes at 5 P. M.

After the final performance of the sixty-seventh National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden, team members, exhibitors, judges and officers and directors of the National met in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for a reception and supper.
BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- Mayor John B. Hynes of Boston was elected to a third term today. He turned back a determined bid by State Senator John E. Powers in a bitterly contested campaign.
An unusually negative and tax-conscious state electorate rejected the $750,000,000 highway bond issue and three other major constitutional amendments in yesterday's election.
A complete sellout has been reported for the anniversary cocktail dance to be held at the Pierre this afternoon for the benefit of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen.

After a hesitant start, cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange turned firm yesterday following the Government's crop forecast. Final prices were 6 to 32 points, or 30 cents to $1.60 a bale, net higher than on Monday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- The outstanding feature of the grainI and soybean futures market today was the lack of any impor-I taut outside buying. Another; bearish report on cotton, which was estimated at 14,847,000 bales, unsettled the soybean market at the start, and as longs started to unlaod in the grain pits it was apparent that the demand was distressingly slow.

Jack Resnick, operator and investor, has sold his purchase contract on the sixty-one-family apartment house at 1220 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx, to Sol Waxman and Samuel Roth, investors. The sale was subject to a new first mortgage of $160,000 held by the Kings County Savings Bank. Ehrlich, Corso Feldman Co. were the brokers
FORT KNOX, Ky., Nov. 8 -The experiment with teen-age volunteers under the new Reserve Forces Act is off to a slow, costly and inefficient start, observers here report.

SEEK and ye shall find. The American Opera Society seeks and finds exciting works to perform. Last night at Town Hall it brought forward Cherubini's "Medea," an opera that is more than a century and a half old and that has the passion and power to move one deeply today.

EVER since they were organized nine years ago the New York Knickerbockers have been plagued by a lack of size. They've had to struggle along with itsy-bitsy fellows like Sweets Clifton, who's only 6 feet 7, Harry Gallatin, who's 6 feet 6, and other such midgets. And the National Basketball Association has no room for shrimps.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Nov. 8 -- Suffolk County Republicans strengthened their control of local offices in today's election.

HARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Other municipalities may have had more important elections today, but it is doubtful if any could equal the minor miracle accomplished by the voters in this town -- the election of a stanch New Dealer and liberal in this long-time heart of Republican conservatism.
Back from a successful road trip, the New York Rangers will skate against the front-running Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

THOSE to whom "The Barber of Seville" is a gay opera by Rossini now have the rarest of chances to see it as a play, superbly performed in French by the visiting Comedie Francaise. "The Barber" is generally considered the masterpiece of eighteenthcentury French comedy (the date is 1775).

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Harold A. R. Philby, a former British official in Washington, today challenged a Member of Parliament who had named him as the third man in the Burgess-Maclean spy case to repeat the charge outside Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) The Army, joining the trend toward automation, announced today that it had figured out a way of assigning replacements to overseas units with punch-card machines.
PARIS, Wednesday, Nov. 9 -The French Council of the Republic approved early this morning Premier Edgar Faure's proposal to hold new parliamentary elections in December.
GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The Soviet Union today rejected reunification of Germany on any terms but its own.

In an age when obsolescence comes easy, the good things that are happening to the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn, where an $80,000,000 Civic Center has reached the halfway point, are cause for optimism among city dwellers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- The General Assembly adopted today a resolution providing for review, in certain cases, of decisions of the United Nations Administrative Tribunal.
THE 1955 version of the Whitney Museum's annuals of contemporary American paintings opens to the public today with one painting by each of 165 artists.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -George Christopher, a Republican in a predominantly Democratic city, became San Francisco's new mayor tonight.
Mexico's equestrian team won the Perpetual Challenge Trophy at the National Horse Show for the eighth time since 1946 last night in Madison Square Garden.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy made an early-morning "surprise" visit to four Queens police precincts yesterday. He found four detective squad commanders absent from their posts. As a result, one acting lieutenant was relieved of his command and transferred, and three others face departmental action.

THE impeccable violinist, Joseph Fuchs, was soloist at Carnegie Hall last night with Leon Barzin and the National Orchestral Association. The concert opened the Tuesday evening series of the orchestra's twenty-fifth season.
Vassily Smyslov took the undisputed lead yesterday in the international chess tournament at Zagreb when he defeated Vasja Pirc of Yugoslavia in thirty-four moves, according to a report from Belgrade.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 8 -- The Israeli Army announced tonight that one of it patrols in the Elath zone was attacked by an Egyptian force this afternoon. The patrol was reported to have repulsed the attackers without suffering casualties.

ONCE you could tell the city boy by his Lord Fauntleroy suit as readily as you could spot his country cousin by the patched overalls. But today the clothes that hang on the hickory limb are of the same cut as those stashed in the Y. M. C. A. locker.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -Federal housing tenants in every state but Wisconsin will still be required to sign loyalty oaths, a Government attorney said today.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- United States Ambassador C. Douglas Dillon defended American trade policy today as a "liberal" one. He warned, however, that this trend might be reversed if other countries did not take reciprocal action.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -Rockwell Kent, the artist, appeared at an informal State Department hearing today in support of his fight to obtain a passport.
Coach Jim Lee Howell of the football Giants, who lost to the Cleveland Browns last Sunday "because we beat ourselves," is not in agreement with Otto Graham's implied charge of "dirty football."
THAT kitchen drudge, aluminum foil, will glitter in the midst of holiday festivities this year.
PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 9 -- Richardson Dilworth, Democrat, scored a landslide victory in yesterday's mayoralty election here.
"A Hatful of Rain," a play by Michael V. Gazzo, co-starring Shelley Winters and Ben Gazzara, opens at the Lyceum Theatre tonight at 7:45 o'clock under the auspices of Jay Julien.

ST. STEPHEN, N. B., Nov. 8 -- Because of the emphasis on grouse and woodcock hunting, both of which have been excellent this season, the deer in the Loon Bay area have been virtually unmolested. This should insure unusually productive hunting here throughout November.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated to day the 1955 cotton crop would reach 14,843,000 bales.

Representing over 7,000 displaced inhabitants of the Benin Islands, we have come to this country at this time to petition the United States Government to permit our early return to these islands which have been our home for several generations.
GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The EastWest struggle entered a new phase today following Vyacheslav M. Molotov's refusal to consider restoration of the German national state except on Soviet terms.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- The deadlock between Yugoslavia and the Philippines for a seat on the Security Council reached record proportions today.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 8 -The Democratic party retained control of the RocklaRnd County Board of Supervisors today, winning in three out of the five townships.
American Airlines has ordered thirty turbo-jet airliners from the Boeing Airplane Company for its transcontinental and other domestic routes.
In Leningrad there is an Institute of the History of Religion of the Academy of Sciences. It is the former Kazan Cathedral.

THE agreeable news this morning is that the New York City Ballet has returned from its six months of traveling and settled down at the City Center for a run. It was welcomed home last night with a friendly and familiar warmth, without the clamor of a grand gala premiere but with perhaps a solider affection.

Democrats won easily in every contested court race in the city last night. But Republican majorities in Nassau and Suffolk, as expected, overturned a Democratic-Liberal margin in Queens to capture one Supreme Court seat.

Two-way traffic on the I. R. T. subway line from Times Square to Flushing, Queens, was slowed at times from a three-minute to a fifteenminute headway between 5:18 and 6:37 P. M. yesterday. The cause was a blow-out of shoe fuses on an undetermined number of trains between the Queens Plaza and Court House Square stations.
MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 9 -- President Ramon Magsaysay's party appeared today to be winning an unexpectedly decisive victory in the Philippines' crucial off-year election.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- A high United States source denied today that discussions here between Communist China and the United States had progressed to a point where a meeting between Secretary of States Dulles and Premier Chou En-lai could be considered imminent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Government and industry are in critical need of supplies of selenium, it was disclosed today.
The four-day, twenty-seventh annual meeting of the National Conference of Christians and Jews opened yesterday at the conference's $1,000,000 headquarters, 43 West Fifty-seventh Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 (UP) -- A Federal district judge today ordered the Army to release three turncoat prisoners of war as a result of yesterday's Supreme Court ruling that they were being held unconstitutionally.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Dr. William G. Carr, executive secretary of the National Education Association, today urged the approaching White House Conference on Education to focus on national issues. The four-day conference opens Nov. 28.
The Army stole a march on the Navy yesterday and snapped up a recruit for 1963. But it took a parade, spaghetti and meatballs, a birthday cake and a good measure of genuine hospitality.
Gov. Edmund S. Muskie of Maine apologized to Harper's Magazine last night for a subordinate's action in canceling the state's advertising with the magazine.
Pastor Martin Niemoeller warned yesterday that any excessive delay in the reunification of Germany would "leave the doors open" for a military government to gain control of that country.

The toy industry expects to gross $1,000,000,000 this year, with the support of heavy advertising. Benjamin F. Michtom, chairman of Ideal Toy Corporation, doll and plastic toy manufacturer, made this forecast yesterday and said he expected these major developments in toy advertising:

GEORGE BALANCHINE gave the New York City Ballet its first new work of the season at the City Center last night in his "Pas de Dix," set to music from Glazounov's old ballet "Raymonda." It was created for Maria Tallchief and Andre Eglevsky and a company of eight, and performed without setting in costumes by Estaban Frances.
A new political faction that pledges its "first loyalty to the membership" has been established by about fifty performers in the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.
The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers opened its sixty-third annual meeting yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, with the heaviest technical schedule of its history.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Israel will submit soon to the United States a request for permission to buy late-model jet fighters, anti - submarine equipment, heavy tanks and anti-tank guns.

The Continental Can Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and New York Life Insurance Company under which the insurance companies will lend $25,000,000 to Continental on forty-year 3 3/4 per cent notes maturing on Nov. 1, 1995.
Sharp gains in strategic sections of the list yesterday carried the stock market ahead to its best levels since Sept. 23.

Modern advertising methods were rejected yesterday as a means of spreading the doctrine of the brotherhood of man across the country.

TORONTO, Nov. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The Ontario Securities Commission today "blacklisted" seven Ontario mining companies and seven mining company promoters. In its bulletin the commission also said that any other concerns in which the individuals figure will lose privileges under the Ontario Securities Act.

The Society of Silurians will present its annual awards at the fall dinner of the organization next Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The organization is made up of men who were in the newspaper business here at least twenty-five years ago.
COLON, Panama, Nov. 9 -- Juan D. Peron indicated today that he had no plans for establishing a home outside his native Argentina.

Edwin R. Broden, executive vice president of SKF Industries, Inc., of Philadelphia, has been named president and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday. He was also elected a director, effective immediately.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 9 -- David Marshall's coalition government was considerably weakened today by the loss of two seats.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy continued yesterday to revamp the detective division by transferring fourteen commanding and superior officers.
Two Brooklyn detectives looking for a stolen car didn't exactly find it; it ran into them and gave itself up.

Textile executives were warned yesterday to improve their profit position or risk being gobbled up by larger operating units that can easily gain control. The warning came from Royal Little, chairman of the board of Textron-American, Inc., who two years ago set out to merge three textile and eight non-textile companies into one corporation with diverse interests.

The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, marked yesterday the fiftieth anniversary of its work on behalf of blind persons. More than 300 volunteer workers attended a celebration luncheon at the St. Regis Hotel.
YONKERS, Nov. 9 -- The City of Yonkers was criticized tonight for failing to provide for its school children adequate educational facilities, services and opportunities.
EUNICE PODIS, no stranger to the local concert scene, gave a piano recital last night in Town Hall. Her playing was, as it generally is, professional, musically satisfactory and secure in technique.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Peter A. Strobel, a New York consulting engineer, resigned today as Federal Commissioner of the Public Buildings Service.

Purchase of the entire outstanding capital stock of the Water Treatment Engineering Corporation, Fort Wayne, Ind., by the Gerity-Michigan Corporation of Adrian, Mich., was announced yesterday by James Gerity Jr., chairman and president of Gerity-Michigan, and Ron D. Baker of the Indiana company.
GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, is going to Bonn Sunday to confer with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- A little boy in Baghdad, Iraq, recently wrote a letter to President Eisenhower. He enclosed two native currency bills, worth $1.25.

Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell marked his twentieth anniversary as minister of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church last night by suggesting that the congregation raise a $1,000,000 addition to its endowment.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee reported today that organized labor spent nearly $2,000,000 during the 1954 political campaign, almost all on behalf of Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Dr. Martha Eliot, chief of the Federal Children's Bureau, today urged a concerted attack against the black market in babies. She said this should include legal, social and medical aid to unmarried mothers.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., and the Packard Division of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation agreed today on a new three-year contract. It follows the pattern established with the Big Three in the industry.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Nov. 9 (UP) -- A Leflore County grand jury refused today to indict two white half-brothers for the kidnapping of Emmett Till, a Chicago Negro boy slain in the notorious "wolf-whistle" case.
IT may seem odd that a musical that was sporadically dull on Broadway should appear rather charming in a Greenwich Village basement, but that is the paradoxical fact.

Continuing his activity on the East Side, Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, has purchased the six-story building containing seven stores and twenty-five apartments at 485-87 Third Avenue and 200-202 East Thirty-third Street.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 9 -- Provisional President Eduardo Lonardi solved today the first major ministerial crisis in his Cabinet by accepting the resignation of his Army Minister, Gen. Leon Bengoa.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Richardson Dilworth offered the unusual contention today that his landslide election yesterday as Democratic Mayor of Philadelphia did not reflect a national or even a state trend.
Today's new film is "The Tender Trap," at the Radio City Music Hall. Heading the cast of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production are Frank Sinatra, Debbie Reynolds, David Wayne and Celeste Holm.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Continuing weakness of British Government securities depressed the stock market today. Losses in industrials were relatively light but widespread.

LILLIAN ROTH gave a magnificent portrayal of an alcoholic in "Outcast," an original drama presented last night on "The United States Steel Hour" over Channel 2. In its understanding, in its poignancy, in its sensitivity, her performance was one that can only be called memorable.

Many stock market analysts these days have been keeping a close eye on a gap. This particular gap is on the vertical line charts of market averages and it appeared on Sept. 26, the first trading day after President Eisenhower's heart attack.
BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Eight Massachusetts cities will have new Mayors in 1956.
Time was when a football team's only worry about the rival defense was whether the backs would be deployed in box or diamond array behind the basic seven-man line.
New York Life Insurance Co., in 225 Broadway, combining the regional and district group offices now at 261 Madison Avenue and 111 Broadway -- Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The American Cotton Manufactures Institute, alarmed at imports of fabric and clothing from Japan, today urged an import quota on cotton goods similar to restrictions already in effect on raw cotton.

Irving Markheim, once a California National Guard undercover agent against the Communist party, told a story yesterday of five years of rejections for Government jobs. The reason, he said, was that, as a former Communist, he was deemed a "security risk."
The second annual observance here tomorrow of Veterans Day will be marked by parades, special memorial services, speeches and the traditional period of silence.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- A search for "sound economic and social awareness" as well as for technological knowledge was demanded today by the president of the United States Steel Corporation.

MANILA, Thursday, Nov. 9 -- The Nationalist party increased its lead today in the Philippine elections. President Ramon Magsaysay's party thus held apparently decisive advantages in seven of the nine Senatorial contests.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., said today that the effectiveness of the Ford and General Motors guaranteed wage plans was not endangered by the defeat of an Ohio referendum on unemployment compensation.
Eleven new public schools will be named by the Board of Education today.

The grim visage of the "cold war" rises again above the "spirit of Geneva" as a result of Foreign Minister Molotov's cynical repudiation of the Geneva directive of the heads of government on German unification and European security. The repudiation has forced the present Geneva conference to suspend further talks on the two main problems it was called upon to solve.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 9 (AP) -- A. B. (Happy) Chandler's landslide vote victory for a return to the Kentucky Governorship reached record proportions today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Cory Corporation today announced the purchase of all capital stock of the Mitchell Manufacturing Company.
The city's proposed 1956 capital budget of $791,736,036 must be substantially revised because of the defeat of Amendment 5 in Tuesday's election, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- South Africa today quit the General Assembly's tenth session. The walkout came in protest against continued United Nations inquiries into the South African Government's race segregation policies.

ALL the actors give wonderful performances in "A Hatful of Rain," which opened at the Lyceum last evening. Shelley Winters, Ben Gazzara, Anthony Franciosa, all the others are at the top of their form.
DENVER, Nov. 9 -- President Eisenhower made an indirect appeal to the Soviet Union today to withdraw its sponsorship from the Middle East arms race.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 9 (UP) -- Johnny Saxton of New York, giving away ten pounds but nothing more, battered out a unanimous decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers tonight while tuning up for another shot at Carmen Basilio's world welterweight crown.
Republican and Democratic leaders were in agreement yesterday that Tuesday's off-year election would result in strong pressure for a reduction in taxes and curtailment of state and local spending.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 12 to 42 points (60 cents to $2.10 a bale) yesterday.

FOREWARNED is forearmed. But when a baby decides to put in an appearance, this hit of philosophy may pale a little. Ask any parents of a first-born about their experiences on D-Day. They may recall strange and wondrous happenings that their most expectant expectations did not account for.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- By an overwhelming majority, the workers of the Ruhr steel industries, core of West Germany's economy, voted today to empower their leaders to call a strike for higher wages.
AMERICUS, Ga., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Northwestern University will receive more than $1,000,000 for research in mental illness in the settlement of a long legal fight.
Entertainment by well-known American and foreign stars of the theatrical and motion picture worlds will be a feature of the annual International Press Ball of the Foreign Press Association.
A case involving alleged attempted extortion by a policeman was dismissed yesterday in Ridgewood Felony Court because the complainant failed to appear.

The Army and the State Department have opened a recruiting drive for stenographers to fill 200 posts overseas. The Army jobs, available in the Far East and Alaska, are open to men and women who are 21 to 50, American citizens and free to spend two years overseas. The salary range is $3,175 to $3,415 a year, plus housing.
" The Vamp," a new musical joshing the silent movie era, its genius directors, sultry queens and other assorted characters, opens tonight at the Winter Garden at 7:45 o'clock.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 9 -- Greek sources asserted tonight that the Balkan alliance was on the verge of dissolution so far as their Government was concerned.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Nov. 9 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion told Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns today that Israel wanted to abide by the armistice agreements but would hit back against any acts of aggression.

In the country as a whole the elections Tuesday were so scattered and so many local issues were involved that it would be dangerous to draw too definitive political conclusions on a national scale. However, the day clearly did go to the Democrats and the trend, if any, was Democratic.

The Idaho Power Company announced yesterday the signing of a contract at Boise with the Morrison-Knudsen Company, Inc., to build the utility's Brownlee and Oxbow hydroelectric projects on the Snake River.

William Woodward Jr. left $2,500 in cash and a lifetime income from one-third of an estate estimated at $10,000,000 to his widow, Ann Eden Crowell Woodward. He was killed Oct. 30 by shots from a shotgun she had fired. She told the police she had mistaken him for a prowler.

More than half of the college graduates of the next ten years will have to enter teaching if the nation's schools are to be adequately staffed during that period. At present, only one-fifth of the college graduates become teachers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad approved today a proposal for new study of a consolidation with the Chicago and North Western Railroad. The action was taken at a meeting of the directors here and made public by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Milwaukee Road.
CHICAGO Nov 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Public Service Commission reserved decision yesterday on a petition by the New York Central Railroad to discontinue passenger service at Worthington and Woodlands, both flag stops on the railroad's Putnam Division.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- This city, in which Democrats outnumber Republicans, has resisted an attempt to inject partisan politics in its mayoralty campaign, which is traditionally nonpartisan.

THE Ritz Thrift Shop, otherwise known as the "Miracle on Fifty-seventh Street," now has a mink-lined annex. This institution is a secondhand fur store where ordinary mortals can buy minks that once graced the bodies of the glamorous rich.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Treasury Department will ask Congress to pass a bill permitting public inspection of applications for tax exemption filed by nonprofit organizations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- There are a few stock phrases for use by political party spokesmen after off-year and by-elections, and when the Democratic and Republican professionals privately agree that the results have shown a continuing or reversed trend this can be determined by the phrase employed by one side and by the other.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 2:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Encouraging gains in the disposal of surplus farm products abroad were reported today by Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture.
It's not quite winter -- but it seemed yesterday that spring wasn't too far away. The circus signed up to return to New York next April at the usual stand, Madison Square Garden.

It was two down and one to go in the annual series of big fall horse shows yesterday. The National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden had joined the Harricburg (Pa.) National in history Tuesday night. Now the only one remaining is that of the Royal Winter Fair in Toronto. It begins tomorrow.

The New York Knickerbockers will open their tenth National Basketball Association home season tonight when they play the Minneapolis Lakers in the feature of a league double-header at Madison Square Garden.

NEWARK, Nov. 9 -- A strike this afternoon by 102 maintenance workers at interchanges along the 118-mile New Jersey Turnpike apparently had little effect on traffic, the state police said. The strike began at 1 P. M. after officials of Local 10 and Local 320 of the Highway Maintenance Employes Union, A. F. L., said that turnpike representatives had turned down their demand for a $20-a-month wage increase.
Halina Czerny-Stefanska, Polish pianist, will make her United States recital debut Monday evening, Nov. 28, at the United Nations General Assembly Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A special Budget Bureau advisory board appealed to business men today to make suggestions for improving and simplifying Government forms for statistical or other information.

Volcanoes, usually associated with the lush islands of the Pacific or the remote Aleutians, erupted into the local news recently when a Columbia research team discovered a submerged volcano off the coast of New Jersey.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 9 -- John D. Schapiro, who wrote the book, will present the fourth edition of his now world-famous thoroughbred extravaganza, the Washington D. C. International, on Friday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 9 -- The Soviet Union's top educational authority said today the country favored a large-scale expansion of international student exchanges.

HAVING stirred up the vengeful natives of Supersuburbia with a hilariously clinical report on "The Exurbanites," A. C. Spectorsky has taken to the mountains. This seems a prudent thing to do until all the tohu bohu blows over. However, it may not solve his personal problems completely. The chances are that he and his publishers have, in "The Book of the Mountains,"* another best seller on their hands.

" I MENTION this Affair chiefly for the Sake of recommending that Branch of Education [accompts or accounts] for our young Females, as likely to be more of Use to them their children in Case of Widowhood than either Music or Dancing."
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 9 -- For two years Royce Flippin has given seven kind of fits to the sons of Elihu Yale.
Committees drawn from New York, Boston and Philadelphia are planning a dinner dance to aid the United States Olympic Ski Team.

The nation's production of wood pulp to fill its vast needs in paper, packaging, building board and other products is rolling toward a new record with a fat 14 per cent gain in the first nine months of 1955.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Sir Anthony Eden tonight offered his own services and those of his Government in settling the dispute between Israel and the Arab states.
GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- The United States has had comparatively smooth passage, for once, in presenting to its principal trading partners its annual report on American restrictions on agricultural imports.

A record depth has been reached in drilling for oil in the Mississippi Delta marshlands about forty miles southeast of New Orleans. At 7 A. M. yesterday the depth of the well being drilled there by Richardson Bass. Fort Worth, Tex., operator, touched the 21,482-foot record established in the San Joaquin Valley of California in 1953.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A picked West German team tonight defeated the touring United States amateur boxers, 6 -- 4, before a crowd of 7,000.

The International Paper Company, said to be the world's largest manufacturer of paper, increased its net earnings and sales in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 compared with the similar periods last year.

The tale of Army's inconsistent football team this season may be found in its statistics. They show the cadets as the top defensive team in major college football and also the leader in fumbling away the ball.

I have noted in the Oct. 31 issue of The New York Times that in the editorial entitled "La Prensa: Still in Chains" you only mention the closing of two newspapers in Indo-America (Latin America): La Prensa of Buenos Aires by Peron and El Tiempo of Bogota by Rojas Pinilla.
Issues of corporate securities having a market value of $24,702,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates as follows:

Samuel Leifer, operator, has purchased the forty-six-family apartment house at 160 East Fourth Street in Mount Vernon, N. Y., for cash over mortgages totaling $138,000. The seller was a client of Lehrich Lehrich, attorneys. Theodore Kamens was the buyer's attorney.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 9 -- Major airplane operators urged today stepped-up development of an automatic cockpit warning device to diminish the danger of mid-air collisions.

Indications that the fund for support of Protestant Episcopal missions would be heavily oversubscribed were seen in the action last night of the fall meeting of the Convocation of Manhattan. The forty-three parishes and missions in Manhattan pledged $492,989 as their contribution, an increase of $101,781 over last year.
Directors of the Fruehauf Trailer Company yesterday declared a stock dividend of 100 per cent on the common, payable on Jan. 13.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Americans are expected to spend a record $44,000,000,000 on new construction next year despite some slowdown in farm and individual house building, the Government said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- The General Assembly's Political and Security Committee decided unanimously today to take up problems involving Korea as its next topic for debate.

The American Legion Magazine blamed deadline problems yesterday for a situation in which the Fund for the Republic is paying $5,700 for advertising space in the publication to reply to a Legion attack.

The nomination of Richard S. Tufts of Pinehurst, N. C., as president of the United States Golf Association for 1956 was disclosed yesterday. The report of the organization's nominating committee will be acted upon at the annual meeting of the association at the Vanderbilt Hotel on Jan. 28.

Following is the text of Prime Minister Eden's address yesterday to the Lord Mayor's Banquet in London, as broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation and transcribed here by the British Information Services:

THE Symphony of the Air is still a first-rate orchestra. All it needs to make it shine in something like the glory it had when it was the N. B. C. Symphony and its maestro was Arturo Toscanini is an accomplished conductor.
DENVER, Nov. 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named today four of twelve authorized members to a commission set up by Congress to plan a memorial to the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The Bronx police prevented a teen-age gang fight last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- The Columbia Broadcasting System lost another of its television executives today to R. K. O.-Radio Pictures, which is being reorganized by its new owners, General Teleradio, Inc.
The State of Oklahoma yesterday awarded $9,000,000 of building bonds due from 1956 to 1961 to the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago.

George A. Mooney, New York State Superintendent of Banks, yesterday disapproved plans of the County Trust Company in Westchester County to acquire through merger the Ramapo Trust Company in Rockland County.
THE National Broadcasting Company's "Television Theatre" held a winning ticket last night on a sprightly script by Frank Kulla, a newcomer out of the starting gate for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today a rules change to permit airlines to offer free or reduced rate transportation to C. A. B. employes on official business.

A plan to improve the facilities for the 13,000 commuters who use the Delaware Lackawanna and Western and Erie Railroads and to offset deficits now resulting from this service was announced yesterday by officials of the two carriers.

HOUSEHOLDERS with an instinct for tracking down a bargain will turn to fresh and smoked pork often this fall and winter. That rich, flavorful meat, prepared to perfection by Chinese and German cooks, is expected to be abundant and low-priced through next February.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Government war orders gave the General Motors Corporation such a head start over competitors that it has captured more than three-fourths of this country's market for Diesel locomotives, Senate investigators heard today.
Nikolaj Minev of Bulgaria defeated Borislav Milic of Yugoslavia yesterday in the seventh round of the international chess tournament at Zagreb, according to a report from Belgrade.

Like other Americans I am deeply concerned over the desultory fighting now going on between the Israeli and Egyptian peoples. Bitter pride and blind passion on the part of both may involve the United States in a conflagration of irreparable loss to all.
GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- Secretary of State Dulles conceded today that the mutual confidence established here last summer among the Big Four heads of government had been "largely shattered."
LONG BEACH, L. I., Nov. 9 -- Mrs. Etta Uhlfelder was appointed a Councilman to fill the unexpired term of her late husband. Harry H. Uhlfelder, at a meeting of the Council held tonight in City Hall.
HARTFORD, Nov. 9 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff asked a special session of the Connecticut Legislature today to approve a $31,373,000 recovery program for his flood-ravaged state.
Developers planning shopping centers in the next few years were warned yesterday to make a careful study of population trends.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Pakistani Foreign Ministry today handed Afghanistan's charge d'affaires in Karachi a note protesting "the flagrant violation of a gentlemen's agreement" to settle the long-standing dispute between the two countries.
Local 975, Steamship Clerks and Checkers Union, International Longshoremen's Union, will give blood to the Red Cross today at 568 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.
Manufacturers as well as retailers who attempt to evade "fair trade" laws were criticized last night by John W. Anderson, president of the American Fair Trade Council.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 9 -- Control of the next nine-member City Council hung in the balance here tonight. Tabulators completed the count of 700 of the 724 precincts in this city's sixteenth consecutive proportional representation election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Tobacco men today opposed any cut in burley production next year. They declared a reduction is unnecessary and would constitute a threat to the national economy.
GENEVA, Nov 9 -- The Foreign Ministers' Conference, on the insistence of the Western delegation, suspended discussion today of Germany's unification.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Following are the texts of a statement by W. C. du Plessis of South Africa before the General Assembly's Special Political Committee today, and of the resolution adopted by the committee, which occasioned South Africa's walkout:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Democratic party gains in yesterday's scattered elections have given momentum to the Republican party movement to draft President Eisenhower or Chief Justice Earl Warren for the 1956 Republican Presidential nomination.
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Andre Dubois, Prefect of Police in Paris, was appointed French Resident General in Morocco today.

Members of the committee for the Grosvenor Debutante Ball, which will be held on Nov. 26 in the ballroom of the Plaza, will meet this afternoon at a tea at the home of their chairman, Miss Clara Workum, at 17 East Eighty-ninth Street.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Johnny Longden, who is here from California to ride Prefect in the Washington D. C. International on Friday, won the feature today with Freedom Parley.
City firemen are due for a "shocking awakening" if they believe that becoming an officer means principally "a change in the color of the helmet and the size of the pay check."

A milestone in education in New York City was passed when ground was broken for the construction of the long-projected High School of Aviation Trades in Queens. Final plans for this institution resulted from the cooperative thinking of members of the city's Board of Education, representatives of the air industries and spokesmen for the armed forces.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 9 -- Today's world may not have prepared itself for the proper utilization of the blessings of the push-button age around the corner, Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan declared tonight.

Agreement in principle has been reached for the acquisition of the Warren Petroleum Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., by the Gulf Oil Corporation through an exchange of stock. Gulf would issue eight-tenths of a share for each share of Warren stock.
THE quick-step rhythm of modern life has inspired a department store display. Today Abraham Straus is putting on view a collection of merchandise notable for its time-saving facilities.

OTTAWA, Nov. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's East Coast potato producers will have to accept sharply - reduced federal price guarantees as a result of increased production and lower market prices, Federal authorities said today.
Plans for a $2,961,000 parking garage extending five levels below the surface of the street in the Brooklyn Civic Center were brought out yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

The George Junior Republic, at Freeville, N. Y., is "the smallest republic in the world," and its citizens are teen-agers who have had trouble adjusting to society. At the Junior Republic 150 such youngsters at a time learn how to live constructive lives under the restraints that even democracy must impose on the individual for the common good.

IT'S embarrassing to have to lean on a creaking crutch such as it's-a-good-deal-for-both-clubs cliche. But there is no escape in trying to analyze the most recent Red Sox-Senators trade of five young Bostons for four older Washingtons. Being a man unafraid of the obvious, Joe Cronin didn't hesitate to use the phrase in a phone conversation yesterday.
The Ford Foundation yesterday designated seven investment banking houses with total capital resources of more than $100,000,000 to manage the first public sale of Ford Motor Company stock in January.

The 1954 estimates of the population of the United States and its territories by the Census Bureau demolish the major argument against statehood for Alaska, that of insufficient population. According to these estimates, the population of Alaska reached 208,000 by the end of 1954 -- an increase of 62 per cent in only four years.

ST. STEPHEN, N. B., Nov. 9 -- There are several effective methods of hunting deer in the big woods, but only one of them is successful when the deer are in the woods, and it would take twenty men, not three, to push them out of these tangles.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges were irregular yesterday. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, hides and silk eased; cottonseed oil, potatoes, onions and rubber rose, and soybean oil, wool and zinc closed mixed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Democrats hailed today a series of local election victories won yesterday. They saw the votes as new harbingers of success in 1956, whether the Republican Presidential candidate was Dwight D. Eisenhower or another man.
DENVER, Nov. 9 -- President Eisenhower had his last official hospital visitors today and he made it a family occasion complete with pictures.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Hugh W. Cross, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, reported here today that the American public was spending about $18,000,000,000 annually for the services of regulated public carriers. He spoke to 600 business leaders at a luncheon of the Central Atlantic Area Institute of Transportation.

MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Government condemned tonight the nation's building program as wasteful, over-ornamental and extravagant and dismissed two leading architects of Moscow.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 -- John D. Dingell Jr., son of the late Representative John D. Dingell, won the Democratic nomination for his father's seat yesterday in a special primary in Michigan's Fifteenth Congressional District here.
JESUIT BEND, La., Nov. 9 (AP) -- A group of Roman Catholic laymen today drew up a charter for a citizens council to oppose the sending of other Negro priests into the area.

Last Saturday, after a first-race spill, Angel Valenzuela hobbled out of the Jamaica track with what appeared to be a broken bone in a foot. There was no break. The jockey's injured foot still aches a bit, but otherwise he's in the best of health.

Guy Gendron's goal four minutes from the end enabled the New York Rangers to earn a 1 -- 1 tie with the pace-setting Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League clash last night at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, decided today to go ahead with development of a middle-range wingless missile.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 -- A church official declared today that division and competition on the denominational level had deprived a large segment of the American public of adequate ministry.
The Urban League of Greater New York called upon the Board of Education yesterday to undertake an "emergency program to desegregate New York City's public schools."
PARIS, Thursday, Nov. 10 -- Fighting to force his proposal for new elections through a reluctant Parliament, French Premier Edgar Faure demanded a vote of confidence on the issue early this morning.

The scholarship fund of St. Christopher's School, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will benefit from a bridge party held by the Triangle Circle, a women's club, on Nov. 21 at the Colony Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The new look on the Washington Senators will not only involve new faces, it turned out today. It will also involve new dimensions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Grants from the Rockefeller Foundation and three private donors have established three $3,000 fellowships in playwriting this year at the University of California at Los Angeles.

The voters of New York State gave a demonstration of independence and discriminating selectivity in their action on proposed constitutional amendments at Tuesday's election. While one may reasonably assume that many people succumbed to the temptation of voting a straight ticket aye or no, a great many others had done their homework, took the trouble to apply it on the machine, and knew what they were about.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The British Government is expected to turn down the latest Cypriote demands that Britain recognize that the people of Cyprus have the right eventually to determine their own future. The Cypriotes pose such recognition as the price for their immediate cooperation.
Conflicting forces appear to be shaping the fate of the non-Russian minorities who make up roughly half the Soviet population.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Grain markets took the overnight selling following yesterday's heavy pressure quite easily this morning. A modest rally followed small initial declines.

GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- Secretary of State Dulles and Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, conferred here for an hour and a half this morning on the continuing threat of Soviet penetration in the turbulent Middle East.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 9 (UP) -- England's Donald Campbell gunned his jet-propelled speedboat Bluebird II an estimated 201 miles per hour today. He fell just short of breaking his world record of 202.32.

LIKE many early nineteenth-century American painters, Ezra Ames, whose portraits make up an exhibition at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, began his career as a sign and carriage painter.

New Jersey Republicans, in the closest legislative race in that state since 1937, retained on Tuesday their 40-to-20 majority in the State Assembly. They did so despite the strongest Democratic opposition in years.
In 1954, the eighty-two voluntary, nonprofit hospitals that are members of the United Hospital Fund served more than 2,300,000 persons, one out of every four resident in New York City.

The bus drama of New York is a current headache. Come rain, come shine, New Yorkers wait for as long as twenty minutes for their bus to come, and when it comes, to stop. But where will it stop? White or yellow lines, soon washed out by rain, are supposed, to indicate the stop area.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Charles Eberling, Democratic Elections Commissioner of Rockland County, committed suicide today in the garage of his home in near-by Germonds.

Rubber prides soared yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange in one of the sharpest rises of the year. Volume was the ninth heaviest of the year. The London market was higher and Singapore was strong.
NEWARK, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Five Ivy League football coaches today agreed they wanted no return to free substitutions.

Frederick A. Marsh of the Garden City (L. I.) Country Club will be nominated as the 1956 president of the Metropolitan Golf Association. The nominating committee of the organization, headed by Stephen Berrien as chairman, made this announcement yesterday.

The Brussels Stock Exchange and the Paris Bourse are considering listing American stocks for trading. And several additional United States issues are under consideration for listing in Amsterdam, where there already is a brisk trade in American and Canadian securities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Sylvania Electric Products Company was acquitted today of charges of price fixing. The Salem (Mass.) company was the only one of five defendant concerns which pleaded innocent and went to trial. The other four pleaded guilty and were fined $2,000 each.

Admiral Earl Mountbatten, Britain's First Sea Lord and Chief of Naval Staff, left for home yesterday after his first visit to the United States in twelve years. While here he held conferences with his American counterpart, Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 10 -- South Africa's Minister of External Affairs bitterly criticized the United Nations today for its decision to keep the Union's racial situation under review for another year.

IT was an all-Balanchine program for the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night, with the "Firebird" as the most interesting work of the evening. Not that it is a new work, by any means, but this was the first opportunity to see it since the Sadler's Wells Ballet recently offered a restoration of the original Fokine version.

When he emerged from the polling-booth on Tuesday the average conscientious voter in this city probably did so with a renewed sense of frustration. He had just finished wrestling with a machine that, however superior to the paper ballot, does present its problems to the non-mechanically minded.

Business loans of leading New York City banks reached a record high of $8,810,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The previous high was $8,721,000,000, on Dec. 24, 1952.
BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- Frederic C. Dumaine Jr., former president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, today surrendered his interest in the half-billion dollar carrier.
The magic of Mozart's chamber music gains by being heard in intimate surroundings as it was last night when the New York Trio played in Carnegie Recital Hall.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 10 -- The insurance industry came] forth with its first suggestion{ today as to how it might suc-I cessfuily write insurance against floods.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Nov. 10 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett's mission to the United States is of great importance to Israel.
A little book that had long been sought by collectors and libraries here was discovered recently in England -- perhaps in a bookseller's shilling bin -- and brought to New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The probability of another race for the Democratic Presidential nomination by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee seemed to be growing today.

Ten Soviet building experts sailed homeward aboard the Queen Elizabeth yesterday after having spent five weeks as guests of the National Association of Home Builders. A group from the association will return the visit next spring.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday rose 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.

TOKYO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Japan and United States motion-picture companies have reached agreement on disposal of nearly $11,000,000 worth of blocked Japanese currency earned by American films here, it was learned today. The agreement will be signed in a few days.

Six years ago tomorrow Isaac Logart had his first professional fight. The Cuban boxer knocked out Ramon Varona in the third round of a bout in his home town of Camaguey, flooring his rival nine times.

Washington, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The American Legion National Commander tonight termed the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization "the international sanctuary of impractical one-worlders, Redtinged radicals and apparently deserters from the ranks of loyal Americans."

NO ONE will ever pin a medal on Dimitri Mitropoulos for his program building. No one would have last night. For the Philharmonic-Symphony concert at Carnegie Hall he assembled trivialities and inoffensive meanderings seasoned by a helping of grimness. There were a few interest/ng minutes, but not enough for a whole ev ning. A concert isn't a place for boredom or penitence.

The six-story apartment house accommodating eighty-four families at 7602 Twenty-first Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by the Brooklyn Realty Corporation to a client of Joseph Cutler, attorney. The Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company and Philip Rothstein were the brokers.
While ship and airplane passenger operations to and from overseas took a seasonal drop here last month, customs receipts from duties and taxes on cargo went up sharply.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday the resignation of Elwood R. Quesada as a vice president and as general manager of its Missile Systems Division.

Advertising research cannot do its full job in the economy and pay its way until management men who spend money for it understand how it works, the first annual conference of the Advertising Research Foundation was told yesterday.
Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority, ordered his top command yesterday to put an end to tie-ups that have slowed the subway system in the last week.
GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- The United States exploded a few Chinese Communist trial balloons today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A former officer of the General Motors Corporation denied today that preferential treatment by the Government in World War II had given the company a head start over competitors in production of Diesel locomotives.

Eighty humorists have chosen their own best stories, essays, poems, cartoons and drawings for "This Is My Best Humor," a new anthology edited by Whit Burnett. Scheduled for Nov. 23 publication by Dial, the 576-page volume contains more than fifty stories and 150 cartoons and drawings from such contributors as James Thurber. Stephen Potter, Abner Dean, Virgil Partch, Ogden Nash and Ludwig Bemelmans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Export-Import Bank is giving "active consideration" to two loans to increase Chilean nitrate production and thus, strengthen that country's exchange position, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The use of trailers to house evacuees from bombed cities is being discussed by the Civil Defense Administration and the trailer industry.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- British Government securities, depressed all this week, were in modest demand today as bear selling dried up. Improvement in gilt-edge securities brought a slightly better tone to the rest of the stock market.
DENVER, Colo., Nov. 10 -- The White House announced today the resignation of Bernard M. Shanley, President Eisenhower's appointments secretary.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano of West Germany said today he hoped that doubts of the necessity for Western European unity would be dispelled by the negative results of the Foreign Ministers' Conference.

Under some circumstances it might be considered "interfering" for Americans to take a substantial interest in the outcome of a distinctly domestic election in the Philippines. In the present case, however, there is reason to absolve Americans from this charge. A major issue in the current campaign and election has been the relationship of the Philippines to the United States, and for that reason we have a legitimate interest in the outcome.

HARTFORD, Nov. 10 -- Much of the hostility that used to exist between business and education now has been replaced by mutual respect and understanding, James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, declared here tonight.
Dispersal of industry to outlying sections results largely from inadequate sites in urban areas, the nation's realtors were told here yesterday at their annual convention.
