WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The chairman of a House subcommittee investigating Government information practices asserted today that there was "a clear need for new legislation" to break down official barriers on news.
Vassily Smyslov of Russia scored 1 1/2 points yesterday in the international chess tournament at Zagreb, Yugoslavia, and stayed in first place with a total of 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- All twelve members of the commission created by Congress to investigate the Government's controversial security and loyalty programs were named today. They were picked under stringent rules designed to make the commission's operations thoroughly bipartisan or nonpartisan.
The State Power Authority split three to two yesterday over a plan to build its own transmission lines for St. Lawrence power. The majority favored the plan.
A horse sale that assertedly boomeranged wound up in Federal Court here yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The state moved today to clean up the Hudson River. The Water Pollution Control Board approved a detailed plan that would force nine cities, eight villages and twenty industries along the river to discontinue practices causing pollution.

The pending first public sale of stock of the Ford Motor Company will be directed by the largest underwriting syndicate ever organized, according to investment houses selected to manage the distribution.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The United States informed Canada tonight that it would not agree to an impending Canadian proposal for the "package" admission to the United Nations of eighteen Communist and non-Communist applicants.

City Councilman Eric Treulich's proposal to fine and jail jaywalking pedestrians is splendid -- as far as it goes. We pedestrians ought to second the Councilman's motion and propose just one small amendment -- namely, that equal fines and equal jail sentences be imposed, with equal regularity, on motorists doing right turns in front of pedestrians who have the green light.
Two steamship companies considering the leasing of major North River piers from the city were assured by longshore leaders yesterday that they would have harmonious labor relations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Roman Catholic officials announced today publication of a new and more readable translation of seven books of the Old Testament.
After five years of piecemeal additions, the alternate-side-of-the-street parking program in Manhattan will be completed Monday.

Nov. 11 was for some years an international holiday. There are many men and women in this country who can remember very well the day in 1918 when half the world celebrated the signing of the armistice that marked the cessation of hostilities in a war that had cost ten million lives.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- American farms turned out another enormous crop this year, equaling the record set in 1948, the Department of Agriculture said today.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Rev. Victor K. Wrigley, third pastor of the Northwest Synod of the United Lutheran Church to stand trial on charges of doctrinal deviation, was found guilty on five of six counts by a synod heresy trial board tonight.
Two new special squads of firemen, supplementing regular companies, will go into service next Wednesday, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 -- Abandonment by this country of all foreign aid was proposed before the Commonwealth Club of California today.
Nuclear propulsion for a major surface unit of the Navy, as well as for some smaller types of vessels, is no longer a long-range prospect.

THERE is nothing wrong with the basic idea of "The Vamp," which opened last night at the Winter Garden. John Latouche and Sam Locke, authors of the book, offer Carol Channing in the role of a motion picture vamp in the primeval days of the screen industry.
CAIRO, Nov. 10 -- The Government of the Sudan fell today on a vote of no confidence.
The nation turned out more steel in October than ever before in a single month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

DURING the summer of 1853 a cholera epidemic raged in Copenhagen. People died in their beds, on the streets and in the fetid hospitals where the dying sometimes shared beds with the dead. Many of the nobility fled from the stricken city, but the old Marchioness Hermione Schnell, widow of the Foreign Minister, refused to leave her palace.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Myron S. Melvin announced today that the Melvin interests were selling the Onondaga Hotel to the L. Schleifer Realty Corp. of New York City for $3,000,000.
Prokofieff's most ambitious opera, "War and Peace," will have its United States premiere next spring. It will be performed by the "N. B. C. Opera Theatre" on television.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- American business men were advised today to do a more vigorous selling job in Latin America if they hope to halt Western European inroads in that "lucrative market."
The Board of Education took steps yesterday to determine scientifically why many children cannot read.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, launched a formal, detailed attack today on President Eisenhower's plan for aerial inspection and exchange of military information between the Soviet Union and the United States.

There has been increasing discussion in recent weeks of our farm surpluses and it seems to me that most of the comments are not directed at the real heart of the problem. We hear much talk of a limitation on production rather than of an ever broadening of distribution of the abundance that God has given us.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The State Department today beat a retreat on cultural exchanges with the Soviet Union.
Carmelo Costa of Brooklyn and Joey Lopes of Sacramento, Calif., will meet in a scheduled ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight will be the second between them.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- A reappraisal of the scope and functions of local Jewish community organizations was urged today at the opening of the twenty-fourth general assembly of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds.
CONTEMPORARY art from the Far East agreeably diversifies the program of this week's exhibitions.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Government today warned Moscow's Mayor Mikhail A. Yasnov that he and his deputy were personally responsible for the city's newly aired architectural errors.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the International Electrical Workers Union, C. I. O., agreed tonight to transfer contract talks to New York City in hopes of ending a twenty-five-day strike by 44,000 production workers in thirty company plants.
MOSCOW, Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union's campaign to foster Scandinavian neutralism went into high gear today with the arrival here of Premier Einar Gerhardsen of Norway.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- West Germany made public today a budget for next year providing for no increase in its contribution to the cost of Western defense.
Ethel Merman, who declined to star in a color "spectacular" because the National Broadcasting Company reportedly would not meet her asking fee, has agreed to appear on a variety show next month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, about to announce that he is a candidate for renomination for President by the Democratic party, passed through Washington on his way to Charlottesville, Va., with the happy mien of a man who at last has come to a firm conclusion after a period of agonizing reappraisal.
A fascinating new weapon for the propaganda war -- a rugged little hand-operated phonograph that can be manufactured for 50 cents or less -- was unveiled here yesterday.
IT MAY seem a bit early to be considering Christmas cards. However, the customer who tries to place an order for an engraved or printed card after Thanksgiving is an optimist.
Approximately 200 applications for record in track and field, swimming and weight lifting will be considered at the Amateur Athletic Union's national convention at Louisville Dec. 1-4.

Samuel M. Lane charged yesterday that the chances of "decent longshoremen to shake the mob off their backs" may have been dealt a "fatal" blow. This he attributed to Governor Harriman's request for the resignation of Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays as this state's Waterfront Commissioner.

THE Federal Communications Commission formally acknowledged yesterday in Washington that the expansion of television had run into a major technical snag. The future of pay-as-you-see television and educational television, as well as competition among networks, is bound to be affected.

A question has been raised by a football fan who pores over the weekly statistics issued by the National Collegiate Athletic Bureau as avidly as any baseball fan studies the weekly batting and pitching averages.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Favorable weather was forecast for President Eisenhower's "home coming" tomorrow. Some officials estimated that 200,000 persons would turn out to greet him.
A DESSERT is easiest to define in terms of what it is not.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 10 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov "unwittingly did us a great service in dispelling this smokescreen of Geneva spirit,'' Governor Harriman declared here tonight. Accepting one of two Humanitarian Awards of the Westchester Council, B'nai B'rith, he told an audience of 2,000 persons in the County Center:
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 10 (UP) -- Civil Aeronautics Administrator F. B. Lee predicted today that general aviation would make a 33 per cent gain by 1960 and would hit the 14,000,000-hour mark by 1965.
Three detectives have been demoted as a result of their appearing as character witnesses for George (The Weasel) Stern, an ex-convict, at a recent deportation hearing.
The United States should practice at home what it preaches and puts into practice abroad -goodwill and tolerance, the National Conference of Christians and Jews was told here yesterday.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 8 -- The political whirlwind raised by the proposed visit here of the former Argentine President, Juan D. Peron, has subsided, but its memory lingers on.

The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday a proposed offering of $30,000,000 of first refunding mortgage bonds. It is proposed to offer the bonds for sale at public sealed bidding later this month. The money will be used to finance construction and pay off bank loans.
The consolidated net income of Cities Service Company for the first nine months of this year amounted to $32,517,636, equal to $3.28 a share.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The British Ambassadors in Israel and Egypt will urge the governments of those two nations to respond to Prime Minister Eden's speech here last night, Foreign Office sources said today.
An old friend and racing associate of the late William Woodward Jr. offered yesterday to do "anything in my power" to keep the famous Belair Stud intact.

A great glory of our nation is its unsung heroes. They include those who without public fanfare hold the line of professional integrity, of devotion to the public interest, of truth seeking and speaking as it is given to them to know truth. They are of the creative minority who supply ideas and performance which are socially responsible and productive.

Certainly a majority of the citizens of the United States who saw in the Nov. 2 issue of The Times the picture of the Secretary of State of this great Republic leaning forward in rapt attention toward the one dictator that remains who fought the democracies in the second World War must have felt the terrific shock that bowled over the undersigned.
WASHINGTON, NOV. 10 -- Another nuclear test in the Soviet Union took place in recent days, the Atomic Energy Commission said tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- All grain and soybean futures registered sharp declines early today. But commission support broadened on the setbacks, starting short profit-taking that resulted in partial recoveries from the lows. Corn and soybeans closed below yesterday's final levels; changes in other grains were mixed.

Two of the top statesmen of the West have now moved to avert a dangerous situation in the Middle East. That President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Eden should both have made portentous statements on Wednesday was no accident of timing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov 10 -- Filmed progress reports by Walt Disney's camera men with the Navy's forthcoming Antarctic expedition, Operation Deep-freeze, will be televised in the spring on the "Disneyland" and "Mickey Mouse Club" TV programs over the American Broadcasting Company network.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Experiments suggesting a revolutionary concept of the mechanism of heredity and the processes whereby all living things recreate themselves in their own image were described here today.
Many dinner parties were given last night at the preview opening of the Maurice Chevalier engagement in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event was a benefit for the French Hospital.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 10 -- A policy of United States support to down-trodden countries was unanimously endorsed by United Church Women in their closing assembly sessions here today.
TRENTON, Nov. 10 -- A free accident - prevention counseling service is being organized here for the benefit of about 7,000 small New Jersey plants unable to afford their own safety engineers.

TOKYO, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The New York Yankees returned to Tokyo's Orakuen Stadium today after playing ten games in other parts of Japan and defeated an all-star team of the Central Professional League, 6 -- 1.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's 5-year-old gelding, Social Outcast, the world's seventh largest money-winning thoroughbred, was regarded today as the top choice for tomorrow's Washington D. C. International at Laurel.

Shares on the New York Stock Exchange dropped an average of 2.6 per cent in October, that institution reported yesterday. The average value of each listed share of stock on Oct. 31 was $54.69, against $56.14 a month earlier.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Dr. Homer Dodge, former president of Norwich University, said tonight a story of a speech he gave on Russian education yesterday in Worcester. Mass., was reported "out of context and gave a completely distorted view" of his opinions.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 10, (Reuters) -- Maj. Gen. Henrique Texeira Lott, Brazilian Minister of War and leader of the constitutionalists, resigned tonight. His action followed a Government refusal to take action against an Army colonel who had publicly urged a coup.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) off to 16 points (80 cents a bale) up yesterday, with the far deliveries strongest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. accused the Small Business Administration today of operating in an "indirect and haphazard" manner and failing to place enough curbs on possible monopolies.

YALE rooters didn't walk out of the Bowl in New Haven last Saturday. They wafted out, stepping daintily down a staircase of rosy clouds. Even if Yale wins the Big Three title, Old Blues won't be more thrilled than they were at the rude and convincing way their heroes manhandled overwhelmingly favored Army.
Stocks held even yesterday in a generally optimistic session. Of the 1,194 issues traded, 489 rose, 458 fell and 247 closed unchanged. Volume was 2,550,000 shares, against 2,580,000 on Wednesday.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, in the Pacific, Nov. 10 -- Something new has been added to this Antarctic-bound icebreaker -- six cozy deck chairs.
Member banks of the Federal Reserve system experienced further pressure against their reserve positions in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- A French Government proposal to elect a new Parliament next month was entangled today in almost impenetrable political cross-purposes.
Cleveland Amory's successful chronicle of American society at play, "The Last Resorts," is in the news again as the basis for a Broadway musical early next season.

Gemelo, owned by W. Arnold Hanger and ridden by Eddie Arcaro, took the Hyde Park, the mile and five-furlong test that occupied the feature spot at Jamaica yesterday. The 18,820 fans made the Lily-Ann Stable's Blacktype the favorite but this 7-year-old son of Market Wise was a soundly subdued second.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A spokesman for United States distillers today proposed raising the tariff on Canadian whisky to $5 a gallon because, he said, some Canadian distillers had not passed along tariff reduction to United States consumers. The tariff at present is $1.25.
ST. STEPHEN, N. B., Nov. 10 -- Having spent the day on and near the fabulous Horseback Ridge, our advice to those planning to hunt this area for the first time is to make the trip on horseback.

Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett said yesterday that Israel would accept arms from any country if her security were threatened. This warning was sounded after Mr. Sharett had replied in the negative to a question as to whether the Soviet Union had offered to sell arms to his country.

President Eisenhower's projected return to Washington today represents a victory for courage and for good medical care. It represents also good fortune, not merely for the President and his family and close friends, but also for the people of these United States.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Friday, Nov. 11 -- Edmund Orgill, prominent business man and civic leader here, was elected Mayor of this city in yesterday's election. It was Mr. Orgill's first political venture.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Conditions for freer exchange of foreign currencies into dollars are "rapidly being achieved," E. M. Bernstein, top economist of the International Monetary Fund, said today.

THE Brothers Tough, members of the oldest neighborhood club in New York, will up-end beakers of the best at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel tomorrow night. The wassail will flow through the Sabbath dawn and sentimental tears will plop in the malt. That is the way of Tough Club parties -- and tomorrow's is the ninetieth.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- William Holden has agreed to star in the Hal Wallis production of "The Rainmaker," the producer announced today. Mr. Holden will step into the role for which Burt Lancaster had been announced a year ago.

What can the average American family do to promote greater international understanding? Most persons would probably reply, "not very much." However, an answer of a positive and practical nature was recently given by Kenneth Holland, president of the Institute of International Education.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 9 -- The Royal Laotian Government told the International Armistice Commission in effect today it had been unable to achieve agreement with Communist-led forces and would hold national elections without them.
A morals charge and one of felonious assault against the president of a liberal arts college of the University of California were dismissed yesterday in Gamblers Court by Magistrate Hyman Bushel.
Washington's plan to sell Israel a "significant" quantity of arms may postpone but will not resolve the Middle East crisis.

An increase last week of 397,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 152,004,000 barrels, compared with 151,607,000 a week earlier and 149,138,000 a year ago.
Dallas, Tex., Independent School District received bids yesterday for the purchase of a new issue of $10,000,000 of school bonds maturing serially on Dec. 1 from 1956 to 1975.
GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- Efforts to find common ground on the least controversial issue before the Foreign Ministers' Conference, East-West contacts, collapsed today.

Consolidated net income of Aluminium, Ltd., and consolidated subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year amounted to $36,776,325, it was announced yesterday. This represents an increase of 36.7 per cent from the $26,904,220 cleared in the corresponding period of 1954.
Nature had kindly second thoughts last night and what had at first looked like a threat of new floods turned out to be only a good, soaking rain.

Buying has been good at the six-day exhibit of boys' wear apparel at the New Yorker Hotel. The show, sponsored by the Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association in cooperation with the Boys' Apparel Buyers' Association, closes this afternoon. Exhibitors reported that bookings for immediate shipment have been slow but spring items were ordered.

The first new breed of dog to be admitted to the American Kennel Club stud book in ten years is now officially a member of America's purebred dog family. It is the Rhodesian Ridgeback, whose admittance was announced by the A. K. C. yesterday.
HONOLULU, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Four of five airmen who parachuted into stormy seas 650 miles from land were picked up last night and early today in a dramatic rescue that the Air Force termed "a miracle."

The first book award of the National Council of Women of the United States was presented in absentia yesterday to Anne Morrow Lindbergh for her latest book, "Gift From the Sea." The award for "the outstanding book about women by a woman" was made yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The Rev. Michael Scott, asked today to be heard on behalf of three South-West African tribes. His request precipitated adjournment of the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee in a fog of legal indecision.

Neither the Soviet Communist party chief, Nikita S. Khrushchev, nor Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin ever will become an all-powerful dictator like Stalin, many Soviet citizens believe. The fact that both men are now in their sixties, while Stalin was only in his forties when his predecessor, Lenin, died, was the reason usually given.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A Court of Appeals decision today opened the way for possible Supreme Court clarification of the non-Communist affidavit issue in labor cases.

The United Corporation looks for 1955 net income "a little greater than 30 cents per share," William M. Hickey, president, said yesterday. He estimated that 23 cents of that total would be ordinary net income from interest and dividends and the rest from profit on sales of securities. United Corporation is a holding company which is in transition to an investment company.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Secret files have been stolen from Scotland Yard.

Before 18,245 fans, a record-breaking crowd for the National Basketball Association, the New York Knickerbockers opened their home league season by whipping the Minneapolis Lakers. 112 -- 105, at Madison Square Garden last night. In the opening game of the N. B. A. double-Header, the Philadelphia Warriors beat the Rochester Royals, 89 -- 84.

South Africa has now followed France in a protest against what each Government regarded as unwarranted interference by the United Nations in its internal affairs. The French, indignant when the question of government in Algeria was put on the General Assembly's agenda, walked out of the Assembly but not out of the United Nations Building and organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The United States has let it be known that "it would be strongly opposed" to the side that started a war in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 808,709 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Two industrial giants yesterday announced billion-dollar expansion programs. Standard Oil (New Jersey), the world's largest oil company, said it would spend $1,200,000,000 in 1956. Chrysler Corporation, third largest automobile producer, disclosed plans to spend $1,000,000,000 over the next five years.

A 71-year-old man was dragged for three blocks under a taxicab in Times Square last night. Despite the crows on the street -- it was the height of the pre-theatre rush -- apparently only one person saw the accident happen.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Lieut. Col. Marcus Lipton, Labor Member of Parliament, withdrew today his charge that Harold A. R. Philby was the "third man" in the Burgess-Maclean spy case.

An investment syndicate represented by Charles Rubman, attorney, has sold the apartment house at 1625-27 University Avenue, the Bronx, to the Shemesh Realty Corporation. The buyers paid cash above mortgages totaling $120,000, according to Shiffman Goldkopf, brokers in the sale.
It's one passing duel after another for Columbia's Claude Benham, who is tied for the top spot among the college passers of the country.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- President Theodor Heuss today appointed Adolf Heusinger and Hans Speidel to be lieutenant generals of the new German Army.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 10 -- A prospect of doubled enrollments within fifteen years threatens to bankrupt this countrys private colleges, educators warned here today.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association closed its tournament season officially today. The finale was a pro-pro team championship at the Vernon Hills Country Club. Thirty-one pairs participated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Government's housing chief said today the widely reported squeeze in mortgage money has been exaggerated. He predicted that the annual rate of housing starts, seasonally adjusted, will not fall below 1,200,000 in the months ahead.

When we think about it, we are all proud of the magnificent hospital system of our city. We marvel at the imagination and foresightedness of our ancestors who created the voluntary non-profit hospital that has become the heart of this system.
Detectives of the narcotics squad yesterday seized heroin valued at $100,000 retail in the apartment of an asserted narcotic peddler who calmed his nerves with prune juice.
Equipped with an unusual zest for living, a fluent knowledge of English and a desire to pass his experience on to fellow paraplegics, a young French veteran of the Korean War returned home yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Retail sales last month dropped 1 per cent below September levels, according to the "flash" report released today by the Department of Commerce.

The Wagner Administration is in the midst of a painful reappraisal of its capital budget for 1956 as a result of the emphatic defeat of Constitutional Amendment No. 5 in Tuesday's election. The voters called a halt to further expansion of locality borrowing power; it may be noted that the vote was especially decisive within New York City, being 281,044 for exempting sewer construction from constitutional debt limits, and 459,744 against it.
Two French women were honored last night by the United States Treasury Post of the American Legion.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Syria proposed today that North Korea as well as South Korea be invited to take part in the General Assembly's debate on the Korean question.
The tax rebate feature of the Wagner Administration housing reform proposals now under consideration was praised yesterday by State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams.

Top models will donate their time to a fashion show, and fashion show editors, garment manufacturers and department store executives will join in presenting skits, at the "Party of the Year," annual ball for the benefit of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute.
A six-story $1,000,000 addition to the New York Medical College-Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals building at 106th Street and Fifth Avenue was opened yesterday afternoon.
BOSTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins stopped the streaking Rangers with a 5-1 triumph tonight for their third victory without a loss over the second-place New Yorkers.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from statements today at the Foreign Ministers' Conference by Secretary of State Dulles, Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan of Britain, Antoine Pinay of France and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov of the Soviet Union and the text of Western and Soviet proposals on disarmament:
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy promoted four detectives yesterday and commended twenty others for their work in breaking up a ring of fur thieves.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 10 (UP) -- Donald Campbell spent an entire day trying to make a record run in his jet-propelled Bluebird II today, but darkness finally halted his efforts after he had made one run down the measured-mile course.
Today's new film is "Running Wild," a Universal-International melodrama at the Palace. Featured in the cast are William Campbell, Mamie Van Doren, Keenan Wynn, Kathleen Case and Jan Merlin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- State health officers asked Congress today for more time to complete the $30,000,000 free polio vaccine program, now scheduled to expire Feb. 15.
DENVER, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower passed his final hospital physical tests today and was cleared to leave here for Washington tomorrow morning.

The flow of Japanese-made blouses into the United States has reached the proportions of "dumping" on the American market, B. H. Lerner, executive director of the National Skirt and Sportswear Association, said yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that 208,633 cars and trucks will be produced in the United States this week for the second highest total in history.
Scores of narcotics addicts and sellers were rounded up yesterday and early today in a series of coordinated raids involving the entire 180-member police narcotics squad.

The United Nations has wisely and properly rejected the Communist and "neutralist" suggestion that the North Korean regime should be a party to the debate on the Korean problems. To have made any other decision would have been to stultify the United Nations and to make it plain that the international organization was more interested in "accommodation" than in the preservation of the international morality to which it is dedicated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- Universal-International held open house last night in the new, headquarters of its Talent Workshop, a bustling school where aspiring young actors and actresses are helped to develop dramatic, singing and dancing abilities. It is under the direction of Jess Kimmel.

Rare is the investor who does not look longingly at the capital gains provisions of the Federal tax law. The reason: on regular income a person in the upper brackets pays 90 per cent or more, but on long-term capital gains the Government's maximum take is just 25 per cent.
Walston Co., member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, will dissolve and reorganize as a member corporation, effective Dec. 1.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Next week a handsome country mansion in the rolling Pennsylvania hills will become the temporary White House, headquarters of the free world.
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 11 -- Five Afghan tribesmen were killed this week in the seventh month of sporadic guerrilla warfare inside Pakistan's North-West Frontier.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced yesterday that Iowa would be blacked out for today's Illinois-Wisconsin football game at Madison, Wis. The Columbia Broadcasting System answered that it would not respect the ban.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 11 -- The Brazilian Army seized control of the Government in a quick, bloodless coup at 2 A. M. today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -Pennsylvania's football team hopes to carry over some of the spirit it showed against Notre Dame last week when the Quakers meet Army tomorrow on Franklin Field.

Sales of the nation's chain and mail order companies in October continued to run well ahead of year-ago levels. The volume of business done by forty companies was 9.8 per cent ahead of-sales in October of last year.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The coach of Jim Golliday, Northwestern sprinter, today sharply criticized an announced effort by the Amateur Athletic Union to credit Golliday with a new world record of 9.2 seconds for 100 yards.

New financing through the public market is slated to proceed at a lively pace next week. Conditions continue to be propitious for the marketing of new issues of common stock, as well as for the sale of corporate and local government debt.

FREDERICK ASHTON'S "Picnic at Tintagel" was restored to the repertoire of the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night after an absence of more than a year. That is far too long an absence for so good a ballet, and especially for one that contributes so effectively to the company's weakest department, that of the story-ballet.
TRENTON, Nov. 11 -- Many New Jersey physicians are resenting a proposal that they administer Salk polio vaccine free of charge in a mass immunization program at public clinics.
A pair of diamond earrings that were recognized by a public school teacher resulted in the arraignment of a young student's mother in Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Emigration to Israel of 45,000 Worth African Jews in the next twelve months was declared here today to be necessary to relieve their "extraordinary economic poverty and critical emergency needs."
West Coast longshoremen will press in the next session of Congress for Government financial assistance to intercoastal shipping and will seek also Federal aid for port rehabilitation programs.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Moshe Sharett, Foreign Minister of Israel, said today that "there is danger of a war to be waged" by the Arab nations against Israel if "they are superior to us in arms."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- All provisions of the covenants on human rights except those on self-determination were in effect shelved today.

ARMED with most of the virtues of the violinistic lexicon, Oscar Shumsky played to a good-sized audience last night in Carnegie Hall. A strong technician, the master of a sweet and well-focused tone, an artist whose musical instincts are always on the side of the angels, Mr. Shumsky provided an evening of admirable music.

With the track sloppy, as the result of Thursday night's rain, front-runners did well at Jamaica yesterday. Among them was Mrs. Anson A. Bigelow's colt, Nail. He did extra well. He collected $64,425 in the Remsen Stakes.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 11 -Princeton and Yale will meet in an Ivy football game tomorrow before a sellout crowd of 46,000 in Palmer Stadium. The kickoff is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.

Events today: Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman, conductor, Max Leavitt and Paul Nordoff, narrators, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 A. M.; Philharmonic - Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor, Jean Casadesus, pianist, 8:45 P. M.
Negotiations are under way for a merger of the major Eastern Orthodox Churches in America.

The first of an eight or nine volume "Bibliography of American Literature" will be issued Wednesday by Yale University Press. Volume I, from Henry Adams to Donn Byrne, has 3,200 entries by forty-one authors. When completed the series will contain 35,000 items by 300 authors.

MANILA, Nov. 11 -- President Ramon Magsaysay said today that his party's electoral victory this week made him feel that he had more of a responsibility than ever before to help the little people of his country.
Two slates have filed nominations for the election of directors to the local board of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

The New York Knickerbockers and the Boston Celtics, who played to a virtual stalemate in fifteen encounters last season, will meet tonight at Madison Square Garden. The game will be the Celtics' first Garden appearance of the new National Basketball Association season and will follow a prep school contest between New York Military Academy and St. Ann's at 7:30.
Referee Simon H. Rifkind has postponed until next Friday the filing of briefs in a contempt action involving the International Longshoremen's Association.

CUTHBERT, Ga., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Randolph County's three voter registrars have resigned in protest of a Federal court verdict awarding $880 in damages to twenty-two Negro residents on a complaint that they had been unjustly deprived of voting rights.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The General Assembly's Political and Security Committee declined today to invite Communist North Korea to participate in debate on the Korean question. This reaffirmed the stand of previous years.

Investigations by three agencies have cleared Manuel A. Gomez, Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, of any suspicion' in connection with the arrest of his divorced wife, Alegria, on a charge of possessing narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee said today that Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State, and Alger Hiss appeared to be "together again" and working for the nomination of a left-wing. Democratic Presidential candidate.
Two decisions -- a studied one and a split-second reaction -- contributed greatly to the lasting fame of Rugby School, one of England's nine public schools.

TORONTO, Nov. 11 (Canadian Press) --Mexico tonight won the first international jumping event at the Royal Winter Fair after a hard fighting American equestrian team forced two jump-offs before a winner was declared

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- An Air Force inventor says present life lines used in water rescues are made of hemp, sisal or cotton rope and are provided with floats to keep them from sinking. But they are hard to see in the water and do not last long.

Cancellation of the American debut of Soviet violinist David Oistrakh with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London tomorrow evening in Carnegie Hall was confirmed yesterday by Columbia Artists Management.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- A 22-year-old flier is believed to be the first man in Britain to have parachuted from a plane flying faster than the speed of sound and lived.

ST. STEPHEN, N. B., Nov. 11 -- Deer hunting during "shirt-sleeve" weather is very pleasant for the hunter, but seldom provide him with venison for the deep freeze. Having exhausted every other theory to account for the poor results during the past two weeks, local hunters are blaming the weather.

The first rise in the current round of newsprint price increases by a domestically owned producer was announced yesterday by Southland Paper Mills, Inc., of Lufkin, Tex. Southland notified customers that it was raising its price $5 a ton, effective Dec. 1. This would bring the cost of its paper delivered in New York to $131 a ton.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 -- Another South American coup was carried out today. It was performed by Venezuela's two representatives in the fourth running of the Washington, D. C., International race at the Laurel track.
Regret at the cancellation of Senate hearings on the status of religious freedom was expressed here yesterday by representatives of Jewish organizations.
BOTH formal and imaginative territory is staked out by painters in six one-man shows now on view.

Rails roared up the grade yesterday and dragged the rest of the stock market behind them to the best levels of the recover movements. Oils, motors, aircrafts, chemicals and mail orders also had strong advances.

The survey of American imports, directed by Don D. Humphrey and jointly sponsored by the Twentieth Century Fund and the National Planning Association, casts a searching light on a subject far too little understood booth at home and abroad. Public interest in it has been heightened by hearings on foreign economic policies begun this week by a subcommittee of the Joint Senate-House Committee on the President's Economic Report.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Marshal Pierre Alphonse Juin called today for a rebuilding of France's armed forces.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A Navy bomber crashed into a destroyer during a simulated low level attack off Southern California today, killing five men.

The purchase this week of 29 per cent of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's preferred stock by bankers "friendly" to Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the carrier, may have a double-barreled significance come Dec. 21.

Princeton's Palmer Stadium, the scene of many thrilling episodes in college football, will be the venue of the game in the East commanding the most interest today on the next-to-last full program of the season.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 11 -- Adlai E. Stevenson suggested tentatively tonight that guards representing the United Nations might patrol the tense borders between Israel and the Arab states.

Not everyone demands modern design in this jet-atomic age. Clock makers report that thousands of grandfather clocks are sold each year. Although grandpa's curled mustache and sideburns are considered passe, the stately old timepieces are gracing modern dwellings.
Penn-Texas Company plans to acquire the Liberty Products Company through a transaction involving the issuance of $12,000,000 of Penn-Texas stock.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The Rev. Michael Scott appealed to the United Nations today to help relieve the "desperate" plight of natives in South-West Africa.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- Russian aspirations in the Middle East are certainly not new. Politically they date from Czarist times. Molotov explained them in meticulous detail to Ribbentrop during a period Moscow would like to forget. The Soviet Foreign Minister displayed much greed in the direction of the Mediterranean (via Turkey) and the Persian Gulf (via Iran).

Optimism prevails in the wine industry based upon continuance of the spectacular growth in sales of American wines since 1941. Most industry spokesmen agree that this year's sales will far surpass those of last year, which aggregated 140,000,000 gallons, a far cry from the average of 63,000,000 gallons sold during the years 1935 through 1940.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A light airplane designed to land or take off in less than 500 feet is in final assembly at the Fairchild Aircraft plant at Hagerstown, Md.

HARTFORD, Nov. 11 -- The word "liberal" and its meaning came in for some critical examination today at the Trinity College fall convocation here. The four-day program, which opened yesterday, has as its theme "The Challenge to Liberal Education."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 10 -- The United States hopes President Tito of Yugoslavia will make a substantial contribution to peace in the Middle East when he visits Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser in Cairo next month.

Admiral Earl Mountbatten's visit to the United States, which ended this week, emphasized the need for a closer rapprochement between the two English-speaking nations in nuclear developments. Britain's First Sea Lord saw most of the U. S. Navy's newest ships and recent developments -- with one outstanding exception. He did not board the nuclear submarine Nautilus.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -The National Academy of Sciences has recommended that the United States build ten instrument-filled space satellites for launching during the International Geophysical Year.

MIAMI, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Miami gave Quarterback Gene Reeves a full-scale tryout tonight and the lanky passer threw for two touchdowns and set up another as the Hurricanes swamped Bucknell, 46 -- 0, before 30,240 fans in the Orange Bowl.

I would like to commend The New York Times on the article that Arthur Daley wrote on Nov. 2 entitled "What Price Amateurism?" Mr. Daley has voiced the feelings of many educators in stating that "principles of amateur idealism have been warped beyond recognition."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 11 -- A special committee on the reorganization of the Rutgers University board of trustees today submitted a report which, if adopted, would greatly strengthen the state's control over the university.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- The Flying Dragon, Pacific Far East Lines refrigerator ship, sailed yesterday for the Far East with the last shipment of holiday turkeys for Army and Air Force Christmas feasts part of her cargo.

Special morning showings of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Oklahoma!" will be held during Christmas week at the Rivoli Theatre. The shows will start at 10 o'clock daily from Dec. 26 through Jan. 2, with the exception of Jan. 1. Afternoon performances that week will be held at 1:30 and 5.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 31 -- This country's coffee exports during the 1954-55 season that ended Sept. 30 paid the highest taxes in Guatemalan history. But the drop in their total value has seriously affected the country's foreign trade position.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 11 -- Thirty nationalist rebels, including Ben Boulaid Mustafa ben Ahmed, former chief of the rebellion in the Aures Mountains of eastern Algeria, escaped from prison at Constantine last night. Nineteen surrendered today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The British Government abandoned Britain's only long-range jet transport project today in a move that leaves the field wide open to United States aims.
Over a seventy-five-year period the public has contributed $56,000,000 to the United Hospital Fund for distribution to its eighty - two voluntary, non-profit member hospitals.
Columbia's football team will meet Navy at Baker Field today in the last game of their current rivalry. The setting is expected to be one of the most colorful in the series that began in 1900.

This Saturday is going to be Different, one announces firmly at breakfast. This Saturday a lot of important things are going to be Accomplished. Someone is thoughtless enough to recall that something of the sort was said last Saturday, at breakfast.

Watch a pedestrian cross a busy street. He does not look at the driver's face, although presumably some expression there might indicate an intention. He looks at the big steel car to see what its intentions are. Watch a driver. He will observe pedestrians, but only as if they were indecisive, unpredictable, subhuman obstructions.

Some 75,000 young New York women look to the Young Women's Christian Association for rooms, friends, new skills, good times, good health and good counsel. The number of these young New Yorkers who look to the Y. W. C. A. is growing. Funds must be raised to serve them during the coming year.

PARIS, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Armand Massard of France, vice president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that judges and referees at the 1956 games would have to take an oath of impartiality.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman accused some of his liberal Democratic colleagues last night of placing party unity above civil rights.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Nov. 11 -The Holyoke Municipal Gas and Electric Department is preparing to bid for development of a nuclear power plant in this city, it has been announced by Department Manager Frank H. King.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The National Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor has suspended the Air Line Pilots' Association and recommended its expulsion by the next A. F. L. convention. The vote was unanimous.
DENVER, Nov. 11 -- With a wave, a grin and a few words spoken into a bitter winter wind, President Eisenhower this morning said good-by to Denver.
Churchgoers in the United States will be asked to share their blessings during Thanksgiving Week with the less fortunate in other lands.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Bill Rigney, who helped win his new job as 1956 manager of the New York Giants by piloting the Minneapolis Millers to their first little world series title, today was named the American Association's manager of the year.

There are not as many differences between the French and the United States Governments as your editorials imply. You suggest that the French Government is weak, confused and helpless. This is no more accurate a description of the French Government than it would be of that of the United States.
Three men were arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday in the interstate theft of $70,000 of woolen cloth. The goods were recovered in a Brooklyn warehouse, the bureau said.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- The Western powers were trying today to arrange another Foreign Ministers' Conference with the Soviet Union next spring. It was agreed by the four powers meanwhile to conclude the current talks Wednesday.

Following are the texts of a talk by President Eisenhower on leaving Denver yesterday, the greeting by Vice President Richard M. Nixon at Washington National Airport and remarks by the President at the capital. The statements were recorded by The New York Times.
Cesar Taormina, home builder, has purchased the vacant block-front on the north side of Astor Avenue, between Matthews and Bronxwood Avenues, the Bronx. He will build sixteen two-family homes.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Anton Schuessler, 42-year-old father of two of three boys slain last month, died today of a heart attack.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- A collaborative study of cerebral palsy, intended to concentrate half a century or more of research into a period of five to ten years, was announced tonight by Senator John F. Kennedy.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 11 -- The general who has emerged, at least for the moment, as Brazil's strong man is little known to the public. He stands high among soldiers and others who do know him.
Pastor Martin Niemoeller called war a "grim madness" last night and declared that pacificism offered humanity its "last chance."
LONDON, Nov. 11-- British military experts have proposed a sweeping reorganization of the British Army, including the creation of a British Foreign Legion.

CAIRO, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, chief United Nations truce supervisor in Palestine, today presented United Nations proposals to the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi, for easing tension on the borders between Israel and Egypt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Two sets of Republican Senators are edging away from the party's orthodox leadership in the Senate and seeking an ever closer identification with President Eisenhower.
Following is the text of a speech last night by Adlai E. Stevenson at the University of Virginia as recorded by The New York Times:

There have been revelations since the ousting of Argentina's President Juan D. Peron in September and the devaluation of the Argentine peso. Economic conditions in Argentina appear to have been far different from what the world had been led to understand.

TRENTON, Nov. 11 -- About 30,000 employes of automobile plants in New Jersey are eligible to receive state and company unemployment benefits simultaneously as the result of a ruling by Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Grain and soybean futures developed a generally stronger tone today, following yesterday's weakness.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- The Famed American Negro operetta "Porgy and Bess" will play here in December or January, despite the State Department's opposition.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Russia will send 145 athletes, officials and delegates in an all-out effort to dominate the 1956 Olympic winter games, the first it has entered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A Midwestern seed industry representative charged the State Department today with "deliberate, misleading distortion" of facts concerning a proposed visit to the United States by Russian seed experts.
Helen Keller, deaf and blind author, will receive a special award on Monday from President Eisenhower's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Any consideration of loans by the Export-Import Bank to Argentine interests will await the arrival in Buenos Aires late this month of Samuel C. Waugh, bank president.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Spain's Ambassador to France, the Count de Casa Rojas, rubbed salt into French wounds today by saying his country had continued to support Moroccan Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef after he was banished by the French two years ago.

The Government is aiming at standardization in the maritime industry. Through a series of basic ship designs it expects to enhance the competitive ability of the merchant marine, Clarence G. Morse asserted last night.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Joseph Sloan of Woodbury, N. J., broke the Cedar Parkway course record today in leading defending St. Joseph's College to victory in the Middle Atlantic States college cross-country championship. St. Joseph's also won the freshman championship.
ROME, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Italy announced today she would ban the export of thirty Itfiian-made Vampire Jet fighters ,ordered by Egypt.

THOUGH not as large as recent estimates indicated, the cranberry crop this year will be more than adequate for demand. Every Thanksgiving and Christmas table can include the traditional cranberry sauce or relish.

The Police Department said yesterday that allegations against Detective Eugene R. Kelley of the Commissioner's morals squad were "under investigation." The case involved the dismissal of Clark G. Kuebler, provost of the University of California Santa Barbara College, in a morals case.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Sale of the assets of Henry Disston Sons to H. K. Porter Company, Pittsburgh, was blocked at least temporarily today.
ALEXANDRIA, La., Nov. 11 -- The hottest idea blowing across the farm areas today is that of a "national soil fertility bank."
CHAUSSON'S seldom played Concerto for solo violin, piano and string quartet was merely one of three concertos presented last night by the violinist, Joan Field, in Town Hall.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Ellwood R. Quesada, retired, said today that one of the reasons he resigned as one of the principal officers of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation was the company's reluctance to give scientific personnel, rather than aeronautical engineers, a big enough hand in the development of "the weapons of tomorrow."

Dr. Theodore R. M. Howard, a Negro physician and crusader for equal rights in his home state of Mississippi, said here yesterday that the United States had no right to go to Geneva and propose free elections in Germany as long as there were no such elections in Mississippi.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- A French informant reported tonight that France intended to resume delivery of jet fighter planes and other arms to Egypt on longstanding orders. The French are selling arms, including jet fighters, to Israel.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 11 -- A united West went to bat for its mining industry this week. It put economics above politics and drafted a program of taxes, tariffs, research and public information aimed at putting mining on its feet and keeping it there.

Your coverage of the Arab-Israeli dispute, cold or hot, has been excellent all along. The same is true of the editorial comments and special articles which have appeared in The Times since the Middle East situation was aggravated by the Soviet-sponsored sale of Czech arms to Egypt.
German visitors to the United States may not be sold on the way American husbands share the kitchen, but they can see some real advantages in the way American parents raise children.
The Board of Estimate was urged yesterday to withhold approval of a proposed 1956 capital budget allocation of $58,018,864 for additional modernization of the subway power plants.

Carmelo Costa, Brooklyn lightweight, gained the decision over Joey Lopes of Sacramento, Calif., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The award was unanimous and met with the approval of the small crowd.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Eisenhower came back to Washington and a heartwarming welcome today.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York needs a revolving fund of at least $5,000,000 "to help meet the moral, spiritual and cultural needs growing out of our changing community," its director said last night.

The lightning coup that we saw in Brazil yesterday was an extraordinary -- and in one sense an admirable -- example of the workings of Brazilian politics. It was praiseworthy because its intention was to enforce a democratic electoral decision and to uphold the Constitution.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The University of Detroit, climbing over the .500 mark for the first time this season, defeated Villanova, 6 -- 0, tonight on a 22-yard touchdown pass play from Quarterback Jim Lobkovich to Half back Billy Russell early in the third quarter.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Nov. 11 -- For years it has been traditional for Lawrenceville to wash an old red shirt thoroughly whenever its football team is beaten by The Hill School. Today, Hill defeated the Big Red, but no one can deny that only a light rinse is in order.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 11 -- Employes of the new Kingston Steam Plant, described by the Tennessee Valley Authority as the world's largest, are arranging to celebrate its completion.
" The Minotaur," a play by Robert Thom, 25-year-old playwright, has caught the fancy of Maude Franchot and Dione Lewis, who plan to produce it on Broadway next September.

A new German Army will be born today when its first contingent is sworn in at a special ceremony in Bonn. This first contingent comprises only 100 men, but its personnel ranges from noncommissioned officers to generals, and it will constitute the organizational cadre for an army of 800,000 men that will form part of the defense forces of the North Atlantic alliance.
New York State is withholding drivers' licenses from 150 epileptics pending a study by three experts in nervous and mental diseases.
A modest midtown building was dedicated yesterday by the National Conference of Christians and Jews to a continuing fight against prejudices and ill will among men.
Dr. Paul Dudley White has stated this week that with President Eisenhower's departure from the hospital, "It's almost like discharging him now * * * from active medical and nursing care."

RAMSEY, N. J., Nov. 11 -- James Tirone, publisher of a weekly newspaper, The Picture Press, announced today that he had filed suit against a rival publisher and the Ramsey postmaster. He charged that they had attempted to suppress his newspaper because in the recent election he had supported independents in opposition to the Republican organization candidates.
GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- The United States offered today to try to extend to all its overseas bases the Eisenhower plan for reciprocal aerial reconnaissance if the Soviet Union accepted the plan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- President Eisenhower will owe the Army about $50 for his forty-seven days in the Fitzsimons General Hospital at Denver.
The 1956 Mercury car prices were lut through the wringer of competition yesterday and shrank an average of $900 eael
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- An official source said today that the Government would discontinue in 1956 its purchases of aluminum for stockpiling purposes.

Scores of police clerks and civilian employes of the Police Department resented being called to work yesterday. Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy had canceled the Veterans Day holiday late Thursday afternoon.
Enduring peace was the hope, but armed might was the reality, as the nation paused yesterday to honor the fighting men, living and dead, of all its wars.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- The Chamber of Deputies ratified today by a vote of 284 to 181 an agreement on the legal rights of United States forces in Italy. The Right joined with the Center to ratify the agreement, against the opposition of the extreme Left, by the largest majority that the present Government has yet had.
GENEVA, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Major parts of the addresses at the Big Four conference today by Secretary of State Dulles and Foreign Minister Molotov follow:

The Storm Trysail Club held its fall dinner meeting at the City Island Yacht Club last night. Prizes were presented for the club's annual Memorial Bay Block Island Race, which started the Long Island Sound distance racing season, and for the biennial Mount Desert race in July. Everett B. Morris, race committee chairman, was toastmaster.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A nun and another woman, convicted by a Dutch court of preventing a 14-year-old Jewish girl from joining her legal guardians, have been arrested in Brussels, the Dutch Foreign Ministry announced today.
BELGRADE, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A Yugoslav Government spokesman said today the attitude of Yugoslavia toward Eastern European countries was unchanged.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 11 -When it meets, Cornell tomorrow, Dartmouth's football team will be enjoying its best health in three weeks. The Green has been plagued by minor injuries to key players. All except one have responded to treatment in time to play host to the Big Red.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The rally in British Government securities gained momentum today. The rest of the stock market also looked steadier. Gilt-edge stocks were helped by October export figures, highest in any month on record, and gained as much as 1 7s 6d ($3.85).

SPACE, time and energy, three important factors in the lives of today's homemakers, are being given more and more consideration by appliance manufacturers. Evidence of this can be found in the number of new, small electrical devices designed specifically to save all three in the preparation of food.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- David Chase, a 9-year-old boy from Arlington, Va., with a white feather in his crease-crown hat, looked glum after the President's car had passed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The State Department said today that it was pushing both short and long-range plans for peace between Israel and Egypt.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- To avoid a French-German crisis over the Saar will be the principal purpose of the visit Sunday of Antoine Pinay; French Foreign Minister, to Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Two persons were found dead today in a small cabin cruiser that was smashed against rocks and partly submerged in Long Island Sound.
In a pleasant brick school-house in Queens yesterday a group of youngsters experienced victories and defeats as do school children anywhere. And that in itself was unusual.
AMPLE curves were the fashion in the days when Lillian Russell, who was no size 10, had her riding habits expertly draped by a young tailor named Harry Roaman.

General Public Utilities Corporation is continuing to "investigate the feasibility of installing an atomic power plant in the Philippines in the not distant future," according to A. F. Tegen, president.

Henry Payson, real estate investor, has contracted to purchase the twelve-story apartment house on plot 63 by 102 feet at 68 East Eighty-sixth Street. Assessed at $300,000, the property is being sold for cash above mortgages of $250,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Progress in the reconstruction of the missing link between fish ancestors and early forms of land animals was reported here today at the closing sessions of the annual autumn meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- Direct negotiations between Bonn and Moscow on the problem of German reunification are "entirely possible," Valerian A. Zorin, acting foreign minister and the first Soviet Ambassador to West Germany, said tonight.

Vyacheslav M. Molotov, like other Foreign Ministers, does a good deal of traveling and no doubt has learned, as all travelers do, what it is essential to take along and what it is essential to leave at home. When he said last week that he had gone back to Moscow from Geneva with "good baggage" and that he was returning "with even better baggage" he must have known what he was talking about.

The new International Airport now under construction at Bogota, Colombia, the aerial gateway to South America, is being planned to handle the new jet transports such as the Douglas DC-8 and the Boeing 707.
KENILWORTH, N. J., Nov. 12 -- This Union County community, named after a famous English barony, will roll out the red carpet Tuesday for Lord and Lady Kenilworth.

RODENTS have run away with the literary popularity contest for the very young, with the rabbits way out ahead, of course, but there are plenty of mouse tales, too. Adult prejudices notwithstanding, the mice in these four books are all well behaved, but not all uniformly successful.

FOUR years ago the English couple Iona and Peter Opie produced "The Oxford Dictionary of Nursery Rhymes," an excellent work, the most scholarly book of nursery rhymes in print. Now that cow has calved, and here is the "Oxford Nursery Rhyme Book," which gives the rhymes and leaves out the scholarly ap- paratus.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A House Government Operations subcommittee this week sailed head-on into one of the major continuing controversies of the capital, the long-standing argument between the Government and the press over how much official information the public has a right to receive.
The Port of New York Authority has awarded a $594,000 contract to a Long Island concern for the construction of a fourth air cargo building at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

WHEN Hestor's father drilled a well on his farm he pierced the roof of the gnomes' underground river. The little men were terribly upset -- and they decided that a journey to the upper world was necessary to set things right.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- When Adlai E. Stevenson announces here next Tuesday that he is ready, willing and able to be a Presidential candidate in 1956, the wraps will come off a carefully fashioned political headquarters.

THE Metropolitan Opera opens its season tomorrow night with the endorsement of the people who count -- its subscribers. The advance subscription sale has exceeded last year's by $15,439. There is $1,551,501 in the till before the first curtain has gone up, accounting for 70 per cent of capacity.

OTTAWA -- Now that the brilliant mosaic of fall's colorful foliage has gone with the winds, and the first snow flurries are here to remind one of things to come, preparations for the winter tourist season is in full swing.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Senhor Luz had continued President Cafe's Cabinet in office when he took over the Presidency, but Senhor Ramos began a complete reorganization of the Government today.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Memories of depression are haunting the coal fields of New South Wales as unemployment follows oil's challenge to coal as fuel in Australia.
The fiftieth anniversary celebration of the Fordham University School of Law will continue Thursday night with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Gertrude Samuels' article "Puerto Rico: Land of Paradox" (Oct. 30) has rendered a genuine service to our residents and to all who are involved in programs for community betterment.
The induction next week of Dr. Hollis L. Caswell as the fifth president of Teachers College, Columbia University, will be marked by a series of discussions on major problems of education.

THE coming of winter creeps into the consciousness by means of numerous symbols: golden maples, unexpected mothballs in the coat pocket, sinister clankings in the radiator, and the arrival of foreign lecturers. To the Englishman living in America, autumn is a predominantly melancholy season, for it is the time where he must explain American football to visiting compatriots.

IT took courage to fight racial prejudice in 1833. In that year Prudence Crandall, young Quaker teacher, opened her school to "young Ladies and little Misses of color" -- and roused her town of Canterbury, Conn., to unreasoning fury.
BUENOS AIRES, Sunday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Political observers here said today General Lonardi had a chance of surviving the crisis and warned not to count him out too early.

THE world of jazz is a relatively small one, highly personalized and deeply contentious. It is a world, not easily understood, whose mores have inspired some remarkably silly fiction, an unreasonable amount of inaccurate documentation and an aura compounded of varying parts of romance and sordidness.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The business trend in Chicago seems to be headed for stabilization, the monthly report of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago showed. Volume of business continued high in October, while percentages of profits underwent only slight changes.

FRANK JUPO has retold an old German folktale and illustrated it with simple drawings which seem based on medieval woodcuts. It is about a village of clever people who think it wiser to turn fools, and who find out their mistake.

PANELING the walls of the basement or the extra unfinished room in the attic is a project well within the realm of the home handyman. On the market today is a variety of paneling that is easy to handle. Furthermore, the panelings come in numerous finishes so that the wall surface can have almost any desired appearance.

NICOLET, Que., Nov. 12 (UP) -- A rumbling landslide apparently caused by seeping water undermined at least five buildings, including a school and the Bishop's palace, today and sent them crashing into the Nicolet River.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 12 -- The British Minister of Education told a group of New England architects and educators this week how his country tried to keep "up with the times and with the children who belong to them."
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 12 -- Federal Housing Administration appraisers are starting a big job -- price-tagging an entire city.

Since their all-time peak in February, 1951, farm prices have dropped about 25 per cent. Farm income is 34 per cent below 1951. Both political parties are agreed that the farm situation will be a major campaign issue next year. There follows a statement of the basic problem, a short history of how each party has attacked it, and new approaches that are now under discussion.
The United States and Britain seemed last week to have settled upon a fresh approach to the Middle Eastern situation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Much has been written about President Eisenhower since his return to the White House, but the record tells us nothing about one of the most intriguing stories in the long history of that lovely mansion.
Peter White, in his article "The Interpreter: Linguist Plus Diplomat" (Nov. 6), has treated an extremely important and difficult subject with a humor and yet a depth which are most enlightening.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said tonight the United States must stand ready to "give Israel the opportunity of obtaining defensive arms" if Soviet-supplied weapons threaten to shift the balance of power in the Middle East.

GENEVA, Nov 12 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov of the Soviet Union has requested a private talk with Secretary of State Dulles, a United States spokesman said. Mr. Molotov will call on Mr. Dulles at 10 A. M. tomorrow.

IT IS startling to reflect how swiftly our national landscape has changed. The traveler through industrialized northern Indiana will see few traces of the swampy wilderness in which this story is set. Yet less than a century ago settlers were clearing the land and wild life was abundant.
Nathaniel B. Barclay has been appointed executive vice president of the Daystrom Furniture division of Daystrom, Inc., Elizabeth, N. J.

LOIS LENSKI continues her interpretation of the American scene in this tale of Chinese-Americans in San Francisco. When 10-year-old Felix Fong moved to the city with his family, he was homesick for the country and longed for friends left behind.

BIRTHDAYS are something you can't get away from, particularly if there are children in your life. How old? they ask about all living things. Leonard Kirkpatrick answers with some tricks for telling the age of various animals.
The twice-dashed hopes for unity among seafaring labor unions will get a third chance later this month.

Progress report on a one-time problem child: After much fussing and fuming, titanium has been disciplined technologically. Engineers have learned how to cope with its tricks and make it perform according to plan.

ONE after the other, heroes of the American past have been dusted off to live again in the comparatively new mediums of movies, radio, comic books and TV. It is perhaps significant that virtually all of the most popular are figures not of our major wars but of the guerrilla warfare with Indians and Bad Men.
How to keep ahead of the nation's expanding and changing grocery needs will be explored here next week by more than 1,500 top food and grocery industry leaders.

TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- Mayors of United States and Japanese cities on the Pacific Coasts decided this week on new moves to promote understanding and fraternity among the communities that share much of the trade between them.
I have twice commented on a news agency report quoting Adlai Stevenson as saying that the Eisenhower Administration was a "government of the rich, by the rich, and for the rich."
ROME, Nov. 12 -- A compromise budget of $6,600,000 for 1956 and $6,800,000 for 1957 was approved for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization tonight.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 12 -- The resignation of Chief Minister David Marshall was demanded yesterday by Opposition members of the Assembly.

AS Henry Adams himself relates, he never tired "of quoting the supreme phrase of his idol Gibbon, before the Gothic cathedrals: 'I darted a contemptuous look on the stately monuments of superstition.' -- Gibbon ignored the Virgin, because in 1789 religions monuments were out of fashion."
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Premier Edgar Faure won a technical victory in the National Assembly today but had only the faintest of hopes of realizing his plan to hold new elections next month.
IT might interest your correspondent, J. F. Kelly, to know that mercantile reporting firms in the nineteenth century did give out information regarding the financial status of individuals.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 12 -- A special Virginia legislative commission recommended today a two-part proposal to avoid enforced racial integration of the state's public schools.

IN one respect, at least, this book differs from the recent run of the presses on Mormons and Mormonism. As the title says it was papa, not mama who married the Mormon, and so, refreshingly absent are the trials and tribulations, joys and woes of life in a polygamous household.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 11 -- Foreign Minister Phouy Sananikone has charged Ho Chi Minh's North Vietnam Government broke the promise it gave at the Asian-African Conference not to interfere in the internal affairs of Laos.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 12 (UP) -- Halfback Jim Swink scored four touchdowns and rolled up a total of 235 yards on the ground today to lead seventh-ranked Texas Christian University to a 47-20 victory over Texas.

If distinction in a plant is measured by varied, sometimes opposing descriptions, and by different opinions concerning its use and value, then considerable distinction belongs to the elderberry. Botanically sambucus, its very name has been in dispute among botanists for generations.

MONTAUK, L. I., Nov. 12 -- Members of the Montauk Boatmen's Association, who have been attempting to police their own ranks to provide safe party-boat fishing off Montauk Point, have just received added impetus in the effort.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Britain is ready to give blanket support for the entry into the United Nations of eighteen countries whose applications are outstanding.

BOOKS like this which an entire family can enjoy are a boon to the budget and to the reader-aloud. This is an original counting book with a nonsensical rhyme and gay full-page picture for every number from one to 20.
RARITAN, N. J., Nov. 12 -- Forty more parking tickets blossomed last night on automobiles in this borough, where the voters last Tuesday denied policemen a pay rise.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Mr. Khrushchev, in one of his jolliest moods, wisecracked, sang and drank fiery Norwegian aquavit today at the reception.
TORONTO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Capt. Kevin Barry of Ireland rode to victory in the international team puissance at the Royal Winter Fair horse show tonight with two faultless performances.
Eighty-eight arrested narcotics addicts and peddlers were arraigned yesterday in various magistrate's courts. They were seized in the largest round-up ever made by the police narcotics squad.

HOMESTEADING in the Texas Panhandle in the Eigheeen Thirties was no lark. The sod house, the dearth of water, the scarcity of neighbors and playmates, the lack of comforts one had back at Grandma's -- all this made Lutie Rollins homesick for Missouri.

HARTFORD, Nov. 12 -- Mayor Richard C. Lee of New Haven, who was re-elected to a second term this week by the largest majority any candidate for Mayor in any city in Connecticut ever received, has become a possibility for an eventual Democratic nomination for United States Senator.
A "smoke screen" to protect outlying areas from fires of an atomic explosion will be among the devices exhibited beginning tomorrow by the Army Chemical Corps.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UP) -- J. Russell Ives of the American Meat Institute said today that an 11 per cent increase in Federal-inspected hog slaughter was expected in the marketing year 1955-56.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- A world-wide appeal to oil-rich countries for free kerosene for destitute Arab refugees was proposed this week by a United Nations committee. The refugees depend on kerosene for heat, light and cooking fuel.

IN THIS amusing, fast-paced story of a boy's trek to the Colorado gold fields, Joel and his Uncle Luke join their covered wagon to a long procession headed for "Pike's Peak or Bust!" On the trail they meet disappointed prospectors creeping home, with "Busted!" for their new and bitter slogan.

FROM our first meeting with tomboy Louy and her family, this highly readable narrative moves swiftly on -- to her friendship with Emerson and Thoreau, her struggle for financial security and her ordeal as a nurse in the Civil War.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- The naming of John P. Smoots of Shaker Heights, Ohio, as national chairman of the Cornell Parents Committee was announced this week. Mr. Smoots is an executive of the Sohio Petroleum Company, Cleveland. a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio.
Arnold Duckstein of Austria shared first place with Vassily Smyslov of Russia after yesterday's tenth-round matches in the international chess tournament in Zagreb, according to Yugoslav reports.

AT THE very top of Hickory Hill, a very long hill, nestled the shiny new house with NOTHING inside. First the blue family car huffed and puffed up the hill, then trucks, the mailman (just to say "Hello"), and at last the great big truck everyone really was waiting for.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Proposed creation of a comprehensive milk marketing order for northern New Jersey and the New York metropolitan area will be among agricultural problems considered at the fortieth meeting of the State Farm Bureau starting here Monday.
FOR the first time in almost twenty years, the Soviet Union opened its doors to tourists this year. An American dentist from Chicago was even allowed to drive his jeep from Helsinki to Moscow.

IN 1905, George Santayana wrote a letter to his colleague in the Department of Philosophy at Harvard, William James, in which, replying with some heat to James' recent criticisms of "The Life of Reason," he broke out:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A top official said today the United States would propose that the United Nations General Assembly conduct a study to define "the whole question of self-determination."

COLOR motion pictures of living micro - organisms photographed in their normal environment in water were shown to a lay audience last week for the first time by Dr. Roman Vishniac, a leading specialist in his field.

PETER, like most younger brothers, gets a little tired of always having his ideas called silly by his brother. One winter night, with a burst of ingenuity, Peter contrives to make a small snowman disappear, then shares his secret only with his mother.
