PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Deep in the jungle of French politics, two oddly assorted safaris, both hunting the same rare trophy -- the head of former Premier Pierre Mendes-France -- met and merged this week in an embarrassed silence.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Illinois, led by its newly found halfback star, Bob Mitchell, pushed Wisconsin around for nearly three quarters today, then hung on grimly to eke out a 17-14 Big Ten football victory.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 12 -- Royce Flippin wound up his remarkable saga of success against Yale today with a repetition of his story-book comeback from the casualty list of a year ago.

ROBERT ALDRICH, who transposed "The Big Knife," Clifford Odets' current critical examination of Hollywood's moviemakers and their mores to the screen, is ready to tackle an even more imposing subject. Last week, the independent producer-director revealed that his company, Associates and Aldrich, had acquired "Candidate for President," an original story by Don Weis, which is being whipped into screen-play form by Ted Sherman.

IN a meeting room of City Hall, at a table facing a great crowd of men and women who look troubled and tense, sits a regal lady, calm and poised in a simple cotton dress covered by a white lace coat. In her grey hair, braided high, are twined some blue flowers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A Senate investigating subcommittee will start a three-week search Monday for violations of personal privileges granted under the Bill of Rights.

SEQUELS are usually tricky affairs and readers who found Mary Norton's "The Borrowers" just about perfect may approach this one with the nervous premonition that it couldn't possibly be as good. It is, though -- and in some ways even better.

WITH this short novel covering the retreat of German troops from the East in 1943, to the days of surrender in 1945, Heinrich Boll, the young writer from Cologne, should find the American audience he deserves.

ALTHOUGH there may be comparatively few remaining days of Indian summer, there is still time to get tender plants into the coldframe for the winter. What will go into the frame depends on the gardener's geographical location and, of course, on his particular interests.

The biggest mortgage broker in the nation isn't placing any more loans on new Grand Central area skyscrapers for awhile. Instead, George W. Warnecke is concentrating on obtaining financing for luxury apartment houses which are springing up in midtown Manhattan.
IN this latest of Peter Buckley's stunning photographic Around the World books, armchair travelers discover Evolene, an isolated valley in Switzerland, the home of Michel Gaspoz, a real boy of today.

A FEW years ago, Laurens van der Post wrote a distinguished book called "Venture to the Interior." It had to do with his memories of a South African childhood and with an unknown mountain he climbed during a raging storm while on a mission for the British Government.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- The forthcoming sale of Ford Motor Company stock not only marks the end of an industrial monarchy but also signals a new era of furious competition among the big three of the auto industry. The future of the smaller independents is less certain but they, too, are hopeful of carving for themselves bigger shares of the 1956 auto market.

Miss Marble tried to prove that women drivers are better than men. To prove this she cites an annual report of the California Highway Patrol, which states that while 33.5 per cent of California operators' licenses are issued to women, they are involved in only 16.25 per cent of California accidents.

THE plot of this attractive picture story for very young children is based on a child's asking and her brother's answering: When is tomorrow? The dialogue between Linda and Pete outlines daily adventures on vacation at Squirrel Island.

VIENNA, Nov. 12 -- Austria's Foreign Minister, Leopold Figi, announced this week that his country would shortly discuss with her neighbor Hungary removal of the minefields and barbwire which delineate Hungary's frontiers. The question whether Hungary could afford to do this raises the problem of the extent to which the East bloc of satellite regimes govern by consent of their peoples.

ONCE more Marguerite Henry and Wesley Dennis have teamed up to produce a picture and information book about a favorite animal, following the method used in their. "Album of Horses." Each of these twenty-seven brief chapters is devoted to one breed of dog and is accompanied by a full-page full color portrait.

TOKYO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Japan's two conservative parties, planning a merger Tuesday despite a threatened minority walkout, have reached tentative agreement on top Soviet and Philippine foreign policy issues.

BASED on a fragment of legend related by Marco Polo, this is a thought-provoking tale of the Three Wise Men of the East. In this version Balthasar, Melchior and Jaspar (best-known as Caspar) are portrayed as the Kings of Saba.

THE growth of the do-it-yourself movement is due in part to the increased leisure resulting from shorter work hours, the migration to the suburbs, where most householders have no janitor to depend on, and the higher cost of skilled labor. But certainly a greater contribution to the movement was the prompt initiative of power tool manufacturers in supplying the needs of amateur craftsmen.

AS if to demonstrate the precept that one should "never underestimate the power of a woman," Elisabeth Margo takes one of the most classically masculine events of all time, the California Gold Rush, and shows with tactful (for a female) zest how it was only a matter of a few years before the gals had this epochal turn of history under control, sociologically speaking.

Today's student traveler in Europe is spending more money, seeing more countries and learning more languages than the post-war student traveler in the late Nineteen Forties, according to a survey issued by the Council on Student Travel, 179 Broadway, New York City. The survey was conducted among 2,500 passengers returning from Europe on student ships sponsored by the council.

THIS novel is announced as the winner of a large prize offered jointly by its publishers and a prominent science-fantasy magazine. For the life of me, I can't think why. If ever a book was neither good science nor good fiction, this is it.

TO those who complain, so often, "Why don't my African violets bloom?" I often suggest "try dividing them," for more than one crown to a pot can mean few or no blossoms. And it also usually means a plant that is not attractively symmetrical.

BOOKS about animals are among the best ways to introduce a child to intelligent and disciplined scientific thinking for thus the observer can profit from the work of other observers before he starts out on his own. A first-class item on this fall's list is William E. Scheele's THE FIRST MAMMALS (World, $4.95), a handsome companion volume to his "Prehistoric Animals" published last year.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- When the curtain goes up on Adlai E. Stevenson's Presidential campaign Tuesday a not-so-reluctant Averell Harriman will be waiting in the wings.

HERE. on a windswept Judean hilltop called Al Mukabbir by the Arabs and The Mount of Evil Counsel by the Jews, stands the castlelike headquarters of the United Nations Palestine Truce Supervision Organization.

ZANZIBAR, Oct. 28 -- An airline flies into Zanzibar and automobiles travel its narrow, winding streets, but even the introduction of modern conveniences has not changed its Arabian Nights' atmosphere.

STARS, cars, stairs, bears, beds, heads, and other things that come in large quantities, make a nice excuse for a picture book for the very youngest. This one may be thinner and less enduring than some of Mr. Slobodkin's books, but it has liveliness, humor and charm.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 12 -- Behind the struggle for control in Brazil lurks the ghost of the late President Getulio Vargas.

THE 9-year-old has discovered spelling and made it his own. A teacher who teaches it -- and expects it to be learned -- has, apparently, made all the difference. As some boys collect odd bits of glass and colored rock, the 9-year-old now collects words.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Slums, the big blight of American cities, are well on their way out.

THE first man in history to burst past the seemingly impregnable barrier of the four-minute mile, Roger Bannister, the blond English footracer, has written an engrossing book which centers around his epic achievement of running the classic distance in 3:59.4.
RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 12 -- Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef today dismissed all the viziers appointed or confirmed to their posts by his predecessor, Mohammed ben Arafa.

SOUTHBORO, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Hugh Scott's two touchdowns paced Groton to a 20-0 victory over St. Mark's today in the sixty-sixth gridiron meeting of the schools since 1886.

THERE is no real reason for taking leave of the herb garden until the air and ground are so frozen that it is uncomfortable to work or even linger outdoors. For even in November there is still much verdure in the fragrant herb garden and the new growth of chervil, sweet cicely and woodruff calls to mind the tender greens of spring.

A PROFESSIONAL carpenter, bricklayer, plumber or even a picture hanger uses his tools efficiently and has learned the tricks in handling the materials of his trade. That this took time any professional will admit. The new home owner, therefore, need not despair if he finds himself all thumbs when he tries to go about one of his new projects. The suggestions below tell how to work with special materials.

THIS is the story of the thirteenth cow -- the little cow that stood exactly in the middle of a long row of big cows in the long stable. She didn't give much milk but the farmer and his wife loved her anyhow and in spite of her habit of disappearing over the fields "toward some new loveliness that only she could find."
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Michigan's revived defense overwhelmed Indiana, 30 to 0, today to force a Big Ten Rose Bowl showdown with Ohio State next week.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- Dr. William E. Park will be the third member of his family to become president of a New England college when he is installed at Simmons Wednesday.

The Vice Admiral Jerry Land medal, one of five top awards of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, has been presented to Walter L. Green, president and chairman of the board of the American Bureau of Shipping.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- John Paluck and Joe Walton, a pair of ends playing like savages on the defense, led Pittsburgh today to a 26-7 upset victory over previously unbeaten and untied West Virginia.

THE reviewer of Edmund Wilson's "The Scrolls From the Dead Sea," Frank M. Cross Jr. and some of your correspondents seek to infer that history and dogma are separate compartments in Christianity and that, therefore the Dead Sea Scrolls are only important to the professional historian. How nice, if it were only true.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 11 -- Gen. Sarit Thanarat, Commander in Chief of the Army, has called for an Army and Air Force "three times the present strength and a Navy four times as strong." He said this was necessary because he believed "Thailand is being subverted more and more by our enemy."
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 12 -- The tabulation of Suffolk County's vote on ten amendments and one proposition in last week's election was completed today.

ONE morning, not long ago, Herbert von Karajan was taking the Philharmonia Orchestra of London through a rehearsal in Carnegie Hall. A slim, sweater-clad figure, he was lounging in a chair planted on the podium, his baton moving scarcely more than a few inches.

DOKI is the papoose baby brother of Flora McFlimsay's friend, Little Laughing Water. One pleasant day, when Doki has been left in the care of his dog and the older children, Laughing Water unties Doki from his cradle-boards so he can play.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Nov. 12 (UP) -- Virginia Military Institute, upset The Citadel, 14 -- 7, today, with the fledglin officers throwing fists as well as footballs at the finish.

THE cliff-hanging stories that lured small boys and girls to movie houses every Saturday afternoon some thirty years ago have a distinguished successor in the tale of Ethelbert, a swimming tiger that manages to escape the charge of a hippo, the jaws of crocodiles, the perils of the Arctic (except for chilblains) and the nets of a "very secret" scientific expedition.

THE fall catalogue of Sears, Roebuck and Co. has reached overseas and scored a smash hit. The United States Information Agency reports that it has thus far sent 3,500 copies of the mail-order catalogue to its outposts in foreign lands.

PHRENOLOGY today is generally grouped with astrology and palmistry as the domain of the ill-trained "professor" who pursues easy money by playing on the credulity of the ignorant. Little more than a century ago the implications of the word were vastly different.

Election Day and Armistice Day promotions combined to give New York and Brooklyn department stores a sizable increase in sales volume last week, compensating for a 10 per cent drop in volume in the preceding week.

One day recently in a public school room in crowded East Harlem, twenty-two youngsters lined up to become Girl Scouts. Eleven were accepted. The disappointed ones may have to wait months or years before they may join.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- West Germany's Army was born today in a Bonn garage. The first 101 members of the armed forces received their certificates of appointment from Defense Minister Theodor Blank in a ceremony that seemed almost studied in its informality.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- The State Citizens Committee for the Public Schools today urged local communities "continuously to re-examine the philosophy and objectives" of their school systems.

NEWARK, Nov. 12 -- A Broad Street blockfront is scheduled to be razed next summer and in its place will rise a twenty-four-story tower building that will serve as the new home offices of the Prudential Insurance Company.

THE commentator is today's tragic figure of broadcasting. His voice has been all but stilled by the coming of television -- little wanted on the home screen and little heard on the remnants of network radio.

Alan (The Horse) Ameche, the National Football League's top ground gainer, will lead the Baltimore Colts against the New York Giants this afternoon. A crowd of 35,000 is expected for the Polo Grounds encounter.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 12 -- Before the largest football crowd ever to see a football game at Archbold Stadium, Syracuse turned back Colgate, 26 -- 19, today.

CLEMSON, S. C., Nov. 12 -- Maryland survived its darkest hour of the football season today by coming from 12 points behind to throttle a keyed-up Clemson team, 25 -- 12, and all but wrap up an Orange Bowl berth against Oklahoma.

As the seasons come and go on Mars vast red areas turn to green, white caps alternately melt and grow at the poles, lines appear that run from the polar caps to areas turning green. The Italian astronomer, Schiaparelli, called the lines "canali," which was too literally translated into "canals." "Channels" would have been a better English equivalent.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 12 -- Pakistan's plan to eliminate "retrogressive" provincialism by merging the semi - autonomous small governments into a single administrative unit with a population of 36,000,000 appeared today to have survived its critics' forecast of immediate failure.
Apparel market activity centers on opening of ready-to-wear collections for spring and late ordering for holiday selling, resident buying offices reported yesterday.

THIS book is of a long agreeable shape, spreading wide enough to accommodate the branches that hold Jimmy Domino's tree house. Jimmy lives there alone, and passersby address him from the ground beneath: a Scotty dog, a wandering singer, a motherly cook.

OFTEN, when I am surrounded by difficult children, I think of Shakespeare's lines, "Peace, children, peace! The king doth love you well." And invariably I visualize the king, anachronistically no doubt, tossing the children a book and the children, unrealistically no doubt, settling quietly down in contentment around the magic pages.

CHICAGO, Nov 12 (AP) -- Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, said today that in event of nuclear attack residents in most cities would have only this choice: "Stay and die, or move out and survive."

I CAN'T recall when a new mystery writer has risen so rapidly and effortlessly to the very top ranks as has Charlotte Jay. Her first novel, "Beat Not the Bones," received the Mystery Writers of America's award, not for "best first." but for "best novel" of 1953.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- An inquest jury found today that Anton Schuessler, whose two boys were murdered less than a month ago, died yesterday from natural causes during shock therapy in a sanitarium.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Somewhat to its own surprise, the Voice of America finds itself playing Pied Piper to the jazz devotees of the world.

For most of its two-year existence the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has been occupied with labor troubles stemming from its battle against the corrupt International Longeshoremen's Association. But for the past two weeks, the commission has been in the thick of an openly political conflict. This is how the conflict came about:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- An Assistant Attorney General clashed with two Democratic Senators today over the propriety of his decision against investigating possible tampering with a witness in the Dixon-Yates power case.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Nineteen whaling fleets from half a dozen countries are getting ready for the new Antarctic summer catching season. It promises to be one of the shortest and most competitive in whale oil history.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 12 -- Halfback Jim Morse gambled on a fourth-down pass with the score tied today and cracked open a taut and tenacious North Carolina team so Notre Dame could roll to a 27 to 7 victory before 38,000 fans.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 12 -- Clergymen in the eleven Western states, Alaska and Hawaii spend more than one-fourth of their working hours dealing with emotional problems of churchgoers. The clerics say they want to work more closely with psychiatrists in meeting community mental health needs.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Nov. 12 -- This industrial city of 22,000 is practically split in two on the issue of whether to change the zoning laws to permit the Dragon Cement Company of New York to construct a $10,000,000 cement plant here.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party chief, disclosed tonight the Soviet Union had developed a twin-jet medium bomber with a range of about 3,100 miles.

WRITERS are wont to complain that too few respect their craft, but television writers -- and those who would be -- are hard-pressed these days to make a strong case. In Hollywood TV circles at least, the writers are being curried, cultivated and compensated, with emphasis in that order, as never before.

THE full and essential quality of Degas' ruthless visual genius must be felt in his sculpture, those electric bronzes of ballet dancers and racehorses, made mostly to please and instruct himself and not cast until after his death.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- A widely read Geneva editor wrote today that if the Soviet Union understood the "spirit of Geneva" to mean the heads-I-win, tails-you-lose position of its Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, here, it would be well to find a new name.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- More than 1,000,000 California workers, representing 80 per cent of those working under union contract in the state, were covered by employer-financed health and welfare plans by the end of 1954.
BISBEE, Ariz., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Freak atmospheric conditions on a 3,000-mile scale today had police radio operators in Arizona and East Coast cities talking to each other.

The election was taken in stride by the business community, and the returns in themselves are not considered likely to create any difficulties in the near-term outlook. The slight edge gained by the Democrats, however, will probably set the scene for policy changes in the farm area. This could bring a change in farm income which would be felt before the big election next year.
OTTAWA, Nov. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The Federal Government has decided against financial aid at this time to bolster Canada's deepsea shipping fleet.

IN spite of the matchless loveliness of their mountains, the Swiss are not regarded as a romantic race. Generally they are credited with solider virtues -- endurance, ingenuity, thrift, courage. But Alyse, "a brown little thing * * * brown hair and brown eyes and two brown beauty spots right on my cheek," was incurably romantic.
ROME, Nov. 10 -- The Italian Communist party, though still the most powerful this side of the Iron Curtain, is in a severe crisis.

THESE lilting tales introduce some refreshing and friendly creatures. Rabbit is a faithful comrade who risks his own safety for the sake of stupid Mole. Cow helps an unconventional leprechaun to get on with his art work.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Five men have been selected as the first to be honored by the National Cowboy Hall of Fame. The site of the hall was dedicated at Oklahoma City yesterday.

ALTHOUGH this second novel by the author of "Templeford Park" is set in Sussex, Bruges, and Paris, its ambience is still that of London. This is the story of Emily Satersham, whom we meet at 20 -- a child of parents who have lived apart for years in one of those separations that used to occur so frequently in Edwardian novels where the English did not marry the- English.

IN a small college town the gulf between those who "belong" because they go to the college and those on the outside because they do not, is wide and definite and not to be crossed. Or so Rosemary thought.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Planning for welfare and medical services must go beyond city limits and encompass "metropolitan areas," Samuel Goldsmith, executive director of the Jewish Federation of Chicago, declared here tonight.

Two men whose company has been busy for a long time making the products that hold up a good many American trousers set about counting up the other day how many suspenders and belts their concern has made. When they got to 200,000,000 they gave up.

APRIL 5, 1956, will mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the founder of Tuskegee Institute in Alabama. Even before he died in 1915, however, the autobiography of the founder, Booker T. Washington. "Up From Slavery," had become a classic, in many ways the most notable of all American success stories.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Army unlimbered its guns for the big game with Navy here two weeks hence by routing overmatched Pennsylvania, 40 -- 0, today. It was the seventeenth straight defeat for the Red and Blue.

The boys' clothing and furnishings field will have an excellent year in 1955 and the outlook for spring and summer volume for next year is even better, according to Ele Schneider, merchandise manager of the boys' wear division for Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

LIVING Shakespeare is now almost wholly lost to the average American citizen. In high schools it is very rare for the student to read anything more than "Hamlet," "Macbeth," or occasionally "Julius Caesar," and from these he thankfully shakes himself free the moment the examinations are over.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The White House "road company," just back from three months in Denver, moves on to Gettysburg, Pa, Monday for a protracted engagement.

PAPA FEATHER'S swapping one day produced an enormous old trailer, so, naturally, the delighted family rollicked away from their one small town to travel and odd-job and play wherever at all they liked.

HAVANA, Nov. 10 -- The number of Cubans emigrating to the United States is rising steadily. From 1946 to 1953 an average of 3,000 left the island yearly for United States. In 1954 8,000 emigrated and in 1955 it is estimated the total will reach 14,000.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- West German officials in Geneva expressed the hope today that the failure of the Foreign Ministers' Conference to agree on German reunification would provide the necessary impetus to West Germany's stalled armament program.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov 12 -- A capacity homecoming crowd watched Amherst defeat Williams, 13 to 6, today on fourth-period pass play.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The agriculture committee of the National Planning Association outlined today a multi-sided program to bolster farm prices and limit surpluses.

GENEVA, N. Y. Nov. 12 -- Undefeated Alfred University humbled Hobart College today, 6 -- 0, in a game that had two endings. The first one was brought about when hundreds of spectators tore down goal posts and swarmed over the field, convinced that the game was over.
A relatively small food chain is attracting much notice in the huge supermarket field.

IN the ninth century while the Danes were raiding England, a stranger, speaking with a slight Danish inflection, appeared at the smithy of an English village. A supernaturally endowed battle axe called Bretwalda had just been forged and at first the villagers feared that the stranger, Wilton, meant to steal it.
There are thirty-five shopping days left before Christmas.

Actors Studio, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the professional advancement of the arts of the theatre, will benefit from the Dec. 12 premiere of the VistaVision film "The Rose Tattoo" at the Astor Theatre. The Hal Wallis production stars Anna Magnani and Burt Lancaster.

Neurologists assembled last week in Boston at the sixth annual convention of United Cerebral Palsy. Of the papers read, that of Dr. Betty Ben Geren, a young research associate on the faculty of Harvard's Medical School, seemed of especial importance to this commentator.

William L. Taub, New York theatrical managers said yesterday, according to The Associated Press, that he had not represented Josephine Baker, night club performer, since June, 1952. An Associated Press dispatch from Quebec Friday said he had represented her since 1952.

AESOP came before La Fontaine and long before Aesop many of the tales associated with his name were circulating among the Hindus. Joseph Gaer, author of "The Adventures of Rama" and other books, here presents some of those stories which were committed to writing in ancient India.
A committee headed by Mrs. Clifford D. Mallory Jr. and Miss Augusta de Peyster has taken over the Dec. 1 performance of "The Vamp," starring Carol Channing at the Winter Garden.

THIRTY years ago last April, John Singer Sargent died in his studio in Tite Street, London. A whole generation has thus grown to manhood and another world war has separated us from the Edwardian era in which the painter and his patrons shone and glittered in the sunset of nineteenth century complacency.

When homes were underheated, serving hot pudding on a cold day used to be eminently practical. Now the physical need for such a warming dish seems to have passed. But a dessert straight from the oven or stove top remains pleasurable in brisk weather simply because it comes as a change; it breaks the pattern of ice cream, fruit, cake and all the other confections usually served at room temperature or lower.

Research on fluctuations in the abundance and distribution of ocean fish will get under way off the eastern seaboard soon.

CORTINA d'AMPEZZO, a picturesque village in Italy's Dolomite mountain range. is preparing for the biggest crowd of visitors in its history. plus the expert skiers and skaters from more than thirty countries. who are expected there for the winter Olympic games, Jan. 26 to Feb. 5.

Christmas club owners in the mutual savings banks of the nation will receive a record $197,311,345 within the next few weeks, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported last week.

WHEN Miss Pati Hill, an American model in Paris' haute couture, abruptly and for reasons unexplained went off to live by herself in a crumbling, beat-up cottage on an abandoned property in the Departement of the Yonne, perhaps sixty miles southeast of Paris, she hacked off her hair close to the scalp.

THIS second book by Mary Elwyn Patchett about her childhood on an Australian cattle station is as good as her first, which is praise indeed. Ajax, the golden dog upon whom the first book centered, is very much present in this story, though this time Tam, short for Tamburlaine, is the focus of much of the action.

LIKE the massive, groaning gate of a medieval castle, the Soviet Iron Curtain is slowly starting to lift. How high it will go is problematical, but there are faint, cautious signs of motion. More may be forthcoming to give the West hope.

BY way of conditioning motorists for Safe Driving Day, Dec. 1, the President's Committee for Traffic Safety is emphasizing driving tips in a nation-wide campaign. None of the tips is new but all are valid, especially if the goal of Safe Driving Day -- a twenty-four-hour period free of traffic deaths -- is to be achieved.

THE public will be given opportunity this week to see in New York approximately two million dollars' worth of stamps and autographed die proofs of stamps. Under the auspices of the Officers Wives Club-New York Area, a fete known as the Roaring Twenties Carnival will be held Friday night at the Commissioned Officers Mess, New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

FOR beginning readers and pre-school lookers preoccupied with the why and how, Grace Skaar's new picture book tells the story of building a house and making a home in the country. FOR theatre-lovers everywhere in this country and for Helen Hayes' many friends in England and those she won last summer in Paris as Mrs. Antrobus in "The Skin of Our Teeth," there could not have been more heartwarming news last week than the announcement that on Nov. 21 the Fulton Theatre would be renamed the Helen Hayes.

Paul had just started learning the alphabet, but he knew every page of "Peter Rabbit" by heart.

Organization of the Judicial Conference of the State of New York has been completed.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 -- The provisional government of Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi cleared a high hurdle last Wednesday. Confronted with a threat from one of the possible leaders of a military junta, General Lonardi acted with grim determination to stifle immediately a movement that threatened to frustrate the democratic ambitions of the government that unseated Juan D. Peron last September.

THE journal is one of the oldest forms of nature writing, and the pattern of the year, spring to spring, is the journal's logical form. Any such nature journal is essentially personal, a kind of intimate visit with the author during which he reveals his inner self, not only the way his mind works but his sympathies and his emotions as well.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Netherlands Foreign Ministry said today it was misinformed when it announced yesterday that two persons had been arrested in Belgium in connection with the Anneke Beekman case.

HANOVER, N. H. Nov. 12 -- The Dartmouth Indians unexpectedly took another scalp at Memorial Field today. They beat Cornell, favored by 6 points, 7 -- 0, before 11,500 overjoyed fans, by scoring in 3:44 of the third period.

MR. ELLIOTT cocks an eye at a Malthusian future and comes up with a fascinating, if glum, prognosis. By the fortieth century, he theorizes in this richly detailed novel, a carefully stratified society will have evolved with but one goal: the gathering of food.

Closed-circuit television, which has been adapted to an increasing number of industrial uses, is appearing on the nation's college campuses as a partial solution to the growing shortage of personnel. Through the TV hook-up a professor can lecture to several classes at the same time.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 -- The American Veterans Committee asserted today that the American Legion spoke "only for a small, militant and articulate minority" rather than for the majority of its members and veterans generally.

THE unique American holiday for giving thanks lies ahead. Everywhere families, relatives and friends will be planning to gather around the table and share the harvest's abundance. Maybe a quail or pheasants felled by the hunter or a browned turkey stuffed with chestnuts will be spread on the board.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish planting and transplanting before frost gets into the ground. Bulbs, roses, shrubs and vines may still be set out. In the Southeast sow seed of turnips, beets, carrots, radishes, peas and salad greens. Also there and in southern California sow annual flowers for winter bloom.

ON Mr. Tresselt's populous farm the first heralders of morning are the birds. Then the rooster joins the chorus, followed by the chickens, ducks, hungry pigs, the goose, the turkey, the pigeons, the dog, the bees and the cows.

It was very pleasant passing the milkman, the huckster and the mailman, going through tunnels and over bridges until -- suddenly -- right in the center of town something went wrong and the trolley stopped.

THE news that Robert A. Heinlein has written a new juvenile TUNNEL IN THE SKY (Scribners, $2.50) should be welcomed by his thousands of fans, for this Stevenson of science fiction writes tales of adventure which are read as eagerly by adults as they are by teen-agers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- The late King Gustav V of Sweden threatened to abdicate in 1941 if his Cabinet refused to let a Nazi army division cross Sweden to Norway, a German wartime diplomatic dispatch published by the Swedish Foreign Ministry said today.

Columbia was no match for Navy yesterday at Baker Field, where the midshipmen gained nearly 600 yards while romping to a 47-0 victory over the Lions. If it had been a fight, rather than a football game, the referee would have intervened at the half, by which time Navy enjoyed a 26-0 spread.

WHEN he is most lucky, the poet sees things as if for the first time, in their original radiance or darkness; a child does this too, for he has no choice. THE top requirement for a peace officer in the brawling frontier towns of the Old West was a lightning-fast draw. Those who had it could expect to live a lot longer. "Western Sheriffs and Marshals" presents true tales of twenty well-known peace officers such as Pat Garrett, Wild Bill Hickok and Wyatt Earp.

SIMULTANEOUSLY with the first performances in this country of Sir William Walton's Troilus and Cressida, Angel has brought out a disk of excerpts from the opera, sung by Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, soprano, and Richard Lewis, tenor, with the composer conducting the Philharmonia Orchestra of London.

THIS year "Bartlett's Familiar Quotations'' is a hundred years old. Everyone knows the book; few know much of anything of the original author. As an act of piety, let us take a look at the man behind one of America's famous books.

The reasons why a stamp exhibition is a success is the overwhelming enthusiasm of stamp collectors as hobbyists plus the desire of many persons who are looking for a hobby to find out what this hobby of philately, which millions are already enjoying, is all about.
SOUTH PARIS, Mo., Nov. 12 -- Residents of this central Maine town are taking without excitement the opening of a $2,500,000 tannery to replace one that closed three years ago.

Specialists in municipal finance are not convinced that the defeat of certain multimillion-dollar bond proposals last Tuesday marked the start of an anti-public borrowing trend by the nation's voters.
WHEN the Columbia Broadcasting System reports that it has a story in the hopper, the odds are that it is referring to Don Moore.

In a letter published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, Dr. Paul Dudley White asks all colleagues to help him find out how many Americans have had heart attacks like that of the President. Dr. White is looking for information on the physician's private cases of coronary thrombosis.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Brown's football team today upset Harvard, 14 to 6, at Harvard Stadium. It was the fifty-fourth meeting between the schools. This was a welcome triumph for Coach Alva Kelley's Bruins, who snapped a four-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Refreshed by a good night's sleep, President Eisenhower devoted an hour today to official business. He submitted to a physical examination and then followed his physician's orders to "take it easy for the week-end."

THERE'S no end of attraction for nursery-age children in books about their own familiar experiences. That's the idea behind "Crunch Crunch." It's about getting up, having breakfast, going to the supermarket to get food for lunch, and then returning home to eat it.

HARTFORD, Nov. 12 -- A Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee will hold a public hearing here Monday on a proposed Federal disaster insurance program. Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, heads the group.

JOSEPH CONRAD died more than thirty years ago, and is more alive than ever. We read him more eagerly today because we are haunted by the hearts of darkness and because -- mysteriously -- he reflects our age better than he reflected his own.
May I add a thought to your excellent editorial of Nov. 6 on cancer research?

SALEM, Mass. -- Any notion that New Englanders board up their historic shrines and museums after the summer tourist season can be dispelled by a visit to the Essex Institute in this old city of witchcraft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Seven visiting Russian journalists got a cool reception at the Capitol today and a lecture on freedom of the press. Later, one observed that "your Senators are not very polite."
I found Alice Marble's "plea" to women drivers very ineffective.

There was too much good news last week for the stock market to do anything but go up. And it did so in a reassuring fashion, despite the restriction on trading caused by the Election Day holiday. For the second successive week, stocks advanced sharply in active trading, with the recovery carrying prices back to their best levels since Sept. 23.

THIRTEEN - YEAR - OLD Brad Porter was a little on the easy-going side that May of 1809 when he settled in alone to look after the new cabin in Maine while his father went to fetch the family from Boston. When the Porters failed to return on schedule, only the devotion of an Indian boy saved Brad from the bitter fruit of carelessness and ignorance in the forest.

SOME penguins, not unlike some people, are mighty unhappy with their lot. Take Mr. Goodenow's peevish penguin, for example -- a young fellow bothered by the fact that he's a bird that cannot fly. After some experimenting, he does come up with a solution that undoubtedly will be familiar to anyone who knows the ways of small, restless boys.

TO Robin's brothers, the mare was "old crowbait," but to Robin she was beautiful, the best friend he had. Robin needed a friend. In an active, working ranch family he had to remain inactive because of the threat of recurring rheumatic fever.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Howell Tubbs' 26-yard field goal and Jerry Elliott's 25-yard touchdown run with an intercepted pass kept Auburn in the bowl picture today as the Plainsmen downed Georgia, 16 -- 13.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -- A dam three-miles wide, aimed at averting a recurrence of disastrous floods in the Los Angeles basin, was dedicated this week.

COON RAPIDS, Iowa. Nov. 12 (UP) -- Roswell Garst, hybrid seed corn producer, laughed off today as a "tempest in a teapot" the State Department's withholding of visas for ten Russians Mr. Garst had invited to this country.
" I'M not from outer space. I'm from Feor. Earth is the planet that is in outer space."

THE thirty-seven stories and poems in this collection have been carefully selected for their variety of mood and experience, and for interest. They are largely from contemporary literature representative of outstanding children's authors, and have been tested out on children.
Changing interpretations of Mozart operas through the years will be demonstrated on Wednesday at 8 P. M. at the New York Public Library.
To bring sectarian religion into the public schools "under whatever guise" is to "strike at the very foundations of our American way of life," Rabbi Julius Mark said yesterday.

TWENTY-SIX unusual folk tales from many lands and ages are re-told here by Frances Carpenter. They range from myths and ghostly legends to robust tales of wit and magic. As the title indicates, dogs and cats play the leading roles, although there are also those human characters whom folklore so often shows us as profiting by the wise assistance of their animal friends.

GEORGE VOSKOVEC, a 50-year-old stage and television actor from Czechoslovakia, will be cast in the most familiar role of not only his career but his life. He will star in a TV play titled "I Was Accused," which is based on the true story of the same George Voskovec who was detained by immigration authorities on Ellis Island for ten months in 1950.

EVERYONE knows ivy and philodendron vines, but few house plant enthusiasts realize how many colorful flowering vines may be grown indoors. Once having tended any of these and seen how cheerful they are during our short winter days, the hobbyist with just plain green-leaved sorts.

THE story of the Sadler's Wells Ballet will gladden the heart of every dancer no matter what his esthetic credo or his way of work. But it may prove to be inspirational also to every member of the theatrical profession or, for that matter, to everyone interested in building up a school or institution -- because basically this tale is not restricted to an art phase.
Museums and galleries provide an unusually crowded week of exhibitions, with an unusual number of outstanding events.

Misty Morn, flying the yellow and purple silks of Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps' Wheatley Stable, won the $85,550 Gallant Fox Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. It seems likely that she also won the 1955 championship among the 3-year-old fillies.

HARTFORD, Nov. 12 -- A team of legal experts is completing a series of amendments to Connecticut's new state primary law that will cut in half the number of possible primaries in state election years.

MACHIAS, Me., Nov. 12 -- Maine hunting improved considerably the past week, with flights of waterfowl arriving in the upper coastal area and colder weather in the northern counties increasing the deer harvest.

Plans for the forthcoming Knickerbocker Ball, called Symphony of Stars, rapidly are nearing completion. Members of the invitation and executive committees have been announced by Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, the co-chairman.
A CENTURY ago babies were dying because there was no known way to preserve milk. The man who found a way is the subject of this human and interesting biography.

Dwight D. Eisenhower had a triumphant reception in this and other cities ten years ago last June when he came back from his final victorious campaign in Europe. We don't know how he felt. He is and was a modest man. He is and was a humane man. As such he knew that the victory in Europe had been won in great part by men who could not come home and who could not parade.

AN old film brand but with new features will be returned to dealers' shelves this week. It is Eastman Kodak Company's Panatomic-X, which has a speed of A. S. A. 25 in daylight, 20 in tungsten, and will be available in 35mm magazines and 828, 127, 120 and 620 rolls.

HOW do we account for the renewed vitality and prosperity of defeated, bombed-out and divided Germany? Why do the Germans, at least the West Germans, seem to have done better than some of the victors?
The opening of the Ford empire to public investment marks two epochal milestones in American corporate history.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 12 -- Jagjivan Ram, Minister for Communications, announced today that forty-two new aircraft would be purchased abroad during the next five years to meet the growing needs of India's domestic and international civil aviation.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Sunderland scored two quick goals for its opposition today but rallied to tie Burnley, 4 -- 4, and moved into first place in the English Soccer League's first division.

THE bridge spanning the wide river was a busy place from dawn to dusk. Farmers bumped and clacked over it in their trucks carrying produce to city markets. From the opposite direction and going into the country went mail, telephone and fire trucks.

THRICE welcome is a book filling so large a need! A generation grows up in America which knoweth not its Bible -- the Book which gave pith and marrow to our English Tongue. Far more than that. From the majesty of its pronouncements comes our moral code.

WHEN Slingin' Sammy Baugh was doing his sharpshooting for the Washington Redskins not many years ago, an enemy tackle with a reputation as a roughhouser came bursting past the defenses of the Capital Braves. He knocked Sammy down, trampled all over him and then administered the elbow and fist treatment. The uncomplaining Texan didn't even give a reproachful glance to him.
A family reunion, with variations, took place before, at and after the Yale game at Princeton, N. J., yesterday.
Major savings in operational costs were made in the last fiscal year by the First Army as a result of an economy program, according to headquarters on Governors Island.

THE post-war current of interest in Japanese political affairs these days has carried some Americans farther, into the deep, if cooling waters of Japanese culture. People who once couldn't tell a No player from a Samisen salesman have been excited by traveling exhibitions like the performances of the Japanese Kabuki dancers or New York's much-viewed Japanese house exhibit.
Sixteen professors have been appointed to the Whitney Visiting Professors Program for 1955-56, it has been announced by the John Hay Whitney Foundation.

A unique way for a football team to achieve an all-winning record is by never listening to its coach. That, of necessity, is the starting point from which the New York School for Deaf eleven has gone through two straight undefeated campaigns.

WHENEVER a playwright becomes intensely harassed trying to measure exact amounts of religion, politics and sex in one character, the chances are good that tickets have been printed for a new play about that canonized habitude of Broadway, Joan of Arc.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- The heads of the British, French and United States delagations met this afternoon to consider the West's answer to the Soviet thrust into the Middle East and the threat of an Arab-Israeli conflict.

It would not be necessary, if these were ordinary times, to take the outcome of the second round at Geneva too tragically. Geneva is not the first city where a meeting of the Big Four foreign ministers has ended in a deadlock, and assuredly it will not be the last.

EXETER, N. H., Nov. 12 -- Andover still is Exeter's master in football. This fact was demonstrated today as the Royal Blue unleashed a last-quarter air attack to down the Exonians, 14 -- 12, in the annual game between the prep schools.

NO matter what the polite and considerate Mrs. Perrywinkle tries to do, she is balked by her newly acquired pets. Her two cats and a dog (called, for no reason, Gallagher, Ginsburg and Sam) take over her bed, her roses, her big chair, her sewing machine, even her food.

IN the air-conditioned laboratories and studios of Detroit technical centers, auto engineers and stylists are busy bridging the gap between the shiny new models of 1956 and the even shinier ones of tomorrow.

DAMARIS HOPKINS was afraid. Today the Pilgrims were sharing their feast of thanksgiving with the Indians. But there were so few Pilgrims and so many Indians! Brother Giles. however, felt no fear for he was certain they could all be friends.

If there are earth-type planets around other stars, as many astronomers believe, life would occur on them much as it did here, Dr. Martynas Ycas reports to the National Academy of Sciences. He is on the staff of the Quartermaster Research and Development Center.

ROSIE, short for Rosario Antonio Cesare Giuseppe Cucina, runs a restaurant on top of a hill. He is a happy man who loves his restaurant, his cooking and his kitchen -- and no wonder, with a kitchen as colorful and well-stocked as his.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Senate study of General Motors Corporation, which began last Tuesday, appears destined to plod along to a conclusion three weeks hence without doing much, if any, damage to the multi-billion dollar concern.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department today announced publication of its annual best-seller, the Yearbook of Agriculture.

As the special "weeks" we observe come and go it is a pleasure to hail a week set aside to stimulate the reading of better books by children everywhere. The special observance to which we refer is National Children's Book Week, designated for the week of Nov. 13 through Nov. 19. This year will mark the thirty-seventh annual celebration of this week, testifying to its general value and popularity.

The excerpts that appear below are taken from papers written by New York school children in answer to the question who was their favorite hero in literature or history. Robin Hood topped all others in popularity, closely followed by Peter Pan. Davy Crockett, Paul Revere, Sherlock Holmes and Joan of Arc tied for third place.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Howard (Hopalong) Cassady put on his greatest show in his farewell to the home folks today, scoring three touchdowns as Ohio State defeated Iowa, 20 -- 10.

LIKE legions of small boys, Jerry wanted more than anything to be a cowboy. A vacation on his grandparents' ranch in Wyoming seemed to promise the realization of his dream, but there were all those chores to do for Grandmother.
State officials, whose plan for loans for middle-income housing died in the voting booths last week, are preparing a new one five times larger.

During the past week one of the world's proverbial and perennial trouble spots has become less troublesome. There is a marked improvement in the situation in North Africa and a hopeful augury for the future.
The white cross on the blue ground, displayed throughout the city on flags and posters, is the symbol of the United Hospital Fund, America's oldest federated charity.
The last of a large and proud fleet of American-flag coastal passenger vessels, active in both the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts before and after World War II, has been sold to a foreign buyer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Mrs. Eisenhower will spend her fifty-ninth birthday Monday in the spot she likes most -- at Gettysburg in the first home the Eisenhowers have owned.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 12 (UP) -- Michigan State, with both offense and defense clicking to near perfection, smashed Minnesota, 42 -- 14, before 51,605 fans today. The victory kept the Spartans in contention for the Big Ten Rose Bowl berth.

WHILE Howard Pyle's four-volume version of the Arthurian legend still is supreme among adaptations of the epic for young readers, many children are discouraged by its length and difficult style. To introduce modern boys and girls to these golden tales, Barbara Picard provides a one-volume adaptation from Malory's "Morte d'Arthur" and other sources, which is enticing in format, illustration and typography and is straightforward in approach.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Pennsylvania steel plants operated during September at 95 to 97 per cent of capacity. Production in the Pittsburgh-Youngstown district was at the best level since 1952, while that in the eastern section of the state reached a new high.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 12 -- The coup by the Brazilian Army appeared today to have succeeded completely.
ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Do men become maladjusted when they retire? Most do not, preliminary findings of a Cornell study indicate.

Alice Marble has pinpointed delightfully and I hope effectively the appalling lack of ordinary courtesy shown by motorists, both men and women. The authorities, those who form traffic-control policy, are largely responsible for that and the rude motorist is in many cases merely following the admonition to "know and obey traffic laws."

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 12 -- A public meeting to discuss a proposition to spend nearly $2,500,000 to build a new high school and remodel the present elementary-high school building will be held at the East Hampton School Tuesday evening.

THE high-fidelity fans, it seems, have found a new excitement. Having wearied their friends and themselves on the wonders of the triangle and other percussion instruments as recorded and reproduced by modern methods, they have passed on to something infinitely more grandiose and complex, something that can provide still higher frequencies and that can shake the house even more thoroughly -- the Organ.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Five college presidents will open a joint financial campaign here for the support of liberal arts education in twenty-two independent colleges in New York State.

NEW YORK never had a Mayor or a Congressman remotely like Fiorello H. La Guardia, "The Little Flower." No one who reads this affectionate memoir will lay it down without a twinge of homesickness for those tempestuous days which, whatever else they were, were made almost painfully exciting by "The Major."

CAIRO, Nov. 12 -- Egyptian leaders told Maj. Gen E. L. M. Burns, the United Nations truce chief, today that United Nations proposals to end frontier fighting at Al Auja were based on a wrong assumption that the demilitarized zone belonged to Israel.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The Attorney General hailed the nation's press tonight for exposing the secret recording of a jury's proceedings.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Since the days when men by accident, and later by design, first began to visit the Southern Polar Regions, our conception of that vast area has slowly crystallized. In 1773, when Capt. James Cook began his circumnavigation of the ice-bound seas, there was no certainty that land might exist in the far south.

IT IS excellent news that the Royal Danish Ballet is actually coming over for a brief visit next season, for this is one of the few great companies in the world. Since it is manifestly impossible for all of us to go to Copenhagen to see it in its own theatre, the next best thing is to be able to see here as much of it as can be conveniently transported.

THE ever increasing employment of Ilex crenata varieties in landscaping offers the first real challenge to the monotonously over-planted yew. I. crenata, the Japanese holly (during the war it was called Chinese), is a true holly.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 12 -- A proposed $75,000,000 bond issue for the rehabilitation of the state penal, eleemosynary and higher educational institutions will be submitted to Missouri voters in a special election Jan. 24.

PRAGUE, Nov. 12 -- Touring behind the Iron Curtain in Rumania, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, this correspondent obtained an impression of strongly installed Governments.

ATLANTA, Nov. 12 -- Employment in the Southeastern states continues to move upward. Workers in non-agricultural jobs were at a record 6,149,200 in September, the regional U. S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported this week. Compared to a year earlier, some 183,400 more workers are on Southeastern payrolls.

Cotton fields that blew white across the huge reaches of the cotton empire, from the Piedmont to the Gulf, westward to Texas and westward again to Arizona and California, are now being, or already have been, picked clean by armies of men, women and children and by thousands of mechanical pickers.

American farmers will raise 63,100,000 turkeys this year. The crop represents another banner year for turkey raisers who have witnessed a 200 per cent increase in turkey consumption from before the war to 1954. Only 17,000,000 gobblers were raised in 1930, compared with a record 65,000,000 last year.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 12 -- Atomic power "will seem as commonplace to our children and grandchildren as the automobile does to us," Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, retired, predicted here today.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy continued yesterday with his reshuffling of the Detective Division.

THIS story, begun in "Thirty-One Brothers and Sisters," continues the adventures of the spirited and delightful Zulu girl, Nomusa. The South African veldt is the background, and daily life in a primitive world is seen through Nomusa's eyes.
A new generation of concertgoers made its lively debut at the opening Young People's Concert of the Little Orchestra Society yesterday morning in the Hunter College Assembly Hall.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 13-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and French Foreign Minister Antoine Pinay agreed today to defer any decision on the Saar until a new government for the territory was elected next month.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 13 --Despite the confident longrange outlook prevailing on the Zurich Stock Exchange, where closing prices of the best American stocks all last week were often higher than in New York, the total daily turnover was not large.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Grain and soybean futures slumped substantially in the middle of last week. But demand picked up somewhat later in the week for wheat and soybeans, while corn was still inclined to drag.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--The Civil Aeronautics Board may be heading for trouble in proposing that airlines be allowed to offer free or reduced-rate travel for board workers on official business.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The stockmarkets have had a bad week. It ended better than had seemed likely until an encouraging statement came to hand Friday on Britain's overseas trade for October.

GENEVA, Nov. 13--Spurred by a threat of Soviet penetration in the Middle East, the Western powers are determined to bring about a settlement between Israel and Egypt as the most important step in stabilizing the area.
"Don't fool around the Rangers," yelled a fan from the gallery at Madison Square Garden last night, and the Toronto Maple Leafs found that the admonition was one they had to obey.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Approximately 10,000 German prisoners of war are now being returned home from Russia. The repatriation of these men is a longdeferred act of justice. Included in this number are many who shocked and horrified the civilized world with their brutal experiments on the German Jewish people.
Brooklyn is the only club with more than one representative on the 1955 Associated Press major league all-star baseball team, which was released yesterday.

STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 13--A week-end fishing trip almost ended in death for a 14-year-old boy in the Great Salt Meadows of Stratford. James Ackley was pulled from the ooze of the flats by the local police after he had sunk to his chest.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 13--Finance Minister Johan van de Kieft and representatives of nearly all parties clashed sharply in the Dutch Parliament last week over the continued rise in Government spending and the number of civil servants.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP)--The Chicago Bears, paced by Quarterback Ed Brown, routed the Los Angeles Rams, 24--3, today to move into a first-place tie in the Western Conference of the National Football League.

New York's Department of Air Pollution Control is broadening the base of its attack by tackling in a small way, at least, the problem of automobile exhaust fumes. First attention will be given to buses. If they emit visible smoke or fumes while stationary or moving for more than 100 yards (a rather long distance, by the way) they will be guilty of an offense.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13-- The unification of Germany maybe the California State Athletic could undertake. Sagging farm prices and crop surplus maybe it could remedy. It might even have a go at the New York waterfront imbroglio.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 13 -- Andre Dubois, the new French Resident General, said today on his arrival from Paris that French-Moroccan negotiations to implement political reforms in this protectorate would start after the formation of a national government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your "News of the Week in Review" of Nov. 6 you state that our association "voted to file formal application under the escape clause of the Reciprocal Trade Act for an increase in tariffs on cotton blouses."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Geneva spirit was hailed as the thawing of the cold war. NATO, whether it meant defiance, defense, or simply diffidence, was the symbol and instrument of the cold war. If the Geneva spirit is to be implemented, NATO must be superseded by a new organization.

The recent reorganization of the Navy Department's Bureau of Aeronautics represents welcome and much needed progress. Similar efforts by the young and able Chief of the Bureau of Ships, Rear Admiral Albert G. Mumma, to strengthen his organization are important to the Navy and the nation.

ALTHOUGH numerous modern writers have speculated that when Christopher Columbus sailed westward bound for India and Cathay he had good reason to suspect the existence of the American continents he himself always insisted that the islands he discovered were the East Indies and that Cuba was an Asian peninsula.

The appeal to shoppers of the Thirty-Fourth Street retail district has been measurably strengthened by Ohrbach's arrival in the area, according to a survey by the New York University School of Retailing.

HARTFORD, Nov. 13--America's great strength lies not in its military might but in its deeprooted spiritual heritage, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States, said here today.
ALEXANDRIA, La., Nov. 13 --Congress likely will try to deal with conflicts and competition within agriculture as well as overproduction and surplus disposal.
Larry Tiihonen was no sorrowful figure Friday as he made his farewell as Lawrenceville's football coach after twenty-seven years. Most of his seasons have been successful ones.
BERLIN, Nov. 13 (AP)--The national Olympic committees of West and East Germany agreed today to send a joint sixty-eightmember team to the winter Olympics at Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy, next January.

MONTREAL, Nov. 13--A second landslide hit Nicolet today. It was minor compared to the one yesterday which roared through five dwellings, killed three persons, left 1,000 homeless, and brought damage estimated unofficially in the millions of dollars.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (AP) --Local 1511 of the Government and Civic Employes Organizing Committee, C. I. O., paid tonight that maintenance workers would return to work tomorrow on the New Jersey Turnpike.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 13-- Gettysburg was putting the final touches today on preparations to become the nation's "temporary capital."
A $2,500,000 hotel with earmuff walls to deaden the din of airliner engines will soon be built at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The Board of Estimate soon will vote salary increases for large group of secondary officials in the offices of Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, City Council President Abe Stark and the five Borough Presidents.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 13-- Sixteen awards were made to Westchester professional and amateur artists today at an exhibition marking the twentyfifth anniversary of the WestChester Arts and Crafts Guild. The 269 entries will be on public display for a week at the Westchester County Center from noon until 10 P. M., beginning Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- High - level controversy within and outside the Administration over basic questions has been raised by conflicting United States and Egyptian versions of the negotiations that led up to Egypt's arms deal with the Soviet bloc.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 13--Best in show of the finest event of twenty-nine conducted by the Onondaga Kennel Association was taken tonight by one of Mrs. Marguerite S. Tyson's fine miniature poodles, Ch. Adastra Magic Fame.
Maj. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu, who emerged suddenly as Provisional President of Argentina yesterday, has spent thirty-six years of his fifty-two years in his country's Army.
THIRTY-FIVE shopping days till Christmas, and time for all good women to begin indoctrinating their husbands in the ways of furs.
A book called "Big Business Leaders in America,"* if it conformed to our race patterns, should contain a number of portraits of tycoons, all a little breathless from either adulation or rancor.

PARIS, Nov. 13--France and South Vietnam will negotiate a new commercial and financial agreement that will define the conditions under which France's economic position can be maintained and developed in Indochina. The accord that was in force since last year has been denounced by Saigon.
Write-in ballots, bearing instructions to place "the saint's name here," were used yesterday to select the name of "St. Nicholas" for the six-weeks-old Greek Orthodox Church of Flushing.

The completeness and diversity of services to be offered the air traveler at New York International Airport are exemplified with the announcement that construction of a 250-room hotel will begin at once. The Port of New York Authority, which is in charge of developing the four commercial airports in the New York area, will erect the building at a cost of $2,500,000.

FRANCIS ROBINSON, assistant manager and press director for the Metropolitan Opera Company, will carry with him to this evening's opening-night performance of Offenbach's "Les Contes d'Hoffmann" a note almost ninety years old that establishes the antiquity of the operatic Annie Oakley.
HAVANA, Nov. 13--A flying relay station, more than two miles aloft, enabled millions of Americans to watch the first live telecast from Cuba to the United States today.
WASHINGTON., Nov. 13 -- Communism and subversion will occupy the Supreme Court this week.
THE John Harms Chorus, at Town Hall Saturday evening, undertook the somewhat rash venture of performing the Verdi Requiem without an orchestra.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 --Although the start of photography is five to six months away, David O. Selznick is losing no time assembling a cast for his adaptation of the Ernest Hemingway novel "A Farewell to Arms."
The United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce has called on Congress to protect business against taxation by more than one country.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $71,644,954,733. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

IF A CHANGE in the publicdining scene is what a restless New Yorker seeks, he will find it at a new "ice cream parlor" that has just been opened at 24 West Fifty-eighth Street by Max Gordon, restaurateur, and Michael Field, professional pianist.

Bookmarks and Their Substitutes When Children's Book Week rolls around the book week people put into circulation, through libraries everywhere, a highly useful little slip of paper. It is a bookmark, and even if all the recipients do not read everything on it about books they are grateful to have it.

James Ronald, Scottish novelist, was scheduled to be deported this afternoon as a public charge, it became known last night. Officials of the Immigration Service said the 50-year-old author would leave this country on the Army transport Gen. A. H. Butner.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (AP) --The University of California at Los Angeles Bruins have lost their ace passer with a broken leg.

LONDON, Nov. 13--Two of Britain's most famous shipping lines, the Clan Line and the Union - Castle Mail Steamship Company, will be brought under one ownership if a merger proposal mailed to stockholders this week-end is accepted.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 13 (AP)-- Rut Walter, Northwestern University's head track coach, insisted today that Jim Golliday's official time for the 100-yard dash is world record-matching 9.3 seconds--not 0:09.2, as reported yesterday by Dan Ferris secretary of the Amateur Athletic Union.
As the first step in the $800,000 study of rapid transit in the metropolitan area, New Jersey commuters are to be asked how they get to and from work.

After early weakness on liquidation in advance of the Government's crop forecast, cotton prices in the domestic market subsequently turned firmer and closed last week on higher ground. At the close on Thursday, futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 10 to 56 points.

GENEVA, Nov. 13--The Foreign Ministers' Conference is headed toward failure on all its major objectives. But it is felt that the cause of that failure may prompt the Western power to return to a saner approach to the great conflict between East and West.

Wells Surveys, Inc., announced over the week-end the successful completion of tests to adapt the world's smallest "atom smasher" to locating and positive evaluating of oil-bearing formations in the field.
The Metropolitan Opera will open its seventy-first season tonight at 8 o'clock with a new production of Offenbach's "Les Contes d'Hoffmann."
A filmed documentary titled "Assignment: India" will be televised in color by the National Broadcasting Company on Thanksgiving Day (Nov. 24) from 5 to 6 P. M.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a long-time summer resident of Owl's Head, Me., I agreed with every derogatory word Bernard DeVoto wrote in Harper's Magazine about my much beloved state. And I doubly appreciate the story in The Times of Nov. 10 describing the cancellation of Maine advertising in Harper's because of the article, and the subsequent apology by the Governor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (AP) --The Philadelphia Eagles spotted the champion Cleveland Browns 17 points in the first quarter and then rallied behind the effective passing and running of Quarterback Adrian Burk to win, 33--17.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) --Washington's powerful defensive unit turned back four San Francisco drives today and set up a touchdown with a recovered fumble to lead the Redskins to a 7-0 victory over the 49ers.
The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will seek a $1,000,000 endowment fund to assure its continued ministry in the "geographic center" of Manhattan.
Federal aid to schools does not have to be provided on a blanket basis to all states and communities, Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University, declared yesterday.

A five-story building containing thirty apartments at 1268-70 Grant Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Mybene Realty, Inc., to the Lilike Realty Corporation, investment group. The sale was subject to two mortgages totaling 61,000.

Rate levels were fairly static in the steamship charter field last week, a period that included two holidays, although some "snipping" was noted. The tanker segment, on the other hand, reported "zooming" rates.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The most crucial appointment the Mayor will make during his term of office is probably to the chairmanship of the City Planning Commission, as The New York Times pointed out in an excellent editorial last summer.
The week-end programs of the New York City Ballet at the City Center contained a number of season's "firsts," and wound up last night with an all-Jerome Robbins bill.

THE Concert Society of New York, which gave its first two seasons in Town Hall, yesterday began an "interim" season in Carl Fischer Hall. The opening concert was attended by the 250 members who made the stop-gap season possible.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 13-- A report that the Government planned to declare a "state of siege," equivalent to martial law, disturbed political circles here tonight.

One of the most puzzling and discussed plays on Europe's stages today, Samuel Beckett's tragi - comedy "Waiting for Godot," is Broadway-bound. Producer Michael Myerberg has set the opening date here for the week of Jan. 23.
CASEY STENGEL was rambling away in one of his nonstop conversations a few months ago. In the middle of a sentence involving John McGraw he suddenly veered off in a different direction.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 (UP)-- Goalies Terry Sawchuk and Glenn Hall held the spotlight tonight as the Boston Bruins and Detroit Red Wings played a 0-0 tie in a National Hockey League game witnessesd by 11,338 Garden fans.

JERUSALEM (Israel Sector), Nov. 13--Israel is still offering to the Arab states routes across her territory, free port facilities at Haifa and compensation for lands left by refugees when they fled in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--It was a restful Sunday at the White House today. The family ehatted, friends dropped by and the man of the house went outside for some fresh autumn air.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13--Anxiety over the steel shortage mounted last week. Steel companies could do little to calm fears of their customers, some of whom are cutting back operations or are unable to increase their activity to meet their own customers' demands.
Fire raged for more than five hours yesterday aboard the Navy's converted Liberty ship Searcher, serving as an ocean radar station, 152 miles southeast of New Tork.

It was an Iron Cross and not a Swastika that loomed upon the wall in a Bonn garage on Saturday when Defense Minister Theodor Blank spoke to the 101 volunteers who constitute the new West German Army. In time there may be twelve divisions of that Army, as contemplated in the agreement with the Western powers.

Foreign exchange market was quiet and fairly steady during the past week. This was due in part to the abbreviated number of trading sessions when the banks were closed on Tuesday for Election Day Holiday and on Friday for Veterans Day Holiday. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar moved narrowly on moderate turnover of business.

The first edition of a novel by Charles Dickens and Wilkie Collins has been scheduled for Jan. 4 publication by Library Publishers. "The Wreck of the Golden Mary," a drama of the sea, was originally written for inclusion in the 1856 Christmas issue of Dickens' periodical, Household Words, and has never been offered to the public in book form.

During all the talk at Geneva, both in the Foreign Ministers' conference and in the bilateral "ambassadorial" discussion between the United States and Communist China, there has been no let-up in the steady application of Red pressures in Asia.

The football snow at the Polo Grounds yesterday was a good one. From a local viewpoint it hardly could have been improved upon, considering that the Giant beat the Baltimore Colts, 17--7 and 33,982 fans, the season's largest turnout here, saw them do it.
Bernard De Voto, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, essayist and literary critic, died at 8:30 last night in the Presbyterian Hospital of a heart attack. His age was 58.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 (AP)-- The Detroit Lions dealt Pittsburgh its third straight National Football, League loss today, 31--28, but not before the Steelers threw a scare in the final quarter.

St. John's Prep of Brooklyn upset its borough rival, St. Francis, 13--6, at Boys High Field yesterday. Bill Jamin scored all the victor's points as the Little Redmen surprised the leader of the Catholic High School Football League.

The Hall Trading Company has sold the five-story office building at 54 Pine Street to Loomis J. Grossman, real estate operator and investor. Originally erected for the Sun Insurance Company, the building is now occupied by A. G. Becker Co., stock brokers. It is on a plot about 26 by 98 feet.
Argentina yesterday was undergoing a split in ruling forces that had been held together for the last two months only by their antipathy to the ousted dictator, Juan D. Peron.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (UP)-- Maurice (The Rocket) Richard and Jean Beliveau led the Montreal Canadiens to a hard-fought 2-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight in a National Hockey League game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--The nation's economy reached new heights in the upward surge of production and services during the third quarter of this year.

A touring jazz concert troupe, comprising the Dave Brubeck Quartet, the Gerry Mulligan Sextet, the Australian Jazz Quartet and Carmen McRae, a singer, reached Carnegie Hall shortly after Saturday midnight.
THE National Broadcasting Company's live television pick-up from Havana was a technical success here yesterday afternoon.

GENEVA, Nov. 13--If the Middle East joins the Soviet bloc it will be a greater blow to the United States than the communization of China. Europe's petroleum resources and much of our own reserve are located there. The Mediterranean's south coast would be lost and NATO outflanked.

Vassily Smyslov, the Russian grand master, took undisputed possession of first place in the international chess tournament at Zagreb, Yugoslavia, yesterday by winning his adjourned ninthround game with Nikolaj Minev of Bulgaria.
The book was closed Saturday on the implausible exploits of a player with a genius for confounding Yale on the football field.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 --The television filming activities of Twentieth Century-Fox have necessitated the construction of a music-scoring and rerecording building feat the Fox Television Center on Western Avenue.

France appears well on the way to obtaining enough oil to meet her needs without spending dollar exchange. This is being brought about through her interest in the Mideast oil fields and the successful drive for the development of home resources.

TO THE EDITORS OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some time ago you published a news story concerning a statement issued criticizing 360 Americans who had signed an amicus curiae. brief supporting the Communist party's position in the pending Supreme Court case concerning the McCarran Internal Security Law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Federal Trade Commission charged four of the nation's leading cosmetic manufacturers with unfair discrimination among customers in the granting of sales promotion aid. Named in the complaints are: Elmo, Inc., Philadelphia; Helena Rubinstein, East Hills, L. I.; Hudnut Sales Company, Inc. and Yardley of London, Inc., both of New York City.

SAINT-SAENS' rather oldfashioned G minor Piano Concerto came to exhilarating life at the Saturday evening concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony in Carnegie Hall under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos.

A purchase that reportedly would make A. G. Spalding Bros., Inc., the nation's largest sporting goods company moved a step closer over the week-end. Negotiations have been completed for the acquisition by Spalding of all the capital stock of the Rawlings Manufacturing Company of St. Louis.
A comprehensive state health insurance system was urged yesterday by the State Congress of Industrial Organizations.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 13 (AP)--The undefeated New York Knickerbockers won their fourth game of the young National Basketball Association season tonight, outlasting Rochester, 94--91.

The state Housing Commissioner has asked the New York City Board of Elections to determine if there was a "slip-up" in the tally of votes on Proposition I in last week's election. Joseph P. McMurray said there was evidence that not all the votes on the proposal had been tabulated.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 13 -- The vice president of a paper manufacturing concern here, his wife and two sons were found dead in their home today. The police said that the executive had slain his family and taken his own life.
