WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)-- The Labor Department reported today that unions gained more than 1,000,000 members in the 1952-55 period but barely kept up with the growth in the nation's work force.

A committee has been formed here to champion the interests of holders of defaulted commercial state notes which the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics issued in 1932 and 1934 to dispossessed owners of foreignowned Russian mines.
Another step in a broad erosion -control program to protect Long Island's South Shore from storm and hurricane damage will be taken today.
Contemporary American music was given another hearty helping hand last night in Town Hall by the concert of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors.
Two intriguing innovations in the use of print media are to be seen in advertising about to appear:

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 13 (AP)--Quarterback Tobin Rote pitched three touchdown strikes and bucked for another score today as the Green Bay Packers broke a three-game losing streak by throttling the Chicago Cardinals, 31--14.

GENEVA, Nov. 13--Secretary of State Dulles and Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, met for almost two hours this morning without breaking the East-West stalemate on any major issue. The atmosphere was described as "informal and cordial."

Techniques used to separate the priceless from the worthless among the new disease-fighting compounds have been challenged by research scientists at the New York Medical College-Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals.
STAFFORD, Conn., Nov. 13 (AP)--The executive was a member of one of Stafford's oldest families--a family known for its quiet reserve.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) --President Eisenhower said today "America welcomes visits of those from abroad as a vital step in the direction of international understanding and world peace."
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13-- The "caretaker" Government of Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi was overthrown by a palace revolution today.

The monthly report of the Shipbuilders Council of America yesterday listed contracts for two new Moore - McCormack Lines passenger vessels. This is the first time in more than five years that an order for a passenger liner has been placed in this country.

ATHENS, Nov. 10--Twenty members of the Turkish Grand National Assembly have made news by quitting the ruling Democratic party. Ten resigned and ten were expelled, a correspondent found during a recent visit.

Despite reverses at Geneva a predominantly optimistic approach to world economic problems is expected this week at the forty-second National Foreign Trade Convention. The meeting, sponsored by the National Foreign Trade Council will open today and continue through Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13--The United States will abstain when the applications of Albania, Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania for membership in the United Nations come before the Security Council and the General Assembly.
Labor and liberal groups have begun an international campaign to block the holding of a United Nations conference in Venezuela next month.
VIENNA, Nov. 13--Recent developments in Poland are causing observers here to ask whether that country is to be permitted by the Soviet Union to take "her own road to socialism."

INSTEAD of playing a solo concert Saturday evening at Hunter College, Rudolf Serkin joined forces with a chamber orchestra directed by Alexander Schneider in an allMozart program. Many more Mozart programs will come during this bicentennial season.
Children will understand moral and spiritual values best if the basic pattern is provided in the home, four Junior high school students declared on the New York Times Youth Forum last night.
A Moslem group is completing arrangements to build a mosque on United Nations Plaza.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 13--A controversy over censorship has developed between South Africa's Minister of the Interior and the Anglican Bishop of Johannesburg.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 13--A retired professor has become this community's "Doctor of Clocks" in a hayloft workroom. Dr. Paul H. Curts, an author of scholarly German works and a former Professor of German at Wesleyan University, won his title after retiring in 1953 and taking up clock-repairing as a temporary hobby.
The city plans to start the New Year right by reducing one major source of air pollution --fumes from the exhausts of 6,000 bus engines.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--Political activity in the waning months of this pre-Presidential election year appears to be rising fast.

Masquerading as "preservers" of the Bill of Rights, Communist leaders in the United States are starting a "national crusade to break down hostility to their party," Msgr. Edwin B. Broderick declared yesterday.

MR. JOHN FREDERICS, one of New York's most famous millinery designers, sat pensively in his airy, attractive new salon at 6 West Fifty-seventh Street, and spoke of how women have changed in their attitude toward buying hats.

Argentina's provisional regime is having growning pains. President Eduardo Lonardi has been forced out after only seven weeks in office, but it is creditable that a new and probably stronger executive, Maj. Gen. Pedro Aramburu, Army Chief of Staff, was ready to step immediately and peaceably into his shoes.

Irwin, Wasey Co., advertising: agency, has leased one and one-half floors comprising 20,000 square feet of space in the twenty-story office building nearing completion at 711 Third Avenue, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 13 --An excited shout of "Golden eagle overhead!" broke up a luncheon today at the National Audubon Society's annual meeting here.
A task force of college presidents began yesterday a round of visits to corporations in New York City to raise funds for their independent institutions.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 13 --The next few months are likely to decide the future of the experiment in nationhood called Pakistan.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (AP)-- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party leader, today laid down a three-point program aimed at revitalizing Soviet agriculture. Although details were not disclosed, the plan involves increased payment for work on collective farms.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14--Unrest in the Middle East will continue as long as thousands of Palestinian Arabs clamor in vain to go back to their homes, now in Israel, United Nations members were told today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The Supreme Court passed on two cases involving racial issues in opinions and orders handed down today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- Senator Allen J. Ellender predicted today that the first new farm legislation aimed at propping income would be a steppedup program for disposing of surplus food and fiber stocks held by the Government.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14--South Africa severed today its last informal link with the current General Assembly session.
The unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee announced yesterday that it had made a new effort to win the recognition of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The Board of Education is to be commended for insisting that exCommunist teachers identify former party colleagues. The board is holding to its original resolution despite pressure by the United Parents Association and other groups.

Robert E. Sherwood, noted playwright and author who won four Pulitzer Prizes, died yesterday morning in New York Hospital at the age of 59. He had entered the hospital on Saturday after suffering a heart attack.
FURNITURE with inlaid mosaic motifs was popular in Mesopotamia seven thousand years ago, but only recently has it caught on here--particularly the mosaic table top.

When Brooklyn's Borough President, John Cashmore, presented world series gifts to the champion Dodgers this year he also awarded a silver coffee service to someone who had never hit a homer, fielded a grounder or stolen a base.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the first nine months of this year had earnings of $13,371,000, equal to $4.73 each on 2,828,228 shares outstanding.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 24 to 79 points ($1.20 to $3.95 a bale) today. Old contracts closed at the highs of the day.
The Curtis Manufacturing Company of St. Louis announced yesterday that it planned to merge with the Central Petroleum Company and the Lewis Machine Company, both of Cleveland.

THERE were schizophrenic aspects to the piano recital that Geza Anda gave last night in Town Hall. Up to the intermission, one could only wonder at some of his ideas. After the intermission he sounded like a different pianist, ending with a rousing performance of the Brahms "Paganini" Variations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Eisenhower worked briefly in his office today before driving to Gettysburg. It was his first visit to his office since his heart attack.
PARIS, Nov. 14 (UP)--French labor unions called a virtual air blockade of France tonight by ordering ground personnel to walk off their jobs at all commercial airports throughout the nation.
The on-again-off-again plan for fifteen special service tankers for the Military Sea Transportation Service are on again as of yesterday.
A Municipal Court trial of a suit testing the constitutionality of the state's Emergency Business Space Rent-Control Law was halted at least temporarily yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The Government moved today to settle the major area of controversy surrounding administration of the "Buy American Act." The Department of the Interior issued a policy statement on the basis of which four small contracts were awarded to foreign concerns.

Avco Manufacturing Corporation's Lycoming division released yesterday the first photograph of a new 825-horse power gas turbine engine it has designed and developed for use on both helicopters and conventional aircraft.
YESTERDAY (Nov. 14, 1955) GENERAL, ASSEMBLY Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Heard statements by Canada and Soviet Union on Korean unification and rehabilitation.
The keel-laying of a new superliner to replace the aging Ile de France is still almost a year away.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 14 --Jose Ferrer and Universal-International are at the point of completing negotiations for the star to direct and appear in "The Great Man."

The city's fire-fighting force was enlarged to its greatest numerical strength yesterday with the swearing in of 294 probationary firemen. The induction brought the roster to a total of 11,654 officers and men, a record, but still sixtysix short of the budgetary quota.

Oklahoma's Orange Bowlbound powerhouse led the United Press college football ratings yesterday for the second week in a row. Michigan State replaced Maryland in second place as the Sooners' chief competition for national honors.
YOUTHFUL observers of the "Let's Read More" slogan of National Children's Book Week, which continues through Sunday, should not lack for new and interesting material.

Helen Keller, who has been both blind and deaf virtually all of her seventy-five years, received here yesterday the first special citation to be awarded by President Eisenhower's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 14--A Baptist minister was absolved today of contempt of court for a letter he had written to a newspaper criticizing Superior Court Judge Frank T. Lloyd Jr.
Arnold Steuer's new play, "The Terrible Swift Sword," opens at the Phoenix Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In his letter published Nov. 8 Ernest Gross has fully stated the policy reasons for dropping our opposition to the admission of twenty nonmembers of the United Nations whose applications are pending. I should like to suggest a procedural change that would help to bring this about and would contribute to the ideal of unversal membership in the U. N. of all nations of the world.
Martin J. Yamin, former Baltimore police magistrate, was accused yesterday in Kings County Court of engineering the murder of Joseph Aronowitz, 40 years old, on a Brooklyn street last Feb. 15.
The price wars that have long raged in American retail circles have crossed the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The Administration is not surprised but it is nevertheless seriously disturbed by the failure of the Foreign Ministers' meeting in Geneva. Despite Secretary of State Dulles' optimism, officials here are now saying privately that events are running steadily against the Administration's policy on Germany.

ATHENS, Nov. 11--This is the export season, when shortcomings of the Turkish economic program appear less glaring. Next spring, however, deficits will begin again to show and there will be no reserves to fall back upon, financial experts there told this correspondent on a recent visit.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 14--A Professor of Criminal and Domestic Relations Law at the University of Maryland Law School was found dead today of a bullet wound in the heart while a class waited for him.
DENVER, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Graham told tonight how he had tied twenty-five sticks of dynamite together to make the bomb.
TRENTON, Nov. 14--Adlai E. Stevenson has been assured of New Jersey's thirty-two convention votes in his expected bid next year for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14--Five centuries of French painting and sculpture went on exhibit here today in deference to a new vogue that Western art is enjoying in this country. However, official arbiters of Soviet artistic taste continued to maintain a tongue-in-cheek attitude.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 111.2 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14--Extremely large receipts of corn depressed corn futures again today. The weakness in corn discouraged buyers elsewhere on the floor, with wheat and soybeans off rather sharply early. Prices later rallied.

THE best thing about the Metropolitan Opera's new production of "Les Contes d'Hoffmann" is its musical style. Thanks to the taste and freshness of Pierre Monteux' leadership, the performance has gaiety and elegance.
YONKERS, Nov. 14 (UP)-- Amber Rodney, driven by Jimmy Jordan, scored a two-length victory in the featured Fanshaw Pace before 26,395 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

By defeating Dr. Petar Trifunovic of Yugoslavia in fortynine moves yesterday at Zagreb, Yugoslavia, Vassily Smyslov of Russia added to his hold on first place in the eleventh round of the international chess tournament.

The Southern Nitrogen Company disclosed yesterday the details of the financing of its new petro-chemical plant at Savannah, Ga. The company had announced earlier that it planned to raise $18,000,000 for the project.
While United States attention has been focused on Europe, the Chinese Communists have continued their slow build-up opposite Formosa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)-- A Senate subcommittee today began a study of freedom in the United States. It was admonished to "let the discontented talk."
DENVER, Nov. 14--A 23year-old youth admitted today that he had planted a dynamite time-bomb that blew up a United Air Lines DC-6B over Colorado.
Gov. George N. Craig of Indiana called upon Republicans last night to defend Secretary Ezra Taft Benson's disputed farm price policy in the 1956 election campaign.

The Metropolitan Opera opened its seventy-first season last night in the maroon and gold Victorian opera house in which it may not be playing many more seasons. The opera was one that never had opened a Metropolitan season -- Offenbach's "Les Contes d'Hoffmann."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 14 --A difference of opinion was reported here today whether the nation was disintegrating culturally or merely going through a healthy social change.
LONDON, Nov. 14--The advance party of the Commonwealth Antarctica Expedition sailed on the afternoon tide today, but only barely.

BOSTON, Nov. 14--A retired musician who is twenty-one years older than the Boston Symphony Orchestra recalled today the beginning of the world-famous ensemble. The orchestra is entering its seventy-fifth year.

Copper prices soared yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York, climbing as much as the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit. The market was influenced by sharply higher prices in London where short covering met few offerings.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 14-- The Chamber of Deputies formally accepted this afternoon the resignation as presiding officer of Carlos Luz, who for two days last week was Brazil's Acting President.

Jimmy Combest made himself the topic of conversation with his accomplishment at Jamaica yesterday. The 32-year-old rider from Colombia, Ky., registered three victories to help the longshot followers among the 27,308 fans "get even" so close to the end of the local racing season.
Walter Alston, first to bring a world championship to Brooklyn, was voted the National League's manager of the year by members of the Baseball Writers' Association of America yesterday.
Wage increases of $1.50 to $4.50 a week were won yesterday by 23,000 long-distance telephone workers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) --The Supreme Court today agreed to rule on the income tax liability of an employe who is allowed to buy stock in his company at a reduced price.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14--A move was developing here today to rescue the human rights covenants from the political limbo to which they have been relegated.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)-- Competitive transcontinental airline service for Denver, Kansas City and Pittsburgh was authorized for the first time today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
THE unfortunately neglected custom of singing an allBrahms recital was revived by Maria Thornauer, contralto, at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening.
The last full program of the intercollegiate football season ds the Harvard-Yale game aring top billing in the East is week with the PrincetonDartmouth meeting.

New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $43,000,000 will be placed on the market by underwriting syndicates today. Among the offerings are public utility preferred stock, and convertible debentures and common stock of industrial enterprises.
The New York Giants will play twenty-one night baseball games at home in 1956, five with the Dodgers, it was revealed yesterday.
Shareholders of Sears, Roebuck Co. approved a 3-for-1 stock split at a special meeting here yesterday.

After thirty years of coaching football, Leigh (Doc) MacCurdy of Roosevelt of Yonkers, is in sight of his first undefeated campaign. Only Saunders-Commerce on Thanksgiving Day stands between the Rough Riders and an all-winning season.

The eyes of the Western Hemisphere are on Argentina and Brazil. These are the two greatest countries of Latin America. Both have grave constitutional crises. Both are committed to a struggle in which the military forces have the decision, but in which the goal is civilian government.

A great variety of products offered to advertising agencies and advertisers were put on display yesterday at the fourth annual Advertising Essentials Show, sponsored at the Biltmore Hotel by the Advertising Trades Institute, Inc.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14--Americans are awakening to the need for an understanding with the Soviet Union despite efforts of sinister groups to befog the issue.
An appeal for volunteers who can take evening or Saturday assignments with the Red Cross blood program was issued yesterday by the New York Chapter. American Red Cross.

Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery rode into Pennsylvania Station yesterday in the cab of an electric locomotive. The trip from Philadelphia by Pennsylvania Railroad was his first train ride in the United States, and he made the last part of it, from Newark, in the company of Engineman H. W. Bauroth.

"DYLAN THOMAS IN AMERICA: An Intimate Journal,"* by John Malcolm Brinnin, is one of the saddest books of recent years--a pitiful and painfully unpleasant ringside blow-by-blow account of the mental, moral and physical disintegration and self-destruction of a gifted poet. It was only two years ago this month that Dylan Thomas died of alcoholic poisoning of the brain in St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City.
MIAMI, Nov. 14 (UP)--A Senate subcommittee heard charges today that physicians and lawyers collected large fees by black-marketing babies in a racket reaching from coast to coast.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 14-- Virginia's Legislature was called today into a special session for Nov. 30.

BACK in the old days football was a relatively simple game. Teams used either the Warner system of attack or the Rockne system, both predicated more on power than guile. Defenses were simple, too. Invariably it was seven-man line with the backs in either a box or diamond alignment. Coaches made adjustments in offense or defense from their stations on the sidelines, the worst spot on the field for watching a football game.

Henry Kennedy, a Scotsman who runs for Michigan State, won the varsity title at the forty-seventh annual Intercollegiate Amateur Athletic Association of America cross-country championships yesterday. The runs were held at Van Cortlandt Park.
A TELEVISION tribute to a free press, with particular emphasis on the work of foreign correspondents, was presented last night by the Overseas Press Club and the National Broadcasting Company.
The New York Board of Rabbis expressed its "vigorous opposition" yesterday to a statement on moral and spiritual values made recently by the Board of Superintendents of the city school system.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 14-- Dartmouth's Lou Rovero, whose 124 yards rushing and fine defensive play sparked the victory over Cornell, will probably miss the Princeton game Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Communist China and the Soviet Union have completed without fanfare a new strategic rail link through Mongolia that eases a major Chinese transport weakness.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 11-- A basic economic reorientation is taking place here. It follows the conclusion of a Thai-Laotian intransitgoods agreement and the extension of the Bangkok-Nakhon Ratchasima (Korat)-Udon railway to the Mekong River.

The first public distribution of common stock of Revlon, Inc., producer of cosmetics, will be made shortly, according to a registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 14-- President Eisenhower came home to convalesce from his heart attack today among "the people who are going to be our neighbors, God willing."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--Joe Adonis, the New Jersey gambler, decided today that he preferred freedom in Italy to jail in the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 14 --Canada urged in the United Nations today that any new avenues looking toward unification of divided Korea should be explored with an open mind. Paul Martin, chief Canadian delegate, also warned against clinging to positions that led only to "blind alleys."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Seven Soviet news men wound up a tour of the United States today with a complaint that they had not been granted the interviews they had requested with "leading personalities."

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Vamp" on Thursday night at the Winter Garden Theatre for the benefit of the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy.
DETROIT, Nov. 14 (AP)--Passenger cars are rolling from United States assembly lines at the rate of more than 29,000 units a day.
HARTFORD, Nov. 14--Senator Herbert H. Lehman accused the Eisenhower Administration today of failing to cooperate with the Senate Banking and Currency Committee in its flood insurance inquiry.

"A great many local communities can support first-class education, and will, if the people properly understand the problem." This statement, made by Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University, deserves reflection, coming as it does from the chairman of the New York State Commission on Educational Finances and a man whose views on education always command respect.
The crippled Navy radar picket ship Searcher reached the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn at 10:05 o'clock last night. The converted Liberty vessel was in tow by the attack transport Capricornus.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14--A Soviet spokesman said today his delegation could not agree to the admission of a bloc of applicants for United Nations membership if Outer Mongolia were not included.

The Middle East might cease to be a menace to world peace if Israel and the Arab states could come to grips with the problem of more than nine hundred thousand refugees, half of them children under 15, now crowded helplessly into ghettoes in the Gaza strip, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The National Labor Relations Board has not announced whether it will appeal a recent decision, by a threejudge panel of the Circuit Court of Appeals here, that deliberate slowdowns by a labor union during the process of bargaining with an employer did not violate the direction of the Taft-Hartley Act "to confer in good faith."

Standard Oil Co. (Kentucky) Standard Oil Company of Kentucky yesterday declared a regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents and an extra dividend of 65 cents on the common stock. The dividends are payable on Dec. 10 to shareholders of record of Nov. 30.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--A Senate investigation is under way concerning the chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission and a Chicago transportation contract.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) --Two Southern Democratic Senators called today for voluntary racial segregation in public schools as the "perfect answer" to the preservation of Negro and white "racial integrity."

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14-- The provisional government of Maj. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu faced today the threat of a nation-wide general strike before it was in power more than twenty-four hours. The strike was called for midnight.
Cook County, Ill., School District 97 announced yesterday that it would open bids Dec. 7 on $6,750,000 of bonds dated Dec. 1, 1955 and due on Dec. 1 from 1957 to 1975.
GENEVA, Nov. 14--Britain's economic stock has gone up markedly in Europe during the past few weeks.
The City Planning Commission was criticized yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa for not preparing a 1956 capital budget "based on existing conditions."
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 14 (UP) --The Federal Government today auctioned the Richmond Virginians of the Class AAA International League for $20,000 to six local business men.

Lease applications are being taken for apartments in the eighteen - story air - conditioned building going up at 32 Gramercy Park South, southwest corner of Twentieth Street and Third Avenue, Hillyer Bell, Inc., managing agent, has opened an office on the site.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14-- Westchester should spend $48,681,927 next year, County Executive James D. Hopkins told the Board of Supervisors this afternoon.

The death of Robert Emmet Sherwood has taken away from us not only one of our most distinguished men of letters but also a valuable and lovable fellow-citizen. Mr. Sherwood was one of the best craftsmen in playwriting of our time. He was a political and social historian, both in his plays and in his prose works.

A committee of women, members of the volunteer group of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, will act as hostesses today through Thursday at the Mark Cross store at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. A percentage of all purchases made at the store during that time will aid the service toward attaining its 1955 quota of $430,000.

The Yugoslav National Folk Ballet will begin a fifteen-week tour of the United States in January, under the auspices of Consolidated Concerts Corporation and the International Music Institute. This will be the first large-scale dance company from a former Iron Curtain country.
In a session in which gains of $2 a share were almost too common to excite attention, the stock market yesterday advanced on a broad front.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The heaviest receipts since 1944 broke hog prices today to a new low since 1942.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 14-- Soviet-West German talks on the establishment of diplomatic relations have been at a standstill for two weeks, authoritative sources said today.

TUNK RIVER, Cherryfield, Me., Nov. 14--The weather man is still making life miserable for the deer hunters in this area. The hunter is provided with cold rain one day and sun and high temperatures the next.

Following are the texts of statements in Geneva yesterday by Secretary of State Dulles and Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, and extracts from remarks by Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, as supplied by Reuters; and an unofficial translation of the four-power proposal presented by Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, as supplied by The Associated Press: By Mr. Dulles This item of East-West contacts, although last on our agenda, is not the least.

THE incredibly prolific and diverse Pablo Picasso is represented this week at the Carstairs Gallery, 11 East Fiftyseventh Street, by nearly 100 etchings done in the years 1930-36. These, of course, were only a part of his output.

The sudden death of Bernard De Voto is a major loss to the world of American letters. Historian and novelist, critic and editor, he was a writer both scholarly and colorful, pugnacious and humorous, skillful and profound.

PROBABLY the best show in the history of the American Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors, the society's fifteenth annual, on view at the Riverside Museum, Riverside Drive and 103d Street, is true to the basic principles of the organization, demonstrating the wealth of style and idiom in modern art.

GENEVA, Nov. 14--Secretary of State Dulles opposed today any mention of another Big Four foreign ministers' conference in the communique to be issued here Wednesday. The present Big Four meeting is to adjourn on that day.

WHEN the weather is damp, as it has been much of the time lately, home cooks often have difficulty with pastries and candies supposed to be crisp or hard. Cream puffs that should be firm are, instead, soggy. Peanut brittle is anything but brittle.

RYE, N. Y., Nov. 14--Mrs. Donaki G. Aldrich of Whippoorwill was elected president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today at the annual luncheon meeting held at the Westchester Country Club. Seventy members attended.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--A four-point program to give small business a larger role in defense production was announced jointly today by the Department of Defense and the Small Business Administration.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 13--Government officials conceded today that there appeared to be little hope of holding truce talks this year to end the eight-year-old jungle war with Communist terrorists. This apparently was their first display of pessimism since the Reds proposed the talks six weeks ago.
"Command Performance," the first ninety-minute weekly show to be filmed especially for television, will make its debut over the American Broadcasting Company network next fall.
GENEVA, Nov. 14--The Soviet Union made it plain today that the Iron Curtain was here to stay.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press)--The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and subsidiaries had net earnings in the nine months ended Sept. 30 of $67,651,667 (U. S.), or $4.53 a common share--highest nine months' earnings in the company's history.
BUFFALO, Nov. 14--Governor Harriman asked the country to declare "constant war on poverty" tonight.

Dr. White on Exercise Dr. Paul Dudley White's remarks about on exercise during the recent Denver press conference doubtless caused some self-scrutiny among those who lead what he called "a chair and elevator existence."
Near-completion of the third and final building in the American Village apartment group in Kew Gardens, Queens, has been announced by S. J. Lefrak, president of the Lefrak Organization, builder.
LONDON, Nov. 14--Ruby M. Ayres, author of more than 100 romantic novels, died tonight in a private hospital at Weybridge Surrey. Her age was 72.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 (AP)--Johnny Podres, the world series pitching hero, went through two physical examinations today. However, he still doesn't know whether he'll be pitching for the Brooklyn Dodgers again next season.

The figures on union membership in the United States just issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics have special interest because of the coming merger of the A. F. L. and C. I. O. and the stepped-up organizing efforts planned for the joint operation.
United States exporters, discouraged by limited sales to dollarshort Latin America, were advised yesterday to undertake joint measures to help the area increase its dollar income.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) --The Marine Corps announced today charges, in its top commands effective following the retirement of Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr. as Commandant in January.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Nov. 14--The United Synagogue of America warned its one million constituents today that an easing of threats to civil liberties was only apparent. The peril continues, the group cautioned.
The United States Golf Association yesterday warned of the dangers to golf, "inherent in organized gambling."
The importance of recreation as a fourth "R" of education was underscored yesterday at the annual meeting of the Play Schools Association at the St. Regis Hotel.

The Columbia Gas System, Inc., yesterday notified government regulatory bodies and stockholders of a plan to reduce the number of its subsidiaries and eliminate duplication of proceedings of member companies before the rate-making groups.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 14-- Nassau County's government in 1956 will cost property owners $1.477 for each $100 of assessed valuation, an increase of $.151 over the present tax rate.
WINNIPEG, Man., Nov. 14-- Prairie hearings of the Royal Commission on Canada's Economic Prospects began here today on a gloomy note.

Fourteen eager young Foreign Service officers, including two women, were introduced in the rain yesterday morning to one of their riskier duties. They had taken a Coast Guard cutter out to the Narrows to board the Liberte, on her way to New York.
The telephone lines between Buffalo and Louisville were working overtime over last week-end as a result of some large-space advertising in two Buffalo papers, The CourierExpress and The News.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14-- Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington complained today that American business as a whole was doing an inadequate job of "telling its story." He advised it to redouble its efforts for the sake of its own free survival.
Gov. Orville Freeman of Minnesota accused the Eisenhower Administration yesterday of deliberately trying to wreck the farm price support program.
The airline industry would like to think practical method could be devised for screening airline baggage and cargo for the presence of a bomb or other instrument of sabotage.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 14-- Two Navy attack-cargo ships put out to sea from Norfolk today and headed for the Antarctic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The Senate Permanent Investigations subcommittee decided today to take very seriously charges made by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that the National Labor Relations Board was "literally honeycombed" with promoters of communistic movements.
TOKYO, Nov. 14--Japan's two conservative parties, the ruling Democrats and the Liberals, dissolved today in preparation for their formal merger tomorrow.
Although Sept. 26 is a rapidly receding memory for the general public, for the New York Stock Exchange it stands out as a day of trial and triumph.

POMPEII, Italy, Nov. 8--The ruins of Pompeii, which have taken more than two centuries to excavate, are disintegrating. Unless something is done quickly, there will be nothing to show a hundred years from now of the once flourishing Roman city except a few heaps of moss-covered bricks and stone.

The oil and gas-drilling operations of Distillers CorporationSeagrams, Ltd., are proceeding satisfactorily, Samuel Bronfman, president, told the annual meeting in Montreal yesterday. The completion of recent surveys confirmed "that our proven oil and gas reserves should more than return our investment in the properties to date," he said.

Speaking to some 300 rookies and newly promoted officers of the firefighting force on Monday, Commissioner Cavanagh said: "Your department has arisen from the slumber of being a waiting service." He described the department's "new role" as "a vital, active, ever-forwardmoving, ever - working department dedicating itself twenty-four hours a day to accomplishing its job."
A WIDE swing through the northern New Hampshire counties and across some of the popular deer hunting sections of Vermont indicated that the whitetails are proving extremely elusive this season.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 76 points (25 cents to $3.80 a bale) yesterday. The close was at about the best levels of the day, with the December contract at 34 cents, the first time it has attained that level since August.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15--Following is the text of the statement read here toady by Adlai E. Stevenson: I shall be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President next year, which I suspect is hardly a surprise.
IN "The Terrible Swift Sword," which was put on at the Phoenix last evening, both the playwright and the director are conspicuously on trial.

The practice of using coupons and other devices to promote sales of branded merchandise was sharply attacked yesterday by Safeway Stores, Inc., supermarket chain. Safeway's position in the controversy, consistently against the use of what it calls "gimmicks," is of special importance, since the chain is a brand marketer as well as a retailer.
City operation of the piers has been a "failure" and "holds no promise for the future," Harold Riegelman charged yesterday.

About 1,500 Bronx residents in the Crotona Park area learned what might happen to them if an atom bomb should explode in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The first borough-wide civil defense test in more than two years called out 500 air wardens, auxiliary police and auxiliary firemen with all their paraphernalia.

A tract of about seven acres in Woodside, Queens, has been assembled by Will Gottfried, real estate operator, for development as an industrial terminal. The property comprises five blocks in the area bounded by Laurel Hill Boulevard, Fiftyeighth Street, Tyler Avenue, Fifty-ninth Place and Fiftysecond Road.
A promise that the city will do all within its power to attract its young people into the field of aviation was given last night at a meeting of the Grand Street Boys at 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.
GENEVA, Nov. 15--A Soviet proposal for a reduction of Western and Soviet forces in Germany was rejected by the Western powers today because it envisaged the continued division of Germany.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP)--The heirs of thirteen of the passengers who died in the crash of a United Air Lines plane in Colorado two weeks agro will be paid a total of $655,000 by the Continental Casualty Company, one of the largest writers of coin machine travel insurance.
A Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Herbert H. Lehman is proposing an $11,000,000-ayear program to help combat juvenile delinquency on a nationwide basis.

The last flickering hope for some positive achievement at the Geneva conference has evaporated as a result of an extension of the prevailing deadlock to the last item on the agenda--namely, the lifting of the Iron Curtain. As the Western Foreign Ministers have pointed out, the problem of the Iron Curtain lies at the root of all other problems because it is the final key to peace.

DENVER, Nov. 15 (UP)--The state charged John Gilbert Graham today with the murder for insurance of his mother in a bomb plot that caused an airliner to crash, killing her and forty-three other persons.
The first air service operating into Moscow by a non-Communist carrier will start at the end of this year.
MOSCOW, Nov. 15--Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet party chief, had second thoughts tonight about remarks he made Saturday about France.

PAINTINGS by the once celebrated French artist Baron Gros (1771-1835) are rarely shown outside of France nowadays. So it is an event of some importance to have now, at Jacques Seligmann's, 5 East Fifty-seventh Street, an interesting selection of his portraits and battle pieces.

A numbers racket handling $500,000 in bets annually on the lower East Side was smashed yesterday, the police reported. Seven persons were seized in three well-planned raids and other suspects were being sought last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15--Colombia and other friends of France proposed today that the General Assembly delete the Algerian question from its agenda.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP)--Prices paid for most butchers hogs rose 25 cents a hundredweight today while sows were steady to 25 cents higher than yesterday. Part of the advance in butchers was lost by the close. Salable receipts totaled 10,000.

The Senate Agriculture Committee made a laudable decision in conducting the series of field hearings now in progress under the leadership of its chairman, Senator Ellender of Louisiana. Moreover, it would appear that the enterprise had already begun to show a profit.

The city's social agencies were criticized yesterday for selecting, "on a Park Avenue basis," those juvenile delinquents they chose to care for and for leaving the serious cases in the hands of the Police Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15--Syria proposed in the United Nations today that a new Palestine commission be set up to "emancipate" lands now held by Israel. Under the proposal these lands would be handed over to Palestinian Arab refugees.

THE final week of the Comedie Francaise opened last night with another double bill and another pair of classical comedies played with the Same exquisite perfection. The earlier impressions are all confirmed.
PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Premier Edgar Faure conceded today that elections might have to be postponed until January.

YONKERS, Nov. 15--A $700,000 increase in operating funds for the city's public schools was proposed today by City Manager Charles L. Curran in his budget request for 1956. This would raise the school appropriation to $6,431,000, as against $7,270,950 asked by the Board of Education.

The New York Adult Education Council will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the performance of "The Great Sebastians," with Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt in the leading roles, on the night of Jan. 31 at a theatre yet to be announced.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have been following the correspondence on the choice of probation staff in the Children's Court with interest. The National Women's Conference of the American Ethical union wishes to declare its opposition to the practice of appointing probation officers according to religious faith.
Two young women were killed yesterday in an office shooting in the main business section of Jackson Heights, Queens.
Glorious sound filled Carnegie Hall last night at the all-Wagner concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra led by Eugene Ormandy. Margaret Harshaw was soprano soloist.
MANILA, Nov. 15--A new and powerful figure has emerged on the Philippine political scene as a result of last week's election.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15 --Still a bit low in spirits after the disappointment of the defeat at Princeton, Yale got down to hard work today for the season's finale with Harvard in the Bowl Saturday.
BUFFALO, Nov. 15 -- Too many self-appointed experts in juvenile delinquency present the symptoms of the problem as its causes, the New York State Welfare Conference was told today.

HONOLULU, Nov. 15 (AP)-- Gov. Samuel Wilder King of Hawaii says he is supporting the Pacific Far East Lines' application to compete with the Matson Navigation Company in the Hawaii-West Coast freight run. But he says he doubts the Hawaii trade could support three lines.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 15--Premier David Ben-Gurion told the Knesset (Parliament) tonight that the offer of Prime Minister Eden in London that Britain mediate Israeli-Arab border disputes was unacceptable.

Daydreams for Students A daydream, says one dictionary, is a "visionary fancy in dulged in while awake." Daydreaming, generally speaking, has long been frowned upon by pedagogues; daydreamers in classrooms have been neither encouraged nor indeed tolerated (if caught indulging in their fancies).

TRENTON, Nov. 15--Gov. Robert B. Meyner made public today a "final" report of the state's investigation into the public activities of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman and his associates in the State Division of Employment Security.
Sharp denunciations of Communist designs in the Middle East were voiced last night at a rally in Madison Square Garden.

An American edition of James Laver's new book, "Victorian Vista," will be published tomorrow by Houghton Mifflin. Described as "a treasure house of Victorian art and manners," the volume presents "the elegance and artifice, the undoubting virtue and rebellious science of the paradoxical Victorians."

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 15 (UP)--Unbeaten Maryland, which has waited two years for a revengeful crack at Oklahoma, got its chance today when the Terps were named as the Atlantic Coast Conference representative to the Orange Bowl.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (AP)--The St. Louis Hawks set a team scoring record tonight with a blistering second-half attack to hand the New York Knickerbockers their first loss of the National Basketball Association campaign, 121-95.
The Republican state committees of New York and New Jersey disclosed yesterday that they had joined forces to sponsor the largest single political fund-raising event ever attempted.
Many football coaches are inclined to take themselves and their problems rather seriously. Michigan State's Duffy Daugherty isn't one of them.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 15 --Officials of the State and Defense Departments have assured Pakistani officials that there would be a "substantial" increase in United States arms aid to Pakistan.

Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross led fifty members of her citizens' advisory committee yesterday on a tour of the reconstructed facilities of the city workhouse for men on Hart Island. The Correction Department recently took over the island from the city Welfare Department to make a rehabilitation center for alcoholics.
Wall Street has succumbed on all fronts to the push-button age.
The State Insurance Department will open next Monday a new series of public hearings on the administration of welfare and pension funds.

TOKYO, Nov. 15--The New York Yankees said good-by to Japan as they ended a monthlong tour of this baseball-crazy island kingdom. The memory of their visit will linger long. As Casey Stengel led his American League champions aboard their special planes for Okinawa tonight, the Tokyo press hailed them as the best possible ambassadors the United States could have sent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Flying tanks, personnel carriers and artillery possibly may reduce the influence of terrain on combat by about 70 per cent by 1970.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--A public inquiry into the official conduct of Hugh W. Cross, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, was unanimously ordered late today by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

GENEVA, Nov. 15 (AP)--Following is the text of a four power declaration on disarmament proposed by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, today: (Translation from the Russian) Being guided by the desire to facilitate the lessening of international tension, strengthening confidence among states, eliminating the threat of war and reducing the burden of armaments.

Studebaker has longer, wider car bodies and increased engine horsepower in the 1956 line. The restyled new models were announced yesterday by the Studebaker division, Studebaker - Packard Corporation. They will go on display in dealer showrooms here next Tuesday.
The machinery was set in motion yesterday for bringing 1,750,000 unionists in this state into a unified labor organization.

COOSA PINES, Ala., Nov. 15 (AP)--House investigators visited the big plant of the Coosa River Paper Company today seeking a solution to the nation's growing newsprint problem of spiraling prices and a threatened shortage.

Al Kaline, Detroit Tigers' outfielder, and Mike (Pinky) Higgins, Boston Red Sox manager, received baseball honors yesterday. Kaline was named American League sophomore of the year and Higgins was selected manager of the year in the junior circuit after polls of the Baseball Writers Association of America members by The Associated Press.
Trial of a landlords' suit against constitutionality of state business rent controls resumed yesterday after Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck denied a mistrial motion.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The Administration has decided to hold back as much as 20 per cent of this year's world-wide economic and technical assistance funds appropriated by Congress.
Foreign investors are going to get a chance to buy stock in the Ford Motor Company.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 15--A New Jersey educator outlined today suggested courses of action for colleges and universities facing drastically increased enrollments.

CARL MORGAN, counsel for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), went down to the West Side docks the other day to pick up from Customs men an old rockingchair that, at first glance, seemed hardly worth the effort.

American Cyanamid An extra dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of 62 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Dec. 23, have been authorized by the American Cyanamid Company.
KARACHI, Nov. 15--For the second successive day political leaders of Pakistan have stirred opposition to a Government proposal for a joint electorate. Traditionally non-Moslems have voted separately.

The California Toll Bridge Authority announced yesterday plans for marketing $46,000,000 of toll revenue bonds to finance construction of a bridge across the Strait of Carquinez, separating San Francisco and Benicia.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 15--There is evidence that the standard of living of the average Czech citizen is lower today than before World War II.
PARIS, Nov. 15--A plea for subjecting the French economy to greater competition from foreign imports was made today by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15--Wheat and corn futures registered fail gains today. Short covering in both pits was supplemented by commission accumulation on the theory that bearish news developments have been overplayed for the present.
YONKERS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Pari-mutuel betting ended for the year in New York tonight when Yonkers Raceway finished its sixth season of harness racing.

Vincent Astor has sold the nine-story industrial building at 628-42 West Forty-fifth Street to Charles Benenson. The new owner leased the property to Schlossmans, Inc., operator of a chain of retail furniture stores in Manhattan, the Bronx and Jamaica, Queens.

IN the somewhat less than perfect world we live in most children by the age of 9 or 10 have known what it is to feel hate and fear, to have to fend off a bully, to stand up for their own or a little pal's rights, to battle with a conscience.
TORONTO, Nov. 15 (Canadian Press)--Charles Dennehy of the United States defeated Bob Ballard of Canada in the international fault-and-out stake at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Congress received today a set of taxation studies indicating that poorer families pay almost as much of their income in taxation as richer families.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America started yesterday a department of psychiatry. Its purpose is to acquaint "future rabbis with certain problems of the individual and the community as viewed by modern psychiatry."

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Nov. 15 --A plan to establish a division of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in Israel was unanimously endorsed here tonight by the biennial conference of the United Synagogues of America.

Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company yesterday declared an extra dividend of 25 cents and a quarterly dividend of 60 cents a share on the common stock. Both dividends will be distributed on Jan. 3 to holders of record on Dec. 3.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--Uneasiness over international affairs has disrupted Administration plans to ask Congress for a "rubber stamp" renewal of the Defense Production Act.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15 --Laura Lee Payne, former stage and film entertainer, will be the hostess of a television interview program that is expected to make its appearance on a national network soon.

Futures prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Rubber, cocoa, potatoes, soybean oil, zinc and silk eased; coffee, sugar, hides, copper cottonseed oil and onions were mixed, and wool and lead rose.

Now that bright chilly days alternate with cool rainy ones, the fireplace once again becomes a warm center of attraction. Advice on storing one essential ingredient for a good fire--the logs--comes our way from the Stavert Company, Inc., in Cambridge, Mass.
LONDON, Nov. 15--The stock market closed firm today, the last day of the current bookkeeping account. Buying of industrials was selective, a good bit of it being short covering.

INGENIOUS scarves, stoles and jackets are favorites this year with Miami designers. So are convertible separates that range from casual beachwear to glamorous "at home'' clothes. Cool cotton is worn everywhere, from cabana to cocktail parties.
More war refugees than she can count exactly call Mrs. Alfred T. Abeles their "American mother." The number is close to 300, she estimated yesterday.
Yesterday's Giant football luncheon at the Polo Grounds turned out to be a meeting between clubs that have a great deal of admiration for each other.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 15 (AP)-- Eastgate, owned by Mrs. Gene Markey's Calumet Farm and generally rated that outfit's leading Kentucky Derby prospect, became a stakes winner today when he scored impressively in the $15,000-added Spalding Lowe Jenkins.
RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 15--Energetic preparations to celebrate the return tomorrow of Sultan Mohammed Ben Yussef after two years in exile moved forward today.
The band played "Auld Lang Syne" late yesterday afternoon at the Jamaica track. The reason: it was the last day of the New York racing season, which had a 196-day run.

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that the awards in a libel action brought against Representative James G. Donovan were excessive, and that unless the plaintiffs agreed to accept reductions a new trial would be ordered.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The State Department announced today it had canceled a visa for Archbishop Boris of the Russian Orthodox Church to visit the United States.

An auction of rare stamps that is expected to be the largest of its kind ever held in this country began yesterday at the Ambassador Hotel. It is being conducted by H. R. Harmer, Inc., stamp auctioneers.
LONDON, Nov. 15--The Prime Minister rejected today a Laborite's suggestion that he recommend the appointment of a royal commission to study the relations between the state and the Church of England.
"Dragon's Mouth," a drama by J. B. Priestley and his wife, Jacquetta Hawkes, will have its American premiere at the Cherry Lane Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15--Fuel consumption in this country will be doubled during the next twenty years, it was predicted today at the annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute. Fuel oil and natural gas, according to Austin Cadle of the Standard Oil Company of California, will supply a major part of the fuel needed to keep the output of electricity expanding.

IT'S thirty-nine days until Christmas and 138 days before the opening of the local horse racing season. The blackest day of the year arrived yesterday, although the sun shone benignly and there was an invigorating bite to the crisp autumnal air. The cavalry posts hereabouts padlock their doors today, thus rendering homeless those get-rich-quick boys, the hoss players.
The painstaking preliminaries necessary to get a new dog breed into the stud book of the American Kennel Club came to a successful conclusion for Rhodesian Ridgebacks last week.

A portrait of Henry VIII by Hans Holbein the Younger is one of four rare paintings recently lent to the Metropolitan, Museum of Art for exhibition. The loan, from Baron Heinrich Thyssen of Lugano, Switzerland, will be on display today through Dec. 15.

YESTERDAY (Nov. 15, 1955) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee 1 (Political and Security)--Heard representatives of United States, Australia and Netherlands oppose Soviet proposal for new international conference on Korea.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized nonscheduled airlines today to operate up to ten flights a month on regular schedules.

MOST home cooks would have been completely unnerved last week if they had been in the shoes of Humbert Gatti, chef of the Plaza Hotel. He had to prepare lunch for twelve of New York's most exacting gourmets, members of La Comite de la Bonne Bouche of Les Amis d'Escoffier.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 15 -- The backbone of the once-powerful Peronist General Confederation of Labor was broken today.

New issues of public utility debentures and common stock totaling more than $35,000,000 will be offered for subscription today. The offerings are as follows: New England Telephone and Telegraph Company -- $30,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures due on Nov. 15, 1991, at 101.064 to yield 3.2 per cent, by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. and associates.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We read with great interest The Times' editorial of Nov. 11 entitled "The Voters' Lament," a timely and thoughtful facing of the questions before the voters on Election Day this year. The Liberal party released its recommendations on the amendments and Proposition No. 1 on Oct. 27.
Oklahoma, Maryland and Michigan State were still running 1, 2, 3 in The Associated Press' football poll yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, MO., Nov. 15 --Medical intelligence officers have applied the most stringent methods in searching for live virus in poliomyelitis vaccine manufactured since the disastrous Cutter Laboratory supply last spring.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP)--Ewart Potgieter, the plodding African giant who had squashed nine previous victims, came off with a ten-round draw against a Canadian, James Parker, tonight in his first real ring test.

Vassily Smyslov of Russia, the leader after twelve rounds in the international chess tournament at Zagreb, played a nineteenmove draw with Alberic O'Kelly de Galway of Belgium for a score of 8 1/2--2 1/2. Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia gained on Smyslov with two victories and a score of 8--4, according to a report received yesterday through Yugoslav sources.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Legislation to sharpen the effectiveness of criminal convictions under antitrust laws was demanded today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming.

GENEVA, Nov. 15 (Reuters) --Following are the texts of statements by Secretary of State Dulles on disarmament and EastWest contacts and of a Soviet proposal on the latter subject: FIRST STATEMENT Yesterday, the French delegation submitted a proposal which, after study, the United States was ready to accept had it been accepted by the Soviet delegation.

After taking some battering as a result of disappointing dividend news, the stock market yesterday overcame the pressure of a number of leading issues selling ex-dividend. While declines outnumbered advances, the industrial price average forged ahead vigorously.

The Virginia Day Nursery will gain from a preview on Friday evening of the CinemaScope film, "Good Morning, Miss Dove," with Jennifer Jones and Robert Stack at the Fox Little Theatre, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 -- The Catholic Women's League of Toronto stuck to its guns today in the face of a controversy over its campaign to get news dealers and bookshops to drop 300 books the league has labeled "objectionable."

ROBERT SCHOLZ' American Chamber Orchestra opened a new season last night at Town Hall. The ensemble is one of the best of its kind in the country and it was cheering to see that even without big-name soloists it drew an audience of more than 1,300.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- Striking Westinghouse Electric Company workers were promised today $500,000 in help from the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.
MOSCOW, Nov. 15--Norway reiterated to the Soviet Union tonight that she would refuse to give bases on Norwegian soil to her North Atlantic allies unless she were attacked or threatened.

THE second new ballet of the season of the New York City Ballet had its premiere at the City Center last night, in the form of Todd Bolender's "Souvenirs." To call it a ballet is perhaps to stretch the term.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa is on sound ground in criticizing policy under which the City Planning Commission drafted the 1956 capital budget on the assumption of voter approval of Constitutional Amendment No. 5, an assumption proved ill-founded when the returns of Nov. 8 were counted.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The "ex-Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies" of Peru, Leon de Vivero, in his letter published Nov. 10, reproaches The New York Times for omitting the name of the former newspaper La Tribuna of Lima in your editorial of Oct. 31 entitled "La Prensa, Still in Chains."
Adlai E. Stevenson's formal announcement of his Presidential candidacy had the effect yesterday of accentuating the division between Senator Herbert H. Lehman and other New York Democratic leaders.
A strike of 2,500 harbor tug and ferryboat workers employed by nine railroads was set yesterday for Monday at 12:01 A. M.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson's formal announcement of his candidacy touched off a variety of comment in Democratic quarters today, most of it friendly.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15--The United States requested an "early meeting" of the Security Council to consider pending applications for membership in the United Nations.
An influential Congressman yesterday advised American industry and labor not to expect legislative relief from foreign competition at the coming session.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 13 --One of the most important and least publicized stories in Asia is the fact of the economic survival of Pakistan, a nation that started with just about nothing as its economic birthright.

Store space in the Green Acres Shopping Center, now under construction on Sunrise Highway in Valley Stream, L. I., has been leased by Glenda Lyn Shops, Inc. The lessee, which operates a chain of women's sportswear and lingerie stores, opened its first Long Island suburban outlet in Freeport in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--A Federal judge ruled today that Congress had the power to question authors of books in United States libraries overseas to determine if they were members of the Communist conspiracy.
Japanese Ambassador Sadao Iguchi took sharp issue yesterday with increasing demands by United States manufacturers for restrictions on imports from his country.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15 --Twentieth Century-Fox demonstrated today its latest development in CinemaScope photography. Scenes were shown from "Carousel," which is in the process of production.
SFAX, Tunisia, Nov. 15-- French-Tunisian cooperation won a qualified victory today at the first legal congress of the NeoDestour party since 1938.
TOKYO, Nov. 15--Japan's new conservative party, the Liberal-Democrats, took over direction of the Government today.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 15-- President Eisenhower, "feeling fine," took his longest walk today since his heart attack Sept. 24. He prepared for a steadily increasing schedule of appointments that will bring most of the Administration's top officials to Gettysburg before Thanksgiving.

VIENNA, Nov. 15 (AP)--Poland announced today a trade agreement with Yugoslavia. The Warsaw radio said Poland and Yugoslavia had signed a protocol in Warsaw that would increase trade between the two countries in 1956 100 per cent over 1955.
The Union of South Africa took steps yesterday to borrow $50,200,000 to aid in the financing of its transportation development program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) --The Department of Agriculture said today Maine growers are dissatisfied with operation of the potato futures market but many dealers and shippers approve.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The denial of foreign-travel permits to citizens against whom charges have been made by informants not known to the State Department or the courts was examined today by the Senate Committee on Constitutional Rights.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Halfback Doak Walker of the Detroit Lions said today the growing use of face guards in the National Football League was sound evidence of dirty play in pro football.

The measured words with which Adlai E. Stevenson has announced that he is a candidate for the Democratic nomination next year mark the official beginning of the Presidential race. No one could have been surprised by Mr. Stevenson's statement that he is available; it has been apparent for many weeks that he intended to run.
The "spectacular" bug has nipped the producers, of a longestablished educational program on television.
Federal, state and city officials conferred yesterday on ways to combat the narcotics problem in the New York area.
Arbitrative machinery on a permanent basis has been set up for the first time in the longshore industry.
The Denver youth who has admitted planting the bomb that blew up a United Air Lines DC-6B evidently made a double mistake in taking out $37,500 worth of insurance on his mother.

GENEVA, Nov. 15--The last hope for even a fragment of accord on the improvement of East-West contacts was extinguished today in the final discussion of this subject at the Foreign Ministers' Conference.
George P. Monaghan, the New York State Harness Racing Commissioner, yesterday suspended Franklin E. Safford, a leading driver-trainer, and took disciplinary action against three other persons.
Christmas business in the nation's retail stores will be 5 per cent greater in dollar volume than last year's record holiday trade, Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., predicted yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15--In an atmosphere of strain and uncertainty, the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee ended today its consideration of the South-West African problem.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The fight of states as well as the Federal Government to punish for sedition was argued in the Supreme Court today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15-- Gwilyn A. Price, president of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, predicted today that use of electricity by residential customers will equal that of the nation's industry by 1973 for the first time in history.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The discerning editor who on Nov. 6 paused to applaud the American Cancer Society for "its decision to engage an international committee of fifty authorities in an appraisal of what has been accomplished in cancer research in the last ten years" should be applauded for a contribution of his own.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15--Adlai E. Stevenson formally announced today he would vigorously seek renomination in 1956 as the Democratic Presidential candidate.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 15--President Eisenhower today reaffirmed his Administration's willingness to enter into formal treaties with Israel and her neighbors to guarantee peace in the Near East. In a letter to Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, which Rabbi Silver read tonight at a mass meeting at Madison Square Garden in New York, General Eisenhower said he believed that true and lasting security in the area must be based upon a just and reasonable settlement.

ALTHOUGH Republican politicians have written their share of books in recent years, Democratic politicians have written more. Most of Franklin D. Roosevelt's lieutenants, mindful of the verdict of posterity, have been careful to put their best feet forward in their memoirs. And now, with a national election less than a year away, books by prominent Democrats are being prominently displayed in the bookshops.

PARIS, Nov. 15--Are four-power foreign ministers meetings worth while? It is fair to ask this question as the present Geneva conference draws to a dreary close. In the realm of negotiation it has accomplished nothing. It has served merely as a propaganda forum for statesmen drawn far from their offices and difficult normal work to make speeches they might have made at home.
The role of basic research in the solution of cancer, heart disease, mental ills and other major medical problems was stressed last night at a dinner conference sponsored by the American Foundation.
The Fire Department's winter campaign against hazardous use of kerosene stoves opened yesterday on the lower East Side.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16--Following is a transcript of the news conference held today by Adlai E. Stevenson. Because many of the reporters did not identify themselves, all questions following a reporter's name were not necessarily asked by him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The State Department refused today to tell Senate investigators who decided in 1953 to confiscate the diplomatic passport of a chief judge of the United States High Commission in Germany.

Larry Walz, Kansas-born pianist who made his local debut in 1949, gave his fifth New York recital last night at Town Hall. He played a formidable program culminating in Ravel's "La Valse," a work of fiendish intensity and awesome difficulty.
EIGHT American girls, aged 12 to 17, arrived in New York this week, neat, clean, propped out by petticoats, and a lot smarter than some of their elders.

Gov. Fred Hall of Kansas attempted last night to prescribe a formula for a Republican victory next year. In it the first ingredient was greater Republican support of President Eisenhower's philosophy and program.
Staggered working hours that would ease the concentrated demands on mass transit would help in the solution of the city's traffic woes, Patrick B. McGinnis asserted yesterday.

The Hudson, one of the lordliest of America's great rivers, is justly famed in the history and the literature of our country. Yet for much of its course it is treated by the citizens of New York not with the respect that is its due but as little more than an open sewer.
The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday the tentative budget requests of the four municipal colleges--City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens
Rather a Large Keepsake Numerous voices have of late been raised urging the preservation of the fabric of the Metropolitan Opera House, even if the company moves away to new premises.
The Transit Authority is considering carrying mail in the subway.

THE fact that many women find it difficult to resume, as individuals, their contacts with the outside world accounts for the success of the Human Relations Workshops at the New School for Social Research.
Isolated stock issues made considerable gains and Josses yesterday, but the market as a whole rose gently and subsided gently to close with a negligible loss.
Efforts of domestic groups to restrict competing imports were assailed yesterday by Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- Tobacco growers are feeling today a pinch in the rigid Federal price support system, that they long have believed fitted their crop so perfectly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--A Democratic leader declared today that the United States could not be governed by "a semi-retired chairman of the board; its President must be the President."
HaUiburton Oil Well Cementing Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $11,638,815, or $3.55 a share, in the first nine months of 1955, it was
The popular stereotype of the advertising man--he charcoal suit, the martini and casual disregard for home and family--is altogether wrong, according to a survey conducted by McCall's Magazine.

Defensive lapses cost the "new" Rangers a victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Broadway Blues carcied the fight to the world champions throughout the sizzling contest, and seemed headed for another surprising triumph over the invaders.

NEWARK, Nov. 16--Twentytwo young men who reported here on Monday for induction into the Army were dumfounded with joy when they were sent home again. They had passed a red light, or parked overtime, or had done something like that a couple of times.

Melissa Hayden gave her season's first performance of "The Cage" with the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night, and a vivid performance it was. This sharp and biting little ballet of Jerome Robbins to music of Stravinsky still has an impact to it, which Miss Hayden makes even more intense.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Nov. 12 in the column on foreign affairs by C. L. Sulzberger the following statement appears: "* * * The fallacy of the northern tier has already been demonstrated by Moscow's leapfrog arms deals in the Middle East.

GENEVA, Nov. 16 (UP)--The text of the three-power declaration on Germany follows: At Geneva, the foreign ministers of France, the United Kingdom and the United States of America tried to reach agreement with the Soviet Foreign Minister on what the four heads of government in July agreed were the closely linked problems of German reunification and European security.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 16--George M. Humphrey said tonight that "confidence in the integrity of the Government" was perhaps the major factor in the growing national financial stability that had given the country "unequaled prosperity."
VIENNA, Nov. 16--Austria has notified countries with which she has diplomatic relations of the text of her recent declaration of neutrality and asked them to recognize it.
A predawn explosion and fire aboard an Italian collier 1,200 miles northeast of New York set into motion yesterday the farreaching ocean-rescue network of the United States Coast Guard.

ONE brand of peanut butter or one luncheon meat outsells all competitors. Why do housewives buy it? Flavor preferences may be the answer, according to Dr. Jean F. Caul, senior chemist with the food division of Arthur D. Little, Inc., Cambridge, Mass.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 (AP)-- Grand Refrain won the $7,500added Pimlico Breeders' Stakes today as a sixteen-day meeting opened before a crowd of 11,204.
"The Lark," Lillian Hellman's adaptation of Jean Anouilh's "L'Alouette," which deals with Joan of Arc, opens tonight at the Longacre Theatre at 8 o'clock.

GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee 1 (Political and Security) --Heard statements by South Korea, Poland, China, Thailand, Turkey, Czechoslovakia and New Zealand in debate on Korean unification and rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 --A Senate subcommittee received documentary evidence today of attempts by the General Motors Corporation to cut off supplies of its Diesel engines from competing bus manufacturers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16 --Secret practice is the order of the day as Harvard points for the Yale game Saturday. Coach Lloyd Jordan continued heavy work in Harvard Stadium on muddy turf this afternoon. Then he switched to the enclosed practice field back of the stadium for a session under floodlights.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety -four cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 9:
ALBANY, Nov. 16 (AP)--The state's revenue from thoroughbred and harness tracks hit a record $63,319,002 for the 719 racing programs in 1955.
The Fire Department will set up soon as new system of "multiple -Alarm squads" to provide extra numbers of firemen and fewer pieces of apparatus on the scene.

The "cease-fire truce" between trucking interests and the Eastern railroads since early this year apparently is ended. A renewal of the costly, bitter and long-standing legal feud between the two industries threatens to break out again momentarily.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16--Adlai E. Stevenson agreed today to a voter test of his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination in the Minnesota preferential primary next March 20.

Bypassing the lily, Vanity Fair is gilding lingerie--and not in any cheap gold, either. Yesterday the concern announced that its holiday line included garments made of nylon tricot impregnated in 24-carat gold.

Two four-story apartments at 1580-1588 President Street in Brooklyn have been resold by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, to a client of Joseph H. Ginsberg, attorney. The property, containing a total of forty-eight apartments of three, four and five rooms, occupies a plot 140 by 100 feet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--Hugh W. Cross was expected in informed Senatorial quarters tonight to resign soon as chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission. This action, it has been authoritatively indicated, would result in quashing a pending Senate investigation of his official conduct.

David Oistrakh, Soviet violinist who arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for a six-week concert tour of this country, said he is "completely recovered" from the illness which prevented his scheduled performance with the London Philharmonia here last Sunday.

Rain, fog, drizzle and other components of a typical British winter took over here yesterday from what remained of the week-end's Indian summer. Although, according to the Weather Bureau, only one inch of rain fell in the twenty-fourhour period that ended at 7 P. M. yesterday, it came down so hard about 11 o'clock in several sections of the metropolitan area that sonic flooding ensued.

HOUSEWIVES conscious of tradition might turn to early American cookbooks in planning a menu for Thanksgiving. On a typically American holiday that invites gourmandism, why not revive this country's culinary past?
From time to time, note has been taken here of trophies at stake in traditional football games.
RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 16--Thousands of Moroccans welcomed Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef back to his throne today after two years of exile.

LONDON, Nov. 16--Despite a contraction of business volume, the stock market maintained its firmness today. Movements were generally in pennies and insignificant, but there were far more rises than falls.

GENEVA, Nov. 16--The Big Four foreign ministers conference ended in failure tonight. No agreement was reached on German unity and European security, on disarmament or on an improvement of East-West contacts. Nor was any date set for another meeting.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., Nov. 16 (AP)--Donald M. Campbell, the only man to pilot a speed boat wore than 200 miles an hour and live, broke his world record today by streaking his jetpowered Bluebird over Lake Mead at 216.2 miles an hour.
The Baltimore baseball Orioles and the Baltimore football Colts may be combined under the same ownership soon.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16--A team of young political veterans was disclosed here today by Adlai E. Stevenson to be the group that will guide his quest of the Democratic Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) --The Maritime Administration was asked today for suggestions to bring about increased participation by American-flag vessels in the movement of strategic minerals.
