CAIRO, Nov. 16--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser warned tonight that United States arms shipments to Israel would plunge the Middle East into an armaments race.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--Dr. John Oliver La Gorce, who has a mountain range, lake, glacier, weather station, rock formation, country club and golf course named after him, will receive a new honor tomorrow night.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16-- The headquarters of the General Confederation of Labor was seized tonight by tank-supported Argentine Marines.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Auguste Lecoeur, former No. 3 man of the French Communist party, was ousted from the party today after having spent twenty months in disgrace.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK YORK TIMES: Senator Paul Douglas in his letter of Oct. 18 answering Robert Wilson of Standard Oil cited the oil industry's own figures and the actual gas price movements in the field to prove that the Senator's high estimates of increasing consumer costs were not "fanciful."

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Chuck Spieser floored Paddy Young four times before he won by a technical knockout at 2:45 of the second round in their scheduled ten-round light heavyweight bout in the Chicago Stadium tonight.
OUT of a fictionalized situation, Mr. and Mrs. J. B. Priestly have written a civilized play, "Dragon's Mouth," which was well acted at the Cherry Lane last evening.
Prince Rainier III of Monaco will be the guest of honor as well as the patron of A Night in Monte Carlo, the imperial ball to be held Jan. 6 at the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

When Willie Hartack left the Laurel Race Course in Maryland at the meetings end on Tuesday and drove toward Pimlico to continue riding there, he had racked up 383 triumphs for 1955. He was the nation's leading jockey and he still had a month to go to increase his score.
New securities of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company and Wheeling Steel Corporation will be offered for subscription today as follows:

THE Kansas City Athletics have been accused of planting a spy, equipped with a surveyor's telescope, in their centerfield bullpen for the express purpose of stealing signs from enemy catchers and relaying the information to Kansas City batters. Manager Lou Boudreau, acting as spokesman for the defendants, denied the allegation--but not vigorously.
The city threatened yesterday to close twenty-five Manhattan and Brooklyn hotels within sixty days if they failed to comply with fire protection requirements.

After three weeks of vain debate the second Geneva conference has ended in total disagreement. As a result the "spirit of Geneva," which promised new hope to the world, has vanished into thin air, and the latest Big Power agreement embodied in the original Geneva directive has been thrown into the dustbin of history to join the many other compacts the Soviets have made and broken.
Two moves by separate sponsors highlighted the maneuverngs yesterday on television's checkerboard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--The Government today ordered an increase in the mill space to be reserved for production of copper -base materials. The purpose was to fill deliveries of copper and copper alloy products for military and atomic energy orders during the first quarter of next year.
LONDON, Nov. 16--Under a ruling of the Court of Appeals here today more than 400 members of European royalty are entitled to claim British nationality.
A team of United States amateur boxers is home from Europe with a word of warning for the 1956 Olympic team.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16--In another few years they'll do it with rockets--send mail and special cargo from New York to San Francisco in an hour or less.

It has been nearly fifteen years since the first century closed for the educational institution known first as St. John's College and later as Fordham. Opening day was in 1841, and the act of incorporation passed by the Legislature about five years later foresaw a future that has been well confirmed, "the said corporation to be in all respects an university."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) --Three Ohio researchers reported today that they had developed a "promising" new test for detecting cancer that had proved at least 90 per cent accurate in more than 1,700 cases.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) - Butcher hoss sold steady to 25 cents higher today as salable receipts at 11,000 head fell 5,000 below the advance estimate. Sows were strong to 25 cents higher.
HOW many of our Presidents were not born citizens of the United States of America? How many were born west of the Mississippi River? How many in Texas? In Ohio? In Virginia?

GENEVA, Nov. 16 (AP)--Following are the texts of the communique ending the Big Four foreign ministers conference and of a statement on disarmament drafted by the Western Big Three but not submitted to the conference:

Only a week after referendum rejection of Amendment No. 1 for $750,000,000 bond issue borrowing to finance highway construction in New York Governor Harriman and legislative leaders have met to take inventory. The question of what to do next was logically referred back to the State Commission on Highway Finance Planning, which will hold hearings and report by Jan. 15.
Mayor Wagner recommended yesterday that private builders be required to pay displaced tenants "a reasonable amount" to help them find suitable housing.

THE increasing cold, coupled with heavy snows in the north, has pushed the last of the lingering ducks and geese southward, and the weather man now offers no assurance that our mild weather will continue.

An order by K. L. M. Royal Dutch Airlines for eight Douglas DC-8 jet airliners was announced yesterday. K. L. M. thus became the first foreign airline to place an order for long-range jets. So far as is known, this country alone is producing jet transports with the range to cross the Atlantic non-stop in either direction.

GENEVA, Nov. 16--The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union opened their meeting here Oct. 27. The agenda for the conference was based on a directive issued by their four heads of government July 23.

KARACHI, Nov. 16--A Foreign Ministry spokesman declared today that Pakistan could make no military commitments to her allies unless the United States gave her more arms and related economic assistance.

The Brooklyn Dodgers were in the news on several counts yesterday. The world champions received congratulations from King Faisal of Iraq, Roy Campanella was named as the National League player making the greatest comeback in 1955 and Don Newcombe confirmed that he would demand a $30,000 salary in 1956.
Two new executives and four new trustees have been elected by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (UP)--The Montreal Canadians stretched their unbeaten string to nine games tonight as Maurice (Rocket) Richard capped a twogoal rally in the last period to give the National Hockey League leaders a 3-2 victory over the last-place Toronto Maple Leafs.
THE ELDER Craftsmen Shop, stocked with handmade items produced by persons 60 years and over who do their work more as a hobby than a vocation, opens today at 850 Lexington Ave.

The State of Massachusetts borrowed $159,791,000 yesterday on serial bonds maturing over fifty years. The obligations were sold to a syndicate or 239 bank and investment houses at an interest cost of 2.31155 per cent.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 80,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week's end total supplies were 152,084,00 barrels, compared with 152,004,000 a week earlier and 147,896,000 a year ago.
Directors of the Johns-Manville Corporation, proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the company's common stock.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Nov. 16 (AP)--Gen. J. Lawton Collins said today the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is "the greatest deterrent" to communism and he believed "we have convinced the Russians they could not quickly overrun'' Western Europe.
Viscountess Harcourt will be guest of honor and will open the thirty-fifth annual bazaar of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York in the ballroom of the Biltmore on Monday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16--Everything in Chicago's about the same. Same candidates. Same smoky rooms. Same cold and wind. Same arguments.
Mayor Wagner and spokesmen for welfare agencies endorsed yesterday the broad outlines of a proposed $12,000,000 Federal program to help fight juvenile delinquency.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 16-- The United States agreed today to sell Brazil $41,220,000 worth of surplus wheat and other farm products on what amounts to a forty-year credit.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16--A resolution asking the Security Council to agree to United Nations membership for eighteen applicants was introduced tonight. It was sponsored by twenty -five delegates to the General Assembly.
FOR families, that enjoy sharing do-it-yourself projects, work on Christmas gifts cannot begin too soon.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 16--The Israeli press applauded Premier David Ben-Gurion today for having rebuffed a British offer to mediate the Israeli-Arab border disputes. It took the attitude that he had scotched a plot against the nation's territory.

Tickets are still available for the Union Settlement's theatre party on Nov. 29. The Women's Auxiliary of the organization has taken over orchestra and mezzanine seats for the performance of "No Time for Sergeants" at the Alvin Theatre.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16--Dr. James B. Conant delivered to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today a letter from Secretary of State Dulles reassuring him of Washington's interest in Germany's reunification despite the failure of the Foreign Ministers' Conference.

Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, chess champion of the United States, drew last night with Vassily Smyslov, Soviet grand master, in the thirteenth round of the international masters tournament at Zagreb, according to a report received through Yugoslav sources.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press)--Charles Dennehy Jr. of the United States, riding Altmesiter, tonight captured the international jumping event at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show. He cleared the ten-obstacle course in a jump-off with a perfect performance in 40.5 seconds.

Future prices on the New York commodity exchanges were irregularly lower yesterday. Hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, silk, lead, zinc and onions eased; cocoa, coffee, burlap and copper rose, and rubber, wool and potatoes ended mixed.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 16 --Top leaders of the Soviet Union will arrive in India Friday. From the look of things now they should be contented tourists by the time they head for home.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16--Wheat and corn futures showed some strength in early trading today on the Board of Trade. But there was little follow-up buying and prices later declined to close below yesterday's final levels.

Bank of America Directors of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association have voted an extra dividend of 15 cents a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 28. The banking institution did not distribute an extra payment last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--A Pennsylvania lawyer told the Supreme Court today that his state could not wait "until blood runs in the streets" to stamp out Communist conspiracies.

A half century ago a young newspaper man named John Oliver La Gorce joined the staff of the National Geographic Society of Washington, D. C., then an obscure organization which published a slim scientific journal. The society now has a membership of 2,150,000 families scattered over the world.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 --Efforts by gangster elements to invade New York's garment industry, and the methods they use to intimidate truckers and shop owners, will be dramatized by Columbia Pictures in a movie titled "Garment Center."

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 16 --President Eisenhower had a "very quiet day" today. The Gettysburg White House marked time awaiting the arrrival of the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, from the justconcluded Big Four Foreign Ministers Conference in Geneva.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 16-- An 18-year-old British subject turned his back on a daily ration of grog in the Queen's Navy today when he chose to serve in the strictly dry United States Navy's men-of-war.
A senior investigator of the State Liquor Authority pleaded not guilty yesterday to a criminal information charging him with perjury.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16--A General Assembly committee today approved the first step in President Eisenhower's "action program for human rights."
ORIGINALITY combines with classic disciplines in the water-colors by Chi Kwan Chen at the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue.

With the younger generation's coonskin craze having subsided almost as quickly as it began, last night's return of Davy Crockett to television was a relatively quiet event. Parents apparently may have to grit their teeth through a few more choruses of that accursed ballad but otherwise the redoubtable Crockett now seems destined to be merely one of TV's many repertory players.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--Industrial production in October, after seasonal adjustment, was about the same as the record high level of September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Nov. 16 --A code of Synagogue practice, designed to establish moral and ritualistic standards for the 586 congregations affiliated with the Conservative Branch of American Judaism, was approved "in principle" here today.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 7 to 30 points (35 cents to $1.50 a bale) yesterday. The distant deliveries closed at the lows of the day. Trading was slow.
A former Baltimore police magistrate interrupted his trial in Kings County Court yesterday and pleaded guilty to seconddegree murder.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--A request from India for a loan of as much as $1,500,000,000 is considered a distinct possibility among high United States officials.
The New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission shut the door yesterday on the unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra began its first New York program of the season at Carnegie Hall last night with a tribute to Olin Downes. In memory of The New York Times music critic, who died last August, Charles Munch directed a heartfelt performance of Mozart's "Masonic Funeral Music."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- Israel formally asked the United States today to sell her arms "under the most lenient conditions of credit and price."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Charles E. Wilson said today the failure of the Geneva conference would have "little or no impact" on the defense program.
ALBANY, Nov. 16--Republican leaders of the Legislature promised today to support "a general tax relief program."
GENEVA, Nov. 16--Secretary of State Dulles flew home tonight to give President Eisenhower and the United States public a personal report on the Foreign Ministers' Conference.
PARIS, Thursday, Nov. 17-- The French National Assembly early today postponed debate on the issue of advanced elections.

The four-story store and apartment building at 1404 Third Avenue has been purchased by Edward Schwartz, who plans extensive alterations to the building. The property, in a lot 25 by 90 feet near Ninetieth Street, was purchased from S. Kalish and others. Edward L. Lane and Milton Ross were the brokers in the transaction.

GENEVA, Nov. 16 (Reuters) --Following are the text of the closing statement today at the Foreign Ministers' Conference by Secretary of State Dulles, excerpts from closing statements by Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, and Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, and the text of the closing statement by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister:
Some thrifty Brooklynites may soon be getting less interest on the money they put in savings banks and they may have to wait longer for it.
The synthetic rubber industry --born during World War II-- will have to bear most of the burden of meeting the world's fast-growing demand for rubber during the next five years.

NEW techniques in printmaking especially the development of large, color woodblock prints, have led an increasing number of painters to work in both mediums. The Brooklyn Museum, in recognition of the trend, will open to the public today an exhibition of paintings and prints by fourteen contemporary American artists who have made contributions in both fields.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) --The Army said today it had abandoned all plans to courtmartial three "turncoat" prisoners who chose communism after the Korean war only to return home earlier this year.
MOSCOW, Nov. 16--Mr. Khrushchev and Premier Bulganin will leave early tomorrow on a month-long trip to India, Burma and Afghanistan.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Joachim Alva, a member of the Indian Parliament, which appeared in your paper of Oct. 7, on the issue of Goa, as well as the challenge of the Indian leader, Jawaharlal Nehru, must be faced and answered honestly.
Party representation on upstate Boards of Supervisors, City Council and Boards of Aldermen has been substantially altered as a result of last week's local elections.

Russia again made it plain yesterday that if that curious political freak known in Moscow as the Mongolian People's Republic and more accurately as Outer Mongolia were not included in this year's United Nations membership "package deal" she would refuse to consider any other membership proposal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--The United States and Pakistan have agreed on the use of about $20,000,000 in United States assistance funds to improve Pakistani air bases, port facilities and highways.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--The Federal Reserve Board today approved an increase from 2 1/4 to 2 1/2 per cent in the discount rate at six of the Federal Reserve Banks. The six others are expected to follow soon.

Carmine G. DeSapio ruled out yesterday any attempt to exclude Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Mayor Wagner from the New York delegation to next year's Democratic National Convention because they might favor Adlai E. Stevenson.
Telling Dartmouth's players what they have been doing-- right or wrong--doesn't satisfy Coach Bob Blackman. He gives them the word--good or bad--in writing.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 --The scope of the proposed production code for TV film producers will cover just about everything from crime to commercials, it was learned today.

FINE embroidery, an art that declined with the advent of the machine, is undergoing a renaissance in home textiles. The embroidered surface appears on new collections of towels, table linens, curtains and bedspreads, and fabrics for draperies and slip covers.
Governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms yesterday elected James J. Lee, partner in W. E. Hutton Co., to be its next president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) --A Federal Trade Commission hearing examiner today recommended dismissal of a falseadvertising case against the manufacturer of the battery additive AD-X2 for lack of evidence.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17-- Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu said today that La Prensa, independent newspaper confiscated by the Peron Government in 1951, "will be returned to its rightful owners as soon as possible."
The "religious quota" system in appointing city probation officers for children was defended and opposed in statements from several quarters yesterday.

THERE never has been any controversy about Rudolf Bing's production of "Rigoletto." It was acclaimed by both critics and public when it was introduced in November, 1951. It was a hit through the next two seasons. And it was a hit again last night when it was restored to the repertory after a season's lapse.
Mayor Wagner has asked the Board of Education's Commission on Integration to submit to him by Jan. 1 recommendations for handling "this increasingly delicate problem" in the city's schools.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Nov. 17 --The "fashionable" appeal of religious affiliation constitutes a major challenge to church and synagogue in the United States today. This fear was voiced today by Charles Rosengarten of Waterbury, Conn., president of the United Synagogue of America.
TORONTO, Nov. 17 (AP)--The United States equestrian team gained the lead tonight in the international jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show with its third victory.
Details of the new pension and welfare plans for performers working in live television were announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17-- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey told the American Petroleum Institute here today that the Eisenhower Administration considers inflation "a public enemy of the worst type."
Thomas E. Murray, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, proposed last night that the United States detonate a hydrogen bomb before an audience representative of all the peoples of the world.
SFAX, Tunisia, Nov. 17-- Tunisia's nationalist movement turned its back today on extremist opposition to France.

It may be that the present collegiate football rules are here to stay--for at least another season. That appeared to be the story yesterday as the game-- 1955 version--received a significant bill of health from Lou Little, Columbia's coach.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17-- Peronist labor leaders yielded tonight to Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu's fiveday-old Government. The country's entire labor force was expected to be back at work tomorrow.
Arthur B. Bisguier, the United States champion, picked up a point in the international chess tournament at Zagreb last night, according to reports from Yugoslavia.

Commodity futures closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges in generally dull trading. Rubber, cottonseed oil, cocoa, coffee, sugar, onions, zinc and silk were mixed; potatoes and burlap eased, and soybean oil, hides, wool and copper rose.
Oswald D. Heck declared himself in favor of a state compulsory automobile liability insurance law last night.

On June 15, 1951, the New York Yankees gave up on a lefthanded pitcher, Tommy Byrne, the wild man of the American League. They had persisted with him, season after season since 1940, despite his erratic course and lack of control.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The Democratic National Committee today unanimously recommended abolition of the party "loyalty oath." The oath is offensive to some Southern Democrats.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 17 --Secretary of State Dulles gave President Eisenhower a ninetyminute report today on the Foreign Ministers' Conference in Geneva.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 17-- President Eisenhower's physicians, reported today that the general's recovery from his heart attack "continues to progress most satisfactorily without complications."

The nation's food processors were urged yesterday by Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, to get prices down through increased efficiencies in manufacturing and distribution.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (UP) --The Reciprocity Club tendered to Connie Mack his customary birthday party tonight, but his broken right hip kept him from attending.

Almost every week recently the American Stock Exchange has been breaking an eighteenyear record for new listings. Thus far in 1955 it has approved sixty-one new listings, against forty-three for all of 1954, thirty-four for 1953 and forty-five for 1952.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Economic experts here expressed the view, vigorously backed by political observers, that India was not likely to raise $1,500,000,000 in the free world. Certainly, it was said, there is no prospect of persuading any United States Government agency or Congress to make so large a loan so long as Prime Minister Nehru led her in the ways of neutralism.
The Fire Department will begin an inspection Monday of every lodging house in the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Senate investigators received evidence today that the Attorney General's "list of subversive organizations" had been misunderstood in its application in loyalty cases in many parts of the country.
Jack Goldsher observed the fortieth anniversary of Altro Workshop yesterday by doing a full day's work as a presser.

More picnic areas on highways, anti-litter slogans on containers and the use of waste receptacles as standard equipment in autos were among the suggestions made at a Keep America Beautiful meeting yesterday.

Loans outstanding on the books of leading New York City banks climbed $118,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the fourth weekly rise in a row, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17--Adlai E. Stevenson was off and running at high speed tonight for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
The release last week of a constructive report on the Chemical Corps of the Army may cost us heavily in the battle for men's minds.
The carpet industry in this country will produce more than 95,000,000 square yards of carpet this year, a new high record and 12 per cent above last year's level.

Operations of the General Dynamics Corporation and subsidiaries for the nine months ended Sept. 30 resulted in a net profit of $13,754,390, equal to $2.74 a common share, according to the report released yesterday by John Jay Hopkins, president.

TUNG KWONG - KWONG, the Chinese pianist who made her debut here in 1953, returned to Town Hall last night for her second New York recital, As in her debut, she impressed as quite a talented pianist, and one noted considerable artistic development in the last two years.

The monthly index of industrial production of the Federal Reserve Board for October maintained, and slightly shaded, the high level reached in September on a seasonally adjusted basis. That level was represented by the figure 142, which means that the rate of industrial activity is running 42 per cent above the average for the three-year "base" period, 1947-49.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17--The Democratic party rally here is a pleasant social gathering, not unlike the mattress manufacturers' convention, on another floor of the same hotel--but it has very little political significance.

The complete disagreement which ended the Geneva conference must now be expected to result in an intensified disagreement between East and West, in which three areas assume primary importance. The first and foremost of these is Germany, which was the principal issue on which Geneva split.
Rocky Graziano told a Senate subcommittee here yesterday that "the mothers and fathers are to blame" for juvenile delinquency. He added, however, that field work could help to combat it.
The Egyptian cargo-passenger liner Khedive Ismail is due in New York late this afternoon, but will be delayed reaching her dock because of a planned security search by Federal officials.

Three former patients of Wassaic State School named eighteen staff members yesterday as having struck them or other patients in their presence. The accused included a physician, two teachers, a matron and fourteen attendants.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17--A fourth section of the projected Baltimore harbor tunnel was launched today at the Maryland Shipbuilding and Drydock Company's plant. Workmen burned away restraining plates and the 300-foot steel segment slid down the ways sidewise, throwing up tons of water.

The Electric Bond and Share Company declared yesterday a dividend of 65 cents on the common stock, the first cash declaration since 1917. The dividend will be payable Jan. 3, 1956, to holders of record Dec. 9. Including a dividend paid in United Gas common during the first half, this brought the year's declarations to $1.25 a share.
The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation has voted a dividend of 75 cents on its common stock, payable on Dec. 20. In the previous quarter the company paid 60 cents and prior to that 50 cents.

AT the Jerusalem Art Center, newly opened at 100 West Fifty-seventh Street, twenty prominent Israeli artists are represented in a show designed to give a general idea of creative activity in Israel today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Between your editorial "The Explosive Middle East" and Hanson Baldwin's column of Nov. 11 The Times reveals a short memory of history and a perplexing system of logic.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Nov. 17 (AP)--Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Adlai E. Stevenson are the leading candidates for the 1956 Presidential nominations in the view of most delegates attending the Associated Press Managing Editors Association convention here.

The sorry mess into which the past and present Administrations had allowed passport policy to fall in recent years is getting a belated airing at this week's sessions of the Senate Committee on Constitutional Rights. Had it not been for two important decisions of the Federal Court of Appeals last June, forcing the State Department to liberalize its passport procedures, the situation today would presumably be worse than it is.
LONDON, Nov. 17 --A quiet investment demand kept prices firm in the stock markets today. British Government loans made small gains.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 16--President Jose Figueres said today he would resume his office Dec. 5, two months after he had turned it over to the Vice President, Dr. Raoul Blanca Cervantes.
A leading industrialist lashed out yesterday against proposals to require Federal rather than state charters for some corporations.
Willie Pastrano, a 19-year-old New Orleans light-heavyweight, will meet Joey Rowan of Phoenixville, Pa., in a scheduled tenround bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Turkey-in-the-Round If the present trend continues this may well be the last Thanksgiving for the turkey-inthe-round. A glance through any supermarket will show that increasing attention is being paid to sections and to miniatures.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 17 --Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today that the Administration now was "leaning toward" a pay-as-you-go plan for financing a $25,000,000,000 national highway building program.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 17 (AP) --J. Addington Wagner, national commander of the American Legion, accused the Fund for the Republic today of giving "comfort to the enemies of America."

The eyes of the fans and of television and movie cameras seldom are focused on the real key man in a football game-- the center. Yet he is the man upon whose skill in handling the ball every play depends.

Kendall Company Kendall Company, maker of textile specialties, has reached an agreement on the acquisition of Andrews-Alderfer Company of Akron, Ohio. The latter manufactures foam-fabric materials and licenses other concerns to make them.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 15--According to Government authorities, the industrial production of Czechoslovakia has more than doubled since World War II. This statement is bolstered by recent estimates of coal and steel production.

Kermit Bloomgarden disclosed yesterday that beginning Dec. 26 the price of orchestra seats at "The Lark" for Monday through Thursday evening performances would be raised, regardless of the critical reception accorded the production.

A Queens County grand jury charged yesterday that unlicensed money lenders there had taken advantage of loopholes in the state usury laws to wring "unconscionable" profits from financially distressed homeowners.
AN interesting as well as traditional Thanksgiving dinner, designed to meet moderate food budgets, will cost $8 for six people, Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon estimated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Condition of weekly reporting member banks in central reserve cities:

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with gains of 3 to 14 points (15 to 70 cents a bale), yesterday. This was 1 to 15 points below the best levels, established just prior to the close.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Secretary of State Dulles said today on his arrival from the Foreign Ministers' conference that he would report to the nation tomorrow on whether it should expect a return to the "cold war."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 796,632 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This total for the week which included Election Day and Veterans Day (Nov. 11) was 12,077 cars or 1.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--A lawyer for the Communist party asserted in the Supreme Court today that the Internal Security Act of 1950 was an unconstitutional attempt to destroy a lawful political party.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 17-- The Director of the Budget said today after a conference with President Eisenhower that the Administration still hoped to balance the budget in both the current fiscal year and the next.

The Lloyd Court Apartments at 982-990 Amsterdam Avenue and 200 West 109th Street have been sold by Lloyd Court Apartments, Inc., to an investing syndicate headed by S. Michael Walzer. The six-story building, on a corner plot about 100 by 100 feet, contains seven stores and fortythree apartments.
PARIS, Nov. 17--The French Assembly virtually buried tonight proposals to hold new elections and opened the possibility of a Cabinet crisis.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 17 (UP)--Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall, the young stars who recently refused professional offers from Jack Kramer of the United States, today gained the men's singles final in the New South Wales championships.

The representative assembly of the Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. O., approved arrangements last night for a membership vote Dec. 15 and 16 on Whether to fight the dismissal of members discharged from their jobs for invoking a constitutional privilege in Communist inquiries.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 17 (AP)--An Air Force transport plane, en route with fourteen aboard to the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada proving ground, crashed today in the snow-cloaked Charleston Mountains.
Salary rises ranging from $250 to $3,250 a year were voted by the Board of Estimate yesterday for 110 political jobholders in administrative posts of secondary rank.

THE New York City Ballet at the City Center last night gave the season's first performance of the BalanchineStravinsky-Noguchi "Orpheus," certainly one of the uniquely beautiful theatre works of our time.

ALTHOUGH the story of St. Joan is old, the spirit is endlessly new. Lighted by the radiance of Julie Harris, it is magnificent again in Jean Anouilh's "The Lark," which was acted at the Longacre last evening.
Greater encouragement of private free enterprise was urged yesterday for all nations seeking the most effective means of substantial economic progress.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 (UP)-- Freedom Parley, D. G. Ross' 5year-old gelding, gained his third straight victory today, scoring by a length and a half at Pimlico.

Kings County Trust Trustees of the Kings County Trust Company, Brooklyn, have recommended a two-for-one split of the authorized and outstanding stock and a 10 per cent stock dividend on the new shares, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17--Further declines were registered early today in grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade. The market dropped without much resistance early, but later met some commission accumulation which steadied prices and started some short covering.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 17--An assassin shot and slightly wounded Premier Hussein Ala today in the Shah Mosque.

California irrigation districts announced yesterday plans to borrow $10,500,000 on revenue bonds maturing in 2004 to finance dam construction. The bonds are to be offered at public sale on Nov. 30. They will be dated July 1, 1955 and will come due on July 1, 2004.
PARIS, Nov. 17--A Soviet architect expressed today lively indignation over efforts made here and in New York to "save" him from return to his homeland.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 --Henry Fonda has purchased from Seton I. Miller a Western story called "The Staked Plains" in which the actor will portray a frontier physician.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 17-- Leading poliomyelitis specialists have pronounced the Salk polio vaccine safe and effective. They have decided it has a few factors that may be improved in the near future.

PARIS, Nov. 17--The Federal Republic in the first half of this year attained the highest level of production ever reached in Germany, according to a report issued today by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation. The agency, Europe's administration body for handling aid under the Marshall Plan, said that West Germany's rate of expansion of output in the period covered was unsurpassed in Europe.

Radio Corporation of America is offering holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for $100,000,000 of new long-term debentures convertible into the company's common shares at a conversion price of $50 a share for the common stock.

The Sterling Investing Corporation has purchased the sixstory apartment house at 432-4 East 149th Street, the Bronx, in an all-cash deal. The seller was Murray Vernon. The building contains twenty apartments and a store.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 9 per cent above those in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

AROUND noon today Charley Scherzinger will board a West-bound plane at La Guardia Airport to go live with his grandchildren in San Marino, in California. He will leave with a glow and with the good wishes of his customers in his ears.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 17 (AP) --The Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission today suspended the co-managers of the world lightweight champion, Wallace (Bud) Smith, and said it expected the action to be recognized nation-wide.
Bolero, one of America's famous racing yachts, has been sold. She will sail under the Swedish flag in next season's Bermuda race. The race will begin June 16.

American newspapers' average stocks of newsprint hit a twenty-two year low in October as consumption during the month continued at a record rate, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 17 --India may have to delay her industrial development programs by at least one year unless she gets large-scale foreign loans.

GENERAL ASSEMBLY Assembly approved report of Credentials Committee which seated Nationalist China; also heard representatives of Britain, United States, Soviet Union, Equador, Australia, Iraq, Denmark, Netherlands, Canada, Belgium, Thailand, Sweden, El Salvador and India in debate on proposed Charter review conference.
An unusual advertising campaign of the General Electric Company is beginning to get results.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 17-- The West German Government has instructed its parliamentary whips to throw the armament program into high gear in response to the intransigent Soviet position on Germany's reunification.

Final plans for the twentieth annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball were made yesterday at a tea given in the home of Mrs. Thomas J. Watson of 4 East Seventy-fifth Street. Present were members of the committees and the mothers of the debutantes.

Commissioner Vincent A. G. O'Connor of the Department of Marine and Aviation yesterday attacked proposals that New York City turn over its waterfront facilities to the Port of New York Authority for development and operation.

ONCE upon a time there was a sports writer whom we'll call Bill. He was a brilliant statistician and historian but a quixotic, undependable chap in many respects. Just before the Yale-Harvard game of some twenty years ago he frowningly approached his boss.

Premier Bulganin and Communist party chief Khrushchev have departed on their tour of South Asia, which is scheduled to take them to India, Burma and Afghanistan. Officially, this is a goodwill mission, in part returning the visits to Moscow made by Prime Minister Nehru and Premier Nu of India and Burma, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Israel has asked the United States to sell her forty to fifty late-model jet aircraft, a number of vessels for use against submarines, heavy tanks, antitank guns and anti-aircraft weapons.
Mayor Abba Hushi of Haifa, Israel, received here yesterday $750,000 in Israel bond subscriptions to aid that country's economy.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 17 (UP) --Nebraska's football coach, Bill Glassford, resigned today and charged that persons who wanted him dismissed had subjected even his wife and son to "verbal abuse."
A former New York Telephone Company employe testified yesterday that in 1954 an early this year he tapped man lines under the direction of John G. (Steve) Broady.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 17--Chin Peng, the young Malayan Communist party leader, agreed tonight to negotiations with the Federation of Malay regime for an end of the 8-year-old jungle war.
Prospects that Proposition One was approved in the recent state-wide election rose sharply yesterday with the first returns from the official count of votes.
The Port of Los Angeles has undergone a major reformation since its longshore labor production was termed the worst in the nation last month at Congresssional hearings.

In a world in which worldliness often seems to be in danger of getting the upper hand it is gratifying to learn what has been happening at Harvard Divinity School. This school, which had existed as a separate department at the university since 1816, fell into a decline through undernourishment.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 17 (UP)-- The New York Knickerbockers trounced the Fort Wayne Pistons, 110--88, tonight in a National Basketball Association game at Memorial Auditorium.

Mr. Murray's Address The text of the address by Thomas E. Murray, member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, at the Golden Jubilee dinner of the Fordham Law School at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night follows: A major purpose of these remarks is to make a proposal that has long been one of my principal objectives as an Atomic Energy Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)-- Northern New Jersey railroad commuter fares today were ordered increased for trips within the state and decreased for interstate trips on three railroads that do not offer Hudson River crossings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Strict reciprocity is likely to rule United States exchanges of technical and scientific delegations with the Soviet Union as a result of the impasse reached in Big Four talks on East-West contacts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17--The Soviet Union declared today that the United Nations Charter "is fairly satisfactory." The only thing the United Nations needs is to have all members, "and primarily the United States," start observing it, the Soviet spokesman said.

Mrs. Charles Keller Jr. received yesterday the seventh annual Lane Bryant award for individual community service. As president of the Urban League of Greater New Orleans, she was instrumental in the establishment of a non-segregated housing unit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Following is a statement in reply to Mr. Murray issued tonight by Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, and Dr. Frank Willard Libby, Dr. John von Neuman and Harold S. Vance, members: The remarks by Mr. Murray about security and classification of information are consonant with the views of the commission.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP)--Much larger receipts than expected caused average and top hog prices to drop today to new lows since early 1942. Losses ranged from 25 to 75 cents a hundredweight on butchers while sows were down about 25 cents.
Weakness in the final thirty minutes of yesterday's stock market resulted in a moderate loss for the day.

Stockholders of the Childs Company yesterday approved purchase of the Plaza Hotel here and the lease of three out-oftown hotels. They also voted to change the company's name to the Hotel Corporation of America and to increase the authorized common stock to 3,000,000 shares from 1,600,000.
YONKERS, Nov. 17--A new $4,445,000 arterial highway crossing the Bronx-Yonkers boundary and reaching into the business center of this city was proposed today by the State Department of Public Works.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposal of the Manhattan Borough President's office to widen either Pearl or Water Street to ninety or a hundred feet between the Battery and Canal Street should be dismissed as an impractical suggestion.

GENEVA, Nov. 17--The Soviet Union is expected to concentrate its diplomacy on West Germany in the next year. Moscow evidently will try to convince the Germans that the unification of their country is politically feasible and economically profitable.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17-- If the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company sign a proposed merger agreement, they will be hailed into court without ado on charges of violating antitrust laws, it was stated today.

A large mid-month increase in float--credit extended by the Federal Reserve to member banks to cover checks delayed in collection helped ease the reserve positions of member banks throughout the country, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

NOUASEUR, French Morocco, Nov. 13--Construction work on all United States air bases in North Africa has been virtually completed and Washington is preparing to undertake vast projects on the Asiatic mainland.

Two armed hold-up men took a total of $7,690 from a supermarket and a dress manufacturer in two hold-ups in Brooklyn yesterday, and escaped. In Manhattan a man armed only with a butcher knife took $477 from a liquor store near Times Square but was captured a block away.
THE deer season will open in the Catskills on Monday, and reports from Sullivan, Greene and Ulster Counties indicate an unusually large deer herd.

BOSTON, Nov. 17--The New England Governors adopted resolutions today urging Federal flood damage insurance. The action was by four of the Governors and representatives of the other two in a session incidental to the opening of the thirty-first annual New England Conference.

Long standing differences between the leading harness horse governing organizations of the nation were brought into the open here yesterday at the second annual meeting of the Harness Tracks of America.

THE redoubtable Pierre Monteux, who was the conductor at the Metropolitan Opera's opening last Monday, was on the podium at Carnegie Hall directing the New York Philharmonic last night. Was Mr. Monteux, who is 80, weary? Not at all.

Robert T. Stevens, former Secretary of the Army, added his voice yesterday to those of other textile industry leaders seeking Government action to stem the growing volume of Japanese fabric imports. Mr. Stevens, who returned recently to his post of president of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturer, spoke at a luncheon given in his honor by he Textile Section of the New York Board of Trade in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Mr. and Mrs. Chester H. Tipton of 25 East End Avenue and Edgartown, Mass., will give a tea dance on Dec. 17 in the Penthouse of the New Weston to honor their debutante daughter, Misss Gail Dixon Tipton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--The proposed new proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission came under heavy fire today at an open hearing before the commission. Five witnesses expressed their criticisms, most of them arguing that the new rules go much too far in trying to curb abuses in proxy fights.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh advocated yesterday a "public health approach" to the problem of drug addiction. He urged that the courts be empowered to exercise "long-term" supervision over all known addicts through a public health agency.
The Temporary State Commission of the Courts came to grips yesterday with its most controversial problem.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Adlai E. Stevenson would not tell the reporters in Chicago yesterday how he will conduct his campaign for renomination, not because he was coy or evasive but because in the nature of his case he could not. He doesn't know, which is why he said that so often.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--The sale of the Euclid Road Machinery Company of Cleveland to the General Motors Corporation came under fire today at a Senate hearing.

More than 500 persons attended the first public stockholder meeting of the eighty-sixyear-old Campbell Soup Company yesterday in the Walt Whitman Hotel, Camden, N. J. The company was a privately owned concern until its common stock was placed on sale a year ago.

Late Autumn Walk There are people who walk briskly through field and wood in this crisp. November weather without pausing to linger at the favorite woodland pool. After all, they think, the beauty is gone from this place, drained away with the color from the leaves.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The United States and Britain "see eye to eye on the imperative necessity" of resolving the Middle Eastern crisis but not necessarily on the methods that should be used.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-The Civil Service Commission's appeals office upheld the dismissal of Dr. Frank S. Home as adviser on minority problems to the Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.

Though a sharp division exists in both parties people seem most of the time to be much more conscious of the conflicts within Republican than within Democratic ranks, perhaps because rebellious Democrats are pretty well confined to one area --the South--where they will almost always end up by voting Democratic anyway.
The schools of today are not what they used to be.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board has proposed to require all airlines to install flight recording devises on their planes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the past this writer has been critical on occasion of The Times' stand on the German problem. It is therefore with pleasure that he calls attention to the general excellence of Thomas J. Hamilton's article of Nov. 13.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18 (AP)--The Federal grand jury indicted a Kansas City attorney today on a charge of perjury. It accused him of giving false testimony about a $10,000 payment that the Government contends was used to bribe public officials.
Referee Simon H. Rifkind began consideration last night of contempt of court charges against the International Longshoremen's Association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The controversy centering on appointments of probation officers to the Domestic Relations Court has no doubt brought the lack of these workers to the much-needed attention of the public.
The lack of educational and social services for mentally retarded children was pointed up yesterday to members of the State Joint Legislative Committee on Mental Retardation.
SEATTLE, Nov. 18 (AP)--The Army identified the following dead today after the Seattle air crash:
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (AP)--The magazine Kommunist, bible of word Communist theory, has quietly changed chief editors without any explanation.

DENVER, Nov. 18 (AP)--John Gilbert Graham asserted in a jail cell interview today he had not planted a time bomb on the Unied Air Lines that exploded Nov. 1 and killed his mother and forty-three other persons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Senate Internal Security subcommittee has scheduled three days of closed hearings in New York next week in a continuation of its investigation of Communist infiltration of the press.

Parent-teacher groups from the city's five boroughs swarmed to City Hall yesterday. Their purpose was to ask the Board of Estimate to authorize school construction and modernization projects omitted from the City Planning Commission's proposed 1956 capital budget of $1,791,736,036.

PARIS, Nov. 18--The Geneva conference made it blatantly clear that Germany cannot be reunited under Big Four auspices for a long while to come. Moscow is not going to yield the East Zone under present circumstances. Instead it counts on the wane of Adenauer's influence and pressure inside the Bonn Republic for bilateral negotiations with the Soviet puppet Government at Pankow.

The United States should send teams of experts to friendly countries of Asia to help them plan for modern rebuilding, Sylvester L. Weaver Jr., president of the National Broadcasting Company, suggested yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 18 --Rice hoarding and soaring salt prices precipitated widespread disorder and threatened famine today in the densely populated delta area of East Pakistan.

The leaders of the two divisions of the National Basketball Association, the New York Knickerbockers and the St. Louis Hawks, will meet at Madison Square Garden tonight. Holy Trinity High School and St. Peter's of Staten Island are paired in the preliminary game scheduled to start at 7:20.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Home Loan Bank Board has sent a letter to the regional Home Loan Banks that has the effect of relaxing somewhat the tight credit restrictions imposed by the board Sept. 8.
PARIS, Nov. 18--The French Government decided today to attempt to meet the conditions set by Parliament for new elections in January.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18--Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov returned here today from the Geneva Foreign Ministers' Conference. He spent one night en route in East Berlin, where he conferred with leaders of the East German Communist regime.

VIENNA, Nov. 17--In the first year of her new five-year plan, which will begin in 1956, Hungary will invest 31 per cent more in industry as a whole but shorten her investment in consumer goods industries by 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--Corporation profits before taxes reached the record rate of $44,000,000,000 a year in the third quarter of this year, the President's Council of Economic Advisers estimated today.

LONDON, Nov. 18--General purpose synthetic rubber is to be manufactured in Britain on a sizable scale for the first time. Production is expected to start in 1958 and it is expected that the initial output will be about 50,000 tons a year.
An attempt to teach "responsibility" to waterfront unions here--through the means of a $300,000 damage suit--is causing concern to the port's tugboat industry.

Another phase of the complicated process of modernizing Third Avenue is under way between 116th and 128th Streets, and between Fiftieth and Seventieth Streets. This is the widening of the roadway from its present width of sixty feet to seventy feet.
Interfaith services and aid to the needy will be features of the religious observance of Thanksgiving Week here.

NOTHING is more hidebound than the traditions that surround a wedding. But this year American florists have kicked over the traces. Fresh ideas in bridal bouquets have produced the first real "something new" in many seasons to carry down the aisle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--Average primary market prices declined 0.1 point in the week ended on Tuesday to 111.1 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products and foods were responsible for the decline in the index.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 18 (UP)--President Eisenhower's appointments to the N. L. R. B. were regarded as compromise choices in a reported contest between liberal and conservative Republican factions to fill the Farmer vacancy.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18--Israel turned down today suggestions that Palestinian Arab refugees should have the choice of returning to their homes or receiving compensation.

LONDON, Nov. 18--The United States Government is expected to announce tomorrow the assignment of Admiral John Cassady and Waldemar J. Gallman, United States Ambassador to Iraq, as official observers to the Baghdad treaty talks that open in Baghdad Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Eisenhower Administration has intervened in the case of Hugh W. Cross, whose conduct as chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission is under Senate scrutiny. The Department of Justice has asked the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations to hand over its transcript of secret testimony in its preliminary inquiry into Mr. Cross' behavior.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 18 --There is growing evidence of a creeping neutralism in Thailand, long considered the strongpoint of the free world in southern Asia.
American Jews were urged yesterday to exceed "all their imposing records of philanthropic generosity" by undertaking the major burden of Israel's immigration and resettlement programs.
President Eisenhower's role, a major one throughout the nation, will become a supporting part on the "Alcoa Hour" telecast a week from tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- President Eisenhower pledged tonight a continuing drive to establish "a just and durable peace" despite the failure of the Foreign Ministers' Conference in Geneva.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 18 -- Bumbling "do-it-yourselfers," photographers and people who like to use chemicals without reading the labels were accused today of making homes as dangerous as highways.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (UP)-- Clever riding by John Choquette helped Nance's Lad, 3-10, gain his eighth victory of the year today in the Dark Star Purse at Pimlico.
Broadway welcomed a new stage hit yesterday -- Kermit Bloomgarden's production of "The Lark," the Joan of Arc drama adapted by Lillian Hellman from Jean Anouilh's French work, "L'Alouette."
The stock market, as measured by The New York Times averages, has been pushing to historic high levels of late in a much less spectacular manner than was the case earlier this year.

MIAMI, Nov. 18 (AP)--Miami's fullback, Don Bosseler, rammed through Alabama's line for three touchdowns tonight to lead the Hurricanes to a 34-12 victory over the Crimson Tide. It was Miami's fourth straight victory.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Nov. 18 (AP)--The Associated Press Managing Editors Association today adopted a resolution condemning "governmental secrecy that is withholding from American citizens facts about their own Government that they are entitled to know."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- Harvey O'Connor, author of books about millionaires, was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $500 today for contempt of Congress. Federal Judge Joseph C. McGarraghy suspended the prison sentence, however.
Close to 300,000 football followers will gather for four of the title games today as the season comes to an end in the East, Middle West and Far West for all but a few college teams.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 (AP)--Paul Crouch, former Communist who had been a prominent witness in many Smith Act trials in recent years, died today at the University of California Hospital, where he had been under treatment for lung cancer.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18--An indictment charging five persons and five business organizations with using the mails to operate a charity racket was returned by the Federal grand jury today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday a decision revoking the brokerdealer registration of R. H. Johnson Co., and a controlled corporation, R. H. Johnson Co., Inc., for alleged fraudulent performance in handling the accounts of six customers.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Sixth-ranked Michigan boasting its finest physical condition of the season, is a 6-point choice to beat Ohio State tomorrow and win the Big Ten football championship and a trip to the Rosa Bowl.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP)-- Mme. Maria Meneghini-Callas boarded a plane here today and left in her wake an angry tangle of process servers.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 15--An old Cambodian desire for an ocean port on the Gulf of Siam is being realized through French and United States economic assistance totaling about $25,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Air Force, having conquered the sound barrier, began testing today the first plane designed to challenge the thermal barrier.

A background of silver and sapphire decorations enhanced with rows of stylized trees bearing glittering stars provided the setting last night for the sixth annual Fan Ball in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.
TORONTO, Nov. 18 (AP)-- Brig. Gen. Humberto Mariles tonight lifted the Mexican jumping team into a tie with the United States in international events at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.
Washington, Nov. 18--If a motorist so much as shuts his eyes, a "sleep inhibitor" covered by one of this week's patents rouses him by blowing a horn.
HWACHON, Korea, Nov. 18-- The great reservoir whose waters provide the power to light the lamps of Seoul and keep its wheels of industry turning was formally renamed by President Syngman Rhee today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 19 points up to 14 points off yesterday.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 18-- Forty-six persons on a plane carrying service men home for Thanksgiving survived a flaming crash early today. But the twenty-seven others, twenty-six of them G. I.'s, died in the wreckage.

Emerging from a conference with the President in the latter's new temporary headquarters at Gettysburg, Rowland Hughes, Director of the Budget, came nearer than any high financial official had come, up to this week, to a flat prediction of a balanced budget--not only for next year but for the present fiscal year, July 1, 1955-June 30, 1956.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)-- A rearrangement of air defense identification zones to make sure that they completely encircle the United States was announced today by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.
American Export Lines announced yesterday the retirement of its operating manager, B. A. Robison. Named to succeed him was Capt. Sydney Blackledge, the line's marine superintendent.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 18-- Strong support for the Eisenhower Administration's farm program was offered by New England dairy interests today at a hearing before the Senate Agriculture Committee.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18--Senator Estes Kefauver charged tonight that the organizational power of the Democratic National Committee had been used to help the Presidential candidacy of Adlai E. Stevenson.

Moves in futures prices on the New York exchanges were irregular yesterday. Most markets were dull with evening of holdings for the week-end accounting for most of the volume. Changes in coffee, sugar, cocoa, soybean oil and hides were mixed; rubber, cottonseed oil, onions, zinc and copper eased, and wool, potatoes and lead rose.
The George B. Pegram Laboratory, containing a 6,000,000electron-volt generator for nuclear research, was dedicated yesterday at Columbia University.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 18 (AP) --The National Executive Committee of the American Legion recommended today that the League of Women Voters disown a pamphlet written by a man the Legion said had been accused of being a Communist sympathizer.

General Electric A quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Jan. 25, has been authorized by the General Electric Company. The giant electrical products manufacturer previously paid 40 cents a share at quarterly intervals.

Carl R. Ruh, a dismissed New York Telephone Company employe, testified yesterday in the wiretap trial of John G. Broady that from January, 1954 until February of this year Broady paid him $100 a week for tapping telephone wires.

IF you want to do Wagner well, turn to American singers. The strength of last night's "Lohengrin," which returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory after an absence of thre seasons, was the performance of the native artists.

Willie Pastrano made a successful New York debut last night by defeating Joey Rowan of Phoenixville, Pa., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden. The New Orleans heavyweight gained the unanimous decision and the outcome was satisfactory to the 2,800 fans who watched the contest.

Joe Lapchick, lanky coach of the Knickerbockers, smiles at adversity. Since his early playing days with the famed Original Celtics, Lapchick has met reverses in stride and emerged on the black side of the ledger.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 18 --Mrs. James Dorment of Montclair was re-elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the annual meeting held today at the Montclair Club.

Several pounds of the paper that philatelists' dreams are made on were put on display yesterday. The occasion was the opening of the three-day National Postage Stamp Show at the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
The Fordham All-Star intramural football team will clash with the Manhattan College AllStars today at 1 P. M. on the Rams' field in the Bronx.
GENEVA, Nov. 18--Exporters and importers agreed today that after a "first reading" the odds in favor of a new world agreement to stabilize wheat prices were better than ever.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18--After a weak start, wheat and corn futures developed firmness yesterday.

Alexander V. Vlasov, the Soviet architect who was sharply criticized in Moscow while visiting here recently, complains that "bandits" and "provocateurs" are trying to prevent him from returning to his homeland. Possibly he does not know what prompted the activities of which he complains.
Stockpiles of prefabricated bridges were described yesterday as an essential factor in emergency repairs after severe floods.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 18-- Princeton will be seeking its first Ivy League title since 1951 tomorrow when the Tigers meet Dartmouth at Palmer Stadium in the final game of the season for both teams. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.
THE large number of competing shows of contemporary art in local galleries is evidence that the month before Christmas is a preferred season for exhibiting.
Economic conditions in New York City improved slightly in the first nine months of 1955 over those of the corresponding period a year ago.
MORE black bears are being seen and shot by hunters this season than in many years. Reports indicate that the bruins are showing up in the farm-fringe areas as well as the big woods.

Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' TV-radio report last night on the Geneva Big Four Conference as recorded by The New York Times. For the last three weeks I've been negotiating with the Russians at Geneva, and that's quite a job.

A FLUFFY, brown-crusted cheese souffle probably was the dish that, more than any other, established the reputation of Daniel, the caterer. The alert, ambitious French - American started making this specialty in a small apartment kitchen in 1944.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Nov. 19--The Rev. Justin Garvey and the Rev. Marcellus White American priests who had been imprisoned by the Chinese Communists, reached freedom here today following their release by the Peiping Government.

The second oldest rivalry in collegiate football will be resumed today when Columbia meets Rutgers at Baker Field. The contest will be the twentyeighth since the Lions first clashed with the Scarlet in 1870.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--Eighty-one policemen got diplomas today from the Federal Bureau of Investigation's school for law enforcement officers. A principal speaker at their commencement exercises was Stephen P. Kennedy, Police Commissioner of New York City, an alumnus.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A 25-to 50-cent drop in the price paid for butchers sent the average and top hog prices to new lows for fourteen years today. Sows sold steady to 25 cents off.

An assemblage of the blockfront on the west side of Second Avenue between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets has been completed by Bing Bing, Inc., and Lee Salomon with the purchase of 1035 and 1037 Second Avenue.
Fire on a New Haven Railroad engine resulted in a chain effect that delayed thousands of commuters homebound from Grand Central Terminal last night.

Americans should not be "nervous" over the failure of the Geneva talks, in the opinion of seven Soviet journalists who have just completed a month's tour of the United States. Agreement on Germany, they said, will come eventually, as it did on Austria.

ENID, Okla., Nov. 18 (UP)-- Ross Rizley, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, complained today that big airlines were benefitting in disputes involving the public interest. He said Congress was partly to blame.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (UP)--Nick Mickoski, with three goals, helped the Chicago Black Hawks to their biggest National Hockey League score of the season tonight as the Hawks beat the Boston Bruins, 6-1.

GENEVA, Nov. 18--William C. McGrath, United States employer delegate, announced today that he was withdrawing from the International Labor Organization's governing body. His action was in protest against the seating of employer delegates from Communist countries.

Through a series of recent public hearings the Tweed Commission asked for--and received in plenty-- criticisms of its comprehensive tentative plan to modernize the structure of New York's courts. But it did not make any considered proposals for changes in the way the judges should be chosen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Defense Department modified present "security risk" practices today as they underwent a daylong attack before a Senate panel investigating violations of constitutional rights.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 18-- The people of New Delhi, prompted by the Government, turned out by the hundreds of thousands today to give visiting Soviet leaders India's warmest welcome.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 18 --President Eisenhower designated Boyd Leedom today to serve as chairman of the National Labor Relations Board. He succeeds Guy Farmer, whose term expired in August.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 18--Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef announced today the 43-year old French protectorate in Morocco was coming to an end and a "new era of freedom and independence" was dawning.
BOSTON, Nov. 18--A Federal District Court Judge ruled today that it was not a duty of air traffic control operators to prevent landings in hazardous weather.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The Federal Trade Commission has completed an investigation of alleged violations by the General Motors Corporation of a 1941 "cease and desist" order.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 (AP)--The 7,000,000,000th passenger car produced in the United States this year was built this week but over-all production declined 3.6 per cent from last week's second best level in history, Ward's Reports said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 --The opening here last night of "Oklahoma!" at the Egyptian Theatre served to clarify an important point of difference between New York critics and local observers in regard to appraisal of the Todd-AO bigscreen system.

Westchester scholastic football's irresistible force and immovable object clash today when the Harrison Huskies attempt to crack the thirty-two-game winning streak of the Rye Garnets. The visiting Huskies, undefeated in six games, have tallied 149 points to 13 for the opposition.

Between Oct. 14 and Nov. 15 the aggregate short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 92,294 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday. The November figure of 2,634,966 shares was the lowest for any reporting date since June 15, when it was 2,598,534 shares.

The long-standing question of whether the Board of Education can compel high school department chairmen to perform duties against their will has been left for the State Supreme Court to decide, it was learned yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18 (UP)--The General Motors Corporation, and the Ford Motor Company, topped a list of contributors in a successful campaign to defeat the guaranteed wage plan in Ohio last week, this was shown in a report filed with the Ohio Secretary of State today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (UP)-- A new regime of business men took over the operation of the Baltimore Orioles today. It is headed by James Keelty Jr., a contractor whose past interest in baseball had been that of a casual fan.

Gross operating revenues of the Knott Hotels Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year amounted to $17,432,998, according to the report released yesterday by Willard E. Dodd, President.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 18--Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, United Nations truce chief, contradicted today an Israeli statement that Egypt had rejected proposals for quieting border tension.
The rise in Federal Reserve discount rates had mixed effects on yesterday's stock market. The close was lower, but the decline was far from unanimous.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 --Yale and Harvard, football rivals since 1875, will meet in the Yale Bowl at 1:30 P. M. tomorrow. More than 60,000 are expected to watch the traditional contest, in which Yale is slightly favored.
LONDON, Nov. 18--The Admiralty disclosed today the existence of a laboratory that tested underwater weapons at speeds up to 100 miles an hour.

YESTERDAY (Nov. 18, 1955) GENERAL ASSEMBLY Assembly continued debate on proposed charter review conference with statements by Yugoslavia, Peru. Greece, Poland, Syria, Dominican Republic, New Zealand, Pakistan, Mexico, Czechoslovakia, Argentina, Norway, Ukraine and Indonesia.
The two-month-old program in Federal Court here to reduce congested trial calendars has succeeded beyond all expectations, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The United States Tariff Commission intends to seek amendments to the highly controversial AntiDumping Act of 1954 which the commission itself must interpret.
SFAX, Tunisia, Nov. 18--The nationalist Neo-Destour party asked Tunisia tonight to break with centuries of economic and social tradition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A panel of experts headed by Secretary Marion B. Folsom today advised Congress that any effective attack on the problem of poverty involved federal aid to education.
The increase of the Federal Reserve discount rate had a sobering effect on the financial markets yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP)-- Michigan State won the Big Ten cross-country championship and Notre Dame captured the Central Collegiate Conference title at Washington Park today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Regarding your Nov. 18 editorial "Passport Inquiry" the following statement of Senator Thomas Hennings was incorporated into the record of the Nov. 17 hearings of the Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights:
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18-- The provisional Government of President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu acted today to destroy the propaganda machine built up by Juan D. Peron.

OBVIOUSLY in keeping with the pious desire to avoid overemphasizing athletics the Yale University Press has chosen today--the day of the annual scrimmage with Harvard--to publish the second volume of George Wilson Pierson's majestic history of Yale University and its place in this country's higher learning.
THERE is a young merchandise man at B. Altman Co. who likes to hold forth on women's handbags.

In its accustomed mood of kindly ferocity, of gay and lightsome mayhem, the New York Financial Writers' Association last night swung the spiked paddle. On the receiving end, in positions of reverse obeisance, were 1,500 leaders in finance, industry and Government.

LONDON, Nov. 18--The stock market ended the week quietly, with prices moving irregularly. Government loans more than recovered early small losses and closed firm. On the other hand, industrial shares, after improving further at the opening, turned slightly dull.

VIENNA, Nov. 18--Austria and West Germany have agreed to exchange Ambassadors and will set up a commission to solve the differences created by the Austrian state treaty. That was announced today during a visit to Vienna by Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister.

For Ages 12 to 16. THESE three biographies of great British scientists of the past and Patrick Pringle's discoverers of the present all convey a sense of strong individuality. It would seem that in science, as in art, it is the solitary worker who discovers and synthesizes.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19--This in essence is the picture of the United States presented by the Soviet journalists who have been touring the country under State Department auspices: The United States is peopled by a simple, friendly folk whose earnest efforts to understand the Soviet Union are impeded by prejudices of the American press and activities of those who fear the easing of international tension.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10--The continuing sinking of Mexico City had a prominent place on the agenda of the first National Construction Congress here this week.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 19--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin said today that the Soviet Union was ready to share its experience in industrial and atomic energy matters with India.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 19--A prolonged wrangle over how to provide emergency care for mentally retarded children has kept the Michigan Legislature in and out of special session since Nov. 1. The deadlock between the House and the Senate now seems unlikely to be resolved for another week or more.

LONDON, Nov. 19--The conference of foreign ministers that ended in Geneva on Thursday was one of the most unproductive ever held. As a result of it, the post-war phase of international relations in which the United States, Britain and France for the West and the Soviet Union for the East attempted to arrange the future of Europe by settling the future of Germany appears over.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--Bipartisan approval of Administration efforts during the Foreign Ministers' Conference came from Congressional spokesmen today. It was accorded in the wake of Secretary of State Dulles' report to the nation last night on the Geneva meeting.

GEORGE HALAS thrilled to the story in the paper that day in 1921. The first sentence related that his Chicago Bears had beaten the Chicago Cardinals for the championship of the National Football League before a thousand or so diehard fans.

HUNTINGDON, Pa., Nov. 19 (AP)--Pat Tarquinio threw five touchdown passes and scored once himself as Juniata beat Ursinus, 38--6, today, in five inches of snow. It completed the third consecutive unbeaten and untied season for Juniata whose victory string reached twentythree.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd will leave Friday for his greatest Antarctic adventure. He expects it to open new vistas in science and the last unexplored region of the earth.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 19 (UP) --Texas Christian ripped Rice's defenses apart today and the nation's seventh-ranked team moved into the Cotton Bowl with a 35-0 Southwest Conference victory before 28,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) --The Civil Defense Administration is turning to electronic brains to save lives in the event of an atomic bomb attack.

Coffee prices have been bouncing up and down during the last twelve months. The declines early in this period did not perturb the housewife. However, until the reductions announced earlier this month, the trend during the latter part of the year had been up.

The Board of Estimate was accused yesterday of "cynical, disgusting and brazen" action in voting $87,710 in pay rises to 110 noncivil service employes, many of them Democratic district leaders or party functionaries.

FOR men who have stood near the top of Rabbit Hill or some other local grade waiting for a freight train on a dark night and then hooked a ride into town, this brawling, boisterous novel of railroading in the Midwest at the turn of the century will be like a return to their yesteryears.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--The Democrats are now moving, though as yet on slow and cautious feet, toward putting foreign policy back into the category of major issues in 1956.
SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 18-- Political affairs, never far from the surface in this smallest of Latin American republics, have risen to a dominant position in El Salvador's social and commercial life.
WAYLAND, Mass., Nov. 19-- An ancient bridge that enabled Maj. Gen. Henry Knox to bring up artillery reinforcements to besieged Boston in the Revolutionary War has been condemned after 233 years.
Thanksgiving Day will be celebrated here on Thursday with the customary mixture of rejoicing and solemnity.
