CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Three top-ranked Democratic Presidential possibilities accused the Eisenhower Administration tonight of failures at home and abroad.

Land-grant college and university leaders, representing sixty-nine state institutions of higher learning with an enrollment of 450,000 students, met last week to discuss the future of higher education, and who among the coming crop of students are entitled to it.

HOUSTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Houston passed for two touchdowns and added two more via the fleet feet of Kennie (Scooter) Stegall to celebrate its tenth homecoming today with a 26-14 victory over Villanova.

THAT creative cooks will never bow to standardization becomes particularly plain at Thanksgiving. To that affectionately held menu of turkey and all the fixin's, culinary experts add their own individual dash of appetite appeal.

MARJORIE McCARRON, a trimly built young woman with hazel eyes and a slow, pleasant smile, does a variety of strange and often forbidding things for a living. She walks through lonely, nightshadowed streets in which women have been assaulted.
TO THE EDITOR: For reminding us of the color and variety of American place names, Allan Taylor's "Communique from the C. A. P. N." (Nov. 6) surely rates some kind of award (an Oshkosh?).
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 18 --The equivalent of a Presidential press conference was instituted recently in Thailand by by Premier Pibul Songgram on his return from a world tour.

A BIOGRAPHY friendly to Walter Winchell is... news. Only his secretary Friday has pinned orchids on him recently. In "Let's Go to Press" one of the equerries in the columnist's stable attempts to reveal the other side. The result is a book that is objective in a prejudiced way.

POWER-BRAKES and powersteering, which have done much to make driving easier and less fatiguing on long trips in good weather, can become serious hazards on slippery pavement -- unless the motorist knows how to use them properly.

Our Glorious Land W.A.T. writes: "Many years ago The Christian Science Monitor gave the verses below as belonging to the patriotic hymn, 'America' --that is, the work of the same Samuel Francis Smith who wrote the familiar four stanzas.

BOULDER, Colo., Nov. 19 (UP) --Colorado wouldn't allow Iowa State within a long punt of its goal today, rolling to a 40-0 victory on a muddy field in the last Big Seven Conference game of the season for both teams.
How strong and sound is a piece of wood? The question is important because lumber is so widely used in building.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19--Nail, the gray colt owned by Mrs. Anson A. Bigelow of Palm Beach, today became the year's top cash-collector among the 2year-olds. He won $67,980 in the Pimlico Futurity and ran his 1955 earnings to $239,930.
ST. LOUIS Here this past week at the annual cnference of the National Rehabilitation Association, the nation's leaders in rehabilitation took inventory of gains made in the past year.
ACRE, Israel, Nov. 7--Hi-yo, Kessef (Hebrew for Silver)! Post another occupation for the new Israelis--bronco buster and cowband coach--and list the professor's name as George Adam.

FROM the wry semi-retirement from national affairs that followed the change in national Administration in 1953, Dean Acheson has now emerged as a new and visibly mellowed sort of public man. Working in high policy had been his old function as Secretary of State, but he returns now as a political essayist.

THE important news of the year to balletomanes is that the three great Tchaikovsky ballets--"Sleeping Beauty," Swan Lake" and "Nutcracker" -- are all available in complete versions by Antal Dorati and the Minneapolis Symphony (Mercury).

THE shifting fortunes of any major writer illuminate not only his own period but what comes after him. Theodore Dreiser was the primitive poet and pathfinder of the Nineteen Hundreds; the hero of the Teens; the venerated ancestor of the Twenties.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -- This city that has become renowned moref or the chemicals than for the angels in its air underwent an agonizing self-appraisal last week and came up with a paradoxical answer: Smog is as bad as ever, but progress is being made against it.

TO THE EDITOR: After reading Wilfrid Sheed's "Is It Cricket to Kick at Football?" (Nov. 13) I remembered my own emotions at my first cricket match. As an American serviceman, my English friends were just a bit apprehensive as to how I should react to their national game.
Strong appeals for financial and legislative aid for retarded children were made yesterday at the final session of the State Joint Legislative Committee on Mental Retardation.
HONG KONG, Nov. 19 -- Two American priests freed by the Chinese Communists declared today they had been threatened with death or torture unless they "confessed" their alleged "crimes."

Reminiscences of debutante balls and cotillions at the turn of the century were related recently by Mrs. Theron Roundell Strong of New York and Southampton, L.I., in her apartment at the Carlyle. Her remarks were prompted by the coming week of important debutante events.

SAN MARCOS, Tex., Nov. 19 (AP)--The Senate majority leader announced today that he had been called to the White House for a conference Dec. 13 with President Eisenhower and others, presumably on foreign policy.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 16--The United States Government is contributing $2,400,000 to resettle about 25,000 Guatemalan peasant families who obtained land under the agrarian reform law of former pro-Communist President Jacobo Arbenz.
Women's apparel markets received gratifying response to spring offerings last week, resident buying offices reported yesterday.

AFTER next summer it will cost appreciably more to go to Europe by ship. Two readjustments in tourist-class fares--a $5 increase in one-way ticket prices last May and another $6 average increase to go into effect on Jan.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER in the Pacific, Nov. 17--The captain of the YOG-34 reported by radio today that life was a bit rough aboard the tanker being towed to the Antarctic by the icebreaker Glacier.
The American Museum of Natural History and the Hayden Planetarium were hosts yesterday to 575 high school and junior high school students from Washington.
SEATTLE, Nov. 19--Averell Harriman flies into Seattle tomorrow night in the role of a money collector and back-slapper for fellow Democrats.

HOLLYWOOD, which has not been averse to glorifying the storied careers of such showfolk as Al Jolson, George M. Cohan and, recently, Ruth Etting, is preparing to add film fame to the name of the late Jeanne Eagels.

The teakwood interior that once graced the spacious library of the Flagler mansion at 32 Park Avenue, near Thirtyfifth Street, has been called into service as the decor for another Park Avenue residence, that of David McNulty at 1 Park Avenue in Shirley, L.I. Mr. McNulty, a 47-yearold electrician at the Suffolk Air Base, has built his onestory home largely with materials salvaged during the demolition of the Park Avenue building.

ANIMALS play a large part in the life of any countryman, and you can almost tell the quality of a farmer by his attitude toward his livestock, even toward the wildlife on his own acres. There's something about life close to the land that makes a wise man aware not only of his own transience but of his tenantship rather than ownership of his acres.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has named 5-year-old Tommy Woodward of Baltimore as its poster boy for the 1956 March of Dimes.

NATIONAL OBSERVATORY-- A five-year plan for the establishment of a national observatory was outlined to astronomers at their semi-annual meeting in Troy, N.Y., by Dr. A. E. Whitford (University of Wisconsin) who was one of the five-member panel appointed nearly two years ago by the National Science Foundation to survey long-term needs in astronomy.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 19 (UP)--The Stanford Indians walloped the California Bears, 19--0, today before 91,500 sun-bathed fans at Stanford Stadium in the fifty-eighth renewal of the "big game."

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 19 (UP)--Lew Hoad, apparently determined to prove himself the world's top amateur tennis player now that he has refused a professional offer, won the New South Wales singles title today by beating Ken Rosewall, 6--2, 6--3, 2--6, 6--1.
ALTHOUGH the value of the telescopic sight is still warmly debated among Eastern deer hunters, it is apparent that at least half the hunters in New England and eastern Canada use them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) --American Protestants, faced with increasing anti-Western sentiment in Asia and Africa, are planning a revolutionary approach to their century-old effort to convert peoples of those continents to Christianity.

The major art event of the Thanksgiving week is an exhibition devoted to Latin-American architecture in the post-war decade. Large-scale photo murals and three-dimensional color slides in individual views will be employed in the show opening at the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday to illustrate the great building boom in eleven countries in the period 1945-55.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Ed Vereb, a halfback, scored two first-half touchdowns behind his second-string line and Maryland fought off George Washington throughout the scoreless second half to gain a 19-0 victory today.

THE extraordinary interest throughout much of the civilized world aroused by the discovery of the so-called Dead Sea Scrolls in 1947 has evoked a number of articles and books. On the scene at the time was Yale Divinity School's Millar Burrows.

IN recognition of the Mozart Bicentennial year of 1956, the record companies are planning a bumper crop of releases. The present estimate of the situation indicates that by the end of that banner year "Eine kleine Nachtmusik" will join the ranks of the most-recorded scores.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 19 (AP)--Twenty of the nation's leading movie stars, directors and camera men from another day, many of them here in person, received tonight the first George Eastman Awards for outstanding contributions to the motionpicture art.

The snow yesterday drove forty little "Robin Hoods," dressed for the balmier clime of Sherwood Forest, into the Armed Forces recruiting booth in Times Square. The boys, wearing green jerkins and feathered hats and carrying bows and arrows, are members of the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twentyninth Street.

One of the largest privately financed apartment developments in the city is under way in Queens. Known as Forest Hills Park, it occupies a tract of more than twenty acres in the Elmhurst-Forest Hills section. It is estimated to cost $42,000,000.

The rental list has been opened on a new East Side apartment building. The six-story structure at 242 East Thirty-eighth Street, southwest corner of Second Avenue, will provide accommodations for forty families. It is scheduled to be completed in February.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 19 (UP) --Minnesota's offense worked without a flaw on the hard driving of Halfback Bob Schultz and Fullback Dick Borstad today to defeat Wisconsin, 21--6, for the first time since 1950.

This is a true detective story, the story of the detection and arrest of John Gilbert Graham on a charge of having planted a bomb on an airliner and thus having caused the death of forty-four persons.

MARI SANDOZ has written one good book after another, including "Old Jules," "Cheyenne Autumn" and "Buffalo Hunters." These are solid studies of the Old West, displaying not only great knowledge of an area and a period but a great sympathy and an intuitive understanding: at times this has seemed almost a personal involvement, as if the author had actually lived through the times she described and experienced them at first hand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States declared today that private and parochial schools had "full right" to receive Government aid. They said the schools were integral parts of the nation's educational system.

AMERICA looks pretty good to a foreign correspondent, still young by most standards, who comes home after nine years of service abroad. It also looks pretty good to the young wife that the foreign correspondent found abroad and brought back with him.

HAVE you ever heard the wind names of the world, which are among the least known and most beautiful of words? They are truly the heritage of all men for they reflect the tongues of history from ancient Cathay to the slang of the United States Army.

WARSAW, Nov. 18--Despite ten years' attachment to the idea of monolothic communism, each of the satellite states differs from the others in more than language and customs, and Poland appears to differ most of all.
ALTHOUGH the current recording year has seen its full share of "1812" Overtures and "New World" Symphonies, it has seen many novelties as well.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 19 --Ohio State stormed to a surprise 17-0 victory over Michigan today in a weird contest that nearly wound up in a free-forall.

IN 1950, a one-time practicing physician and psychoanalyist named Immanuel Velikovsky advanced the extraordinary hypothesis that the planet Venus originated about 1500 B.C. as a comet torn from the planet Jupiter, and that on the way to its present station in the solar system, Venus had a cataclysmic brush with the earth, stopping the earth's rotation for a full day and causing devastating floods and other disasters.
A $9,000,000 international airport at Punta Caucedo, less than fifteen miles east of Trujillo City, is being planned for the jet transport age.
The Army and the city agreed yesterday to untangle the ferry lanes from the Battery to Staten Island and Governors Island.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 19 (AP)--Michigan State whipped Marquette, 33--0, today at Macklin Stadium and then erupted into a happy hysteria, of celebration over the word that Ohio State had downed Michigan to send the Spartans to the Rose Bowl.

TO THE EDITOR: Peter T. White, in writing "The Interpreter: Linguist Plus Diplomat," (Nov. 6), gave a number of interesting verbal faux pas which have been committed in translation, for all the excellence of U.N. and other diplomatic interpreters, who, as he said, have become indispensable at today's conferences.

"The American Treasury," reviewed in adjoining columns, draws on many fields to illustrate our "life, laughter and literature." The quotations below are from two of its chapters. "Essayists and Aphorists'' and "Tellers of Tales.''

AMONG the scores of philanthropies which claim the respect, admiration, and support of the American public, there is a comparative handful which seem to enjoy a prestige out of all proportion to their relative size. They have captured the popular imagination, not because of the numbers they serve, but by virtue of the peculiarly personal nature of their service.

A system of stand-by mortgage commitments to builders has been hailed as the answer to the restricted money market by Louis H. Meyer, vice president of the J.I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation of Jersey City, N.J.

With its beat weapon--the pass--made ineffective by a swirling snowfall, Columbia ended its football season on a dismal note yesterday. On hand to take advantage of the poor visibility and a slippery gridiron was a determined Rutgers eleven.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 19 (Reuters)--Iran has ordered two 32,000-ton oil tankers from the Verolme United Shipyards here as a start to building up her own tanker fleet.
Three new East Side apartment buildings have embarked on a joint landscaping project designed to present a pleasing appearance when viewed from upper-story windows.

HOLLYWOOD. SOMEWHERE from thirty to fifty million moviegoers are expected to cast votes before the deadline one week from tonight in the Council of Motion Picture Organization's first annual Audience Award election.
Extensive improvements are planned for the Times Square Hotel at Eighth Avenue and Forty-third Street, which is to pass to new control next January after an ownership of thirtytwo years.

IF a nation's taste in humor is any reflection of its character, then England has been a bonny and summery place to be for the last one hundred years. "A Century of Punch Cartoons" may sound like a formidable serving of suet pudding to the American who knows of Punch by hearsay.

AMONG the military memoirs of Civil War generals, the narrative of Lieut. Gen. Richard Taylor, C.S.A., has long held a high place. His "Destruction and Reconstruction," originally published in 1879, was marked by a sprightly writing style and by a rare skill in portraiture, qualities that reflected the sound education and the broad culture of the aristocratic son of President Zachary Taylor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- Representatives of 233 national organizations will take part in the White House Conference on Education that opens a week from Monday.

When reporters for the British Travel Association asked a cross section of American visitors what they had liked best about their stay in Britain, the answer given most frequently was "our meetings with the British people."

WHEN I named my selections for a small desert island library a few weeks ago, a correspondent suggested that I might well have found a place for a good dictionary. The suggestion was made in no unkindly spirit; simply on the grounds of usefulness and possible enjoyment.

Four more major trade shows have signed five-year leases in the New York Trade Show Building at 500 Eighth Avenue, according to Louis J. Glickman, owner and operator of the structure. The property was formerly the Ludwig-Baumann store.

HANS KELSEN is one of the world's leading authorities on legal theory and international law. But he does not read Russian and is unfamiliar with the spirit and practice of Soviet jurisprudence, and the luxuriant growth of quasi-judicial administrative and police practice.

THERE are contenders in every generation for the title "Mr. New York." In our own, there is Grover Whalen. Usually described as our official greeter (he loathes the word), he has played a part in every administration from Hylan to Impellitteri.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 19--Nation-wide rejoicing for the return of Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef to the Moroccan throne was marred today by several killings. One Moroccan notable was crushed to death with a rock and five others were wounded, one fatally, in a melee in a courtyard of the Imperial Palace.

BRIGHTON--A happy collaboration between man and nature has gotten Utah's ski season off to an early start. Just as contractors completed new lift lines at Brighton and Alta, the season's first storms dumped from three to four feet of snow on the neighboring Wasatch Mountain resorts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- For whatever it may be worth this far in advance of the convention -- scheduled for this city next August -- the Democratic nomination for President seems as of today to be in the firm and eager grip of Adlai E. Stevenson.
SHAKESPEARE might have found himself more at home with television than with the modern stage on at least two counts, Maurice Evans observed the other day.

INDUSTRIES new to the land of Israel are sprouting up here and there. The recent discovery of oil is but one of them. Perhaps more unusual and significant is the development of agriculture. To a nation that once knew little of fields and farms, agriculture has become an integral part of the economy.
Federal Maritime Board approval of the exclusive patronage system in foreign trade to and from the Great Lakes area is a threat to the American merchant marine, the Isbrandtsen Company says.

IN the first chapter of "Bloody Mary," Theodore Maynard emphasizes that he uses his title ironically "in savage defiance or even bad taste." Actually, although he regards Mary Tudor, the much-maligned daughter of Henry VIII and Katherine of Aragon, as one of the "holiest" of English sovereigns, and as pure, courageous, devoted, noble, honest and pious besides, he is not savage or defiant about anyone, not even about the Queen's enemies.
A beginning has been made in the city's long-range attack on air pollution and there "has made significant progress in eradicating the immediately correctable sources of pollution."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19-- Princeton's football team won the Ivy League title today despite a snowstorm and a stubborn Dartmouth team. With a fourth-period touchdown, the Tigers overcame a 3-0 lead established by the Indians in the second quarter to win, 6-3.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--The Army engineers are about a quarter of the way through one of their most unusual projects, the mapping of Latin America.

THE first hard-cover sciencefiction anthologies to be put out by general trade publishers appeared in 1946 and caused a minor sensation. The two collections sold out immediately. Apparently--so it was said at the time--readers had seized upon science fiction as the interpreter of the newborn atomic age.

NATIVE trees and shrubs bearing interesting and decorative fall fruit are to be found in abundance and variety along almost any road or lane in the Missouri Ozark country around my home. And most of these natives grow equally well much farther north.

Soldier THE other day this newspaper broke a story to the effect that Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, retired Army Chief of Staff, was writing his memoirs and that it would contain considerable criticism of the Administration's defense policy.

Before his heart attack, President Eisenhower had a tough working schedule. In Washington he was at his desk at eight and would normally stay there eight to ten hours Monday through Friday. Appointments began at eight-thirty and continued until mid-afternoon.

A SAW, a hammer and a screwdriver will start a person on his way to being a handyman. Adding a vise to the tool collection takes him out of the novitiate class. Which vise can be a problem, because there are so many different types, let alone makes, from which to choose.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) --The Administration intends to go ahead with its plan to relax some East-West trade restrictions despite failure of the Geneva conference.

The current session of the General Assembly, which until now has borne out prophecies that it would accomplish practically nothing, seems all of a sudden to be on the threshold of solving one of the most intractable United Nations deadlocks.

The Philadelphia Eagles, fresh from a 33-17 victory over the league-leading Cleveland Browns, will oppose the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds today. Five other games are on the National Football League schedule.
TOZEUR, Tunisia, Nov. 18-- This is the desert country of southern Tunisia, where slogans of internal autonomy and independence have a remote sound.

Except for one game, the fourteenth round in the international chess tournament at Zagreb was completed yesterday. The leader, Vassily Smyslov of Russia, added 1 1/2 points for a score of 10 1/2-- 3 1/2, according to a report from Yugoslav news sources.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 20-- The weather had no respect for tradition and Lafayette's football team had even less respect for favored Lehigh on snowswept Taylor Field today.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Nov. 12 were 9 per cent higher than in the corresponding week last year. It was the twenty-ninth consecutive weekly gain reported by the Federal Reserve Board.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 19--Syracuse made its first visit to West Virginia University in nine years today and toppled the Mountaineers to their second straight football defeat, 20--13, in a snowstorm.

MRS. TURNBULL has five successful novels to her credit; as her many readers know, the elements that have given her stories their appeal lie in her unabashed use of sentiment, backstopped with plots full of color and incident.

THE first substantial rib of the spinal system of crosscountry toll roads, thirtyseven miles of the Northeast Extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, will be dedicated Tuesday. And, weather permitting, it will be open to pay traffic at 8 A. M. the following day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Following is a statement issued by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States today on the place of the private and church-related schools in American education: Freedom under God is America's dearest treasure.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- Right-wing Republicans stepped up their attack against labor's political activities today with suggestions that union funds were being used illegally.
HAVANA. SINCE the day, less than five years ago, when Cubans saw their first home-grown telecast, video has flourished and become a major industry here.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 19 (UP)--Purdue's defense-minded Boilermakers, using a fumble recovery as the only break they needed, beat Indiana today, 6--4, to retain their mastery over the Hoosiers in the "Old Oaken Bucket" series.

WHITE HOUSE--Guides The President's Committee for the White House Conference on Education has approved study guides on the six main subjects scheduled for discussion by 2,000 participants at the national conference in Washington Nov. 28-Dec. 1.
The board of directors of the new National Association of Social Workers asked yesterday for increased Federal expenditures and for "leadership" in the field of social welfare.

CHARLES FOSTER, Professor of English at Grinnell College and author of a book on Emerson's poetry, might have used as a subtitle to his penetrating study of Harriet Beecher Stowe the phrase, "The Author Everybody Almost Knows."

BOSTON, Nov. 19 (UP)--Favored Boston University ended its season with a 2-6 record today by walloping slow-moving Temple University, 25--0, before an estimated 8,000 snow-covered fans at University Field.
"STRANGER than fiction" might well describe the flowering of witch hazels. When other flowering shrubs and trees are bare, the witch hazels are producing fragrant, yellow, spidery blossoms.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 19 (UP)--Dick Reich provided the ground power and the passing of two sophomore backs the scoring thrusts as Kansas scored a 13-7 victory over Missouri today.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 19 (UP)--Vanderbilt, scenting a possible bowl bid, rolled over Florida, 21--6, today to close its home season brilliantly before a chilled crowd of 16,500.

IN writing or America's early history, Margaret Allis always reflects the diligence and care that go into research for the documentary data of her novels. But she is a story-teller, too, and in the present work she makes human drama as important as the turbulence of the times.

WHEN the French art magazine L'Oeil published its first bright and informative number last January some people wondered if it could continue to maintain the high standard of text and reproduction it at once established.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP)-- Low-income families are caught up largely in an unhappy economiceducational cycle that improves neither their lot nor the country's.

The West was brought up sharp last week against the fact that a new and extraordinarily difficult phase in the East-West struggle was at hand. At an end was a brief era whose limits were marked by the two Geneva conferences -- the summit conference of last July, the foreign ministers' conference of the past three weeks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Labor's big merger two weeks hence will still leave much unsettled inter-union rivalry. Many unions, particularly in the buildling trades, are uneasy.
The religions of the world can stand together against communism, Rabbi Samuel M. Segal declared yesterday in sermon at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

After experimenting on twentyfive adult subjects, E. Colin Cherry and B. McA. Sayers of City and Guilds College, and Pauline M. Marland, speech therapist, of St. Mary's Hospital, and St. Thomas Hospital, London, England, report in Nature that stammering can be suppressed.
Americans should avoid indifference in world affairs at a time when the nation's self-preservation depends on its foreign policy, the United States Ambassador to Switzerland said yesterday.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19--Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, is convinced that the people of the Soviet Union hate and fear the idea of war and that the Soviet Government is convinced it can gain its ends without resort to war.

TO THE EDITOR: Your cover picture of Nov. 6 showing a bullet-spattered signpost on the BeershebaGaza road in Israel and an Israeli soldier sent me searching through my files until I came up with a picture [see below] taken in the identical spot in June, 1954.

TWO books, published within a few weeks of each other, bring to life the era from 1908 to 1927 in which that towering figure and contradictory genius of American industrial life, Henry Ford constructed and sold 15,000,000 of his famous Model T cars.

Under some pressure from a Senate subcommittee and some adverse publicity of an unofficial nature, the Defense Department announces that it has changed its "security risk" system. In the past it has felt free to give less than honorable discharges to inducted men who had thought wrong thoughts or belonged to wrong organizations before getting into uniform.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Halfback Levi (Chuck) Johns shook off three Arkansas tacklers and raced 65 yards for a touchdown to break up a defensive struggle and start Louisiana State toward a 13-7 victory today.

A VARIED group of operas, from Italy to China, is scheduled for release by Angel. Among the standard issues will be "Rigoletto," "La Boheme" and "Manon Lescaut." Less familiar is the forthcoming "Eugen Onegin."

The recent appointment of Bob Bragan as manager of the Pirates, which followed on the heels of the naming of Bill Rigney to succeed Leo Durocher as skipper of the Giants, points clearly to a trend in the major leagues.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 19 --Dr. Joseph Charles Roper, a New York and Greenwich physician who had taught at Bellevue Hospital and Cornell Medical College in New York, died last night at his home in near-by Riverside. His age was 86.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 19-- The Brazilian Chamber of Deputies is the political pulse of the nation and frequently a zealous guardian of the Constitution.

Lee Schoenfield is showing a new model in an expanded section of his Knickerbocker Knolls development in Hicksville, L.I. The houses are being erected on a tract of more than eighty acres he purchased some time ago.

THERE may be quite a few people who have never seen a cork oak tree. And many of them may assume that they are only found along the sunny coasts of the Mediterranean. But actually the cork trees (Quercus suber) thrive in parts of this country where warm climate, good rainfall and acid-type soil are found.

A community of 170 homes, known as Fairfield at New Shrewsbury, has been opened on a 135-acre tract on Sycamore Avenue, adjoining Red Bank, N.J., and the Rumson estate area. Two model houses, a split-level and a rancher, are being offered at $19,990 and up.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 19-- Reunion with Germany has been made the official policy of the pro-German parties in the Saar.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19--The morning after Adlai E. Stevenson let the cat out of the cellophane bag this week a woman walked into his headquarters at 231 South LaSalle Street and offered to contribute to his campaign.

HAVANA, Nov. 19--A Chesapeake Bay yachtsman, John Todd of Easton, Md., sailed his Boomerang to a well-earned victory today in the opening race of the thirty-third annual world championship of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 17 (Reuters)--Life is becoming slowly better for the 600,000 inhabitants of the Bulgarian capital, though to the foreigner the standard of living still seems well below that of the West.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--An East German geographer has beaten United States explorers to mapping their own discoveries.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19--The Democratic party's attacks on the Administration's conduct of foreign policy are beginning to assume the proportions of a major Presidential campaign issue.

ABOUT the middle of the nineteenth century, in the quiet sunshine of provincial prosperity, New England had an Indian summer of the mind; and an agreeable reflective literature showed how brilliant that russet and yellow season could be.

THE Overseas Press Club found itself trapped in an awkward affair last week, a television spectacular bearing the title of "Dateline II." Amid interludes of vaudeville, the program endorsed the heroism of foreign correspondents, freedom of the press and love of country.

JOHN MALCOLM BRINNIN has described this personal memoir of his friend and fellow poet, Dylan Thomas, as an act of exorcism, and the reader will easily understand why, as he reads on; but I take it also as a very honorable attempt to set his share of the record straight, at a time when the events he writes about are so near and bitter a memory to him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--The United States has resumed title to the site of old Fort Union, established in 1851 as an Army post in New Mexico to cover the Santa Fe Trail. It will become part of the national park system, according to the Assistant Secretary of the Interior, Wesley D'Ewart.

CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 19 (AP)-- Drexel Tech, with Frank Russo scoring two touchdowns, beat Pennsylvania Military College, 20--6 today. This completed Drexel's first unbeaten season since football was introduced at the college thirty-six years ago.

A severe test looms ahead of our colleges and universities. The sharp rise in the national birthrate which began with World War II and has continued since will soon make itself felt in a record flood of high school graduates applying for higher educational institutions.
Heavier loads are being shouldered these autumn days by the men who deliver fuel in the form of wood to the consumer.

In the small hours of a November morning three years ago Adlai E. Stevenson read into the microphones his concession of defeat by Dwight D. Eisenhower. As he turned away, a reporter called out, "What about '56?" Mr. Stevenson feigned shock: "Fifty-six! Have that man's head examined."

Grady Crumpley of Flushing captured the individual title and Andrew Jackson High gained the team crown yesterday in the fiftieth annual cross-country championship of the Public Schools Athletic League.

RINGOES, N.J., Nov. 19-- The first national championship field trial for cocker spaniels ever held in the East began in midwinter conditions today with eighteen dogs starting and ten left at nightfall to continue for more competition tomorrow.

To the Screen Editor: In his recent review of "Rebel Without a Cause" Mr. Crowther engages in exactly the "pretense of 'understanding' that can gravely mislead" as that which he accuses the film's producer of following.

THREE seasons ago, it was labor that took the Pittsburgh Symphony to nearby towns; this year it's capital. In more specific terms, the Manufacturers Light and Heat Company is sponsoring the orchestra in towns near Pittsburgh in a manner that suggests the 1952-53 experiment, in which the United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., underwrote the cost of the orchestra's concerts in North Braddock, Johnstown and Bethlehem.

WHAT may turn out to be an unusually interesting election inside the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists is now in progress. Ballots for about 4,000 performers here, who will elect thirty-five persons to the local board, went in the mail last week.
Many emotionally disturbed delinquent boys will receive treatment and retraining as a result of a benefit theatre party to be held under the auspices of the Children's Village on Nov. 29.

THE first twenty-one years of Mary Todd Lincoln's life were spent in Lexington, "capital" of the Bluegrass region of Kentucky. Among her friends were the Clays -- Henry, the Great Compromiser, and Cassius, the bold emancipationist; and the Breckinridges -- the Rev. Robert J., stanch Unionist, and John C., Confederate general and War Secretary.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 19-- The establishing of a Westchester Parkway Authority to provide bigger parkways and higher tolls is again being sought by county officials.

WASHINGTON. THE wisdom of this nation's foreign policy is directly related to the quality of the men and women who compose the Foreign Service. Diplomats constitute our official channel of communication with other governments, and our observers of life and policy in other countries.

BOSTON, Nov. 19--Considerable strength for Adlai E. Stevenson was evident this week in New England following his declaration that he would seek the Democratic Presidential nom the Democratic Presidential nomination again next year.

Washington made another attempt last week to slow down the business boom. To Wall Street's general surprise, the Federal Reserve lifted the rediscount rate--the rate at which member banks borrow from the system--from 2 1/4 to 2 1/2 per cent.

LONDON. THE three estates of the motion picture world--the makers, the sellers and the exhibitors--often have their differences of opinion and approach, but here for the present at least they are bound together by a great resolve.
TORONTO, Nov. 19 (AP)-- Ireland scored a clean victory tonight in the international challenge trophy event at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

UNLIKE many crime "confessions," which leave the reader with a suspicion that they have been padded, this highly readable tale, breathtakingly paced, is loaded with adequate material for several books.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 19--Pittsburgh combined a driving ground attack with two key passes to defeat Penn State, 20-0, in a snowstorm today and boost its chances for a postseason bowl offer.

Members of a men's committee met last Wednesday at the home of their chairman, Robert S. Salant, to discuss plans for the seventeenth annual White Elephant Party. The event will be held in the ballroom of the Ambassador on Jan. 20.
PARENTS, duly concerned about the excessive time children spend in viewing television, might consider counterbalancing this kind of entertainment by providing a new stock of well-selected records.

SURVEYING the record industry's 1955 output of folk music, one is struck first of all by its sheer bulk. The pioneers in the field stepped up their production. Companies that never had given folk music much attention brought it out in quantity.

NEW DELHI. IN cities all over India, streets, and bazaars are being tidied up a bit, lawns are being clipped and children scrubbed in honor of the state visit of Soviet leaders this month. The country "naturally" wants to do itself proud in welcoming Russia's Premier Bulganin and Communist party boss Khrushchev.

KYLE ROTE had been as sensational as advertised in the pre-season training camp of the New York Football Giants in 1951 and Steve Owen's eyes glistened at the sight of him. So Stout Steve began to dream some big dreams. Here, perhaps, was the best halfback he'd ever coached, a star unmistakably destined for greatness.

Benefit dinners in the Rendezvous of the Plaza will precede a theatre party at the Dec. 19 performance of "The Lark" at the Longacre Theatre. Julie Harris is starring in the Jean Anouilh play, which has been adapted by Lillian Hellman.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19--The national policy committee of For America met here this week and announced that the organization was reorganizing as a political action committee, retaining its title, "For America--Not Incorporated."

THE Hussite Wars were a series of conflicts in fifteenthcentury Bohemia and Moravia that involved a religious struggle between Hussites (followers of John Huss) and Roman Catholics, a political struggle between Czechs and Germans and a social struggle.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 19 (UP) --Northwestern, without a victory in eight games, played Illinois to a 7-7 tie today and missed an opportunity to upset the Illini when Dale Pienta fumbled on the Illinois 8-yard line in the final minute of play.

IT may be confidently asserted that the Harvard class of '29 has produced more books, more articles and more millions of words about contract bridge and other games than any other college class in history.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--Applications for Government-insured housing have shown a substantial decline in the last two months.

THE consumer's willingness to buy remains strong despite a slight rise in prices generally, food excepted. The movement of most types of consumer goods continues to show substantial gains over a year ago. Last week the Federal Reserve Board reported that the output of nondurable goods in October again touched the high point that was reached in June.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 19-- The Democratic organization here is beginning to realize that George R. Brunjes, its successful candidate for Mayor, was in earnest when he said that all municipal appointments would be made on a merit basis.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--The deadlock of the foreign ministers at Geneva has brought United States foreign policy to a new and critical crossroads.

The display of a model house marks the formal opening today of High View Estates on Granite Springs Road and Sarles Drive at Sparkle Lake in Yorktown Heights, N. Y. The building has been furnished and decorated by Jack Shaw.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Nov. 8-- Until recent years New Zealand has been free of gang activities by youths.

GREENSBORO, N.C.--If you are not in too much of a hurry to get to Florida or if you are bound for the Gulf Coast, there is a scenic route that offers a fine alternative to the beaten trails to the deep South.
BIG BEND NATIONAL, PARK, Tex., Nov. 19--The nation's newest national park, which sprawls over 9,000 square miles of mountains and desert on the Rio Grande, will be formally dedicated Monday.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Water house plants as often as needed, most of them daily. For appearance and prevention of insects, clean off foliage once a week. Place small plants under the faucet and spray with tepid water, wipe off the foliage of large-leaved plants with a damp cloth but don't rub hard.
The first measurable snow of the season fell on the city yesterday, but it was hardly enough to create a winter wonderland.
FLORIDA'S professional froggers, whose hunting grounds, or rather marshes, are back in the vast Everglades, intend to take out paying guests this winter to help with their operating expenses.

SEATTLE, Nov. 19--"Propeller failure" was attributed by a DC-4 pilot today for a crash with twenty-seven fatalities just after a take-off early yesterday from Boeing Field here.

AN imposing group of operas is scheduled for early release by London Records. Three of them will be by Mozart--"Cosi fan tutte," "The Marriage of Figaro" and "The Magic Flute." All will be done by Vienna Opera singers.

A collection of French contemporary art, furniture and decorative accessories will be on display at a cocktail dansant in the ballroom and Trianon Room of the Ambassador on Dec. 8. Mrs. George Richard (Helen Menken) is chairman for the event, a benefit for the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled.

STEEL casement windows have certain advantages over double-hung windows. They also are easier to maintain. However, it's important to keep one point in mind. If neglected, steel casements rust, and rust is death on steel.

The Virginia Council on Health and Medical Care has been honored in the Group Division of the 1954 Lane Bryant annual awards for community service for its work in rural medical care. While in a strict sense the community served was Virginia, the award points up the broader meaning nationally of successful programs to attract physicians to rural areas in need of medical care.

IN rounding up the last year's most noteworthy LPs that fall within the classification of contemporary music, this writer is tormented by the thought of viewing as a single field a literature so broad and heterogeneous.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19--Bubbling with confidence and good cheer, former President Harry S. Truman held court today in the middle of Democratic political whirlpools here and declared that, he too, was running--"only to keep my reputation."

SO wrote a poet in an "Ode to Cheese," that wonderful food invented some three thousand years ago and enjoyed by man and praised in prose, song and verse through the ages. The newest testimonial to this gastronomical delight is "The Complete Book of Cheese" by Bob Brown.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 19 (AP) --Delaware defeated Bucknell today, 27--12, on a snowy field.

MONTREAL, Nov. 19--The Richard boys -- Maurice and Henri--scored half of Montreal's goals tonight at the Canadiens routed the second-place New York Rangers, 6--1. It was the tenth triumph in a row for the Montreal sextet.
The resignations of several top level secretaries or assistant secretaries in the Pentagon are expected within the next year.

LONDON. IT is not often in London that two exhibitions of major importance open in the same week. The great assemblage of Portuguese Art at the Royal Academy's Galleries, in Burlington House, and the retrospective exhibition of paintings by Stanley, Spencer at the Tate Gallery provide such an exception.

THE irregular airlines have always bridled at the term "non-scheduled." And after the liberalized operating rules accorded them by the Civil Aeronautics Board last week, they should have an easier time convincing the public to stop calling them "non-skeds."

AYELET HASHAHAR, Israel, Oct. 30--Archaeology in the military manner seems to have proved its value here during the first season of the Hazor diggings. Dr. Yigael Yadin, former Chief of Operations of the Israeli Army, commanded the campaign against a fortress city of the past that had its site here.

A theatre party to augment the Wellesley College Library Building Fund will take place at the Feb. 29 performance of "Pipe Dream," the new Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, starring Helen Traubel, which opens at the Shubert Theatre on Nov. 30.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 19--An Anglican priest, an outspoken opponent of South Africa's racial discrimination policies, has been told by a Government employe that he "deserved to be strung from a lamp post."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 19 --Notre Dame's Fighting Irish, sparked by Paul Hornung's pinpoint passing and accurate plaeekicking, stormed from, behind today with 10 points in the final eight minutes to beat Iowa, 17-14, for its eighth victory in nine games.

RECORDS are not made entirely in the concert hall. Between instruments and living room is a critical phase--usually secret and often denied--during which artists decide which bits of their music or song will become public.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 19-- The White House released today an exchange of greetings between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India on the occasion of the latter's sixty-sixth birthday last Monday.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (Reuters) --Luton Town today swamped Sunderland, 8--2, scoring four goals in a thirteen-minute spell in the first half. The defeat toppled Sunderland from first to fifth in the first division of English League soccer.

The importance of achieving personality in art will be the subject of a lecture by Martin Craig, sculptor and teacher, on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The lecture, one in a free series on art, will touch on methods of teaching that result in imitation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--An expert recommended today that Congress make a few basic changes in its practices. The effect, he said, would be more efficiency and a strengthening of the responsibility and accountability of party leadership.

STORRS, Conn., Nov. 19 (AP) --Taking advantage of one big break, the University of Connecticut Huskies defeated Holy Cross, 6--0, today on a field made sodden by a blinding snowstorm. It was Connecticut's first football victory over the Crusaders.
MANILA, Nov. 19 (UP)--The New York Yankees gave 20,000 fans a faultless display of bigtime baseball by beating an allFilipino team, 5--0, today.
Students in public schools should be taught godliness but not religion, the president of the New York City Board of Education declared yesterday.

THERE will be a new slide size in the contests and exhibitions if an experiment just launched succeeds in making headway. The popular 2x2-inch slide mount, which shows the 1x1 1/2-inch, 24x36mm frame provided by 35mm film, has been redesigned to hold a 38x38mm portion of the No. 120 film used in twinlens reflex cameras.

SOME four years ago Richmond P. Hobson Jr--son of the Merrimac hero of the SpanishAmerican War -- wrote "Grass Beyond the Mountains," a remarkable account of the discovery of the last great cattle ranges in North America.

You walk of an evening and the November stars are a multitude; and off to the east the constellation known as Orion is rising and to the west, also near the horizon, is Aquila, the constellation called the Eagle. The night is quiet, country quiet, with only an owl or a fox speaking, or a distant dog, and the soft song of the brook as it leaps over the rocks on the near hillside.

RENATA TEBALDI'S Aida was worth waiting for. She was scheduled to sing the role last season, her first at the Metropolitan Opera, but became ill. The commitment was carried over to this season, and yesterday afternoon it was fulfilled nobly.

TOKYO, Nov. 19--Relations between Japan and her near neighbor, the Republic of Korea, have hit a new low. The Seoul Government now threatens to fire upon Japanese fishing vessels violating the boundary set arbitrarily by President Syngman Rhee.

BUFFALO, Nov. 19 (AP)-- Lieut. Col. Edward A. Silk, holder of the Medal of Honor, died yesterday at the Sampson Air Force Base Hospital following a recent operation for a duodenal ulcer. His age was 39.

THE author of "The Little Madeleine" is taking a sentimental vacation away from the fog of her London, Paris and Normandy farm stampinggrounds. The avowed purpose is to visit Nice, where her longdead father did his military duty, and the bleak mining town, which she can still remember from her earliest childhood, before she went to grow up in Montmartre.

When the only woman member of the Legislative Council of New Guinea visits New York, she sees a play, she goes to the United Nations, she walks through Times Square and is "almost embarrassed by the hospitality."

BIOGRAPHERS who grapple with entertainers--a diva from the Met or a clown from the circus, a screen hellion or one of the theatre's immortals -- commonly wield the whitewash brush with fatal skill. Perversely they gloss over their target's excesses and heresies, in so doing reduce him from a d'Artagnan to a dullard.

Led by Bob Pettit with 33 points, the St. Louis Hawks defeated the New York Knickerbockers for the second time in five days last night. The Hawks gained a firmer hold on the lead in the Western Division of the National Basketball Association race by winning, 104 to 91, at Madison Square Garden.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 19-- Oklahoma's mighty Sooners buried the title hopes of Nebraska's fired-up Cornhuskers under a relentless avalanche of touchdowns today for a 41to-0 triumph. It marked the 10th Big Seven Conference football title for Oklahoma in ten campaigns.

SEATTLE, Nov. 19 (UP)--Fulloack Credell (Incredible) Green lived up to his nickname today as he led Washington to a 27-7 victory over Washington State. The Pacific Coast Conference game, ending the season for both teams, took place on a quagmire field before 30,000 homecoming fans.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 19 --Preliminary studies of this year's polio rates indicate that the Salk vaccine may be even more effective than originally expected. At the well-publicized Ann Arbor ceremony last April 12, the vaccine was proclaimed 80 to 90 per cent effective against paralytic polio.

CHORES around the house as in the garden change with the season. Fall perhaps more than any other is the time for repairs and refurbishing of the house in which so much time will be spent during the next six months.

Outer Mongolia--the country whose bid for admission to the United Nations has threatened to balk the "package deal" to enlarge the U.N. membership --is a 600,000-square-mile area in central Asia, sparsely populated by 900,000 people, of whom only 15 per cent live in cities.
COLVILLE, Wash., Nov. 19-- One of the grimmest combats in the history of public power development in the Pacific Northwest now is being waged.

TODAY'S audiophiles, like Dodger fans, no longer need wistfully cry: "Wait till next year!"
A GOOD, solid program--one might almost call it a typical Boston Symphony program --was presented by that orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

WITH the opening of a new hotel at St. Maarten in the Dutch West Indies, more accommodations are available for the browsing tourist. This development has brought another, a new package trip to tiny Saba, one of the most picturesque islands in the Antilles group.
A rich collection of Jewish art, painstakingly assembled to replace one lost in World War II, will be lost again to its owner this week. But this time it will be through his own volition.
STROUDSBURG, Pa., Nov. 19 --Several towns and villages in the Delaware River watershed complain that they were snubbed or ignored by the Army Engineers in the emergency flood repair program.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19-- The University of California at Los Angeles' Sam Brown and Bob Davenport led the Bruins to a Rose Bowl bid and its third straight Pacific Coast Conference championship today. The Bruins posted a 17-7 victory over the University of Southern California before 95,878 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

To the Screen Editor: I SAW the picture "Trial" some time before it opened in New York and I awaited with interest the comments of the New York critics. Mr. Crowther's review was up to his usual high standard and receives my thanks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn. Nov. 19 --In a bleak, wintry setting on a gridiron that looked like a huge skating oval, Yale defeated Harvard today, 21--7.

TOMORROW night Helen Hayes achieves a distinction rarely accorded an artist. In recognition of her fifty years on the stage and her position as one of the nation's most beloved actresses, the Fulton Theatre becomes the Helen Hayes. One other living star, Etliel Barrymore, enjoys similar enshrinement.

Ocean towing is a tedious calling. Day follows day with a monotonous sameness of green seas and sunlit or lowering sky. Not a ship breaks the horizon as the tows keep clear of the steamer tracks. Conversation withers and dies after a few days.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -- Argentina's General Confederation of Labor, one of the powerful monolithic supports for the Peron decade, was dismembered this week by the Government of Maj. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu, which was still in its infancy.

Old Master painting's, furniture and rare books and manuscripts will be autctioned in two sales this week at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. A third sale will offer a collection of Judaica.
VICENZA, Italy, Nov. 19-- This quiet little city on the northern edge of the Venetian Plain has taken United States service men to its heart.
RANGAMATI, Pakistan, Oct. 28--The idea that the West is an advanced society goes up in smoke here, for when a Buddhist tribesman marries he quits work.

Last week's increase in the discount rate--the rate banks pay for loans from the Federal Reserve -- will bring further pressure on rates in some segments of the money market and will make it harder for banks to make loans.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19--The Big Four members of the United Nations met for two hours today but failed to reach agreement on the question of admitting new members to the world organization.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19-- A program has been started to alleviate the 'traffic jam" in Los Angeles County's Superior Courts.
An analysis of United States foreign trade last week showed that the main problem in the field is how to maintain its current healthy expansion.

PHOTOGRAPHS for holiday giving are offered in a group show by eight photographers on exhibition through Jan. 6 at A Photographer's Gallery, 48 West Eightyfourth Street. The contributors are divided about evenly between new names and well-established workers, the group as a whole offering a widely varied selection of theme and style.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 19-- President Eisenhower has called top Administration officials to join him at Camp David in the Catoctin Mountains next week for meeting's of the Cabinet and the National Security Council.

In the opinion of Dr. Russell Couch, professor of poultry husbandry and biochemistry and nutrition at Texas Agricultural and Mechanical College, far more attention has been paid to vitamins than to minerals in animal and human nutrition.
EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 19 (UP)-- Speedy Oregon staged four long marches today to gain a 28-0 Pacific Coast Conference football victory over Oregon State.

The sweeping revision of New York State's code for fireresistive construction of industrial, commercial and public assembly buildings, adopted last Wednesday by the Board of Standards and Appeals, has brought the law up-to-date with today's construction methods and materials.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his column on Nov. 8 Arthur Krock reports that Stephen A. Mitchell and other Democratic leaders are considering a new proposal under which the Vice Presidential nominations would be made in advance of the Presidential nominations at the national party conventions.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19-- The city's Department of Commerce was advised today that a new zoning classification for 'waterfront industry" was imperative to insure more advantageous use of such land.

FOR more than three decades Claire R. Reis has been championing the cause of the contemporary composer. When the League of Composers, for which Mrs. Reis had labored devotedly, was merged with the United States Section of the International Society for Contemporary Music some months ago, she became, honorary chairman of the new group.
Heirs Of Attalus' The Stoa of Attalus, now being reconstructed in Athens by American scholars and philhellenes, makes Americans heirs of Attalus like the Romans.
TRENTON, Nov. 19--A record hospital building program is under way in New Jersey. It is expected to be completed within the next two years at a cost exceeding $150,000,000.

IT is hardly surprising that new recordings of Mozart's five most celebrated operas should come as harbingers of this bicentennial season. At present the score stands at new "Don Giovannis" from London and Epic, another on the way from Cetra, a "Figaro" from London and one promised by Victor, an Angel "Cosi fan tutte," a London "Magic Flute" and a Decca "Seraglio."
For a good many years November and December have been the months of Thanksgiving, Christmas and tax selling.

ON Oct.18, 1943, an article in Time magazine contained the obituary of Wahoo I, until that moment the most phenomenally successful of all our fleet submarines in World War II. The story, labeled "A Knock on the Door," described the torpedoing of a Japanese transport plying across Tsushima Strait, between Japan and Korea.

SELDOM has a book been written which was filled with more errors of fact, more transpositions of time and place, more confusions of concept than this rambling, prolix work by Pierre van Paassen. Yet, seldom has a book been created more true, more perceptive in its understanding of a people and their way of belief and of the significance of this belief to the rest of the world.
HARTFORD, Nov. 19--Connecticut is on its feet again. It is a trifle shaky but getting stronger each day.

THE festive holiday season provides new inspirations for the flower arranger. Themes might be developed from the cuisine with turkeys, pheasants, quail, fruits and vegetables as the basic ideas. Perhaps farms, fields and harvest will provide suggestions for some other designs.

MISS DEASY'S heroine and narrator is a self-possessed girl of 19, whom we meet as she is abandoning Bryn Mawr, in the middle of her sophomore year, because her father is having financial difficulties. On the train home-- home being Queensport, a city in the Upper South--this Betsy Donlon encounters a young man who has been associated with her father in state politics.

NOT in the memory,of the oldest inhabitant has there been such a busy, international and unpredictable dance season as the present one is turning out to be. This week is full of overlappings, conflicts and general complexity.

THERE are few more dramatic documents than the record of Joan of Arc's first trial in 1431. Her authentic voice reaches us across half a millennium, a unique blend of peasant simplicity and shrewdness, mystic power and earthy humor.

HARDLY anyone engaged in gardening underestimates the value of compost for growing plants indoors or out. Its beneficial effects on the soil itself is a fact accepted by all. Certainly, then, it is worth while to take some time in selecting and blending the materials and providing the right conditions for the composting process.

THE night which Walter Lord reconjures for us in tense and telling detail is the night of April 14, 1912. It was a night of grandeur and terror. It was the end of an era of security and the beginning of a time of danger and disbelief.

Secretary Dulles, reporting to the nation Friday night on what happened and did not happen at Geneva, was fully aware of what happened in the atomic testing ground of Eniwetok in the Pacific. It was against this background that he presented his simple and straightforward narrative and explanation.
VIENNA, Nov. 19--Financing at Austrian production by selling corporation securities was predicted by Austrian Finance Minister Reinhard Kamitz today.
LONDON. THE SPEAKER: Question Number 9. MR. J.E.B. HILL asked the Minister of Agriculture the annual financial cost of damage done to crops by pigeons.

THERE has been a great deal of argument about the creature known as the "Abominaable Snowman." For nearly seventy years there have been reports of the existence of an unknown animal in the upper valleys of Nepal and Tibet.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Nov. 11--Economically and politically, this new partner in the Netherlands Kingdom is moving ahead like a robust toddler. It knows where it wants to go, but not quite how to get there.
Many college freshmen Know very little about American history, if a sampling in an Ohio institution is any indication.

DURING most of the years of its relatively short existence, jazz has had to be content with a small, almost cult-like audience. From a recording point of view, it was not a field from which large profits might be expected.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A lecture tour sponsored by the Robert Schalkenbach Foundation of New York has taken me across the continent and brought me into contact with many sections of the American people. I was asked to speak about race problems in South Africa, with particular reference to their relation to the land problem, and on the taxation of land values with exemption of improvements in South African towns.

NEW ENGLAND and Thanksgiving Day are practically synonymous. Many people will return to New England for their forthcoming Thursday turkey dinner, and many more will simply turn their thoughts to that region.

TOMORROW will be a great day at Big Bend National Park, Texas, when it is officially dedicated as the newest addition to the National Park system. Although the park was established in June, 1944, this ceremony marks its formal adoption into the country-wide chain.

BERLIN, Nov. 19--Before an applauding crowd of many thousands, the leaders of the West Berlin Government today laid the full blame for the failure of the Foreign Ministers' Conference on the Soviet Union.

TOKYO, Nov. 19--Turbulent Japanese politics, fractured and confused since the war, boiled down to a two-party system this week, at least temporarily. Observers hailed this development as a milestone in the island empire's evolution from the authoritarian rule of centuries to modern representative government.

rise to any very close approximation of complete goodness, nor descend to the ultimate nadir of evil. Justin Valley, the "gladesman" of the title, is-- at least at the outset--a thrifty farmer tilling his acres and providing loyal support for those under his family roof.

SATIRE, which is allowed under the First Amendment, is not a popular art form in America today. France has a Canard Enchaine, West Germany a Simplicissimus, even Sicily a yellow - beaked Becco Giallo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--In 1932, when bread lines were forming on the streets, Senator Robert M. LaFollette Jr. and a few others decided they would like to find out just how deep the depression actually was. Nobody knew because there were simply no figures in those days.

WACO, Tex., Nov. 19 (UP)-- Quarterback John Roach threw two fourth-down touchdown passes today to lead Southern Methodist to a 12-0 victory over Baylor in a rough-and-tumble Southwest Conference game.

It begins at Pittsburgh's Golden Triangle where the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers meet. From there it flows 981 miles in a west-to-southwesterly direction, passing the nation's great steel mills, bituminous coal fields, atomic plants and fertile farm country.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19--A multi-million dollar aerial rapid transit system of rubber-tired, mile-a-minute trains running on concrete trainways sixteen feet above city streets was proposed for Los Angeles this week by Henry K. Norton, eastern transportation executive.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 19-- Dr. Marion Hathway, in private life Mrs. Theodore R. Parker, educator and social worker, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Bryn Mawr Hospital. Her age was 60.

BESIDES the activities of the larger companies, the week contains other dance events of interest in the outlying districts. Among them is a performance by Paul Draper at the "Y" at the conclusion of a brief tour that opened in Chicago early in October.

One of the highest honors of the engineering world, the 1956 John Fritz Medal, was presented last Wednesday to Philip Sporn, president of American Gas and Electric Company.
BOSTON, Nov. 16--The Boston Police Department appeared slated this week for an overhauling of its crime reports.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 19--An international center to encourage understanding and tolerance will be provided here by the newly incorporated Verhelle Foundation. The nonprofit, educational and humanitarian organization will be open to all interested in extending welcome to men and women of other nations, other races and other ways of worshipping God.

THIS is a concise account of the genesis of the South's web of racial segregation laws and customs. It underscores the theme that Jim Crowism was contrived from a true linseywoolsey, that, even before Jim Crow laws, the South had already woven a garment of considerable variegation with respect to racial accommodations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- The forepart of last week witnessed free selling of corn futures on the Board of Trade, reflecting extremely heavy receipts and weakness in the spot market as cash buyers backed away. Soybeans also came in for free selling, and oats were affected. Wheat was heavy at times, but showed a capacity for coming back and was fairly strong later.

Arthur Koestler's new book, "Trail of the Dinosaur," which Macmillan will publish on Dec. 5, is a collection of essays similar to his famous "The Vogi and the Commissar." In addition to the political essays Mr. Koestler's readers naturally expect from him, "Trail of the Dinosaur" will contain discussions of such literary subjects as the future of the novel and the pros and cons of science fiction.
A lively and rewarding session of the Composers Forum Saturday night at Columbia University's McMillin Theatre was devoted to music of two young Americans, Mel Powell and Daniel Pinkham.
Thomas J. Curran predicted yesterday that Republicans would support compulsory automobile insurance at the next session of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- The Army and Air Force are at odds over secret tests in which the Army's anti-aircraft rocket, the Nike, knocked down a Matador jet bomber missile, officials asserted today.

The official attitude of the State Department toward Spain and the former Peron regime in Argentina does not reflect the way American people feel about dictatorships, according to the Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, dean of New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

VIENNA, Nov. 20 -- Bargain hunters from European industrial countries, notably Switzerland, the Netherlands and Belgium, and from the United States have converged on Vienna in the last few days. They have been sent out by large international concerns and hope to pick up at knocked-down prices choice remnants of once-flourishing industrial enterprises in the zone of Austria recently evacuated by Soviet troops after ten years of military occupation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Senate Banking Committee announced today the successful completion of negotiations with Government agencies and private groups for gatherings badly needed statistics on institutional investments in stocks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, demanded today that the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act be scrapped.

The charter market rebounded last week after undergoing three weeks of pressure on rates by coal interests. As coal rates climbed again gains were noted in almost all other commodities, too. Tanker rates, however, continued on a sharp upward curve.

IN spite of the late announcement of her opening, Carmen Amaya was greeted at the Holiday Theatre last night by a large and excited audience. The ovation that met her on her initial appearance and the enthusiasm with which each of her four numbers was received were fully merited, for she danced with all the fire and passion that have long been associated with her.
Thanksgiving Day should inspire "real Americans" to express their gratitude to God not only in prayer but also in works of mercy, Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly declared yesterday.

RUDYARD KIPLING, an authentic literary genius and one of the greatest masters of the short story in English, died a little less than twenty years ago. He was 70 years old and had been famous for forty-six years. Already critical favor had turned away from him. Kipling's very popularity antagonized numerous literary intellectuals.
The medical superintendents of the municipal hospitals have asked the city to classify them into three groups with salaries geared to hospital size.

A new Jewish chapel for the city penitentiary on Rikers Island was dedicated yesterday afternoon by Commissioner of Correction Anna M. Kross. Religious and civil leaders and Jewish inmates of the penal institution attended.

" THE Caine Mutiny Court Martial," seen Saturday evening over Channel 2, was ninety minutes of brilliant television theatre, an outstanding achievement of the season in all respects.
Your issue of Oct. 28 reports that the Tariff Commission has increased the duties on British-made cast-iron soil pipe. This act was taken under the "anti-dumping" provisions of our legislation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- United States officials disclosed today that the three Western powers had agreed at Geneva to publish "as much as possible as soon as possible" of the record of the recent Foreign Ministers' Conference.
The new front steps planned for the refurbished City Hall will be wired for sound to provide an ever-ready system for broadcasting public speeches and ceremonies.

SEATTLE, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Civil Aeronautics Board officials examined today "specific evidence" gathered in their investigation of the crash of a nonscheduled DC-4 airplane near here Friday that killed twenty-seven of seventy-four persons aboard.
TRINT's GROCERY is like no other city grocery. It is a neighborhood institution with some of the flavor of the old village tavern.

Harold E. Stassen complained yesterday that Adlai E. Stevenson's recent speeches had had an adverse effect abroad on United States foreign policy.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 20 -- Tengku Abdul Rahman, Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya, received a new message from the Communists today regarding proposed peace talks.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 20 -- Considerable interest is being shown here in plans for the building of a large dam on the Surinam River, eighty miles south of Paramaribo, and also for erection there of an aluminum factory.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 20 -- French Morocco appeared today to be heading for a breakdown of law and order. There seemed to be no effective national authority capable of controlling the populace. In the twenty-four hours up to noon, fourteen persons were killed in clashes, or murdered and sixty others were wounded, many of them seriously. No arrests were made.

The Church of Christ treads a danger-filled path, the Rev. Martin Niemoeller said yesterday. The German clergyman, a member of the Central Committee of the World Council of Churches, preached at the Broadway Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

The Giants smothered the Philadelphia Eagles, 31-7, yesterday at the Polo Grounds. With this easy victory over a club that had virtually ruined their season at the outset, the Giants jumped from last place in the National Football League's Eastern Conference into a tie for third.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Princeton University will celebrate its first Ivy League title since 1951 with a bonfire, a ceremony traditionally reserved for Big Three championships, on Cannon Green tomorrow night.
SEATTLE, Nov. 20 -- Former Senator Harry P. Cain's home state is interested in a Department of Justice move to have him disqualified as hearing officer in a Subversive Activities Control Board case.
Lerner Shops has leased a 16,000-square-foot store in the Green Acres Shopping Center being built by the Chanin Organization on Sunrise Highway in Valley Stream, L. I.

Neither snow nor icy streets nor wintry blasts kept stamp lovers from setting an attendance record at the National Postage Stamp Show the last three days.

AURICH, Germany, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- West Germany has launched a ten-year dike-building and drainage program to save 1,630,915 acres of coastal land from the waters of the North Sea.

P. camps in West Germany.
An educator who says he stumbled into the teaching profession will be inducted tomorrow as the fifth president of Teachers College, Columbia University.
Representatives of seventy-five patriotic societies participated yesterday in their annual service at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Fund for the Republic, said today that it judged all job applicants, including Communists, on the basis of their individual qualifications.

Arthur B. Bisguier, the United States chess champion, gained his sixth victory yesterday in the international tournament at Zagreb, Yugoslavia, and tied Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia for fourth place. Each has a record of 9 1/2 -- 5 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Proposals for major and minor revisions in the United Nations Charter, their feasibility and their probable effects on that body and the United States are examined in a detailed study published today by the Brookings Institution.

Elmo Roper, marketing consultant, has been elected president of the Atlantic Union Committee by its national board of governors. He succeeds the late Associate Justice Owen J. Roberts of the United States Supreme Court, who founded the organization in 1949.

The five-story Delphic Towers apartment property at the southeast corner of Hudson Boulevard and Eighty-seventh Street in North Bergen, N. J., has been sold by the P. E. NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- Mrs. Marguerite S. Tyson's miniature poodle, Ch. Adastra Magic Fame, "asked for" and won best in show at the Newark Kennel Club's thirty-seventh annual allbreed event today. The show was held at the Newark Armory.

Dividend interest rates payable next year on both life insurance and annuity policies of Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America will be raised by one-quarter of 1 per cent to 3 per cent, it was announced over the week-end. Normally, a tie with the hard-hitting Canadiens of Montreal would be satisfactory to the Rangers. The Broadway Blues played a 1-1 deadlock with the Flying Frenchmen at Madison Square Garden last night, but the outcome was not particularly pleasing to the Ranger followers in the crowd of 15,358 fans.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Nov. 20 -- Tunisia has become the site of a struggle between the Moslem and Western worlds.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- An award for student creative writing achievement has been established at Princeton University in honor of the late F. Scott Fitzgerald, author and a member of the Princeton Class of '17.
AGRA, India, Nov. 20 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev sat today in the throne room of the Mogul emperors, admired their taste but shook his head at their economics.

Seven new films, including an import from France, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow: Today--"Diabolique/' a French-t made suspense drama produced and 'directed by Henri-Georges! Clouzot, at the Fine Arts.!

Legislators have been asked to compel insurance companies to pay back $17,000,000 in special premiums collected from employers and labor - management welfare funds under the State Disability Benefits Law.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 20 (AP) -The Missouri Valley Amateur Athletic Union board of managers today voted to lift the suspension of Wes Santee, this country's fastest miler.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- A long-time capital social rule says that proper Washingtonians should call at the White House once a year and leave a calling card.
BUFFALO, Nov. 20 -- The Right Rev. John J. McMahon of Buffalo today called The New York Times the "chief protagonist" of a "growing, dangerous idea" involving freedom in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Federal grants totaling $441,038 have been awarded to fifteen organizations in eight states for research or demonstration projects that show promise of helping to rehabilitate handicapped persons.

DAVID OISTRAKH, who has the reputation of being the Soviet Union's best violinist, made his American debut at Carnegie Hall early last evening. He quickly proved that he belongs with the best anywhere.
NEW DELHI, Monday. Nov. 21 -- Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin said here last night that he was "certain" the Soviet Union and the Western powers would be able to solve the problems dividing them.
BOSTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins and the Toronto Maple Leafs battled to a 1 -- 1 tie in a National Hockey League game before 10,697 tonight.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 -- The Maryland National Guard was ordered desegregated today in the first such action by any state south of the Mason and Dixon's line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Rough Ranger training now is open to any physically fit Army man, regardless of branch of service. It has been limited to volunteers from infantry, airborne and armored divisions.
HAVANA, Nov. 20 -- Cuban yachtsmen led today after the first two races of the world Star Class sailing championship.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 (UP) -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced plans today for extension of its "Piggyback" freight service.
