Under tariff filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington, the road, effective tomorrow, will offer inter-line piggyback service to Cleveland Detroit, Chicago, St. Louis, Akron, Fort Wayne, Youngstown and surrounding industrial communities for shippers in the Boston and Providence areas.
ATHENS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The largest electrification project ever planned in Greece may be assigned to Italian companies.

The veteran virtuoso, Mischa Elman, joined forces with Pierre Monteux, the veteran conductor, to bring a breath of spring to the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony in Carnegie Hall early yesterday afternoon.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is hunting more than 2,000 "draft delinquents" in New York, the city director of Selective Service said last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Before leaving for Camp David, the President will confer privately with Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency. The C. I. A. works closely with the Security Council, which advises the President on defense and foreign policy matters.

Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the New York State Assembly, has had the political courage to speak out unqualifiedly for compulsory liability insurance for automobiles. In doing so at a time when other spokesmen of both parties are either silent or juggling with timid alternatives, Mr. Heck assumes a leadership that is sadly needed and that makes him conspicuous if lonely.

Brooklyn's six-member Democratic delegation in the House of Representatives protested strenuously yesterday against the prospective lay-off of 600 civilian employes of the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- A ten-man delegation from the United States Congress was in London tonight to start a week's visit as guests of the British Parliamentary Union.
RINGOES, N. J., Nov. 20 -- The national field trial championship for cocker spaniels that was concluded today developed into a family affair with the victory of F. T. Ch. Greatford Meadowcourt Pin.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Following the shakeout of the previous week, stock markets in the last few days have staged a modest but welcome recovery.

Marquis James, who died Saturday morning, was brought up in the Cherokee Strip when Oklahoma was wilder than it is now. He shied away from formal schooling and got a good deal of his education by working for a long series of newspapers and, between assignments, reading whatever books he could lay hands on.

The battleship Mississippi, oldest Navy ship in commission, was hostess yesterday to 1,100 windwhipped visitors at Pier 88, North River, at Forty-eighth Street. The ship was commissioned in December, 1917.
An operating deficit of $9,211 is shown by Fordham University for the 1954-55 fiscal year in the annual report of the president, published yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- The Coast Guard rescued fourteen men from two wrecked vessels today. It also responded to calls for assistance from several other ships damaged by high seas whipped by winds that hit gusts of eighty miles an hour.
Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett of Israel reiterated yesterday that his nation must purchase military supplies even at the risk of paralyzing its economic development.
THE BOWL of nuts that traditionally winds up the Thanksgiving feast may look this year as if a miser had arranged it. Nut supplies generally are the smallest in ten years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Illiteracy is inflicting "casualties" on the Army at the rate of four men out of every 100 who enter the service.

Pete Rothermel, the head football coach at St. George's of Newport, R. I., and George Wheeler, who assists him, were concluding a discussion of strategy for their game with Milton. Also in at the gabfest was Dail Rhee, the team's captain.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Michigan State greeted today's official word of its Rose Bowl nomination as the Big Ten's representative with noisy enthusiasm, but without the near-rioting that accompanied a similar announcement two years ago.

A letter published on this page today from Arthur Levitt, State Controller, offers welcome clarification and extension of remarks on the problems bearing on state aid to education, a subject which will be one of the most perplexing to go before the 1956 Legislature.
A continuing trend by young and old to increase educational capacities is reflected in the thirteenth annual financial report of the Board of Higher Education.

IT was an astringent version of Oliver Goldsmith's "She Stoops to Conquer" that was offered yesterday on "Omnibus" over Channel 2. Except for Hermione Gingold, in the role of the kittenish Mrs. Hardcastle, the cast of the eighteenth-century farce about courtship and mistaken identity appeared self-conscious and restrained.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights, entering its second week on public hearings tomorrow, already appeared to have started governmental reform.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- The main question about the Democratic party's Presidential campaign now is not who is going to run but how liberal or progressive or moderate-conservative Adlai E. Stevenson will be in the campaign.

THOSE Italian family acts that delight circus goers seem to be just as popular in fashion circles nowadays. During the last month or so, three fashion families from the land of the pizza have trooped through New York.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 20 -- A panel of distinguished Brazilian physicians will examine Joao Cafe Filho tomorrow to determine whether Brazil's President has recovered from a recent heart attack.
VENICE, Nov. 20 -- The Veneians can hardly believe their eyes -- or their ears and noses.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers scored 14 points in the fourth quarter today to beat the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 27 -- 21, and remain in the thick of the race for the National Football League's Western Conference crown.
MANILA, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Elston Howard and Bill Skowron hit home runs as the New York Yankees concluded their tour of the Far East today with an 18 -- 6 triumph over a team of Filipino stars.

BUFFALO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Horace Ashenfelter defeated seventy-two athletes at snow-covered Delaware Park today as he posted a course record in winning the National Senior Amateur Athletic Union 10,000-meter cross-country run title.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Vic Janowicz scored a touchdown, a field goal and four points after touchdown today to lead the Washington Redskins to a 31-0 victory over the Chicago Cardinals before 16,901 fans.

The five-story business building at 120 East Fifty-seventh Street has been resold by Jack Brause, real estate operator and investor. Purchase was made by S. Beryl Lush of Philadelphia, an investor, through Cushman Wakefield, Inc., and Charles Recht as brokers.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Sanford Waxer, 27 years old, said today the Army had classified his discharge as "honorable" after a loyalty investigation that involved Dr. Alfred Kelly of the Wayne University faculty.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- British automobile manufacturers will receive the first opportunity in production based on new designs and techniques developed by Harry Ferguson.
DURANT, Miss., Nov. 20 (UP) -- A small Presbyterian church demanded the resignation of it pastor today because he defended two white men who were said to have advocated racial integration.

When economists argue about The Industrial Revolution -- and it is a subject that seems to deserve all three capitals -- they find their examples almost exclusively in Britain and America. It is probable that more books have been written on these than there were factories in both countries in 1848.
Nathan Milstein completed Carnegie Hall's great day of violin playing last night. Among the 2,300 who assembled to hear him were his two forerunners in the hall, Mischa Elman and David Oistrakh.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 19 -- Machinery has been set in motion for Guatemala's first legislative and municipal elections since the Communist-infiltrated regime of Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman was overthrown in July, 1954.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, in the Pacific, Nov. 19 -- The United States Navy has a university at sea.
WARSAW, Nov. 18 -- Poland redefined this week her drive for the development of simple farm cooperatives as opposed to the Soviet-style collectives.

DIDCOT, England, Monday, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- The death toll in a Wales-to-London excursion train wreck rose to ten early today when rescue workers found a woman's body buried beneath the debris of one of the seven smashed coaches.

MAURICE EVANS brought a delightful sparkle to television yesterday afternoon. His revival of George Bernard Shaw's "The Devil's Disciple," with himself as Dick Dudgeon and Dennis King as Gen. (Gentleman Johnny) Burgoyne, was played to the hilt for a richly amusing ninety minutes (Channel 4).
The observance of the central of the death of Poland's great national poet began here yesterday. It is being marked by both foes and friends of the present Warsaw Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Inventories of both manufacturing and trade concerns showed a book value of approximately $80,000,000,000 at the end of the third quarter, the Government disclosed today.

When Thanksgiving Day approaches, Charles F. Noyes does not order just one turkey. This year he bought ten and a half tons of them. He shipped them yesterday to 1,081 friends over the world. "It's simply a goodwill gesture," he said, that began thirty-one years ago "and seems to have snowballed."

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -- The Mizrachi Organization of America today called on the Federal Government "to negotiate immediately a mutual assistance pact with Israel that will guarantee the permanence of Israel's present frontiers."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- William P. Rogers, Deputy Attorney General, today called the slaying of Emmett Till "a real black mark" in that the boy's killers "have not been brought to justice."
The National Association of Manufacturers gave its blessing yesterday to a new lay-off plan designed to take the steam out of union pressure for a guaranteed annual wage.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20 -- Three generals active in the revolt that overthrew Juan D. Peron were put out of circulation today by the new regime of Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The short-term borrowing costs of the Treasury have increased to the highest point in more than twenty years.

Directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. yesterday did not split the stock. Instead, they declared a year-end dividend of $3 a share on the common, bringing 1955 distributions to $7, against $5.50 last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Poland charged today that the United States had placed obstacles in the path of Czechoslovak and Polish armistice inspectors in Korea.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 21 -Britain and four other members of the Baghdad pact took the first steps today to set up a permanent defense organization along the Soviet Union's southern border.
WASHINGTON, NOV. 21 -- A covey of helicopters made transport history today, by carrying the nation's leading political strategists to a rendezvous with President Eisenhower in the Maryland mountains.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Protestants and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State today called the 1955 statement of Roman Catholic bishops a bid for Federal aid for parochial schools.
Thomas E. Murray, member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, deserves the gratitude of the entire world for his address at the Fordham Law School.

In inspection of the city's lodging houses started yesterday morning when Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. and firemen went through a 50-cent-a-night establishment on the Bowery. The Commissioner and his men were looking for fire violations and they found them.

Stocks moved without much direction yesterday in one of the dullest sessions of the month and finally closed lower. Oils, coppers, aircrafts and rails were mixed. Chemicals, motors, steels and electrical equipments were soft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -Two members of President Eisenhower's Cabinet and Adlai E. Stevenson, titular leader of the Democratic party, will address the first joint convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- The ingenuity of Westchester County housewives is undergoing a severe test. Delayed railroad trains and the resulting uncertainty of just when commuting husbands will return from New York are the cause.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett said today that Israel might take arms even from the Communist bloc if she were driven into "a very tight corner" where her survival was at stake.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -- Blevins Davis' and Robert Breen's production of "Porgy and Bess," which opened its West German tour Friday, with a thundering success in Duesseldorf, has opened a window on a United States that is little known to the German people.

LAST night's staged reading of "Anna Christie" at the Phoenix Theatre served little purpose but to demonstrate the versatility of Geraldine Page. Miss Page has the makings of an ideal Anna. She brought a kind of frowzy luminosity to the role of Eugene O'Neill's pathetic trollop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Representative Arthur G. Klein said today his House commerce subcommittee was "greatly encouraged" by a two-year $75,000,000 expansion program to double the capacity of southern newsprint mills.

Secretary of State Dulles' report to the nation shows that our policy of military containment has now reached the end of a dead-end street. The conditions which led us to hope for the success of this policy no longer exist.
SEATTLE, Nov. 21 -- Following is the text of an address by Governor Harriman prepared for delivery at the Washington State Democratic dinner tonight:
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 (AP) -The board of directors of the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company today recommended to stockholders a three-for-one split in the company's common stock.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Britain's shipbuilding industry, which was worried not long ago about dwindling orders, is now enjoying a boom.

A three-day hearing into employe pension and welfare plans, designed to gather information on which to base recommendations for state legislative control, was begun yesterday by the State Insurance Department.
Mayor Wagner's Committee for a Quiet City will ask the public for financial as well as moral support in its crusade against irritating street noises.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Television will have to struggle along as best it can for the immediate future, at least without active participation by the Screen Producers Guild as a source of production.
Events today: Cesare Siepi, bass, Carnegie Hall; Henri Deering, pianist, Town Hall; Manhattan Orchestra, Jonel Perlea, conductor, Manhattan School of Music, all at 8:30 P. M.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 21 (AP) -- A construction engineer, who spent $2,000 in legal fees, today won reversal of a motor vehicle fine of $10.
Two machines were introduced to Wall Street yesterday -- one to speed up stock brokerage calculations and the other to expedite deposits and withdrawals at a savings bank.

The American Radio Association, C. I. O., has entered a formal objection to the formation of American Bulk Cargoes, Inc., a joint venture of American President Lines and the Pacific Far East Line. The union has asked the Federal Maritime Board to withhold approval pending a complete review.
Several lawyers in the city were scratching their heads last night in amazement over a new deal that has come to light in Long Island real estate.
While there have been many notable apparitions of the Virgin Mary, the appearance of Christ before a reigning Pope is believed unique in modern history.
Four youths who flooded a minister's home in misguided vengeance were ordered yesterday to pay him $2,125 to repair the damage.
WHEN Christmas cards first went into commercial production in the United States in 1875 Santa Claus was conspicuous by his absence.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 22 -- Ichiro Hatoyama was elected Premier today by an overwhelming vote of both houses of the Diet (Parliament).

Family Curb, Not Censorship, Urged by Welfare Forum on the Problem Here Those who contend that certain comic books contribute to juvenile delinquency have failed to prove their case, social welfare leaders were told last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Two witnesses accused the General Motors Corporation today of trying to kill competition in the auto parts and repair business. A Senator promptly raised a threat of possible Congressional action.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- American and other foreign oil companies whose rights in Austria were wiped out first by the Nazis and then by the Russians seem certain to get at least a substantial part of them back from the Austrian Government.

Moves in commodity futures were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges in generally dull trading. Price changes in coffee, lead, copper and sugar were mixed; cocoa, rubber, zinc, wool, hides and silk rose, and cottonseed oil, onions and burlap eased.

Down on Fourteenth Street two weeks ago Willie Hoppe, whose name has been synonymous with the best in billiards for more than half a century, played an exhibition at three cushions. The "Boy Wonder" of sixty years ago still is a top man in the game, though he has retired from tournament competition.
At the unlikely corner of Hubert and Collister Streets, an off-Broadway troupe put on a realistic drama yesterday with a single set -- a Magistrate's Court.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Duke Power Company at a special meeting today approved a 2-for1 split in the company's stock. They also increased the authorized shares from 5,000,000 to 12,500,000 and noted to reduce the par value of the common from $25 to $17.50.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission overrode the Montana State courts today and ordered Montana's intrastate railroad freight rates increased by 9 per cent. The order directed that the revisions be made by Feb. 10, 1956.
RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 21 -- French military and civilian authorities throughout Morocco received instructions today to suppress by force all manifestations of violence and lawlessness.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The thousands of high school students expected to visit Washington next spring will be treated to free concerts by the National Symphony Orchestra.

Lester Patrick, the old "silver fox" of the National Hockey League, is here to see his first hockey game at Madison Square Garden since he left New York in 1949. The 71 - year - old former Ranger coach will be at the Eighth Avenue arena tomorrow night when the local six meets the Boston Bruins.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A decision in the Louisiana maneuvers by Gen. O. P. Weyland has caused one of the liveliest doctrinal arguments between the Air Force and the Army in recent years.

The Army violates civil rights when it gives anything less than an honorable discharge to an inductee because of pre-induction membership in or association with the Communist party or subversive organizations, it was held yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee opened hearings today on the nation's immigration policy. It heard a Senator and religious and labor representatives urge that the policy be liberalized.
A lively looking Greek goddess in company with a faun, a centaur and sprightly artists took over the pool in the restaurant of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday.
Orson Welles will star in a repertory program at the City Center for six weeks beginning January.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, in the Pacific, Nov. 21 -A balloon-supported antenna of 500 feet was launched today. It is designed to overcome the notoriously bad communication conditions in the Antarctic.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Nov. 21 -- In office for two months, the first autonomous Government of Tunisia is being subjected to an increasing barrage of criticism for its inaction.
Capt. Charles A. Ryan of the Steel Fabricator, an Isthmian Steamship Company employe since 1922, was named commodore of the Isthmian fleet yesterday.
SEATTLE, Nov. 21 -- Governor Harriman berated the Eisenhower Administration tonight as bungling, contradictory, incompetent and short-sighted in its conduct of foreign affairs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- The United States is closing part of its refugee program in Greece because enough applications have been received to fill the 17,000 United States entry quota.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21 -Joao Cafe Filho announced tonight he would return to the Presidency of Brazil. Congress, controlled by his foes, moved immediately to prevent him from doing so.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 21 -- A formula for the settlement of the year-long tax dispute between the South Korean Government and foreign business men here was agreed on today by a business group and the Korean Ministry of Finance. If approved tomorrow by President Syngman Rhee it will go into effect immediately.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, the Democratic leader of the Senate, put forward today a thirteen-point program for the second session of the Eighty-fourth Congress.
Army concedes that Navy's football team should be a pre-game favorite for the annual clash of the service elevens on Saturday in Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Bert Bell, commissioner of the National Football League, said today a rules proposal would be made at the January league meeting in Los Angeles to encourage more punt returns.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 21 -- Chanting "hate Yale, hate Yale," jubilant Princeton University students burned a Yale football player in effigy tonight to celebrate their first Ivy League title since 1951.
Amid simple ceremonies, the Fulton Theatre last night became the Helen Hayes.
An auction of 169 parcels of city-owned property held yesterday by the Board of Estimate in the Council Chamber at City Hall brought $782,830.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Michigan State, Ohio State and Michigan dominated the 1955 All-Big Ten football team selected today by The Associated Press.

The engagement of Paul Paray and Leonard Bernstein as guest conductors of the Philharmonic-Symphony during the 1956-57 season was announced yesterday by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York. The society also announced the reappointment of Dimitri Mitropoulos for his sixth season as musical director of the orchestra.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Britain urged the Trusteeship Council today to take action as promptly as possible on a proposed plebiscite to determine the future of British Togoland.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Secretary of Labor today stepped into the growing Republican controversy over the approach to organized labor in the 1956 political campaign.
A Queens carpet executive who lost both legs when muggers threw him into the path of a subway train won a $150,000 settlement against the Transit Authority yesterday.
BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- The hospital of the future must be organized like a modern department store to "merchandize the product" of good health, Dr. Howard A. Rusk asserted tonight.

Connecticut Light and Power Company has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $20,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent mortgage bonds. The transaction is to be underwritten by a syndicate headed by Putnam Co., Charles W. Scranton Co. and Estrabrook Co. Money raised by the sale would be used to pay off bank loans incurred in financing construction.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a case involving the Government's right to dismiss a Federal employe from a non-sensitive job as a security risk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to pay off the $21,577,989 debt it owes its parent, the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, through a preferred stock issue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A program prepared by the City of Hoboken, N. J., to eliminate its slums and other blighted areas, has been approved by Albert M. Cole, administrator of the Housing and Home Finance agency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- In his oblique criticism of the speech Adlai E. Stevenson made to the Democratic gathering in Chicago Saturday night Gov. Averell Harriman of New York uttered a historic political truth. "Moderation" and "middleof-the-road" are traditional Republican, not Democratic, campaign positions.

For twenty years the Federation of the Handicapped, Inc., 211 West Fourteenth Street, New York 11, has carried on a steady campaign to bring to the public a realization that men and women, no matter how badly handicapped, can become useful citizens and earn part or all of their own living if they are properly trained.

The building eontaihing fourteen at 98T Fifth Avenua, near Seventy-ninth Street, ham been-purohased for investsent by Antoinette and Philo-I monet bfarstcano. The property, assessed at $13d,000, was sold subject to mortgages of $1/5,000.

Thanksgiving Day football rivalries are as traditional in New Jersey as the holiday turkey. Most of the games involve neighboring communities, but it is more than geographical juxtaposition that keeps the rivalries going.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 593 pints of blood on Friday. Included were 174 pints taken at the Hearst Corporation, 250 West Fifty-fifth Street; 102 at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, 215-35 Thirty-eighth Avenue, Bayside, Queens, and 100 at the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, 180 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

By winning his adjourned fifteenth-round game and drawing in the sixteenth, each time with a Yugoslavian opponent, Vassily Smyslov of Russia continued unbeaten in the international chess tournament at Zagreb, Yugoslavia, yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The British Government now considers the visit to London next spring of top Soviet leaders as an important opportunity for extensive discussions on East-West issues.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 21 -- An Argentine federal judge handed down today an opinion that the extradition of deposed President Juan D. Peron should be sought on charges of "illicit association."

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- The National Stevenson for President Committee opened its office here today. The nonprofessional political group will coordinate efforts of volunteers to nominate and elect Adlai E. Stevenson to the Presidency.

Today's new film is "Queen Bee," a suspense drama produced by Jerry Wald and starring Joan Crawford, at Loew's State. Ranald MacDougall's screen play was based on a novel by Edna Lee. Barry Sullivan, Betsy Palmer and John Ireland have principal roles in the Columbia presentation, which was directed by Mr. MacDougall.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (AP) -Happy over the formal selection of the University of California at Los Angeles football team to represent the Pacific Coast Conference against Michigan State in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 2, Bruin students staged an impromptu celebration on the campus in the rain today.
The Department of Housing and Buildings recommended yesterday a $500 fine and thirty days in jail for building violations in the skyscraper Lincoln Hotel. The violations assertedly date from 1948.

For years now every foreign tourist in Moscow has had to make a pilgrimage to the Metro, Moscow's subway. At every station this tourist has had to oh and ah in admiration at the sumptuous statuary, the elaborate decoration and other features that make this subway resemble at times more a museum than a means of transportation.
ROME, Nov. 21 -- Pope Pius XII confirmed a personally today that he had vision of Christ during his desperate illness last December.
A State Supreme Court justice reserved decision yesterday on motions for and against arbitration in the discharge of Melvin L. Barnet, formerly a copy editor for The New York Times.
Democracy needs responsible "thinking" citizens, not "walking encyclopedias," an educational conference was told yesterday.
Not as a protest to the present hi-fi fetish, but as a possible solution to a propaganda problem, comes a little hand-operated plastic phonograph developed by the Radio Corporation of America.
MOUNT TREMPER, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Snow flurries and a cold wind greeted deer stalkers on the opening of the Catskill season this morning. Despite the adverse weather the success ratio was fairly high.

Net income of the Coca-Cola Company and consolidated subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year amounted to $22,989,062, equal to $5.39 a common share, according to a report yesterday by William E. Robinson, the president.
Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad restored the company's $4 preferred stock to a regular quarterly dividend basis yesterday for the first time since 1931.

Attorneys for the New York Central Railroad expect to file an application next Monday with the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission for permission to reduce commuter service on the road's West Shore division, the railroad announced yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 21 -The Stamford League of Women Voters unwittingly interrupted City Hall affairs today when the organization began a project to iron out flood-soaked municipal maps.

THURMONT, Md., Nov. 21 -- President Eisenhower's top advisers arrived by helicopter today at Camp David, his mountain retreat. A National Security Council meeting brought the President up to date on foreign and domestic issues.
A reduction of $100,180,887 in the City Planning Commission's proposed 1956 capital budget of $1,791,736,036 was recommended yesterday by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Trade in both grain and soybean futures was extremely dull today, with outside interest not much in evidence on either side of the market.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -In a split decision, the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania today authorized the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society to open a branch in suburban Ardmore. The ruling had been awaited in banking circles since last May, when the high court heard argument on the society's appeal from an order of the State Banking Board.
LODZ, Poland, Nov. 21 -- This textile-producing city of 650,000 inhabitants is cited as a better example than Warsaw of urban life in post-war Poland.
It's front and center for Army and Navy this week in football's spectacle of spectacles.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -By Jeepers, running over a slow track, won the featured Gridiron Purse at Pimlico today.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- Britain set a new record last month for exports to the United States, as well as for total exports.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -More than 7,000,000 passenger cars have been built so far this year. Only a major work stoppage could prevent the industry from reaching the record 8,000,000 total this year. Such a stoppage is not in prospect.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -Ray M. Gidney, Controller of the Currency, said today he has barred further mergers by two fast-growing banks in Nassau County and another in Suffolk County, N. Y.
BOMBAY, Nov. 21 -Policemen shot and killed ten persons and wounded 300 in fighting rioting mobs of 300,000 textile workers who paralyzed business and transport in this city today.

Radio station V71CA has leased the htrteenth floor in 415 Madison Avenue, a twentyfour-story building going up on the northeast corner of Fortyeighth Street. The structure, being erected by Samuel Rudln, is scheduled for occupaney in February.

An advertising budget amounting to "several million dollars" will be expended by The Anahist Company between now and March, when the season for colds is at its height. This was made public yesterday by John S. Hewitt, president of Anahist.

Two sophomore quarterbacks, who helped their teams gain season-ending victories last Saturday, topped the list of "unsung heroes" of the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association yesterday. They were Princeton's John Sapoch and Bill Whiteacre of Rutgers.
Minor league clubs continue to face added problems in their course of survival.

A new defense alliance came into being yesterday with the first meeting of the five nations of the Baghdad pact. These are Iraq, Iran, Turkey, Pakistan and Britain, with the United States as a cordial observer and well wisher. The two-day meeting in Baghdad was made possible when the last of the group -Iran -- adhered to the treaty a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Peter T. Schoemann of Milwaukee was named today as general president of the Plumbers and Pipefitters Union, A. F. L. He succeeds Martin P. Durkin, the former Secretary of Labor, who died last week.

BAUMKUCHEN and stollen made in Munich by a famous German bakery, Kreutzkamm, will be flown here in time for Christmas. Charles Co., 340 Madison Avenue, is accepting orders that will be delivered about Dec. 15.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Classmates of four Harvard undergraduates who were killed in the Korean war have established a scholarship in their memory. It will be awarded each year to a student in Lowell House, one of the seven upperclass residence centers.

Mrs. Henry Sears Lodge heads a committee of debutantes of last season, who are aides for the seventh annual Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League, which will take place tomorrow night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

HAVANA, Nov. 21 -- Cuba continued to dominate the world Star Class sailing championship as Jorge De Cardenas scored his second consecutive victory today. Jorge took the third race, which was sailed in a 25-mile wind.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- The trend toward centralizing television production on the West Coast is bound to lead to stagnation of the industry, Jackie Cooper, star of "The People's Choice" series, today told a meeting of the Hollywood Advertising Club. Mr. Cooper declared he was not throwing brickbats at the Hollywood TV industry and that the same "stagnation" would result if programs originated solely from any one locale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -Customers of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Corporation introduced today the first of five witnesses in an effort to prove to the Federal Power Commission that the big natural gas wholesaler is not entitled to an $8,600,000 annual rate increase.

A new issue of 400,000 shares of common stock of Kimberly-Clark Corporation, paper manufacturer, will be offered for public subscription today by a syndicate of investment houses headed by Blyth Co., Inc. The shares are priced at $46.375 each.
NEWARK, Nov. 21 -- Twenty-one old masters from American collections will be placed on exhibition at the Newark Museum tomorrow.
The National Broadcasting Company, which will televise the Sadler's Wells Ballet on Dec. 12, is trying to arrange a performance by the New York City Ballet on Dec. 25.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Bennie Oosterbaan, Michigan coach, said today the two players expelled from the Michigan-Ohio State football game Saturday have apologized to their teammates and coaches.

Oklahoma remained the nation's No. 1 football team in the weekly Associated Press nationwide poll yesterday, but Michigan State finally ousted Maryland from second place in the rankings by a margin of 6 points.

Two new stock issues were admitted to trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. They were 500,000 shares of Sherman Products, Inc., $1-par-value common stock and 3,000,000 shares of Cuban American Oil Company 50-cent-par-value common.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Most butchers sold steady to strong today although some light weight offerings were as much as 25 cents higher in early dealings. Sows sold strong to 25 cents higher.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 21 -- The two top leaders of the Soviet Union used the forum of India's Parliament today to attack the policies of the Western powers. Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin told 700 members of both houses of Parliament that the West's new disarmament proposals were setting back arms reduction "at least ten years."

In the very act of endorsing a Charter review conference yesterday the United Nations General Assembly made it clear that such a conference will not be held for at least three years and that when it meets it will not make any drastic alterations -- and perhaps no alterations at all -- in the Charter.

TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- Six employes of the State Division of Employment Security were suspended today without pay for thirty to ninety days. The action resulted from the long investigation into the activities of ormer Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Defense Department had a new problem in its security risk program tonight -- what to do about past decisions in the light of the new rules made public last Friday.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Former Premier Pierre Mendes-France charged today that France was turning her back on the Western European Union in favor of a six-nation federal Europe.

AARON ROSAND, who gave his first New York violin recital in four years last night at Town Hall, is a superbly equipped musician. If he continues to grow, we may soon find him crowding the top rank of violinists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- The Post Office will allow a letter in each Christmas package this year at only 3 cents additional postage.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The British Government disclosed tonight that two Foreign Office officials had resigned as a result of the Burgess-Maclean spy case.

Columbia's 1955-56 basketball team is a fast one and possesses the savvy to "be every bit as strong as last year." Coach Lou Rossini pointed out yesterday that his current crop of Lions has the potential to surpass the showing of last season's outfit.

A dinner dance was given last night by the Society of Mayflower Descendants to celebrate the 335th anniversary of the signing of the Mayflower Compact. The fete was held in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 21 -- The Afghan Lio Jirga (Grand Assembly of Chieftains) announced today that it fully supported Afghan Prime Minister Sardar Mohammed Daud's demand for a plebiscite in Pathan-occupied areas of Pakistan.

The opening of hearings yesterday on the basic Immigration and Nationality (McCarran) Act of 1952 gives the Eisenhower Administration a chance to make good on the President's campaign promises "to rewrite the unfair provisions" of that law in order "to get the bigotry out of it."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 21 -- Twelve leading researchers from nine countries met here today in the first exchange of information on poliomyelitis vaccination between United States, European and South African medical scientists.

As far as science is concerned, there is no disease that is unconquerable. There are only diseases that have thus far resisted solution. Within our own lifetime we have witnessed the dramatic con quest of "killers" that had been the scourge of mankind.

Even the most nerveless gambler is well aware that the law of averages eventually will work against him. Not one would take 100-to-1 odds that he could steadily catch a coin flipped thirty-four feet into the air. Yet every day tens of thousands of pedestrians gamble their lives against getting hit by a car or truck as they snake across crosstown streets, most of them just thirty-four feet wide.
Mrs. Ann Woodward yesterday submitted voluntarily to detailed questioning in the death of her husband, William Woodward Jr., 35-year-old wealthy sportsman.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Schools that meet the teacher shortage by lowering standards were rebuked tonight by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Government is going to test a new typewriter keyboard that could revolutionize that office companion of millions.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Prices closed 8 points (40 cents a bale) higher to 12 points (60 cents a bale) lower than on last Friday. Only the nearby December advanced.

Teachers College, Columbia University, inducts a new president today, Dr. Hollis L. Caswell. Born a Kansan, schooled in the Middle West and coming to Columbia for his doctor's degree, he has been on the staff at Teachers College since 1937 and its dean since 1949.

ROME, Nov. 21 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt urged Italy today to mediate between Egypt and the Western Powers and an Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman said his suggestion was "under consideration" here.

The stories of a group of Americans, who at crucial moments had the courage to do the one thing that seemed right, regardless of the consequences to their public and private lives, are told in "Profiles in Courage." The book, to be issued Jan. 3 by Harper, is written by John F. Kennedy, Senator from Massachusetts.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- The General Assembly decided in principle today to call a conference of the United Nations membership to review the Charter.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Methodist Church said today that it had 9,313,278 members in the United States and its possessions, a gain of 90,126 from a year ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Iraq demanded today that Israel surrender part of her territory for the settlement of Palestinian Arab refugees.
The threat of a strike at midnight Nov. 30 was served yesterday on privately operated bus lines that carry 3,000,000 New Yorkers a day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Government might be sued for damages resulting from Coast Guard negligence in the operation of a lighthouse beacon in the Gulf of Mexico.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 21 -Greater state awareness of the high cost of public schools in the suburbs of metropolitan New York was demanded today. The Legislative Committee of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors offered a plan for revision of the formula that controls distribution of state aid to the schools. A committee of top educators had been at work with the committee for six months.
The state lost another move yesterday in its effort to dismiss a suit challenging the constitutionality of its emergency rent laws on office and loft space.

Another issue of $50,000,000 of New York State Thruway bonds bearing the guarantee of the state government will be offered at public sale on Dec. 7, it was announced yesterday. The borrowing will mark the sixth undertaken by the offering of bonds in the public market since the permanent financing of the $1,000,000,000 improvement was begun in May of 1953.

THE snow has just begun to fall, but fashion has already chosen to turn its face to the sun. Here are the highlights of the resort collections that New York designers have just concluded, new ideas for southern vacation clothes, and perhaps a forerunner of what's to come for summer.
FORT LEWIS, Wash., Nov. 21 (UP) -- The first West Point graduate ever court-martialed on a charge of collaborating with the enemy went on trial today.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 21 -- Lewis L. Strauss reiterated his warning here today that a dangerous shortage of scientists and engineers confronted this country.
The Kaiser Engineers division of the Henry J. Kaiser Company has been awarded a contract to design, build and procure the material and equipment for a $130,000,000 steel plant expansion in India.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 21 -- All-out war to rid the Malay Peninsula of Communist guerrillas and end the eight years of jungle fighting was declared today by the British and officials of the Federation of Malay States.
RICHLAND, Wash., Nov. 21 -- Waste heat from atomic reactors is being used for the time for large-scale space heating in the Hanford works of the United States Atomic Energy Commission here.

A key economic barometer -orders for machine tools -- is on the rise. Last month, according to the National Machine Tool Builders Association, the industry received orders worth $103,400,000, the largest total of any month since July, 1952.

TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the right of the Borough of Palisades Park to prohibit the erection of motels. Such an enterprise, the Bergen County community had argued, would impair existing property values.
Who rules the Soviet Union during this next month while Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party chief are visiting India, Burma and Afghanistan?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Governor Harriman's speech in Seattle tonight was the most severe indictment of the Administration's foreign policy by a Democratic party leader since President Eisenhower entered the White House.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 -- Herschel D. Newsom, master of the National Grange, declared today that the Administration's Farm advisers were "far behind the farmers' thinking in their approach to agricultural problems."
New York City is losing $3,000,000 a year because of defective and outmoded water meters, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.

The International Longshoremen's Association urged yesterday the abolition of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission. This was the first step in the unaffiliated union's program for improving waterfront conditions in the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Most, if not all, fathers registered in the draft may look forward to deferments "fairly soon."

The board of directors of Out-board, Marine and Manufacturing Company, producer of engines trademarked with the names Johnson and Evinrude, have approved an expansion program costing from $12,000,000 to $13,000,000 and calling for an issue of new common stock.
Warren Lee Pierson, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, urged yesterday a prompt review of the recent 50 per cent increase in the United States tariff on Swiss watches.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Walter O'Malley, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, expressed enthusiasm today for preliminary studies made for a domed-over, indoor baseball stadium under consideration for the borough.
"I'd rather have this job than be president of United States Steel."

Counsel for interstate trucking interests have asked Federal District Judge Thomas J. Clary to meet with them and attorneys for the Eastern railroads today in Philadelphia to fix a trial date for a pending $250,000,000 damage suit the truckers have brought against the railroads.

KATHERINE DUNHAM returned from five years of international wandering to open a four-week season at the Broadway Theatre last night under the auspices of S. Hurok. Her company, except for her three featured dancers, Lenwood Morris, Vanoye Aikens and Lucille Ellis, is almost entirely new, but happily her program still contains some of her best old numbers.
The kingdom of Yemen has granted to an American company the first oil and mineral concession in the nation's history.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- A resolution favoring legislation for a professional practices act for the teaching profession was adopted here tonight. The act would permit teachers accused of department violations to be tried by "their peers."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The reported execution of a new group of former associates of Mr. Beria was interpreted in Washington tonight as another blow at secret police prestige in the Soviet Union.

The Beethoven-Brahms recital played by the pianist Henri Deering at Town Hall last night demonstrated the performer's ability to get over the keyboard in a manner acquirable only through long and tedious practice.
Four new films open at first-run theatres today. The programs follow:

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 22 (UP) -- Roosevelt Grier, New York Giants football tackle, is skilled at avoiding the mousetrap play on the gridiron. But he was fooled yesterday at another sport called "Switch the Handkerchief," and lost $500 in the contest.

Louis Zamperini, who at 16 set a world interscholastic track record and made the Olympic team in 1936, has written with Helen Itria his autobiography, entitled "Devil At My Heels." The book has an introduction by Billy Graham.
Louis E. Wolfson, Florida financier, has acquired more than a third of the common stock of the Scullin Steel Company, an important supplier to the railroad industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Following is the text of the opinion of Judge Luther W. Youngdahl of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia holding that passports cannot be denied on evidence of secret informers:

Botany Mills, Inc., yesterday announced a long-term self-perpetuating renewal of its arrangement granting H. Daroff Sons, Inc., of Philadelphia, men's clothing manufacturer, exclusive use of the names "Botany 500" and "Botany."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- The General Assembly's Political and Security Committee called again today for a settlement in Korea "in accordance with the objectives of the United Nations."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Six men were killed and three injured, one critically, in an accident aboard the carrier Ticonderoga last night in the Mediterranean. The ship is with the Sixth Fleet.
AMES, Iowa, Nov. 22 (UP) -- An unexploded dynamite time bomb has been found in a women's dormitory at Iowa State College.

MILWAUKIE, Ore., Nov. 22 -- Governor Harriman of New York charged today that the Republican party had a "firm and settled policy" of strangling the development of the West and giving away its natural resources.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 22 -- President Eisenhower appointed Clifford Cook Furnas, chancellor of the University of Buffalo, today to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for Research and Development.
The City Council passed yesterday six local laws embodying one of the most sweeping housing reform programs in the city's history.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the first United States World Trade Fair would be held in the new Coliseum April 14-27, 1957.

The Wagner Administration has some good achievements to its credit, but we must say it takes a disappointingly long time to reach decisions on some fairly important matters. We could cite a number of these. One is the question of allowing the Port of New York Authority to proceed with construction of a $50,000 temporary heliport at the foot of West Thirtieth Street in Manhattan.

John C. Williams, chairman of L. Bamberger Co., Newark department store, on Jan. 1 will become president of United Advertising Agency of Newark and New York. The agency will change its name to Williams London, Advertising.
Directors of the American Sugar Refining Company yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of $1.25 and a year-end dividend of $1 on the common, both payable on Jan. 3.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 22 -- Representative Jamie L. Whitten suggested today that Congress might be forced to deny funds for the control of farm production unless the Administration moved boldly to sell surplus farm products competitively on world markets.

A union official said yesterday that Federal law and Supreme Court rulings prevented states from passing regulatory legislation dealing with employe welfare plans in industries engaged in interstate commerce.

IRVINGTON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- A 22-year-old employe at the Nevis Cyclotron Laboratory of Columbia University here was electrocuted tonight while he was making an adjustment on the massive equipment.

The use of gamma radiation to simplify operations, cut production costs and produce new and better petroleum products was disclosed yesterday by the Esso Research and Engineering Company, Linden, N. J., a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company, New Jersey.

Preliminary plans were announced yesterday for the construction of twenty-one shopping centers by Food Fair Properties, Inc., a newly formed realty subsidiary of Food Fair Stores, Inc. One of the centers will be in Maimi, another will be in Reading, Pa., and the others in the East Coast area between Connecticut and Florida.
The Long Islander who is selling property on the moon at $1 an acre, had a busy day yesterday. The entrepeneur, Robert R. Coles of Glen Cove, reported he had been "run ragged" by customers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- Five men have been executed and two others sentenced to life imprisonment on charges of having conspired to conceal the activities of Lavrenti P. Beria, late Minister of Internal Affairs.
Consolidated net income of Burlington Industries for the year ended Oct. 1 was $16,370,000, it was announced yesterday. This was 94 per cent more than the $8,437,000 cleared a year before.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad reduced its maintenance staff and costs this year. There also was a sharp increase in the number of trains arriving late. These points were made in evidence presented yesterday before Edward L. Block, hearing examiner for the Public Service Commission.

The Titanium Metals Corporation of America announced yesterday a reduction of 30 cents a pound in the price of titanium sponge, and markdowns ranging from 60 cents to $3 a pound in quotations of titanium mill products including sheet, strip, bar, billet, wire and plate.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. yesterday reduced staple-and-tow prices on its three synthetic fibers -- nylon, Dacron and Orlon -- effective today. The company also announced a new type of Orlon staple.
The Federal Immunity Act of 1954 was praised last night as a way to protect national security against subversion without sacrificing civil liberties.
In branch libraries in Brooklyn, families are reading aloud to their neighbors.

A budget of $7,839,574 has been approved by the board of foreign missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America during its November meeting here. It is the largest budget in the board's 119 years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The business boom in the United States entered the fourth quarter of the year on a rising scale and has continued to mount through more than half of the period.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 22 -- Prime Minister Robert D. Menzies, as president of the 1956 Olympic Games, gave assurances today that Melbourne would stage the event in keeping with the highest Olympic standards. The Duke of Edinburgh will open the 1956 Olympiad here a year from today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A Federal District judge ruled today that military courts might not try civilians accompanying the armed forces for crimes committed overseas.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 22 -- The five powers of the Baghdad Pact announced tonight the establishment of a permanent political, military and economic organization that will have its headquarters here.

The Western Maryland Railway Company is offering its stockholders today subscription rights for the purchase of 128,597 new shares of the carrier's common stock at a price of $41 a share. Shareholders may subscribe at the rate of one new share for each six held.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Wednesday, Nov. 23 -- Brazil's Congress began action early today toward imposing a state of siege throughout the nation for thirty days.

Of all the agencies in the Federal Government none carries a heavier responsibility year in and year out than the Federal Reserve System, whose thankless task it is to manage the nation's money supply with the sole objective of keeping the economy on a reasonably even keel.
Government and textile quarters in Washington yesterday expressed doubt that Japan was actually embargoing cotton goods shipments to the United states, according to the Associated Press.
RYE, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- A new high mark in office automation was reported tonight, by Horry F. Prioleau, president of the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company.

Gaining his tenth victory in the eighteenth and semi-final round of the international chess tournament at Zagreb, Vassily Smyslov of Russia last night clinched the first prize, according to Yugoslav news sources.
Men and women associated with the late Robert E. Sherwood in the theatre, arts and letters will unite in tribute to him next Tuesday afternoon at the ANTA Theatre.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The general price trend in grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade was downward in early trading today, but corn tightened up and this led to partial recoveries in wheat and soybeans.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Harvey J. Harman, head coach of the Rutgers football team for fourteen seasons, was relieved of his post in a surprise move today. Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, the president of the university, informed Harman that he would be reassigned to other duties during the next academic year.
NEW LIQUID coatings for surfaces in the home perform a variety of tasks.

More than $200,000 was contributed yesterday to the annual campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies at a luncheon in the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. Each of the 2,000 guests at the event, sponsored by the women's entertainment industry division, gave $100 or more.
HONG KONG, Nov. 21 -- The accelerated mobilization of private tillers into land-pooling producer cooperatives has been going full blast in Communist China.

THURMONT, Md., Nov. 22 -- President Eisenhower told his Cabinet members today how much he had appreciated their "perfection of coordination and cooperation" when he was out of touch with them after his heart attack in Denver.
Mayor Wagner announced last night a twelve-month target for carrying out further traffic reforms. These include an anti- jaywalking ordinance, more off-street parking facilities and more policemen.

The United Cigar - Whelan Stores Corporation yesterday offered to buy 250,000 common shares of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., at $20 a share. The block would represent nearly a third of Bayuk's 786,120 outstanding common shares.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Democratic leadership in both houses of Congress gathered today behind a thirteen-point legislative program. The program was intended both to anticipate and to go beyond President Eisenhower's own recommendations.
Americans are drinking more Canadian and Scotch whiskies, according to Harry Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized new air service today between the Southwestern and Northeastern areas of the country and to some cities lying between the two areas. Six major lines were affected.
The United States Plywood Corporation in the quarter and half year ended Oct. 31 produced the highest earnings and sales in its thirty-six-year history.

GENEVA, Nov. 22. -- The French economy seems to be moving ahead, but on a precarious path of its own. Increasingly, France's Continental neighbors are expressing concern about the divergence between developments in France and elsewhere in Europe.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Some critics of United States foreign policy complain that we are "pact-happy," that we have over-extended ourselves by promising military support for too many countries in too widely spread an area. We are indeed committed to defend no less than forty-five nations on five continents.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Prime Minister Eden rejected in the House of Commons today a Laborite proposal that the Soviet Union be invited to a Big Four conference to discuss a complete arms embargo to the Middle East.
Net income of the Southern Railway reached $30,051,198, or $10.61 a share, in the first ten months of this year. This compared with $18,890,814, or $6.31 a share, earned in the like period last year.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Army will come up to its fifty-sixth football game with Navy in Philadelphia Saturday in better shape physically than it has been since its crack performance against Penn State in early October.

Although the response to Sunday's appeal by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program for donors with O-negative blood has been good, the organization still needs more of the rare type because of a threatened shortage.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 22 -- The National Constituent Assembly approved tonight a law regulating the Congressional and municipal election set for Dec. 18. There was widespread opposition to it from the press and public.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Another ship carrying scientists and equipment left Britain today for an unspecific destination in the Vahsel Bay region of the Weddell Sea in the Antarctic. It was the 540-ton motor vessel Tottan, chartered by the Royal Society in support of the forthcoming International Geophysical Year research.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 22 -- Prime Minister Robert. G. Menzies defended General Motors-Holdens, Ltd. tonight against a profiteering charge made by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, opposition leader.

A football fan of statistical bent sat with pencil and paper the other day and proved, to his own satisfaction, that the formalization of the Ivy League in 1956 should give the East its most exciting football season in years.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges were irregular yesterday. Cocoa, rubber, wool, cottonseed oil and copper eased; zinc, hides and lead rose, and coffee, sugar and potatoes ended mixed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Justice Department acted formally today to have Harry P. Cain, a member of the Subversive Activities Control Board, disqualified from sitting in the Washington Pension Union case.
The Arab nations are in "an emergent revolution," and Israel should realize that time is on their side, the executive director of the American Council for Judaism declared yesterday.

WHAT has been described as one of the world's biggest building booms has been taking place in Latin-American countries in the decade since the war. This movement, with its many innovations, has now been summarized in a striking and dramatically installed exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 22 (UP) -- The sheriff's office today blamed the death of an eighteen-month-old infant on two telephone "hogs" who refused to get off a party line so his mother could call for help.

George Bagby gave a cocktail dance yesterday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for committee members of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation. Final plans were discussed for the annual Bagby Memorial Concert on Dec. 2 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf.
A RATHER odd kind of litigation has enmeshed A. J. Kron, an artist and picture-framer, in a pitiful tangle that seems about to destroy him, business-wise.

The Boston Bruins, the only team to defeat the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden this season will meet the Broadway Blues in a National Hockey League match at the Eighth Avenue arena tonight. The game will start at 8:30.
Freedom House yesterday found "three serious setbacks" offsetting gains in the balance sheet of freedom for 1955.
PERFUME is one of the few gifts that, though personal, can be generously shared with others.
Operations of North American Aviation, Inc., in fiscal 1955 were the "most successful in the company's history," it was announced yesterday by J. H. Kindelberger, chairman.
TOM EWELL, star of "The Seven Year Itch," and Jane Wyatt appeared last night in "Daisy, Daisy," a new comedy by Sumner Locke Elliott on "Playwrights 56" over Channel 4. They had a busy evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Merger of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation of San Francisco and the Gaylord Container Corporation of St. Louis was approved today by stockholders of the two companies.

Cotton futures rose 7 to 28 points (35 cents to $1.40 a bale), on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The near-by December contract closed at the high of the day and the spring months near their highs.

ALFRED LESLIE ROWSE, one of the most eminent of living British historians, is now two-thirds of the way through his magnum opus, a massive three-volume study of the Elizabethan age. The first volume, "The England of Elizabeth," which was greeted with rapturous enthusiasm in this space four years ago, was a brilliant analysis of the structure of Elizabethan society.
The bowl-bound Oklahoma Sooners, fresh from the capture of their tenth straight conference championship, led the next-to-the-last weekly ratings of the United Press board of coaches yesterday.
A "rational population policy" for the world and the nation was advocated yesterday by a former assistant Secretary of Commerce.
The United Hospital Fund, this country's oldest federated charity, represented eighteen voluntary hospitals when it was organized in 1879.
RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 22 -- Morocco's Sultan and top French officials acted swiftly today to restore order in this protectorate.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 22 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry said today that in the last thirty-six hours Egyptian Army forces launched four attacks against Israeli troops and civilians.
Four head of city-dwelling cattle, facing exile to the suburbs, won a reprieve yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court.

New York University ran headlong "into a low spot" in basketball last season, when the Violet won only eight of twenty games. But the picture is much brighter on the University Heights campus this campaign.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Government expenditures on inland waterways was termed today "pure and unadulterated" subsidization of waterway carriers.

NANGAL, India, Nov. 22 -- A United States engineer and a Soviet Communist leader met today in the foothills of the Indian Himalayas and exchanged some pointed thoughts about visas, competition and cooperation.
New York City continued to finance capital improvements in the public capital market yesterday.

As a legitimate spokesman of the enslaved nations of Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland and Rumania the Assembly of Captive European Nations once again raises its voice against the admission of Soviet-controlled puppet Governments of Albania, Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania to membership in the United Nations.

A one-story building at 80-00 Cooper Avenue in Glendale, Queens, has been leased from the Atlas Terminal, Inc., by the Hampton Sales Company. The lessee, wholesale distributor of major appliances and general merchandise, has its sales offices at 108 East Twenty-eighth Street in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- An independent maker of automobile heaters accused the General Motors Corporation today of having frozen him out of the Chevrolet market. He said G. M. had forced dealers to buy cars with factory-installed heaters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, had a chance yesterday to examine photographic art and architectural treasures of Korea.

HAVANA, Nov. 22 -- Skippers and crews of the yachts competing in the world Star Class championship were the guests of President Batista today on their rest day after three days of sailing in rugged seas.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Hogs dropped to another new low in nearly fourteen years today under the weight of the largest receipts for a Tuesday in more than four years.

Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, who first came to Teachers College, Columbia University, as a graduate student thirty years ago and who later returned to join the faculty, was inau gurated yesterday as president of the college.
Commuting will become still more expensive on Dec. 6 for those who ride the Long Island Rail Road.

ROME, Nov. 22 -- The oldest Romans are now said to have been much older than Romulus and Remus. About 200,000 years before Rome's legendary founding in 753 B. C., the twins' ancestors hunted wild animals in this area, according to this theory.
ONCE a year, and once only, the historic garments of the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are worn by human beings. Last night was the night.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York yesterday announced the election of H. R. Searing as chairman and Harland C. Forbes as president.
The Columbia Broadcasting System canceled plans yesterday to televise a program about crime solution from the police laboratory in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- All of the Social Security checks sent to a Communist serving time in Atlanta Penitentiary for conspiracy against the Government have been ordered impounded.

USING the same confused thinking that impelled Roy Riegels to run toward the wrong goal line in the Rose Bowl game, the Amateur Athletic Union has violently reversed its field in the Wes Santee case. Riegels was stopped by his own team-mates before he could cross irrevocably into the end zone. Perhaps the A. A. U. also will be stopped by team-mates before the Santee action becomes final.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The United States Consumers' Price Index was unchanged from mid-September to mid-October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Israel and the Arab states were warned today to settle their disputes over the fate of the Palestinian Arab refugees.

LARGE GRADE A eggs are 77 cents a dozen, 10 cents more than a year ago at this time. Medium eggs also cost a dime more than last November. Worse still, egg prices are likely to continue high through next spring.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The British Foreign Office today accused Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of hypocrisy in his speech to the Indian Parliament yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The new car being developed by Harry Ferguson will work on the turbine principle, according to indications given in London newspapers.

The dramatic events in Brazil these past few weeks tend to hide an essential, down-to-earth problem. This is simply whether the results of a fair, democratic election for President and Vice President on Oct. 3 are to be honored or not.
MONTREAL, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Marie Dionne has been forced by frail health to abandon her hopes of becoming a nun and has been ordered to rest for a month, an older sister of the quintuplet said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A Federal judge ruled today that the State Department must disclose the information upon which it bases a decision to deny a passport.
RONALD LEONARD, 'cellist and winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award, made his debut in recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 22 -- The Nassau County grand jury will open its investigation Friday into the shotgun slaying of William Woodward Jr., 35-year-old sportsman.
A Republican fund-raiser called on his party yesterday to raise a war chest that would offset "a big-money drive" by organized labor for the 1956 Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A tightening of the money market after the Federal Reserve Board's crackdown on credit expansion may delay briefly announcement of plans for a $12 billion refinancing of Government securities coming due on Dec. 15.

The six-story store and apartment building at 485 and 487 Third Avenue has been resold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to a customer of L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers in the transaction. The property, at the southeast corner of Thirty-third Street, contains seven stores and twenty-five apartments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower was busy today in the White House wrapping her out - of - town Christmas gifts.

Eleven legislators from seven North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries talked about everything from American supermarkets to machine automation at a luncheon and round-table discussion at New York University yesterday.
Paul A. Pfeffer, who has been convicted of murder and who is scheduled to stand trial on a manslaughter count, was found guilty yesterday of assault, robbery and grand larceny in a third case.

The 22,000-gross ton passenger liner now building in the Netherlands for the Holland-America Line will be named the Statendam. This was announced here yesterday by Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager of the line for North America.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., NOV. 22 -- The Army and Navy game is a serious football clash, but it also has a lighter side.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- A spokesman for the Congress of Industrial Organizations and a Boston banker agreed today that the Federal Government should liberalize unemployment compensation. They also agreed it should help finance new industrial plants in areas of "chronic" unemployment.

The criticism of the position recently taken by Adlai Stevenson in regard to certain aspects of our foreign policy, launched by Harold Stassen on his return from a three weeks trip in Europe and fuller reported in the Nov. 21 issue of The New York Times, suggests that he must have a very short memory.
Jim Lee Howell, coach of the Football Giants, yesterday said that Paul Brown "is the best coach in football and the Cleveland Browns are the best team in football."
MOUNT TREMPER, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- A buck has to be careless only once in these mountains' and he is transmuted into venison.

The Waterfront Commission may complete presentation today of its case against the application by Nacirema Operating Company, Inc., for a permanent license as a stevedore. The company now operates in the Port of New York District under a temporary license.
Commercial paper rates were increased by one-eighth of one percentage point yesterday by both dealers and finance companies.

The recent election has pointed up the need for a permanent personal registration law. It is significant that, with over half the population in the state, the city cast a bare third of the vote. So the vote upstate represented twice the percent age of the qualified voters that it did in the city.
Thanksgiving's preview yesterday foretold a story of family reunions and sated appetites.
The season for gourmets and hearty eaters is upon us.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A friend and a foe of the McCarran -Walter Immigration Act, both Senators, agreed today that prospects for major changes next year were nonexistent.
The Dodgers yesterday added to their minor league chain with the purchase of the Macon (Ga.) club of the South Atlantic (Sally) League.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 23 -- Export of all Japanese cotton goods to the United States has been suspended by Government order pending adoption of control measures.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy warned shoppers and storekeepers yesterday to be alert during the Christmas shopping period for thieves, pick- pockets and check forgers.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 22 -- An annual program of 100,000 scholarships to enable gifted students to go to college was proposed here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A House subcommittee predicted today that Southern newsprint mills would double their present capacity in the next two years. The subcom mittee's view were expressed in a statement by Chairman Arthur G. Klein, Democrat of New York, on the group's return from a one-week inspection trip in the South.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Roman Catholic Bishops in the United States announced today a revival of their campaign against "indecent" movies.

The Lexington Democratic Club voted 180 to 23 last night to support Adlai E. Stevenson for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Its vote confronted Carmine G. DeSapio with a ticklish and delicate political problem.

One hundred and fifty years ago in November there was born at Versailles "The Great Frenchman." The appellation was that of Gambetta, a bull-throated orator and demagogue, perhaps, but still a man who knew his way among men of greatness.

CESARE SIEPI, a leading basso at the Metropolitan Opera since 1950, gave a distinguished recital at Carnegie Hall last night. Opera singers as a rule do not thrive in the concert hall, but Mr. Siepi's performance would have been no mean achievement even for a song specialist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Army promised today to give serious reconsideration to policies and practices that had branded inductees as "security risks" for activities and associations prior to military service.

Governor Harriman may be, as he says, not an "active" candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but we hope he will pardon us for thinking that he is acting like one. In fact, he has been acting like one since the day he was elected Governor of New York.

The one-story industrial building at 625 Bergen Street in Brooklyn has been sold by the Bukzin Realty Corporation to Julius Selinger. The structure, containing 10,000 square feet of space, will be used by the new owner for the manufacture of metal partitions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Egyptian officials said today that they were seeking a firm commitment from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to help finance the High Dam at Aswan.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- The Arab states rejected tonight an Indian compromise proposal under which the General Assembly would decide not to take up the Algerian question at this session.

The latest increase in the discount rate -- the rate banks pay for loans from the Federal Reserve System -- was immediately interpreted as an indication that Reserve officials believe the economy is continuing to expand rapidly.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Little League Baseball, Inc., today relieved Carl E. Stotz as commissioner of the nationwide organization promoting baseball for boys.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 22 -- German sources reported today hat East German military units were replacing Soviet troops on the frontier with West Germany.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Esther Williams will report at Universal-International next month without her swim suit to co-star in "The Gentle Webb." The star recently ended her exclusive service contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, but still has commitments with the studio for three films, to be made over a period of five years.

Many reservations have been received for the fifth annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic to be given on Tuesday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. As in previous seasons, proceeds from the event will be used to help meet the operating expenses of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Pittburgh's Panthers will meet a Southeastern Conference team in the Sugar Bowl football game here Jan. 2.

Fishermen beware! During the first six months of 1956 you may be asked to tell a true story of your exploits to a person who knocks on your door. Some of the hunters of the United States may be requested to do the same.
Stocks staged a sharp rally yesterday after four days of declining prices. For the first time since Nov. 4 a majority of the issues traded moved in the same direction.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 22 -- James E. Chappell, editor of The Birmingham News and President of the Birmingham News Company, will retire tomorrow after forty-five years' association with that paper. His newspaper career began in 1907 when he became a reporter for the old Nashville American.
The authority of the State Rent Administrator to issue certificates of eviction when tenants refuse to permit property improvements was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.
"The Last Love of Don Juan," described as "a travesty with a moral," by Edwin Justus Mayer, will have its New York premiere at the Rooftop Theatre, 111 East Houston Street, tonight at 7:45.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 22 -The political atmosphere in Thailand is at the boiling point.
Mayor Wagner intervened yesterday in the dispute between eight private bus lines and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.
OTTAWA, Nov. 22 -- The Canadian Government has decided to get the all-Canadian pipeline started even if it has to meet most of the cost itself.
The presence of a doctor aboard an ordinary cargo ship last week was said to have saved two Italian seamen burned in an explosion aboard the freighter Dea Mazzella.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 22 -- Israel fears that Egypt may achieve military superiority in crucial categories of jet planes and heavy tanks as a result of the supplying of arms by the Soviet bloc.
MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- The sixty-two mile Volga-Don Canal, most highly publicized achievement of the Stalin era, was sharply criticized today for its ornate architecture.
