LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The lords of British golf have decided that their Walker Cup team players will have to be the best golfers in the land from now on and that the old school tie won't be a prime factor for making the squad.

The stock market advanced again yesterday but some of the steam went out of the forward drive in late trading, as the Thanksgiving recess neared. As a result, prices closed below their best of the day.
The Woodward town house at 111 East Seventy-third Street was robbed of about $40,000 in jewelry in 1954, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Walgreen Company and its subsidiaries set a new sales record of $192,735,093 in the year ended Sept. 30, C. R. Walgreen Jr., president, reported yesterday. Sales were nearly $8,500,000 greater than the $184,267,030 volume in the preceding fiscal year.

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 23 (Reuters) -- The six-nation European Coal and Steel Community announced plans today to break up the sales organization of a German cartel in the Ruhr valley. It controls one-third of the community's entire coal output.

FEW adults in the hectic shopping days ahead will bear more bewildered expressions than those childless ones turned loose in a toy department with a list of youngsters' names and ages but nothing more to go on in selecting their gifts.

Despite previous vocal opposition, Michael J. Quill is indicating that his union may be part of the merged labor movement. The president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., has called the union's executive council and board to a special meeting on Dec. 5 "to discuss the course our union will follow."

HONG KONG, Nov. 23 -- Communist China has told private Chinese business men to make "mental preparations" now for a step-by-step nationalization of the "means of production." It has announced its intention to "buy off the bourgeoisie in the course of a little more than ten years."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today that private initiative would have to do much of the job of improving conditions in low-income areas.
Mayor Wagner succeeded yesterday in reviving stalled negotiations between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and eight private bus lines.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 -- Pennsylvania and Cornell will meet tomorrow in the sixty-second game of their football series.
The City Planning Commission yesterday fixed Dec. 7 as the date of a public hearing on its proposal to allow restaurants in restricted districts to provide live music.

THE more one knows of Bach the more one comes to see how much he placed his music at the service of his religious ideas. And Bach, the marvelously persuasive musical preacher, was very much in evidence at last night's concert of the Bach Aria Group at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, The Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 16:

The nation's oil industry plans to increase its operable refining capacity by 334,900 barrels a day, or 4.6 per cent, by Sept. 30, 1956, according to a survey made by the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The dispute between the Army and the Air Force over missions of Army aircraft remains unsettled. However, the Army will be permitted to continue experiments with a new type of reconnaissance unit in the Louisiana maneuver, Exercise Sage Brush.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Argentine newspaper men had an unusual taste of freedom of information today for the first time after ten years of press control under the dictatorship of ousted President Juan D. Peron.
Mrs. Watson B. Dickerman of 1120 Fifth Avenue has her painting back and the art collection of Lord Beaverbrook, the British publisher, is minus one Fragonard.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- An anthology of poetry came today from Capitol Hill, whose halls are famed rather for their prose.

SEATTLE, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Jim Sutherland was dismissed today as backfield coach of the University of Washington football team that was torn by a revolt of thirty-three players against Head Coach Johnny Cherberg.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Navy bombed West Point today with leaflets. It was all part of the preliminary antics to the annual football classic of the service teams at Philadelphia on Saturday.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports, helped by increased sales abroad of minerals, metals, chemicals and forest products, jumped 16 per cent in September to set a record for the month.

IT happened about a quarter century ago. Just before a traditional college football game, the sports pages were filled with dire predictions. The game the season before had wound up as a virtual free-for-all and the revenge motif was constantly being stressed. Everyone, it seemed, was out to "get" everyone else.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 23 -- This town sank deeper than ever in its water troubles today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- France proposed today a new approach to the world deadlock on disarmament through a program of conciliation and compromise.
YONKERS, Nov. 23 -- The annual transition of the Cross County Center here into "Christmas City" took place today. The title will be retained through the yule season.
What is the baseball draft? How does it work? What is its purpose? Those are questions fans are asking these days.
An 11-year-old soloist captured rush-hour crowd of travelers yesterday in Grand Central Terminal.

In a two-day joint investigation of food stores in the city by the Department of Investigation and the Department of Markets, 104 underweight packaged turkeys were found in eight stores. The short weights ranged from four ounces to one pound thirteen ounces.

A reversal in the color trend in men's tailored sportswear has been forecast for the spring season. Manufacturers expect the dark charcoal shades with light trim to be popular this fall, but light hues with dark trim will be in demand in the following seasons.

Daily newspapers throughout the country and in Canada will for the next year be running advertising designed to promote maximum effectiveness of newspaper advertising. One series of the copy is aimed at national advertisers and their agencies and is designed for use by papers in major advertising centers.
Railroad companies are planning to raise $14,925,000 in the public market during the next fortnight to help finance the acquisition of new equipment.

We congratulate the Wagner Administration and the City Council on passage of constructive, comprehensive legislation to improve housing conditions in New York. There may be room for argument about some provisions of the six local laws, which now go to the Board of Estimate and the Mayor for final action, but there is no doubt that an important forward pioneering step has been taken.

Princeton's "anonymous" linemen, nonplaying captain and hard-working substitutes won the Ivy League football championship this season but only one Tiger player earned enough individual glory to gain a place on the 1955 all-Ivy team.
CAPE MAY, N. J., Nov. 23 -- A family of three and a crew of three were safely brought ashore here today. Their 63 - foot schooner had become disabled Saturday at 11 P. M.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Nov. 23 -- Dr. Chester C. Travelstead has left his post as dean of the School of Education of the University of South Carolina apparently because of a speech in which he called for an end to racial segregation in the public schools.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- Television and motion picture rights to "The Great Mouthpiece" by Gene Fowler have been acquired by Josef Shaftel, according to a spokesman for the producer. It is understood that Mr. Shaftel plans to start production of an initial cycle of twenty - six half - hour television films next year.

Moscow's struggles for power continue unabated. The latest six victims to be executed were comparatively minor figures. Their alleged chief, Beria, was killed almost two years ago. Why were these victims required now? What truth can there be in the charges that they conspired together when it is known from the Soviet press itself that two of the Georgians now executed, Rukhadze and Rapava, were actually political enemies?
On Thanksgiving Day, we give thanks for the blessings bestowed upon us. And high among those blessings is the long, healthy life we now enjoy.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- Governor Harriman, in a statement issued here tonight, said that he seriously questioned whether "any increase at all is justified at this time" in Long Island Rail Road fares."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Army announced today further modifications in some procedures that had branded G. I.'s as security risks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The District of Columbia courts have finally cut so deeply into the discretionary powers of the Secretary of State over the issuance of passports to American citizens that he will be obliged to appeal to the Supreme Court or passively forfeit most of those long exercised.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Under an international convention that came into force on last Sunday importation of samples and advertising materials from abroad will be eased for traders and merchants in the fifteen signatory countries.

A syndicate headed by Robert H. Lindy has purchased the seventy - four - family apartment house at 1192 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx. Kerbel Zipes, operators, sold the property subject to mortgages of $230,000. The buyers were represented by Richard S. Hull, attorney. Ehrlich, Corso Feldman were the brokers.

THE whole country will be reading John O'Hara's new novel, "Ten North Frederick,"* this winter. It is the kind of book that everyone wants to read and discuss, either out of fury or admiration, but very, very seldom in a spirit of languorous apathy. That, as you will see, is natural, since this is the best book he has written, deeper, more uncompromising, more disturbing than anything that has gone before.

A prosecution witness in the wiretap trial of John G. (Steve) Broady testified yesterday that the police had made no effort to question him in detail during a raid on Feb. 11 on a telephone tapping center at 360 East Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Federal Trade Commission issued ten more complaints today against allegedly misleading advertising of accident and health insurance policies. Meanwhile, a proposal within the commission for a completely new approach to the problem languished for lack of industry backing.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that a Hunter College faculty member, discharged for Communist party membership, was entitled to a court trial of the charges against him.

The Islip, L. I., Union Free School District 9 sold yesterday $4,516,000 of bonds due serially on May 1 from 1956 to 1985 to a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co., at a bid of 100.4599 for obligations bearing an interest coupon of 3.2 per cent. Reoffering was at yields ranging from 2 to 3.1 per cent.

The Waterfront Commission's case was not completed yesterday at its hearing on the application of the Nacirema Operating Company, Inc., for permanent licensing by the bi-state agency as a stevedore. Harold McGowan, assistant commission counsel, who is presenting the case, said it would continue Monday in the commission's headquarters at 15 Park Row.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Subversive Activities Control Board asked Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. tonight whether he wanted to disqualify former Senator Harry P. Cain from sitting in judgment on an alleged Communist-front group.
LEWISTON, Idaho, Nov. 23 -- Governor Harriman of New York accused the Eisenhower Administration today of having "deliberately" driven down farm prices.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 23 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas has shrugged aside criticism of Guatemala's new electoral law as unimportant, compared with the security and political progress he contends the new law would afford.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 23 -- The Administration is considering a plan that would cost up to $400,000,000 in its first year of operation to pay farmers for cutting their production of surplus crops.

Next month will be what Coach Ken Norton terms the "testing month" for his Manhattan College basketball team. Before sending the Jaspers through a workout yesterday, Norton said, "By January, we hope we'll be rolling like last year."
BONN, Germany, Nov. 23 -- The information service of the German Industry Institute reported today an extraordinary intensification of Communist propaganda among West German factory workers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Prices were under moderate pressure on the Board of Trade today, with weakness in soybeans tending to unsettle the grain list. But, there was an expansion of commission absorption on the setbacks, which tended to steady the markets.
" Janus," a "romantic comedy" by Carolyn Green co-starring Margaret Sullavan, Robert Preston and Claude Dauphin, has its New York premiere at the Plymouth Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.

Instead of being defeated by 22,500 votes, as unofficial returns indicated election night, Proposition 1 appeared yesterday to have been approved by 24,700 votes or more. The proposal provides aid for middle-income housing.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Vince Martinez, 148 1/2 pounds, won a unanimous decision over Chris Christensen, 149, tonight in easy fashion before a crowd that booed almost continuously in the last two rounds of their ten-round fight.

The Union Pacific Railroad, fifth largest rail carrier in the nation, plans to split its preferred and common stocks five-for-one. Directors recommended the action yesterday and also ordered an extra dividend of $3 a share on the present common stock.

There are 350 specialists on the New York Stock Exchange, appointed to make markets in the Exchange's 1,550-odd stocks. Yesterday, a double dozen of these hardworking broker-dealers undertook one of the most exacting jobs of their experience.

Today's new film is "The Treasure of Pancho Villa," a drama featuring Rory Calhoun, Shelley Winters and Gilbert Roland, at the Palace. George Sherman directed from a screen play by Niven Busch. Edmund Grainger produced for R. K. O.-Radio Pictures.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, as trustee for a pension fund, made a first mortgage loan of $2,250,000 on the New York Trade Show Building at 500 Eighth Avenue, northeast corner of Thirty-fifth Street. Brooks, Harvey Co., brokers, arranged the financing for Louis Glickman, owner of the property.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company will occupy a two-story building to be erected at 160-62 Sip Avenue, near Journal Square, in Jersey City. Containing 11,380 square feet, the building will be used for a consolidation of the company's commercial forces in three Jersey City offices at Bay and Erie Streets, 921 Bergen Avenue and 26 Journal Square.
THE Catskill region has provided deer liver for a Thanksgiving tidbit for many hunters since the opening of the season there on Monday.
A biographical study of Sir Edward Elgar, English composer who died in 1934, by Percy M. Young has been imported by Macmillan for distribution Tuesday. It is titled "Elgar O. M."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 23 (AP) -- West Germany revamped its Defense Ministry today and named two career generals to top jobs in building up the nation's new 500,000-man armed forces. The generals fought in the German armies of World War II and eventually opposed Hitler's faltering leadership.

HAVANA, Nov. 22 -- In the fourth race of the Star Class world championship today, E. W. (Skip) Etchells of the Central Long Island Sound fleet sailed Shannon to the most convincing victory of the series. He won by 2 minutes 15 seconds from the defending champion, Charlie de Cardenas of Havana.
One of the striking features of this college football season has been the relegation of the forward pass to the background as an offensive weapon.

In a city where housing for middle and upper income families still tends to be somewhat at a premium it is a pleasure to note the number of apartment houses currently under construction. Work has just begun on the most recent addition, a ten-story and penthouse apartment building on Tenth Street just west of Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Atomic Energy Commission ruled today that the controversial and canceled Dixon-Yates contract had been invalid because there had been a probable violation of the "conflict of interest" laws in its negotiation.

CONTEMPORARY sculpture is to be shown in a gallery set aside for the purpose at the Grand Central Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue. A number of artists represented in the opening group show are members of the Sculptors Guild, and others have worked at the Sculpture Center.

The appointment of Joseph Mazer to head the United Jewish Appeal's special drive for $25,000,000 was announced yesterday by Rabbi Herbert A. Friedman, executive chairman of the organization. Mr. Mazer is treasurer of the Hudson Pulp and Paper Company of New York.
The State Department's long-established habit of denying passports on the basis of evidence known only to itself has been struck another well-deserved blow by the Federal courts.
A group of insurance executives urged yesterday that union welfare funds operating under labor-management trusteeships be subjected to state insurance laws.

The Great Northern Railway's gross revenues rose to $224,125,610 in the first ten months this year. The company carried down to net income $27,712,068 of the total, equal to $4.56 a share on 6,078,132 shares of capital stock outstanding.

The annual tea dance for the benefit of St. Joseph's Day Nursery will be held on Sunday afternoon at the Stork Club. Mrs. Charles R. Barrett heads the benefit committee. Serving with her as co-chairmen are Mrs. Francis R. Curry and Miss Mary Ann Travers.

Forty-seven young women were guests of honor last night at the New York Junior League's seventh annual Debutante Ball. The event, held in the grand ballroom of the Plaza in a setting of green and white, the traditional colors of the league, served as a benefit for the organization's Welfare Trust Fund.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Soviet Union has set off its largest nuclear weapon so far.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- The criticism by Roman Catholic Bishops in the United States about the alleged increase in morally "objectionable" motion pictures was pondered today in official silence by Hollywood studio heads and by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 23 -- The Times of India sharply criticized the visiting Soviet leaders today for having used the Indian Parliament for a "one-sided" denunciation of Western policies.

Rubber prices soared yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange in one of the sharpest rises of the year. The near-by December option rose to a high for the year. The London market was higher and Singapore was strong.
GENEVA, Nov. 23 -- The next world tariff conference was called today for Jan. 18, 1956, in Geneva. Twenty - five nations have already indicated plans to participate.
The Chase Manhattan Bank may elaborate somewhat Dec. 6 its plans to build a Rockefeller-Center-type development in the financial district.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee is investigating the Fund for the Republic with a view to holding public hearings early next year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The General Assembly will meet Friday for a showdown on the Algerian question.
BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers, sparked by Ray Felix and Carl Braun, rallied in the final period and went on to defeat the Boston Celtics, 115 -- 111, in overtime tonight.
GENEVA, Nov. 23 -- Switzerland has embargoed arms sales to Egypt, Israel and other Middle Eastern countries.
Spokesmen for several of the companies cited by the F. T. C. were quick to defend their advertising practice yesterday. They condemned the commission for what one termed "punitive publicity."
Steve Allen and his television troupe will make a week-end trip to Spain early next year to film a program for his "Tonight" show.
The Anaconda Company yesterday authorized payment of a year-end dividend of $2 a share on Dec. 22.

France must come back to the General Assembly of the United Nations. Foreign Minister Pinay walked out of the Assembly on Sept. 30, when it was voted to debate the Algerian issue. This is an anomalous and even dangerous situation, for the United Nations makes no sense without France any more than it would without us or the British.
The Soviet practice of using women workers for even the heaviest and most dangerous work may be coming to an end, according to a hint in the Soviet labor newspaper Trud.

The Austrian Ambassador's letter in The Times of Nov. 7 cannot dispel serious doubts about the safety of certain groups of new refugees in Austria, doubts first raised in Michael L. Hoffman's Geneva dispatch to The Times of Oct. 18.

Tallulah Bankhead, the actress, has sold her country home on Bedford Road in Pound Ridge, N. Y., to Edwin L. Tatro. The property consists of a brick dwelling, swimming pool and about fifteen and one-half acres. It was an all-cash transaction, according to the Security Title and Guaranty Company, which insured title.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Britain's commercial television, two months old, has discovered that highbrow programs attract neither viewers nor advertisers.
The weight of President Eisenhower's duties was described yesterday as "criminal" by a former White House staff member.
TO see Edwin Justus Mayer's "The Last Love of Don Juan" is to be reminded of the Comedie Francaise.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov 23 -- Eddie Erdelatz outdid any broken-field runner of the season in evasive action today.
The first authoritative estimate of how much the diet of the country's steel-hungry industries would be increased in the next four years was made yesterday.

It is natural to say we have "so much" for which to be thankful on this national holiday devoted to the giving of thanks. We do, indeed. We have a high degree of human comfort. We have enough to eat. We are sheltered from the cold. We enjoy relative health.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 23 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Opposition leader, who is electioneering in Tasmania, reproached two Roman Catholic Bishops tonight for having made what he called unjustifiable statements in an effort to influence electors.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower is continuing to convalesce "satisfactorily" and without complications from his heart attack.

STONEWALL, Tex., Nov. 23 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that he felt "very much inclined to make the race" for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1956. He said he was not interested in the Vice Presidential nomination of his party.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Oklahoma's crude oil allowable was set today at 582,000 barrels a day for December and January. But the Corporation Commission said the situation will be reviewed next month.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy appeared yesterday before the Kings County rackets grand jury to express his views on juvenile delinquency.

DES MOINES, Nov. 23 (AP) -- R. W. Nebergall, chief of the Iowa Bureau of Criminal Investigation, said today a laboratory analysis showed a bomb-like device placed in an Iowa State College women's dormitory did not contain explosives.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The United States Senate Public Works Committee has asked the Army Engineers to review their flood control reports for Westchester County and areas surrounding the Hudson, Delaware and Ramapo Rivers.

Midstream in the East River, almost exactly opposite to the United Nations Building, is small, rat-ridden Belmont. To celebrate the tenth anniversary of the U. N. would it not be possible to set on this bleak island, in the place of its light-beacon, a big Statue of Peace, to be a pendant to New York's beloved Statue of Liberty?

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 23 (UP) -- A. and M, which rose from the cellar to football heights in one year, will take the field tomorrow as the heavy favorite to down Texas and win its first Southwest Conference crown since 1940.
Trains ran late again yesterday on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, causing distress alike to the public and the road's officials.

A former graduate chemistry student, accused of killing his parents for their insurance two years ago with poisoned champagne cocktails, was granted the major portion of their $75,000 estate yesterday in Bronx Surrogate's Court.

DURING the next thirty days, nearly $960,000,000 will be spent in this country for children's playthings. The traditional opening of the Christmas shopping season today, during which 50 per cent of the toys and games usually are sold, finds New York department stores geared for the rush that can bring 250,000 customers a day into Macy's alone.
QUEBEC, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Maurice Duplessis of Quebec said today if Quebec Province newsprint manufacturers "want newsprint price control, they're going to get it."
MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- A modest production of "Hamlet" presented by the first British theatrical company to come here since the Russian Revolution received a tumultuous reception from Muscovites tonight.

Everyone knows why Americans eat turkey on Thansgiving Day, but there is quite a bit of confusion over how a bird indigenous to North America got named for a distant country where his particular species is unknown.

IN writing "Incident in an Alley," the drama seen last night on the "United States Steel Hour" on Channel 2, Rod Serling, one of television's most prolific and successful dramatists, was inspired by an incident from life.
When the New York Giants and the Cleveland Browns meet at the Polo Grounds on Sunday in a National Football League game, Don Heinrich will start at quarterback for the New Yorkers.

Once again the season is with us for the purchase of those cheerful Christmas seals that denote contributions to the never-ending war against tuberculosis. During the past ten years there has been a dramatic drop in the number of deaths from tuberculosis and the lives of most patients suffering from this disease have been greatly prolonged.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The United States Embassy in Moscow issued visas today to five Soviet agricultural specialists for a twenty-five-day visit to this country.
PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The French Cabinet was reported today to have taken a pessimistic view of its chances of surviving in the face of growing parliamentary hostility over the electoral issue.

The Atee Realty Corporation, Tobias Gluck, president, has purchased the six-story building containing forty-three apartments at 709-715 West 169th Street. The seller was the Park Haven Realty Corporation, of which Max B. Cane is secretary.

Plans long in the dreaming and then the talking stage have now taken solid form with the announcement that a United States World Trade Fair will be held in the new Coliseum for two weeks beginning April 14, 1957. This is excellent news, which Mayor Wagner could announce with justified pride.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today approved a proposed air service between Hawaii and Tahiti.
The visit of Soviet leaders to India and an uneasy political situation in Thailand have emphasized the capabilities and the limitations of the Southeast Asia collective defense treaty organization.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 23 -- John N. Popham, southern regional correspondent for The New York Times, received a certificate of appreciation today from the Southern Regional Education Board.
WARSAW, Nov. 23 -- A Polish observer in the United States has said propagandists here have been "unwise" in their criticism of the United States.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The stock market remained quiet today, with prices still moving irregularly. Several of the Government's medium-dated stocks gained slightly. Price movements among industrials generally were limited to a few pence.

It was like old times at Madison square Garden last night as the New York Rangers and the Boston Bruins battered away at each other in a National Hockey League game. What made it especially nostalgic was that the Rangers showed to excellent advantage as they subdued the visitors, 4 to 0.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Thursday, Nov. 24 -- Proclamation of a state of siege in Brazil has been delayed by protracted Congressional debate.

IN this land of plentiful yuletide cheer, the young understandably may be more imbued with the spirit of "getting" than "giving.'' However, as one educator has observed, "We need not worry too much over children's desire to get when we see how great their pleasure is in giving when offered at holiday times the chance to do so."
Peace and hope dominate the thoughts of millions of Americans at home and overseas on this Thanksgiving Day.
OTTAWA, Nov. 23 -- The Canadian Government was urged today to re-examine its foreign trade policy in view of recent developments within the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

WITH a full-length version of "The Nutcracker" in its repertoire, the New York City Ballet would seem to need nothing less urgently than a toy-shop ballet, but "Jeux d'Enfants" is exactly that. Choreographed jointly by George Balanchine, Barbara Milberg and Francisco Moncion, it had its second presentation last night at the City Center.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, today called for a halt "once and for all" to bank mergers which tend to create local banking monopolies.
BOMBAY, India Nov. 23 -- Bombay, a city living under threat of riots backed by India's Communists, played host today to two leaders of the Soviet Communists.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 23 (AP) -- A scientist who has been working in the wilds of Kukukuku Land has returned here with fossils of hitherto unknown kangaroo-like animals that lived about 10,000,000 years ago. He is G. D. Woodard of the University of California.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Federal Maritime Board moved yesterday to improve the competitive position of American President Lines with other American-flag steamship companies in the around - the - world service.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Farrelly of New York and Bernardsville, N. J., and Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. McKeon, also of this city, and Ridgefield, Conn., and Southampton, L. I., gave a dinner dance at the Colony Club last night in honor of their debutante daughters, the Misses Elizabeth Carbery Farrelly and Katharine Manning McKeon.

Three leading Long Island banks, which have been setting a breath-taking merger pace this year, appear to be intent upon further expansion despite the fact they were barred this week from further bank acquisitions.
Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan dismissed yesterday an indictment returned by one grand jury after another grand jury had refused to indict in the same case.
The appointment of Vice Admiral James Fife Jr., U. S. N., retired, as director of the Marine Historical Association of Mystic, Conn., has been announced by Philip R. Mallory, president.

Domestic production of synthetic rubber rose to a record high of 88,113 long tons last month, compared with 83,507 long tons produced in September, The Rubber Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday to close 3 points higher to 25 points lower than on Tuesday.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- Thirty-seven visitors who had been stormbound for five days on a man-made radar island 110 miles at sea reached Boston today. They had high praise for their rescuers and a new respect for the 8,000-ton platform that sheltered them.

MONTREAL, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Newsprint company officials today declined to comment on a statement by Prime Minister Duplessis that price control may be introduced if Quebec newspapers do not receive special price consideration.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Visitors at the United Nations gave an interested but puzzled reception today to the latest gift acquired by the world organization.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld upheld yesterday the citizenship of a Greek-born restaurateur whom the Government wanted to deport for voting in a Greek election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A Federal judge in Boston has cited a Boston real estate concern for contempt of court for failing to file required reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, S. E. C. officials disclosed today.

You correctly pointed out in your editorial for Nov. 16 that at the Geneva conference Mr. Molotov in rejecting Western proposals for lifting the Iron Curtain "in effect frankly admitted that the Soviets fear free contacts between the Soviet people and the outside world."

A 64-year-old grandmother was held in $7,500 bail yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld on charges of bringing an expectant mother here from Canada for the purpose of selling the soon-to-be-born baby.
COLVILLE, Wash., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Residents of this thinly populated farming and mining county yesterday chose private power over public power in an election to see which would continue to serve them.
GENEVA, Nov. 23 -- The Ambassadors of the United States and Communist China held a comparatively long meeting today but nothing was settled between them.
BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- A $4,500,000 shrine and monastery, intended to "serve the spiritual needs of Boston's workers and shoppers," was dedicated today by Archbishop Richard J. Cushing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A new Executive Order prescribing regulations for the employment of unpaid experts and consultants is awaiting President Eisenhower's signature. A formal announcement is expected this week, probably Friday.

Last night in Carnegie Hall the eminent Soviet violinist David Oistrakh repeated the triumph of his Sunday debut. Again the hall was full, again a few hundred listeners overflowed on the stage, and again most violinists in the vicinity were in the audience, listening intently.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Little League baseball policy dispute boiled anew today. Four staff members quit to join forces with the deposed commissioner, Carl E. Stotz, who called a meeting of 300 field workers for Dec. 10-11 at Pittsburgh.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower today scheduled a series of political and legislative appointments that will return him to active control of the Republican party. They may also bring him back to Washington to stay by Christmas.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 23 -- Andre Dubois, French Resident General, said today that cooperation of military authorities in Spanish Morocco was essential to re-establish order in this protectorate.
Four former detectives, who vouched for the character of George (The Weasel) Stern, an ex-convict, at a deportation hearing, were ordered yesterday to face departmental trial.

Big Joe Uwanawich, the gypsy scofflaw, won an adjournment in his traffic case yesterday after promising Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh that he would go South to collect money from other Uwanawich scofflaws.

The familiar front-door Christmas wreath of tangy, green pine boughs may have met its waterloo. This could be the case, at any rate, in homes where the sweet - toothed young are given their choice of this type garland or one of edible quality.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Prime Minister Eden named seven prominent Britons today as a committee to examine British security procedures and to consider whether they needed strengthening.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The chairman of a Senate inquiry asked General Motors automobile dealers today to come forward and testify despite their fear of reprisals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A Chicago banker formally assumed office today as the State Department's top economic expert. He took the occasion for some tongue-in-cheek observations about his new diplomatic role.
Governor Harriman returned to New York yesterday from a Western political speaking tour. Next week he will make a somewhat similar invasion of the South.
UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 24 -- Optimism over the use of atomic energy for peaceful purchases was voiced tonight by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Under Secretary General of the United Nations.
HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 23 (Reuters) -- West German shipowners expect to have a fleet of trans-Atlantic passenger ships in operation again within a few years.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Globe-Democrat said tonight that Matthew J. Connelly, appointments secretary for former President Harry S. Truman, had changed his testimony before a Federal grand jury after learning another witness planned to change his testimony.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The Netherlands contended in the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today that it should no longer be required to submit data on the former dependent territories of Surinam and the Netherlands Antilles.

In view of the failure of the Geneva conference to provide "any further useful initiative" toward breaking the 10-year-old deadlock on disarmament, the United Nations Disarmament Commission is moving to end its inconclusive debate and to submit the issue to the General Assembly as the authority of last resort.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- Further light was shed today on the recent execution of six former Soviet Georgian security officials. They had been accused of having conducted the "terroristic annhilation of honest Soviet citizens."
Macy's served up its traditional Thanksgiving Day parade yesterday with a fifty-foot balloon turkey and all the glittering appurtenances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd said today he believed the forthcoming United States Antarctic expedition would mark the beginning of permanent human habitation of that icy continent.
The Iron Mines Company of Venezuela has just placed an order with the Bethlehem-Sparrows Point, Md., shipyard for another 6,000-deadweight-ton bulk ore carrier for its Orinoco River run.
The man who gave Britain her head start on jets, Sir Frank Whittle, says he is "horrified" at Britain's abandonment of her only long-range jet airliner.

King Haakon of Norway at 83 is the world's oldest reigning monarch. The celebration in honor of his Golden Jubilee at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Nov. 25 brings into sharp focus the great cultural and social achievements of a fellow-democracy during the past fifty years.

PIERRE MONTEUX began last night the second of two weeks in which he is guest conducting the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. The major part of his program was given over to five excerpts from Berlioz' lengthy dramatic symphony "Romeo and Juliet."
The National Manpower Council called yesterday for improvement in the quality of the country's high schools.
A stationary kerosene heater flickered and then exploded in a Brooklyn home yesterday morning, killing three children, 2, 3 and 4 years old.

WHEN Eddie Erdelatz Was still a comparatively new boy on the block, he attended a dinner honoring. Red Blaik, his opposite number at the West Point end of the Army-Navy axis. The gracious red-head accepted an award for outstanding coaching achievement and left the hall with Erdelatz.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The British Government plans to combat anti-British violence in Cyprus with increasingly stern police and Army measures.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- Canada has sold between seven and eight million pounds of surplus butter to a Dutch importer for eventual resale in East Germany an official of the Department of Agriculture said here today The contract also includes an option to buy an additional 3,000,000 pounds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -A Department of Agriculture report on cotton today forecast a worsening of the problems of shrinking markets and mounting surpluses.
HAVANA, Nov. 24 -- Charles de Cardenas of Havana retained the Star world championship today by placing sixth in the finale by the five-race series.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Roger Seydoux, French High Commissioner in Tunisia, was understood today to have backed a request by the Tunisian Government for its own police force.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Nov. 23 -- Security decisions that might involve the danger of war appear to be in abeyance here until Israel finds how the United States treats her bid for arms.
Three young women were honored last night at a dinner dance given jointly by their parents in the St. Regis Roof.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -The Federal Trade Commission today accused eleven leading food manufacturers and two grocery chains with more than 220 outlets in the East of using unfair and discriminatory business tactics.

A study pinpointing the share of each of the forty-eight states in recent exports to Switzerland was issued yesterday by the American Society for Friendship with Switzerland. This showed that twenty-eight states were each the source of more than $1,000,000 of American commodities imported last year by Switzerland.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- A banking service whereby banks take over credit, accounting, bookkeeping and collection functions on charge accounts for retail stores has been adopted in a number of communities throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported tonight that $2,373,000,000 worth of new corporate securities had been sold during the third quarter of this year.
MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- Twelve men have been sentenced to prison for instigating a riot after a soccer match in Soviet Armenia last month. The sentences ranged up to twenty-five years.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Premier Edgar Faure said tonight France hoped for a solution of the Saar question that would take account of her rights and facilitate a French-German economic "association."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Eisenhower Administration has decided to put fresh steam behind the President's proposal that the United States and the Sovet Union make regular military inspection flights over each other's territory.
CLEVELAND, Friday, Nov. 25 -- The National Grange early today called for emergency Federal aid to farmers and the development of farm programs cut to fit the needs of individual commodities.
The Mayor of New York will entertain the Mayor of Rome today, reciprocating for the honors accorded Mr. Wagner in Italy last June.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 24 -- Three children in a cart stole the spotlight from the President of the United States today.
The State Chamber of Commerce warned its members yesterday that Governor Harriman might be planning some state tax "adjustments" that would have the same effect as tax increases.

OWNERS of a home freezer are the luckiest in dealing with leftovers from the Thanks- giving turkey. They are in the position of being able to forget completely about the bird by putting away the sliced meat, well wrapped in moisture-vapor-proof paper, at zero storage.
PROVIDENCE, Nov. 24 -- Colgate's football squad is no respector of tradition. While most Americans spent the day cutting turkey, the Red Raiders carved up Brown University's Bears.
Staging burlesque performances is as much a civil right as the usual conceptions of free speech and assembly, the New York Civil Liberties Union held yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 22 -- The South Korean Army will pass Friday one of the most important milestones in its short life of seven years. On that day, it will have been handling its own supply lines for six months.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The United States has informed other delegations that it will not campaign against admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 24 (AP) -- William and Mary held favored Richmond to a 6-6 deadlock before 12,000 fans today and kept the Spiders from taking second place in the Southern Conference.

BERWICK, Pa., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Harrison Browning Ross, 31, of Woodbury, N. J., won the Berwick marathon for the ninth time today. He far outdistanced a field of forty-four in the running of the forty-sixth annual event.

A biography of H. I. M. Haile Selassie I is planned for Jan. 10 publication by Macmillan entitled "The Lion of Judah Hath Prevailed." The author, Mrs. Christine Sandford, wife of the British consul who was also adviser to the Emperor and Director-General of Addis Ababa Municipality, has lived many years in Ethiopia.

I The six-story apartment house at 3535 DeKaIb Avenue in the[ Bronx has been sold by Geisinger Rau, real estate operators, t6] the 3535 Realty Corporation.] Ehrlich. Corso, Feldman Co. were the brokers in the transaction. The property, on plot 100 by 100 feet, contains forty-three apartments. It was soldfor cash above mortgages of $360,000,
HELETZ, Israel, Nov. 24 -- Oil, gleaming to Israelis as the stuff of economic independence, flowed here today from the state's first producing well.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Our Dance won the thirteenth running of the $10,000 Exterminator Handicap at Pimlico today, scoring by three lengths over Rock Cottage.

Feed the hungry and thank God for your blessings -- that was the theme at many Thanksgiving services yesterday as Christians and Jews across the land raised their voices in thanks to God. Many houses of worship were adorned with fruits and vegetables of the harvest, which were later distributed to the poor.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 24 -- Argentina's provisional government abolished today one of the Peron regime's most repressive measures, the law on crimes against the security of the state.
The letter of Nov. 12 from Marice Winograd, dealing with Arab refugees, greatly oversimplified the problem and presented on some of the facts.
Cardinal Spellman will visit troops in Labrador and Greenland next week.

ALL is not sweetness and light for the wildfowlers on the Maryland marshes. The open conflict between the Federal and state waterfowl regulations has placed the Federal and state wardens on opposite sides of the fence -- with the shooter perched on the rail.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Syria proposed today that Palestine refugees be resettled in Israeli-occupied areas that were called "predominantly of Arab ownership."
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Prices remained dull most of today but were said to be improving at the close. The late improvement lifted one or two Government stocks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Democratic National Chairman challenged the Eisenhower Administration today to punish "wrongdoing" involved in the repudiated Dixon-Yates power contract.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The unbeaten and untied Miami Redskins struck for all their points in the last quarter today in defeating the University of Cincinnati, 14 -- 0, before 27,000 football fans.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 118 -- 97, tonight before a crowd of 8,537. It was the Warriors' seventh straight victory. The attendance was Convention Hall record for a National Basketball Association contest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- American Federation of Labor marine firemen are refusing to sign aboard West Coast ships in a dispute with two other maritime unions over terms of a master contract covering all three.

Consumption of steel mill products in the West is expected to set a record this year of about 6,200,000 tons. The estimate is made by Kaiser Steel Corporation in its annual market report, issued for publication today.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Today was a red-letter day at Harrow. The school welcomed back its greatest son, Sir Winston Churchill, and the borough extended its first honorary freedom.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 24 (UP) -Nfilwaukee's Socialist Aayor, Frank ZeidIer, announced today that he would run for a third term. His surprise announcement came after a Public Enterprise Committee meeting Wednesday night had adopted a platform that he favored. Mr. Zeidler had said that he wished to retire after this term because of the pressure of the office.

Registration statements covering American depository receipts for securities of eight foreign companies have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, with Guaranty Trust Company named as depositary, according to an announcement yesterday by Guaranty Trust.
The Soviet Government travel agency, Intourist, has set up machinery to speed the procedure for obtaining Russian visas.

Eduardo Lausse of Argentina, with twenty-nine straight victories, including twenty-five knockouts, will face Gene Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, in the main event at Madison Square Garden tonight. The middleweight fight is scheduled for ten rounds.

The four-story apartment house accommodating twentyone families at 319 Summit Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by Roy and Despina Vafiadis to Joseph F. Stone. The property occupies a plot 50 by 112 feet and contains suites of three and four rooms. It was sold through J. I. Kislak, Inc., asL broker. Jesse 1Koskowitz was at-I tozmey for the sellers and Her-/ man Silverstein acted for the] buyer. ]

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Virginia Tech won the Virginia Big Six football title today by overpowering Virginia Military Institute, 39 -- 13, after the Key-dets had thrilled a crowd of 24,000 by scoring twice in the first seven minutes.
NEW CASTLE, Ind., Nov. 24 (AP) -- National Guard troops alternated patrols on a "very quiet" Perfect Circle Corporation strike scene today long enough for all to eat Thanksgiving turkey dinners.

A group of East Coast gas utilities plans to announce today formation of the Council of Local Gas Companies with an avowed purpose of opposing Congressional approval of the Harris-Fulbright bill, which would remove from Federal hands control of natural gas at the well heads.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Chester C. Travelstead reasserted today that he had not resigned, but had been dismissed as dean of the University of South Carolina's School of Education because of a speech against race segregation in schools.

Three more units have been leased in the Wykagyl Shopping Center, which is scheduled to be completed early next year on a three-acre tract at the southwest corner of North Avenue and Northfield Road in New Rochelle, N.Y. Sam lViinskoff g= Sons are the owners and builders.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 24 (AP) -- A near-riot broke out in downtown Savannah tonight following a high school football game. Five policemen were injured before a mob was dispersed with tear gas.

Xavier High's football team easily defeated Fordham Prep, 20 -- 6, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. The victory was the thirteenth for the cadets in the 29-year rivalry. Fordham has won fifteen, and one game ended in a tie.
DANVILLE, Ill., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Three persons were fatally injured today and six others were hurt, four of them critically, in a two-car collision fifteen miles northwest of Danville.
SINCE "farce" is an opprobrious epithet in the theatre, let's call "Janus" a comedy -- in fact, "a romantic comedy." the program says.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The determined Detroit Red Wings snapped the Montreal Canadiens' eleven-game unbeaten streak tonight, 3 -- 2, by rallying for two third-period goals in a bruising National Hockey League game at Olympia.

RYE, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Rye High School's 33-game winning streak, one of the longest in the nation, ended today when Harrison came from behind in the last ten seconds for a 13-12 victory before 10,000 fans.
The nation celebrated Thanksgiving Day yesterday with family reunions and turkey feasts. It also gave thanks for peace and plenty and prayed that world peace would continue and be made more secure.
THE suspicion that television has taken over the American home is a fact. The Census Bureau stopped counting people long enough to find out that, as of June:

DENVER, Nov. 24 (UP) -- A 78- yard run on the last play gave Denver University a 6-3 victory over Wyoming University in a game today that resulted in a free-for-all between rival players. The crowd was confused too as to whether the touchdown had counted.

Negotiations between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. and eight private bus lines were recessed yesterday for Thanksgiving. Talks were scheduled for 10 A. M. today between the union and the New York City Omnibus Corporation.
A guide of spiritual and moral values for public school teachers won public endorsement yesterday from Roman Catholics and Protestants. It is vigorously opposed by the New York Board of Rabbis.

Betting on the horses at the nation's running tracks apparently will smash all records this year, although there will be a slight decline in attendance, an Associated Press survey disclosed yesterday.
CHANNEL 2's "The Longines Thanksgiving Day Festival" washed down yesterday's turkey with a copious flow of music and ballet.
An elaborate National Baby and Children's Show is scheduled at the New York Coliseum Aug. 4 through 12, with many products designed to assist children to be healthy and mentally alert to be shown.

Neither the President's Committee for Traffic Safety nor the 72,000,000 licensed drivers in the nation believe that the traffic accident problem can be solved with a "day" or any other short-term promotional device. But the experts who deal with the problem day in and day out are convinced that the dramatic appeal of Safe Driving Day next Thursday can return long-range dividends in the form of longer life for thousands of motorists and pedestrians.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A hitherto unknown group of serious virus diseases now is attacking cattle in at least twenty states.

Victor Eubank, 72-year-old retired member of the staff of The Associated Press, left his Greenwich Village apartment last Saturday evening after telling a friend he was going out to dinner. He has not been seen since.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Democratic National Committee's Special Advisory Committee on Agriculture sought unanimously today to commit the party to a return to higher farm subsidies. It also recommended an all-out Democratic attack on the Eisenhower Administration in this field in the 1956 campaign.

NEWARK, Nov. 24 -East Orange High stepped ahead of Barringer to break a tie in a football series that was fifty-nine years old today. East Orange won, 21 to 13, before 12,000 fans, but the result was in doubt until the favorites' high-scoring back, Charles Munford, tallied in the last minutes.

Hulan E. Jack, Manhattan Borough President, will take his first walk in Central Park's disputed Ramble tomorrow. And four of his top aides will be invited along on the hike to inspect the twenty-two-acre midtown wildwood that has become a near battleground between the Department of Parks and bird watchers.
Word has just come to me that the people of New York voted down the proposal for Panther Mountain Dam in the Adirondack region.

New housing being constructed or planned by the New York City Housing Authority will accommodate twice as many families as it displaces, Philip J. Cruise said yesterday. The chairman of the authority made the statement to dispel what he described as a widely held misconception.

Over consistent objection from the Soviet bloc, bolstered by a few possibly misguided associates, the United Nations has voted to continue the case of Korea upon its agenda. Nothing has been changed and, unfortunately, nothing more has been done.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer returned to his office, the Palais Schaumburg, today after a seven-week illness. Dr. Adenauer fell ill Oct. 7 with bronchial pneumonia.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 18 -- Chin Peng, a 33-year-old Chinese-Malayan, has risen in fifteen years from the obscure job of stencil-cutter for propagandists to secretary general of the Communist party on the Malay Peninsula.

BERN, Switzerland, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Sss Confederation, I whose permanent neutralit wasI established by the Congress ofj Vienna in 1815, today folTna/lyt recognized the permanent neu-I trality of Austria. established by] the .ustlan Parliament on Oct. i 26, 1955.
GENEVA, Nov. 24 -- European efforts to inject more competition into the industrial economy have produced a new and strange species of economic institution in the Ruhr coal fields.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Texas wrote an end to the colorful Texas A. and M. football story today with a 21-6 triumph that will be classed as one of the great upsets of Southwest Conference history.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Labor party outlined today a three-year plan for the formulation of a domestic program to appeal to millions of voters.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Cornell ran up its second highest football score against Pennsylvania today and finished third behind Princeton and Yale in the Ivy group.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 24 -- Egyptian forces in the Gaza strip fired across the armistice lines at Israeli forces in the Negev today, according to reports reaching Army general headquarters here. Bursts of machine-gun fire were opened at 10 A. M. in the Beeri sector, an Army spokesman said. The fire was not returned.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Detroit Lions today wrecked the Green Bay Packers' last hopes of winning the Western Division title in the National Football League. The Lions won, 24 -- 10, in a sloppy game witnessed by 51,685 fans.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 24 - President Eisenhower today sent greetings to King Haakon VII of Norway on the fiftieth anniversary of his reign.

THE DOOR is always open to the woman job applicant in one of the largest businesses in the country, the armed forces. Its standing number of women in the Army, Navy, Marines and Air Force is depleted monthly by those who leave after their enlistment period to marry or return to civilian life.
LATE this afternoon when early dusk enshadows Chinatown's ancient outward untidiness, Mai Que Chang will close the city's smallest post office, forever. It is at 13 Mott Street.

A FASCINATING and informative study of modern India's struggle to introduce democracy within the framework of its ancient heritage was offered yesterday afternoon on a remarkable television program presented by the National Broadcasting Company.

The completion of eighteen rounds of the international chess tournament at Zagreb yesterday required several long sessions to bring decisions among the contenders for second place, according to Yugoslav news sources.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today named twelve advisers to help it keep private atomic plants safe and healthy.
ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, at Sea, Nov. 24 -- Wearing Navy lifejackets, three turkeys floated across 1,700 feet of the Pacific today, to end up as a Thanksgiving Day dinner.

Thirty-seven young women, most of them from the New York area and Massachusetts, made their debuts last night at the annual Gotham Ball in the Plaza. The New York Foundling Hospital is the traditional beneficiary of the event.

DUBLIN, Nov. 24 (Reuters) A battle of the Atlantic in miniature is being fought just off the rugged west coast of Ireland where the hardy folk from tiny fishing villages are fighting an "invasion" by "foreigners" from Dublin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Americans enjoyed last year one of the largest post-war increases in the standard of living, the Federal Reserve Bulletin said tonight.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Nov. 24 -- Frobisher-Ventures of Montreal will begin surveys next year for a new $50,000,000 hydro-electric project on the Nass River in northwestern British Columbia. Premier W. A. C. Bennett of British Columbia made the announcement today in Victoria, the provincial capital.

Earnings of Solar Aircraft Company, San Diego, Calif., during the six months ended Oct. 31, were greater than during the corresponding period last year despite lower sales, it was announced yesterday. Net profits were $603,434 or 88 cents a common share on 683,902 outstanding shares. During the like 1954 period earnings were $411,600 or $1 cents on 672,783 shares of common stock.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Tax officials thought they had 50- year-old Bill Hughes dead to rights.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The President's Committee for Traffic Safety called on the nation today to follow the example of Rhode Island, Connecticut, Massachusetts and the District of Columbia in cutting down auto accidents.

Thanksgiving morning, about breakfast time, in a one-family frame house in Brooklyn. A stationary oil heater in the kitchen. Four members of a family in the house: Mrs. Charlotte Mitchell, aged 23, the mother, and three children, Allen, 4; Jayne, 3, and Betty Lou, 2.
Affiliated Fund achieved record assets of $335,606,525 on Oct. 31, an increase of $54,691,643 over assets of $280,914,882 a year earlier.

A few days ago a Queens family decided to move far away from that borough because it has been victimized by a young hoodlum who threatens to harm a youthful member of that family in retaliation for court action against the young hoodlum.
Events today: Bizet's "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; New York Philharmonic- Symphony, Pierre Monteux, conductor, Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.
A third Walt Disney program will be broadcast by the American Broadcasting Company network, beginning on Monday, Dec. 5.

The Aleutians are a 1,200-mile chain of natural islands, lying off the Alaska Peninsula. By comparison, the new radar island that lies 110 miles east of Boston is small, displacing only 8,000 tons as contrasted with one doesn't know how many tons in the Aleutians. The inhabitants of the Aleutians, a few thousand all told, fish and watch the planes going over on the route Mrs. Lindbergh called "north to the Orient."
BERLIN, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Communist China's Deputy Premier Chen Yi was quoted today as having said Red China would invade Formosa if negotiations with the United States broke down.
Net earnings of the Tennessee Corporation in the first nine months of this year rose to $5,287,900, a record for any such period, the company reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- Directors of the Motion Picture Industry Pensions Plan have voted to raise retirement payments from $20 to $50 a month, it was announced today through the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

LAST night's performance by the New York City Ballet at the City Center included the season's first presentation of George Balanchine's choreographic creation on the last three movements of Mendelssohn's "Scotch Symphony."

Plans to populate two new musical productions -- "The Ziegfeld Follies" and "My Royal Past" -- were outlined yesterday. Both shows are scheduled for presentation on Broadway in the late spring.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The Soviet Union rejected today a French proposal for a new approach to world disarmament through a program of compromise and conciliation.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 24 -- South Africa is suffering from a severe shortage of skilled and semi-skilled labor.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The Soviet Union rejected today a French proposal for a new approach to world disarmament through a program of compromise and conciliation.
BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -Plans for an intensive study of a solar eclipse on Dec. 14 were outlined today by the Cambridge Center of the Air Research and Development Command.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The number of business mergers in 1955 will break all records for a quarter of a century.

It isn't the gum we chew that makes capitalistic America repellent to visiting Communists. It isn't any soft drink we drink that lands our civilization in the gutter. It isn't the boogie-woogie, which wasn't, after all, invented by Wall Street bankers.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Sir Anthony Eden suggested today that the end of Egypt's blockade of Israel and the return of Arab refugees to Israel were types of concessions that might lead to a settlement of the Israeli-Egyption dispute.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Britain dismissed as "unrealistic" today a Saudi Arabian proposal that the dispute over the oil-rich Buraimi oasis in southeast Arabia be referred back to arbitration under a neutral commission.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Goalie Lorne Worsley attained his second shutout in two nights against Boston and Wally Hergesheimer chipped in with a three-goal "hat trick" as the New York Rangers swamped the inept Bruins, 5 -- 0, tonight. A crowd of 12,863 watched the game at the Boston Garden.

When 3 1/2-year-old Susan Eisenhower sent to her ailing grandfather as a birthday gift a book titled "150 Ways to Play Solitaire" and two packs of playing cards, she was providing him with the wherewithal to play a game that has been the classic companion for generations of convalescents, travelers, service men, shut-ins, prisoners, retired people, as well as the great and the lowly seeking relaxation from everyday tensions or an end to loneliness.

It was a proud day for the Daniel Clancy family of Rosedale, Queens, yesterday when the forty-fifth annual handicap walking race was finished. There was also some gratification at the United States Military Academy at West Point.
The National Council of Teachers of English has entered the controversy over whether Johnny can read.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Federal Court ruling requiring the State Department to produce adverse information used in denying passports was acclaimed today by Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- "Mr. Hagerty said Mr. Hall would come to Gettysburg 'at the President's invitation' for a 'political discussion of Republican party matters'" (from a Gettysburg dispatch in today's issue of this newspaper).

DENVER, Nov. 24 (AP) -- District Judge Edward J. Keating has refused a psychiatrist permission to examine John Gilbert Graham, 23 years old. charged with murder in the Nov. 1 dynamiting of an airliner.

CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 24 -Mayor D. H. Mackay of Calgary attacked today what he termed "special privileges" of Canadian railways. He suggested that Canada's two great railways could be amalgamated in the national interest.
BOMBAY, India, Nov. 24 -Nikita S. Khrushchev said tonight that some of the international issues discussed at the recent Geneva conference might not be "ripe" for settlement.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Norbert H. Robichaud, D. D., Roman Catholic Archbishop of Moncton, N. B., received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Assumption College at ceremonies tonight commemorating the 200th anniversary of the dispersal of the Acadian people by British troops.

A few days ago a sorely troubled man, Atomic Energy Commissioner Thomas E. Murray, made a dramatic proposal. Let us invite the whole world, Russian and Chinese Communists included, Mr. Murray proposed, to Eniwetok to witness the explosion of a large thermonuclear bomb and to make clear the problem that the radiation products of this bomb create for all humanity.
