GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 25 -- The Greenwich Water Company and the Port Chester (N. Y.) Water Works, Inc., said today they could now "proceed toward final completion" of the Mianus Valley reservoir.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The rabbits of Britain have found their scourge in George Horatio Charles, fifth Marquess of Cholmondeley, pronounced, as all Anglo-American humorists know, "Chumley."

HAVANA, Nov. 25 -- The winners of special trophies in the thirty-third world championship of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association were announced today. The presentations will be made during the final dinner at the Havana Yacht Club tomorrow.
Forrest W. Price has been named manager of factory branch distributing operations for C. B. S.-Columbia, a division of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Sale of stock to promote a so-called sidewise parking device was halted in New York State yesterday by order of Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey.
Gifted pupils who sometimes become problems, for want of methods to teach them, called yesterday for less concentration on commas and colons and more on values.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Soviet Russia passed another international milestone in competitive athletics today when it entered the winter Olympic Games to be held here from Jan. 26 to Feb. 8. The Russians never have competed in the winter games.

Mrs. Mai Que Chang put the hand-lettered Cantonese sign "Closed" in the wicket at Post Office Contract Station 233 for the last time at 4:30 P. M. yesterday. Chinese have brought mail to the three-by-nine station at 13 Mott Street for thirty-seven years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Daimler-Benz Company of Stuttgart - Unterturkheim, Germany, received a patent this week for a jet-assisted racing car. It applies the force of its own exhaust.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Army and Navy will meet on the football field for the fifty-sixth time here tomorrow with Navy a touchdown favorite in what promises to be a repetition of last year's rousing fight.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, rejected today bilateral talks with the Soviet Union on German reunification.

HALIFAX, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- The grounded Liberian freighter was being battered by heavy waves and high winds off northern Cape Breton this afternoon as rescue squads tried frantically to lower life lines down overhanging cliffs.

THE copy of Whit Burnett's "This Is My Best Humor"* on our table skips from Page 72 to Page 105, a vagary appropriate to an excellent vaudeville of hilarity. What dazzling spoofs and satires are thus left out of Mr. Burnett's engaging anthology we may never know. But, with your permission, we may profitably devote that unexpected interval to another new book, a biography of an absent member of the company, Robert Benchley, 1889-1945.

Miroslava Nachodska, Czechoslovakian figure-skating star who fled from behind the Iron Curtain in February, arrived here yesterday. She and seventy other European refugees landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, in a plane chartered by the Inter-Governmental Committee for European Migration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- There were renewed reports here today that this country would make new tests of hydrogen and atomic bombs in the Pacific next spring.
A Federal Court review was sought yesterday in the case of a 35-year-old former entertainer from Argentina who assertedly had been held incommunicado here as a possible security risk.
A plan calculated to make public housing available for the first time to small communities was disclosed here yesterday. The community selected for the test was Goshen, N. Y.

The six-story apartment house at 638 East Second Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Master Properties to the Noret Building Corporation. The property, on plot 60 by 100 feet, contains thirty-eight apartments and eight stores.

FOR anyone seriously intending to lose weight (not an unusual resolution after Thanksgiving), a sound investment might be "How to Reduce Surely and Safely" ($2.95, McGraw-Hill, 158 pp.). The author of this new book is Dr. Herbert Pollack, who has been associated with Mount Sinai Hospital for several years. Previously he was a fellow in medicine at the Mayo Clinic and lectured at the Cornell and Columbia medical schools.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt takes his first crack at a race he designed in 1937 when his Social Outcast leads a record field of eight to the post tomorrow for the nineteenth running of the $50,000 Pimlico Special.
ANYTHING can happen at an auction, public sale experts are fond of saying. When it is a benefit auction, this familiar comment is repeated with emphasis.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 25 -- Several employes of The Cincinnati Enquirer, led by John F. Cronin, city editor, revolted against the top management of that morning and Sunday newspaper today in a series of three meetings at the Hotel Metropole.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Control of the National Tea Company, Chicago, one of the country's fastest-growing grocery chains, has been bought by Canadian business interests headed by W. Garfield Weston of Toronto.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the Board of Estimate would undoubtedly consider soon the possibility of advancing the effective date of the proposed ban on kerosene heaters in dwellings.
Fewer than 6,000 candidates, instead of the expected 20,000, have applied for appointment as policemen since the test filing period opened Nov. 3. The deadline for applications is next Tuesday.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Governor Harriman today applauded the thirteen-point legislative program for Congress advanced this week by Senator Lyndon Johnson, Democrat of Texas, the Senate majority leader.
The tightest labor market since World War II has confronted retailers here with a difficult problem in hiring enough temporary help for the Christmas rush.
OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- The projected visit to Canada of four leading Russian Orthodox Church personalities appears today to have reached an impasse.

A tentative plan for production of newsprint in Florida was disclosed yesterday by the Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation, now a major producer of household tissue and kraft paper products. If carried through, it could result in an annual production of 100,000 tons of newsprint within two years.
This country's boys and girls -- and their teachers -- were praised here yesterday for their interest in national and world affairs.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The British Medical Association has urged the Government to continue permitting the manufacture of heroin. A ban on such manufacture becomes effective Dec. 31. The association's plea in the matter is supported by influential medical practitioners and a number of hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, called today for a tax "readjustment" by Congress in its forthcoming session, without any over-all reduction in Government revenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today its approval of the initial financing of Yankee Atomic Electric-Company, which proposes to build an atomic power plant in Massachusetts.

Mrs. Julia Robbins Hoyt Giles, actress known on the stage and in films as Julia Hoyt, bequeathed nearly all of her $1,000,000 estate to fourteen charitable organizations. She also willed her eyes to the Eye Bank, her will, filed in Surrogate's Court, disclosed yesterday.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 25 -- Hugh W. Cross, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, submitted his resignation to President Eisenhower today. The President accepted it immediately.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 25 -- Mississippi took an impassive attitude today to the Interstate Commerce Commission's order.

Everyone who has the interest of the United Nations at heart will breathe a sigh of relief that France is coming back to the General Assembly. This was arranged with yesterday's votes in the Political Committee and General Assembly deleting the Algerian issue from the agenda.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 25 -- The leaders of the major Nationalist parties have agreed that France should remain in charge of Morocco's foreign affairs and national defense until Morocco is ready to take over those tasks.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Dow Finsterwald of Bedford Heights, Ohio, took a one-stroke lead with a par 72 in the opening round of the $5,000 West Palm Beach open golf tournament today.

HALIFAX, N. S., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Air and sea-borne efforts to rescue thirty crewmen marooned in a storm-lashed freighter wrecked on a northern Cape Breton cape failed today. Tonight a rescue convoy headed by a snow plow floundered over mountainous roads toward the scene with breeches buoy equipment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines were expected today to appeal a ruling by a Civil Aeronautics Board trial examiner that they refund millions of dollars in subsidy payments.

RALEIGH, Nov. 25 (AP) -- West Virginia's massive Mountaineers, held to a 7-7 standstill in the first half, scored three last-half touchdowns, two by Joe Marconi, to defeat North Carolina State, 27 -- 7, tonight. A rain-soaked crowd of 4,000 saw the game played on a muddy field.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Production of feature pictures by Hollywood studios and independent producers will reach its highest level in four years next week.

TRENTON, Nov. 25 -- Brig Gen. H., Norman Schwarzkopf will resign his position as administrative director of the New Jersey Department of Law and Public Safety early in January. Deputy Attorney General John Thevos, Camden Democrat, will succeed General Schwarzkopf, a Republican, in the $15,000-a-year position, it was reported yesterday.
POONA, India, Nov. 25 -- It simply will not seem possible to many Englishmen, but the Russians were toasted in a mess in Poona today, and in colored water, too.
BAGHDAD, Nov. 25 -- Negotiations over Syria's demand for higher transit tolls on oil piped across her territory have reached a critical stage.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Secretary of the Air Force Donald A. Quarles said today Russia "has more airplanes than we do," but the United States has more nuclear weapons and atomic bombers.
Coffee and rubber futures contracts were the featured performers yesterday in an otherwise dull and quiet commodity market. Coffee advanced sharply and rubber closed mostly lower.

The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, dedicated yesterday a plain brick and wood structure to house the Chapel of Our Saviour and the residence of the chaplain at Manhattan State Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy asserted today that the Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights was helping to "torpedo" the Government's security risk program.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 25 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion said today that as he understood the new suggestions by Sir Anthony Eden for an Arab-Israeli settlement, "the essential point of inequality remains."

The Protestant Council of the City of New York will be host on Sunday, Dec. 4, to church-going delegates attending the merger convention of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Terry Brennan, Notre Dame's young football coach, tonight said that regardless of the result of tomorrow's game with Southern California he would consider 1955 a highly successful season. The intersectional contest is expected to draw a crowd of 90,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Army today assigned Maj. Gen. George Van Houten as commander of the Military District of Washington, succeeding Maj. Gen. John H. Stokes Jr.

SLIDELL, LA., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Burglars burned through the steel vault of the Bank of Slidell today. They escaped with several thousand dollars in coins before being routed by the bank's automatic tear gas system.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The United States renewed its pledge today never to use nuclear weapons except in defense against aggression.
Sales of vermouth, both domestic and imported, are running 8 per cent ahead of last year, the previous record period, according to John L. Tribuno, head of Vermouth Industries of America.
HAVERHILL, Mass., Nov. 25 (AP) -- David J. Coddaire, an original member of the Subversive Activities Control Board, said tonight he had resigned to return to private law practice.
RARELY is specialization carried so far as it was last night by the Encore Artists group at Carnegie Hall.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 25 -- Brazil was put under a state of siege tonight.

PEMBROKE, Ont., Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Dr. James J. McCann, Revenue Minister, said last night the Algoma Steel Corporation, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., next spring will begin development of an "enormous" iron ore deposit in the Calabogie, Ont., area which will yield some $500,000,000 to the economy of the Upper Ottawa Valley.

It was a fine bird, done to a turn. It was so large the cook barely could carry it to the table, although it was much lighter when she took it away again. Following that, it made perfect sandwiches, and was good as cold slices and good as hash.

Paul Brown, the coach of the Cleveland Browns, frequently has been referred to by his contemporaries as a shrewd operator. Few, if any, have outsmarted him in player deals. Only a handful have been able to outwit him when the chips were down on the gridiron.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission's segregation decision will not destroy Georgia's law requiring segregation on bus and rail trips beginning and terminating within the state, Attorney General Eugene Cook declared today.

A grant has been made to the Film Council of America by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation to support the council's film users' guide. It is published bi-weekly and provides information on the latest 16-mm. film releases.

THE painter Daniel Schwartz, who is having a first one-man show at the Davis Gallery, 231 East Sixtieth Street, is a devotee of the American scene, which he portrays in a drily romantic way. He paints no more, and no less, than what he sees.

The aggregate reserve position of member banks of the Federal Reserve System Wednesday pointed toward a tighter money market next week. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday net free reserves showed a minus $633,000,000 on Wednesday against a minus $287,000,000 a week ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The project for a United Nations fund for economic development made progress today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Communist Czechoslovakia's effort to prevent her people from reading Western publications has reached into the flower garden of the United States Embassy in Prague.

PANAMA, Nov. 25 -- The Liberal party directorate decided last night to nominate presidential and vice presidential candidates for 1956 elections. This action ruled out the possibility that the slate of the Administration's national coalition party would run unopposed.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- The West German Foreign Office announced today it had given its agreement to Valerian A. Zorin as the first Soviet Ambassador to Bonn. A memorandum to this effect was communicated last evening to the Soviet Government through its embassy in Paris.

White and gold chrysanthemums and autumn foliage in varying hues of yellow provided a colorful decor last night for the first Junior Assembly for this season. The event was held in the main ballroom of the Plaza. It is one of the oldest and best-established dances for debutantes in this city.

Pension plans don't always work out as expected. That is why actuaries now are giving closer study to the contractual rights of an employe and employer in a plan which is terminated. Actuaries are insurance specialists who determine statistical probabilities.

FAILURE to clean a surface thoroughly before it is painted causes the paint to peel and blister shortly after the job is finished, says Miss Gena Thames. Home furnishings specialist of Rutgers University. Her warning applies to all surfaces, including walls, woodwork, floors and furniture.
Dr. Polykarp Kusch, Nobel Prize winner in physics, said yesterday that greater economic security was needed to end the scarcity of science teachers.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Two wing tanks from a Delaware Air National Guard Sabre jet plane fell in the heart of near-by Newport, Del., today. A building was damaged but no one in the community of 4,000 was injured.

New issues of securities are continuing to advance on the capital market in substantial volume in the face of the pause given the money market last week by the increase in the Federal Reserve System rediscount rate to 2 1/2 per cent.
QUEBEC, Nov. 25 -- A member of the Liberal opposition in the Quebec Legislative Assembly today asked that prices paid to farmers for pulpwood be increased.

Market operators came alive yesterday to the fact that rails as well as industrials can be the media of stock splits. As a result, The New York Times rail average jumped to the best level in twenty-five years on its largest one-day gain since July 24, 1933.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The nation-wide polio vaccination program is leaving the school house for the private physician's office and the public health clinic.
"Appointment With Adventure," which has had its closest call away from the TV screen, can take a deep breath. The Columbia Broadcasting System has renewed the program's lease.
The New York Giants possibly, even probably, will become tenants at the Yankee Stadium, Horace Stoneham, president of the club, said yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, Kan., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Representative Clifford R. Hope, ranking Republican on the House Agriculture Committee, announced today he would retire from Congress at the end of his present term.

Eduardo Lausse of Buenos Aires punched out a unanimous decision over Gene Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, at Madison Square Garden last night. The middleweights waged a rousing ten-round struggle that satisfied a crowd of 4,000.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 25 -- A Nassau County grand jury found tonight that there had been no evidence of crime in the fatal shooting of William Woodward Jr. at his home in Oyster Bay, L. I., on Oct. 30.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Senator Estes Kefauver announced today that a subcommittee he heads would resume its hearings on the Dixon-Yates power contract next Friday.
In 1954 the eighty-two voluntary, nonprofit hospitals that are members of the Unit ed Hospital Fund reported the highest operating deficits in their history.
GROTON, Conn., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The world's first atomic-powered submarine left here today to show Navy and Atomic Energy Commission officials what she can do.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Terrorists killed a British soldier in ambush tonight in retaliation for the killing of a Cypriote by British Commandos.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Italy and Libya announced today an agreement to establish a mixed arbitration commission to take over the functions of the United Nations Tribunal in Libya.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Pierre Monteux, conductor, Robert Casadesus, pianist, 8:45 P. M.; Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, Town Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Carmen Gutierrez, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30 P. M.; Joliet Township Grade School Band of Joliet, Ill., conductor, Charles Peters, Manhattan Center, 9 A. M.; Ithaca College Concert Band, Walter Beeler, conductor, Manhattan Center, 1:30 P. M.; College Jazz Goes to Carnegie Hall, Carnegie Hall, midnight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation to import 300 million cubic feet of natural gas daily from Canada.

CAIRO, Nov. 25 -- A Czechoslovak Government trade delegation arrived here today to complete a trade and payments agreement with Egypt. The agreement will provide for exchange of Egyptian agricultural goods and textiles for Czechoslovak machinery and manufactures.
Canadian Pacific's passenger fleet carried more than 35,000 passengers on sixty-one trans-Atlantic crossings during this year's St. Lawrence River shipping season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- State Department quarters are growing more confident that neither Israel nor the Arab states will start a major war for the present.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 25 -- The Rutgers University Board of Trustees by a 28-8 vote today adopted a reorganization plan giving the state more control over the university.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 -- The National Grange, a middle-of-the-road farm organization painted a gloomy picture of the farm situation today.

EDWARD R. MURROW'S "Person to Person," which has long been dropping in on people in spacious mansions or commodious apartments, finally paid a call last night that was well adapted for a small screen.
DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Domestic passenger car production this week will total 151,470 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias said today she would re-enter a Galveston, Tex., hospital this week-end for another cancer check-up.

Three boys and a girl were turned loose in Macy's toy department before it opened yesterday morning with instructions to grab all they could in two to five minutes. They made off with $668 in assorted treasures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Following is the text of the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission, issued today, directing interstate railroads to end racial segregation on all passenger trains. A similar order on the desegregation of bytes followed the same pattern.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Bing Crosby called off today a special showing for the Notre Dame football team of the movie "Guys and Dolls" after criticism of the film from Roman Catholics.

Spectators in Felony Court yesterday were so moved by the story of how a Negro minister was persecuted by white people in the South that many went forward to shake his hand after his arraignment as a fugitive from South Carolina.

A vacant plot of 25,000 square feet at 12 to 28 West Thirteenth Street has been sold by the Hale Operating Corporation to the Vilbrook Realty Corporation. The property has a frontage of 215 feet in the block between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. It will be leased out for use as a parking lot.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Martin Kelso Elliott, a 47-year-old Hoosier, will probably succeed Mr. Cross as chairman of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission decreed today that racial segregation on trains and buses that cross state lines must end by Jan. 10. The decision applied also to public waiting rooms in railway and bus terminals.

The results of this year's inoculations with the Salk vaccine have not yet been exhaustively analyzed. Preliminary reports have done much to dispel misgivings aroused by the discovery of live virus in batches of supposedly killed vaccine. For this reason it is widely assumed that poliomyelitis has been conquered.
The nineteenth and last round of the international chess masters tournament was played in Zagreb yesterday, according to Yugoslav news sources.

Not all the news coming from abroad these days is bad or alarming. The failure of the Geneva foreign ministers' conference induced an atmosphere of pessimism that was understandable but perhaps exaggerated. Those seeking a note of cheer can contemplate what was officially called "a most successful" meeting in Baghdad of the five nations now belonging to the Baghdad pact -- Iraq, Turkey, Iran, Pakistan and Great Britain.

Butcher Sherrerd and associates are offering a new issue of $2,367,000 of revenue bonds of Pennsbury Joint School Building Authority, Bucks County, Pa. The issue bears interest coupons ranging from 4 per cent to 2.85 per cent. The bonds will come due from 1958 to 1995 and are priced to yield from 1.8 to 3.1 per cent.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 25 -- Sir John Kotelawala, Ceylonese Prime Minister, disclosed today on his return from visits to Thailand and Singapore that a strong anti-Communist front was being planned by Asian countries. The Prime Minister also visited Australia and New Zealand on his tour.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 -- The order to end segregation of passengers in interstate travel apparently will have its biggest impact on public waiting rooms. In many places in the South they are segregated by state or city law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- J. Sinclair Armstrong, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today proposed tighter rules governing proxy fights would not interfere with "traditional American freedom of the press."
