Now, even while talk of "negotiating a settlement" was in progress, they have struck twice in typical raids, causing death and destruction.
SHORT HILLS, N. J., Nov. 25 -- Ten young women were presented tonight at the Short Hills Debutante Ball at the Short Hills Club. Many cocktail and dinner parties were given before the fete.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- Soviet diplomacy is engaged in a highly energetic effort to capture political sympathies in the Middle East and South Asia. Moscow bases its campaign upon two propaganda postulates: that the U. S. S. R. is the sole big champion of anti-colonialism; and that only the Soviet Union has solved the problem of how to industrialize underdeveloped areas swiftly.

MADISON, Conn., Nov. 25 -- The sage who coined the phrase concerning a bird in the hand and two in the bush must have been a woodcock hunter. So far as we are concerned, the quest for "timber-doodle" holds more challenge and interest than the hunting of any other form of upland game.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Premier Edgar Faure asked today for a new vote of confidence from the National Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The Army announced today it would form a third airborne division in the next eighteen months.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court disposed yesterday of the test case on burlesque shows in New York in ten minutes. But the question of whether there would now be an actual burlesque show in this city after ten years of unofficial ban remained unanswered.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- All grain futures except soybeans showed marked easiness at the close today. December wheat led the sell-off.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The French Government decided today to resume its seat in the United Nations General Assembly.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- The cream of the Dresden art collection, one of the richest in existence and newly returned from "Soviet captivity," was placed on exhibition in East Berlin today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 -- The Democratic National Chairman charged tonight that the Eisenhower Administration was trying to dismiss as partisan "smears" instances of misfeasance so flagrant that they had initially been spotlighted by "Republican" newspapers.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 25 -- A suggestion was made today that the newspaper La Prensa be returned to Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz with certain strings attached.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The Air Force, despite its doubts about the value of the Army's Mike anti-aircraft guided missile, is using the weapon to protect some vital strategic bomber bases.

Pausing here momentarily yesterday before hopping a plane for Paris, where he will discuss a film assignment, Jerome Robbins revealed that he would definitely direct "The Bells Are Ringing," the Jule Styne-Betty Comden-Adolph Green musical that will bring Judy Holliday back to Broadway.
CAIRO, Nov. 24 -- Egypt has suddenly called off her violent crusade against the French in North Africa. The French bought the Egyptians off with a promise to resume shipments of arms.
A hearing scheduled by the Federal Maritime Board for Dec. 6 may clear the way for the return of the Arnold Bernstein Line to North Atlantic service after an absence of nearly two decades.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren distributed candy and balloons to infantile paralysis patients at Children's Hospital today.
A documentary film on an Soviet atomic power plant was shown here last night for the first time in this country.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., met separately yesterday with the New York City Ombinus Corporation and the Third Avenue Transit System in efforts to resolve a contract dispute before a strike set for Wednesday midnight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Following are the letters exchanged by President Eisenhower and Hugh W. Cross on Mr. Cross resignation as chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission:
The Syracuse Nationals, last season's National Basketball Association champions, will meet the New York Knickerbockers tonight for the first time in the current campaign.

PARIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization decided today to pay $24,000 to three American women dismissed because they would not appear before a United States loyalty board.
PARIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- An authorized spokesman said today some of the slower French Ouragan jet fighter planes had been delivered to Israel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Egypt's Deputy. Foreign Minister said today that foreign offers to mediate Egyptian-Israeli quarrels were appreciated by his Government.

MOSCOW, Nov. 25 -- The sentencing of a Soviet citizen who had returned from residence abroad to only five years in exile was interpreted here today as part of a campaign to induce anti-Communist Russians to return to their homeland.

CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 25 -- An investigation to determine the amount of control that American capital has over the Canadian oil industry has been opened by Dr. John Davis, energy adviser to the Gordon Commission on Canada's economic future.
Loans by Federal Home Loan Banks to member savings and loan associations rose $69,000,000 during October, despite the September announcement that the Federal banks were tightening the lid.

The new German "citizen-soldier" army has begun to assume more definite form with the appointment of its top commanders, whose character and personalities are bound to have a profound influence on shaping the spirit, the loyalties and the traditions of this new addition to the North Atlantic defense forces.

Gross operating revenues of the Southern Pacific Company and its solely controlled affiliates reached $558,787,902 in the first ten months this year. This was $38,571,538 above the January-October gross last year.
Mrs. Maria Kramer, president of the Lincoln Hotel, pleaded guilty in Municipal Term Court yesterday to violations of the multiple dwelling laws. She paid a fine of $250.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Treasury announced today what officials called a "neutral" financing offer to refund $12,212,000,000 of securities maturing Dec. 15.

BE she frivolous or sensible, tailored or frilly, any woman likes a luxurious Christmas gift. And it's a pretty safe guess that something of fur, leather or jewelry will live up to this description in her eyes.

The report in your issue of Nov. 21 on the observance of the centennial of Poland's poet Adam Mickiewicz contains the following statement: "Much of his work is characterized by what has been described as a seething hatred of the Russians.
Loans to business outstanding on the books of leading New York City banks increased only $15,000,000 in the week
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 25 -- The Nationalist party elected today a new South African Senate, which will give the Nationalists undisputed control of Parliament.

In ordering an end to segregation of Negroes traveling from one state to another on railroads or buses the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday was extending throughout its own area the substance of previous Supreme Court decisions, especially last year's against segregation in the schools.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The strengthening of the West is the answer to the rigid Soviet attitude at the last Geneva conference, Sir Anthony Eden declared tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The United Nations swung open the door today for France's return to the General Assembly.

A tract of about 170,000 square feet at 38-20 Review Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Commercial Metals Company of Texas to the Mandel Motor Truck Exchange, Inc., dealer in used trucks and parts.
Cotton futures closed steady, 1 point lower to 42 points higher than Wednesday, on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Strength was most pronounced in the new crop months.

Once more, in the month Sept. 15 -- Oct. 15, the consumer price index has remained unchanged from the month previous, at 114.9, or 14.9 per cent above the base period for the index, 1947-49. Rarely have we witnessed such a demonstration of stable consumer prices, or, stated another way, stability in the purchasing power of the dollar.

Ministers and art teachers have something in common. They are both low men on the salary totem pole. This was brought out in a study appearing in the 1956 Yearbook of American Churches, published recently by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

College jazz, first introduced to Carnegie Hall last year on Thanksgiving week-end, returned last night for the first of two successive evenings featuring collegiate jazz bands. Princeton and Yale held the stage last evening, represented by Stan Rubin's Tigertown Five and Eli's Chosen Six.
DENVER, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Was a whistle blown? If so, who blew it?

A new $100,000,000 refinery that the Tide Water Associated Oil Company calls "the largest ever built from the ground up" is taking shape on a 4,800-acre site on the Dela ware River, fifteen miles south of Wilmington.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York urged yesterday that the state supervise workers' welfare and pension plans.

SOLAR COOKER-- An experimental utensil that cooks rice with the heat of the sun has been designed by Saizo Goto, president of an optical company of Tokyo, Japan. His cooker weighs 250 pounds and measures approximately three feet in diameter.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 26 --This town has won a ten-year battle to control Dutch elm disease.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--Every Wednesday morning at the John Eaton Grade School on Thirty-fourth Street in Washington, the third row in the fourth grade brings in "news" for discussion, and this week one of the topics was "the school problem."
Two office buildings are to be erected by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company in Los Angeles, Calif., where the concern has completed three structures and has another one under way.

IN this on-the-spot analysis and discussion of the current state of affairs in French North Africa, Edmund Stevens, a foreign correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor, has turned in a fine piece of reporting.

Fifteen years ago scientists engaged in basic research were dependent on grants from philanthropic foundations and the income from university endowments. It is otherwise today, largely because of the huge sums appropriated by the Government for the support of research conducted in Federal laboratories or in university laboratories under contract with the Atomic Energy Commission, the Office of Naval Research, the National Science Foundation and other official agencies.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 26 (AP)--Long-distance scoring sallies, two of them romps of 95 and 72 yards by Carl Brazell, enabled South Carolina to overcome Virginia today, 21--14, in an Atlantic Coast Conference football game.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26--The Soviet Union confirmed today that it had recently exploded its "most powerful" hydrogen weapon, embodying "important new achievements" of Soviet scientists. The weapon was a bomb, according to the Soviet announcement.

TOKYO, Nov. 26--A series of unusual vibrations recorded Tuesday afternoon on the Kyoto University tasimeter, a modification of the microphone, may have been caused by a nuclear explosion, the university's earthshock experts speculated today.
A 64-year-old grandmother, accused in the asserted illegal sale of a baby, won a double court battle to escape custody yesterday, only to be locked up by immigration officials.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Start spreading mulches where needed for winter protection. Spread oak leaves under broadleaved evergreens, peat moss, salt hay or any clean material under buddleia and other half-hardy shrubs. Evergreen branches may be sufficient covering for bulbs and perennials. It is important to mulch all newly set perennials.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP)--Don Fairfield, a young player from Casey, Ill., fashioned a 4-under-par 68 today for a three-stroke lead after thirty-six holes in the second annual $5,000 West Palm Beach open golf tournament.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 26-- Four cars of the Boston-New York express train, the Owl, left the rails here at 5:23 A. M. today, blocking three of the four main line tracks of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

THE Screen Producers Guild last week finally ended the suspense. It announce that as an organization it would not undertake a week television motion picture series because conformity to today's standards of filmed video might impair its prestige.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26--A school construction program for next year costing more than $36,000,000 was announced this week by Benjamin C. Willis, Superintendent of Schools. It calls for forty-two new building's or additions.

IN his quest for a new setting for a historical novel, Glenn Pierce has gone back to the year 800 and taken for his hero one Eric, Count of the Norman Shore. He has sent his protagonist to Baghdad as the envoy of Charlemagne.

ONE of the more welcome of our anthologies is Martha Foley's annual collection of short stories rescued from the vast quagmire of American magazines. As usual, she has compiled a volume varied enough to suit all tastes and temperaments.

APPLETON, Wis., Nov. 26 (UP)--A Republican party official has disclosed that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy recommended appointment of a convicted gambler and bootlegger as postmaster of Appleton without consulting party leaders.
Parent education and child development will be furthered by a recital on Dec. 14 by the young Negro baritone, Robert McFerrin, at Town Hall.
A mounted policeman is required to sit on his horse fifty minutes out of every hour while on duty--New York City Police Department.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 24--A report of a difference of opinion among American officials as to whether the United States should "support" President Syngman Rhee for re-election has aroused considerable feeling among Korean leaders.

THE Christmas shopping season is in full swing. The next twenty-four shopping days will provide the bulk of Christmas volume, but retail business has been good since Election Day. On the basis of Federal Reserve Board reports for department stores, retailers throughout the country will go ahead of last year's volume by about 7 per cent.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 26 --A representative group of New England dairy farmers has been shown how a few practical changes in management methods can increase income and production.

HOLLYWOOD. ANTIQUE Dutchmen walked about High Tor last week wrapped in mists as winds keened through scraggy pines and whispered among the crags and rocks. But they were not on New York's historic mountain.
TRANS-WORLD Airlines, which is sponsoring a guessing contest on the future of aviation, is itself the subject of some unsponsored speculation.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 26-- The statues of Juan D. Peron and his late wife atop the unfinished monumental building of the Eva Peron Foundation have been wrapped in burlap.
BELZONI, Miss., Nov. 26 (UP) --Neither white nor Negro leaders could provide a direct motive for the shooting. The N.A.A. C.P. chapter "hadn't made much noise here lately," a white leader said.

NO one really interested in the theatre's welfare likes the idea, but it is becoming increasingly evident that prices for tickets are likely to climb. Portents in recent months indicate that regardless of how unwilling they may be to make the move, producers are thinking that a price boost is their only salvation.
Models are being shown by builders today in two new housing developments in Nassau County. One of the groups is in Plainview and the other is in East Meadow.

There are only twenty-four shopping days until you, know what -- and stores everywhere will be bustling with shoppers eager to find "just the right things." It is a good idea to keep hobbies in mind, for often gifts along these lines provide great excitement for both donor and receiver.

The Canadians of Montreal will meet the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. It is likely that the largest crowd of the local season will attend the contest, which is scheduled to start at 7 o'clock.

HONG KONG. THE women of Communist China, after six years of official encouragement to look as much like locomotive drivers as possible, are now being told that it is time to start looking like women again The campaign seems to have begun last spring with a "letter to the editor" of The Peiping Chinese Youth Daily.
JOSEPH SCHUSTER, who gave a 'cello recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, played not only like a master of his instrument but also like a master of music as well.

IN the golden age of the 10cent haircut and the 15-cent church supper, there was only one public auditorium in smalltown America where the citizenry could gather to vote, dance, hold a strawberry festival, see a velocipede performance, hear a lecture on the twelve apostles or attend a drama presented by a touring repertory company.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26-- Pinned down for twenty-five minutes by a diversified attack cleverly directed by George Welsh, Army got off the floor today to overpower favored Navy in their fifty-sixth football meeting, 14 to 6.

IT'S enough to make a Communist out of the most loyal denizen of Sardi's. For it turns out that the biggest angel in show business is not Roger Stevens or Howard Cullman but a man named Nikolai Alexandrovich Mikhailov.

The formation of a syndicate to serve as a check on rapidly increasing acreage prices in the central and eastern areas of Suffolk County was announced yesterday by Leon R. Edelstein, real estate broker in that section.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 26 --President Eisenhower endorsed today a statement by Senator Walter F. George of Georgia calling for a continued "nonpartisan foreign policy regardless of who wins or loses in 1956."
DENVER, Nov. 26--Adlai E. Stevenson's recent statement that this "is a time for moderation" was attacked tonight by Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan.
BANGALORE, India, Nov. 26 --Nikita S. Khrushchev said today Soviet scientists had succeeded in an "unprecedented" nuclear explosion using a "minimum" amount of nuclear material.

WHEN he comes face to face with illness or problems in engineering or law, the average American citizen realizes he lacks the necessary specialized knowledge and turns to the doctor, the engineer or the lawyer. When it comes to education, however, it would appear that every man is his own expert and seldom hesitates to challenge the opinion of the trained educator.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26-- California's organization Democrats are mounting an extensive campaign to overwhelm any Presidential overtures of the man who won the state's Democratic endorsement in 1952, Senator Estes Kefauver.
PARIS, Nov. 26--Considerable strengthening of the French Army in terrorist-ridden Algeria was decided upon today.

Acreage tracts in New Rochelle and Eastchester have been purchased by builders for housing developments in Westchester. In other activity in the county, new models are being shown today in colonies in Armonk and Valhalla.

In the days of woodsmen and Indians, when there was a Harvest Moon and a Hunter's Moon in September and October, November brought the Beaver Moon. One reason was that by November the beaver pelts were prime. Another reason was that by November's time of full moon the beavers, wise in the way of the seasons, were ready for winter.

Atomic power will cost more, perhaps twice as much more, as power produced by an efficient coal-burning central station. One reason is the difficulty of disposing of radioactive wastes--the by-products of fission, which are the equivalent of "ashes."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--Traditionally, the use of very rough words in battles for public power and place has rejoiced and characterized Democrats much more than Republicans in our political history. Gov. Averell Harriman of New York has become the leading party champion of the tradition in these opening stages of the pre-convention contest for the Democratic Presidential and Vice Presidential nominations.

IN Monterey, California, there is a street named Ocean View Avenue but called Cannery Row. A number of years ago it was a colorful street lined with sardine canneries, Chinese hotels and restaurants. It was enlivened with honky-tonks and pleasure domes interspersed with weed-grown vacant lots strewn with timbers and rusted pipes and boilers cast out by the canneries.

VERDI'S "Un Ballo in Maschera," one of last season's successful revivals, received its first performance of the current season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera. The cast contained no newcomers except Giorgio Tozzi, who sang the subordinate role of Samuel.

WITH three companies playing extended seasons simultaneously, these are full days for the dance-goer. Carmen Amaya and her company continue in their nightly (except Monday) programs, with Saturday and Sunday matinees, at the Holiday Theatre; Katherine Dunham and her company do likewise at the Broadway, and at the City Cen ter the New York City now goes into its fourth week of repertory.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 22--The Amazon Queen, a push-type tug that will be the most powerful boat in operation along the Amazon River, now is en route frmo Houston, Tex., to Belem do Para, Brazil. From that city the tug will start its maiden voyage up the Amazon to Iquitos, principal Peruvian river port, and then up the Ucayali River to Pucallpa.

The American Merchant Marine Institute hailed yesterday National Grange endorsement of the Government's maritime subsidy policy and the law that reserves at least 50 per cent of all United States aid shipments for American-flag vessels.

WHEN the first frosts crack the persimmons and Texans turn from the silence of fishing to the camaraderie of hunting, the ancient impulse for story-telling has its season, too. Along the creek beds and the rivers, eyes smoking from wood fires, men rediscover they are haunted with a need for minstrelsy, for the tale rather than the short story.

Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack strolled over the Ramble yesterday morning to see the grounds of his proposed compromise in the dispute over those twentytwo acres of Central Park. Bird watchers want the Ramble untouched; Park Commissioner Robert Moses and elderly pensioners want the city to build a recreation building for the aged there.
TOKYO, Nov. 26--The Central Council of Japanese Labor Unions reiterated today its demand that Honest John rockets be taken out of the country.

IN the rapidly growing volume of material on oriental art available for both the scholar and the more casual reader both of these books are distinct contributions. They succeed in being both scholarly and interesting for the lay reader.
EXECUTIVES of the American Stamp Dealers Association said last week that the seventh annual National Postage Stamp Show sponsored by them on Nov. 18-20 was the most successful one yet held.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 26--A new highway traffic safety center is being established at Michigan State University.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- Pope Pius XII has ordered the Sacred Congregation of Rites to publish a decree whereby the liturgical rites commemorating the crucifixion, burial and resurrection of Jesus Christ are restored to what they were originally.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The peculiar position of the Vice President has long been an important weakness in the American form of government. President Eisenhower's continued recovery will present him and the Republican party with a fine opportunity to remedy that weakness.
The controversy over methods of developing moral and spiritual values in the public schools reverberated yesterday at a meeting of the National Council for the Social Studies.
Baseball is about to move into the spotlight once again. The annual major and minor league conclaves are just around the corner.

THE defection of Vladimir Petrov, chief of Soviet espionage in Australia, and his wife proceeded in two stages. Vladimir broke his Soviet ties on April 4, 1954, his wife, Dusya, (Evdokiya) remaining in the Soviet Embassy at Canberra under close observation.

MONTREAL--It takes no great amount of looking by a repatriated citizen to note the changes wrought in this city's night life. A saunter down the midtown sector of St. Catherine and Peel Streets reveals the same facades of neon-lighted bars and bistros, theatres and restaurants that have been in evidence for many years.
American athletes are confident they can repeat their past Olympic triumphs in the 1956 games in Australia--if they get there.
PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Nov. 9--Within a decade or two, Surinam may become the first "Asian" country in the Western Hemisphere.

The second group of Soviet agricultural experts to visit the United States this year landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday morning en route to Iowa. There they will buy hybrid corn and the machinery necessary to plant and harvest it.

The three-year drain on United States gold stocks apparently is slowly coming to an end. The United States' holdings are now down to the lowest levels since 1946. So far this year, the gold loss has been the smallest in three years, and has been less than 3 per cent of the amount sent abroad in 1953.

Dr. R.E. Carroll, a dairy veterinarian of Buena Park, Calif., reports in the Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association that small magnets can cure cattle of internal troubles caused by Swallowing iron objects. By prescribing magnets for internal use in cattle, Dr. Carroll has been able to reduce the number of operations to remove harmful metal objects in their stomachs.

The twenty-five-year-old 142-foot ketch Atlantis has entered the Pacific Ocean for the first time. She belongs to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, Mass. It will be the task of the scientists on board to study ocean currents, marine life, the geology of the ocean bottom and the chemistry of Pacific water.
THE almost minute-by-minute recapitulation of the career of the late Glenn Miller as a band leader, which is being doled out in flossy annual packages by Victor, has now reached the war years.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26--The University of Southern California, an in-and-out team with four losses this season, upset Notre Dame, 42-20, before 94.892 amazed football fans in Memorial Coliseum today.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26 (AP)--Les Dodson, 18-year-old Kalamazoo, Mich., College student, today reached the final of the national junior indoor tennis tournament with his second major upset in two days.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 26--Consumption of Lake Superior iron ore soared to 7,850,438 tons in October as the nation's steel mills continued to accelerate production.

A dozen or more witnesses will be heard this week at the first public hearings of the Joint Legislative Committee studying illegal interception of communications. Included will be private investigators, victims of wiretapping and telephone company employes.

A strong wave of residential building activity in Manhattan during the next five years is predicted by Joel W. Schenker, president of Urban Housing Associates. He estimates that more than 90 per cent of the new apartments will be on the East Side.

MONTREAL, Nov. 26 (UP)-- Jean Beliveau, who makes a habit of scoring against Goalie Terry Sawchuk, tallied twice to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-1 victory over the Boston Bruins before 13,418 fans tonight.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26 -- Soviet children are the latest beneficiaries of the thaw in East-West relations. Henceforth their reading will be enriched by the literary and technical achievements of United States, British, French and other foreign children's publishing houses.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 26 -- A Christmas program in world understanding is being planned for about 100 foreign students studying in United States colleges and universities.
Thirty teen-age magicians have just received a gift of $650 to buy glasses with false bottoms, white rabbits, trick hats and other props of the craft.

When an organization observes a centennial or other significant landmark in its history, the usual pattern is to focus the observance on its specific accomplishments. Generally, there is a review of its history, a "pointing with pride" to past, and an expression of confidence in "continued progress" in the future.

SARASOTA, Fla., Nov. 26-- The outdoor statues at the Ringling Art Museum here are doomed to crumble unless something is done soon, according to Rutherford J. Gettens of the Smithsonian Institute. Mr. Gettens was here recently at the request of state and museum officials to inspect the stone and bronze pieces.
WARSAW, Nov. 26--A substantial number of Poles are supported from abroad, particularly the United States, through methods that other Communist-led countries do not countenance.

After twenty-seven days of operation, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy pronounced his special traffic emergency task force a success yesterday. He said it had taken action in 3,952 trafficlaw violations.

Leaders in the nation's real estate field and industrialists will join with former Governor Alfred E. Driscoll and State Banking Commissioner Charles R. Howell in addressing delegates to the thirty-ninth annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards.

THE theme for activities in Manhattan this week is "Christmas Decorations." First on the roster is the annual open forum of The Garden Club of America which is to be held Wednesday morning in the auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

SHAKESPEARE was wrong, says historical novelist David Taylor: sometimes the evil that men do is interred with their bones, while the good lingers on to make heroes out of heels and hoodwink highschool history classes.

HIGH up on one of the huge bare rock walls of the vast collection of temples at Ellora in India, a discerning traveler can see an apsara floating out of reach. She is very lightly carved, and very beautiful.

HOLLYWOOD. WHAT'S the matter with Hollywood?" The man who ran with the question was Jerry Wald, Columbia's executive producer. "We're devoting too much effort toward finding nothing more stimulating or inspiring than a 'surething,' "he began.

THIS account of a ten-week tour of the Soviet Union by Marguerite Higgins of The New York Herald Tribune starts off on a breath-taking note. Just before she crossed the border she wrote a letter denying in advance any injurious utterances against the United States that might be attributed to her "as a result of duress or torture."

THEODOR HEUSS, President of the German Federal Republic, was born in 1884 in the small town of Heilbronn in southwestern Germany. The region around Heilbronn, full of quaint old little towns in the valley of the Neckar River, was in 1849 the scene of the last armed resistance of German liberalism, a resistance speedily crushed by the Prussian Army.
ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 26 (UP)--L. Judson Morhouse assailed three top Democratic Presidential contenders tonight for their "campaign of sound and fury" against the Eisenhower Administration.
BANGALORE, India, Nov. 26 --By this time a couple of million Indians in half a dozen cities have seen and cheered a goateed Russian and the stocky little man who never leaves his elbow.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26-- An old-fashioned red brick building at St. John's College has been transformed into the bustling International Labor Orientation Center.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 22--Only one man has publicly announced his candidacy for the Presidency of Peru, although elections are just a little more than six months away. He is Senor Manuel Prado, wartime President from 1939 to 1945.

MAPLES, to most gardeners, mean large, heavily foliaged shade trees, lovely to look at and many of them gorgeous in fall coloring, but unsuited to the small or medium-sized garden because of their size and density of shade.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 23-- Seventy-nine years ago, as a boy of 15, Britain G. Roth began his newspaper career at The Allentown Chronicle. Today, as on every weekday except Thursday, he was at his desk in the news room of The Evening Chronicle writing his editorial page column.

TO THE EDITOR: The main argument of the book is that knowledge is advanced and social progress is made only by those who are willing to experiment with new ideas, to think freely, and to stimulate others to imaginative thought and action.
Albert A. Dodds Jr. has been elected vice president in charge of manufacturing of the Manhattan Shirt Company.
BANGALORE, India, Nov. 26 --The Soviet leaders have marred the triumph of their welcome to India by what has turned out to be two important political blunders.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26-- The Democratic Congressional leadership has now put down liberalization of the McCarranWalter Immigration Act as a part of its basic program for the session opening on Jan. 3.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 26 --One hundred thousand citizens roamed Karachi's streets from dawn to dusk today, screaming for a Jihad (Holy War) against India.
DETROIT, Nov. 26--Michigan Republican leaders are trying to heal a rift within their ranks that might jeopardize the party's effectiveness in next year's campaign.

Men in high office bluntly charged last week that the nation's public schools had failed to maintain educational standards and had neglected gifted students, causing the nation to be faced with a dangerous shortage of scientists, engineer and other technically trained men and women.

THIS small, well-designed book of text by the poet Langston Hughes and pictures by the photographer Roy DeCarava is a delicate and lovely fiction-document of life in Harlem, told, with astonishing verisimilitude, in the words of an elderly Negro woman, a grandmother ten times over, and seen, with a corresponding truth, through her bright old eyes.
PAXTON, Ill., Nov. 26--Stephen A. Mitchell, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said here today he was a candidate for Governor of Illinois in 1956.

JOE ROSENFIELD JR., who took the Alcoholics Anonymous cure successfully, as a result considers himself "the happiest man in the world." To help others reform, he has written his autobiography. For most of the book he is quite unhappy, living the life of a Southern cad.

Opportunities for the musical education of children in one of the city's most congested areas will be furthered by the Dec. 6 performances of "Janus" at the Plymouth Theatre. The entire orchestra section of the theatre has been taken over by the Third Street Music School Settlement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--A large and costly package of programs designed to end the "depressed state of American agriculture" was proposed today by a study group.

THE publication of Thomas H. Johnson's interpretative biography of Emily Dickinson so soon after the appearance of his three-volume variorum edition of her poems is something of a literary wonder. With the late George Frisbie Whicher's life and Millicent Todd Bingham's recent "Emily Dickinson's Home," it rounds out the history of Emily Dickinson and her work.

TORRINGTON, Conn.-- Among the solicitous inquiries which poured into this place after the disastrous flood produced by Hurricane Diane on Aug. 19 was one from an 8-year-old boy. He wanted to know what had happened to Santa Claus.

Miss Sarah Keys, whose complaint of segregation against a North Carolina bus line was upheld by the Interstate Commerce Commission Friday, expressed happiness yesterday at the outcome. She added, however, that "it is a big relief to have it behind me."
About $869,868,624 of savings were lost in investments in the thirty-seven railroad lines of European Russia that are shown on the map and tabulation on the first page of this section.

THERE have been many suggestions for improving New York City's mail service, but the latest, that subways be used to speed up deliveries, should cheer even the habitual grousers. Actually, deliveries in the business district have risen to some three a day, with a transit time of fifteen hours at most for local letters.

ONE always has hesitated to use the word "definitive," which has an awesome finality about it, a closing-of-the-doors effect. But if the new Victor three-disk album, of the four Rachmaninoff Piano Concertos and Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini is not definitive, then the word has no meaning.

A STUDY of birds in nineteenthcentury America-- an ambitious and much-needed project--has been undertaken by Robert Henry Welker, an authority on the subject. He is here concerned not only with isolated bird studies but also with the men who made them and their impact on their times.

AS passionate believers in their way of life, Americans have always been gratified when "backward" people adopted their institutions. But if the converts were American Indians, they fared as badly as those who rejected the white man and all his ways.

SAN SALVADOR, Nov 21--El Salvador, disturbed by continuing ship delays in its three Pacific ports, has determined to go ahead with its plans for the construction of a national port at Acajutla, in the western end of the country.
George Martin Weiss will be directing the destinies of the Yankees for at least another six years.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 26--Utah's delegation to the White House Conference on Education has been, accused of ignoring public sentiment on school issues.
A collection of Chinese semiprecious stone jewelry and other art objects will be auctioned on Wednesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, near Twenty-sixth Street.
PROSPECTS for the sportsman who wants a combined hunting and fishing trip in the South are bright. Even the Bahamas offer interesting possibilities.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 26 (UP)--Millard Howell Tubbs, who was named after Alabama's greatest passer, threw for two touchdowns against Dixie Howell's old school today to pace a 26-0 victory that made Auburn sure of a third straight bid to the Gator Bowl.

A HAMMER is the handiest tool in the handyman's collection and it is usually the first one he buys. Although to the average person, "hammers are hammers," there are over three dozen in different types and sizes in common use.

THE last time I saw Benny De Voto was in Glacier Park in the summer of '53. He was on one of those long Western forays he repeatedly made. They contributed fruitfully to his work in Western history and his pugnacious polemics in Harper's magazine, some of which have just been collected under the title, "The Easy Chair."

LONDON, Nov. 26--In Cyprus, the last remaining British-ruled bastion in the Middle East, terrorism reached a new pitch this week. Today the British Governor and commander in chief, Field Marshall Sir John Harding, declared a state of emergency in an effort to pacify the island outpost.

TO THE EDITOR: Mr. Maclver's book, Mr. Hook says, is a "full-throated polemic," written in a tone of angry partisanship, quite incompatible with judicious inquiry and, in some of its assertions, a "gratuitous libel" on the professors, administrators and trustees of American universities.

SINCE Dimitri Mitropoulos' appointment as musical director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in 1951-1952, he has been assisted by the same triumvirate of guest conductors -- Bruno Walter, George Szell and Guido Cantelli.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 26 --The Boulder Brook Club fall horse show opened for the thirtyfirst time today in the familiar setting of the big indoor arena and the adjacent outside ring.

BAGHDAD, Nov. 24--The Premiers of Turkey, Iraq, Iran and Pakistan, and the British Foreign Secretary met here in the Kasr al Zahour (Palace of Flowers) this week and drew a line across the Middle East's northern tier against a southward march of Russian Communist influence.

WHAT the Victorians ate, wore, slept or rode in, laughed at, wept over, hung on their walls, balanced on their piano racks and advised their young not to do is the concern of James Laver in this combination anthology, picture book and running commentary designed to heighten by a couple of cubits the wave of interest in all things Victorian which, according to the editor, is about to break upon us.

The New York Giants, victors in their last two games, will engage the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds today in the locals' last home game of the National Football League season. The starting time is 2:05 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The basic challenge confronting the United States in the Middle East, and generally in Asia, is who will hold the torch that lights the way of ancient peoples into the twentieth and the twenty-first centuries.

THE Polar Eskimos of the Thule area in northwest Greenland lived in the Stone Age until less than a century ago. Having no contact with the busy outside world, their culture was based entirely upon local resources -- on hunting seals, walrus, caribou and polar bears, and raiding the flocks of auks which crowded the birdcliffs near Cape York.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 26--This residential community of 34,000 persons has just completed one election, but its special referendum to be held next Thursday has stirred up even more interest.

PERHAPS no man knows better from grim, personal experience how Communists negotiate than does Admiral Joy. For ten months and twelve days, he faced the Chinese and North Korean delegation in the long fight to hammer out a reasonable armistice in the Korean War.
HARTFORD, Nov. 26 -- A controversy has arisen in Connecticut over whether the new primary law, which becomes effective Jan. 1, will increase or decrease the power of political "bosses" in the state.

THE sunny, milky colors of Stephen Greene's new paintings at the Borgenicht Gallery create an impression of lightness that is really at variance with their somber character. As in the past he draws on Biblical subjects, not so much to illustrate them but to search out just those sorrowful or tragic episodes which are in keeping with the emotional intensity of his art.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26-- Speedy approval of a call for a Constitutional convention in Virginia is expected at the special Legislative session that opens Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26-- Seldom in the sixty-five years Army and Navy have been meeting in football have spectators at the service classic had it so good as they did today. The sun was shining brightly, the breeze was gentle and to the warmly-wrapped crowd, the 40degree temperature was just right.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Nov. 26 (UP)--The Edmonton Eskimos defeated the Montreal Alouettes, 34--19, before a record 39,417 fans at Empire Stadium today to retain the Grey Cup and Canada's professional football championship.

LONDON, Nov. 26 (Reuters) --Today's results in British soccer and rugby: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Arsenal 0, Burnley 1. Aston Villa 0. Tottenham Hotspur 2. Blackpool 0, Manchester United 0 (draw).

ATLANTA, Nov. 26--Georgia Tech gained its fifth straight bowl bid by romping to an impressive 21-3 victory over Georgia today before 40,000 fans. As a result the Engineers were selected to meet Pittsburgh in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans on Jan. 2.

STARKVILLE, Miss., Nov. 26 -- Eagle Day's quarterbacking try and the brilliant running of a halfback, Earl Blair, gave Mississippi a 26-0 victory over Mississippi State today and a second-straight Southeastern Conference title.

ORCHIDS were popular long before the Christian era. In ancient China they were known as the "queenly flower." As recently as 100 years ago or less, orchid growing was the traditional "hobby of the rich," but today they are grown on city apartment window sills, in tiny greenhouses and, in fact, in any sunny spot in homes all over the country.

TO THE EDITOR: Harry Schwartz, in his article "The Iron Curtain--From the Other Side" (Nov. 13), states that a dramatically large offer should be made to invite young Soviet people to visit the United States.

Judicial history was written in the United States last week. Judge Luther W. Youngdahl, in the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, ruled, in effect that the Department of State could not deny a passport to an American citizen without submitting the basis of its denial to judicial inspection.

CAPE NORTH, N.S., Nov. 26 (Canadian Press)--A Canadian Navy helicopted, flying perilously close to a giant cliff, maneuvered down to the deck of the wrecked Liberian freighter Kismet II today and lifted her twenty-one crew members to safety.

Complaints against racial discrimination on public conveyances have been coming before the Interstate Commerce Commission ever since it was set up in 1887 with broad authority over all interstate transportation. The I.C.C., following Supreme Court doctrine established in Plessy v. Ferguson in 1896, has consistently ruled that as long as "separate but equal" facilities were maintained, it would not intervene.

EVERGREEN shrubs and trees are always worthwhile and are useful almost anywhere around the home grounds. But their value is never greater than in the winter, when their characteristic color enlivens the scene.

SHE was mother ship to a 5 pocket battleship and hell ship to 300 British merchant seamen. Big and powerful, with her 11,000 tons gross tonnage and twenty-one-knot flank speed, she lay, when fully loaded, sound and deep in the sea.

PARIS. EVER since that Sunday morning in August when 900,000 Parisians watched Burt Lancaster, Gina Lollobrigida. Tony Curtis and Katy Jurado parade down the Grand Boulevard and up the ChampsElysees on horsedrawn floats, Paris has followed the progress of the Hecht-Lancaster production of "Trapeze" with considerable interest.

THERE'S something sure-fire about an anthology of humor; even on the least promising scale of averages some of the offerings are bound to be pretty funny. Such a book is a fairly safe gift--for Christmas, as a thank-you-for-a-pleasantweek-end, or a more durable present to the bed-ridden than a stack of gladioli or a jar of grape jelly.

THE five players who won the American team championship of 1955, and in January will go to Paris to play France's European champions for the world title, have invited Charles Goren to be their sixth member.
VALDAGNO, Italy, Nov. 25-- A combination of American machinery and Italian capital is trying to change the outward appearance of the Italian men.

DESPITE Hollywood's official taboo on the depiction of illegal drug traffic or drug addiction, the moviemakers are showing signs of being willing to reconsider, if not actually tackle, this ticklish subject.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 26--Terrorists, said to be members of the Irish Republican Army, struck again at Northern Ireland today but were forced to flee across the border to their hide-out in the Irish Republic.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System has made some definite decisions about extensive changes in its Sunday afternoon television lineup beginning Jan. 8. Among the major changes are a half-hour news program to be conducted by Eric Sevareid and the introduction of a one-hour drama series.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 26 -- The United Nations Command renewed today its efforts to obtain from the Communists an accounting of missing United Nations prisoners. But the Communists promptly denied that they were retaining any and countercharged that it was the Allied side that was retaining their prisoners of war.

To Have or Not to Have To have or not to have an early election is a question that France is concerned with today. In fact elections have been a concern in France for some time now, and they help to illustrate the volatility and complexity of the French people.

Exporters of British tweeds, flannels and worsteds, which make up into handsome suits, sport jackets, skirts and coats, had something of a problem. They wanted to sell their goods in this country. But the word "imported" on the label was not enough, they knew, because it could mean inferior goods as well as those of quality.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) --Navy's football squad was told today between the halves it would go to the Cotton Bowl if it beat Army.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Florida's twenty state parks and nineteen historic memorials have become tourist attractions of unusual pulling power. In the fiscal year ended last June 30, the number of visitors to them was estimated at 2,137,635.
Something has been added to the New York Giants' spring exhibition schedule, which was announced yesterday by Secretary Eddie Brannick.

In the ancient city of Baghdad last week an effort was made to forge the newest link in the Western defense chain. Great Britain and four of Russia's southern neighbors--Iraq, Iran, Turkey, Pakistan --established a permanent Middle East Treaty Organization to be connected with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Southeast Asian Treaty Organization.

EACH year the fates at about 20,000 children are decided by persons who give them or sell them to couples they know only casually, if at all. The prevalence of such irresponsible gray and black-market placements, in view of the effect that illchosen homes can have on the children involved, has become a problem so serious that it is being examined by a Senate subcommittee.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Nov. 19 were 6 per cent higher than sales in the comparable week last year. It was the thirtieth consecutive weekly gain in volume reported by the Federal Reserve Board.

MIAMI, Nov. 26 -- Miami's Hurricanes, hard-pressed by a Florida team fighting desperately to salvage some glory out of a dismal football season, whipped the 'Gators by 7--6 today in a bruising game that was in doubt up to the final gun.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 26-- The teams of Charles Sullivan and Tom Byrne, New York Athletic Club, and H.R. Reeve and H.A. Geidel of the home club scored double victories to lead the way into the semi-finals of the pro-amateur squash racquets tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.
ABOARD U.S.S. GLACIER, in the Pacific, Nov. 25--For 120 Seabees Antarctica is expected to fulfill their desire to get in a little exploring before the world runs out of explorable areas.

WHEN it comes to science the most impractical of men is the business man who has amassed a fortune and considers it his social and moral duty to endow scientific research. Medicine is especially attractive to him because sickness and physical suffering are always with us.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The largest organization of lawyers in the country wants to be twice as big.
An international convention permitting freer interchange of commercial samples and advertising materials--proposed twenty years ago--has at last been put into effect.
During the last two weeks two Soviet experts on electronics and automation have been guided quietly through a number of industrial installations in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A Senate subcommittee was apparently faced today with the choice of exercising its subpoena powers or abandoning plans to hear grievances of representative General Motors automobile dealers.

Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged the United States yesterday to offer treaties to Israel and the Arab states and to "use the power and the prestige of the American Government to protect the boundaries of every state" in the Middle East.

BELZONI, Miss., Nov. 26 (AP) --A Negro active in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today he was shot by white men who fired from an automobile parked outside his rural grocery last night.

TOKYO, Nov. 16--A young Japanese was being interviewed for a job as driver for an American's car. Among other qualifications the young man listed himself as a graduate of Waseda University, class of 1951. He said he had been acting as a chauffeur since he got his degree.
CHICAGO and Dallas will be linked by a shorter and faster rail route on Dec. 5 when the Santa Fe opens a new track via Denton directly into the metropolis of northern Texas.

A.W. Fleming, Regional Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, has announced that Federal income tax forms for 1956 would reach taxpayers by mail between Dec. 27 and Jan. 10. Each taxpayer who filed in 1955 will receive forms if he is at the same address or has a new one known to the Post Office.

MY first encounter with Thornton Wilder as a man of the theatre was in Glasgow about twentyfive years ago. I was judging a competition between amateur dramatic societies; a Jewish group offered what I recall as a brilliant performance of "The Long Christmas Dinner."

Eleven young women were introduced formally to society at dinner parties given in advance of the annual Grosvenor Debutante Ball last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The fete served also to raise funds for Grosvenor Neighborhood House.
English teachers were urged yesterday to help revive a waning interest in literature as a means of combating prejudice, malice and unreason.
DANZIG, Nov. 25--Poles have taken over this war-wrecked German city and its shipyards, and are creating new life and industry.

THIS remarkable book deals with "the fatal dialectic of civilization." Does the very progress of civilization lead to the release of increasingly destructive forces ? On the whole, this was the conclusion of Freud and of many of his more orthodox followers.
A powerful searchlight is to be turned upon America's vast educational system.

THE hybridizing of flowers is fast becoming a fascination for those who like to grow a special kind. Even camellias, the queen of the southern flower belt, have come under deft hands of amateurs. Koseku Sawada, well-known professional camellia hybridist, advises that "gardeners shouldn't hesitate because of lack of scientific knowledge.

COLD or snowy weather gives everyone a chance to catch up on repairs and odd jobs within the house. Here as well as outdoors there may be new and improved tools, short cuts or a simple professional technique that will make working easier.

EVEN before the Thanksgiving turkey was ordered the first of the season's Santa Clauses had sprouted on local street corners. Now with each day that passes their number grows. From billboards and television screens, from newspapers and comic books, from just about every sort of surface designed to carry timely messages, a jolly St. Nick beams out upon the children.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 25-- The reaffiliation of Saar trade unions with the West German Trade Union Federation in the near future may be on the way.

THE number of tours and cruises across the Pacific Ocean will increase sharply during 1956. According to the Pacific Area Travel Association, 127 major trips already have been scheduled by steamship lines, airlines and travel agencies beginning the first week in January and continuing through December.

Members of the United Nations have now decided to give themselves another two years before they have to decide whether they should try to amend the Charter or leave it as it is. Even forgetting about the veto, there are plenty of things wrong with the Charter, but most countries would rather put up with these faults than run the risk of making things worse.

In 1900, Robert de Forest, New York Tenement House Commissioner, reported: "Tenement conditions [are] indescribable * * *; vile privies and privy sinks, foul cellars * * * occupied as sleeping places, dilapidated and dangerous stairs * * *, buildings without adequate water supply * * *."

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 26 (AP) --Gov. Walter J. Kohler broke sharply today with his Republican party organization by vetoing a bill it sponsored to set up new boundary lines for the two Milwaukee County Congressional districts.
Rear Admiral William N. Thomas, former Chief of Navy Chaplains, declared yesterday that he had never found a "real infidel" among seagoing men.

Whatever else may be said of Russian Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and First Secretary Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Russian Communist party they cannot be called men of mystery. They may be seen these days taking off their shoes in tribute to Mahatma Gandhi.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 26 -- Jim Swink closed out his college football career with one of his greatest games today. He paced Texas Christian to a 20--13 victory over Southern Methodist and the Southwest Conference championship.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 26--A summary of experience in the production and use of polio vaccine in eight countries was publsihed here this week by the World Health Organization's special study group. The group includes twelve of the world's leading polio researchers from nine countries, including the United States.

The Soviet Union announced last week that six former officials had been executed and two sentenced to life imprisonment on charges of having conspired with the late Lavrenti P. Beria to seize control of the country. This brought to nineteen the number of men executed on such charges since late 1953.

THUS the Columbia Encyclopedia, in the brisk manner of lexicographers counting the trees while overlooking a fine south forty stand of forest. For Pottsville, along with everything else including the Molly Maguires, is Gibbsville.

An uneasy peace has settled over the Washington Square neighborhood. The dust of demolition and construction has subsided for the time being, as has the pounding of rivet and hammer. In the lull between projects that are constantly changing the familiar contours of this famed section of New York, Greenwich Villagers are wondering about what's going to be torn down next.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 (AP)--Times Square won the third leg of the $75,000 American Pacing Classic today, throwing the event into a tie between the winner and Hillsota, who finished third. Diamond Hal, finishing fifth today, settled for third money over all.

THE world of the seashore is not just a strip of sand or rock washed by tides and waves. It is a three-dimensional world, extending inland to the edge of dunes and marshes, up into the air as high as sea-feeding birds will fly, and out into and under the sea where the kelp forests and plankton pastures of the continental shelf offer shelter and food to thousands of familiar and unfamiliar submarine creatures.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 26-- President Joao Cafe Filho said today he had never planned a coup.

A back-of-the-scenes disagreement between the United States Coast Guard and New Jersey State officials has reached a stage where yachtsmen and other boat operators face dangerous navigation. The area is along the 120-mile New Jersey stretch of the intracoastal waterway.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 26 --Members of the Investment Bankers Association of America began to arrive here in substantial numbers today for the forty-fourth annual convention of their organization, which will get under way tomorrow at the Hollywood Beach Hotel.

THE motto for this morning is Every Man His Own Producer. There is such a range and variety in the spoken word this season that a man can put a show together quicker than you can say Joshua Logan, and this without corralling angels, hunting for the right house or bearing the slings and arrows of outraged critics.

"NOTHING brings men nearer to the gods than giving health to their fellow creatures," said Cicero, but Rabelais, himself a physician, characterized the healing art as "a farce played by three actors: the physician, the patient and the disease."

DELRAY BEACH, Fla.-- Residents and visitors here just now are at a pitch of excitement over a rumor -- originating no one quite knows where--that President Eisenhower may spend a winter vacation at the Gulf Stream Golf Club near here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--A labor leader disclosed today his one-way correspondence with Republican leaders about some recent unpleasantness.

AMERICAN FOLK SONGS FOR CHILDREN: There Was a Little Tree, The Monkey's Wedding, Froggie Went a-Courting; Shep Ginades with guitar (Elektra, 10-inch). The songs are mostly about animals and they are sung with humor, rhythmic vitality and excellent enunciation.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (UP)--Army rejected a possible invitation to the Cotton Bowl today. After the cadets 14-6 upset of Navy, Coach Earl (Red) Blaik said he "had enough football for one season."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26--During the half-time high jinks in the well-refrigerated Municipal Stadium today the midshipmen were coyly subtle almost to the point of obscurity. They dreamed up a parade of floats designed to indicate the striking progressiveness of the Navy.
TORONTO, Nov. 26 (UP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs shook off an assortment of injuries tonight to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 7--4, before 12,609 National Hockey League fans.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 26-- Oklahoma's undefeated football team, trying to look impressive enough to retain No. 1 ranking without revealing too much of its offense to Maryland scouts, battered Oklahoma A. and M. by 53--0 today.

Work is being speeded on one of the newest luxury-styled apartment buildings on the East Side. The superstructure of the twenty-story building at 50 Sutton Place South has been completed and the brickwork has reached the penthouse level.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 26-- Two hundred civil defense workers from New York City and seven counties converged upon this city today. They came to the aid of 1,000 local volunteers after a simulated atomic bomb attack on the Silver Lake Reservoir area, just north of White Plains.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26 (Reuters) --Following is the text of the Soviet statement today announcing the carrying out of hydrogen bomb tests: Recently, in connection with the plan for scientific research and experimental work in the field of atomic energy, tests of new types of atomic and thermonuclear [hydrogen] weapons have been carried out in the Soviet Union.

NO other artist has left so important a visual record of American history as Gilbert Stuart, who was born in a Rhode Island snuff mill on Dec. 3, 1755, just 200 years ago. Acquiring transcendent skill in his narrow specialty of "face painting," he had the opportunity to depict all the leaders, male and female, in the creation of the United States.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., Nov. 26 (UP)--Colorado A. and M., the Skyline champion, upset the University of Colorado, 10--0, today. Halfback Gary Click of the Aggies finished a brilliant college career by scoring all his team's points.

The Very Rev. John A. Flynn, president of St. John's University, called yesterday for approval of state legislation that would increase the number of Regents Scholarships by 650 annually for fourteen years. This would restore the original 5 per cent ratio of scholarships to graduates, established in 1913 when the program began.
BERLIN, Nov. 26--East Germany has elevated its state security service to the level of a ministry in a reorganization designed to strengthen the Central Government's operations.

Twenty-seven newspaper men with five to fifty years of journalistic experience will attend the American Press Institute's seminar for city editors, which opens tomorrow. The two-week sessions will be held in the institute's conference room at Columbia University.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 26--Every customer among the 20,275 at the Pimlico track today was able to follow the progress of the winner of the Pimlico Special every step of the way. The collector of first money of $40,000 was Brookmeade Stable's 11-to-1 Sailor, and he was in front from shortly after the start.
TULSA, Okla., Nov. 26 (AP)-- The Glenn Pool, an oilfield whose opening started an Indian Territory town's rise to a Southwest metropolis, was fifty years old this week.

THIS is a charming fable by Rumer Godden dealing with the triumph of the sensitive and the disregarded over the insensitive who command the established order of things. Like all Cinderella stories, it affords us the pleasure of seeing the haughty get their come-uppance and the meek inherit at least a bit of the earth.
The New York Public Lirary's multimillion-item picture collection in the Central Building on Fifth Avenue will be open every Thursday until 10 P.M. beginning this week.

This year's Salk polio vaccine program was decried yesterday as "a tragic demonstration of confusion and misunderstanding which should never have happened and should never be allowed to happen again."

LONDON, Nov. 26--There was quite a commotion in Downing Street last Tuesday. Nowadays, with the Government under the cautious leadership of Sir Anthony Eden, the street is little visited by sight-seers. Tuesday was different.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26-- The battle between champions of public power and of private power has taken a new turn.

AS all architects are well aware, keeping up with Frank Wright is a back-breaking assignment. Now in his sixty-second year of practice, Wright continues to astound the profession by his dogged refusal to offer anything resembling conventional answers to the problems of his clients.

The first two-way transaction involving a "trade-in" of an older house for the purchase of a new dwelling at Country Club Estates in Oradell, N.J., has been completed. Details of the transaction were reported by George H. Beckmann, Inc., agent for the housing development, who acted as broker in the deal.

Demolition of three houses in the Greenwich Village section, believed to have been built by John Jacob Astor in 1820, has become imminent to prepare for the construction of a new apartment building at 50 King Street.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 26 --Tennessee rang out midnight for Vanderbilt's "Cinderella" team today with two last-quarter touchdowns that blasted the Commodores' Sugar Bowl dream by a 20-14 score.

Additional committees have been appointed to work for the success of the Gala Buffet Dansant, which will be held at the Ambassador on Dec. 13 for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery. Miss Louise Marock is chairman for the event.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The Atomic Energy Commission has asked the Budget Bureau to approve an expenditure of $8,500,000 for training nuclear engineers.
The successes that an imported Pekingese, Ch. Chungking Tino, has had in dog shows within New York City limits continued yesterday.
GENEVA, Nov. 16--The oldest and largest experiment in giving children a truly international education has been so successful here in Geneva that it is tending to burst at the seams.
BOSTON, Nov. 26--Boston, an ancient city by New World standards, will salute the Eternal City, Rome, in week-long observances beginning Monday.
BOSTON, Nov. 26--"Wait for the opposition to make the mistakes."

Figgers THE other day Doubleday handed out a statistic that was quite roseate. The publishing house announced that with the 125,000-copy first printing of Evangelist Billy Graham's "The Secret of Happiness," the book became the fifth Doubleday title this year to have 100,000 copies printed before publication.
THELMA RITTER, who will be appearing on television this week in "The Late Christopher Bean," said the other day that she was particularly pleased by one aspect of the production.

OCCASIONALLY a contributor to group shows in this country, Edouard Boubat, French photographer, was presented last week at Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, in his first one-man exhibition in the United States.

A greater effort to induce students to enter the teaching profession was urged recently by Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, president of Teachers College, Columbia University. He proposed three courses which, if undertaken now, hold promise of increasing the supply of good teachers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26--The Soviet Union charged today that its frontiers were endangered by Iran's membership in the Baghdad Pact. It said Iran had violated her treaty obligations to the Soviet Union and "contradicted good neighborly relations" between the two countries by allying herself with Turkey, Iraq, Pakistan and Britain.

Plans have been completed for the Sibelius ninetieth birthday concert to be held next Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The occasion also will honor the memory of Olin Downes, late music critic of The New York Times, who played an important part in wining recognition for Sibelius' music in the United States.

TO THE EDITOR: David L. Cohn's fine article, "White Shadow Over Dixie: Too Much Cotton" (Nov. 13), in which he discussed the cotton problem in the American South, contains a small but commonplace error.

ONE of the most encouraging phenomena of the day, as far as the ballet is concerned, is the growing tendency toward its establishment as a creative entity in our opera houses, where it belongs logically and historically.

OVERSEAS air travelers who want the greater comfort and prestige of first-class accommodations will pay a higher premium next year for the wider seats, extra knee room, "free" drinks and red velvet treatment.
IN London last spring Jean Anouilh's "The Lark" seemed pale and trifling. In New York, it is sublime.

FREDERICK C. SCHANG of Columbia Artists Management, in charge of the United States tour of the Soviet violinist David Oistrakh, had dropped a hint for the press to do its business promptly and clear out.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The best information available in Washington today indicated that the Soviet had tested a hydrogen bomb substantially more powerful than 1,000,000 tons of TNT.
HOUSTON, Nov. 26 (UP)-- Baylor passed for 84 yards and added a 54-yard punt return and a field goal today to defeat Rice Institute, 15--7, before 33,000 spectators.

A blacksmith's son this month saw his "brain child" achieve a listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Along the way, he himself has climbed from earning $10 a night as a jazz musician to $171,000 a year as president of his company.
The bituminous coal industry is digging itself out of a financial hole.

IN the small garden the dwarf rhododendrons really excel. They can be planted and will look equally well as shapely small specimens or as dense clumps many square yards in extent. The versatility of the dwarf rhododendrons is remarkable.

MAKING Christmas presents now in the quiet of the family kitchen will ease the holiday rush next month. The cook chooses delicacies that may be frozen or stored at room temperature till time to give them away.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Nov. 26 (UP)--Clemson's backfield, led by 195-pound Joel Wells, outscored Furman's surprise offense, 40--20, today before 10,000 fans in the season finale for both teams.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 26 --Sol Rotenberg's Hickory Hill, second to Wise Margin in last Peek's Narragansett Special, today won the featured seventh race, a $3,500 allowance of six furlongs at Narragansett Park.

TWENTY years ago, toward the end of his second novel, "Butterfield 8," John O"Hara made two generalizations, the first about life, the second about writing. "There comes one time in a man's life," he declared, "if he is unlucky and leads a full life, when he has a secret so dirty that he knows he never will get rid of it."

Felt, one of the oldest textiles known to man, has also become one of the most versatile. Although a good portion goes into hats, millions of pounds a year end up in other consumer and industrial products.

HOLLYWOOD. THE special events department of the Columbia Broadcasting System television network is turning once again to stage literature in its search for material. Negotiations are currently under way with John Hersey and Paul Osborn with a view to acquiring television rights to "A Bell for Adano."

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 26 (AP)--The White House here said today that President Eisenhower had reveiced no request from the Governor of South Carolina for an explanation of the Justice Department's refusal to issue a fugitive warrant for a Negro minister wanted in the state.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 26--Tulane rode the passing and running of Quarterback Gene Newton for two touchdowns in the first half today, then held on doggedly to tie favored Louisiana State University, 13 to 13, before 55,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The issues in the forthcoming campaign will be pretty much what the Democrats choose to make them. The Republicans, being the party in power, naturally rest upon their record and upon the popularity of their leader-- a device they may have to employ indirectly if President Eisenhower is not a candidate to succeed himself.

A business survey conducted by the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry among 515 Chicago area concerns confirmed the high level of business activity during the third quarter and predicted a continuation of the pace in the fourth quarter and first quarter next year.

VIENNA. TWO weeks after "Fidelio" formally had opened the new house, it appeared that the directors of the Vienna Opera would not indulge in many experimental techniques. The performances were distinguished by excellent acting, fine singing and first-rate orchestra playing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your excellent advice in your editorial of Nov. 11 should encourage many more families to invite to their homes the foreign students at near-by schools.

ATHENS, Nov. 25--The Government of Premier Constantin Karamanlis is considering holding the next general election possibly in January. It was thought the elections had been planned for April.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) --The Navy plans to step up production of guided missile ships next year. These probably will include an atomic-powered submarine able to fire bombardment missiles.

LOWERING fuel bills by as much as 30 per cent may sound like wishful thinking to many home owners struggling with the household budget, but it can be done-- with insulation. There are many materials on the market today which the home owner can install during a week-end.

Beginning next Thursday, the aged, the infirm and the underprivileged children in ninety-five hospitals and institutions will be treated to Christmas and Hanukkah programs of entertainment. The programs, which will reach into institutions of all faiths, will continue through Dec. 31.

There is no evidence that any downturn in the present high level of business activity will occur during the remainder of the year. That is the finding of the latest monthly survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

An exhibition of fifty paintings on Christmas themes, executed by American and foreign artists for the Hallmark Art Award competition, will be on view at an invitation benefit preview at the Wildenstein Gallery on the night of Dec. 20.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (AP) --It's Georgia Tech and Pittsburgh in the Sugar Bowl for 1956, the Sugar Bowl president, Bernie Grenrood, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--A pilot study of a group receiving unemployment insurance showed that they had spent substantially more for food, shelter and other items in the family budget than they drew in benefits.
Recent Soviet offers of economic aid to India, Egypt and other under-developed non-Communist countries can have a bearing on relations between Moscow and Peiping.

THE game of taking pictures under poor lighting conditions, then struggling in the darkroom to achieve a semblance of a printable image, is currently the favorite pastime of amateur and professional alike.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Nov. 21 --A bush pilot turned airlines executive, F. Russell Baker, has completed a merger to make his concern, Pacific Western Airines, Canada's "biggest" in numbers of aircraft and third in miles of scheduled routes flown.

CANADA is flexing its muscles. Its cities and industries are growing. There is new wealth in the land, and with it has come an increased desire to enrich life. One senses from afar that people are no longer content, in the field of the arts, with modest symphony orchestras, provincial opera companies, routine schools.
The largest graveyard in the world is a financial graveyard.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 25--Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, former President of Guatemala, who has been living here since Sept. 2, intends to make his home in Prague for at indefinite period.
Dressy sportswear types for holiday selling got the biggest play in the women's apparel market in the last week, resident buying offices reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20--Empty seats and empty plays art driving tha Soviet theatre to look for new ideas. The dramatic output of the capitalist world is being closely scrutinized and some pre-revolutionary Russian theatrical techniques are being revived.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Nov. 18 you published side by side two noteworthy items: Thomas E. Murray's address to the Fordham Law School proposing a demonstration of the thermonuclear bomb before the rulers of the world and Hanson W. Baldwin's discussion of the Chemical War Report.

There are 345 days to go before the '56 Presidential election; 239 days before the first national convention (the Democratic), 107 days before the first Presidential primary (in New Hampshire), and 37 days before the Eighty-fourth Congress convenes for its pre-campaign session.

AMONG authorities on world affairs there is increasing concern over the steady weakening of our international position. The new Soviet tactics can be successfully met, they say, only by a fundamental switch in some of our present policies. On the other hand, the political experts are equally certain that such a switch in an election year is impossible.

This has turned out to be a year for the blue chips. At the end of 1954 the fifty top corporations listed accounted for a bit less than 52 per cent of the market value of all common stocks on the New York Stock Exchange.

THE accident toll attributed to driver drowsiness is higher in the winter than in the summer. One of the main reasons for this is that car windows generally are kept closed on cold days and the warmth inside combined with lack of fresh air helps to dull the senses of the man behind the wheel and makes him more susceptible to fatigue on long trips.

THIS general survey of exploration opens with Hanno Carthaginian venturing beyond the Pillars of Hercules about 530 B.C., and concludes with speculations on highly contemporary journeys through interplanetary space.
