TWO recent articles on this page by M. A. Lacoste, a critic on the Paris review Le Monde, dealt with the problems, hardships and financial insecurity of the French artist and the difficulties in the way of obtaining recognition.
ORIENT POINT, L.I., Nov. 26--Half a mile off the tip of Long Beach Point in Gardiners Bay, a boxlike room with a fourway view is up for sale.

Stock market operations last week were influenced by stock split-ups, tighter money rates and the suspension of trading for the Thanksgiving Day holiday. The price trends were often diverse, depending on the day's developments.
ATLANTA, Nov. 26--The Interstate Commerce Commission order to end racial segregation in interstate travel faced opposition today from officials of at least six Southern states.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 22--The Dutch, who had no illusions about the Soviet new look in the first place, have put down the failure at Geneva as a valuable lesson to the world in basic Soviet policy.

Air France announced yesterday that it had ordered twelve jet airliners. The plane is the 470-mile-an-hour French twinjet Caravelle. It is designed for flights of 250 to 1,000 miles and can carry seventy passengers.

CHIVES, tarragon and mint are three favorite flavouring herbs that respond well when taken from the garden and forced into fresh growth on a sunny window sill during the winter. The chief prerequisite is a period of rest, or dormancy, brought about by freezing.

The Government of Israel sees no ground for compromise in the Eden proposals for a settlement in Palestine. This was made clear on Friday in an interview given by Premier Ben-Gurion to this newspaper's reporter, Harry Gilroy.
Seventh-Day Adventists now number more than one million, the general conference of that denomination has announced.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Farmers would receive up to $5,000 a year for diverting surplus producing land to grass, forage and trees under a new subsidy plan drafted by Agriculture Department experts.

A people that has no Interest in its own history or in the historical and architectural monuments of its past can hardly consider itself fully mature as a nation. The growing concern with these matters in the United States is an important indication of our own cultural development; but the problem of preserving the tangible reminders of this heritage, in brick and wood and stone, is not an easy one.

HANDSOME and eye-filling is the exhibition of LatinAmerican architecture which just opened--with appropriate Good Neighbor pomp --at the Museum of Modern Art. Under a luminous ceiling in the white gallery, the installation, designed by Arthur Drexler, is a three-part fugue of eight-foot-high blow-ups, photographs set flush in dramatic brown walls of insulating cork (like some rich Mexican organic decorative material) and groups of stereopticon views.

TOKYO--Japan is rapidly assuming a new role as a tourist objective for nonJapanese. Within their own country the Japanese are the most indefatigable tourist on earth. Flocks of school children in uniform, mixed groups of Youth Hostelers, and busloads of adult sight-seers are everywhere, photographing each other in front of every national cultural treasure.
Quite the most crowded week of the art season thus far brings in with it, beginning tomorrow, an unusual number of outstanding events in museums and galleries.
The steamship charter market held its gains last week and, in some cases, advanced fractionally.

Moving irregularly, cotton prices closed last week with moderate net gains, according to the New York Cotton Exchange. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts were up 4 to 32 points for the week. In the preceding week, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange had been up 32 to 156 points.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks toppled the Boston Bruins to their fourth straight setback tonight as they gained a 6 -- 0 National Hockey League victory before a Garden crowd of 8,021.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- A controversy over the Administration's buy-American policy met a quiet bureaucratic end here last week.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 -- An ability to hit high C or low A is one of the prized attributes of members of the Japanese Communist party these days. Onetime bully boys of Communist shock troops now are attending singing school. A tenor voice is more in demand than big muscles.
Prof. Allan Nevins of Columbia University said yesterday that the Jewish communities had been among the bulwarks of liberty in the United States.
Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, offered some advice last night to Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey on how to develop Island Beach, N. J.
ANNA RUSSELL, already a veteran imp of the concert stage, opened new and alarming vistas of her art last night in Town Tall.

There can be only apprehension and dismay over the report that groups of Pakistanis are clamoring for a "holy war" to settle the disputed case of Kashmir. This is not the right answer to the problem. The Pakistani Government has repeatedly asserted its authority to keep down irresponsible demonstrations, knowing that any sort of outburst would simply make a bad situation worse.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Navy's football team got a somewhat subdued welcome home today.
QUIETLY, without preliminary fanfare, a young California pianist appeared at Town Hall for his debut recital yesterday afternoon and proved to be one of the most promising talents of the season.

A two-day invasion of Carnegie Hall by college jazz bands wound up early Sunday morning with the Spring Street Stompers of Williams and Dartmouth's Indian Chiefs doing their best to be heard above the din of an audience that was sending up a steady and enthusiastic barrage of paper airplanes and confetti.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Syria is to receive nearly $30,000,000 a year in pipeline royalties under a draft agreement with the Iraq Petroleum Company, Finance Minister Abdulwahab Haumad said today. The pact apparently settles a three-year-old dispute over payments.

ERATH, La., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Father Labbe said "over 700 children" were handled in shifts in the catechism classes. The classes run every day and children from the public schools in this small French community are released from school for the religious instructions.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley admitted yesterday that traffic in this city was likely to get worse and said that if it did, "something may have to give."

Studies to find new atomic furnace elements that will stand up longer has led to the development of a new X-ray spectrometer by General Electric Engineers. The device, which has been installed at the Atomic Energy Commission's Hanford plutonium plant in the State of Washington, is so sensitive it can detect changes as small as a billionth of an inch in the distance between crystal facets.

The Metropolitan Opera's revised version of "Tosca," with settings and costumes redesigned by Frederick Fox, will be shown for the first time Thursday night, Dec. 8. It will be led by Dimitri Mitropoulos, who has conducted the opera in a concert version at the Lewisohn Stadium but not at the Metropolitan.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Outside buying interest was low in the grain market last week but there was fair support in corn on the theory that bearish developments had been exploited sufficiently for the time being.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins scolded fellow Republicans today for what he said was their failure to support the Secretary of Agriculture's defense of the Administration's farm program.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 27 -- Czechoslovakia's engineers were scored today for failing to turn out new lines of consumer goods and for spurning "good and useful" foreign innovations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 27 -- Latin America is worried that the United States may begin "dumping" its agricultural surpluses in world markets.
NEWARK, Nov. 27 -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company listened in on some Newark city employes' telephone conversations last week, it admitted today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Serious concern over the procedures that will be followed by the White House Conference on Education was voiced today by labor representatives who will take part in the program. The four-day meeting, which will be attended by 2,000 invited delegates, will get under way tomorrow evening.

ERATH, La., Nov. 27 -- Bishop Jules B. Jeanmard excommunicated three Roman Catholic women today for beating a woman teacher who had instructed Negro and white children in the same catechism classroom.

MIAMI, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Three key players in Army's defeat of Navy accepted assignments today with the North squad for the Shrine North-South college all-star football game in the Orange Bowl, Dec. 26.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 27 -- Brazil's Government and Army heads went out of their way today to assail communism.

Waterfront Commission charges against the Nacirema Operating Company, Inc., are based on "innuendo, suspicion, suggestion, surmise and inference piled upon inference," Richard Steel, special counsel for the company, declared yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Business in the stock markets here continues to shrink, although in some directions -- notably in new capital issues -- there is increasing activity in financial London. There is little or nothing to suggest any revival in share trading this side of Christmas.
