A typical school superintendent is an extraordinarily busy man.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- President Juho K. Paasikivi of Finland today celebrated his eighty-fifth birthday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Senate subcommittee investigating violations of constitutional rights has run into rough sledding.

RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 27 -- French military circles indicated today that the rebels in the Riff region were led by a Moroccan Communist. Officers identified him as Mohammed el-Khabouchi, 40-year-old Berber born at Tizi Ouzli, who served in Indochina under the French.
Another effort will be made today to end the seven-week strike at thirty plants of the Westinghouse Electrical Corporation, six of them in the metropolitan area.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 27 (UP) -The Syracuse Nationals took the lead at the opening whistle tonight and led all the way in downing the New York Knicker-bockers, 85 -- 74, at the War Memorial Auditorium.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Washington Senators will reap the only "reward" for finishing last in the American League by getting first pick of 3,184 minor league players tomorrow as the major league draft opens a ten-day series of winter baseball meetings.
The Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York has granted an absolute charter to the Mayor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement, it was disclosed yesterday.
OOTACAMUND, India, Nov. 27 -- The Soviet leaders have been packing a considerable amount of official homework into their swing around India.

ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, in the Pacific, Nov. 27 -- From a tri-motored Ford plane flying over latitude 90 degrees south on Nov. 29, 1929, came the following message: "My calculations indicate that we have reached the vicinity of the South Pole."

Veterans of the armed forces who are potential leaders in journalism will receive preferential consideration for Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler memorial scholarships in journalism at Columbia University.
Nashua, whose racing future remains doubtful but whose past is brilliant, yesterday was hailed as "horse of the year" in The Morning Telegraph and Daily Racing Form annual poll.
Governor Harriman declared a new "war on poverty" yesterday. He said he would propose a special state commission to study ways to fight poverty as part of a broad program to help low-income families.

Tony Cerrato, whose mother tongue is Italian, struggled for the last few days to memorize an eight-word thank-you speech in English. He was to deliver the words at a breakfast yesterday in his honor at Fordham University.

ROME, Nov. 27 -- Pope Pius XII heard a heavenly voice before seeing an apparition of Christ during his grave illness last December, the Vatican said today. It was denied, however, that what the Pontiff heard was Christ's voice, as some reports had asserted.

Russia's new challenge should be met by a stronger military position by the United States, a determined North Atlantic Treaty Organization and economic aid to Asia, Louise Hsieh, a high school pupil, told the New York Times Youth Forum last night.
Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion of Israel has appealed to the National Committee for Labor Israel to send "young pioneers and scientists" to his country to hasten the development of the Negev.

Here it is winter, or so near it as to make slight difference, and yet the picnic season holds on. It seems to die harder each year. Already the winds from the north have brought bad news from the Arctic. In theory the picnic season should have ended, for traditionally the picnic is a part of summer.
Anti-Communist Poles announced yesterday they would picket the United Nations this evening because a concert sponsored by the Polish delegation is to be held at 8:30 in the General Assembly Hall.
Rockefeller Center employes, Laurance S. Rockefeller announced yesterday. He is chairman of the center's board.
The eighty-two voluntary, nonprofit hospitals that are members of the United Hos pital Fund carry on their activities 'round the clock, 365 days a year.
ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- The average New Yorker earned a record $2,163 last year despite a nationwide drop in personal incomes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today offered farmers little hope that their production costs will go down next year.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 26 -- With the South Korean Presidential election only six months away there is no evidence that Dr. Syngman Rhee intends to retire. In fact, the evidence is all to the contrary.

Only one film is slated to open this week. This is "Lady Godiva," a Universal-International period drama in Technicolor with Maureen O'Hara in the title role, George Nader, Eduard Franz and Victor McLaglen, which arrives at the Palace on Friday. Arthur Lubin directed and Robert Arthur produced.
Eighty-one per cent of the nation's department, chain and specialty stores expect higher sales during this year's Christmas season than in the same period a year ago.
The six-story apartment house at 24-36 Laurel Hill Terrace, near West 181st Street, has been sold by the 1660 Topping Avenue Corporation to a client of Dreyer Traub, attorneys.
A Unitarian minister yesterday described the Dead Sea Scrolls as history's most significant archaeological find in so far as they exerted influence on modern Christian thought.

True to the tradition of show business, of which professional football must be considered somewhat a part, the Giants left 'em laughing -- and gasping -- in the season's gridiron finale at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The 45,699 fans who saw the Giants and the mighty Cleveland Browns ring down the local curtain with an exciting 35-35 tie hardly could have hoped for so smashing a contest with such a smash finish.
MOUND BAYOU, Miss., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation opened a preliminary investigation today of the shooting of a Negro leader in the fight against segregation.

The collected "Writings of Walt Whitman" will be published in twelve volumes by the New York University Press, Fillmore Hyde, director, announced yesterday. He described the plan as "probably the most ambitious project on an American poet ever undertaken."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 (UP) -The Baltimore Colts defeated the injury-ridden San Francisco 49ers, 26 -- 14, today on the rifle-arm of George Shaw and the running of Alan (The Horse) Ameche to close out the most successful home season in club history.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 27 -- Henri Salaun of Boston won the Ticknor-Glidden squash racquets tournament at the Englewood Field Club today with a 14-15, 15-9, 8-15, 15-9, 15-4 victory over G. Diehl Mateer of Philadelphia.

ROCKEFELLER CENTER'S 1955 Christmas tree rested last night in a parking lot on a fifty-foot logging truck near the New Jersey end of George Washington Bridge. It should start rolling into the city around 8 A. M., possibly an hour before.

Between 1870 and 1950 actual producers in our economy -- those engaged in manufacturing, extraction and construction -- multiplied almost three times. Those engaged in selling and repairing and other service industries multiplied ten times.
RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 27 -- The Communist world is winning the friendship and confidence of the Burmese people.

The first Sunday of Advent, which commemorates the period between the Angel Gabriel's annunciation to Mary and the birth of Christ, was marked yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with a solemn mass followed by the opening ceremonies of the Forty Hours' Adoration.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Les Richter, a 230-pound guard, kicked three field goals in the fourth quarter, the last with seven seconds left to play, to enable the Los Angeles Rams to beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 23 -- 21, today. The Rams took first place in the Western Conference of the National Football League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Instead of waiting for the new labor federation to kick off the expected big organizing campaign after the merger next week, many of the unions have set out on their own to gather new members.

In many respects things have changed since Gilbert wrote "Ah, take one consideration with another -- a policeman's lot is not a happy one!" But the New York City Department of Personnel is, nevertheless, meeting with a somewhat puzzling lack of success in persuading young men to apply for the job of patrolman in the Police Department.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Bing Crosby, Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra will be on hand when "High Society" goes before the camera at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer early in January. Signing of the trio was reported today by Sol Siegel, the producer.
CONSIDERING the current emphasis on unusual wall treatments for the home, a revival of interest in tapestry art was inevitable. Two events currently in progress indicate that it is with us now.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Washington lobbyists are getting a chance to tell Congress what they think of the law regulating their activities.

The first trade delegation to come here from one of the Soviet Union's satellites arrived yesterday from Rumania. The three-man group let it be known at once that their country was eager to resume trade with the United States because, for one thing, there was a critical shortage of machinery.

Henry G. Waltemade, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, said yesterday "there is probably more conscious effort on the part of American business men today than ever before to apply the values of our vigorous Christian heritage to everyday business activity."
PARIS, Nov. 27 -- French steel prices will increase starting tomorrow as a result of a decision of the High Authority of the Coal and Steel Community.
A Texas girl, not quite 2 years old, came here yesterday to get a pair of artificial legs. Later she also will get a pair of arms.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Some additional details have been revealed concerning the behind-the-scenes moves that preceded the abdication of King Edward VIII in 1936. They are related in a biography of Geoffrey Dawson, late editor of The Times of London, which is to be published here tomorrow.
There's nothing like an Army-Navy game for football thrills except another Army-Navy game the year after, and ever and ever.
The homeward trek from the long Thanksgiving Day weekend got under way yesterday in traditional hurry-up-and-wait style.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Veterans Administration has developed a simple test to guard against a tuberculosis patient's leaving the hospital too soon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The American Legion commander said today the veterans' organization wanted Congress to determine after an investigation whether the United States should withdraw from the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organization.
PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Premier Edgar Faure, threatened with parliamentary defeat of his Cabinet this week, asked today for a constitutional reform to reduce French governmental instability.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 27 -- A drive to get a substantial share of Federal highway grants for urban feeder routes began today at the opening of a four-day convention of the Amercian Municipal Association.

Japan's efforts to restrict exports of cotton textiles to the United States should be commended rather than criticized, J. Spencer Love, chairman of the board of Burlington Industries, declared yesterday. If the step proves effective, he said, it will be in the right direction.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 27 -- Only one home in twenty-two in this country is equipped with mechanical air conditioning at the present time, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., disclosed today in reporting initial findings of its first annual survey of the home cooling market.

Even a lead of three goals was insufficient for the Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night. The New York skaters were tied by the leader-leading Frenchmen, 3-3, to the disappointment of the Ranger fans in the capacity crowd of 15,925.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 27 -- Confidence in the economic outlook dominated business on the Zurich Stock Exchange all last week. Demand was lively and turnover considerable.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 (AP) -Leo Elter and Vic Janowicz, a pair of former steel city residents, returned to Forbes Field today and engineered the Washington Redskins to a 23-14 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League game.

The machinery of labor unity began to grind here yesterday. The executive committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations met at the New Yorker Hotel to give formal approval to merger arrangements with the American Federation of Labor.

Two thousand delegates from all the states and territories of the United States are meeting in Washington today for a four-day "White House Conference on Education." They will be dealing with the most important secular subject that any community or nation has to face. It is a subject that can be as dry as dust or as exciting as an expedition to an unexplored far region of the earth.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 27 -- President Eisenhower prepared today for three weeks of political conferences. These will start tomorrow when he meets Leonard W. Hall, chair man of the Republican National Committee.
Ten university medical schools have just received grants totaling $7,150,000 for medical education from the Commonwealth Fund, it announced yesterday.

Leonard Sillman, who has been seeking a director for "Serena," is confident that Lehman Engel is equipped to handle the job. Although Mr. Sillman thought it was premature for him to verify the appointment, he acknowledged yesterday that contracts had been drawn for Mr. Engel to stage the musical.
VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Nov. 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Jouett Shouse's Ch. Barrage of Quality Hill was named best of breed at the second specialty show of the Boxer Club of Long Island today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus denounced today the state of emergency imposed on this riot-swept island as a British device to "bend the national resistance of the people" by force.

The Joint Legislative Committee to Revise the Banking Law will hold a public hearing Dec. 13 and 14 at the New York County Lawyers Association, 14 Vesey Street. This was announced yesterday by State Senator George H. Pierce of Olean, committee chairman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Post Office Department is delivering first-class headaches to the railroads by switching mail to trucks and airplanes.

A taxpayer building at 11-19 Northern Boulevard, Great Neck, L. I., has been sold by Benjamin and Mollie Scharer to the Cedar Building Corporation. Alexander Herman was the broker in the deal. Yarner Bregstein represented the buyer.

Two United States delegates to the General Assembly of the United Nations agreed last night that a demonstration of the destructive power of the hydrogen bomb, aside from stunning and frightening the world, would accomplish nothing.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Riviera Wonder, a 4-year-old gray gelding, gained the open jumper crown tonight as the Boulder Brook Club's two-day fall show came to an end. Wonder, ridden by Al Fiore, is owned by Mr. and Mrs. Bernie C. Mann of Port Washington, L. I.
BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- Dr. Martin Niemoller, president of the Evangelical Church in Germany, will deliver a series of three lectures on peace next week at Boston University.

" A TRUE respect for the beauty of natural materials -- and a restraint in using accessories -- are the most important things I learned in Japan." So says David Leavitt, architect, who recently returned to this country after more than a year working in Tokyo.

" COSI FAN TUTTE," one of Mozart's rarest jewels, returned to the Metropolitan Opera last Saturday night after a season's absence. After admiring its grace, wit and perfection of style, one was prepared to welcome "Cosi fan tutte" back on almost any terms.

WEST POINT N. Y., Nov. 27 -- There were many red faces in the Navy today following Army's upset 14-to-6 victory over Navy at Philadelphia yesterday, but none to compare with that of Lieutenant Herbet E. Whyte of Rapid City, S. D.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., Nov. 27 -- The question whether the picturesque Deepdale Golf and Country Club here is to become a village park and golf course or the site of a private housing development is causing a heated controversy.
The long-heralded mutual assistance pact between the International Longshoremen's Association and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., was concluded here yesterday.
WARSAW, Nov. 27 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski is out of secret internment and is living at a monastery in southeastern Poland, according to an authoritative source here.
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 27 -- The Netherlands Bank is continuing to convert dollars into gold. It is held here that the authorities want Dutch reserves to be as depreciation-proof as possible.

ATHENS, Nov. 27 -- Sophocles Venizelos' Liberal Democratic Union has announced its advocacy of "equal and proud friendship to all sides," meaning the Soviet bloc on one hand and the Western powers on the other.

" THUNDER IN WASHINGTON," by David Davidson, presented last night on the "Alcoa Hour" over Channel 4, was a play of uncommon timeliness, power and controversy. It also was a play that evoked a little exasperation at the end.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Screen Gems, the Columbia Pictures television film subsidiary, has completed agreements calling for the production of two new major TV series. Bryan Foy, the motion picture producer, will produce "Emergency," a new series that will draw upon the files of emergency hospitals for story material.

Block-by-block inspections will have been made of every building in Manhattan in the next two or three weeks, according to Mrs. Bernice P. Rogers, Deputy Commissioner of Housing and Buildings. She said yesterday that similar checks -- started March 1, 1954 -- were half completed in other boroughs.

As a recently returned Fulbright scholar and visiting lecturer at the University of New Zealand, I wish to commend you on your editorial of Nov. 22 urging a revision of the Immigration and Nationality (Walter-McCarran) Act of 1952.
The top utility executive of France liked what he saw in America the last three weeks.
CLIPPER SMITH, the football coach, was driving along the coastal road in California many years ago when a billboard caught his eye.

Air rights of an adjoining property have been acquired by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company to provide an increase in the floor space of the thirty-eight-story office building to be erected at 666 Fifth Avenue, at the southwest corner of Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Administration's foreign policy, looking more like a major 1956 campaign issue every day, was attacked and defended today in a round of statements.

The arrival of the Italian Minister of Defense, Paolo Emilio Taviani, in New York today to join the Minister of Public Instruction, Paolo Rossi, is a pleasant reminder that the United States always has its true and tried friends in Rome. Other prominent Italians are coming to help Boston put on a week-long tribute to the Eternal City, beginning today.

An assertion that "no sensible alternative" exists to the 15 per cent advertising agency commission system is made in an editorial in the Dec. 3 issue of Tide, now being distributed. Morgan Browne, editor of Tide, who signs the editorial, assails Gilbert H. Weil, general counsel of the Association of National Advertisers.
The New York City Ballet at the City Center restored Lew Christensen's "Con Amore" to the repertory at yesterday's mationee, and did so in spirited and skillful fashion.

Like many other agencies of this city the New York City Mission Society raises funds through mail appeals. One such appeal of ours, in reference to our Good Neighbor Community Center in East Harlem, was returned from Scarsdale with an unsigned note that said in effect that East Harlem's five-story walkups are as good as their inhabitants deserve and concluded, "Enough of this maudlin so-called charity."

ROBERT CASADESUS, who was soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony a fortnight ago, was back with it again Saturday night and yesterday afternoon to play two works -- the Mozart Concerto for Piano and Orchestra in C minor (K.491) and d'Indy's Symphony for Orchestra and Piano on a French Mountain Song.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Delegates began arriving today for the White House Conference on Education. It will be the nation's greatest stock-taking of its public schools.

The arrival of the Italian Minister of Defense, Paolo Emilio Taviani, in New York today to join the Minister of Public Instruction, Paolo Rossi, is a pleasant reminder that the United States always has its true and tried friends in Rome. Other prominent Italians are coming to help Boston put on a week-long tribute to the Eternal City, beginning today.

An assertion that "no sensible alternative" exists to the 15 per cent advertising agency commission system is made in an editorial in the Dec. 3 issue of Tide, now being distributed. Morgan Browne, editor of Tide, who signs the editorial, assails Gilbert H. Weil, general counsel of the Association of National Advertisers.
Persons who fear death are afraid of losing their material holdings in this world, the Very Rev. Hughell E. W. Fosbroke said yesterday at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Soviet Union is completing construction of the world's largest atom smasher, a Communist party paper said today.
The nation has passed a political milestone. This month, the city-manager, plan became the most popular form of government for cities with more than 25,000 inhabitants.
The world's largest combination tanker-ore carrier is now on her maiden voyage, and she is carrying the largest single oil cargo ever borne afloat.

AVON, Conn., Nov. 27 -- It's a lucky thing Herb Cochrane doesn't discourage easily. As athletic director and football coach at Avon Old Farms, the revitalized prep school in the Farmington River Valley, Cochrane probably holds a record in the problem department.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Earl Buchholz, 15-year-old St. Louisan, today became the first player to win the boys' division two straight years in the national indoor junior and boys tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Imam Ahmad of Yemen was represented today as having decided to bring his ancient kingdom, nearly unchanged and isolated for a thousand years, into the twentieth century.
The Rev. Albert L. Neibacher cautioned yesterday that the "deadly disease" of secularism and materialism in this pre-Christmas season would require "spiritual surgery."

The third in a recent series of expansion moves will soon put McAllister Brothers, Inc., into the automobile, truck and passenger ferry business between Orient Point, L. I., and Old Saybrook and New London, Conn.

IN Norway north of the Arctic Circle spring comes late and April can be the cruelest winter month. It was cruel indeed in 1943 when Jan Baalsrud encountered some of the most harrowing adventures yet recorded about survivors of the Second World War.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 27 -- Undisturbed by special details of armed police, a crowd of 15,000 persons demanded today that the Government declare war against India.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 27 -- At the opening session of the Investment Bankers Association Convention here today it was indicated that the trade controversy over extending the underwriting authority of commercial banks will not be permitted to become a convention issue requiring the I. B. A. to take sides as an association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- This Government is watching with the greatest attention the political maneuvering for the succession of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in West Germany, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Nationalist China and President Syngman Rhee in South Korea.
Robert Anderson, the playwright who won prominence for "Tea and Sympathy," has sold one of his earlier plays to television.

THE Little Orchestra Society in the past has tested the uses of ingenuity and the power of suggestion and found that a vast apparatus is not needed to create illusion. In its performance of Ravel's "L'Enfant et les Sortileges" at Town Hall last night, a child's enchanted world was evoked in a simple, amusing way.

The likelihood of longshore labor disturbances has been eased by the agrement signed Sunday between the International Longshoremen's Association and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Louis Waldman, I. L. A. special attorney, made this estimate of the agreement yesterday before the unofficial Citizens Waterfront Committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -President Eisenhower is being urged to withhold until late February or early March any announcement whether he, will be a candidate for re-election.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Charles (Deacon) Jones of Iowa finished like a sprinter today to win the seventeenth annual National Collegiate A. A. cross country run. He covered the four-mile course in 19:57.4.
Work has started on the first Title I nonprofit cooperative colony in Brooklyn. Ceremonies marking the start of the project will be held tomorrow afternoon on the site in the Fort Greene area.

Events today: Searle Wright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Wheeler Beckett Orchestra of New York, Wheeler Beckett conducting, John Corigliano, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15.
Two of the main thoroughfares in Jackson Heights, Queens -Thirty-fifth and Thirty-seventh Avenues -- will become one-way streets soon, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley, announced yesterday.
Police Inspector Michael J. Murphy was named yesterday as executive director of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

Harvey Love of Harvard University was elected president of the Rowing Coaches Organization of America yesterday at the annual meeting at the Gramercy Park Hotel. He succeeds Norman Sonju of Wisconsin, who presided at the meeting.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The British Government gave notice in the House of Commons today that Britain intends to challenge the United States' commercial jet supremacy on the lucrative trans-Atlantic air routes with slower but more economical turboprop airliners.
One of the twenty counts against John G. (Steve) Broady, accused of being the key figure in a wiretap conspiracy here, was dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein.
A chill mass of Arctic air swept across most of the nation yesterday. It chased the holiday zephyrs from the East Coast and brought to New York the coldest temperatures of the season.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 28 -- President Eisenhower issued today a new "conflict-of-interest" order sharply restricting the activities of several hundred men serving the Government under the Defense Production Act on a "dollar-a-year" basis.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Ten members of a family came here today for surgical treatment of what was believed the largest case of hereditary jaundice in medical history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Although the White House Conference on Education has been heralded as the "culmination" of the greatest stock-taking, the American people have ever made of their schools, it may actually prove to be the springboard for even greater grass-roots efforts in education.
Directors of the Cities Service Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday and also voted to distribute a stock dividend of 2 per cent on the outstanding shares.
A special fund for the aid of needy musicians has been established by the Musicians Foundation, Inc., in memory of Olin Downes, music critic of The New York Times.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The British Government still hopes to settle the situation on Cyprus by secret negotiation, authoritative sources said today.
MIAMI, Nov. 28 -- A fourhour bridge session was cited today by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, as a measure of President Eisenhower's recovery from his heart attack.

LUDWIG BEMELMANS, humorist, novelist, illustrator and homme du monde turns out to be something of an artist as well in his exhibition of nearly fifty works at the Hammer Galleries, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street.
CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Trade Minister C. D. Howe said today that the world's wheat markets generally were demoralized by the United States' surplus disposal program.

Observations by some gloomy economists that the installmentbuying public was living beyond its means were challenged yesterday in Chicago by a top consumer finance official. The challenger was E. F. Wonderlic, administrative vice president of the General Finance Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- An Agriculture Department economist predicted today that the economic squeeze on farmers would probably get tighter next year.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The auto industry's production pace slowed slightly last week for the Thanksgiving Day holiday, but the assembly lines were back in high gear again today.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 28 -- The nation's investment bankers today heard praise of the Eisenhower Administration for promoting an expanding economy and at the same time safeguarding the buying power of the dollar.

Milton Berle will not appear on his television show tonight because of "extreme physical exhaustion." Eddie Cantor, who was to be a guest on the program, had to withdraw last Friday when he became ill with a kidney infection.

United States District Court Judge George H. Moore issued yesterday in St. Louis a ten-day temporary restraining order against the proposed merger of the Brown Shoe Company and the G. R. Kinney Company.

A plan for a "game-of-theweek" television broadcast of major league baseball contests, which would aid the treasuries of minor as well as major league clubs, was revealed yesterday by Walter F. O'Malley, president of the Dodgers.
A forty-foot welded steel mural symbolizing the industrial life of the city was erected yesterday in the lobby of the newly remodeled trades center building on Eighth Avenue.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Directors of Montgomery Ward Co. today voted a 2-for-1 split in the common stock, increased the regular quarterly dividend to $1 and declared a year-end extra of $1.25.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 28 -- Much of the popular interest in Australia's national elections, to be held Dec. 10, appears to center on the leader of the party that is generally expected to lose. He is Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Labor party chief and stormiest figure of colorful Australian politics.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- A leader of the repudiated "ornamentalist" school of Soviet architecture called today for a sweeping program to bring the Soviet Union abreast of foreign architectural and construction technique.

Elmer F. (Trigger) -- Burke took the witness stand yesterday in his trial for first-degree murder. He testified that he was so intoxicated at the time of the killing that he had no knowledge of being at the scene.
TOKYO, Nov. 28 -- A young chemistry student at Gakushuin University who makes his own bed and cleans his own room became an adviser to Emperor Hirohito today.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- A Foreign Office spokesman who last week described Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin as "thoroughly hypocritical" was supplanted at the regular midday news conference today.
WASHINGTON,-Nov. 28 -- Proponents of Federal rather than private development of Hell's Canyon carried their fight to the courts today.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, Nov. 28 -- The Royal Commission looking into Canada's economic prospects for the next quarter century today reached the most westerly point at which it will seek clues to the future.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- The United States and Britain appeared today to have given up their hopes of getting speedy consideration by the Security Council of the question of admitting new members to the United Nations. Both had sought to have the matter taken up in the Council before it was aired in the General Assembly.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- Members of the United States delegation to the. United Nations boycotted a recital presented here tonight in commemoration of the centennial of the death of Adam Mickiewicz, Poland's greatest poet.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 28 -- President Eisenhower returned from his office to his farm this afternoon, secure in the knowledge that he once more was immune from the glances of tourists.
ABOUT this time of year it's a rare mother who doesn't begin wishing for some "really decent pictures of the kids" to tuck in with her greeting card and annual report to friends.
Medical care of the armed services is rapidly becoming the major problem of the Pentagon.
MANILA, Nov. 28 -- Army disclosures of an extensive Chinese Communist-backed effort to infiltrate Chinese schools there have revived a move for government control of these schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -The Post Office Department said tonight that a man recommended by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, as acting postmaster for his home town of Appleton, Wis. "has not been appointed."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 28 -- A three-day conference that political leaders said would be decisive in Pakistan's efforts to wrest the adjoining state of Jammu and Kashmir from India, ended tonight. It adopted a resolution that contained the same charges that Pakistan has made against India for the past seven years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that new commitments by commercial banks for mortgage "warehousing" loans had declined only slightly since summer.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- Anthony Perkins has been tagged for stardom by Paramount. He will get his chance to make good by playing the title role in "The Jim Piersall Story."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- Frank Wisbar, the producerdirector who originated the "Fireside Theatre," is re-entering the television arena after a year's absence. He expects to have an experimental color series, "The Valley of Blue Mountain," ready for next fall. Final photography of the first halfhour film started today at the Sam Goldwyn studios under Mr. Wisbar's direction.

TOKYO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Gaetano Martino, Italian Foreign Minister, winding up a week of trade and goodwill talks, left here last night. His parting statement was that "we have done some good work, we have made a step forward" in settling problems with Japan.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28 -Ten players were drafted by major league clubs today as the wheels started turning in baseball's annual minor league convention.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 28 -The Brazilian capital has lived under a state of siege for three days, but one has to read the newspapers to realize it is here.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer conferred today with three leaders of the Free Democratic party critical of the demands of Dr. Thomas Dehler, party leader, for bilateral discussions on German unity with the Soviet Union.

Stockholders of the Dole Hawaiian Pineapple Company approved yesterday steps to complete the company's acquisition of two canning concerns. They are F. M. Ball Co., Oakland, Calif., and the Paulus Brothers Packing Company of Salem, Ore.
An increase in the city's annual sewer rental charge to property owners was proposed for the fourth time yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 28 (AP} -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, was chosen yesterday as the candidate of a new political party -- the Pioneer party -- for President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission today ordered radio station WWBZ, Vineland, N. J., to shut down because of past horse racing broadcasts described as helpful to bookmakers.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 28 -- The contract bridge team of David Warner of Philadelphia, Mark Hodges of Chattanooga, Tenn., J. Van Brooks of Detroit, and Edwin J. Smith Jr., of Grosse Pointe, Mich., took a first session lead today over a field of thirty-nine teams in the open team of four bridge championship.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 28 -Nassau County political leaders urged today a new drive to enact cost-cutting changes in the state's optional permanent personal registration law.
Mounting demand for steel sent operations of the nation's steel mills last week to a record of 2,416,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings. This was in spite of the Thanksgiving holiday.

Despite a strike of nonoperating employes between March 14 and May 11 that paralyzed the road's operations, the Louisville and Nashville Railroad's earnings for the first ten months this year ran nearly 33 1/3 per cent above those of 1954.

"The Search for Bridey Murphy," a record of an experiment in hypnosis by Morey Bernstein, has been scheduled for Jan. 5 publication by Doubleday. Mr. Bernstein, a young business man of Pueblo, Colo., tells how he hypnotized a young woman and succeeded in putting her through an age regression in which she recalled details of her life when she was between 18 months and 15 years old.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that "our greatest hope" for curbing juvenile crime lay "in the home, the church, the school and the neighborhood community," when the children were still of elementary school age.
BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The president-elect of the American Medical Association today urged physicians to learn more about people than details of their anatomy.

Transcontinental GasPipe Line Corporation's directors voted-yesterday to recommend a two-for-one split of the 3,500,000 shares of common stock that were outstanding. Stockholders will be asked at special meeting at Houston on Jan. 10, 1956, to pave the way for the split by authorizing a doubling of common to 10,000,000 shares.
The East's football squad that will play in the thirty-first annual East-West college charity game at San Francisco on Dec. 31 was named yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, returned here today to face a demand from some Administration leaders for a reappraisal of important aspects of foreign policy.

The contract to purchase the twelve-story apartment house at 68 East Eighty-sixth Street has been resold by Henry Payson, operator, to an investing client of Reuben Lesser, attorney. The property is assessed at $300,000.
BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The head of the Republic Steel Corporation said today another steel price increase might be on the way.

New York's Chinatown got a new post office yesterday, replacing a cubicle eight feet by nine feet that had served the area for thirty-seven years. The new station, with 1,150 square feet of working space compared with the old office at 13 Mott Street, was opened at noon at 14 Pell Street.
CHICAGO Nov 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Prices moved irregularly and without trend today. Although trading was restrained, the undertone was described as firm. Best gains were made on American buying of selected issues. Ford, Borax and Bowater werp among favorites of American .westors and showed some of the sharpest rises of the day.

The 1956 Rambler line, with increased engine power and longer bodies, was announced yesterday. Manufactured by American Motors, the models will go on display in Nash and Hudson dealer showrooms here Dec. 15.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The chairman of the White House Conference on Education made it plain today that every delegate will have a chance to be heard.

Shipbuilding and repair yards in this area are capable of taking over work from the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, without Government subsidy, it was declared yesterday by James S. Nelson, president of the New York and New Jersey Dry Dock Association.
BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- Two United States Congressmen, the wife of one of them and an Army officer were detained in East Berlin for four hours yesterday, United States Army officials disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Wheat and oats were especially weak early in today's session on the Board of Trade, with scattered long liquidation and some local pressure. But wheat prices later rallied to close with gains for the day

Jamaica's twenty-two game winning streak is the longest by a Queens basketball team in at least twenty-five years. The Beavers have not lost since bowing to Jefferson, 58 -- 44, in November, 1954. A 70-13 victory over Flushing last Wednesday bettered the twenty-one straight triumphs scored by Newtown from 1949 to 1952.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad said today it wanted to cancel its plan to offer $6,600,000 of equipment trust certificates for competitive bidding because interest rates are so high in securities markets.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- An agreement aimed at ending the bitter four-months strike at the New Castle, Ind., plant of Perfect Circle Corporation was reached today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Civil Service Commission revealed today that it maintained a card index file with names of 2,000,000 persons "allegedly affiliated with some sort of subversive organization or activity."
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 28 -- Gardiners Island, where Captain Kidd buried a $40,000 treasure in 1699, has a temporary new corporate tenant.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The selection of Gary Glick, Colorado A. and M. quarterback, as the National Football League's bonus draft choice today is the latest of many developments pointing to A. and M. as a good prep school for prospective professional players.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, called on President Eisenhower today to halt Republican partisanship on foreign policy as the way to a 1956 campaign truce in that field.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 28 -Efforts are continuing to narrow the margin of difference between what Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, will concede on the Cyprus issue and what Archbishop Makarios will or can accept on behalf of the dominant Greek community.

FORT LEE, N. J., Nov. 28 -- A 13-year-old Leonia boy, object of a search for four days, was captured this morning by the police of two towns after he had threatened to shoot his father and the policemen. The revolver he pointed at them was empty.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Vanderbilt and Auburn, both of the Southeastern Conference, will play in the eleventh Gator Bowl football game here Dec. 31. This was announced today by Sam Butz, the selection committee chairman.
Travelers were delayed up to three hours yesterday on sixty trains bound into or out of the city.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 28 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Executive order today strengthening the "conflict of interest" regulations on Government advisers:

The next few days will probably decide whether the United Nations is to become almost universal by electing eighteen new members in a "package deal." A General Assembly committee will probably vote this week on the Canadian resolution calling for "the widest possible membership."

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 28 -- The chairman of the Republican National Committee said today after a forty-five-minute conference with President Eisenhower that he believed the President would run for re-election "if he thinks he is able."

Future prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly higher yesterday. Coffee, cocoa, wool, potatoes, copper, zinc and burlap rose; rubber, hides, sugar and cottonseed oil eased, and changes in lead, onions, silk and tin were mixed.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Willie Hartack, the nation's leading rider, rode four winners and ran his total for the year to 390 at Tropical Park's opening today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged at 111.1 (1947-49 equals 100) over the week ended Nov. 22, 1955, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 28 -The deer in these hills have changed their habits this year. Hunters must tramp the oak and beech ridges rather than hunt the old orchards and hill pastures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)--Following are the texts of remarks by President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon at the opening session of the White House Conference on Education tonight. The President's talk was shown on film; Mr. Nixon delivered his in person.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- Britain, the United States and Turkey called on all governments today to continue supporting the United Nations' program for aid to Palestine Arab refugees.
The Municipal Art Society joined yesterday with bird watchers and others in objecting to a recreational center for the aged in the Central Park Ramble.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 -- A group of Democrats close to Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan is attempting to persuade him to become a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1956.

A sixty - five - foot Norway spruce, weighing three and a half tons, was hoisted and lodged in a fixed position at Rockefeller Plaza yesterday morning, opening the annual Christmas activities at Rockefeller Center.

The Roxy Theatre will inaugurate a reserved seat policy involving 1,000 seats in the mezzanine. The new policy will coincide with the opening of "The Rains of Ranchipur" on Dec. 15. The film will be accompanied by a stage and ice show entitled "Happy Holiday -- Anywhere, U. S. A."
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 28 -- Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu forecast tonight the prompt return of the newspaper La Prensa to its former owners.

Donations to the New York regional Red Cross blood program will be made today at the Sinclair Oil Company, 600 Fifth Avenue; East Midwood Jewish Center, 1625 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, and New York Telephone Company, 1530 Carroll Street, Brooklyn.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 28 -- The new City Council will not take office for its two-year term Dec. 1 as provided in the City Charter, it was believed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -Four corporations pleaded nol contendere and charges against Nicholas and George Kulukundis Greek shipowners, were dismissed today in a clean-up of criminal actions resulting from the purchase of a surplus Government ship.
PARIS, Nov. 28 -- Premier Edgar Faure will face a crucial vote of confidence in the National Assembly tomorrow, with the French Communist party as the probable arbiter of his fate.

In line with their long-standing campaign to break up all defensive alliances of the free world the Soviets have launched a particularly vigorous offensive against the latest such alliance -- the Middle Eastern Treaty Organization provided by the Baghdad pact.

WITHIN a short time, possibly a week, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve a new preservation process of interest to consumers. It involves an antibiotic that may assure them fresher, better-tasting poultry.

Representative Franklin L. Becker (R., N. Y.) said yesterday that he would make every effort to have the 1958 ArmyNotre Dame football game transferred from Michie Stadium at West Point to the Yankee Stadium.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 -Former President Truman reiterated today that he had "no preference" among Democratic Presidential aspirants.

When fathers cast about these days for the big holiday presents for their boys, sooner or later their thoughts turn to trains. This is the right year for taking notice, too, for fifty-five years ago -- in the year 1900 -- the first successful toy electric train took to the home tracks.
Our hospital bills stamped "paid" may include such items as rooms, nursing care, laboratory fee, anesthesia, special oratory fee, anesthesia, special medication, blood and so on.
MADRAS, India, Nov. 28 -- Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin told 200,000 Madrasis tonight that the Western powers were trying to push the Asians into preparations for "a new war."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs are still at a twenty-year high.

Anita Loos, one of Broadway's busiest writers these days, has added another project to her list of current works. It is a musical adaptation of "Gigi," which will be produced by Gilbert Miller and Herman Levin late next season. No decision has been made yet as to who will furnish the songs.
A suit seeking an investigation into the qualifications of Ralph John De Meo as City Director of Purchase was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by the Citizens Union. His salary is $10,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- John L. Lewis told Congress today that no new law was needed to get after the "human jackals who are feeding off" union welfare funds.

The cotton futures market moved irregularly yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final prices were 19 points (95 cents a bale) lower to 48 points ($2.40 a bale) higher than on last Friday. New crop months displayed the most strength.

CAIRO, Nov. 28 -- Newspaper men working in Egypt are subject to prison sentences and fines for publishing "false news" contrary to the "public interest," according to an amendment to the penal code, approved last Wednesday and published today in the official gazette.
Walter P. Reuther will head the industrial union department of the merged labor movement.
Oklahoma was acclaimed the 1955 college football champion yesterday by the United Press board of coaches.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 28 -- The formation of a tri-state commission with broad policy-formulating powers to find the answers for the pressing problems of the New York metropolitan area was suggested today by Mayor Wagner of New York. He made the proposal in opening a panel discussion of metropolitan area and fringe problems at the annual Congress of American Municipal Association, now in session here.

The bank building at 115 Chambers Street, which formerly was occupied by the American Irving Sayings Bank, has been purchased by the Small Investors Real Estate Plan, Inc., Albert Mintzer, president. The structure will be completed by the buyer and was not bought for inclusion in SIRE, a plan for acquiring realty for small investors.
WARSAW, Nov. 27--Polish authorities are engaged in a serious struggle against widespread alcoholism.

While washing machine manufacturers are succeeding with their advertising in persuading prospects to buy machines, they are failing to make a second sale when that same prospect wants to buy a replacement.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 28 -- An Iowa district judge ruled today it was illegal for hospitals in this state to retain physicians as staff members and then bill hospital patients directly for the services of these specialists.
Plans to sell $21,000,000 of bonds were announced yesterday by the Salt River (Arizona) Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District.
Dr. Paulo Arsenio Virissimo Cunha, Foreign Minister of Portugal, arrived in New York yesterday on an official visit to the United States.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 28 -- Michael E. Bowman, a starting lineman for two seasons, was elected captain of Princeton University's 1956 football team today. Royce N. Flippin, the retiring captain, received the John Prentiss Poe Memorial Cup, the highest award the university can confer upon a football player.
ATLANTIC CTTY, Nov. 28 -The ninth exposition sponsored by the Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration Institute opened here today in Convention Hall.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation set new highs in gross revenues and net earnings in the first nine months of this year. Substantial increases resulted from the operation of properties not held a year ago.

TRENTON, Nov. 28 -- The New York Central Railroad sought here today the right to curtail sharply passenger service on its West Shore, or river, division between Weehawken and West Haverstraw, N. Y. In an application filed with the Public Utility Commision, the railroad requested permission to confine its future passenger service to eight commuter trains in each direction daily.

CAIRO, Nov. 28 -- A negotiated settlement of the Arab-Israeli dispute has become a tangible possibility for the first time since the 1948 Palestine war, according to authoritative Egyptian and British sources.

The Union of South Africa entered into agreements yesterday with Dillon, Read Co., Inc., representative for an investment banking group, and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to borrow a total equivalent to $50,000,000.

RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 28 -The internal insurrections that have interfered with the development of Burma during the eight years of her independence are on the verge of being eliminated, in the view of Burmese officials.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 28 -By unanimous vote the Westchester County Board of Supervisors petitioned the state today for revision of the Friedsam formula for state aid to education.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 28 (AP) -The Philadelphia Warriors of the National Basketball Association have been granted draft rights to the schoolboy basketball sensation, Wilt (The Stilt) Chamberlain, four years in advance, it was revealed today.

One of the greatest battles for freedom of the press in our hemisphere has at last been won. La Prensa of Buenos Aires, confiscated on March 20, 1951, is being restored to its rightful owners and will resume publication under the direction of its courageous and able publisher, Alberto Gainza Paz.

It is 7 in the morning. You are in one of a line-up of sixty-one sports and family-type automobiles, waiting for the starter's flag to send you off on the 1,200-mile, three-day 1955 Great American Mountain Rallye of the Motor Sports Club of America.

In the developing debate on the foreign aid program there are two clear positions -- one favors more aid, the other less. C. L. Sulzberger in his dispatch of Nov. 20 states the case against less aid. A recent State Department release stated the case for contingent reductions.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla. Nov. 28 -- Members of the Investment Bankers Association have disapproved by a vote of 524 to 83 legislation that would extend the underwriting power of commercial banks to certain local government bonds not backed by tax power but by tolls, such as tolls from turnpikes, or other special revenues.

Fordham's basketball team is young in point of experience, and "a lot will depend on how fast we learn in competition." That's how Coach Johnny Bach sized up his current outfit yesterday before a workout at the Fordham gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Army announced today a reorganization in the General Staff to improve administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Edgar H. Dixon will incidentally be performing a public service if he takes to Federal court his claim and that of his partner, Eugene A. Yates, for reimbursement from the Government for the canceled Dixon-Yates contract with the Atomic Energy Commission.

Stocks started well yesterday, weakened before the end of the first hour and drifted downward for the rest of the day. Motors, National Tea, Montgomery Ward and Kennecott Copper were the softest issues near the close.

The Irving Trust Company announced yesterday that registration statements it had filed covering American depositary receipts that the bank issues against shares of British, South African and Dutch companies had become effective Friday.

State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams has halted the issuance of eviction certificates for twenty-three East Side tenements pending an investigation into the business dealings and good faith of the owners.
Tony Johnson, 174 pounds, East Side, knocked out Billy McNeece, 171 1/2, Central Islip, L. I., at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

As President Eisenhower begins with his advisers to hammer out Administration policy for the coming year, one of the most important and difficult questions he has to face involves the kind and the extent of foreign aid. At present American assistance to our friends and allies abroad is primarily military.

More than 80 per cent of the personnel of the 106th Bombardment Wing, New York Air National Guard, turned out yesterday at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, to answer an alert within the prescribed two hours.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2S -- Fourteen years of enforced separation are about to end for a naturalized United States citizen and his Soviet wife.

Howard (Hopalong) Cassady, Ohio State's dynamic 172-pound halfback, and Calvin Jones, a rugged 220-pound Iowa guard, yesterday were chosen on The United Press All-America football team for the second straight year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28--A resolution expressing confidence that a satisfactory resolution of the Moroccan question would be achieved in negotiations between France and Morocco was approved tonight by the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly.
RABAT, French Morocco, Nov. 28 -- Disagreements among rival nationalist parties seemed today to be delaying the formation of French Morocco's first representative Government.
Directors of the American Express Company yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 37 cents a share from 30 cents and elected two officers to top executive posts.

Northern Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues ad net income for the twelve months ended Sept. 30. Operating revenues of $104,666,926 compared with $80,746,187 in the twelve months ended Sept. 30, 1954.

Officials of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., and the Westinghouse Electric Company resumed efforts yesterday to settle a six-week strike. The strike has idled 40,000 workers in thirty plants across the nation.

ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Greek Government announced a sweeping crackdown today on the nation's three biggest banks. The aim is to end a shortage of investment cash impeding the nation's economic life.

BELZONI, Miss., Nov. 28 (UP) -- Gov. Hugh L. White urged local authorities today to investigate thoroughly the shooting of a Negro civil rights leader to avoid "serious trouble" with the Federal Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers passed over the nation's top college football players to select a 25year-old defensive quarterback as their bonus in the National Football League partial player draft today.
Better quality and slightly higher prices will be the keynote for shoes in the spring.

IT'S impossible to recall a football week-end as enormously satisfying as the one just past. First of all there was the thrilling spectacle of Army climbing off the floor to stop Navy, 14 to 6. Secondly, there was the thrilling spectacle of the Giants climbing off the floor to tie the Browns a day later, 35 -- 35, and barely avoiding a haymaker in the final twenty-five seconds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)--The Senate study of the General Motors Corporation turned up complaints today that G. M.'s finance-insurance affiliates were hurting independent car repair shops.
Satisfaction with the present make-up of the New York Yankees was expressed by George Weiss, the club's general manager, yesterday.

Charlie Sticka, a big star at a comparatively small college, muscled his way in among the Frogs from somewhat larger puddles yesterday to take a place on the 1955 Associated Press all-East football team.

Osmond Fraenkel has been retained as counsel by the Variety Club Foundation to Combat Epilepsy with the object of obtaining reforms that will eliminate legal discrimination against victims of epilepsy as automobile drivers.

GENEVA, Nov. 28 -- The United States has reported to its trading partners substantial progress in removing import controls on agricultural products. It has also reported some progress in altering the basic conditions that make such controls necessary.
Fire Commissioner Cavanagh received well-deserved praise on your editorial page Nov. 16 for the "new role" of "fire preventers" he has given New York City firemen.

Disorderly charges against four youths who flooded a clergyman's home in mistaken retaliation were dismissed yesterday in Queens Adolescent Court when their parents presented a $2,125 check to pay damages.

Scholarship students at the Downtown Community School, 235 East Eleventh Street, will benefit from the seventh annual three-day International Fair to be held Friday, Saturday and Sunday at the school.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- President Eisenhower today called for limited Federal aid to education. He went further in his request than at any previous time.

The Department of Correction deserves the gratitude and support of the city for the idea that it has been stubbornly developing -- that "correction" must mean what it says: to reform, to improve, to set right. This was surely the intention when Judge Anna Kross, for twenty years a magistrate dedicated to humanity in the law, was appointed the Commissioner of Correction.

The attention of the New York State Commission of Correction has been directed to the editorial comment appearing in your Nov. 9 issue, wherein the totally inadequate and consequently undesirable conditions at the House of Detention for Women in New York City were succinctly set forth.
PARIS, Nov. 28 -- The proposal for a European pool of resources for nuclear energy has received the endorsement of an international technical group and may soon receive wide political backing.
A strike against at least two major private bus operators was declared "inevitable" yesterday by officials of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., after a break-down of negotiations.

FOR a generation now four nineteenthcentury American writers have seemed more interesting to twentieth-century critics, students and readers than the rest of their contemporaries. Melville and Whitman, Henry James and Henry Adams speak to us with an immediacy that seems to surmount the barriers of time. Only Whitman was an optimist and he celebrat. ed. the...virtues of democracy, virtues we now see derided and imperiled.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29--The Ford Motor Company has made Cleveland its largest base of operations outside of the company's home offices and its giant Rouge plant in Dearborn, Mich. The breadth of Ford operations here was displayed today during a visit by members of the press to the company's new stamping plant and engine plant No. 2.

The speeches made by Messrs. Bulganin and Khrushchev in their current tour of India have been marked by much hypocrisy, but the low point thus far was reached in Mr. Bulganin's Madras speech. The Soviet Premier assured his listeners there that the West is trying to push Asia toward "preparation for a new war."

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 29--A mild boom for Mayor Wagner of New York as the Democratic candidate for Vice President was started here today at the thirtysecond annual congress of the American Municipal Association.

SINGAPORE, Wednesday, Nov. 30 (AP)--Ong Ah-too, 35year-old Chinese truck driver sentenced to death in the mob slaying of Gene Symonds, an American news man, won his freedom today from a court of appeal.
TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner questioned today the feasibility of establishing a tri-state commission to tackle pressing problems of the New York metropolitan area.

It almost seems as if we have had a year without Winston Churchill-- but that is impossible. In or out of office Sir Winston is a man to be reckoned with. There is no denying, however, that of all the years of the twentieth century we heard less of Winston Churchill in 1955 than in any other year.
When it comes to financing, what's good for General Motors is not necessarily good for thousands of smaller businesses.

The Traffic Department moved yesterday to aid Santa Claus. The department made a temporary change in parking rules in many of the city's shopping centers to give the merchants a more rapid turnover of customers during the pre-Yule rush.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP) --Representative Emanuel Celler. Democrat of Brooklyn, said today President Eisenhower's new order on Government dollara-year men was almost a "word-for-word" repeat of steps taken by Congress.

John Ludewig, an executor and trustee of the late William Woodward Jr.'s estate, said last night at his home in Maywood, N. J., that "there has not been a decision" as to the disposition of Woodward's Belair Stud thoroughbred holdings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--Is it possible to have a school district without a school?
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29--France returned to the General Assembly today with none of the drama that marked her walkout sixty days ago.

BERLIN, Nov. 29--It has never been precisely clear to Western public opinion just what coexistence between the Communist and democratic blocs really means. Secretary Dulles once said to this writer: "When we are talking about coexistence we are actually talking about something entirely different from the Russians.
Although streptococci bacteria have been found to be the cause of heart damage after rheumatic fever, the germs remain an enigma to medical science.
Nat Holman is in his thirtyfifth year as head coach of City College's basketball team, and the coming campaign undoubtedluy will be his "hardest."
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 29 (AP)--All sixteen Cabinet aides of Premier Adnan Menderes resigned tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 20,000 head, Market active and uneven, steady to 25c higher than yesterday's average on butchers; most advance on weights 240 pounds and heavier; sows
Arthur Miller, playwright, found himself cast yesterday as the central figure in a drama with a plot almost as thick as many of those he himself has devised.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 --Specialists of the nation's investment banking industry came up today with far-reaching proposals for revamping Federal taxation of capital gains and income. In summary, they proposed: q A 50 per cent ceiling on taxation of earned income.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29--In announcing today that Nationalist China would veto, if necessary, the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations, Dr. T. F. Tsiang said his Government had not decided whether it would abstain or vote against four other Communist candidates.

FEW who plod by the home of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at 65 Liberty Street, downtown, realize that in it dwells the oldest existing body of its kind in the world. The chamber was organized in 1768 by twenty local merchants to promote the "General Interest of the Colony, and the Commerce of this City in particular."

A housing colony is planned for an acreage tract in the Suffolk County area of Long Island where 287 acres have been purchased on Hot Water Road at Calverton in the township of Brookhaven. The land was acquired from the Peconic Forge Company by Herbert Kravitz and associates.
RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 29-- There is no effective opposition party in Burma to act as a check on the political group in power.
CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 29-- The Calcutta police had to rescue the touring Soviet leaders today from the welcoming crush of one of the largest crowds in Indian history.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 29-- The Virginia Legislature convenes in this capital of the Confederacy tomorrow to tackle what has become in many Southern minds the greatest issue since the Civil War.

ABOARD U. S. S. GLACIER, in the Pacific, Nov. 29--Taking advantage of a lull between gales, this Navy icebreaker rushed food and water today to twenty-five men living on short rations aboard her tow. The crew was down to its last nine meals when the supplies arrived.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to correct an impression created by an article in the Nov. 25 issue concerning the Board of Education document on moral and spiritual values in the public schools.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (Reuters) --The Soviet Union offered the West today a reciprocal agreement to halt nuclear weapon tests. The move was viewed here as Soviet propaganda aimed mainly at India and Japan.

A first-class man with a brilliant record in the Police Department has been chosen as executive director of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission. He is Inspector Michael J. Murphy, whose rapid rise through the ranks has been based on intelligence, character and hard work.
LONDON, Nov. 29-- The De Havilland Aircraft Company predicted today that its Comet Mark IV jet airliner would be in service on world air routes "before any other jet airliner."

The body of Prof. Donald Randolph Charles, geneticist and biologist who committed suicide last Saturday night, will be claimed this morning in the City Morgue by his estranged wife for burial in Rochester.
Another count in the indictment against John G. (Steve) Broady, accused of being the mastermind of a wiretap conspiracy here, was dismissed yesterday in General Sessions Court.

A warm, vivid word portrait of the late Robert E. Sherwood as an eminent dramatist, historian, Presidential adviser and man of letters was drawn yesterday afternoon by men he had worked with in the arts and government.

Folks will be decking the halls this holiday season with anything but holly. The greenery will have to be pine, laurel or even mistletoe. Mistletoe comes from New Mexico and is thick with berries this year. But not so holly.

Deferred from last season, "Pipe Dream" begins its local career at 8 o'clock this evening at the Shubert. Adapted from John Steinbeck's lusty novel, "Sweet Thursday" (a sequel to his "Cannery Row"), the show represents the seventh musical created by the collaborating team of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d.
Twenty-one years ago in Coney Island, Concetta Costa made her husband, Giuseppe, one of the proudest papas in the neighborhood with a bouncing baby boy.

NEW CASTLE, Ind., Nov. 29 (AP)--Perfect Circle Corporation strikers voted 86--72 today, under pressure from top officials of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., to accept a contract to end their four-month-old strike.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--The Post Office Department decided today against appointing the man Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had recommended for acting postmaster of Appleton, Wis.
The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations gave final approval yesterday to next week's merger with the American Federation of Labor.
ALBANY, Nov. 29--The State Federation of Labor called today for increased benefits under the state's social insurance programs.
Contract talks between the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., broke off yesterday with both sides firing bitter parting shots.
A formidable round of price increases is smiting industry and the man on the street.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Unsatisfied Judgments opened two days of public hearings yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel. It is seeking advice on how the public can be protected best against the uninsured motorist.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 29-- With two inches of snow on the ridges the still hunting was far from still, but with the thermometer hovering around ten degrees no hunter did much standing. The deer were alerted far ahead of the hunter, for the crisp snow made quiet movement impossible.

LUXURY with a capital "L" has arrived from Germany just in time for Christmas. The world's first 90-gauge stockings, so sheer they're almost invisible --except for the delicate taupe color, pointed French heel and seam--will be available at Jay Thorpe early next month.

Construction of a $1,065,000 railroad freight terminal in the Chelsea area was announced yesterday by Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of the Department of Marine and Aviation. He described the terminal as "the most modern and efficient railroad car float facility in the Port of New York."
